title: Big Lender in India To Buy Competitor
description: The Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation, India's second-largest long-term lender, said yesterday that it would acquire Scici Ltd., the country's third-largest long-term lender, for about four billion rupees ($111.7 million). The merger will be effective on April 1. It will leave Industrial Credit 25 percent shy of the assets of the country's largest long-term lender, Industrial Development Bank of India. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Challenge to the Origin of a Florentine Chapel
description: The Pazzi Chapel in Florence is considered one of the cornerstones of Renaissance architecture, and to most scholars, it marks one of the highlights of the career of the great architect Filippo Brunelleschi, who is best known as the man who designed the dome of the cathedral in Florence. Brunelleschi was a figure in 15th-century Italy somewhat like I. M. Pei in 20th-century America, a celebrated architect who managed not only to attract a continual stream of commissions from the rich and powerful but also to win broad acclaim from both the populace at large and serious scholars. And the chapel, put up in the mid-1400's by the Pazzi banking family, rivals to the Medici, seems to sum up his ideas of Renaissance architecture perfectly.

title: A Falling Hotel Vies With a Dropping Ball
description: Nearly half a million people gathered on the Las Vegas strip tonight to ring in the new year and watch the Hacienda Hotel implode.

title: PSC to Pay $99 Million To Expand Shipbuilding
description: Seeking to expand its international shipbuilding business, PSC Industries Bhd. of Malaysia said yesterday that it would pay $99.2 million to bolster its stake in the Danish shipyard Danyard A/S. The move will raise PSC's stake in Danyard to 75 percent from 48 percent. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Holloway Eases Into Starring Role
description: Shaheen Holloway stood at the free-throw line in the final seconds of Monday night's game against Rhode Island. The score was tied, 70-70. But for the 20-year-old Seton Hall shooting guard, dealing with pressure wasn't new.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP., Pittsburgh, completed the purchase of Infinity Broadcasting Corp. for about $4 billion in stock and $1 billion of assumed debt. It also completed the sale of its residential security business, Westinghouse Security Systems, to Western Resources Inc., Topeka, Kan., for $368 million plus the assumption of debt.

title: Cowboys' Williams And Irvin Investigated
description: Acclaimed as the defending Super Bowl champions, but dogged all year by players' legal troubles and suspensions, the Dallas Cowboys were rocked again yesterday by an allegation of rape from a 23-year-old woman that came just five days before a critical playoff game.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HONIGBERG, ELSIE
description: HONIGBER, Elsie. 12/31/89

title: Without Rest or Richter, Rangers Left Struggling
description: Heavy fog in Dallas after Monday night's victory over the Stars prevented the Rangers from arriving at their hotel here until around 4:30 A.M. today.

title: In Peru, Terrorism Exists on Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: A Governor Ends 1996 With a Touch of Wry
description: A lot of people might have thought that 1996 was a bad year for Bill Weld. He spent millions of dollars, and thousands of hours, campaigning for the United States Senate in one of the most closely watched races in the country. And the popular, patrician Governor of Massachusetts lost.

title: AMP TO TAKE 4TH-QUARTER CHARGES OF $195 MILLION
description: AMP Inc., a leading maker of electrical connectors, said yesterday that it would take fourth-quarter charges of $195 million, primarily for a revamping plan that was approved earlier by its board. The company, based in Harrisburg, Pa., said on Dec. 12 that it would take unspecified charges for a plan to cut costs, increase productivity and sell, close or revamp poorly performing businesses. AMP said it expected to disclose details of its plan before it reported fourth-quarter earnings, on Jan. 22. The company announced the charges after the stock market closed. Shares of AMP fell 50 cents, to $38.375.

title: Singapore's Economy Expanded 6.5% in '96
description: Singapore's economy expanded 6.5 percent in 1996, the Prime Minister said yesterday. The rate of growth was the slowest pace since 1992, when gross domestic product gained 6.2 percent from the previous year. The figures are adjusted for inflation.

title: Ethics Panel Puts Off Action on Gingrich
description: The House ethics committee decided not to proceed with any action against Speaker Newt Gingrich until after the election of a speaker for the new session. That means House members will vote without a complete review of the ethics charges against Mr. Gingrich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILLIE, VIRGINIA BARNET
description: KILLIE - Virginia Barnet. Devoted wife of the late Ronald M. beloved mother of Peter, James and Thomas. Loving grandmother of Alex, Amy, Nina, Sean, and Liom. Services 10AM, January 2nd, St. John the Martyr, 250 East 72nd St., NYC. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Three Bowl Players Will Enter the Draft
description: Three players whose teams reached bowl games -- TREMAINE MACK and KENARD LANG of Miami and TONY GONZALEZ of California -- decided yesterday to pass up on their senior seasons and enter the National Football League draft in April.

title: The Cowboys Should Ban Irvin Now
description: IF the Dallas Cowboys were really America's Team as they like to proclaim, their owner, Jerry Jones, would suspend Michael Irvin now. If only because, with so much smoke, the flames can't be far away.

title: In a Shift, Grants Are Given to College Presidents
description: College presidents have plenty of practice handing out academic goodies like degrees, awards and scholarships, but now the tables are turning.

title: Ordinance on Legal Bills
description: Jackie R. Mattison, the former chief of staff to Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, is scheduled to go on trial on Tuesday for bribery charges. And his legal expenses could be paid by the city if a proposed ordinance is passed.

title: VALERO SEES POSSIBLE MERGER ACCORD BY FEBRUARY
description: The Valero Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had received a number of proposals since it announced plans to spin off its refining and marketing business and sell its remaining natural gas assets, and that it could have a merger agreement by February. ''A number of companies have submitted written proposals indicating a significant level of interest,'' Valero said in a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In each case, the filing said, the potential buyer would like the company, which is based in San Antonio, to spin off its refining and marketing operations through a distribution to shareholders. The buyer would then acquire Valero's remaining natural gas-related services business through a stock swap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTEN-GOLDMAN, HANNAH EMILY
description: OTTEN-GOLDMAN - Hannah Emily. Beloved wife of Jacob. Devoted mother of William and Susan Otten. Loving grandmother of Erin, Richard & Jenna. Services Thursday, 1 P.M. at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Schwartz, Senior Giuliani Aide, Is Planning to Resign From Post
description: Richard J. Schwartz, the senior adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the architect of the administration's workfare program, plans to resign later this month, city officials said yesterday.

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR most, New Year's Day is a time to pause and look ahead; to dust off those valiant resolutions to lose weight, learn French, read Proust. For a foolhardy few, it is also an opportunity to predict what will happen in the year ahead.

title: U.S. Chain Buying Global Hotel Group
description: In a deal that would create a major international luxury hotelier, the Doubletree Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Renaissance Hotel Group for $780 million in cash and stock.

title: For 49ers, Pressure Will Be On the Line
description: The change was made, appropriately, after the San Francisco 49ers lost at Green Bay almost midway through the season. The adjustment created, arguably, the best defensive line in the National Football League this season. But will even that be enough to compensate for a glaring weakness in the rematch?

title: Israel Corp. to Raise Chemical Concern Stake
description: The Israel Corporation, one of Israel's largest holding companies, with investments in more than 70 companies, plans to double its stake in Israel Chemicals Ltd., one of the country's largest chemical concerns. The Israel Corporation offered to buy Shoul Eisenberg's 12.45 percent stake in ICL for $128.4 million. After the transaction, which still needs approval, the company will hold 24.9 percent of ICL. Mr. Eisenberg, an Israeli billionaire who built his fortune as a young refugee in Japan after World War II, is chairman of the Israel Corporation. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Serb Protests Take On a Holiday Mood
description: With the high-pitched chirps of thousands of whistles and a display of fireworks, anti-Government protesters welcomed in the new year, expressing hope for the beginnings of democracy in Serbia and for the end of one-man rule by Slobodan Milosevic.

title: No Headline
description: ''It is your basic battle between good and evil. We are good, and they are evil. Evil always loses to good.'' BILL EVANS, a Florida State fan. $(1:6.$)

title: BANPONCE TO ACQUIRE ANOTHER PUERTO RICAN BANK
description: The BanPonce Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Roig Commercial Bank for $120 million in cash and stock, bringing together two of Puerto Rico's largest banks. BanPonce, the parent company of Banco Popular, offered about $200 a share for Roig, half in stock and the rest in cash. Roig, based in Humacao, has $900 million in assets and $680 million in deposits, and operates 25 branches. BanPonce is based in San Juan and has 214 Banco Popular branches in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPPELMAN, MORRIS
description: KOPPELMAN - Morris. Today on your birthday, we remeber you with love and miss you so very much.

title: Brodeur, Dunham Fall Flat
description: In the Devils' last game, goalie Martin Brodeur had come in for his rookie backup, Mike Dunham, after one period with the Devils trailing Anaheim -- and New Jersey had come back to win.

title: Golota to Stand Trial
description: Seventeen days after losing a second fight to RIDDICK BOWE because of low blows, the heavyweight boxer ANDREW GOLOTA arrived in his native Poland yesterday to stand trial for a 1990 brawl in a disco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, ALFRED, P.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE OUTFITTERS STOCK FALLS ON OUTLOOK
description: Shares of American Eagle Outfitters Inc. fell 26 percent yesterday on news that the apparel retailer would not meet Wall Street's earnings expectations for the third quarter. The company, based in Warrendale, Pa., also said that sales at stores opened at least a year fell 16.9 percent for the four weeks that ended on Dec. 28, while total sales declined 14.1 percent from the corresponding period last year. First Call Inc. had forecast that American Eagle would earn $1.26 a share, with five analysts' estimates ranging from $1.24 to $1.31, for the three months ended on Feb 1. American Eagle operates in 307 mall locations in 39 states. Shares of American Eagle fell $2.875, to $7.875.

title: New Year's Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A Prison Left Behind Becomes a Career
description: It was May 1976, and Terry George was in captivity near Belfast, in what the English call the Maze Prison and the Northern Irish call Long Kesh, accused of carrying arms for the Irish Republican Army. His fellow prisoners were digging an escape tunnel under the prison walls. For three weeks they had been working around the clock with shovels made from aluminum food trays.

title: Street Game Gets a Patent: Indoor Skelly
description: THE asphalt battlefield known as a Skelly board has 13 numbers, one for each box where raw-knuckled players hunch over and flick wax-filled bottle tops as they vie for the title of Killer Diller. Generations of New Yorkers grew up playing this quintessential street game that required nothing more than bottle caps and chalk to draw the board. But Darryl Jones thought his Skelly board needed one more number: 5,467,985.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLISON, EDWARD S.

Devoted husband of Muriel, beloved father of Margaret Christiansen, Edward, Amy and the late James. Loving brother of Cyrus, Gloria Tolins and the late Anthony. A man of strength, integrity, generosity and compassion who will be greatly missed. Reposing at O.B. Davis Funeral Home, Port Jefferson Station.

title: The Virtual New Year
description: The very first minute of 1997, as brought to you by network television, could hardly have been a more literal display of America's pre-millennial cultural schizophrenia. New York -- the booming city of falling crime and skyrocketing tourism -- welcomed in the New Year at a moment when Times Square has rarely looked more like Las Vegas, while Las Vegas, enjoying its own boom as the nation's fastest-growing city, worked overtime to simulate New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about new insights into the way a mouse forms memories of new environments misstated an affiliation of Dr. Robert Muller, a scientist who participated in the research. He is at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn, not Columbia University.

title: Number of Slain Police Officers Is Lowest Since 1960
description: The number of police officers killed in the line of duty in 1996 dropped dramatically, to the lowest level since 1960, according to figures released yesterday by the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund in Washington. Experts said the decline was at least partly attributable to the major decrease in murder in many of the nation's big cities.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARISON, DAVID ANDREW
description: BARISON - David Andrew. Jan 1, 1995. ''When good men die, their goodness does not perish.''

title: HOSPITALS START OPEN COMPETITION UNDER A NEW LAW
description: For hospitals and health insurers in New York State, the new year promises to be one of the most turbulent ever as a new law takes effect lifting price controls on hospitals and forcing them to compete in an increasingly cutthroat health care market.

title: Brief Scuffle By Diplomats Goes Global
description: A scuffle that barely seemed worthy of the New York City police blotter turned into an international incident yesterday with a protest from Russia, angry words from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a cautious wait-and-see stance from the State Department.

title: The New Year, Observed
Peru Guerrillas And Hostages Face the Press
description: In a remarkable and unexpected development in the 14-day hostage crisis here, Marxist rebels who stormed a reception at the Japanese Ambassador's residence permitted television cameramen and still photographers to breach the compound's security wall and enter the residence, where they filmed and interviewed rebels and some of the remaining hostages.

title: Sales Incentives Bolster Fiat Shares
description: Shares of Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, jumped yesterday as investors wagered that car sales incentives approved by the Government on Monday would increase Fiat's operating profit.

title: Florio Adviser Settles Case
description: A political adviser to former Gov. Jim Florio agreed on Monday to pay $86,000 to settle a Federal case accusing him of taking kickbacks in 1990 to help an investment bank win a $237 million municipal bond contract, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Lew Ayres, Actor, Dies at 88; Conscience Bound His Career
description: Lew Ayres, the movie actor who skyrocketed to fame as a disillusioned German soldier in ''All Quiet on the Western Front'' in 1930 and was also celebrated for playing the title role in ''Young Dr. Kildare'' and the series of films that followed it, died on Monday in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 88.

title: He Fishes. She Paints. The Twain Meet.
description: NICK LYONS is the envy of just about anyone who is in love with fly-fishing. He is a masterly fisherman who has devoted large chunks of his life to patiently outwitting trout and other coveted species in world-class waters -- and on top of that he makes a living at it. When he is not standing in a pristine stream with his fly rod, he is either writing about fishing or publishing books about it.

title: What's an Overnight Sensation Doing in a Place Like This?
description: LOOKING over the shoulder of her companion at the bar, a woman on a tall stool smiled an ''I know you'' smile across the room. Geoffrey Rush, who had been sitting over a Scotch for more than an hour, smiled back, waggling his fingers in pleased if somewhat sheepish acknowledgment.

description: A couple of weeks ago, after Madeleine K. Albright had finally ended Boutros Boutros-Ghali's hopes of a second term as Secretary General, the defeated and dispirited Egyptian diplomat at last got his chance to ask Ms. Albright, by then President Clinton's choice as Secretary of State, a few undiplomatic questions.

title: Islamic Militancy vs. Money-Making in Iran
description: Isfahan, wrote Jean Chardin, the 17th-century French traveler, ''was expressly made for the delights of love.''

title: Rehnquist Criticizes Congress On Raises
description: Making Congress the focus of his annual report on the state of the Federal judiciary, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today criticized the legislators for failing to raise judges' pay, saying the issue threatened to affect the morale and quality of the Federal judiciary.

title: Samsung Loses Chance To Take Over Fokker
description: Samsung lost a chance to revive its failed bid to take over the bankrupt Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. yesterday when other Korean airplane makers rejected its offer to form a consortium. The three proposed partners -- Hyundai, Hanjin and Daewoo -- have notified the South Korean Government that they will not join Samsung Aerospace Industries Ltd.

title: New York City Takes a Bow As Homicide Rate Plunges
description: New York City ended 1996 with fewer than 1,000 homicides for the first time since 1968, a milestone that city officials say reflects its continued success at aggressively fighting crime.

description: The invitation to the International Debutante Ball was addressed to Mr. and Mrs. David Eisenhower. Tucked into a pink envelope with silver writing, it rekindled bright memories for Julie Nixon Eisenhower, who recalls her sleeveless white dress, her long kid gloves, the series of deb ''pre-parties'' and, most of all, her date: David, the grandson of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, a young man she had met as a child playing in the White House.

title: Bond Prices Post Steep Losses on Strong Economic News
description: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday, ending a year in which they dropped during much of the first six months, recovered most of their losses and then turned down again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, WILLIAM
description: FRIEDMAN - William, 86, died on December 30, 1996, in Palo Alto. Former teacher and principal in the New York City Public Schools, which he loved. A straight and simple man of uncommon decency, kindness and sweetness, he made life better for his family, friends, students and colleagues. He is missed. Memorial service is private.

description: Michael Irvin and Erik Williams came to the Dallas Cowboys from different paths, from different places.

title: A Childhood Stolen, a Man Created
description: The van, stuffed with blockers and the slight running back with the misleadingly vulnerable appearance, set out from a hotel on Canal Street and pointed west toward Baton Rouge and the home of Willie Wheeler. Warrick Dunn's grandmother was ready. There was crayfish etouffee, her grandson's favorite, and gumbo, and ribs, and macaroni and cheese, more than enough for everyone.

title: Longer Tenure for Top Fed Bank Executives
description: Top Federal Reserve bank officials can now stay in their jobs longer.

title: Talking and Reading In Place of Listening
description: Sadie and Evelyn may seem at first to be unlikely friends. Sadie likes to talk. Evelyn likes to read. But neither of these two elderly Jewish women, living alone in a condominium complex in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., likes to listen.

title: Gabriel Lewis Galindo, 68, Veteran Panamanian Diplomat
description: Gabriel Lewis Galindo, the Panamanian diplomat and businessman who helped negotiate the Panama Canal Treaties, spearheaded efforts to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and served until recently as his country's Foreign Minister, died on Dec. 19 in Denver, where he had been undergoing medical treatment. He was 68 and suffered from fibrosis of the lungs.

title: The Cadets Storm Back, But Stumble
description: Even before J. Parker lined up for the 27-yard kick, even before the kick sailed toward the uprights as the last 33 seconds of a remarkable Army season began ticking off, Bob Sutton was welling with pride today at the Independence Bowl.

title: Internet Security System to Be Tested
description: Mastercard International Inc., the International Business Machines Corporation and a Danish bank said yesterday that they had tested a system that is the first to protect the security of credit card transactions on the Internet using a new industry standard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSS, DOROTHY KINNE
description: MORSS - Dorothy Kinne, of Westfield, NJ, died December 24, wife of the late Dwight F. Morss. Born 1896 Syracuse, NY, graduate of Smith College 1919 and Syracuse University 1920. Surviving are two daughters, Sally M. McCracken, Savannah, GA, and Margaret M. Stokes, Waitsfield, VT, twelve grandchildren and seventeen great grandchildren.

title: Four Seasons of Sex, Blacks, Jews and Clinton
description: After four seasons on Comedy Central, ''Politically Incorrect'' makes it to ABC next week in a five-times-a-week late-night incarnation, which may prove there is life after ''Nightline.'' In a preview tonight at 10, fans can enjoy moments from programs past and others can get a glimpse of the politico-show biz banter they have been missing or avoiding for years. Lest anyone take ''Politically Incorrect's Greatest Hits'' seriously, Bill Maher, the moving spirit, promises, ''It's all been satirized for your protection.''

title: Swiss Economists Lower Their Forecasts
description: Cutting an earlier forecast, the Association of Swiss Business Economists said yesterday that it expected the country's economy to grow about six-tenths of 1 percent next year as construction spending and exports rise less than previously estimated. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a New York State appellate court decision striking down rules governing psychiatric experiments on children and the mentally ill misstated the timing of a halt in a study involving spinal taps on suicidal adolescents. It was 18 months ago, after a lower court ruling, not after the appellate one.

title: Stars Release Makarov
description: The Dallas Stars released the veteran right wing SERGEI MAKAROV, likely ending the former Russian star's National Hockey League career.

title: Champagne's on Ice for the Millennium
description: THE corks have popped to welcome 1997. And now, Champagne houses in France are preparing for the millennium with special bottles to be released in 1999. Some wine shops are starting to take paid reservations for limited-edition Champagnes. To welcome in 2000, Perrier-Jouet has 2,000 jeroboams (the equivalent of four standard-size bottles) of the 1995 vintage fermenting in its Epernay cellars. The price, $2,000 each, includes an overnight stay at the company's Art Nouveau mansion in France. Champagne Louis Roederer has a cellar with 2,000 methuselahs (the equivalent of eight bottles) of the 1990 Cristal, for $2,000 each. Dom Perignon 1993, bottled in jeroboams, will be sold at charity auctions for a minimum bid of $2,500 a bottle. Only 1,993 bottles are available. Pol Roger has 1,000 jeroboams of the 1988 Cuvee Winston Churchill, but has not announced the price. Budget-minded planners may soon be able to buy nonvintage Cuvee 21 from Vranken Champagne Demoiselle, a new import, for $85, and set it aside for 2000.

description: Business Day's annual survey of the year ahead and the year past for the economy, markets and industry.

description: LEWIS - Sally. Cherished mother of our dearest friend Madeleine. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family and grieve with them for their loss.

title: Kiwi Airlines to Fly Again
description: Nearly four months after it filed for bankruptcy, Kiwi International Airlines will resume service from Newark to four cities, officials said yesterday. The carrier is scheduled to be back in the air on Jan. 20, with flights to New York City, Chicago, Atlanta and West Palm Beach, Fla. The reservation office will open tomorrow afternoon, Kiwi officials said. In November, a Federal court approved a $5 million loan to Kiwi from an investment group led by Dr. Charles C. Edwards. TERRY PRISTIN

description: Money may not buy happiness, but it will buy Harmony.

description: An article on Dec. 17 about charitable giving by the financier George Soros referred incompletely to the financing of ballot initiatives in Arizona and California to permit the use of marijuana for medical purposes. While Mr. Soros was the initiatives' single largest donor, with gifts of more than $1 million, another donor, Peter Lewis, also played a major role, giving more than $800,000.

title: Low-Fat Diet Hasn't Cured Our Medical Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother of 3 Is Arrested In a Death
description: A 38-year-old Bronx woman was arrested yesterday and charged with reckless endangerment in the death of her 10-month-old daughter, who was found with a fractured skull and other injuries indicative of child abuse, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, ABRAHAM
description: WASSERMAN - Abraham. December 30, 1996, age 90 years, of Brooklyn, New York. Beloved husband of Ida for sixty-six years. Brother of Samuel and Ruth Wasserman of Silver Spring, Maryland. Father of Edel and Zelda, Rhoda and Charles, and Malvina; grandfather of Stepehn Wasserman, Diane and Matthew Feldman, Ellen and Jim Hamlin, Terry and Jeff Friedman; great grandfather of Jeffrey and Brian Feldman; Alexandra Hamlin and Zachary Friedman. Service at Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, opposite Kings Plaza at noon January 1, 1997. In Lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Workmen's Circle Division of ORT, 817 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

title: After All the Champagne, Time to Smell the Coffee
description: After the rush of holiday festivities and the big New Year's Eve blowout, post-party depression can easily set in. The albums here are quiet and contemplative, but none too reassuring. They offer private moments as a corrective to all the public jubilation.

title: Is the Grinch Running Bosnia's Government?
description: On Sarajevo's main street, named Marshal Tito after the Communist leader, a photograph of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini peers from the wall of the Iranian Cultural Center at the bright Christmas decorations in the Benetton clothing store across the way.

title: A Tough Road Test Is Ahead For Knicks
description: They face Hakeem Olajuwon one night. Then, later on, come visits to Michael Jordan and Reggie Miller within 48 hours of each other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIMIS, SYBIL
description: PRIMIS, Sybil. Beloved mother of Sandra Polotkin, Dr. Ronald A. Primis and Lance R. Primis. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinetown, NY.

title: Sale of Forest Expected Soon
description: A $55 million deal to sell 15,800 acres in Sterling Forest to two nonprofit groups is expected to be signed in the next few weeks, the owner of the property said yesterday. Louis Heimbach, the president of the Sterling Forest Corporation, said that only a few details remained to be worked out with the Open Space Institute and the Trust for Public Land.

title: Personal Health
description: NORMA LEVORSON spent a quiet Christmas with her husband, Jerry, at their home in Albert Lea, Minn., and said she enjoyed it thoroughly. A few years ago, the couple spent another ''delightful'' Christmas at a lovely hotel in Chicago, where they attended a neighborhood church and a theatrical opening.

title: Correction: Business Inventories and the Economy
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday with an article about companies' efforts to control inventories reflected erroneous calculations of the adjustment for business inventories. The chart suggested incorrectly that growth in business inventories had not kept pace with the overall economy. Here is a corrected version.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Consumer Confidence And Home Sales Surge

title: Mid-Season Jolt: Few New Shows From Networks
description: The television season reaches its halfway point this week with two familiar trends in place:No new hit has lighted up prime time, and all the broadcast networks continue to be hit by mass defections of viewers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENES, DR. MAGDA
description: DENES - Dr. Magda. It is with deep sorrow that the Faculty, Graduates and Canadidates of the New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis mourn the untimely death of Magda Denes, PhD, on esteemed faculty member and supervisor in our Program. Her commitment to an existential point of view was the cornerstone of her intellectual vitality and clinical acumen. An inspired academician, she contributed to the growth of students as well as colleagues and only recently completed an important memoir which will remain a testament to her strong convictions and ability to give literary expression to profound emotional experiences. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family.

title: As Cold, Happy Sardines Filled Times Square, Many Natives Fled
description: The annual New Year's Eve countdown in Times Square is yet another example of the cultural divide between New York City and the rest of the country. While millions of Americans watch the ball drop on television each year and hundreds of thousands of them make the pilgrimage to Broadway to see it in person, all the revelry and whooping and hollering tends to send many native New Yorkers running for cover, and last night's celebration was no exception.

title: The French And Germans Hear Refrain: Tighten Belts
description: Sounding remarkably alike in televised New Year's addresses, the leaders of France and Germany urged their restive voters tonight to keep making sacrifices so their countries can meet increasingly tough global economic competition against Europe's welfare-state economies.

title: Cooper Agrees to Pay $6.85 Million in Suit
description: Cooper Industries said today that it had agreed to pay $6.85 million to settle a class-action shareholder lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court here, contending that the company misled investors about its earnings outlook.

title: A Powerful Final Quarter Makes Wall Street's Year
description: Stock and bond underwriting roared back in the final three months of 1996, ending a year on Wall Street that left many rubbing their eyes with disbelief.

title: Casting for Silver Salmon, Renewing a Life
description: THE salmon hit the grill with a sizzle, and I had to blink away a tear. I was getting emotional about a fish? Well, this was not an everyday fish. It was a 12-pound silver salmon I had caught with a fly rod last August on the twisty Nushagak River in the remote wilderness of southwestern Alaska.

title: Helpless to Avoid Layoff, Breadwinner Seeks Aid
description: At noon on Monday, Charles Wright sat in a midtown burger joint, sipping his coffee and wiping his eye. He was not crying -- there is less to be sad about now, although he still has worries.

title: New Year, Old Deduction
description: The new year is bringing the return of a popular program that allows taxpayers to deduct a portion of their property taxes from their state income tax. The deduction, which was repealed in 1990, was reinstated in a bill enacted in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIVIN, LEO
description: ZIVIN - Leo. Passed away Dec. 28, 1996. The Board of Directors, friends and colleagues of Israel Bonds-Divison of Organizations mourn the loss of their chairman for the last 25 years, prominent attorney and stounch friend of Israel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Blossom and his family. Leo never waivered from his support and commitment to the Israel Bond Porgram. Next to his family, Israel was his love.

title: Purdue Violated Rules
description: The Purdue basketball coach, GENE KEADY, and his assistant, FRANK KENDRICK, committed an ''inadvertent violation'' of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules by making telephone calls to the home of a prospective recruit, the university said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDERICO, ANA ROSA (NEE AVALA)
description: FEDERICO - Ana Rosa (nee Avala) on December 30, 1996. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Reposing at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home, Inc. 41-45 58th St. Woodside, NY, Wednesday 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Thurs 9:45 A.M. at The St. Sebastian Church, Woodside. Interment to follow at The Maple Grove Cemetery.

title: Class Notes
description: The 20-year-old man with a Mohawk haircut, multicolored pigtails, tattooed arms and rings on every finger was an engineering student at a New York college when he sent E-mail to a public official, threatening to torture him and rape his young daughter. The F.B.I. arrested the student a few days later as he sat in his pajamas eating breakfast.

title: It's Jan. 1? Where Could Clintons Be?
description: Why, for the love of Pete, does President Clinton keep coming back to ''Renaissance Weekend,'' the annual, deeply earnest, invitation-only intellectual and spiritual chaternalia held during the New Year's holiday?

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Hawgood Is Suspended
description: The N.H.L. suspended San Jose defenseman GREG HAWGOOD for two games and fined him $1,000 yesterday for slashing BORIS MIRONOV of the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Vanguard Cuts Fees on Four Index Funds
description: Vanguard Group Inc., the second-largest mutual fund group in the United States, behind Fidelity, said today that it planned to reduce the transaction fees on four index portfolios by as much as 50 percent, effective on Thursday.

title: How World Stock Market Fared in the Fourth Quarter
From Childhood Hobby To a Creative Therapy
description: James Goldman's love affair with juggling began when he was a teen-ager. The hobby consumed him. He practiced until he could toss and catch balls, rings, clubs, knives, burning torches and finally hatchets. At the age of 14, he joined a vaudeville-style troupe that entertained virtually any audience that would sit still for them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLSWORTH, MARLI
description: EllSWORTH - Marli, 81, widow of Professor Theodore D. Ellsworth, on December 31, 1996. Mother of Rellina Zerolla, sister of Lydia Cippola and grandmother of Valeria Zerolla. Mrs. Ellsworth was a Red Cross volunteer for many years in the Family Court, New York County. Interment to be at the United States Military Academy Cemetery at West Point, New York.

title: Memo to Helms: Why and How We Need U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Executives on the go can expect to shell out more for air fares, hotels and car rentals next year.
description: HOTEL room rates climbing 5 percent -- or more. Air fares also increasing at least 5 percent domestically -- and 7 percent on international flights. Car-rental rates up 4 percent to 5 percent. But a little less bounce to business travel -- with growth slipping to about 3 percent from 4 percent in 1996.

title: Leftovers Start Over, Thanks to Food Pros
description: FOR a week, you have eyed that five-pound box of cheap cookies that a business associate sent over. You have wondered what to do with the scraps of Christmas ham.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-10

title: Gingrich Hearing Is Delayed Till After Speakership Vote
description: In an apparent setback for Speaker Newt Gingrich, the House ethics committee announced today that it would not proceed with its two-year investigation into ethics complaints against him until Jan. 8, one day after he is to stand for re-election to the leadership post.

title: China to Alter Export Tariff on 18 Items
description: China will remove or reduce export tariffs on 18 products, including raw cashmere, next year in a move that may increase costs for the world's largest cashmere producer, the Inner Mongolia Erdos Cashmere Products Company. Products on which tariffs will be lifted include silk, cashmere, pigments and scrap lead, the official China Daily reported, citing the State Economic and Trade Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, RALPH
description: SHAPIRO - Ralph, left us on December 28. He was loved by all who knew him for his enjoyment of life and his generous nature. We mourn with his caring wife, Robin, and with his children.

description: To the Editor:

title: On New Year's Eve, Not Many New Yorkers
description: The annual New Year's Eve countdown in Times Square is yet another example of the cultural divide between New York City and the rest of the country. While thousands of Americans make the pilgrimage to Broadway to see it in person, all the revelry and whooping and hollering tends to send many native New Yorkers running for cover.

title: Baseballs That Go Roller-Skating
description: British visitors to the United States sometimes pronounce baseball a long, dull game. ''But what about cricket?'' indignant Americans then retort.

title: Victimization
description: To the Editor:

title: Charges Against Schott Could Affect Her Role With Reds
description: Marge Schott, whose ethnic and racial comments have undermined her position as managing partner of the Cincinnati Reds, faces potentially more serious trouble in baseball over charges of fraudulent sales reports that General Motors has lodged against her with a state regulatory board in Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHEINMAN, ALAN
description: SCHEINMAN - Alan

description: In percent

title: GE CAPITAL SERVICES ACQUIRES ITALIAN FACTORING FIRM
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its GE Capital Services subsidiary had acquired Barclays Factoring S.p.A. of Milan, Italy. Financial terms were not disclosed. GE Capital Services, based in Stamford, Conn., said Barclays Factoring would become part of the company's commercial finance business and would change its name to GE Capital Factoring S.p.A., effective immediately. Factoring firms finance small companies by buying certain assets. GE Capital Services provides specialized financing to businesses and consumers.

title: Peter J. Roylance, 68, Researcher at Merck
description: Peter James Roylance, a physician and researcher with Merck Sharp & Dohme, a subsidiary of Merck & Company, the pharmaceutical company, died on Saturday at his home in Long Hill Township, N.J. He was 68.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, ARLENE (MASTER)
description: LIPTON - Arlene (Master), of West Hartford, CT. Died December 31, 1996. Beloved wife of Michael, devoted mohter of Jonathan and Suzanne and adored daughter of Mary Master and a special sister to Jeffrey. Funeral services and burial Thursday in West Hartford, Ct. For information Weinstein Mortuary of Hartford.

title: Staying Afloat in D.C.
description: After struggling with entrenched mismanagement for more than a year and a half, the financial control board that effectively runs the District of Columbia has taken over the schools, ordered new accounting and personnel systems and cut about 3,000 jobs from one of the most bloated city governments in the country. About 1,000 more jobs will be cut soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUNT, HELEN PHILLIPS
description: BLUNT - Helen Phillips. On, December 27, 1996 in Falmouth, ME. Born in Pittsburgh, PA. Daughter of the late John Hartley & Bessie Lew Phillips. She and her husband of 48 years, William W. Blunt, lived in New York City, Scarsdale, N.Y. and Ridgefield, CT. Mrs. Blunt moved to New Canaan, CT. after her husband's death in 1983. She maintained her life-long interest in music, sewing and the arts through membership in local groups and her own painting and drawing. She also was a leading participant in the New Canaan United Nations Study Group. She relocated to Foreside Harbor in Falmouth, ME. in August 1996. Helen was a source of inspiration, strength and humor to family and friends alike. She will be sorely missed. Surviving are a daughter Joan Murray of Portland, ME & a son William W. Blunt of Dallas, TX and six grandchildren. Memorial service will be held in the spring in Elmsford, N.Y. Inquiries Hay & Peabody, Portland, ME.

title: Heating Oil and Crude Oil Climb as Cold Grips Europe
description: The prices of heating oil and crude oil jumped in a shortened session yesterday on expectations that higher European prices, spurred by cold weather and shipping disruptions, could reduce supplies available to the United States.

title: U.S. TAKES A STEP TO MAKE ITS PARKS FREER OF VEHICLES
description: The Interior Department today took a step toward eliminating intrusions of man into the Grand Canyon, restricting aircraft flights in a harbinger of an overall plan to restrict even automobile traffic at the canyon and in some of the nation's other heavily traveled parks.

title: North Korea's New Message
description: North Korea's apology Sunday for attempting to infiltrate South Korea by submarine-borne commandos last September was remarkable enough, coming as it did from a country whose past statements have been largely limited to apocalyptic military threats and crude ideological belligerence. But Pyongyang's expression of ''deep regret'' for the submarine episode and its promise to make sure that such infiltrations will not be repeated turns out to be part of an even broader and more promising diplomatic breakthrough.

title: Don't Violate Rights of College Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Feminine Mystique in the Eyes of an 'Auntie Man'
description: THE WOMEN

title: Researchers Link Artery Disease and Multiple Ovarian Cysts
description: Researchers say there appears to be a link between coronary artery disease and multiple cysts in the ovaries, a finding that suggests doctors treating either condition should be on the lookout for signs that the other may be present.

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial markets in the United States and most of the world will be closed today for New Year's Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed.

title: Bonus for Lilco Stockholders if State Takes Over Debt
description: Long Island Lighting Company shareholders would get a stock price bonus if the state were to take over the $4.5 billion debt for the defunct Shoreham nuclear plant, according to Lilco's merger agreement with Brooklyn Union Gas.

title: Cloak-and-Dagger Tale in Bogota Has German Accent
description: The arrest of a German couple at the airport here after they secured the release of a woman kidnapped by leftist guerrillas has provoked diplomatic tensions between Colombia and Germany. The incident also raises questions about the role of foreigners in financing Colombia's guerrillas.

title: Loews leases space next to its Manhattan headquarters, with an interior passage planned.
description: THE Loews Corporation has leased 49,200 square feet on four floors at 655 Madison Avenue, at 60th Street. The space will have a connection inside the building to 667 Madison, the Loews corporate headquarters. The 15-year lease was valued at almost $25 million.

title: Strangling of a Little Girl Who Had Everything Stuns Boulder
description: Newspapers with headlines about this city's first homicide of the year lay unopened in front of a house where yellow and black crime tape still hangs awkwardly next to large plastic candy canes outside.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday with an article about companies' efforts to control inventories reflected erroneous calculations of the adjustment for inflation in the national figures for business inventories. A corrected chart appears today on page 62.

title: Alzheimer Patients Present a Lesson On Human Dignity
description: THEY looked for all the world like elderly professionals, dressed casually in the typical New York hues of black and gray. But the two women and one man, sitting in front of a packed room at a recent meeting on Alzheimer's disease, were not researchers or directors of programs. They were patients, they had Alzheimer's disease and they were there to tell what it was like to know you have a disease that is slowly, inexorably, killing your brain.

title: O'Connor Regrets Quick Tongue, But Still Loves Leading the Flock
description: He regrets allowing himself to be drawn into partisan political battles, like the one he touched off when he criticized Geraldine A. Ferraro on abortion. He regrets that he denounced Salman Rushdie without having even read ''The Satanic Verses.'' Most of all, John Cardinal O'Connor says, he regrets being so ''arrogant'' that he talked incessantly to the ever-insatiable news media, offering opinions on subjects he knew little about.

title: Alliance or Not, Rose Is Still in the Title Chase
description: The Rose Bowl may have seceded from the union, or the Bowl Alliance, but it is still on television. Someone here is undefeated (Arizona State), someone here is agitated (Ohio State) and someone not here is interested (Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden and Florida Coach Steve Spurrier, to name two).

title: Food Notes
description: Training for the Super Bowl

title: Spain's Santander Hopes to Become No. 1 in Latin America
description: What Spain's monarchs lost in the 19th century, Emilio and Ana Patricia Botin are determined to reconquer in the waning years of the 20th: Latin America.

title: Therapy Is a Must
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, REV. BR. DENNIS (BORROMEO)
description: FLYNN - Rev. Br. Dennis (Borromeo) C.F.X. On December 30, 1996 in Brooklyn. A distinguished and beloved Xaverian Brother for 64 years. He taught English and Latin at Xaverian highs chools in NY, MA, and MD. Son of Patrick and Margaret. He is survived by brother Jerome P. of Brooklyn and five nieces and nephews. Visitation Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 at McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue of 97th Street, Brooklyn. Wake service 8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10AM at the Saint Xavier School Chapel, Louisville, KY. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Ryken House, 1609 Poplar Level Road, Louisville, KY 40217 gratefully accepted.

title: Brown May Tighten Its Rules on Alcohol
description: To improve safety at campus parties, Brown University is considering tighter rules for social gatherings where alcohol is served.

title: One Journalist Takes a Chance and Others Just Follow
description: Ever since Tupac Amaru guerrillas took hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here on Dec. 17, the Government has tried to tightly control the rebels' access to the news media.

title: Utility to Take A-Plant Charge
description: Baltimore Gas and Electric said this week that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $58 million, or 39 cents a share, to cover the cost of buying electricity during a nuclear plant shutdown. Analysts had forecast fourth-quarter earnings for the utility company of 29 cents a share.

title: Why Wall Street Bonuses Were So Big
description: In 1996, even the dullards in the financial markets found it easy to make money. Blue-chip stocks soared despite an up-and-down year in the bond market. Driven by the bullish stock market. Wall Street chalked up huge profits issuing a record-shattering $193 billion in new stocks and bonds. Most Markets around the world shared in the bounty.

title: In Germany, An Echo Of Uproar In Colombia
description: The arrest of a freelance German operative in Colombia has raised questions about the personality and style of the man who allegedly sent him there -- Bernd Schmidbauer, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's senior intelligence aide.

title: Lilco's Reviled Chairman Emerges on Top Again in Merger
description: William J. Catacosinos has a job that few people can appreciate, other than meter maids, dentists and maybe George M. Steinbrenner 3d. He is the chairman of one of the most detested businesses in the nation's corporate pantheon, the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: A Waste Not, Want Not Noodle Dish
description: In this season of leftovers, Karen Lee, a caterer and cooking teacher in New York, supplied a recipe that seems suitable for this column because it is both healthful and relatively quick to prepare. If you happen to have leftover ham or roast beef instead of chicken or turkey, they can also be used. Chinese cooking always has a lot of steps but each one is very swift.

title: Dow Falls 101, Closing Out A Generally Exuberant Year
description: The last day of the year disappointed investors looking for the stock market to end 1996 with a last burst through the finish line.

title: BT OFFICE PRODUCTS PAID $42 MILLION FOR SWEDISH OUTFIT
description: BT Office Products International Inc. said yesterday that it had paid about $42 million for J. F. Bjorsell A.B., Sweden's largest office-products distributor. BT Office Products, which distributes office products and supplies to mostly midsize and large businesses in the United States and Europe, disclosed the purchase in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The acquisition of Bjorsell gives the company, which is based in Buffalo Grove, Ill., a presence in Scandinavian and Baltic markets. Bjorsell, based in Boeras, Sweden, had about $85 million in revenue last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  READER, JOEL HARRIS
description: READER - Joel Harris. Beloved son of Arthur (Lillie) Reader and the late Ruth Reader; loving brother of Jane Reader (Aaron) Liebowitz and Marty (Susan) Reader, and their children. Services were conducted in Los Angeles, Ca.

title: Now, What About Lilco's Debt?
description: The proposed merger of Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company should provide Long Island residents some modest financial relief. But those residents will still pay more for their utility bills than most Americans do. The solution to their problem is for state leaders to put aside partisan bickering and agree on a plan that would allow the state to assume Lilco's huge debt.

title: Copyright Pacts Are Still Facing Foes in Congress
description: Even though the Clinton Administration pushed through two international copyright treaties in Geneva last month, American supporters and skeptics see a fight shaping up in Congress, where approval is required, and, Administration officials concede, far from assured.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKSDALE, WALTER LANE
description: BARKSDALE - Walter Lane. The faculty, students and alumni of New York University School of Medicine mourn the loss of one of our distinguished professors, who served on our faculty for over 30 years. Lane Barksdale taught countless students, now alumni, who enjoyed the benefits of his dedicated teaching and renown as on outstanding research scientist. Dr. Barksdale received his PhD at NYU and soon after joined the faculty. He was a Professor of Microbiology of NYU School of Medicine, a Fellow of the Pasteur Institute Paralysis Fellow. We mourn his loss and extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Psychiatric Research
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRSTFEDERAL FINANCIAL IN DEAL FOR SUMMIT BANCORP
description: The Firstfederal Financial Services Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Summit Bancorp for $17.3 million in stock to increase its business in Ohio. The bank holding company said it would exchange 1.87 shares of its common stock for each share of Summit Bancorp if shareholders of both companies approved the merger. Firstfederal, based in Wooster, Ohio, is the holding company for the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Wooster and for Mobile Consultants Inc. Summit Bancorp, based in Akron, Ohio, will continue to operate under its own name. Shares of Firstfederal did not trade yesterday; they closed at $38.875 on Monday. Summit's shares last traded at $41, this past Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAY, SIMONNE, (NEE PERRIER)
description: FINLAY - Simonne (nee Perrier). Died on 12/31/96. Born in Paris 4/8/10. Predeceased by her husband Edward A. Finlay. Dear sister of Paulette Boudet. Loving mother of Edward Finlay of Bloomfield, NJ, Daniel Finlay of Ithaca, NY, Jacques Finlay of Pike, NJ, and Maureen Jaimes of Scarsdale, NY. Also survived by ten grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

title: Iran Contributed $500,000 to Bosnian President's Election Effort, U.S. Says
description: Even as the United States was trying to roll back Iran's influence with the Muslim-led Government of Bosnia, Iran contributed at least $500,000 last summer to boost the election campaign of Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic, Administration officials said today.

title: MORTON TO ADD FRENCH AND ITALIAN CONCERNS
description: Morton International Inc. said it planned to buy the salt business of Paris-based Compagnie de Suez S.A. for $290 million and an Italian coatings company for undisclosed terms. Morton would pay $195 million for 67.5 percent of Suez's stake in Compagnie des Salins du Midi et des Salines de l'Est, which had estimated 1996 sales of $270 million. It would offer to buy the remaining publicly traded shares in a cash tender. Morton, based in Chicago, said that adding the French salt business would result in combined salt sales of about $870 million. Morton also said it would acquire Pulverlac S.p.A., a maker of powder coatings, which is based in Desenzano del Garda, Italy.

title: New Standards Put Stress Not on Answer but Logic
description: Tackling a new kind of math problem with three fellow eighth graders at Intermediate School 292 in the East New York section of Brooklyn, Quannesha Harper stood up from her desk and leaned over to study the length of her foot.

title: Fire Leaves Many Homeless
description: Thirty Jersey City families left homeless by a fire on Monday spent the last hours of 1996 in local hotels, officials said. Ida Martinez, 49, was killed in the blaze, which gutted two apartment buildings and an adjacent single-room-occupancy hotel on Milton Avenue in the Heights section. The cause was under investigation, said Tom Gallagher, a city spokesman.

title: A Black Madonna, Remaking Herself Again
description: For behavior that never fails to make news, even after 14 years as a pop star, Brenda Fassie is known as South Africa's black Madonna. But in truth, she vacillates between nearly being its Kurt Cobain (flirting with drugs and suicide) and sometimes being its Bette Midler (motherly in a wacky way).

title: No Headline
description: The Times is printed today in two sections. The Living Section begins on page 49 and Business Day on page 61.

title: It's a Call to Arms (and Legs, as Well)
description: Which is easier to shoot, a goose stuck in the mud or one flying through the trees? Which is easier to sack and to stop, a quarterback who has mobility or one who is a dead duck because he moves like a cement truck?

title: Longing for a Greasy Spoon
description: It seems only a couple of years ago that I was grousing to a friend in a Greek diner about the $3 minimum when all I wanted was a cup of coffee, then asking the gods why New York didn't have the sort of cafes Paris and Rome do?

title: Gunman in Hebron: Unbalanced Loner, Driven by a Mission
description: When he left his army unit, took a bus from Jerusalem to Hebron and fired into a market yesterday, Pvt. Noam Friedman, above, joined the ranks of Jews who have used violence to block a peace accord they loathe.

title: And Now, From the New 'Hernia' Collection ...
description: Until recently, a brushed steel surface had everything going for it: edge (literally as well as metaphorically), craft, heft and texture. Call it high-tech grown-up: it signaled the homeowner was one of the welderati.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JANE PAULEY, the anchor of ''Dateline NBC'' and ''Time and Again'' on MSNBC, will be the host of this year's Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards for excellence in television and radio journalism.

title: Despite Its Charms, Horror Can Pale
description: HE lives in the old Steve McQueen place, a Hollywood Hills aerie that he calls ''Zenlike,'' but the veteran fearmonger and director Wes Craven insists that his home shows no sign of being haunted by anybody. Present owner included.

title: If Nets Make Deal, Gill Could Be Gone
description: Kendall Gill has given up pounds and inches, pieces of his flesh and easier shots over similar-sized players. He has given up his shooting guard spot, his body on a nightly basis and even wondering when it will end. And yet with everything Gill has unbegrudgingly sacrificed in moving to small forward, the Nets could give him up for the team's future should they decide to trade Gill, their most marketable player.

title: Pataki Needs to Finish Battle on H.M.O. Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Isn't on Edge Despite China Takeover
description: With scarcely six months remaining before Britain relinquishes Hong Kong to China after 150 years of colonial sovereignty, the anxiety among the general public seems to have missed much of the territory's business community.

title: I Remember Larry
description: One of the unheralded spies of the postwar era was Larry Wu-tai Chin. As an agent of Chinese Communist intelligence, he penetrated the C.I.A. and served as Beijing's ''mole'' for more than two decades.

title: Delay the Vote for Speaker
description: The House ethics committee now says that it will not be able to resume its investigation into Newt Gingrich until Jan. 8, one day after the Republicans have scheduled a vote on Mr. Gingrich's future as Speaker. The committee also says it will not be prepared to recommend the level of punishment Mr. Gingrich deserves for violating House ethics rules until later in the month. For the Republican leaders in the House, there is only one honorable and practical response to these announcements, and that is to delay the vote on the Speakership. The House cannot be asked to decide such an important matter on the basis of incomplete information about Mr. Gingrich's fitness for office.

description: If the stock market has been looking like Aesop's hare the last few years, the real economy -- of cars and computers, health care and consulting -- has surely been the tortoise, advancing steadily though slowly. But the next 12 months, chief executives around the country say, may turn out to be the year the tortoise has its revenge.

description: How long can the United States power the world's economy nearly alone? The economic recovery of the 1990's has been driven by the United States as growth in other industrialized nations has lagged. The outlook for much of Europe is positive, but Japan may slip back into recession.

title: Bus Crashes Into Building
description: A driver crashed a bus into an apartment building here yesterday after he was attacked by a passenger, the police said. Sgt. Wally Wolfe said the driver was attacked after he stopped the Greenville-Lafayette bus traveling southbound on Ocean Avenue shortly before 8 P.M. He said the driver had stopped the bus to ask a male passenger to either turn down his radio or to stop smoking marijuana. Shortly after that, Sergeant Wolfe said, the driver was hit over the head with a pipe or the radio. He lost consciousness and the bus mounted the sidewalk and crashed into the three-story building at Ocean and Stegman Avenues. The driver was taken to Jersey City Medical Center, treated for head injuries and released. Sergeant Wolfe said no passengers were seriously hurt. The police arrested Damian Tyner, 22, of Jersey City.

title: Trial to Begin in Girl's Killing
description: More than two years after 7-year-old Megan Kanka was abducted from her Hamilton Township home and raped and killed, the trial of the man accused of killing her is about to begin. Prosecutors say that Jesse Timmendequas, a neighbor with a history of sex crimes, lured Megan to his home by telling her she would see a puppy. Jury selection will begin in Hunterdon County on Jan. 13, but the trial will take place in Mercer County. Meanwhile, the law inspired by Megan's murder in July 1994 has been mired in a legal battle, and the provisions requiring a community to be notified when a dangerous sex offender is living in it have been blocked pending a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

description: A year ago, it looked as if the cable television industry was about to be strangled by telephone cords.

description: Some day a doctoral candidate in sociology or music might find the makings of a dissertation in the mystifyingly persistent link between the late 19th-century Viennese waltz and the ushering in of the new year. One can understand why the Vienna Philharmonic usually devotes its New Year's concerts to this repertory; it is, after all, a kind of archaic national pop music, with nostalgic connotations of a long-vanished empire and a gilded imperial style.

Apple outsed its chief executive and flirted with a merger. In the end, it went back to its roots, buying Next Software and bringing back Stephen P. Jobs, one of its charismatic founders.

title: Undress That Chair!
description: Tomato juice and hair of the dog is not going to do it for me in 1997 if there are still slipcovered folding chairs anywhere in sight. Talk about dishonest, which is an easy thing to do in decorating (think fake books and television sets hidden in cabinets), whoever decided that honest, no-nonsense, decent-looking folding chairs have to be clotheshorses, disguised with fanciful skirts and finished with even more ridiculous swags or bows?

title: Europeans Question the French Over Disagreements With U.S. : What's With Paris?
description: PARIS  A string of French diplomatic fumbles that led to headbutting with Washington on issues as diverse as Zaire, Iraq, trade, United Nations leadership and NATO reform has also sown doubts among its European neighbors about France's methods and manners in seeking a stronger Europe, Western policymakers say.

description: In November 1995, state health officials proposed a series of sweeping new regulations for health maintenance organizations -- the first revisions in more than two decades. Next month, these rules are to become final, officials said this week.

title: Local Politics: For Many, It Has Mattered
description: AS noted in this column just a few days ago, the phrase ''all politics is local'' has been a favorite American aphorism for about a century. With good reason. It speaks the truth, pithily explaining that politics is not theoretical or distant, that elected officials make decisions based on the impact back home because how else will they get to keep their jobs?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALSEY, BRYANT
description: HALSEY - Bryant. Age 85, a retired executive from the Cafritz Company of Washington, D.C. and a real estate consultant with national and international affiliations died on Wed. January 1, 1997. Mr. Halsey was born in Manhattan and attended Choate School and majored in architecture at Princeton University. He began his real estate career with Douglas L. Elliman in NYC in 1935. During W.W.II he served as a Lieutenant Commander in Naval Intelligence anti-submarine activities. After the war he established his own consulting firm. He was involved in the development of many diverse projects including the Pan Am Building in N.Y. Main Pl. in Dallas and 20th Century City in L.A. He was a developer and builder of single family homes and projects. In 1957, he built the Ideal Home for Better Homes and Gardens Magazine in Morristown, NJ. In 1963, Mr. Halsey moved to Washington, D.C. to become President of Westminister Investing Corporation which purchased 78 properties including 7 Corners Shopping Center. Subsequently he became economic consultant to the National Corporation for Housing Partnerships. Mr. Halsey retired as president of the Cafritz Company in Washington, D.C. in 1992. Mr. Halsey was widely recognized for his imaginative and innovative approach to developing and financing commercial real estate. He attributed much of his talent to the training he received from his father, Charles Bryant Halsey, who among many other projects inititated the commerical development of upper Madison Ave, NYC, which in 1913 was a residential area. Mr. Halsey had been a member of the National Association of Home Builders, the N.Y. Real Estate Board, the Washington Board of Realtors and the Fairfax County Industrial Development Commission. He had also been a Trustee of Lambda Alpha (Land Economics Society), a director of the NJ. Home Builders Association and a member of the Advisory Board of the Fairfax County National Bank. Affiliations include the Princeton Club of N.Y. the Rumson Country Club in N.J. and the City Tavern in Washington, D.C. Mr. Halsey was an avid yachtsman & hand been a member of the Larchmont and Manhasset Bay Yacht Clubs in N.J. the Sailing Club of the Chesapeake and the Classic Yacht Club of America. Among the many boats he had owned was the ''Richard Smith'', an 81 foot bugeye built in 1880. After residing in NYC, N.J. and then Arlington, Va. for the last 27 years, Mr. Halsey and his wife moved in 1994 to their new home on Dividing Creek on the Chesapeake Bay near the town of Kilmamock, Va. where Mr. Halsey continued his love of the water and sailing. Mr. Halsey is survived by his wife, Loraine, a son, Charles Bryant III of Sterling, Va. a daughter, Hilary Lynn Halsey of Burke, Va. and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 4, 1997 at 2:00 PM at the Wicomico Parish Church, Va. In lieu of flowers the family request that any tributes take the form of contributions to The Wicomico Church Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 70, Wicomico Church, Va. 22579. ''Bryant Halsey was a true sailor. He felt the wind, and rode out the storms in antiticipation of favorable winds hin the following days.''

He has also crafted an innovative, no-holds-barred passing game that floods the defense with speedy sure-handed receivers and uses timing, a pinpoint passing quarterback and an offensive line that usually gives him time to hit deep patterns. Now, just in time for 1997, Spurrier has come up with yet another wrinkle -- the 12-man offense -- designed especially for Florida's rematch against Florida State tonight in the Sugar Bowl.
