title: The Real Foster Care Experts
description: When New York's child welfare system took James Knight from a neglectful mother at age 7, he had no idea that what lay before him was going to be even worse. He and his four brothers and sisters were placed with a foster mother in Queens. Mr. Knight, now 21, says she beat them repeatedly with belts and broomsticks. He sought help from police and child welfare officials but got none. They interviewed the children only when the foster mother was present, he said.

title: Investors See a Correction, Sometime
description: Oh, what a hard year it was to be a bear. And it is not getting any easier, notwithstanding recent market jitters, less rosy forecasts for 1997 and a caution from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.

title: Church Aids Families Refused by City
description: For the last two days, Reynaldo Guzman's children have slept near people they hardly know and played with toys they cannot keep. They watch television in a church basement. And for all this, he is thankful.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Victim of Gulf War

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, JACKSON
description: CROSS - Jackson, in his 90th year, passed away in Vero Beach, FL. December 29, 1996. Son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Frank Bethel Cross. Beloved husband of Anne Meyer Cross. Devoted father of Mitzi Scrivan, Susan Benoit and Alice Dorrance. Loving grandfather of Kate, Andrew, Tessa, Cyrus, Sam and Anne. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY and former resident of Fairfield, CT. Graduate of The University of the South, Class of 1930. Memorial service 4 PM, Friday, Jan 3, 1997, First Presbyterian Church, Vero Beach. In Lieu of flowers contributions in his memory are welcome to The University of the South, Sewanee, TN. 37383.

title: Hotels Look For 5th Year Of Growing Profitability
description: Hotel industry executives were sorry to see 1996 come to an end, because it brought a fourth consecutive year of record profits -- a long stretch for a business known for severe boom-and-bust cycles.

title: Peruvian Rebels Free 7 More, But the Standoff Is Unbroken
description: Despite recent signs that negotiations to end the hostage crisis at the Japanese Ambassador's residence are stalled, Marxist guerrillas today released 7 of their 81 captives, including Peruvian Government officials and Japanese businessmen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORIAN, RAYMOND
description: DORIAN - Raymond, on Dec. 31, 1996. Dear husband of Grace and father of Linda Casaletto. For information Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home 212-877-9700.

title: Out of the Fire, Onto the Plate
description: A NINTH generation of the Boch family is now working at Villeroy & Boch, the venerable German dinnerware company, which will celebrate its 250th anniversary next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLAK, DR. LEWIS FISHER
description: POLLAK - Dr. Lewis Fisher. On December 31, 1996 in Springfield, MA. Beloved husband of Karen Leslie. Adored father of Adam Sydney, Noah Benjamin, and Dara Beth. Dear step-father of Michael Nichols. Cherished son of Clara Pollak Ulansky and the late Dr. Sydney S. Pollak. Loving brother of Dr. Edward and Karen, Dr. Henry and Audrey, Ann and Soul Adelman. Adored uncle. Dear Son-in-law of Elaine and Daniel Woodard. Service Friday, January 3, 1997, at 11:30 A.M. at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Brood Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Shiva at the Edelman residence.

title: Safe and Sound
description: The hallmark of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy over the past two years has been the low cost and low risks of its activism. Although critics charge that the Administration is prone to dangerous, wholesale interventions, a close look at the record shows that the military operations it has initiated have been discretionary and largely successful.

title: A Prison Term in Tibet
description: Last week, the Chinese Government gave a 30-year-old scholar of Tibetan music an 18-year prison sentence for espionage. Even by Chinese standards, the sentence is astonishingly long. It is also a warning to Tibetans that their already scarce liberties are now further endangered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, NATALIE USDAN
description: SCHNEIDER - Natalie Usdan, on January 1, 1997. Beloved wife of Dr. Harry M. Schneider, adoring mother of Elizabeth M. Schneider, lvoing sister of Beatrice Lieben, Zipporah Epstein, Leo Usdan, devoted grandmother of Anna and Matthew Schneider - Mayerson. Services Thursday, January 2, 1997, 12 noon, ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Family will observe shiva at the home of Liz Schneider.

title: Payoff Still Elusive In Internet Gold Rush
description: Before corporate America's recent dash into cyberspace, the last time so many people went so far and spent so much to get so little was perhaps the gold rushes of the 19th century. In 1996, Internet lucre proved as elusive as the mother lode.

title: Keeping Color Photos Bright and Fade-Free
description: THE holidays are over, the gifts given and received, the family snapshots taken. Now comes the tricky part: getting the film processed properly, and storing the pictures so that they will last as long as possible.

title: Theodore Baird, Professor, 95
description: Theodore Baird, an emeritus professor of English at Amherst College and a specialist in teaching students how to write, died on Sunday at Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass. He was 95 and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: In Mexico, an Uneven Recovery
description: A few of the Mexicans who will help determine how the economy performs this year were milling one holiday afternoon outside the display windows of a famous department store in Mexico City's central square.

title: WHAT HAPPENED: A Copper Trader Loses Big
description: Yasuo Hamanaka was known as Mr. 5 Percent for the portion of the world copper market the controlled. But while he was reporting big profits to Sumitomo, the giant trading company that employed him, Mr. Hamanaka was piling up $2.6 billion in trading losses. Mr. Hamanaka now faces forgery charges and investigators are trying to determine if anyone else at Sumitomo knew about his activities.

title: Suspect in Slaying Is Seized in Casino
description: Even before Fitzroy Morris moved from his native Antigua to New York a year ago, he spent much of his spare time in casinos, playing blackjack and working as a card dealer, the police said.

title: Debate Over Taxes in '97 Is Likely to Stress 'Relief'
description: Goodbye, tax reform. Hello, tax relief.

title: Dark Ages for Tabletops
description: There is no design trend that deserves to die faster than colored dishware: glasses that make the richest Pomerol look like a medical sample, colored plates that make sauces look like engine ooze. Colored dishware turns a meal into a morass.

title: WHAT HAPPENED: A Boom in Mergers
description: Boeing's $14 billion acquisition of McDonnell Douglas capped a record year for mergers as companies turned their attention from cost-cutting to growth. The rising stock market helped finance the deals. Pushed by the Pentagon, few industries consolidated more quickly than military contracting, which has carried out more than $40 billion mergers the last four years.

title: Crackdown On Fraud Intensifies
description: Stock market scam artists are making creative new efforts to defraud investors -- and forcing regulators to take aggressive new steps to try to thwart them.

title: Aikman Handles Media Blitz Over Irvin
description: Studying zone blitzes and Carolina's sack-happy 3-4 defense. Breaking down film and finding a way to better a career 11-1 playoff record. Troy Aikman will gladly cope with that.

title: No Holiday for Pupils' Gifts to Neediest
description: Although students have been on break for the holidays, the seeds of generosity planted in schools in and around New York are sprouting in the form of donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A Backpedaling Spurrier Expects a Clean Sugar Bowl
description: Steve Spurrier ran his first reverse of the year today. The coach of the Florida Gators, after a relentless monthlong campaign in which he maintained Florida State used illegal and unethical tactics in its victory over his team on Nov. 30, declared his satisfaction that their rematch in the 63d Sugar Bowl on Thursday night would be fair.

title: Zapata Buyback Sends Stock Up
description: Shares of the Zapata Corporation rose 21 percent Tuesday after the company offered to buy back as much as half its stock, including $13.5 million in shares held by its chairman, Malcom Glazer.

title: Time Runs Out on Sun Devils' National Title Bid
description: Phillis Germaine lives on a well-lighted street in Mesa, Ariz., where she raised two sons. The older one, Bruce, attends Arizona State, and today the younger one, Joe, beat Arizona State.

title: Drying Oneself With Daisy Petals
description: THE daisy motif, which wilted with the flower power of the 60's, is sprouting again on everything from towels to clocks. Liza Niles, a professor in the textiles department at the Parsons School of Design, thinks the naivete and 60's allusion of the daisy satisfy a desire for the organic or natural.

title: Gas Rate Increase Is Sought
description: The Elizabethtown Gas Company asked state regulators Tuesday to approve a $14 million rate increase that would allow the company to pass along to its customers recent price increases in natural gas. The increase would raise the annual gas bill for the average residential customer with gas heat by $116, The Associated Press reported. If the Board of Public Utilities approves the rise, it will take effect Feb. 1, the company, which serves 240,000 customers in northern and central New Jersey, said.

title: The Spill-Over Effect
description: Since introspection is a big part of the new year, I find myself pondering a couple of design conspiracy theories (don't tell Oliver Stone).

title: From Captive of Iraq to Captive of an Illness
description: When she returned home from the Persian Gulf in 1991, Specialist Melissa Coleman was saluted as a hero, if only for having survived the war.

title: Blind Faith in the Fed
description: Ten years ago this January, stock prices increased in nine of the first 10 trading days of the month. Over the entire month, the market rose an astonishing 13 percent -- a fitting beginning for the second leg of the greatest bull market in history.

title: A Streak Glistens Daily: Hitting 2,600 on Slopes
description: For Paul Schipper, a retired airline pilot, skiing has become life's sweet obsession. How else to explain The Streak, a 15-year stretch that as of tomorrow adds up to a whopping 2,600 consecutive ski days on the slopes of Sugarloaf, Me.?

title: Soft Fields Of Flowers
description: LONG blades of grass and wisteria leaves seem to dance across satins, velvets and organzas in a new collection of pillows by Susan Unger, a New York designer.

title: A 90's Coach, With a Dash of Lombardi
description: The young quarterback was a marvel. He could throw with the power of a rocket launcher, was as quick as a springbok and could dance from defenders like a rumba king. Just one problem: he thought he was Jesse James.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEINBERG, PAUL
description: KLEINBERG - Paul. 1/2/94. Dad, '96 was full of family miles-tones-bringing loving memories of you-your insightful perspective, your love and encouragement.

title: Rising Dollar Has U.S. Executives a Bit Concerned
description: The dollar's rally last year against its two main rivals -- the Japanese yen and the German mark -- pushed the American currency up far enough that American executives have begun to worry anew about its impact on competitiveness, sales and profits.

title: King Kong Would Be Miffed
description: In a taxi hurtling home, perhaps feeling a bit queasy in the wee hours of New Year's Day, anyone looking up for reassurance to that great beacon of New York glamour, the Empire State Building, might have become queasier still.

description: MORRISON - Kenneth. The Board of Governors and members of Fresh Meadow Country club extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Karen, his children Kirsten and Todd and the entire family on the the passing of our former golf professional who served our club for many years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The DUKE AND DUCHESS OF KENT are grandparents once again. LADY HELEN TAYLOR, their daughter, and her husband, Tim Taylor, an art dealer, have a second son. The child, born the day after Christmas, is 26th in line to the British throne.

title: Who Asked?
description: I really hate the new trend in televised sports coverage toward snazzy graphics providing unrelenting scoreboard information in the corner of the screen. Take Fox's coverage of the World Series, where the Fox Box was constantly displayed, set into a tiny baseball diamond. The excuse for the flagrant, distracting self-promotion was that it provided a visual display of information -- the score, the count, the runners on base -- but none of that was as easy to read as the Murdoch network's three-letter declamation of its technological presence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAMOLEN, MIRIAM
description: MAMOLEN - Miriam. Of New York city, died 12/29/96. Memorial service planned in Spring. For information: 609-494-1482. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to New York Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

title: New War Zone, New Tactics
description: The birth pangs of RU-486 and the accompanying political, religious and ideological pangs reach the screen tomorrow night in ''The Abortion Pill.'' Although the producers' hearts are with the women who have taken the drug or would take it if it were available here, their report gives ample attention to the arguments and emotions of those who have been trying to stop its use.

description: International A3-9

title: Bomb Found Under Truck
description: Wilbur Brandon, of Caldwell, thought someone was playing a practical joke on him when he found a bomb under his truck on Tuesday, but the police are not laughing. The device -- two 20-ounce plastic bottles taped together with a firecracker between them as a detonator -- had enough power to destroy his truck and set his house on fire, the police said.

title: For Hungarian Army Officers, It's 'Eyes West!'
description: In the last few years, Col. Tibor Nagy has been systematically unlearning everything he was taught as an officer in Hungary's army, shedding habits of a lifetime.

title: Charge That a Man Hid His Nazi Past Shocks His Neighbors
description: Widowed and retired, Michael Kolnhofer blended in well in this quiet, middle-class neighborhood since moving here about 18 months ago.

title: Israeli Wounds 6 Arabs in Hebron Rampage
description: An Israeli soldier with a history of mental problems opened fire today on a crowded Palestinian market here, wounding six Arabs and delaying the completion of the agreement on a transfer of power to Palestinians in Hebron.

title: The Link Grows Cloudy Between Jobs and Prices
description: The current economic recovery is nearly six years old, and the annual inflation rate is a meager 3.2 percent -- the lowest level since World War II for an expansion this old. Economists are coming up with all sorts of explanations for the unusual milestone. And gradually many are concluding that inflation has become harder to explain.

title: The Crimson Crop Is Plenty Green
description: Harvard M.B.A.'s, presumably well trained to go out and manage things, instead are increasingly inclined to get jobs where they tell other people how to manage things. And manufacturing is continuing to decline as a source of employment for new M.B.A.'s.

title: Do Computers Lift Productivity? It's Unclear, but Business Is Sold
description: The Dell Computer Corporation has designed its newest factory without room for inventory storage. The Chrysler Corporation can increase vehicle production without building new factories. And the General Electric Company expects to save millions of dollars by buying spare parts for its plants over the Internet.

description: They were the Sirens of the South, beckoning to generations of vacationers driving to Florida.

description: There are few books in La-Toya Pankey's apartment on 102d Street near Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan, and even fewer places for an 8-year-old girl to steal away to read them.

title: Or Maybe New York Is Shrinking
description: One of the most astonishing things I saw on my first visit to Europe in the 1960's was a Mercury Monterey. That behemoth, so at home on American expressways, looked ostentatiously out of place in the narrow corridors of ancient cities. Happily, there was only one.

title: Red Storm Streak Is Spurred by Minlend
description: He is not exactly a David among Goliaths. It just appears that way sometimes when you watch St. John's power forward Charles Minlend outmuscle some of the bigger, stronger forwards in the Big East Conference.

In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to a favorite charity.

title: Heat's Quick Start Helps Keep Nets at Bay
description: The clean-cut Shawn Bradley always has that just-shaved look, never a sign of stubble. But tonight he looked different, more rugged than usual. And it had nothing to do with the appearance of some facial hair.

title: DI INDUSTRIES TO BUY ASSETS OF FLOURNOY DRILLING
description: DI Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the operating assets of the Flournoy Drilling Company for about $37.2 million in stock and debt. DI Industries, a Houston oil-drilling services holding company, said the assets to be acquired included 13 drilling rigs, 17 rig-hauling trucks and a yard and office complex in Alice, Tex. The company said it expected to employ Flournoy's workers. DI Industries said it would issue 12.4 million shares and assume about $800,000 in debt in the transaction. DI Industries stock rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $2.938 a share. Flournoy Drilling is based in southern Texas.

title: Six U.S. Lawmakers File Suit Challenging Line-Item Veto
description: Six members of Congress filed a lawsuit today challenging the constitutionality of a new law that gives the President power to cancel selected items of spending in bills that he signs.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NORTHERN TELECOM SELLS 25% OF INTERNET COMPANY
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said yesterday that it had sold 25 percent of its newly formed Internet security company, Entrust Technologies Inc., to a group of institutional investors for $26 million. The investors include Olympus Partners, J. P. Morgan & Company, Societe Generale S.A., T. Rowe Price Associates and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. Northern Telecom, a phone equipment maker based in Mississauga, Ontario, said it was selling the stake to let Entrust have more freedom in choosing partners other than Northern Telecom and in selling its technology. Entrust provides software used to scramble and identify information on the Internet.

title: In a Tough Hint to Rebels, Peru Fills Hostages' Jobs
description: With the siege of the Japanese Ambassador's residence in its third week, leftist guerrillas have been freeing Peruvian and foreign dignitaries in dribs and drabs, at once alleviating the crisis and heightening the fear of a violent showdown.

title: L.I. CENTER LACKS AIR CONTROLLERS
description: Federal aviation officials have failed to meet their commitment to increase the number of air traffic controllers in the New York region, raising air safety concerns among both lawmakers and union officials, who contend that the controllers are increasingly being overworked.

title: $25 and Under
description: When Opaline opened three months ago on Avenue A, it was noteworthy for two reasons. First was its size. With 120 seats, it was much larger than the usual East Village hole in the wall. Second was the restaurant's marketing concept. Opaline, the menu says, is a synonym for absinthe, the ''turn-of-the-century liquor favored by poets, courtesans and esthetes,'' symbolizing a restaurant that will offer ''all the piquancy of a well-appointed Parisian cafe, frequented by esthetes who take their pleasures seriously.''

title: The Cutting Edge
description: ''Blech: The New York Phase,'' Vinyl, 157 Hudson Street, between Hubert and Laight Streets, TriBeCa, (212) 343-1379. One of electronic dance music's most consistently innovative labels, Warp, will be presenting a handful of its top artists at the club Vinyl tonight in what promises to be a long and crowded but rewarding night: new sounds and the kinds of performances where you aren't sure whether anyone is actually onstage. The electronic whiz kid the Aphex Twin leads the pack. On recent albums, he reinvents drum and bass, flirts with lounge music and even sings. But live, he can be so uncompromising that he'll play the turntables with sandpaper instead of records. The duo Autechre works with a variety of slow to midtempo beats (which seem to be getting funkier as the band evolves) and a panoply of tortuous electronic sounds. And Jimi Tenor seems able to slip into any groove, from Prince-derived electro-funk sung in falsetto to frenetic techno based on the theme from ''Caravan,'' by Juan Tizol and Duke Ellington. The performances, interspersed with disk jockey sets, begin at 10 P.M. and end near sunrise. Admission is $25. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Dow Sinks but Then Rallies At End, Dropping Just 5.78
description: The stock market opened 1997 in wild trading yesterday, with share prices first falling in a continuation of the pre-holiday slide, but then rallying late in the day.

title: Serbs' Eyes on Milosevic: Crackdown or a Coup?
description: Six weeks into the political crisis here, which began when the Government canceled the results of municipal elections won by opposition parties, noisy demonstrations have become a routine, if more subdued, part of the landscape. It seems clear that the next move -- and the direction this confrontation will take -- is up to the President, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: U.S. Accepts Suffolk's Bid To Import Electricity
description: In a development that could further complicate negotiations to reduce electricity rates on Long Island, the Suffolk County government has won Federal approval to buy a significant amount of electricity from outside New York State and sell it to residential customers through the transmission lines of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Dispute on Blue Cross's Assets
description: The State Attorney General has taken a ''crucial first step'' toward requiring Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey to turn over millions of dollars to a charitable trust before it merges with a private insurance company based in Indianapolis, the state's largest consumer group said yesterday. The group, New Jersey Citizen Action, said Blue Cross has as much as $1 billion in assets that accumulated as it received tax breaks and subsidies for being the state's insurer of last resort.

title: 'Hoo-wee!' Jackson Sounds on Top of His Game
description: Like Mel Allen on baseball, Don Dunphy on boxing and Marv Albert on basketball, ABC's Keith Jackson evokes his sport. He is college football. He is the bell cow, the big ugly, the big tree with his britches hitched up high, blending natural eloquence with a dab of ''Green Acres.'' You should want to hear his bemused twang from late August to bowl time, no more so than when a national title is on the line, as it was last night at the Sugar Bowl. Oh me.

title: Settlement on Waste Site
description: Nearly 300 companies that improperly dumped hazardous waste at a Superfund site in Camden County agreed yesterday to pay $30 million to complete the cleanup of the landfill.

title: Breaking Up Youth Gangs Seen as '97 Police Priority
description: In an effort to continue the record drop in crime that New York City experienced during 1996, the Police Department will focus on breaking up youth gangs in 1997 by computerizing its intelligence about illegal weapons, gun sellers and drug dealers and trying to establish a curfew for juveniles with criminal records, according to an internal memorandum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHALING, JAMES TYLER
description: WHALING - James Tyler, on January 1, 1997, of Chappaqua, New York. Son of George A. and Suzanne (nee Kelly) Whaling. Brother of Collins Baker, Sally and Mark Wahling. Interment Dellwood Cemetery, Manchester Village, VT. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to Blythedale Children's Hospital, Bradhurst Avenue, Valhalia, New York 10595 or Colgate University would be appreciated.

title: U.S. Mediation Fails to Achieve Accord on a Pullback in Hebron
description: An American mediator failed again today to conclude a long-delayed agreement on a partial Israeli pullback in Hebron as it became increasingly evident that the Palestinians were digging in on their insistence for deadlines and guarantees for the further withdrawal of Israeli forces in the West Bank.

title: Indurain Pedals His Last Mile
description: Ending three months of speculation, Miguel Indurain announced today that he was retiring from professional bicycle racing at age 32 and after five victories in the Tour de France, the world's greatest bicycle race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, DR. MAURICE
description: BAUM - Dr. Maurice. On January 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Winifred. Devoted father of Louis and Paul. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. Brother of Rosalyn Swede. Services are today, 10 AM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: Gingrich Strains to Retain His Hold on the House
description: Newt Gingrich's re-election as Speaker of the House appeared threatened today, at least for the moment, as the number of Republicans unwilling to commit themselves to him reached 27.

title: First Baby Bell Seeks to Enter Long Distance
description: In a milestone on the road to deregulated telephone service, the Ameritech Corporation applied for permission yesterday to offer long-distance service within its own region.

title: In Chaotic Zaire, River Is a Lifeline to the World
description: Thirty-six years of chaotic independence have hardly made Zaire synonymous with institutional dependability. But early each morning, as if it is the exception out to prove the rule, the riverboat Matadi fires up its engines for a day of travel back and forth across the milewide waterway that separates this country from Congo.

title: Condominiums Planned For the Mayfair Hotel
description: When the Colony Capital real estate investment group became the new owners of the Mayfair Hotel, at Park Avenue and 65th Street, after a foreclosure sale in late May, their initial idea was to maintain the property as a hotel.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the front page of the special Outlook '97 section of Business Day yesterday showing growth in gross domestic product carried incorrect seasonal labels. The economy grew at a 4.4 percent rate in the summer of 1981, not the fall; at an 8.2 percent rate in the winter of 1984, not the spring, and a 2.3 percent rate in the summer of 1996, not the fall.

title: F.D.A. Proposal Would Ban Using Animal Tissue in Feed
description: The Food and Drug Administration today proposed a ban on the use of any tissue from a wide variety of animals in feed to prevent the spread of mad cow disease if it ever occurred in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZMAN, JUDGE WILLIAM
description: HOLZMAN - Judge William. Beloved husband of Kate. Dear brother of Morton Holzman. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

description: The Food and Drug Administration has issued an warning on several herbal liquid products that are believed to have sickened dozens of New Year's Eve revelers here.

title: S.E.C. Delays New Order-Handling Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission slightly delayed some aspects of its new order-handling rules yesterday. The commission said the rules would take effect on Monday, Jan. 13, rather than on the preceding Friday.

title: ONEIDA ANNOUNCES NEW BUYER FOR CAMDEN WIRE
description: Oneida Ltd. agreed yesterday to sell its Camden Wire Company unit to International Wire Group Inc. for $44.5 million in cash and the assumption of $15.5 million in debt. The sale replaces a November agreement to sell the unit for $51 million to the Aarque Capital Corporation. International Wire, a closely held company in St. Louis, was formed in 1995 by the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. and its management affiliate Mills & Partners Inc. Camden Wire makes noninsulated conductor wire for electronics, transportation and consumer products companies. It accounted for about $149 million of Oneida's $514 million in revenue in the 1995 fiscal year.

title: GROUP WANTS SHAREHOLDERS TO REPLACE REXENE BOARD
description: A group of investors in the Rexene Corporation said yesterday that it would try to replace the Rexene board and amend the company's bylaws. The investor group, led by Wyser-Pratte & Company and Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, said it had mailed a preliminary solicitation statement asking the shareholders of Rexene, a chemical company, to call for a special meeting. The group wants the company to reconsider a $16-a-share takeover offer by the privately held Huntsman Corporation of Salt Lake City. Wyser-Pratte and Spear, Leeds hold about 10.1 percent of Rexene's outstanding common shares. A majority vote is needed to call a special meeting.

title: Who Will Pay for a Generation of Expensive Plants?

But the never-ending debate about nuclear power's future is once again heating up, this time fanned by fears that many nuclear plants could become financial albatrosses as deregulation gives business and residential consumers choices about where they buy power.

title: Restaurants
description: Angelo and Maxie's Steakhouse is the perfect tourist spot. Visitors can experience American abundance, marveling at a menu that offers plates of prime rib weighing almost two pounds apiece. Foreigners are entranced, and yet most of the people who pour through the door are Americans eager for a taste of the past. Angelo and Maxie's, which has a name straight out of the song ''Lullaby of Broadway,'' celebrates a long-gone America where people smoked and drank and ate huge hunks of red meat. Judging by the reception the restaurant has received, it is an America many New Yorkers would like to have back.

title: Unsettling Results of Mixing Up and Down
description: THE photographs of Lisette Model induce a very specific kind of vertigo, the feeling of looking up and looking down simultaneously. Model, who was born in Vienna in 1901, lived in Paris in the 20's and 30's and finally settled in New York City until her death in 1983, is best known for photographing the extremes of society: the very rich lounging on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice and the very poor lying on the streets and benches of New York and Paris. But the sociological drama of her photographs, 20 of which are now on view at the Pace Wildenstein MacGill Gallery, is more than matched by a parallel visual effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMAN, GERALD HOWARD
description: ULLMAN - Gerald Howard, on December 30, 1996 in Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of 51 Fifth Avenue, New York City. Loving husband of his late wife, Marcia Dubey Ullman. Survived by his second wife Susie Press Ullman; his son Steven M. Ullman and daughter Marjorie Ullman; grandchildren Jerry and Michael Ullman. Mr. Ullman graudated with honors from Dartmouth College and Harvard Law School. Prior to enlistment in the U.S. Army in 1941 he served on the staff of Assemblyman Irving M. Ives (R), Majority Leader. Upon his honorable discharge as Captain in 1946, Mr. Ullman again served U.S. Senator Ives in Washington, D.C. Thereafter he was counsel to two New York state legislative committees under Republican New York States Senators McNeil Mitchell and Seymour Halprin. Mr. Ullman began his private law practice in New York City in 1948 specializing in international ocean transportation. He was General Counsel for the National Customs Brokers and Forwarders Association along with many other firms including freight forwarders, customs brokers, steamship lines, customs brokers, steamship lines, NVOCCs, motor property brokers, exporters and importers, and public warehouses. During his more than forty years in practice, Mr. Ullman litigated shipping issues extensively in federal trial and appelate courts, including the U.S. Supreme Court and often appeared before Congressional committees on shipping matters. Mr. Ullman drafted the 1961 amendment providing of the licensing of ocean freight forwarders and participated in the drafting of the Shipping Act of 1984. In addition, Mr. Ullman recently served as lead counsel before the U.S. Supreme Court obtaining a final ruling holding unlawful restrictive and costly union requirements (the ''50 Mile Container Rule'') that seriously impeded movement of U.S. exports and imports. This victory has been described as a major contribution candidate for New York State Assembly in 1960 and 1962, and for civil court in 1969. Mr. Ullman was described by the nonpartisan Citizens' Union as ''a distinguished and able lawyer ... who is highly regarded for his ability and high integrity.'' Mr. Ullman was the author of the books ''The Ocean Freight Forwarder, the Exporter and the Law,'' and ''U.S. Regulation of Ocean Transportation Under the Shipping Act of 1984,'' which are widely used in shipping circles, in law schools, and by merchant marine academies. In addition, Mr. Ullman wrote extensively in law journals in the United States and Europe on the legal issues involved in the intermodal movement of traffic and has had articles cited by the U.S. Supreme Court. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 5th at 12:30 PM at the Village Temple, 33 East 12th Street, NYC.

title: Total Immersion Jazz
description: Abraham Burton Quartet, Visiones, 125 Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 673-5576. One recent evening, as Abraham Burton blew his alto saxophone with atomic power, making quick manipulations on a single sirenlike note, and the pianist James Hurt began a wild percussive piano solo that made the keys sound like tuned congas, the room became a gallery of frozen expressions. It was a moment when nobody thought about ordering a drink. The five-alarm Abraham Burton Quartet only recently drafted Mr. Hurt and hasn't yet recorded with him; here is a chance to see a good young band before the word gets out. It's a return to the sort of full-impact, total-immersion jazz that New York used to have a reputation for incubating. Sets are at 9, 11 and 1 tonight and tomorrow night and at 9 and 11 on Sunday night. Admission is $10, $5 on Sunday, with a $10 drink minimum. BEN RATLIFF

title: Climb Onto That Snowboard: Surf's Up on the Big White
description: THE first technical term added to a beginner's vocabulary when learning to snowboard is ''face plant.'' These words describe what happens when the downhill edge of a moving snowboard touches the mountain, sending the rider flying with a violent jerk face first into the snow. From the chairlift at Stratton Mountain in Vermont, snowboarders and skiers have a bird's-eye view of faces being planted all over the slopes. For beginners, face plants are a common occurrence; for the intermediate snowboarder, face plants are a constant fear, and for anyone who has spent a long day on the mountain, face plants are what happen over dinner in a hot bowl of soup.

title: Psychedelia Revisited
description: Holger Czukay, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3055. Supporting the theory that ideas are transmitted like viruses, with people who have hardly come into contact catching them at the same time without knowing the source, is the recent spate of reunited progressive and space-rock bands from the 60's and 70's. Innovators like Gong and Cluster, which had never performed before in the United States, suddenly popped up in local clubs last year, following in the footsteps of Faust and two bands calling themselves Hawkwind. Now it's Holger Czukay's turn. Mr. Czukay was the classically trained leader of Can, responsible for the era's best droning, pulsing psychedelia, and he was sampling before there were samplers, working with spliced tape and shortwave radio. Like many of his contemporaries, he will be using the electronic dance music that evolved out of his work as a crutch, collaborating with Dr. Walker of the ambient techno act Air Liquide in performances tonight and tomorrow night at 9. Malcolm Mooney, Can's original vocalist, and U-She, Mr. Czukay's wife, will also be performing. Admission is $15. N. S.

description: The red neon lights that decorate the windows of Calvin Klein's Madison Avenue store are more than minimal-style Christmas decorations. They are the work of the sculptor Dan Flavin, who died last month. The artist's light sculptures also glow in Calvin Klein stores in Tokyo, Seoul and Zurich.

title: Air France Plans More Cost Cuts
description: Air France said yesterday that it would cut costs by 15 percent in the next three years in an effort to stay competitive with its European rivals. The new cuts come on top of a 20 percent reduction in the previous three-year period, the company's chairman, Christian Blanc, said.

title: Settlement in Bond Case
description: Nicholas A. Rudi Jr., who advised Jim Florio when he was Governor of New Jersey, agreed this week to pay $86,000 to settle civil charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had accepted kickbacks to help a bank win a $237 million municipal bond contract. Mr. Rudi settled the case without admitting or denying wrongdoing.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Texaco Settles With U.S. To Avoid Discrimination Suit

title: TAKEOVER TALK LIFTS STATE STREET BOSTON STOCK
description: The stock of the State Street Boston Corporation rose 12.6 percent yesterday as investors rushed to buy on speculation that the Bank of New York Company was preparing a takeover bid for the company. In New York Stock Exchange trading, State Street Boston stock gained $8 a share, closing at $71. Late on Thursday, the Bank of New York said that it had filed with the Federal Reserve Board and Massachusetts Board of Bank Incorporation to increase its ownership stake in State Street to 9.9 percent from 4.99 percent. In the filing, the Bank of New York described the increased stake as ''noncontrolling'' and for investment purposes. State Street reaffirmed its intention to remain independent.

title: Florio Disparages Strategy
description: Former Gov. Jim Florio is still not disclosing whether he intends to try to win back his old job, but yesterday he did have plenty to say about the state Democratic Party's new plan to close ranks behind the candidate who emerges as the front-runner. Such a move, he said, would represent ''a dramatic reversal'' of longstanding efforts to rid New Jersey of old-style back-room politics. ''It sends out the opposite message of what the party has been talking about for a long time,'' Mr. Florio said. Mr. Florio notified Tom Byrne, the state Democratic chairman, that he would not participate in the endorsement process. Mr. Byrne recently proposed that county organizations agree to endorse the candidate deemed to have the best chance of winning the Democratic nomination. Mr. Florio, a partner in a Piscataway law firm, was defeated by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in 1993.

title: Yanks Invite 13 to Camp
description: Willie Banks, a former first-round draft pick from Jersey City, and Katsuhiro Maeda, a former Japanese League pitcher, were among the 13 nonroster players the Yankees invited to spring training yesterday. Pitchers and catchers are scheduled to report on Feb. 14, with position players due on Feb. 19.

title: Ex-Coach Pleads Guilty
description: A former Western Hockey League coach who helped develop some National Hockey League stars pleaded guilty Thursday to sex crimes involving some of his former players.

title: Fetal Abuse Charge Rejected
description: In May 1995, prosecutors say, Laurie Barker gave birth to a one-pound premature baby girl who had so much cocaine in her blood that she died 42 minutes later. Ms. Barker, now 31, of Newark, was indicted in February on charges of aggravated manslaughter and endangering the welfare of a child. Prosecutors contended -- in the only case of its kind in New Jersey -- that she showed ''extreme disregard for human life'' by repeatedly taking drugs during her pregnancy.

title: Swedish Plan to Sell Bank Stake Is Reported
description: The Swedish Government was reported yesterday to be considering selling a quarter of Nordbanken A.B. to Investor A.B., a Swedish holding company controlled by the Wallenberg family.

title: Falk, Ewing and Knicks Prepare to Haggle
description: David Falk was seated a few rows behind Ernie Grunfeld at the USAir Arena on Thursday night in Landover, Md. At halftime of the game between the Knicks and Bullets, Falk, Patrick Ewing's agent, made a short walk to Grunfeld's seat.

title: Barnes & Noble to Move Into Yale Co-op Store
description: The 111-year-old Yale Co-op has been left homeless after the university announced yesterday that Barnes & Noble would take over the Eero Saarinen-designed store that has been the co-op's home for 35 years.

title: Food-Stamp Fraud Charged
description: Hui Sook Kim and his wife, Linda, ran an odd sort of grocery store, according to Federal court documents. The shelves of H & L Groceries in East Orange were nearly bare, the refrigerators empty, the cans of food faded with age. The Kims did a brisk business with food stamp recipients -- hundreds of thousands of dollars since June 1995, prosecutors say -- but quite often, their customers would walk out without any groceries, surveillance cameras found.

title: Corrections

Although such a change was approved by the Arizona Legislature, it was vetoed in April by Gov. Fife Symington.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Chief Retires
description: After heading the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. for 28 years, Charles Marciante will officially retire as president on Sunday and nominate his successor, officials said yesterday. Mr. Marciante's choice is Charles Wowkanech, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the organization's second-highest ranking official. Mr. Wowkanech will serve as interim president until the union's 44-member executive board votes on whether to approve his nomination. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Construction Spending Rises In Sign of Economic Strength
description: Construction spending rose unexpectedly in November at the fastest rate since March of last year, the Government said today, in yet another sign the economy was heading into the new year on a firm footing.

description: Avoiding a discrimination lawsuit by the Government, Texaco Inc. has agreed to a settlement under which a Federal agency will directly monitor the company's compliance with employment laws, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Boutros Boutros-Ghali on his last day as United Nations Secretary General misstated his plans for a new book. He intends to write one, but the subject has not been determined; a memoir of his years in the Middle East has already been completed and is to be published in April by Random House.

In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to Trinity Church, Southport, Visiting Nurse Services of Connecticut, Inc. or St. Vincents Med Center Foundation Office, Bridgeport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENNEY, GEORGE CLINTON
description: TENNEY - George Clinton. On January 3, 1997 in Orleans, MA at age 98. He was born in Provo, UT on July 13, 1898 and was a survivor of the San Francisco earthquake and fire of 1906. He attended the University of California at Berkley which awarded him an honorary doctorate. He joined the McGraw Hill Company in San Francisco of which he became President and he retired as Vice President of McGraw Hill in New York in 1960. He went on to take leadership roles in the communities of Truro, MA and Sanibel, FL. He served on the Truro Planning Board, and in Sanibel he was a Planning Board member and Library Trustee. He was the founder of CROW to rehabilitate injured wildlife. Mr. Tenney was a ardent outdoorsman, hunter, fisherman, master gardener and gourmet chef. His wife of thirty eight years Janet M. Tenney of Tampa, FL survives. Burial will be private. Memorial gifts may be made to the charity of choice.

Loving brother of Zeva E. Williams. Granduate of The Hillel School, attended Ramaz Yeshiva and graduate of SUNY Binghamton. Marc was a devoted Zionist and veteran of the Israeli Army. We will miss him.

title: Harried Shoppers Turned to Gift Certificates
description: During this past Christmas shopping season, a miracle did occur. Retailers offered something at full price, and customers bought it in droves. It was gift certificates, and they sold in record numbers, retailers and those who follow them said yesterday.

title: Chancellor to Sell Stock
description: The Chancellor Broadcasting Company and one of its units plan to raise $200 million by selling two kinds of preferred stock to investors in separate, private offerings. Chancellor will sell $100 million of a new class of convertible preferred stock, while its Chancellor Radio Broadcasting Company unit will sell $100 million of a new class of exchangeable preferred stock. Chancellor and its unit will use proceeds from the sales to complete the previously announced acquisitions of 12 radio stations from closely held Colfax Communications Inc. and eight radio stations from OmniAmerica Group. Chancellor shares rose $1.4375, to $25.3125. Chancellor said it had agreed to sell or swap some of the stations it is acquiring. The Chancellor unit plans to use the proceeds from those transactions to pay down its credit-agreement borrowings.

title: Film Furor Gratifies Long-Ago Tutor of Dalai Lama
description: China's efforts to derail two films being made about the Dalai Lama may have guaranteed their success even before they are released, suggests the author of a celebrated book on which one of them is based. Heinrich Harrer, whose ''Seven Years in Tibet'' has sold millions of copies in many languages since 1953, says China's interference with the Columbia Pictures film being directed by Jean-Jacques Annaud has stirred wide interest in the project.

Dr. Geddis attended Fordham Prep, Fordham University and graduated from Georgetown Medical School in 1933. Bronx resident for 87 years and practiced locally until 1990. Veteran of W.W. II. Former Director of Medicine at Misericrodia and Westchester Square Hospitals and President of the Medical Board at Westchester Square. Former Professor at New York Medical College. Member of the American Medical Society and New York State and Bronx County Medical Societies. title: MORTON'S TO SELL 19 ATLANTA-BASED RESTAURANTS
description: Morton's Restaurant Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Atlanta-based Mick's and Peasant restaurants, resulting in a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $9 million to $12 million. The restaurant group, the parent company of Morton's Chicago Style steakhouses and Bertolini's Authentic Trattorias, said it had signed an agreement to sell its 19 Mick's and Peasant restaurants to the MRI Acquisition Corporation and the PRI Acquisition Corporation for $6.8 million. MRI will have an 80.1 percent stake in Mick's Restaurants and PRI will have an 80.1 percent stake in the Peasant Restaurants. Morton's will retain a 19.9 percent interest in the restaurants.

Three of the victims were identified as Pushpinder Virk, 36, and her two sons, Nick Virk, 9, and Shawn Virk, 7. A teen-age girl, believed to be the woman's daughter, was also killed, said Capt. Ray McCann of the Willingboro Police.

They are right about that, but wrong in concluding that there is a flaw in computer dealing. It is, we now know, the ''normal'' deals that are abnormal.

title: If Patriots Should Lose, Jets May Hit the Phone
description: From their sideline perch, the Jets could have a wider array of coaching choices after this weekend's playoff games. But if New England wins, the waiting will most likely continue.

title: Variety Not as a Spice, but the Entree
description: The drummer Joe Chambers spent his first set at Birdland on Thursday night quietly going after change. He switched the ends of his drumsticks to vary his sound. He spent a good part of the show playing just his ride cymbal, dictating the tempo with the sharp pinging of wood hitting metal. His patterns never quite settled in. And when a new part of a tune showed up, he moved his focus to another part of his kit, or brought bass drum, snare and floor toms together for the bouncing, rounded sound of sticks on skin.

description: How does Russia look to Europe at the present moment? Usually, the attention of Western observers is not focused on Russia's overall condition and the forces at work in the country but on the latest developments, like the elections to the Duma, the presidential contest, the firing of Aleksandr Lebed, Boris Yeltsin's heart surgery. title: INSIDE
description: Another Letter Bomb Found

title: Devils Rediscover Virtue of Defense
description: Save for a few nifty defensive plays and the rare odd-man rush, this was not a highlight reel-type game.

title: Best of the City's Schools Share Vision, Not Methods
description: At Public School 31 in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, 5-year-olds sit up straight with their hands folded on their desks while teachers with rubber-tipped pointers drill them in spelling and arithmetic.

title: Despite Prosperity, the Governing Party Fears the 'Knife Edge' : In Singapore, Still a Sense of Fragility
description: SINGAPORE  The transformation of Singapore from a congested tropical slum to a gleaming antiseptic metropolis in less than 40 years is well known  a small, but remarkable, part of what the World Bank has called East Asia's economic "miracle."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SCOTT STUART
description: GOLDBERG - Scott Stuart. Beloved son of Diane and Marvin, dear brother of Bruce. Services Sunday, 11 A.M., at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Henry L. Yeagley, 97, Theorist on Bird Flight
description: Henry Lincoln Yeagley, a physicist who developed a theory in 1942 to explain why birds could fly great distances and then return to the precise spot they had left, died on Dec. 26 in State College, Pa. He was 97 and lived in State College.

title: Chance of Hebron Deal Fades As Israelis and Arabs Dig In
description: The prospects of an agreement on an Israeli pullback in the West Bank city of Hebron, an agreement that officials repeatedly described as imminent over the past two weeks, seemed to grow dimmer today as Palestinians and Israelis drew firm lines over the future of their political process.

title: Retirement Denied
description: Turkey's weight lifting champion, NAIM SULEYMANOGLU -- known as Pocket Hercules because he is 4 feet 11 inches tall -- denied yesterday that he had retired. But Suleymanoglu, a three-time Olympic gold medalist, said he was seriously considering leaving the sport.

title: Messier Remark Upsets Referee
description: Don Van Massenhoven, a National Hockey League referee, was formerly a police officer in Ontario. Bryan Lewis, the league's director of officiating, said Van Massenhoven was deeply concerned about Mark Messier's charge that the referee displayed a ''vendetta'' against the Rangers during Thursday night's 4-3 victory over the Islanders at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZMAN, WILLIAM
description: HOLZMAN - Judge William. Beloved husband of Kate. Dear brother of Morton Holzman. Services Sunday, 10 A.M. at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: WINSTAR ACQUIRES RIVAL MILLIWAVE
description: Winstar Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of its closely held rival Milliwave L.P. for $115 million in cash and stock, giving Winstar access to a broad swath of the radio spectrum nationwide. Milliwave's largest asset is radio-spectrum licenses, which will increase the transmission capacity of Winstar in 36 of its markets and add more than 50 new major markets to its operating territories. Winstar is paying $40 million in cash and almost 3.6 million shares. Since the deal was announced last July, Winstar's stock price has fallen, bringing the value of the stock portion of the price to $75 million.

title: Serbia Rejects European Call To Honor Vote
description: The Government of President Slobodan Milosevic today rejected calls by an international organization to reinstate opposition victories in Serbia's key cities.

title: Gerald Williamson, 95, St. Louis Engineer
description: Gerald V. Williamson, a St. Louis civic leader and mechanical engineer who joined the battle against air pollution early on, died of heart failure last Saturday at a nursing home in St. Louis. He was 95.

title: From Restaurateur to Intimate at the White House
description: Shortly after the 1992 election, President-elect Bill Clinton was jogging through the streets of Little Rock when an old friend, Charles Yah Lin Trie, happened to drive past the moving entourage of Secret Service agents and television camera crews. Mr. Trie, according to several acquaintances who heard him recount the story, leaped from his car to salute Mr. Clinton, and was rewarded when the President-elect trotted over to shake his hand.

title: WET SEAL STOCK DROPS AFTER DISAPPOINTING SALES
description: The stock of Wet Seal Inc. tumbled more than 18 percent yesterday after an investment firm said Wet Seal's same-store sales for November and December were below analysts' expectations. Wet Seal is a clothier for teen-agers. The investment firm Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company said sales at Wet Seal stores open at least a year increased less than the predicted 6 percent. The firm downgraded Wet Seal's stock to long-term buy from buy. Ladenburg, Thalmann also said that the company's fourth-quarter-earnings estimate of 45 cents a share ''may be at risk'' if Wet Seal does not post significant same-store gains in January. In Nasdaq trading, Wet Seal fell $3.375, to $14.75.

title: Packers-49ers: A Rematch With Attitude
description: We have seen this playoff matchup before.

title: A Shy Scholar Coaxes Dartmouth to Embrace the Creative Loners
description: James O. Freedman, the president of Dartmouth College, was at home, browsing in his private library, which he considers the most comfortable place on earth.

title: EQUITABLE CONSIDERS SALE OF REAL ESTATE UNIT
description: The Equitable Companies said yesterday that as part of its plan to continue to reduce its real estate portfolio, it is exploring alternatives for its Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc. unit. Equitable said it had discussed a possible sale of the unit but had made no agreement. Equitable Real Estate said its goal was to enter a ''strategic alliance'' to enhance its position, expand its line of products and services and widen its global reach. Equitable Real Estate manages pension fund assets invested in real estate.

title: House G.O.P. Is Said to Be United On Keeping Gingrich as Speaker
description: The chairman of the Republican Party asserted today that ''virtually every'' House Republican would vote to keep Newt Gingrich as Speaker on Tuesday, while House Democrats conceded privately that they probably could not prevent Mr. Gingrich's re-election and would prepare, instead, for the next battle -- over how severe his punishment will be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MONA (NEE CHRISTIE)
description: CLARK, Mona (nee Christie). 24 March 1921-28 December 1996. Mona will be remembered with love, fondness and admiration by all who knew her. Devoted mother of her sons Christie and Russell. She was a Peace Crops volunteer in 1970-1972, which is just one example of a source of warmth and pride for us.

title: When Beckett Decided He'd Fix the Record
description: With very few exceptions, conversations with Samuel Beckett were strictly private and not for publication, but in 1989, the last year of the playwright's life, James Knowlson interviewed him weekly over a five-month period. At the time, Beckett was in a nursing home in Paris. The interviews were for ''Damned to Fame: The Life of Samuel Beckett,'' the recent authorized biography of the Nobel Prize-winning writer.

title: Times Square's Neon May Shine, but the Play's Still the Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''The girls are anxious to return to work. I'll bet the customers are, too.''

description: NEW YORK

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: HILLS STORES STOCK DOWN AS RESULTS FALL SHORT
description: Shares of the Hills Stores Company dropped 17 percent yesterday after the discount retailer posted disappointing sales and lower profit margins for December. Though total sales and sales at stores open more than a year rose in the four weeks ended Dec. 28, by 3.6 percent and 4 percent, respectively, the latest month included 24 shopping days before Christmas compared with 22 shopping days in December 1995. For the four weeks that ended on Dec. 23, same-store sales fell 7.7 percent, the company said. Hills Stores described the latest monthly data as disappointing. On the New York Stock Exchange, Hills Stores' stock fell $1, to $4.875.

title: Suspect in Three Sexual Assaults Arrested
description: The police arrested a parolee yesterday in connection with three sexual assaults that occurred last year in the Inwood section of Manhattan.

title: One Who Got Away
description: To the Editor:
