description: To the Editor:

title: Oklahoma Bomb Defense Accuses U.S. of Misconduct
description: Defense lawyers in the Oklahoma City bombing case today accused the prosecution of misconduct in its handling of a witness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBI, SUSAN G.
description: JACOBI - Susan G. On January 1, 1997, in New York City. Beloved and cherished daughter of Margaret Jacobi Fidanque. Wonderful stepdaughter of the late Benjamin D. Fidanque. Adored sister of Harold, Wendy and Margaret Lynne. Loving aunt of Kerry and Meg Jacobi and Crystil and Patrick Laney. Dearest stepsister of David and Ann Fidanque. Susan died of complications following an heroic effort to overcome melanoma of the liver. Susan was a wonderful inspiration to family, friends and to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Dr. P. Alberto Paclucci Research Fund, c/o Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 100th St. and 5th Ave, NYC, NY 10029. Memorial service Sunday January 5, 1997 at 2 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, NYC, 212-288-3500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELLMAN, EDWIN
description: PELLMAN - Edwin, on January 2, 1997. Former Assistant Principal of Ettinger J.H.S. 13 and Wagner J.H.S. 167. Beloved husband of Miriam. Memorial services on Sunday at 4 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the New York City Ballet, School of American Ballet or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Rankings All Agree: The Gators Are No. 1
description: By not long after sunrise on the morning after, an imperfect method of determining a college football champion had systematically cleared every obstacle the University of Florida had faced to produce the most memorable triumph the Gators have known.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIA, FEDERICO
description: DAVIA - Federico. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Federico Davia, a beloed artist and friend. He will be sorely missed by his many friends in the company and we extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: The Trap of Ethnic Identity
description: Given the right temptations, nations and peoples are capable of almost anything. Historians tell us that black Africans willingly sold slaves to the West and that free blacks throughout early America bought and owned them. Imagine a different history still, with Africans as the primary slavers and Europeans as the slaves. The trade would have been just as brutal, given the ferocity of African warrior kings in previous centuries and the episodes of genocide the continent suffers today.

title: 4 Partners in Airbus Industrie Reach Accord on Revamping It
description: Ending months of squabbling, the four partners in Airbus Industrie reached an accord today about how to restructure the airplane manufacturer to make it more competitive, but Airbus said it would not release details of the agreement for several days.

title: Country For Sale
description: We know that a hundred thousand bucks get you a night in the Lincoln Bedroom, but what did the really serious loot from conglomerates like Indonesia's Lippo Group and Thailand's Charoen Pokaphand Group buy from the Clinton Administration? The answers await; much of Washington's political press is still unpacking from its off-the-record New Year's schmooze with the President at Renaissance Weekend.

title: Pure Destiny For Spurrier And Gators
description: A TRIUMPHANT Steve Spurrier met the news media yesterday morning, less than 12 hours after celebrating a 52-20 Sugar Bowl victory over Florida State. But Friday had a Sunday morning feel to it. No gloating or glowering. This son of a Presbyterian minister thanked pollsters and credited a higher power. ''God has smiled on the Gators,'' he said. ''Destiny, that's why we're here. We're a team of destiny, that's all you can say.''

title: Officials Release Names of Sex Offenders
description: Under a new law intended to inform communities of potential dangers from sex offenders, New York law enforcement officials yesterday released the names and addresses of 17 men living around the state who have been classified as posing a ''high risk'' of committing more crimes. Police agencies around the state are developing plans for how they would make the information public. In New York City, for example, officials said the list can be viewed beginning Monday by anyone who has identification and fills out a form.

title: Police Get List of Freed Sex Offenders
description: Under a new law intended to inform communities of potential dangers from sex offenders, New York law enforcement officials yesterday released the names and addresses of 17 men living in neighborhoods across the state who had been classified as posing a ''high risk'' of committing more crimes.

title: CUMMINS ENGINE BUYS BACK 1.3 MILLION SHARES FROM FORD
description: The Cummins Engine Company said yesterday that it had bought back 1.3 million of its common shares from the Ford Motor Company and would repurchase 1.7 million more shares on the open market. The company also said that Kenneth R. Dabrowski, a vice president at Ford, had resigned from Cummins Engine's board, as planned under a 1990 investment agreement with the auto maker. Cummins, a maker of diesel engines, said it would issue 3.75 million shares of its common stock to an employee benefits trust. The stock would be used to finance employee retirement savings programs. In New York Stock Exchange trading, Cummins Engine rose $1.25, to $46. After the purchase from Ford, Cummins has about 38.2 million shares outstanding.

title: Goals for Superintendents
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said he would use recent state reports on New York City's schools to develop goals for district superintendents. Page 28.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: A Brand-New Calendar's Rhythms
description: This is the week of the calendar. People are hanging their favorite illustrated calendars for 1997 on the wall and scribbling all those crucial phone numbers in their pocket calendars, along with birthdays, anniversaries and urgent deadlines that cannot be trusted to memory. The entries transform blank pages into the milestones of a job, a family, a life.

title: Fidelity Investments Fund Manager Resigns
description: Fidelity Investments is starting 1997 the same way it ended 1996 -- by losing another one of its star fund managers.

title: Apple Expects A Big Loss For Quarter
description: Apple Computer Inc. said late today that it expected to report a loss of $100 million to $150 million for its most recent quarter, a much sharper loss than analysts had expected.

title: Eighth Letter Bomb Is Found in U.S., and F.B.I. Takes Inquiry to Egypt
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation began inquiries in Egypt today as an eighth letter bomb, bearing an Alexandria, Egypt, postmark like the earlier ones, was discovered at a Federal mail center outside Leavenworth, Kan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSIEN, LOIS ING
description: TSIEN - Lois Ing. Peacefully, on January 1, 1997. Adored wife for 51 years of Kia Dwei Tsien, cherished mother of Dawn Tsien & beloved sister of Anna May Ing Chang. Possessed of an uncommon degree of strength, courage and talent. Memorial service, 4 P.M. Sunday, January 5, 1997, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 at Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Clearing the Way for an AIDS Vaccine
description: After a Government-appointed panel criticized its foundering AIDS vaccine effort, the National Institutes of Health last month called a brilliant microbiologist and Nobel laureate, Dr. David Baltimore, to the rescue. A newcomer to vaccine research, he will become part-time chairman of yet another committee of outside advisers. This is unlikely to overcome the handicaps of the N.I.H. in promptly developing a vaccine.

title: Company Briefs
description: SHERIDAN HEALTHCARE CORP., Hollywood, Fla., said it would sell 11 office-based physician practices in Florida, resulting in a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $17 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Hartford Panel Votes For School Choice
description: A high-profile state advisory panel voted narrowly today to recommend that every school system in Connecticut be required to accept students from other districts as part of a statewide program of interdistrict public school choice.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Gay Rights, Prejudice And Politics in Mexico
description: Since Pedro Preciado came out as a homosexual 18 years ago, he says, the police here have arrested him a dozen times, often punching and kicking him before hauling him off to jail and imposing a fine for violating ''public morals and good customs.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, IRENE
description: MORSE - Irene. On January 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Earl. Loving mother of Albert, Jonathan and Stephen. Dear sister of Dorothy and David. Adoring grandmother of Stacy and Benjamin. Service was January 3, 1997 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Dow Up 101.60, But Ends Week Little Changed
description: Stock prices staged a broad, sharp rally yesterday, a rebound that left market averages little changed at the end of a volatile holiday-shortened week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONEBRIDGE, EDNA A.
description: STONEBRIDGE, Edna A. January 3, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late Henry and Elizabeth A. (nee Scanlon). Loving friend of Walter and Mary T. Bishop and their children Mary, Walter and Bridget. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch and Son Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside, L.I. Funeral mass St. Sebastian's R.C. Church, on Monday, 10:30 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visitation on Sunday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M.

title: Supreme Court to Decide on No-Knock Drug Searches by Police
description: Less than two years after ruling that the police are generally required to knock and announce their presence before entering a home to conduct a search, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether to create a blanket exception to that rule when the object of the search is evidence of illegal drug dealing.

title: Judge Limits Police Stops Of Taxicabs
description: In a move that could limit the Police Department's three-year-old push to reduce crimes against cab drivers, a Federal judge has thrown out crucial evidence against a passenger arrested after officers pulled over a livery cab in the Bronx for what they called a random safety check.

title: Metrocards Sent Late, Irritating Elderly Users
description: Peg Myerson loves her Metrocard. Her half-fare card has meant a lot less standing in line at subway token booths -- a serious concern for someone with multiple sclerosis. So when her old card expired on Dec. 31 and a new card did not arrive in the mail, she had a problem.

title: At One With Canterbury's Elements
description: AMONG the tally of natural features in Canterbury is one whose mention is delicately avoided by tourist brochures, though it says much about this region on the eastern side of New Zealand's South Island. At the very least, it explains why the inhabitants appear to squint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNUNU, JOHN SALEH
description: SUNUNU - John Saleh. On January 1, 1997. At his home in Gulstream, FL. Born in Boston, MA. March 21, 1909 and a longtime resident of Forest Hills, NY until his retirement of Florida in 1979. He was an entrepreneur and was President of Peerless Export Co. of New York City. He loved to travela dn was fluent in half a dozen languages. He is remembered by all his family as a loving father, grandfather and great grandfather, and by his friends as on honest, kind, generous and decent man. Beloved husband of Victoria and father of Governor John H. Sununu of New Hampshire, Dr. Alexandra Sununu of NYC and Charles Sununu of Gulfstream, FL. He was also grandfather of Congressmanelect John E. Sununu of Bedford, NH and Catherine, Elizabeth, Christina, Michael, James, Christopher and Peter Sununu and Nicole, John, Jimmy, and Tommy O'Shea. He was also great grandfather of John and Catherine Grace Sununu. He was a Knight of the Order of St. Ignatius of Antioch, and a devoted and active member of the Orthodox Church. Services at St. Mary's Antiochian Orthodox Church, 1317 Florida Mango Road, West Palm Beach, FL 33406, Saturday, January 4, 1997. Memorial gifts may be made to St. Mary's Church.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Slashed
description: An off-duty New York City corrections officer was slashed in the face during a robbery attempt in Brooklyn early yesterday, but managed to shoot and arrest his attacker, the police said.

title: How to Recognize the Call of a Vanishing Breed of Bonds
description: IF you have been holding on to some old municipal bonds, it's time to check the dates on them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENDAR, BERTRAM E. JR.
description: GEMDAR - Bertram E. Jr. 83, of Manhattan. Died of cancer Saturday, January 4, at St. Luke's-Rossevelt Hospital in Manhattan. Born in Brooklyn, a son of Bertram and Irma Gendar. He graduated from Williams College and Brooklyn Law School. He served in the U.S. Coast Guard during World War II and in the Coast Guard Reserve after the war. He retired from reserve service with the rank of Captain. He was a lawyer for Gulf Oil Company in the overseas tanker division before opening his own law practice in Manhattan. He married Jacqueline Burns, the light of his life, August 25, 1962. His daughter, Alison of Yonkers, survives. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Dollars for Scholars of Taconic Hills, PO Box 304, Hillsdale, NY 12529.

title: Obscure Maine Lost-Goods Law Turns Finders Into Weepers
description: Biking over a bridge here last August, Lisa Knobel spotted a gold necklace on the ground and unexpectedly ignited a controversy over Maine's law concerning lost valuables.

title: Clinton and G.O.P. Are Unlikely To seek Medicare Premium Rise
description: Administration officials say President Clinton has made a significant decision about budget strategy for 1997: he will not propose any increase in costs for Medicare beneficiaries, but will try to cut back payments to hospitals, doctors and others who provide health care to the elderly.

title: About the 'Reading Performance' Ratings
description: The ''reading performance'' scale in the final column of these listings is a statistical measure devised by The New York Times to give parents an extra tool in measuring the effectiveness of schools. It takes traditional measures of success -- scores on tests given across the state -- and adjusts them to put a spotlight on the differences that schools are making in the lives of students.

title: One Solid Vote for a Nuclear Power Comeback
description: BRUCE D. KENYON is president and chief executive officer of the Northeast Nuclear Energy Company, which puts him in charge of all Northeast Utilities nuclear activities. He was brought in from the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company last year to help get the company's four Connecticut nuclear plants back in operation. In the early 1980's, Northeast was considered one of the top nuclear plant operators in the country. But because of safety and operating issues at the plants, the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission has taken the unusual step of not only placing them on a ''Problem Plant'' list, but also ordering that the plants not be restarted until the commission can be assured they will operate safely.

title: Crime
description: Piece of cake. That's what Michael Connelly makes it look like in his terrific new police procedural, TRUNK MUSIC (Little, Brown, $23.95), when a Los Angeles loser named Tony Aliso pops up dead in the trunk of his car. Aliso was a nonplayer (''probably the last guy in Hollywood who hadn't traded in his Rolls on a Range Rover'') who laundered dirty money through his soft-core movie company, and his execution-style murder has all the earmarks of a mob hit. Case closed. Finito. Yawn.

title: Rich, 82, and Starting Over
description: WHEN John Kluge was a sophomore at Columbia University in 1935, he flirted with the idea of moving to China to start a competitor to the British East India Company. A scholarship student, Mr. Kluge was earning extra money by working as a private secretary for a classmate, the son of the President of China, Lin Sen.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MUSIC, IN A FOREIGN LANGUAGE

title: Irsay Relatives Agree
description: ROBERT IRSAY's wife will collect his $25,000 monthly salary from the Indianapolis Colts and his son will get to see his medical reports as a result of the latest court appearance by the bickering relatives. NANCY IRSAY and JIM IRSAY both left Hamilton Superior Court on Friday in Indianapolis claiming victory in their battle over the ailing team owner's estate and medical condition. The two sides reached agreements on the salary and medical report issues before the hearing. Nancy Irsay, the owner's second wife, will also submit an expense report to First Chicago NBD Bank, which is the legal guardian of Robert Irsay's estate.

title: Rushing To, and From, The Rule of Law
description: Call it the last minute rush to judgment.

title: Hopping (Table And Party)
description: HIGH-PROFILE New Year's Eve parties given by New Yorkers on holiday seemed to keep guests firmly planted in one place -- whether aboard the billionaire Ted Fields's yacht in the waters around St. Bart's or at the oil magnate David H. Koch's annual gala in Aspen, Colo., where 600 people played until dawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SALLY (NEE NAROFF)
description: LEWIS - Sally (nee Naroff), on December 29, in her 84th year. Devoted wife of the late Samuel L. Lewis; adoring mother of Joan Lewis, Madeleine and Jack Kem, Gayle and Mitchell Levison; and loving friend of Shula Fever. Very special grandma to Lowell and Jill Kern, Russell Kern, Danielle (Levison) and Andy Perry,a dn the late Nicole Levison. Proud great grandmother of Jacob Spencer Kem. A woman of great strength and conviction, she guided us with her wisdom, uncanny intuition, and wonderful sense of humor. She was dearly devoted to us as we were and always will be to her.

title: On a Mission From God
description: THE DISCOVERY OF HEAVEN

title: Barbara Ferdon, Bradley J. Falduto
description: Barbara Ferdon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Ferdon of Alpine, N.J., was married on Tuesday to Bradley Joseph Falduto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Falduto of Kenosha, Wis. Judge Eddie C. Sturgeon of the Municipal Court of El Cajon, Calif., officiated at the San Diego Princess Resort.

title: New Year's Resolutions For Co-ops
description: STILL writing ''1996'' on your checks and correspondence?

title: Crown Heights Case Heads Back to Court
description: It has been more than five years since violence rocked Crown Heights, Brooklyn. And a jury had earlier acquitted a black man accused of stabbing a Hasidic scholar to death in the outbreak. Now that suspect and another man go on trial tomorrow on charges of violating the scholar's civil rights. Up to 250 prospective jurors will arrive in Federal court to fill out questionnaires meant to elicit their attitudes toward Hasidic Jews and black people. Lawyers have already started sparring over jury selection.

title: The Boor War
description: I never appreciated the importance of urban cranks until I met a woman named Miriam Seigel one afternoon on West 23d Street. She was struggling with a heavy grocery cart, and when I gave her a hand she introduced herself. It turned out she was the grandmother of David Remnick of The New Yorker. As she began extolling his writing talents, she was distracted by a couple of teen-age girls who were loudly exchanging obscenities. One of them threw an empty bottle on the ground. She seemed to be in a dangerously unhappy state of mind, but Mrs. Seigel promptly intervened.

title: Time Warner Official Breaks With the Mayor
description: In the old days, they had a relationship born of politics and mutual self-interest that grew into something resembling friendship. There were small dinners at Gracie Mansion, and one-on-one lunches in the Mayor's private dining room at City Hall. Richard D. Parsons, the schmoozy president of Time Warner, had, after all, known Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for more than two decades, from their days as ambitious young Washington lawyers -- Mr. Giuliani worked at the Justice Department, Mr. Parsons at Gerald Ford's White House -- through their years at the same New York law firm.

title: Just 26, but Thinking Far, Far Ahead About Money
description: AT an age when many people don't set their financial sights much higher than a new car, Greg Smith has paid off his college loans, bought a house and acquired a large nest egg. He even employs a staff of three at his home.

title: Looking Back on the Oracle as Everyman
description: HOWEVER RELIABLE A television reporter's words, it always helps to watch his gestures. On this week's episode of ''Cronkite Remembers,'' an eight-part series in which Walter Cronkite reminisces about his career -- from newspaper copy boy to a CBS anchor as solid as Mount Rushmore -- he attacks what he calls ''political censorship'' during the Persian Gulf war, when the Pentagon refused to let reporters near the action. ''Democratic people -- that's us,'' he says, pointing to himself, who are ''entitled to know what our troops are doing under our orders and in our name, were denied the facts.''

title: Students Teaching Others Reading
description: Your look at Long Beach School District's team effort approach to reading highlihghts the benefits of pairing strong readers with weaker ones. This past summer I was fortunate to be part of a cross-grades approach at Long Beach High School that matched older and younger students on a variety of learning units. Ironically, best results were achieved with the weaker older students who benefited from the mental and emotional support they could show others.

title: Action Hero
description: A few years ago, I stopped at a neighborhood market for some late-night ice cream. As I got out of my car, a young man hailed me from across the street. He was college-aged and dressed to the nines: expensive pullover, dress shirt and slacks so sharply creased they could have cut frozen fish. I thought he wanted directions; he had that urgent late-for-a-party look. When he reached me, he pulled up his sweater and smoothly drew a pistol from inside his waistband. ''Get in the car,'' he ordered.

title: New Zealand on Two Wheels
description: FOR a middle-aged bicyclist, New Zealand may be the most rewarding place on earth. I spent much of four weeks there this past autumn indulging my bicycle jones, both independently on the North Island and on an organized tour in the south.

title: Love Among the Cubicles
description: Maybe the guy who refills the vending machines is putting something in the coffee, but the office seems to spark one romance after another. It can be a lovely thing to see. What is it like at your office? Are people falling head over heels? And is anyone anybody getting any real work done? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, CHARLES
description: WEINSTEIN - Charles. Dearest husband of Sadie. Loving father of Sandra and Donald Miller, Martin and Ginger Weinstein. Adored grandfather of Jody, Mark, Robin, Nancy and Todd. Beloved by all who knew him. Service noon, today, at the Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Children With Something Up Their Sleeves
description: Look, Mom, no gloves. The children have solved the problem of continually losing their gloves, with a sweeping new fad: oversize jackets with yardlong sleeves that more than cover the hands and that dispense with the drudgery of pulling on gloves. The look was seen on thousands of youngsters visiting New York City during the holidays. Some of them aren't even using the sleeves: after zipping up the jacket, they wiggle their arms out of the sleeves, which are left trailing, turning the jacket into an alien-looking cocoon.

title: Defense Spray Law Leads to Lessons in Use
description: On a recent morning, 52 elderly residents gathered at the Doles Center on South Sixth Avenue here to learn about pepper spray. It was the first session conducted by the Westchester County Office for the Aging in response to a New York State law, which went into effect on Nov. 1, legalizing the possession of personal defense sprays and their use for self-defense.

title: Lecture Series at Lehigh Inspires (Movable) Poster Art
description: Marvin Simmons knows when his posters are good: when they're stolen from all over the Lehigh University campus in Bethlehem, Penn.

title: Gym Dandy
description: FRIDAY NIGHT: THE MUSIC DRIVES; HEADS BOB with the beat. The ponytailed blonde (highlighted) delicately lifts stray tendrils off her sweaty cheeks. She does not mop her brow; it might destroy her makeup. This is Spinning class at the Reebok Sports Club on Columbus Avenue. Spinning is the trademarked name for a routine performed on stationary bikes to the rhythm of pop music and the voice of a deejay-instructor. It is tough. One sweats a lot. After class, the blonde works a water bottle over and around her smearproof lips while chatting with a fellow (male) spinner. He is probably not aware that she is wearing foundation, eye liner, lipstick and mascara; there is nary a telltale puddle or smudge to betray her artifice.

title: They Sing, They Dance Once Again
description: EVERY FEW YEARS, HOLLYWOOD LOOKS longingly back to the glory days of the movie musical -- which reached its commercial zenith in the mid-60's with ''Mary Poppins'' and ''The Sound of Music'' -- and wonders how to reinvent the form for a less innocent age. Disney, with blockbuster hits like ''Aladdin'' and ''The Lion King,'' has triumphantly resurrected the animated song-and-dance fantasia. But where are today's live-action movie musicals, the sequels to Busby Berkeley extravaganzas and Technicolor MGM confections like ''Singin' in the Rain'' and ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers''? Five years ago, Disney's singing-dancing ''Newsies'' did a resounding belly flop. And two years later, after preview audiences turned thumbs down on James L. Brooks's ''I'll Do Anything,'' which had an original rock score, Nick Nolte and Albert Brooks found themselves stripped of their tunes and toe shoes in what became the musical that wasn't.

title: Public Schools: Choice or Chance?
description: LONNEE HAMILTON'S son, Max, is only 4 and won't start kindergarten until the fall of 1998, but Ms. Hamilton, a writer who lives in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, already feels as if she has fallen behind. Some other mothers have begun schmoozing with principals, checking out seminars and hiring private consultants to help them select the perfect public school for their 4-year-old. ''I know there are great public schools in New York City,'' Ms. Hamilton said recently. And she echoed the bewilderment experienced by scores of parents of soon-to-be kindergartners: ''I have no idea how you're supposed to find them.''

title: Where the Appetizers Are Superstars
description: BUTTER-yellow sponge-painted walls, expansive picture windows, discreet art, bouquets of roses on the bar, dramatic lighting created by sleek wall sconces, spotlights and tiny, brilliant-blue hanging lights. Sound like the Island's newest Tuscan trendsetter? No. Its name is Hunan Taste. For a dozen years, this Greenvale mainstay looked like any other Chinese restaurant with curved and peaked roof, bright colors and stone foo dogs flanking the door. Last summer it was transformed into a spare, modern beauty. Only the foo dogs are left to hint at its ancestry.

The cartoon chronicles Brain's ensuing artistic temper tantrum, in which he crticizes the commercial's script and chews out the people who run the studio. That's it. No big jokes, chases or mayhem.

title: All Eyes On Airborne Daredevils
description: AIR shows are one of the top three attended events in North America, surpassed only by major league baseball and auto racing. Eric Tulin, based in Hartford, an East Coast air show promoter, attributes this to the love of flight that goes back at least as far as the myth of Icarus and the celebration of technology that is a bit more recent. One need only look at the wonder on the faces of the crowd to realize the fascination air shows exert.

title: Stop the Gingrich Express
description: For several days it has been clear that the House Republicans should either delay the Speaker's election set for Tuesday or choose an interim Speaker to serve until the ethics case against Newt Gingrich is settled. But the Republican leadership and excessively obedient Republican members are insisting on holding the vote before the House hears the ethics committee's reports on the details of Mr. Gingrich's admitted wrongdoing and his recommended punishment. Let's be plain that the Gingrich faction is urging an act of breathtaking irresponsibility -- a vote-in-ignorance for one of the nation's highest offices. If delay does not become an option by Tuesday, there is only one honorable course for Republicans with spine, and that is to stop Mr. Gingrich's re-election by voting against him or abstaining. With careful maneuvering, a small G.O.P. coalition of conscience could force the leadership to suspend the process rather than risk handing the Speakership to the other party.

title: Awakening to Sleep
description: SLEPT BADLY AGAIN last night. Perhaps you did, too. I was in a strange city and in a strange bed filled with the overabundant warmth of a hotel room. At home, I often come awake for an hour or two in the early morning, 3:30, 4. A thread of thought -- the merest particle of wakefulness -- presents itself, and soon the bedside light is on and I'm reading again or lying in the dark, thinking. I often put off going to bed, as I did last night, for no good reason. Like a kid with an 8:30 bedtime in the eternal twilight of summer, I can't quite bear to quit consciousness. The itch of waking won't subside. This is an old and by now not particularly troublesome habit, though its effects are sometimes tedious and grow more pronounced the older I get. Like almost everyone, I borrow more from sleep than I can ever hope to repay, and I can feel the debt being exacted whenever my attention dissipates. There are days when I wonder what it feels like to be fully awake.

title: State Government Gone Sour
description: A new session of New York's State Legislature kicks off this week. By any logic, 1997 should yield an improvement over last year's dismal performance, when the lawmakers set an all-time national record for an overdue state budget. But perpetually late budgets are merely a symptom of far greater problems with New York's state government. Despite its unusual triumph last month in making long-overdue reforms to the New York City school system, the Legislature is for all practical purposes a dysfunctional institution.

description: NO one will travel from Montauk to visit the tiny, modest Mixing Bowl Eatery at 2601 Merrick Road in Bellmore (826-7971), nor should they. Yet this 28-seat storefront that looks like hundreds of other Island spots offers rewards to those who live nearby or find themselves in the neighborhood. Rewards like fast, alert service, fresh food and affordable prices.

title: New York City Firefighter Killed While Jogging Near His L.I. Home
description: James Halversen, a New York City firefighter, drove away from his Long Island home at 9:30 P.M. on Friday, his golden retriever by his side, and headed for a high school track where he often jogged in the evening. Three hours later, his wife, Rosalie, eight months pregnant with twins, found her husband lying unconscious on the track at Centereach High School. He had been shot several times in the legs and chest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEVAI, BELA B.

When asked his profession he jokingly called himself ''just a golfer.'' Bill Nevai was loved and cherished by all for his wide interests and great knowledge. His wit and good humor brought fun into many lives. Bill Nevai's wife and business partner of 60 years, Clara, will miss him most. He is survived by his sons, Andras and Peter De, grandson, Nandor, sister lionka Sole and all the members of their families. He will be remembered forever.

We found his enthusiasm ominous, suspecting that he had in mind a kind of meta-narrative featuring two viewpoints on a four-decade-old marriage as it followed a declining arc toward self-destruction.

The animal's behavior, quite unprovoked, was bizarre enough that rabies was strongly suspected and she began treatment a few hours later.

title: Moscow on the Thames
description: In his first collection of short stories, Zinovy Zinik guides us through the hall of mirrors of his own emigre experience. A Russian writer who left the former Soviet Union in 1975 and now lives in London, Mr. Zinik has written six novels, but only one of them, ''The Mushroom Picker,'' has been translated into English. Abetted by a bitingly ironic voice and an openly autobiographical terrain, ONE-WAY TICKET (New Directions, $19.95) has the freshness of a first impression. Mr. Zinik's wry narrator, who appears in all eight stories, is, not surprisingly, a Russian emigre living in London, a man caught in a crossfire of conflicting emotions about his past and present worlds. By turns caustic and uneasily nostalgic about his homeland, he is nonetheless wounded when he returns on two visits and finds his friends and family bitter and divided. England, however, is no more welcoming: Mr. Zinik memorably portrays literary London as a sort of Mad Hatter's tea party, floating on Pimm's Cup and sexual intrigue. In this purgatory, the narrator feels threatened by more recent emigres who beseech him for help and force him to face the hard fact of his own displacement. Mr. Zinik unflinchingly shows this man's cravenness, but he also illuminates lovely and delicate moments of communion, as when the narrator, waiting in a Vienna bus stop with a Lebanese Jewish immigrant, suddenly finds himself reading the man a newspaper article about Lebanon. Throughout these stories (which have been translated by Frank Williams, Jamey Gambrell, Alan Meyers, Bernard Meares and Priscilla Meyer), Mr. Zinik excels at depicting such shifts in himself and others, calibrating the subtle distinctions between generosity and fear, pride and pity. If at times he tells too much, spelling out emotion rather than trusting his imagery, nonetheless his insights into the pains of statelessness are poetic and powerful. Laura Winters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, CHARLES JAMES
description: HARRINGTON - Charles James, a former Vice President of DuPont, died suddenly on January 1st at Bethesda Hospital in Boynton Beach, Florida. He was 85 years old. Mr. Harrington was born in DuPont, Washington and has been a resident of Greenville, Delaware for 82 years. He graduated from Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Connecticut, Princeton University - class of 1933, and received his PhD in chemical engineering at MIT in 1937. He joined the DuPont Company in 1937 and retired in February 1976. During World War II he worked in Hanford, Washington on the Manhattan Project, which produced the atomic bomb. He was the DuPont representative in London from 1947 to 1952 and the following two years was a negotiator for the company in Japan. He was general manager of DuPont's Elastimer Chemicals division from 1964 to 1967. In 1972 he became Vice President. He served on the Wilmington Trust Board of Directors. He was the chairman of the executive committee of the Medical Center of Delaware and subsequently chairman of the Board of Trustees. He was a recognized philanthropist in the Wilmington community. Mr. Harrington was active in state and national Republican politics, a member of the Heritage Foundation, and on the national council of the World Wildlife Fund. He was a member of the Wilmington Club, the Wilmington Country Club, Greenville Country Club and the Vic Mead Club. In Florida he was a member of the Gulfstream Golf Club and the Gulf-stream Bath and Tennis Club. Mr. Harrington was married to Mary Gertrude Sproat in 1941. She died in 1979. In 1983 he married Elinore Hoelzel Hoopes. In addition to his wife, he is survived by two brothers, Willis and George, four stepchildren and seven step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church Christiana in Greenville, Delaware at 11 AM, Tuesday January 7th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent ot the World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24th St SE, Washington, DC 20031-1175 or the Washington Humane Society, 7319 Georgia Ave. NW, Washington, DC 20002.

title: Jungle Gem
description: Byron Haskin's film NAKED JUNGLE (1954) scores on two levels. It's a compelling love story about a South American plantation martinet (Charlton Heston) and his mail-order bride (Eleanor Parker). And it's a jolting special-effects thriller as an army of ravaging killer ants looms in the background. Mr. Heston and the beautiful Ms. Parker are excellent as two strong personalities in conflict and the color photography is stunning. The direction expertly projects the approaching menace. There's not a false or dull moment in this handsome, tingling, eye-filler. Grab it! -- SATURDAY at 3 P.M. on TNT. -- Howard Thompson

And suddenly, everyone has an explanation for what has gone wrong. We're in a trough between trends, goes one refrain; grunge, gangsta rap and alternative rock have all been played out, and their successors haven't surfaced yet from their undergrounds. When the next big thing arrives -- a new dance music permutation? trip-hop with tunes? unsentimental country-rock? reworked 1970's soul? -- the music business may pull through, or so it hopes.

title: What Only Words, Not a Film, Can Portray
description: THERE APPEARS TO BE NO RECORD OF Henry James's ever having seen a movie. He died in London in 1916, at the age of 73, almost a dozen years before the introduction of sound. The highbrow term ''film'' was decades in the future; what people went to was the picture show. And if Charlie Chaplin was deemed an artist by the discerning few, James was assuredly not among them. No one distinguished more stringently between High and Low than this illustrious literary master, the sovereign author of sublimely compelling tales and architecturally resplendent novels.

title: Airline Food

I've brown-bagged meals on airlines for years and have gotten frowns and glassy stares. All I ever need on a trans-Atlantic flight is milk and hot water because I bring a single portion of cereal in a disposable bowl, my own coffee bag and a homemade blueberry muffin.

Dependent on its waters for much of their fish and rice, they have repeatedly been victimized by its floods, which have wiped out hundreds of thousands of people over the centuries. So it is not surprising that, in this century, China's leaders should dream of harnessing the river, taming its floods and turning its raw power into electricity. And now, near the small town of Sandouping at the mouth of the Three Gorges of the Yangtze, their dreams are slowly taking shape.

title: Earth Works
description: In most art books pictures are peripheral; the art seems to snub or humiliate them. The photographs taken by the British artist Andy Goldsworthy of the ephemeral objects he constructs are part of the art: the perfect moment when light, shade and shape reveal what he imagined from the start. His latest volume, WOOD (Abrams, $49.50), is a sequel to his ''Stone.'' The several years of work recorded here are intimately related to a ballet, ''Vegetal,'' which Mr. Goldsworthy created for a French dance company, and the book's sections follow the order of the ballet's scenes. The stone cairns he builds around tree trunks are familiar in many countries by now, as are the conical ''houses'' made of broken tree branches in which he balances impossible pinnacles of round stones each atop another unsupported. Here the most vivid work, done on four continents, is in sand, clay, leaves and ice: clay packed into haunting presences emerging from trees, red sand carved into womb shapes, sand swirled into serpentine forms among Egyptian statues in museums, a leafy hazel branch wrapped with poppy petals, hickory leaves snailed into a stone hole, stalks of horse chestnut leaves dancing below a wall of fern fronds, a giant hollow snowball sheltering under an oak, a handmade ice ribbon curling around a tree to catch one moment of blazing late winter light. Mr. Goldsworthy's remarks are mostly journal entries laconically recording his relentless labor, day and night, spent in shaping wonders that cannot endure. His eloquence is reserved for the splendidly reproduced photographs of creations that immediately convince one -- at the most basic, sensual level of knowing -- that the beauty of the world lies in the fragility of Earth itself, in its impermanence and in the swiftness of its self-transformations. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: A Town That Needs Pity
description: When asked to define what ails their hometown, residents of Lefors, Tex. -- a dusty Panhandle burg of 652 people -- tend to cite the flat local economy and the flatter landscape. Whatever the cause, serious worries about Lefors's future last year prompted Norman Baxter, the local school superintendent (pictured below), to propose a public-land giveaway. The prize: 14 small city-owned lots, winners to be chosen from a national lottery. Conditions: To claim their land, victors would simply have to live on it. Outcome: Discouraging. Since the November drawing, only five of the winners have accepted ... tentatively. Can Lefors really be that bad? We sent a native Texan to find out.

title: Where Your Pet Can Be Groomed or Become a Bride

But after rescuing a cat from an air-conditioner in 1975, the cat's owner (an opera singer) arranged to have Doris Day call telephone her.

title: Half-Pregnant in Hebron
description: This is a moment of real import in Arab-Israeli diplomacy. The talks between Israelis and Palestinians are poised for either a decision that will have a huge impact on their relations or disintegration that will have a huge impact on the region. But instead it is turning into a mini-version of the final negotiations, with the stability of the whole region and the Israeli political alignment in the balance.

title: What Price Will Women Pay for Success?
description: As the warm-ups began, and the women from the University of Connecticut jogged onto the basketball court, Kara Wolters had to take a peek. A sellout in the Civic Center -- 16,294.

title: Harry Helmsley Is Dead at 87; Amassed Billions in Property

Helmsley, New York's preeminent real estate investor, broker and deal maker whose reputation late in life was clouded by tax evasion charges in a case that led to a four-year prison term for his wife, Leona, died Saturday at Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 87 and lived mainly in Scottsdale and in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Cowboys Are Quick To Spread The Blame

There was Deion Sanders, woozy from his head being slammed into the turf, not high-stepping but being taken off the field on a cart. There was quarterback Troy Aikman, the poster boy for post-season precision passing, tossing three interceptions. And there was Michael Irvin, standing on the sideline in the second half in a gold suit instead of his blue-and-white uniform, his arm in a sling from what may be a fractured collarbone.

Painted hurriedly in May and June of 1937, the huge canvas denounced the Nazi bombing of a little Basque town at the height of the Spanish Civil War. Yet, like Goya's ''Disasters of War'' etchings of more than a century earlier, ''Guernica'' has come to symbolize the atrocities of all wars in which military might is turned against civilians.

title: Fixes for Social Security
description: A 13-member Federal advisory panel split three ways yesterday over plans to bolster the finances of the Social Security system. But the important lesson from the panel's report is that Social Security is not in the profound crisis suggested by some critics. Sensible reform can get it most of the way through the next 75 years, the normal planning period. The three-way split developed over other issues -- whether and how to invest in stocks, protecting subsidies of low-wage workers, shrinking the Government's guarantee of retirement incomes and shoring up the economy's savings rate.

title: Corrections

title: Silly Anchors and Other Movie Myths
description: Does a real-life Citizen Kane exist today, some media baron using the press to enhance his personal power? That is one of the few provocative questions in ''Hollywood and the News,'' a glib AMC special that asks how accurately movies have depicted journalists. Tom Brokaw nominates Rupert Murdoch. Barbara Walters mentions Mr. Murdoch too, but doesn't think he has Kane's insatiable desire to control the news. And Bernard Shaw says that if Ted Turner, his boss at CNN, ever tried to influence a story, ''I would run him over getting out of the office.'' Don't you wish these three had been put in a room together and really encouraged to go at that question?

title: Insecure Nuclear Materials
description: It does not take much highly enriched uranium to fabricate a small nuclear weapon. Using a relatively simple bomb design, less than 15 pounds of such enriched uranium can produce a weapon with the explosive power of 1,000 tons of TNT. Almost that much weapons-grade uranium now sits lightly guarded in Georgia, one of the newly independent states produced by the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. Russia, which promised last September to take possession of the material and secure it, ought to do so without further delay.

title: PLACER AGREES TO HIGHLANDS'S PORGERA MINE PROPOSAL

On Sunday, Highlands, which is listed on the Australian Stock Exchange, proposed the sale of its Porgera stake to Placer as an alternative to Placer's bid of 75 cents (Australian), or 60 cents (United States), a share for the company. Placer now holds about a 46 percent stake in Highlands Gold. Placer Dome said the agreement to buy the Porgera stake was conditional on Highlands's securing an acceptable underwriting agreement by Jan. 10 to raise at least $126 million for the new company.

With notable exceptions, including the admirable quarterback, Troy Aikman, the Dallas players blamed the press's preoccupation with the Cowboys' off-field behavior for Sunday's 26-17 loss to the Carolina Panthers. Renault's market share fell in 1996 to 10.1 percent from 10.3 percent in 1995, mainly because of a drop in its share of the French car market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, EDWARD
description: GINSBERG - Edward. The officers and staff at National United Jewish Appeal mounr the passing of Edward Ginsberg, UJA General Chairman from 1968 to 1971, and UJA President from 1971 to 1974. Following the Six-Day War, Mr. Ginsberg, led a UJA leadership team to Israel to survey the war's impact on immigrant absorption and report back to the American Jewish community. The resulting campaign exceeded all other UJA fund-raising efforts including those of the post-World War II and Nazi Holocaust years. His dedication to Israel an the Jewish people included serving as Trustee of United Israel Appeal, Chairman of the Join Distribution Committee, and Vice President of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society. A Life Trustee of the Jewish Community Federation of Cleveland, Mr. Ginsberg was also the recipient of the Charles Eisenman Award, the Federation's highest honor. His leadership and dedication will be greatly missed. To his wife, Rosalie; his children, William and Robert; daughters-in-law, Inger and Jan; grandchildren, Tracy and Amy; his sister, Mildred Sindell, and the entire family, we extend our deepest condolences.

title: A Sri Lankan Priest Is Excommunicated For His 'Relativism'
description: The Roman Catholic Church rarely talks these days of heresy, a verdict that carries eerie echoes of the Inquisition and ends in automatic excommunication, the harshest penalty in canon law. And so theologians took note when the Vatican's doctrinal authorities found a 72-year-old Sri Lankan priest and scholar guilty of having ''deviated from the integrity of the truth of the Catholic faith,'' and formally cast him out of the communion of the church last week.

title: ENRON ACQUIRES ZOND, A MAJOR WIND-POWER COMPANY
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the Zond Corporation, one of the largest developers of wind-powered electricity generation, and formed a business unit to focus on developing renewable energy projects. Terms were not disclosed. Zond, which is based in Tehachapi, Calif., will become a subsidiary of the Enron Renewable Energy Corporation, which was formed to develop projects for Enron, which is based in Houston. Zond is expected to break ground this year on the largest single wind-power project to date, to supply power to the Northern States Power Company.

title: HARBINGER ACQUIRING SUPPLYTECH FOR $49.2 MILLION
description: The Harbinger Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Supplytech Inc. for about $49.2 million in stock and added that it would take a first-quarter charge of $7.5 million to $10 million as a result. Harbinger, based in Atlanta, said it would issue 1.6 million new shares of common stock to acquire Supplytech, of Ann Arbor, Mich., bringing its total number of shares outstanding to 13.5 million. Both companies provide electronic data interchange software and services used to exchange information in business-to-business communications. Harbinger shares rose $3.125 yesterday, to $30.75.

title: Earth Is Target for Space Rocks At Higher Rate Than Thought
description: ASTRONOMERS who scan the sky for big rocks on a collision course with Earth are getting new support for their pet nightmares from once-secret military data. The readings show that the planet is continually struck by speeding boulders that explode in blasts the size of atomic detonations, and that the rate of bombardment is higher than previously observed.

title: Harper Is Back, but He's Not at Home
description: On the surface, it's another member of the old guard still carrying around emotional scars because he was no longer wanted. But as Derek Harper returns to Madison Square Garden for a game against the Knicks tonight, he does so with considerable respect from his former team.

title: Where There's a Will, There's a Disk
description: IF you have never contemplated the consequences of your demise, the new year is as good a time as any. One good place to start is Willmaker 6 (Nolo Press, about $30), a program that has been around for more than a decade on floppy disks and that has now added a CD-ROM. I tried the Windows version, but a Macintosh edition is also available. A throwback to an era when bytes were precious, the program requires about three megabytes of hard disk space and no more than a basic machine with a simple printer.

title: Halfway House Pulls Offer

Mason had served 16 years of his 57-year sentence for the 1980 murder of a fellow gang member when the state parole board approved his release because officials of an Atlantic City halfway house had promised to take him in. The decision outraged local politicians, and last week, the halfway house, Joseph House, said it would back off.

title: DOUBLETREE RAISES BID FOR RENAISSANCE BY MORE THAN 5%
description: The Doubletree Corporation said yesterday that it had increased the amount of stock it planned to pay for Renaissance Hotel Group, raising the acquisition price more than 5 percent, to $890 million in cash, stock and assumed debt. Doubletree, of Phoenix, would pay 0.4342 share of its common stock and $8 in cash for each Renaissance share. The transaction values Renaissance shares at $26.67 each, based on a Doubletree stock price of $43. Last week, Doubletree agreed to pay 0.4105 share plus $8 in cash for each Renaissance share in a deal that valued Renaissance shares at $25.30 each, based on a Doubletree stock price of $42.15. The purchase price also includes the assumption of $70 million of Renaissance debt. Shares of Renaissance, which is based in Hong Kong and owns hotels under the Renaissance, Ramada and New World names, rose $1.875 yesterday, to $24.375. Shares of Doubletree rose $1.25, to $44.25.

title: SILICON GRAPHICS SEES DISAPPOINTING RESULTS IN QUARTER
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said it expected to break even on operations for its quarter just ended because manufacturing problems had made it fail to meet demand for its newer computers. Wall Street had expected fiscal second-quarter earnings of 24 cents, excluding charges, based on the average estimate from IBES International Inc. Silicon Graphics, a maker of work stations and high-end desktop computers that is based in Mountain View, Calif., said the results did not include charges from its purchase of Cray Research Inc. in July, and that it expected fiscal second-quarter revenue of about $825 million. This was the second consecutive quarter for which the company attributed disappointing results to problems with a product transition it began in October. Shares of Silicon Graphics, which released its news after the close of trading, rose 25 cents yesterday, to $26.875.

title: WESTINGHOUSE PLANS TO MOVE OFFICES TO NEW YORK
description: When the Westinghouse Electric Corporation completes a spinoff of its industrial businesses and becomes a media company, it plans to move its headquarters to New York from Pittsburgh, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. Westinghouse said in November that it planned to focus on its radio and television operations, which include the CBS network and Infinity Broadcasting. Only a handful of jobs, including that of Michael H. Jordan, the chief executive of Westinghouse, who will hold the same title at the new media company, will be added at CBS headquarters, officials said. Westinghouse has cut employment at its Pittsburgh headquarters from 1,000 in the early 1970's to 450 today. Westinghouse did not respond to requests yesterday for comment.

His dream of building New York City's first empire from the unproven raw materials of the Internet and other new media was still intact, even if he conceded there was no shortage of people rooting for him to fail.

title: Airbus Says '96 Orders Were Triple Those of '95

Including orders that were not yet firm, it sold 498 jets in 1996, giving it 42 percent of the global jet market. In 1995, Airbus had orders for 106 planes worth $7 billion.

title: Personal Health

Before getting the flu, he was perfectly healthy with no known risk factors for lung infections -- a nonsmoker and occasional social drinker with a healthy heart, immune system and respiratory tract. Plus, he was only 58 years old, too young -- in theory -- to warrant taking the pneumonia vaccine, which protects people against 23 strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae, which are the most common causes of bacterial pneumonia.

title: VTEL TO BUY COMPRESSION LABS FOR $80 MILLION

Under the agreement, each Compression common share will be exchanged for 0.46 Vtel common share. That values Compression at $4.65 a share, based on Vtel's closing price Monday. Shares of Compression Labs closed yesterday up 12.5 cents at $4.37 a share on the Nasdaq Stock Exchange. Vtel stock was down 37.5 cents, to $9.50 a share, also on the Nasdaq. Vtel, of Austin, Tex., said it expected to issue about 8.4 million new common shares in the transaction.

title: Guns and the Violent
description: Should a man whose wife had accused him of abusing her be allowed to own guns, even though the charges were eventually dismissed? That was the question put before the State Supreme Court yesterday, The Associated Press reported. An appeals court had ruled that the rifle, shotgun and three handguns seized from a Clinton Township man after his arrest must be returned. But Jim Lankford, an assistant Hunterdon County prosecutor, asked for a reversal of that ruling in order to protect the man's wife from further violence. Gary Needleman, the man's lawyer, argued that there was no legal basis for depriving his client of properly registered guns. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Webtv Plans High Quality Video Via Modem
description: An upstart Silicon Valley company that delivers the Internet via television sets plans to announce on Wednesday that it has developed a new digital compression technology that will permit users to receive ''television-quality'' video over ordinary high-speed modems.

title: Manning May Be Playing Waiting Game on the Draft
description: Archie Manning and son Peyton finally got around to a business discussion about the Jets yesterday. ''I can tell you this,'' Archie Manning said from New Orleans. ''Peyton's completely straddling the fence.''

title: Ex-Secretary Sees Bureaucracy From the Other Side

description: The wintry weather that has battered much of the West for two weeks, causing some of the worst storm damage in decades and killing almost three dozen people, blew ominously eastward today into the nation's midsection.

description: Newt Gingrich narrowly won re-election as Speaker of the House today despite defections by nine Republicans troubled by his admission of ethics violations.

title: Court to Review Use of Rights Law in Sex Case
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Federal Government had properly used a Reconstruction-era civil rights law to prosecute and convict a Tennessee judge for sexually assaulting five women who worked for his court or had cases before him.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a telephone dictation error, an article yesterday about Representative Newt Gingrich's campaign to retain his post as Speaker misstated the Republican response to Representative Matt Salmon's suggestion that Mr. Gingrich step aside. Mr. Salmon was jeered, not cheered.

description: Retailers who had hoped that consumers would honor their Christmas wish for a solid 1996 holiday selling season will apparently have to settle for mixed results.

title: WORLD COLOR PRESS TO ACQUIRE RAND MCNALLY UNIT
description: World Color Press Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Rand McNally Book Services Group, a unit of Rand McNally & Company that produces hard-cover books for book clubs and various mail-order publishers. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. World Color, a commercial printer based in Greenwich, Conn., will acquire operations in Versailles, Ky. and Taunton, Mass., which employ about 1,700 people. The Book Services unit, one of the three largest domestic producers of hard-cover books, accounted for $150 million of Rand McNally's $500 million of annual revenue, a spokesman for Rand McNally said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

The company will finance the acquisition with an offering of eight million common shares.

title: AMERICAN PAD AND PAPER TO BUY SHADE-ALLIED
description: The American Pad and Paper Company said yesterday that it would buy Shade-Allied Inc. for $51.5 million, broadening its business to include paper used in inkjet printers and copying machines. American Pad and Paper said Shade-Allied had about $90 million in sales last year. Based in Green Bay, Wis., the company has plants in four states. Shade-Allied provides so-called machine papers, including specialized paper designed for use in copying machines and printers. Shares of American Pad and Paper rose $1.75 and closed at $24.75.

title: Trucker Sentenced in Rapes
description: A truck driver who kidnapped a waitress in Mahwah and raped her repeatedly as he drove across the country was sentenced yesterday by a Federal judge to 60 years in prison. The driver, David J. Ward, 39, of Golden Valley, Minn., had pleaded guilty in July to the December 1995 attack. He abducted the 24-year-old woman as she left work, kept her handcuffed and bound with tape in the sleeper cab of his truck, and raped her four times before she escaped in Indianapolis three days later.

title: Back, Yes, but Subdued
description: They gave Newt Gingrich the benefit of the doubt today. They gave him some time. But he neither looked nor sounded like the self-assured revolutionary of old, and few who watched him today believe that he would ever again wield the kind of power that he once did.

title: Dallas's Williams and Irvin Used Cocaine, Accuser Says
description: Erik Williams and Michael Irvin of the Dallas Cowboys both used cocaine on the night that a 23-year-old woman said she was sexually assaulted at Williams's home, the woman told the police in an affidavit made public yesterday.

title: Wine Talk
description: A QUARTER of a century ago, it was not unusual to see a young couple on their first visit to France at Allard, the famous old Left Bank bistro. Seeing that everyone else was drinking Sancerre with their oysters and coquille St.-Jacques, the tourists nervously ordered a half bottle.

title: In Columbia Pact, New York City Ties Pay to Hospital Productivity
description: In a new contract with the medical school that provides doctors at Harlem Hospital, New York City's public hospital agency has for the first time linked how much it pays to how well the doctors meet specific goals, from the number of patients they see to the number of child immunizations they do.

They crammed into her Government office, picked at hors d'oeuvres and watched televised images from the House of Representatives, looking for a spot of red -- her trademark color -- in the sea of gray and blue.

title: Suspect in Bias Case Caught
description: On June 9, the authorities say, a Jackson Township man walked into a 7-Eleven store in East Windsor and began yelling racial epithets at a two employees, one Korean and the other Indian. On Monday, the man, Christopher Boyvin, 32, was charged with bias harassment, the State Attorney General's office said yesterday. The crime is punishable by a maximum prison term of 18 months, said Chuck Davis, a spokesman for the Attorney General. Mr. Boyvin, who fled to London after the incident, was caught by United States Customs officials on Dec. 28 as he crossed the border from Canada, Mr. Davis said.

description: CARAPETYAN - Dr. Haig, died on December 15, 1996. He was born in Isphahan, Iran on November 16, 1904. He arrived in the USA in 1932. He received his medical degree in 1934 at the Univ. of Michigan, in Ann Arbor, MI and received his OB/GYN Degree in 1937 from Massachusetts Memorial Hospital in Boston, MA. He established an infertility Clinic at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. In 1988, he received a citation of merit for his distinguished service to St. Luke's Hospital. He was an honary member of the Metropolitan Opera Club and he belonged to the West Side Clinic Society. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, a brother, a son and four grandchildren.

title: New Chief, and Explanation
description: Capt. William Thynne, a 25-year veteran of the Jersey City Police Department, will be sworn in as chief on Thursday. He will replace Brian Anglin, who had planned to retire this spring but was asked to step down Jan. 1. No reason was given at the time, but Michael Moriarty, the city's Police Director, said yesterday that Mayor Bret Schundler, who is facing re-election in May, did not want the Police Chief to leave office in the middle of the election. Traditionally, police officers split into factions during mayoral campaigns, and Mr. Schundler hopes that a new chief will be better equipped to maintain order in the ranks, Mr. Moriarty said.

title: A Good Deed Doesn't Go Unpunished
description: MARTHA PINCKNEY wonders if she should have just slammed the door on Rosemarie McCummings last August, when the woman showed up at her Bronx apartment with five children in tow and nowhere to go. Of course not. Ms. McCummings, whose brother used to go out with Ms. Pinckney, had returned to New York from Virginia after she lost her job, her mother and her house.

title: 9 Uncomfortable Davids, and Goliath Still Alive
description: They are an odd assortment of Davids who nearly toppled the House Goliath today, with virtually nothing in common except, now, the possibility that they will be ostracized by their party.

Total billings were not disclosed, but American spending was estimated at more than $20 million.

description: What's a little peach juice between total strangers? In fact, it's the basis of a lawsuit filed against DAVID LETTERMAN by JANE BRONSTEIN, a professional bridge player from New York.

title: With These Brothers, 3 Is a Madding Crowd
description: It says something about this drab television season that many of its most inventive moments come from network promos for shows. For a while there was French Smith, Harry on ''Third Rock From the Sun'' (one of the year's bright spots), dancing expressively to the ''Flashdance'' theme: ''He's a maniac, maniac on TV.'' More recently, the relentlessly promoted new sitcom ''Chicago Sons,'' about three grown brothers living together in that city, offered a clever parody of ''Bonanza,'' with the theme rewritten to show a few crucial differences between these guys and the Cart wrights: ''They don't ride, they don't rope, they don't know Hop Sing.'' (''Hop Who?'' someone sings, ignorant of the Cartwrights' cook.) The series has its premiere tonight, and it turns out that the promos are infinitely funnier than anything on this flat, predictable show.

title: Albright Faces Senate Hearing Today on New Job
description: In her long career, which has mixed academia, politics and government to an unusual degree, Secretary of State-designate Madeleine K. Albright has shown a consistent interest in issues of press freedom and individual rights in authoritarian countries.

title: PANEL CRITICIZES PENTAGON INQUIRY ON GULF ILLNESSES
description: A special White House panel today sharply criticized the Pentagon's investigation into whether exposure to chemical weapons had hurt the health of Persian Gulf war veterans and said further study was needed since the inquiry's shortcomings had clouded the issue.

title: When Criminals Wear Blue
description: Residents of Harlem's 30th Precinct know what it is like to live with police who are scarcely better than the criminals they are supposed to chase. Following a scandal that broke two years ago, 33 of the precinct's officers, one-sixth of the force, were convicted of perjury, drug dealing and robbery. The sad consequences are now becoming clear. Because these convictions damaged police credibility and tainted police evidence, perhaps 2,000 prosecutions have been threatened and many have been dropped altogether.

title: Tax-Free Medical Savings

The accounts, known as medical savings accounts, are intended to encourage people to cut down on unnecessary doctor's visits. They provide tax breaks in return for a high deductible.

His many old students and colleagues on the faculty will particularly miss this fine personification of classical French education. The entire Lycee community shares his loss and expresses its sorrow to his widow, Dorothy Brodin, and his family. A service will be held on Saturday, January 11, at Saint Gregory the Great, 144 West 90 Street, New York at 11:00 AM.

The third-largest airline in the United States said it expected to save $62 million a year as a result of the revamped service. The Atlanta-based company will cut between 600 and 800 jobs. title: VIACOM TO TAKE $100 MILLION CHARGE
description: Viacom Inc. said it plans to take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $100 million to close 50 Blockbuster Music stores and relocate its Blockbuster Entertainment unit's headquarters. The company is closing the stores, which represent 10 percent of all Blockbuster Music retail stores, because of sluggish sales. Viacom had already announced it would be moving the Blockbuster headquarters to Dallas from Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Viacom's shares rose 62.5 cents to $34.625 on the American Stock Exchange. The company's fourth-quarter cash flow is expected to rise to about $554 million from $444 million in the year-earlier quarter, helped by such box-office successes as ''Star Trek: First Contact'' and growth of the MTV network, analysts said. The company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $4.5 million a year ago.

title: Risks of Many Kinds in Reworking Social Security
description: Social Security may not be getting a face lift this year, but the report from a Federal advisory panel released Monday insures that Washington, for the first time in more than a decade, will be forced to look long and hard at what ails the giant public pension system. A host of radically different proposals -- with radically varying effects on the economy, on the financial markets and on the incentives for Americans to save for retirement -- are now on the table.

title: Christopher and U.N. Chief Discuss Differing Agendas for Change
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher came to the United Nations today to congratulate the new Secretary General, Kofi Annan, telling him that the Clinton Administration was confident it could ''now begin again to renew a close relationship'' with the organization, a State Department spokesman said.

title: Hebron Negotiations Are Still Deadlocked
description: The stalemate between Israel and the Palestinians over deadlines for future Israeli withdrawals in the West Bank persisted today, despite continued efforts an by the American mediator to find a compromise.

title: Marlene D. Daniels, 55, Expert on Maritime Law
description: Marlene D. Daniels, a noted expert on maritime law and a partner in the New York law firm of Seward & Kissel, where she headed the maritime finance department, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 55.

title: Futures Trading Starts in a Dow Jones Index
description: When stock market derivatives were new, more than a decade ago, Dow Jones & Company wanted nothing to do with them. Fearing that ''the investing public may associate Dow Jones with the highly speculative futures market,'' it even went to court in 1982 to assure that no futures or options would be traded on a Dow Jones index.

description: To the Editor:

title: HARRIS AND GE POWER SYSTEMS FORM VENTURE
description: GE Power Systems and the Harris Corporation formed a venture to provide energy management systems and services to utilities and industrial customers. The companies said the venture, GE Harris Energy Systems, would design, manufacture and market computer control centers and other electronics intended to help utilities identify the most cost-effective method of dispatching power, track power quality and recommend actions to optimize operations. GE Power Systems, a unit of the General Electric Company, provides power generation equipment and has annual revenues of more than $7 billion. Harris, with yearly sales of more than $3.6 billion, is a communications and electronics company.

title: A Havoc of Meddling Fools Wrapped Up in One Man
description: In the final, infuriating moments of ''The Wild Duck,'' Gregers Werle -- Ibsen's stand-in for all the meddling, idealistic fools of the world -- surveys the havoc he has wreaked with no acknowledgment of his culpability. He's like a drunk in a fatal car crash who wipes out the occupants of the other vehicle while himself escaping with barely a scratch.

title: BREED TECHNOLOGIES TO BUY BTI INVESTMENTS
description: Breed Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire BTI Investments Inc., a holding company that owns Custom Trim Group. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Custom Trim, which had revenues of $108 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, supplies leather-wrapped steering wheels, shift knobs and other original equipment components. Breed said the acquisition expanded its integrated interior product line, presented an opportunity to consolidate manufacturing operations and reduced overall costs of shift knob and steering wheel leather-wrapping operations.

title: 4 Youths Held in Assault of Girl, 14, at Party
description: Four teen-age boys from Ridgewood have been accused of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl on Dec. 20, apparently after she became intoxicated during a house party, the authorities disclosed today.

title: Hashimoto's Visit Takes Up the Japan-China Balance : Tokyo Poses ASEAN Puzzle
description: SINGAPORE  As Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan began a tour of Southeast Asia on Tuesday, he brought with him a puzzle for the region: how to balance the interests of Japan with the growing influence of China for the benefit of other Asian countries.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARILYN HORNE, the mezzo-soprano, will assume a new role this summer. She has been named director of the voice program at the Music Academy of the West, a summer school for young pianists, singers and instrumentalists in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Math Lesson Plans Ready
description: Last spring, the State Board of Education approved a series of goals that it said would provide every student in New Jersey with a ''thorough and efficient'' education, as required by the State Constitution. Critics immediately attacked the standards as too vague. Now, officials are about to offer specific lesson plans to help teachers put the standards into practice. The first set, to be unveiled today at a Board of Education meeting, deals with math, the only subject that did not draw any controversy, Joan Vas, the president of the Association of Mathematics Teachers of New Jersey, said yesterday.

title: The Ebonic Plague
description: Like a fire raging out of control that was started by a single match, the once-arcane pursuit called ebonics has now become a topic about which every American has a loudly voiced opinion. But there's something bizarre about the burning ebonics debate: For all the smoke and noise, it isn't really a debate at all. Almost everyone has the same opinion.

title: Bid Is Raised By Newmont In Gold Battle
description: The battle between two of the top gold mining companies in North America continued yesterday as the Newmont Mining Corporation raised its offer for the Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corporation to $2.15 billion in an attempt to break up the merger agreement between Santa Fe and the Homestake Mining Company.

title: Clinton Chooses His Fifth White House Counsel
description: President Clinton today named Charles F. C. Ruff, a former Watergate special prosecutor, to be his fifth White House counsel, a job that has increasingly come to require deft handling of a host of ethics controversies and Congressional investigations.

title: New Vines Are Hurt By California Rains
description: The floods that left dozens of vineyards in the Napa and Sonoma Valleys under water last week washed away some newly planted vines, wine makers said. But they added that damage to older vines was slight, and that the timing of the storm had minimized the threat to this year's harvest.

title: Calls for Cuts in State Capitals
description: Saying that tax-cutting has helped reinvigorate the economies of both states, the governors of New York and Connecticut used their introductory addresses to their legislatures yesterday to urge the lawmakers to continue on that path to assure continued growth.

description: Acting on the conclusions of an outside investigator hired by the company, Texaco Inc. dismissed one senior executive yesterday, suspended another and cut off benefits to two retirees for engaging in improper conduct that was secretly recorded.

description: Some film classics are born. Others are made. ''The Big Sleep,'' Howard Hawks's classic mystery starring Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall, falls into the second category.

description: Florists' Transworld Delivery Inc., known as F.T.D., said this week that it would dismiss 14 percent to 35 percent of its staff and close two of its three United States branches in a bid to become more efficient.

description: Nearly 25 percent more ninth graders in New York City passed the state's college-prep math exam last June compared with the year before, but their achievement still lags behind the rest of the state.

title: Biggest Loss of the Night for Rangers Could Be Kovalev
description: The Rangers lost for only the fourth time in their last 21 games last night and their goaltender, Mike Richter, lost for the first time in 17 games. But there was much to fret about because the Rangers also lost Aleksei Kovalev to a knee injury, possibly for a long time.

description: President Boris N. Yeltsin, who underwent quintuple bypass surgery in November, was hospitalized this evening after his doctors detected early signs of pneumonia, the Kremlin announced.

description: Beginning a campaign to build Congressional support for his education proposals, President Clinton plans to announce on Thursday that the percentage of borrowers defaulting on their Federal student loans has dropped to 10.7 percent.

description: Crude oil jumped to a six-year high on fears of short supplies and news that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia had been taken to the hospital with signs of pneumonia.

title: Houses Before Gardens, The City Decides
description: IN its drive to build affordable homes in some of the city's poorest neighborhoods, the Giuliani administration has sounded the death knell for hundreds of community gardens that have, over the last 20 years, risen out of the rubble and rats of bankrupt, abandoned land.

title: Montreal Bank in Dublin
description: The Bank of Montreal said today that it would open a bank in Dublin to service North American companies that have set up offices in Ireland and across Europe. The bank, one of the 10 largest in North America, will also focus on companies in the International Financial Services Center in Dublin's docklands and European companies operating in the United States and Canada. The bank's decision strengthens Ireland's reputation as a premier site for North American companies locating in Europe.

title: Fines for Budget Delays

title: AMP IS CUTTING 1,000 JOBS IN A REVAMPING
description: AMP Inc. said yesterday that it would cut about 1,000 jobs, or 2.2 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring plan that includes closing and consolidating plants and streamlining product lines. AMP, the largest maker of electrical and electronic connectors, said Dec. 31 that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $195 million, primarily for restructuring moves. AMP's earnings in 1996 were weaker than expected and it attributed the change to slumping prices and sluggish sales in the personal-computer and communications markets. Shares of the company, which is based in Harrisburg, Pa., fell 62.5 cents to close at $39. AMP said it would phase out its Riverhead, L.I., plant and move some of its assets to its Greenville, S.C., plant.

title: School Choice Not Close
description: New Jersey's new school financing plan will eventually allow students to attend schools outside their home districts at no cost, but not anytime soon, the State Education Commissioner said yesterday.
