description: It's not Atlanta, and it's hardly Lillehammer. But a gathering of former Olympians, eight of whom are gold medalists, will be mingling with recreational skiers who show up at Stowe, Vt., this weekend.

title: A Muted Madeleine Albright
description: If Madeleine Albright is contemplating any significant shifts in American foreign policy during Bill Clinton's second term, she did a good job of disguising it yesterday. In a determinedly cautious appearance before a friendly Senate Foreign Relations Committee, President Clinton's nominee for Secretary of State stuck mostly to platitudes and familiar strategies, clearly eager to avoid any surprises that might endanger her likely confirmation by the Senate.

title: Pilots Reject American Air Labor Pact
description: In a move that took the company and Wall Street analysts by surprise, pilots at American Airlines voted down the tentative contract agreement yesterday that their union's leaders had reached with the company in September.

title: Canadian Police Widening James Case
description: After the recent conviction of Graham James, the Canadian junior hockey coach, on charges of sexually assaulting teen-age players, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said today that they are widening their investigation of James to include players living in the United States.

title: Companies Roll the Dice On Digital Videodisks
description: Makers of consumer electronics equipment and computers are betting that palm-sized digital videodisks, or DVD's, may ultimately transform both of their industries, replacing videocassette recorders and video game, CD-ROM and audio compact disk players.

title: G.M. to Regain American Market Share, Executives Say
description: General Motors executives said here today that they expected to reverse the long decline in the company's share of the American market while expanding G.M.'s highly profitable overseas operations.

title: Pension Economics
description: Today, millions of elderly Americans are nearly as well off in retirement as they were in their working years. But to live that well, they are absorbing, in Social Security and Medicare alone, an ever-growing portion of the nation's annual income. And one of the big questions raised by this week's Federal advisory report on Social Security is whether this trend should continue or whether more of that money should go to younger people.

title: Bluesy Tribute to a Master of Be-Bop
description: As an encore at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night, the saxophonist Jimmy Heath stood up and took a solo on a borrowed tenor saxophone. Mr. Heath is surreally calm. He opened with a few short phrases of perfectly rounded be-bop ideas. Then he carefully composed long lines of notes, strings of them, that seemed glued together and endless. When he finished, the audience gave him a standing ovation.

title: Marbury, 19, Plays in a Man's League as if He Were a Charter Member
description: Before a game last week in Boston, Stephon Marbury of the Minnesota Timberwolves was pacing the locker room. Was Marbury worried? Are you kidding? He just couldn't wait to play.

title: Nasdaq must wait a little longer for its new market-maker rules.
description: LONG-AWAITED new rules for the Nasdaq stock market were delayed by a week yesterday, largely because the Securities and Exchange Commission had not yet decided on some important details. Trading in 50 stocks under the new rules will now begin on Jan. 20.

title: Readers See Greater Need And Increase Their Giving
description: Saying they are unnerved by a bitter shift in the political winds against the poor or encouraged by an unexpected change in their own good fortunes, some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have increased their donations this year, accelerating the fund to its best pace since a record-setting appeal five years ago.

title: A Seething Start
description: Gov. George E. Pataki waved an olive branch in his third annual address to the Legislature today. But the legislators, particularly the Democrats, are in a testy mood these days, and many were openly hostile to the Governor's appeal. And that augurs a major battle over his agenda, as Mr. Pataki enters what by all accounts will be a politically pivotal year for him.

title: Corrections

Mr. Michel was a former Republican leader of the House, not a former Speaker.

title: Despite Pact, Buses Face Border Barrier
description: On Jan. 1, the North American Free Trade Agreement gave United States and Mexican bus lines the right to carry passengers across the border and throughout each other's lands.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article yesterday about the Secretary of State-designate, Madeleine K. Albright, included two erroneous references to her background. She was a member of the National Security Council in the Carter Administration, but it was Zbigniew Brzezinski, not Ms. Albright, who was President Carter's national security adviser. And Ms. Albright assisted in Mr. Brzezinski's memoirs, not Mr. Carter's.

title: A Vision of Simplicity Is New Grist for the Mill

title: CAPSTONE ANNOUNCES $22.6 MILLION IN NEW INVESTMENTS
description: The Capstone Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to invest $14.7 million in six existing health care operations and that it planned to invest $7.9 million in four health care operations under development. Capstone, a Birmingham, Ala., real estate investment trust, said the $14.7 million in new investments would include $10.3 million in mortgage financing for an assisted living operation in California and three skilled nursing clinics in California and Tennessee. The remaining $4.4 million is for the acquisition of an ambulatory surgery clinic in Missouri and a physician clinic in Florida. The $7.9 million in planned investments would include $2.7 million in mortgage financing for three assisted living operations and a $5.2 million equity investment in an assisted living business in Georgia.

title: Reminder on Governor's Speech: After 'All Rise,' All Will Sit
description: Wayne Jackson, the State Assembly's sergeant-at-arms, found a peculiar note on his desk when he arrived at his station in the Assembly Chamber this morning, a few hours before the Governor gave his annual address to the Legislature.

title: Corrections

title: SHIVA STOCK PLUNGES ON LOW EARNINGS EXPECTATIONS

Shiva, based in Bedford, Mass., said after the financial markets closed Tuesday that it expected to report net income of 5 cents to 7 cents a share for the quarter ended Dec. 31. Analysts had predicted 20 cents a share. Shiva, which provides equipment and software for computer networks, attributed the steep decline to the loss of a $5 million order from I.B.M. late in the quarter and to a reduction in inventories. In trading, shares of Shiva fell $15.625, closing at $19.25 on Nasdaq.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN 5 HOTELS

title: Correction
description: An article Dec. 27 described a reporter's efforts to find out how the magician David Copperfield performed his tricks in "Dreams and Nightmares," a Broadway show. The article included an interview with a man identifying himself as an audience "plant" who aided the magician. The man said he was disgruntled about being paid late for his work. He identified himself as Seth Greenspan, an employee of the show, but that identification was false. After the article was published in The New York Times, the show's producer visited The Times with the real Seth Greenspan, who produced full identification. A telephone number at which the impostor was initially reached has since been disconnected.

title: EUROPEAN AIRLINES TO BROADEN ALLIANCE WITH DELTA
description: Swissair A.G. said it and its European partners, Sabena S.A. and Austrian Airlines, had agreed to deepen their pact with Delta Air Lines Inc. with the intention of increasing their share of the trans-Atlantic market. Flight operations at Swissair and at Sabena, the Belgian national airline in which the Swiss company owns a 49.5 percent stake, have been in the red for years, while Austrian, of which Swissair owns 10 percent, is barely profitable. Swissair said the alliance would start offering a joint booking service and unified fares on Feb. 1. Revenue from the venture will be shared, Swissair said.

title: Lazy Justice

By a 7-to-2 vote the Court held that in sentencing a convicted defendant, Federal judges may take into account previous charges -- even though the defendant was acquitted of them -- to impose a sentence that exceeds the maximum allowed for the charges of which the defendant was found guilty.

However, he said that so far the N.F.L. was ''just listening,'' that no agreement on a rescue plan was near and that there was no assurance that anything would come of the talks.

title: NETSCAPE SHARES DROP AFTER ANALYST CUTS RATING
description: Shares of the Netscape Communications Corporation slid 19 percent after a Wall Street analyst cut his rating on the stock on the ground that the software maker's revenue growth might stall. Netscape shares fell $10.875, to close at $47.875, after William Gurley, an analyst with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, lowered his rating to ''accumulate'' from ''buy.'' Investors reacted to Mr. Gurley's move because Deutsche Morgan Grenfell underwrote Netscape's November sale of five million shares. Netscape's fourth-quarter earnings will exceed Wall Street forecasts only slightly, Mr. Gurley predicted. The company is forecast to earn 10 cents a share, based on the average estimate of 18 analysts polled by First Call. Netscape, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes software used to navigate the Internet and to send information within computer networks.

title: Controversial Gay Magazine Shuts Down

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIN, PIERRE EUGENE
description: BRODIN - Pierre Eugene, 87, on 1 January 1997 in New York, NY. Beloved husband of Dorothy Rothschild Brodin for 48 years. Father of Alain Brodin of Remalard, France. Dr. Brodin was an internationally known teacher, author, and literary critic who played a crucial role in Franco-American studies during and after World War II. He was born in Paris in 1909 and came to the United States on a Chapman Fellowship at Harvard University in 1932. He wa a professor and Director of Studies of the Lycee Francais of New York from its founding in 1935 until his retirement in 1976. Dr. Brodin was one of the founders of the Exole Libre des Houtes Etudes (The free French University of New York). He served there as a professor, Dean of its Faculty, and, finally, its President. The Ecole Libre was founded in 1941 to provide a place for European scholars to continue their work during World War II. After the war, it continued as a focus for interdisciplinary and intercultural studies. Dr. Brodin's published works include both fiction and non-fiction, most importantly volumes of literary criticism which focused on both French and American writers. He received significant honors from the French government, including the Legion of Honor, as well as the Order of Leopoid from the King of Belgium. Mme. Brodin will receive Dr. Brodin's friends and colleagues from 7:30 PM-9:00 PM on Friday, 10 January of Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at East 81st Street. The Funeral Mass will be in the Brodin family vault in Royan, France. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pierre E. Brodin Scholarship Fund, C/O Cusack & Stiles, 61 Broadway New York, New York 1006.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIN, PIERRE EUGENE
description: BRODIN - Pierre Eugene, 87, on 1 January 1997 in New York, NY. Beloved husband of Dorothy Rothschild Brodin for 48 years. Father of Alain Brodin of Remalard, France. Dr. Brodin was an internationally known teacher, author, and literary critic who played a crucial role in Franco-American studies during and after World War II. He was born in Paris in 1909 and came to the United States on a Chapman Fellowship at Harvard University in 1932. He was a professor and Director of Studies of the Lycee Francais of New York from its founding in 1935 until his retirement in 1976. Dr. Brodin was one of the founders of the Ecole Libre des Houtes Etudes (The Free French University of New York). He served there as a professor, Dean of its Faculty, and, finally, its President. The Ecole Libre was founded in 1941 to provide a place for European scholars to continue their work during World War II. After the war, it continued as a focus for interdisciplinary and intercultural studies. Dr. Brodin's published works include both fiction and non-fiction, most importantly volumes of literary criticism which focused on both French and American writers. He received significant honors from the French government, including the Legion of Honor, as well as the Order of Leopold from the King of Belgium. Mme. Brodin will receive Dr. Brodin's friends and colleagues from 7:30 PM-9:00 PM on Friday, 10 January at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at East 81st Street. The Funeral Mass will be held at the Church of Saint Gregory the Great, 144 West 90th Street, at 11:00 AM on Saturday, 11 January 1997. Burial will be in the Brodin family voult in Royan, France. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pierre E. Brodin Scholarship Fund, C/O Cusock & Stiles, 61 Broadway, New York, New York 10006.

title: FIRSTCITY AND HARBOR FINANCIAL IN $46 MILLION DEAL
description: The Firstcity Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Harbor Financial Group Inc. for about $46 million in stock. The move represents the latest step in the turnaround of Firstcity, whose predecessor, the First City Bancorporation, was closed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in 1992. Harbor owns the Harbor Financial Mortgage Corporation of Houston and Dallas-based New America Financial Inc., which together operate 37 mortgage offices nationwide. The companies originate and service residential and home improvement loans and commercial mortgages. The combined company will have $440 million in assets, $80 million in equity and 825 employees. Firstcity, based in Waco, Tex., will issue 1.6 million shares valued at $46.2 million at yesterday's closing price of $28.875 a share.

But neither Congress nor President Clinton seems inclined to try anything more creative than the isolation strategy that over nearly four decades has failed to budge Fidel Castro from his autocratic ways.

title: Bids for Hughes Electronics Rest on Future Stock Value
description: The two bids for the military businesses of the Hughes Electronics Corporation are likely to come to perhaps $10 billion, but will hinge less on their face value than tax considerations and estimates of the future value of the stock of the winning company, people close to the situation said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRANK SINATRA was admitted to the hospital yesterday suffering from what doctors said was a heart attack. He was undergoing treatment at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where Dr. Rex Kennamer said the prognosis was good.

description: The New York Times announced the appointment of Dennis L. Stern yesterday as vice president for human resources. He will be responsible for the paper's news as well as business departments, which formerly maintained mostly separate personnel functions.

title: Corrections

title: G.M. OF CANADA TO BUILD 240 ARMORED CARS
description: The Canadian Government said yesterday that it had awarded a contract for 240 armored cars, worth $552 million (Canadian), or $407 million (United States), to the diesel division of General Motors of Canada Ltd., a unit of the General Motors Corporation. Deliveries of the armored cars are to start in January 1998 and be completed in December 1999. The division is based in London, Ontario.

title: An Evening of Death: 3 Murderers Are Executed
description: With the prick of a needle, once, twice, three times, the state's executioners put to death three killers on a single wet, icy night in southern Arkansas.

title: Ice Bowl: The Sequel?
description: The forecast for Sunday's Packers-Panthers game is brutal: snow showers, a temperature of perhaps 5 degrees, winds of up to 30 miles an hour and a wind-chill factor of 30 below to 50 below. The last championship game played at Lambeau Field was the Dallas-Green Bay Ice Bowl game on Dec. 31, 1967. That game had a temperature of -13 degrees and a wind chill of 46 below. Green Bay survived, 21-17.

title: Corrections

description: Sue Williams

title: CLEAR CHANNEL TO BUY 2 MILWAUKEE RADIO STATIONS
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire two Milwaukee radio stations, WMIL-FM and WOKY-AM, from the Chancellor Broadcasting Company for $40 million. Clear Channel, which is based in San Antonio, already owns WKKV-FM in Milwaukee. When it completes this and other deals it is working on, Clear Channel will own or program 104 radio stations and 18 television stations in 33 markets in the United States. The deal with Chancellor, a radio broadcasting concern controlled by the investment group Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. of Dallas, is subject to the completion of Chancellor's purchase of two stations from Colfax Communications of Los Angeles.

title: Lack of Love and Hygiene Curdles Royal Romance
description: As a clever sidebar to the present-day adventures of Charles and Di and Fergie, ''A Royal Scandal,'' Sunday's ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation, is a gloriously wicked reminder that, as far as royal shenanigans are concerned, nothing's new. This story, all true and narrated wryly by Ian Richardson, also involves a Prince and Princess of Wales and a marriage that went wrong. Only this one took place 200 years ago and involved George, son of the unstable George III, and Princess Caroline of Brunswick (Braunschweig), Germany. She failed to heed her father's advice: ''The heart has nothing to do with royal marriages.''

title: A Fund-Raiser Faces Trouble
description: This should be a time of triumph for a political fund-raiser like Marvin Rosen, who as finance chairman for the Democratic National Committee over the last 16 months was responsible for designing the machine that raised $120 million and helped to insure President Clinton's re-election.

title: So What's For Sale? Dealers Optimistic

title: G.O.P. Fires Shot as Battle Over Budget Nears

description: Mudslides on Perkins Lane in Seattle were carrying houses and huge madrone trees down toward Puget Sound the other day. The woman I love once walked me through one of these houses, where she had lived when her children were babies. I can imagine her sadness if she were there, but it would not compare to the the heartbreak of thousands of citizens saying, ''We lost everything . . . .''

When a young Federal agent questions Potter's authority, that whippersnapper seems like a villain. How could he? We already love Potter because he's really Jim Rockford! James Garner plays Potter with the same engaging manner and sense of authority he brought to Rockford, but without the comic relief. He adds heft and likability to this modestly engaging thriller.

title: 'Big Sleep' Plus Naps
description: It's oddly reassuring to sink into the sleazy net of Howard Hawks's 1946 film noir classic ''The Big Sleep,'' and gradually lose track of the whys and wherefores in this endless daisy chain of Los Angeles mayhem. Isn't it the same with our daydreams of modern-day conspiracy theories? Eventually our fantasies of interlocking plots and cover-ups fog into a smoggy vision of an evil so pervasive and fiendishly convoluted that we end up throwing up our hands. Ah, we sigh, hasn't the world always been this corrupt and rotten? And mmm, isn't it delicious? Especially when peopled by tarnished sophisticates like Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall, whose charged encounters are one long teasing train of innuendo?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARWELL, BASIL B.
description: BARWELL - Basil B. 81, of Sun City, AZ, died on January 6, 1997 at his home at a heart attack. In 1960 he became Executive Vice President of Culbro Corporation in New York City, where he worked until 1990, completing 55 years of employment for the same company. He remained on the Board of Directors until his death. He retired in 1990 to Sun City, AZ where he created Presentations by Seniors, on 83-person, non-profit organization that fights prejudice and racism in the public schools. He is survived by his wife, Lucille Vogel Barwell; two daughters, Lynn Padwe of Larchmont, NY; Nina Barwell of Watertown, MA; and three grandchildren, Phil Padwe, Margo Padwe, both of Larchmont, and David Barwell-Werth of Watertown, MA. title: Tax Reform, 10 Years Later

title: Highway Plan Is Criticized
description: Since the 1930's, people in central New Jersey have talked about the need for a highway that would connect the New Jersey Turnpike and Route 1. But plans to build a $303 million toll road, to be called Route 92, have drawn criticism from the United States Environmental Protection Agency. The E.P.A. has advised the state that the case for a new 6.5-mile highway is not compelling enough to justify destroying 33 acres of wetlands, as the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has proposed. To build the road, turnpike officials must get the approval of the State Department of Environmental Protection, and the state agency said it will consider the Federal report before deciding whether to issue a permit. Lynn Fleeger, a spokeswoman for the turnpike authority, said the toll road is needed to relieve congestion on Route 1 and on local roads in Plainsboro and South Brunswick, where development is booming.

The move comes two days after more than 60 percent of the 9,300-member Allied Pilots Association rejected a contract proposal reached by American and union negotiators in September. Under binding arbitration, a third party -- an individual or a panel -- would resolve issues, like wage increases, on which the sides cannot agree. Union leaders could not be reached for comment yesterday. They had previously said they would not accept arbitration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIN, PIERRE EUGENE
description: BRODIN - Pierre Eugene, 87, on 1 January 1997 in New York, NY. Beloved husband of Dorothy Rothschild Brodin for 48 years. Father of Alain Brodin of Remalard, France. Dr. Brodin was an internationally known teacher, author, and literary critic who played a crucial role in Franco-American studies during and after World War II. He was born in Paris in 1909 and came to the United States on a chapman Fellowship at Harvard University in 1932. He was a professor and Director of Studies of the Lycee Francais of New York from its founding in 1935 until his retirement in 1976. Dr. Brodin was one of the founders of the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes (The Free French University of New York). He served there as a professor, Dean of its Faculty, and, finally, its President. The Ecole Libre was founded in 1941 to provide a place for European scholars to continue their work during World War II. After the war, it continued as a focus for interdisciplinary and intercultural studies. Dr. Brodin's published works include both fiction and non-fiction, most importantly volumes of literary criticsm which focused on both French and American writers. He received significant honors from the French government, including the Legion of Honor, as well as the Order of Leopold from the King of Belgium. Mme. Brodin will receive Dr. Brodin's friends and colleagues from 7:30 PM-9:00 PM on Friday, 10 January at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at East 81st Street. The Funeral Mass will be held at the Church of Saint Gregory the Great, 144 West 90th Street, at 11:00 AM. on Saturday, 11 January 1997. Burial will be in the Brodin family vault in Royan, France. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pierre E. Brodin Scholarship Fund, C/O Cusock & Stiles, 61 Broadway, New York, New York 10006.

title: Midori Balances on a Bartok Tightrope
description: When Bartok wrote for the solo piano he was writing for himself; the violin was an invitation to explore the musical soul of someone else, a someone else compounded, perhaps, of the peasant fiddlers he had heard on his folk song-collecting trips and of the young professional players, all female, with whom he had worked in his youth. That might account for certain features of his Second Violin Concerto that make it a loner among the tightly composed works of his last two decades: its improvisatory character, its fluctuating moods (including memories of the dangerous eroticism of ''The Miraculous Mandarin'') and its generous rhapsodic sprawl.

title: MCI BEGINS TO CUT WORK FORCE NATIONWIDE
description: The MCI Communications Corporation has begun cutting its work force nationwide as part of what it calls ''a minor realignment'' that will eliminate about 1,200 jobs, or less than 3 percent of its 52,000-employee payroll, within a couple of months. A spokesman said yesterday that the cuts would occur in the business markets division, which accounts for more than half of the company's $15 billion in annual revenue. MCI is under pressure from the AT&T Corporation and others in the corporate long-distance market, and its consumer business has not had a big hit since its Friends and Family consumer discount plan.

title: In a Dialectic of Virtuosos, Musical Opposites Attract
description: The group led by the trumpeter Dave Douglas at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday seemed odd at first: it brought together two esteemed members of ostensibly different jazz scenes, Mr. Douglas and saxophonist Chris Potter. Mr. Douglas is a force on the Knitting Factory axis, Mr. Potter a star on the mainstream jazz circuit. But musicians are usually open-minded, and such groupings are often products of packaging and circumstances. Besides, these two have been friends for years. Both can play just about anything, and the band they put together, including James Genus on bass and Ben Perowsky on drums, has extraordinary promise. Its success suggested that the raiding of two supposedly opposing teams should continue.

The $316 million (Australian), or $249.5 million (United States), sale of 25 percent of Porgera was contingent on Highlands' getting the support of investors for the sale of $160 million (Australian) worth of shares in the new company, Highlands Pacific. Investors, faced with little time in which to make up their minds and a declining gold price, did not agree to do so.

title: VITRO OF MEXICO IN DEAL TO SELL ANCHOR GLASS UNIT

The agreement supersedes a previous deal, announced in October, in which Anchor would have been sold to the Ball-Foster Glass Container Company for about $365 million. Anchor received the Consumers and Owens bid on Dec. 2, and said it would support their offer as a higher and better bid. Vitro said the agreement had been approved by the bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del. Anchor Glass filed for protection from its creditors in September. Owens-Brockway, of Toledo, Ohio, and Consumers Packaging, of Toronto, both manufacture glass bottles and jars. Vitro produces glassware, plastic containers, aluminum cans and household appliances.

Invacare made the offer in a letter to the medical-device maker on Jan. 2. Based on 12.8 million Healthdyne shares outstanding at the end of the third quarter, Invacare's offer is valued at about $160.4 million. Healthdyne shares soared yesterday on the news, closing up $3.6875, or 39.86 percent, at $12.9375. Invacare shares were unchanged at $28. title: A River Runs Through It
description: The Mississippi River is at once a mystical landmark soaked in historical and literary associations and an easily accessible but sprawling and multifaceted physical fact. In MISSISSIPPI CURRENTS: Journeys Through Time and a Valley (Morrow, $35), Andrew H. Malcolm, a former reporter for The New York Times who now works for the Governor of Montana, and Roger Straus 3d, a photographer and the chairman of High Tide Press, succeed to a remarkable degree in capturing both Mississippis, the matter-of-fact and the mythic. Most of Mr. Straus's photographs, even those of the grittier, workaday aspects of the river and its people, evoke the Mississippi's mystical aspects, while Mr. Malcolm's text, with a permanent tinge of cynicism, tends to focus on the reality of the river and the sillier, sadder side of being an American tourist attraction. Mr. Straus's shots of Minnesota's Lake Itasca, the source of the Mississippi, show a sunrise and an icebound winter scene; it is left to Mr. Malcolm to describe the T-shirt and postcard vendors and the coins tossed into the water by tourists. In Hannibal, Mo., Mark Twain's hometown, Mr. Straus offers two placid images -- one of the riverboat Mark Twain, the other of the dilapidated Hotel Mark Twain, without a human visible in either one. It is Mr. Malcolm who describes the tacky theme park that the town has become. Even Mr. Straus's photos of the interior of Federal Express's vast Memphis sorting facility speak to the reader's sense of geography and logistics, while Mr. Malcolm sarcastically puts things into modern perspective, noting that ''a parcel can get across town in Phoenix faster and cheaper by going through Memphis.'' Mr. Malcolm and Mr. Straus manage to capture much of the magic of the river without ignoring even the less attractive parts of the reality. Hal Goodman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERWOOD, PETER W.
description: SHERWOOD - Peter W., 76, a consulting chemical engineer, died on Friday, January 3, at his home in White Plains, NY. He died of a heart attack. Prior to retiring in 1995, he was head of Peter Sherwood Associates, a New York based chemcial and economic consulting firm. Mr. Sherwood was the author of several hundred publications on markets and technology of petrochemicals and has lectured extensively in these fields. He was an internationally recognized authority in these markets. He was an invited speaker at the United Nations conference on the development of petrochemical industries for the developing countries, held in Teheran, Iron in 1964. Before establishing Peter Sherwood Associates in 1963, he had more than twenty years oe xperience in management, technical and advisory positions with Kappers Co. and the Ethyl Corporation. Peter Sherwood obtained his engineering degrees from columbia University. He was a lifetime member of the Chemists' Club and on the Board of Trustees from 1978 to 1981. He was also a member of the American Chemical Society. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Teresa Sherwood, and his son, Douglas Peter Sherwood.

title: Threesome
description: THE DESERT WORLD (Marlboro/Northwestern University, $19.95) is a brief, impressionistic and intensely romantic novel by the French author Pierre Jean Jouve (1887-1976). Set primarily in Switzerland in the early decades of this century, it concerns a pastor's son named Jacques de Todi, a poet named Luc Pascal and a melancholy Russian woman, Baladine Nikolaievna. Jacques is torn between his longing for the absolute -- especially as it is manifested in nature -- and a particular attraction to young boys. Baladine is drawn out of her deep apathy only by her love for Jacques. And Luc, who starts off as Jacques's friend and protector, falls for Baladine. Depending on your perspective, the narrative is either startlingly modernist or naively primitive. As translated by Lydia Davis, it ignores conventions of plot and structure, wanders through multiple points of view and occasionally offers oddly constructed sentences. Though the novel begins with Jacques and meanders through Baladine's story, it ends with Luc (who may be a stand-in for the author) trying to make sense of it all. A contemporary author would psychologize this story to death -- these people all need a good shrink -- but Jouve leaves it mysterious, yielding a haunting story from a time when love affairs could still be tragic and people still believed in the redemptive power of art. David Guy

title: A Threat to the Adirondacks

Mrs. Whitney, the heir to one of America's great fortunes, is also the owner of one of America's largest unspoiled tracts of private wilderness, 51,000 acres of forests, streams and lakes in New York's Adirondack Park. She now proposes to subdivide 15,000 acres of that land into 40 lots averaging about 300 acres. Mrs. Whitney promises to take precautions to protect the environment, but common sense suggests that chopping 15,000 acres of contiguous wilderness into what her press release calls ''40 exclusive shoreline estates'' would be ecologically harmful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZEL, VERA
description: MAZEL - Vera. On January 4, peacefully of natural causes at her West Side studio of 48 years. She was a noted voice teacher for many singers on Broadway, at the Met and in the movies, including Yul Brynner, Shirley Yamiguichi and Jacques Kayal. Born on Christmas Day, 1906, in St. Peterburg, Vera fied Russia in 1918, settling with her uncle, Dr. Michael Klatchko, and her brother, Dr. Emanuel Maisel, in Shanghai, China. She was an accomplished pianist and became a voice teacher after studying the physiology of the throat at a Shanghai medical college. Vera will be remembered by her students as a brilliant, strong-willed but loving friend who guided and inspired their careers and lives. Vera is survived by her cousins Masha, Doulgas and Michael Engmann of San Francisco. A reception honoring Vera will be held on January 22nd at 5 PM. Call 212-233-7243 for details. Donations in Vera's memory may be made to the Julliard School, Lincoln Center, New York City.

description: MOST co-op and condominium shareholders and board members have a basic understanding of the term ''conflict of interest.'' Most would agree, for example, that a board member who votes on a matter that will directly enrich himself or herself has a duty at least to disclose that fact to other members.

title: A Wonderful Place for A Murder
description: THE first time I visited Edinburgh, during a season that the natives laughably refer to as ''spring,'' I nearly perished from the cold and the damp and the icy drizzle that weeps incessantly down the stone walls and cobbled streets of that wind-swept city on the Firth of Forth. Without stopping to unpack the useless clothing I had brought, off I ran to Victoria Street to buy a cashmere turtleneck with a matching tam that came down to my eyebrows and over my ears. Ah, better. My second stop was an antiquarian bookshop on Princes Street, where I spent $10 on an original 1924 edition (eureka!) of ''The Fatal Countess and Other Studies'' by William Roughead.

title: Five Acres, and a Tax Break?
description: THE headquarters of BMW of North America sits on a bluff in this well-to-do suburb, flanked by apple and peach trees. Not only does the orchard offer a pleasant view to BMW workers choosing to eat lunch outdoors on warm days, it also provides a significant tax break for the company. The property tax bill for the 20-acre orchard is just $373.52.

title: Roger Goeb, 82, Who Composed For Orchestra and Taught Music
description: Roger Goeb, a composer whose works were admired for their deft coloration and inherent lyricism, died on Jan. 3 at the Parker Jewish Geriatric Institute in Queens. He was 82 and lived in Rockville Centre, L.I.

description: FOR financially stretched parents everywhere, it can signal great relief: a grandmother mentions that she wants to help pay for her grandchild's education.

title: A Season Short on Truly Memorable Turns
description: DOES NEW YORK CITY BALLET perform George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' in the fall-winter season? Does the sun rise in the morning? As dance enters the new year, it feels as if City Ballet's ''Nutcracker'' run, which ended just last Sunday, was the only certainty in an unusually sparse autumn for dancegoers in New York.

description: EXPECTATION surrounds the Long Island Power Authority as it meets tomorrow for the first time since Lilco and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company agreed on Dec. 29 to merge.

title: CHARITY BEGINS AT ... THE MARKETING MEETING, THE GALA EVENT, THE PRODUCT TIE-IN
description: Like Linda Evangelista, I, too, have been photographed nude in the struggle against breast cancer (''Charity Begins at . . . the Marketing Meeting, the Gala Event, the Product Tie-In,'' by Lisa Belkin, Dec. 22). My photo shoot did not include glamour lighting and a ''come hither'' makeup job, but rather the application of purple lines from a surgical pen and a 35-millimeter camera in a surgeon's office the day before my mastectomy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREIS, DEBORAH
description: KREIS - Deborah. On January 9, 1997, in Lake Worth, FL. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Robert and Leonard. Dear sister of Zeida Platt and Melvin Rafish. Loving grandmother of Donald, Ellen and Matthew. Service today, 11 AM, at Hellman Memorial Chapel, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, NY. Interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Never Too Young to Be Perfect
description: MANY Americans have been riveted by the televised images of JonBenet Ramsey, the kindergarten beauty queen who was murdered in her family's home in a wealthy neighborhood of Boulder, Colo., the day after Christmas. A 6-year-old, JonBenet was already a veteran of the children's pageant circuit, having won a half-dozen beauty crowns. Many of her photographs show her posed coquettishly in showgirl costume and lipstick, her hair a highlighted blonde.

description: EIGHT and one-half million dollars. That is the projected savings that hospitals in the Westchester area expect to achieve this year by joining forces and becoming members of the Health Star Network in Armonk.

Visitation Tuesday, 9 AM-11 AM, at the Waldeck Funeral Home, 7614 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment Holy Name Cemetery, Jersey City, NJ, Immediately following vistation.

title: Future Space Station Will Need Added Safeguards, Panel Says
description: Designers of the planned international space station need to take added measures to reduce chances of the orbital outpost's being damaged or destroyed by space debris and meteoroids, an expert panel has warned.

title: St. Paul
description: St. Paul has always maintained a stubborn pride in the face of Minneapolis, its more glamorous, populous and publicized twin across the Mississippi. ''That town over the river'' is still how St. Paul's old world aristocracy refers to what is considered nouveau riche Minneapolis.

description: SEPTEMBER'S forecast is inevitably amended come January. Herewith, a report on mid-season substitutions, cancellations and additions to the state's theater schedules offered in no special order.

description: The images that linger are not of Tim Duncan's 4 blocked shots, his 14 rebounds or the shots that led to his 26 points. Nor are they of the 3-pointers rained down by Wake Forest upon the Duke defense en route to a decisive 81-69 victory.

title: Lydia K. Gringer, Peter M. Schinasi
description: Lydia Krysia Gringer and Peter Mark Schinasi are to be married today at the Essex House in New York. Rabbi Noam E. Marans is to perform the ceremony.

title: PAINT PLOT
description: Last month, Lita Albuquerque, a California artist, was accused of Zionist imperialism thanks to a piece she produced for the Cairo Biennale, an international art competition. ''Sol Star'' was a mythopoetic evocation of a golden bee, symbolized by 99 blue circles painted in a honeycomb pattern on the desert sands of Giza. Trouble began when a local surveyor -- hired to help lay out the design (left) -- decided that Albuquerque's real, nefarious purpose was to paint a field of six-pointed Stars of David near Egypt's most famous pyramids. He alerted a prominent right-wing journalist, who cried foul. Albuquerque pronounced herself innocent and shocked, and gamely volunteered to reposition her circles into a map of the stars. Her compromise paid off: she took second place and won 40,000 Egyptian pounds.

title: Streetwalking Takes a New Turn and Travels by Car
description: ''There are a thousand girls on these streets with worse stories than mine,'' says the 31-year-old known on the street as Dimples. She came to New York a decade ago with nothing in her jeans but her body and has been working the streets ever since. ''Then again,'' she adds, ''you probably ain't gonna see too many girls standing on the streets anymore, nohow.''

title: Gertrude Bernstein, David Edelstein
description: A FRIEND recently asked David Edelstein why he did not wait a little longer to marry Gertrude Bernstein, whom he had dated since September. ''Are you kidding?'' replied Mr. Edelstein, 83. ''At my age, I don't even buy green bananas.''

title: Real-Life Role Helping Battered Women
description: THE actress Kathleen Turner is known for many roles, but none in which she is a victim. She always appears self-assured.

title: A Happy Ending Rescues a Venerable Tragedy
description: NORMALLY, a company touring with ''La Boheme'' would be a major non-event. But last month, New York City Opera Company's management decided to cut costs by substituting two pianos for its tour orchestra. Musicians were furious, and presenters, some with already sold-out houses, threatened cancellations. The tour was in jeopardy. Presto! Hot arts news. If the imbroglio were in a Rossini opera, it would be the frantic sextet at the end of act one.

title: China Grows, Russia Shrinks, Albright Juggles
description: RWANDA, Peru, Serbia and even Cyprus have lately had their share of Washington's fitful attention. But the big game afoot this year for Madeleine K. Albright, soon to be confirmed as Secretary of State, is how to handle relations with two of the world's largest and most insecure nuclear powers: Russia and China.

description: KALTMAN - Leo. Beloved son, husband, father and grandfather. Services Sunday, 12 noon, Garlick Funeral Home, Yonkers.

title: Ursula Niebuhr, 89, Founder Of Barnard Religion Department
description: Ursula Niebuhr, the founder and longtime chairwoman of the department of religion at Barnard College, died on Friday at her home in Stockbridge, Mass. She was 89 and the widow of the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr.

title: Breathing Life Into Beleaguered European Theater
description: THESE ARE NOT HAPPY days for theater in Europe. Only in England are a handful of authors regularly writing plays that people want to see. Everywhere, top actors fear losing lucrative television and film work if they sign up for the full run of a play. Audiences are graying because young people find movies and rock concerts more fun than theater. To make things worse, the crucial lifeline of government subsidies is being squeezed.

title: Headline For Irvin: 'Innocent'
description: MICHAEL IRVIN is still a free man today. He is also an innocent man, and he has the police statement to prove it. On Friday night, the Dallas police said Nina Shahravan, a 23-year-old woman, had recanted her charges against Irvin and his teammate, Erik Williams.

A free telephone link in the kiosk enables visitors to book hotels, theater, concert and movie tickets or even to shop or to order flowers. The six-month pilot project, begun in November, will be developed and adjusted according to customer response.

title: Still Frozen After All These Years
description: In the face of mocking skeptics, cryonics enthusiasts (who wish to be frozen at death, in hopes of being revived by future medical breakthroughs) maintain their faith. Some 70 people are now on ice around the world, none more famous than Dr. James H. Bedford, who 30 years ago today became the first cryonically frozen human. This intrepid ''cryonaut'' deserves mitten-handed applause for hanging in there. It hasn't been easy.

Repenning of Kenilworth, Ill. The Rev. Janet Hatfield Legro, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Women in Sports Endorsed by Girl Scouts
description: The article ''Women in Sports Still an Issue'' $(Nov. 17$) underscores an important message with which Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. wholeheartedly agrees -- sports are good for girls. The benefits which girls receive from participating in sports -- increased self-confidence, self-esteem, achievement in school, leadership skills and a myriad of health benefits -- are widely known and well documented.

title: Megan Jury Issue: Is Name a Taint?
description: By now, everyone knows what the prosecutors say happened to Megan Kanka. In the summer of 1994, they say, the 7-year-old girl was lured into the home of a neighbor with a record of sexual offenses against children, where she was raped and strangled. Her body was left in a pile of weeds in a park near her home in Hamilton Township.

title: THE ULTIMATE APPROVAL RATING
description: I have always found it curious that Presidential rankings like the one conducted by your panel of usual suspects routinely relegate Grant to the failure heap, ostensibly for Cabinet peccadilloes that seem so commonplace in the course of a Presidential term today (''The Ultimate Approval Rating,'' by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., Dec. 15). If Grant's tenure were really so terrible, how then to account for the fact that, on completing eight years in office, he left the Presidency as one of the most admired men in the world?

title: Making Radio Waves
description: BY 8 P.M. the airwaves of WNYC-AM were buzzing with complaints. It was the day after Thanksgiving, and listeners were reacting to the news that ''New York Beat,'' a live call-in show with Dara Welles, was about to be canceled and replaced with taped programming, including BBC news.

title: A Delegation for Gingrich, But Not All the Time
description: In his first two years as Speaker, Newt Gingrich could not always count on New Jersey's Republican delegation to toe the party line.

title: A Maestro Takes Fond Leave of an Old Love
description: EVEN IN NEW YORK, THE 6 foot-3-inch figure of Kurt Masur looms large. Just ask the members of the New York Philharmonic, who have toiled in his shadow for the last five and a half years. Mr. Masur's diminutive Japanese wife, Tomoko Sakurai, and her family call him the Elephant and give him elephant tchotchkes. But in Leipzig, a storied cultural capital, where memories of Bach and Mendelssohn, Goethe and Schiller have been fitfully preserved, Mr. Masur is regarded as a peer among giants, and his physical size is only a part of his stature.

title: Bit of Bayou Country Right in Heart of Smithtown
description: CAJUN JOE'S, a new restaurant at 60 Terry Road in Smithtown (360-7300), has more ups and downs than a roller coaster at an amusement park. Its food is authentic and ersatz. Its Cajun and Creole dishes sometimes are a bull's-eye and sometimes miss the target completely.

description: IT'S the middle of January, but it still looks a lot like Christmas. Lights are merrily winking and blinking on a good many houses, trees and bushes. Christmas trees are heavy with ornaments and shimmering with tinsel. And stockings, now empty, hang from fireplaces.

description: HENRY DARGER IS NOT WHAT most people have in mind when they think of a folk artist. He didn't live hundreds of years ago or anywhere near a farm, and his work owes little to tradition and everything to his lifelong, sometimes violent, obsession with little girls.

title: East Meets Central Park West
description: FOR YEARS, JADE ALBERT LOOKED AT HER APARTMENT THE WAY MANY New Yorkers do: as a place to change clothes and sleep, but nothing to write home about. ''I used to feel like Cinderella coming home after the ball,'' she recalls. Then Albert, a children's photoghraper, decided to buy ''a grown-up apartment,'' in George Mort Pollard's 1918 Hotel des Artistes, one of several artists buildings on West 67th Street. With its exotic mix of historical references (neo-Tudor arches and Moorish fixtures, for instance) and its double-height living room, the duplex was loaded with charm, but its rooms were tiny.

title: New Bill Would Allow Wrongly Convicted to Sue
description: David Shephard spent more than 11 years behind bars for a rape he did not commit. Released in April 1995, Mr. Shephard, now 34, has been trying to put his life back together. Nothing can make up for the years lost or the fact that he did not see his son grow up, but he believes he is entitled to more from the state than an apology from a judge, which is all he has received so far.

title: Phone Messages Help the Elderly Alone at Home
description: LAST April, six days before her 90th birthday, Lillian Lambert climbed on her flowered sofa in her apartment and reached up to change the top light bulb on a pole lamp. She lost her balance and fell, fracturing a rib. Mrs. Lambert could not get up, nor could she reach the telephone to call for help. There was no one to help her to her feet or drive her to the hospital. She spent the night on the floor.

title: San Francisco Marks Sea Lions' Seventh Year
description: California sea lions have been living at San Francisco's Pier 39 for seven years now, and the waterfront tourist complex was designated a wildlife viewing area this month by the California Watchable Wildlife Project, a state agency. Although the sea lions are in residence throughout the year, their numbers soar in January and February during the annual run of herring in San Francisco Bay. At the peak of the season, 600 of the dark brown pinnipeds can be seen sunbathing on docks or floating in nearby waters.

title: Sam Shepard's Aim Wavers in a Replay Of 'Tooth of Crime'
description: MANY OF SAM SHEPARD'S PLAYS, especially the early ones, have the manner of things written in a single burst of delirious energy, when ideas, characters and dialogue come so thick and fast that there is no time to connect them in any orderly way, and no need to. His dazzling imagination and wild associations somehow catch the temper of the times to create a valid, highly poetic dramatic cohesion. It is now also clear that he occasionally likes to tinker with finished scripts to the point where, after having taken something apart, he can't always put it back together again. With pieces left over, the reassembled object doesn't always function with its intended pinball-machinelike spontaneity.

title: The Silent Boom
description: As a boy, I had A good lesson in the psychology of money while swimming across a dark lake in the White Mountains. On a whim, I dove to the bottom to grab a handful of whatever was there. Rising to the surface, I found myself holding a soggy but intact $100 bill. My first instinct was to swim back to shore and dance a little jig for the benefit of everyone who had failed to find a $100 bill. Only when it was too late, after word had spread and dozens of kids were popping to the lake's surface clutching globs of mud, was my urge to celebrate publicly overcome by a desire to keep my discovery to myself, on the off chance that the bottom of the lake was littered with $100 bills.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 29 about the closing of the American Velvet Company in Stonington referred incorrectly to the difference in labor costs at its mills in Connecticut and Virginia. Unemployment compensation alone is 20 times as high in Connecticut as in Virginia; it is not all personnel costs that are 20 times as high.

description: THEIR fifth-grade son, his ankle sprained, hid under a blanket in the family's West End Avenue apartment as John and Marina Averyt talked about middle school, not exactly a light subject.

title: Police Investigate Cowboys' Accuser
description: The announcement made by the Dallas police Friday night that an accusation of rape against two Cowboys players was false came after a week of sifting through evidence and testimony, which the police said increasingly raised questions about the accuser's credibility.

title: The Nets Press Youth To Avoid Smoking
description: The Nets, so far, are hardly setting the N.B.A. on fire. They're not much on smoke, either. This week the team announced a program called ''Smoking: An Offensive Foul,'' aimed at discouraging tobacco use, particularly among children.

title: Landmark in Nantucket's Black History Restored
description: For the better part of this century, the one-room building at one of Nantucket's busier intersections had not looked like much. Its roof leaked. It badly needed reshingling. Its ceiling arched over nothing more historic than bicycles and vehicles that leaked oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDEN, AUDREE H.
description: SIDEN - Audree H. On January 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Ronald Siden. Dear mother of Michael (Carolyn), Marc and Andrew. Adored sister of Stan Weisenberg. Beloved finances of Dr. Edmund Slakter. Services Sunday, January 12th, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave, New York City.

title: Airplane Crash a Blow to Detroit and Industry
description: The deaths of all 29 people aboard a commuter plane that crashed near here on Thursday struck hard at this city and the industry for which it is famous.

description: A 19th-century convent and girls' school in Singapore has been transformed into a four-acre plaza with outdoor arcades, restaurants and shops.

description: Following are some key measures from the first New York State Report Cards, issued this month for every public school in the state.

title: New Home for Gay/Lesbian Health Center
description: ''Future Home of Community Health Project'' reads a sign above the graffiti-covered ground floor of the six-story warehouse now being gutted at 356 West 18th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues in Manhattan. The name of a bygone tenant -- T & E Casselman Inc. -- is barely visible above an entrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILLER, CLAIRE
description: FILLER - Claire. January 9, 1997. Wonderful daughter to the late Fannie and Dan Berger. Darling wife to the late, great Jimmy. Adored mother of Suzanne Lovett, loving mother-in-law of Bill. Services and interment private.

title: Crime Is Down. Streets Are Clean. What's a New York Comedian to Do?
description: New York City, as everyone knows by now, is resurgent, the blissful capital of the world. Nothing to complain about anymore. So what's so funny?

title: Talks Resume Between Peru And Guerrillas
description: Peruvian officials, signaling a reopening of negotiations that appeared to have reached a standstill, have renewed contacts with leftist guerrillas holding 74 hostages, establishing what President Alberto K. Fujimori described as a radio bridge to the rebels.

title: Don't Give Legitimacy To Subway Panhandlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Daddy's Dome
description: PLANS to demolish and rebuild the Hayden Planetarium are still stirring controversy as the old building counts down its last days.

title: The Pirates of Penance
description: Poor Disney. Every time it turns around the guardians of political correctness or the sticklers for historical accuracy, or both, are after it like that cartoon croc snapping at Captain Hook's keister in ''Peter Pan.'' Last week the entertainment giant moved to appease one group only to incur the derision of the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, LT. COL. CRAGIN CROYLE
description: CURTIS - Lt. Col. Cragin Croyle, OBE, of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, died suddenly on Jan. 3, 1997. He was 65. He is survived by his wife, Susan, and five children, Diana Price of Bellmore, NY; Harry Curtis of Summit, NJ; Laura Curtis of Boulder, CO; Cragin Curtis and Devon Curtis of Bermuda. Contributions may be made to: St. John's Ambulance Brigade, PO Box DV, 575 Devonshire, DV BX, Bermuda.

title: A Prosecutor Drops Kevorkian Charges
description: Saying that any renewed effort to prosecute Dr. Jack Kevorkian would be ''an exercise in futility,'' the new Oakland County prosecutor, David Gorcyca, dismissed a long list of assisted-suicide charges that his predecessor had filed against Dr. Kevorkian and two assistants in October.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERGER, BEN
description: GREENBERGER - Ben. A special man whom I've known most of my life. To Joan and Gerald and Harry, you were as fortunate to have hime as he was blessed to have you. My condolences to Alyse and Mark and Bruce.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Relic

title: Seoul Takes Its Cue From Mrs. Thatcher
description: WHEN South Korea enacted its basic labor laws in 1953, it was in the midst of the Korean War. Communist North Korea claimed that it was a worker's paradise. To counteract this, South Korea provided such generous worker benefits as a near guarantee of lifetime employment and a one-day-a-month paid menstruation leave for women.

title: A Legend Grows, and So Does an Industry
description: LONG BEFORE the murder that belatedly brought her to the attention of the English-speaking world, Selena had earned the title Queen of Tejano Music and the affection of Mexican-Americans in small towns like this one, the self-styled strawberry capital of Texas. So it was only fitting that when a Hollywood production company decided to transform the martyred singer's short life into a movie and to film some of its concert scenes at the county fairgrounds here, the crowd of extras that assembled was full of people who had seen the real Selena perform and adored her.

title: More Hospitals Providing Cancer Care
description: WHEN Cecilia Chadderton began having trouble breathing during her seventh month of pregnancy she was worried. A visit to North Shore Hospital in Manhasset intensified her fears when doctors found a five-inch tumor growing on her sternum. The pressure from the baby and the tumor had collapsed her lungs. Doctors delivered her baby girl two months early, and Mrs. Chadderton went into chemotherapy for four months.

title: Read All About It
description: China's going to have a free press.

title: A Price of Success: An Unbalanced Portfolio
description: PICKING stocks may not replace fixing teeth as his profession, but Bruce Bieber, a dentist in Bayside, Queens, is no passive investor.

title: Rain of Cash In Car Crash Tempts Poor From Miami
description: At first, Faye McFadden thought there had been a terrible accident. People were running everywhere, shouting, looking at the ground and picking things up.

title: Making Something From Something Else
description: A CAR is a car, and a coupe is a coupe, except as envisioned by manufacturers at the North American International Auto Show, which opened here last week. In both production vehicles that will be available in 1997 and 1998, and in concept designs that signal the shape of the auto industry to come, manufacturers are continuing to blur the lines between cars and trucks, and even among types of cars.

title: Health Care as a Symptom of Wider Ills
description: WILFRED REGUERO has spent 30 years in medicine seeking to improve health care access, particularly for those who need it most: the poor, the elderly, the children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSOBKA-MORAWSKI, EDWARD
description: OSOBKA-MORAWSKI - Edward, former Premier, Poland, died Jan. 9, 1997, Warsaw. Our condolences.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: TRIALS By Anne Tolstoi Wallach. Dutton, $24.95.

title: A Home-Grown Revival Of the Sports Car
description: SPORTS cars go fast, and most are gone before long. But the Chevrolet Corvette has had an unprecedented 45-year run since the first white convertible rolled off a temporary assembly line in Flint, Mich., in 1953. Credit a cult of buyers who made it the best-selling two-seater of all time, with more than a million produced.

title: For Half a Million, This is Still the New World
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins always talked about New York City as a ''gorgeous mosaic'' of peoples and faiths. Last week, city demographers added a whole new panel of tiles to the design with the release of a sweeping portrait of the 563,000 legal immigrants who coursed into the city from 1990 to 1994.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: More Advice for the Nets
description: The Nets are off to a less than rousing start this season. What advice would you give the Nets or their new coach, John Calipari?

title: Jury Selection Bogs Down In Bribe Case In Newark
description: Jury selection in the Federal bribery-conspiracy trial of the top aide to Newark's Mayor and an insurance broker bogged down this week as questioning of potential jurors revealed that some had heard about the case from news reports and others had a jaundiced view of politicians in general and Newark politics in particular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths
description: MICHAELIS - Arnold J. The Actors' Fund of America mourns his loss and celebrates his life. Masterful interviewer. Fund historian and chronicler, Arnold inspired everyone with his love for life and the entertainment profession. We grieve with his son, Dana, daughter Lisa, their mother Marianne and three grnadhcildren. Memorial service noon on March 6, at The Aurora, 475 West 57th Street, NYC. RSVP to: 212-489-2020.

title: Some District Officials Fear Tax Cut Would Hurt Schools
description: On Long Island, where homeowners have complained for years about soaring property taxes, government and civic leaders applauded Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal yesterday to ease residents' tax burdens.

title: Legislators Meet, Surprised at Limit On Shift of Power
description: When Republicans swept into office on Capitol Hill two years ago, there was much talk about a vast transfer of power and money from Washington to the states. Entire Federal programs in such areas as welfare, environmental protection and highway maintenance would be radically transformed into block grants, they said, with state leaders exercising wisdom on how best to spend the money.

title: Can Superman Be Superseded By a Capeless Wonder?
description: LONG ago on a Kansas farm, Martha Kent made the first supersuit for her teen-age son, Clark, who had arrived as a baby in a space capsule. Her Superman would wear a skintight blue leotard, a flowing red cape and a big red ''S'' on his expansive chest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESSLER, LOUIS (LYMEY)
description: BRESSLER - Louis (Lymey). It is time to say goodbye to our very dear, lifelong friend. He gave something special to each of us and we each will miss him.

title: Fear of Flying
description: To the Editor: Three days after the fear of flying article appeared, I was airborne, going from Los Angeles to Salt Lake City for the Thanksgiving weekend. My deep breathing during takeoff reminded me of the thanks I meant to give before leaving town to the Travel section for its accurate portrait of the fears of flying. It's comforting to know that others also worry whether a lumbering jumbo jet might be traveling too slowly to get airborne. I think the problem us white knucklers suffer is that we take the law of gravity too literally.

title: Nursing Home Today, Casino Tomorrow?
description: WHILE buildings have gone up and down and casino progress has swirled all around it, the King David Care Center has maintained a reassuring predictability.

title: 'Sentence First -- Verdict Afterward'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Employees of a Megastore Get the Power of Numbers
description: By the time Vicki M. Butler applied for a job at a Home Depot store in Sacramento, Calif., in late 1992, she had been an Air Force mechanic, a greenhouse manager and a general repairer of homes.

title: Banality, Nausea, Triple Execution: Guards on Inmates' Final Hours
description: LAST week Arkansas carried out the second triple execution in the state and the nation since the death penalty was reinstated in 1976. Prison officials argue that such multiple executions minimize overtime costs and reduce stress on prison employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, REBECCA
description: EDELSTEIN - Rebecca. On January 11, 1997. Beloved wife of Julius for 71 years. Loving mother of Joyce and Shelly Pitkin, Phyllis and Richard Edelstein. Adoring grandmother of Carla, Daniel, Franklin, Sharon, David, Bonnie, Steven, Meeghan, Jeffrey, Mark, Bruce and Francesco. Great-grandmother of David, Alexis, Maya and Allie. Funeral 10 AM, Sunday, January 12, Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer, Forest Hills.

title: Georgia Plots a Future Free of Russia's Sway
description: The Georgians were the last to know. Without even a hint of consultation with this country's authorities, the Russian border guards who still patrol Georgia's frontiers seized the Almaz, a Ukrainian ship, recently and took it to the Georgian port of Batumi.

title: HERMAN-NEUTICS
description: The academics who insist on deifying Melville remind me of sports fans who believe that great players must be great people (''Herman-Neutics,'' by Philip Weiss, Dec. 15). Writing a great novel or being a great quarterback doesn't mean you are incapable of beating your wife. Let's grow up and accept the fact that flawed human beings can do wonderful things in life.

title: Huge Cruise Ships Are Coming Along
description: WITH terms like forward and aft, starboard and port, life at sea has a language of its own. But in recent months the cruise industry's vocabulary has resembled that of the sports pages. The new ships are routinely described as ''three football fields long,'' their weight is compared with that of rival ships the way a Sumo wrestler's weight is compared with that of his opponent, and the fact sheets listing the size of lounges, spas and balconies is reminiscent of baseball owners boasting about the sky boxes in their new stadiums.

title: Fur? Just a Little Trim
description: The fur-trimmed coat has returned as a fashion force, after an absence of 50 years. The coats recall the movie star glamour of the face-framing lavish fur collar of the 1920's, 30's and 40's, when Hollywood was a major fashion influence. By 1950, the full-length mink had displaced the trimmed coat.

title: What a Difference Two Decades Make
description: THEY struck without warning on a brittle, sun-filled afternoon. Dressed in white coveralls, the demonstrators pounced on the Chinatown headquarters of Asian Americans for Equality last Monday, quickly plastering its ground-floor facade with posters proclaiming ''Greed,'' ''Profiteering'' and ''Corruption.'' As startled employees hastily locked the front door, Seth Tobocman, a member of the arts collective ABC No Rio, stood up on a milk crate.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7

title: How Schwab Builds One Fund From Many
description: WITH roughly 8,000 mutual funds out there, it's no wonder investors struggle to pick just a handful for a simple portfolio. Do-it-yourself types sometimes resort to choosing among those with five stars from Morningstar or those that appear on the Select List of top performers from Charles Schwab & Company.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the International Debutante Ball referred incorrectly to the flowers on the tables. They were real, unlike the arrangements of the same size, design and pink and silver colors on the edge of the stage. The report also misspelled the name of the mother of one debutante. She is Princess Chantal, not Chantel.

title: Texaco's Hasty Apology
description: WE'RE sorry, said the Texaco chairman, Peter I. Bijur, after tape recordings came to light in November of top executives seemingly behaving like bigots and plotting to cover the company's collective backside. We're shocked. We're ashamed, and we'll make it up to you.

title: In the Director's Chair, It Was the Year of the Actor
description: THE BIGGEST MOVIE TREND of 1996? It wasn't movies about aliens or movies with music. It was movies directed by actors. And two of those films, Al Pacino's documentary ''Looking for Richard'' and Stanley Tucci's ''Big Night,'' have not only landed on critics' 10-best lists but are possible candidates for Oscar nominations.

title: How Football Got Sacked
description: It has been nearly 37 years since Roger Kahn's famous essay in Sport magazine, ''Football Is Taking Over,'' signaled the ascendancy of football over baseball. (Basketball was scarcely in the picture then.) ''Almost every franchise in the National Football League seems solid,'' Kahn wrote, ''and some -- the Giants, the Rams, the Browns, the Bears and the Colts -- 24-carat. The pro football stars are famous and becoming more so. The fans are intense enough to riot. . . . For nine consecutive years, attendance in the National Football League has increased. This is the hot sport, the sport everyone seems to be talking about.'' A few weeks after the death of Pete Rozelle, the architect of the N.F.L.'s success, and on the verge of another Stupor Sunday, it might be time for a reassesment.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ethiopian Art
description: To the Editor: Readers who are interested in Ethiopian work as described in ''Ethiopian Folk Art Thrives in Israel'' (Nov. 24) may want to know that they can buy examples of it at the New York office of the North American Conference on Ethiopian Jewry, 165 East 56th Street. A color brochure may be obtained by writing or calling (212) 752-6340. This nonprofit group uses the proceeds to assist the parents and children of those Jews in Israel.

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: After reading Suzanne Carmichael's Practical Traveler column, ''What Airlines Owe Passengers'' (Oct. 27), I feel compelled to write about my experience with Delta Airlines:

title: Breakthrough
description: IMPURE SCIENCE

description: To the Editor:

title: As Federal Bias Cases Drop, Workers Take Up the Fight
description: Even as the Government scales back its antidiscrimination efforts and voters show impatience with affirmative action, minority and female employees are increasingly taking matters into their own hands.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Message to Love: The Isle Of Wight Festival

title: Diplomats Who Do Wrong
description: IN 1982, a North Korean diplomat grabbed a woman's breasts in a park in Eastchester, outside New York City, and then holed up in his country's mission to the United Nations for 10 months, before he finally pleaded guilty to a minor charge and left. A few years later, the Ambassador of Papua-New Guinea plowed his car into four others on Wisconsin Avenue here. Though alleged to have been soused, he went home with impunity. More recently, Uganda's Ambassador was nabbed by customs agents in Florida as he was trying to smuggle home antitank weapons. He, too, left the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, PAULINE
description: GREENE - Pauline, on January 1, 1997 in Florida. Memorial service Jan. 26, at Lincoln Guild House, 303 West 66th Street, New York City.

title: Fear of Flying
description: To the Editor: The fear of flying article was of particular interest to me since I really do not know anyone who had a greater fear than I. Advice given to me by a British pilot 25 years ago enabled me to overcome it.

title: Spicy Chicken and Lamb Make Up an Indian Meal
description: WHENEVER I visit London I make a point of going to the Bombay Brasserie in Kensington, which has come out with ''The Bombay Brasserie Cook Book'' by Chef Udit Sarkhel (Pavilion Books Limited).

title: Bellmore, With Eye on Past, Bets on a Downtown Resurgence
description: IN the 1960's, Bedford Avenue in Bellmore was a thriving downtown shopping district. It had a movie theater, two five and dime stores, a Bohack's Supermarket and a variety of mom and pop shops. By the late 1980's, business got so bad, people were saying that the last one to leave town should turn out the lights.

title: Questions in Dallas
description: The announcement by Dallas police that two Cowboys players had been falsely accused of rape came after a week-long investigation that led detectives to question their accuser, a 23-year-old woman who police officials said had previously sought to work as a drug informer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWTON, BERNARD
description: NEWTON - Bernard. On January 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Devoted father of Claudia Steinberg, Neil Newton and son-in-law, Jerold Steinberg. Dear grandfather of Benjamin and Rebecca Steinberg. Professor Emeritus and Department Chairman of economics, Long Island University.

title: Drug Tests? Congress Says, 'Sign Us Up'
description: In their first piece of legislative business, House members agreed last week to drug-testing in the House, but put off deciding who should be tested (members? staff?), how (urinalysis? hair samples?) and when (pre-employment? random?). Punishment is also still to be determined (first warning? firing?) Members who do not want to be tested argue that while certain executive branch employees are tested, the President and Vice President are not.

title: School as America's Cure-All
description: SOMEWHERE between ebonics and Newtonics lies the basic dilemma of American education.

title: Job? Kids? A Sad Route To a Happy Balance
description: MIKE ZISMAN and his wife, Cindy Ebert, used to argue over how much time they each spent with their three children. He thought she spent too much; she thought he spent too little. That tension became so great that the couple divorced in 1994, though they remained close friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, LILLY WAHWER
description: CLARK, Lilly Wahwer. In loving memory. Born in Riga, Latvia, June 18, 1898, died New York City, Jan. 8, 1997. Ballerina, equestrienne, multilingual, Diplomatic hostess in London, Berlin and Havana. She worked for the Near East Relief in Erivan, America, 1921-1923. She leaves daughter Doris and 4 grandsons, the Westbay brothers in Colorado, nieces, nephew, and counsins in Riga, Arizona, California, Rochester, New York and Canada and friends in NYC. A memorial service will be held in Rochester in the spring.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Losing It
