description: BLACK ART SHOW

title: In Ridgewood, a Private School Within a Public School Aids the Autistic
description: In a class for six autistic children, patience has its rewards for Sandi Bland, the teacher. That was evident, one day before the holiday break, as she taught reading to an 8-year-old boy.

title: A Rent Strike Based on Fear
description: Herbert Evans's one-room apartment is a mine field of duct-tape patches, a leaky ceiling, missing tile, mousetraps and Kitty Litter. ''Every time it rains I get flooded here,'' an angry Mr. Evans said of the Seaview Estates apartment he moved into last August. ''I had to get a cat because of the mice problem. I don't even like cats.''

title: Wall Street's Boom Echoed in Fairfield Housing
description: A SURGE in speculative building of multimillion-dollar homes in Fairfield County is being attributed by realtors, architects and builders to good times in lower Manhattan. The Wall Street boom has led home builders for the first time since the roaring 1980's to put up houses of at least 7,500 square feet with four-car garages and swimming pools in advance of finding buyers.

title: Whitney Hopkins, Park Duncan
description: Whitney Grace Hopkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Hopkins 2d of Gulfstream, Fla., was married yesterday to Howard Park Duncan, a son of Barbara P. Goldschmid of Breckenridge, Colo., and William M. Duncan of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Stay-at-Home Spouses Get I.R.A. Break
description: STAYING at home to raise the kids and manage the household is politically correct these days. As of Jan. 1, it became financially correct, too.

title: He's Not Heavy, He's My Baby
description: When I was 24 I went to Europe for a year carrying one compact duffel that fit comfortably under an airline seat. In this bag I had packed a few interchangable pieces of mostly black clothing, along with a blank journal and an elastic clothesline that could be stretched across any room. I wore my only pair of shoes - brown loafers. My small purse accommodated my wallet, train pass, travelers' checks, passport, pen, comb and lipstick. Such austerity pleased me and seemed necessary. I was starting my trip with no itinerary and no return date or ticket.

title: Corruption Lite, Democracy's Junk Food
description: A NEW year dawns, and once again the nation is rooted to the sofa, awash in the gray glow of the cathode-ray tube, taking in a pageant of misdeeds. The Speaker of the House took donations to tax-exempt foundations and funneled them into partisan projects. The President transformed the White House into a Motel 6 for well-heeled supporters. It is all pretty squalid, some of it maybe illegal, and there is broad support for doing something about it, ''it'' being vaguely described as the corrupting effect of the checkbook on democracy.

title: At Coliseum, Real Estate Lions Become Gladiators
description: NINE competing plans for the redevelopment of the New York Coliseum site on Columbus Circle are on display in the lobby of 10 Columbus Circle, the office tower that adjoins the Coliseum, where they will remain through January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAINTER, JAMES L. PHD
description: PAINTER - James L. PhD., 52, on Jan. 9. After a courageous battle against leukemia. Survived by mother Ida S. Painter, sister Eleanor White, niece Jessica. Dearest companion to Inger Nennesmo. His wit and friendship will be missed. Services Monday, Redmond Funeral Home, Freeport, Pa.

title: High Court Takes Up Suit Against Clinton
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments tomorrow about whether a sitting President can be sued over his private behavior in a case that could prove both politically damaging and personally embarrassing for President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINDHEIM, FREDERICK J.
description: WINDHEIM - Frederick J. Resident of Realeigh, NC. Beloved son of the late Jack and Adele Windheim of Larchmont, NY. Dear brother of Gilbert A. Windheim. He was a good and loyal friend to the many who loved him. He will be sadly missed. Memorial services will be held at Temple Israel of New Rochelle at 1 PM Sunday, Jan. 19.

title: CHARITY BEGINS AT ... THE MARKETING MEETING, THE GALA EVENT, THE PRODUCT TIE-IN
description: It is worse than bizarre to see an emaciated model (with, so far as is coyly revealed, perfect breasts) posing to sell an article about how breast cancer is a ''hot'' charity these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERALNICK, MARK, PHD
description: SERALNICK - Mark, PhD, born December 26, 1954 passed away January 6, 1997 at the age of 42. Mark died in the loving arms of his wife Carrie and his mother Shirley. Mark, originally from Newburgh, New York, lived in Palatine, IL. Mark was the first American to graduate with a PhD from Tokyo University, Japan. He died after a long and courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his loving wife Carrie (nee Miresso), his father Herman, his mother Shirley, his sister Isabel and many beloved family and friends. Services are January 13, 11 AM at Smith-Corcoran Funeral Home, Palatine, IL. Memorials may be made to the University of Nebraska Medical Center for Cancer Research, 600 S. 42nd Street, Omaha, NB 68198. For information 847-359-8020.

title: Will the Diesel-Bus Fleet Survive Trenton's Eco-Politics?
description: The belching diesel bus, long a hallmark of New Jersey's public transportation system, will be fighting for survival this year in in the State Legislature.

title: Lady Liberty Laces Up at the Garden
description: Please don't call them ''the Rangers' new jerseys,'' said Neil Smith, president and general manager of the hockey team. The phrase sounds like an oxymoron, he said, especially when the Blue Shirts play the New Jersey Devils, which they will tonight.

title: Drastic Fixes, Tomorrow
description: The odd thing about this deafening Social Security debate is that most economists acknowledge that the annual increases are too big, that they are based on a faulty Consumer Price Index. Simply give retirees a true cost-of-living increase -- 1.1 percentage points less than they get now -- and the hole in the dike will be plugged for many decades, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan says. That's impossible, of course, because it would mean cutting payment increases now, as in today. Politicians, for all their talk, are scared to death to touch next month's check. So the experts are ignoring Mr. Moynihan's sober counsel, taking refuge in proposals that -- drastic as they are -- are way off in some fuzzy future. The truly drastic idea: investing some Social Security money in stocks, either under the Government's control or the individual's. In other words, if we see a balloon defying gravity, everybody just hop aboard. It'll never fall.

title: Grumbling on the Job: A Worker's Right or a Wrong?
description: COMPLAINING about your job with colleagues is a well-established ritual, presumably unassailable. But be careful; it's not. A little-noticed Federal appeals court ruling has shown that employees can be dismissed for muttering to one another within earshot of customers.

title: New Video's Aim: Guiding Children In Show Business
description: THE model was captivating in a yellow cable-knit sweater and blue jeans, spanking-white sneakers and brown hair brushed softly to one side. At 4, Zachary Dahlia is as likely to be posing for advertising photographs as playing in his preschool group or practicing karate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANCROFT, MARY
description: BANCROFT - Mary. January 10, 1997, at home. Loving mother of Mary Jane Taft of Atlanta, GA, and the late Sherwin Campbell Bodger Jr. Dear grandmother of six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced.

title: Ms. Rogers, Mr. Schofield
description: Whitney Hayden Rogers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Harriman Rogers of Castine, Me., was married yesterday to Robert Hayden Schofield Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Schofield Sr. of Palm Beach, Fla. Bishop Calvin O. Schofield, the Episcopal bishop of southeastern Florida and a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach.

title: Yellowstone Park Bison Killed to Settle Suit
description: Rangers at Yellowstone National Park shipped 146 bison off to slaughter this week as part of a temporary plan to keep the animals from migrating outside the park and running into conflicts with private landowners.

title: Who Needs Another East-West Highway?
description: As a devoted runner who has spent many a beautiful Sunday morning on the roads in and around the stretch of Route 25A that is the subject of so much controversy and as the president of the area's local running club, I would like to make it clear where the local running community stands on the proposed changes to what we runners lovingly call Fish Hatchery Hill $(''Protests Lead to Revised Plans for Rte. 25A,'' Dec. 15$).

title: Cowboys Didn't Do It
description: The Dallas Cowboys lost their playoff game against the Carolina Panthers last Sunday, but they won back part of their reputation on Friday.

title: Green Bay Is Braced for Carolina and the Cold
description: The Packers and the Panthers have talked about this day since the opening of training camp in July. Having fallen short of making the Super Bowl in a loss at Dallas last year in the National Football Conference championship game, Green Bay's preseason Super Bowl vows had a ring of truth.

title: Woods Catches Lehman With 4 Straight Birdies

title: Mrs. Helmsley Becomes Queen Without a King

Helmsley, she will own a large chunk of a city that has made sport of chronicling her imperiousness. Atop the pinnacle of power, she is essentially alone except for the servants and the few people who have stuck with her. Whatever can be said of Mrs. Helmsley, most people who know her agree on her devotion to her husband -- almost to the point of obsession.

title: For Writers Who'd Rather Be on MTV
description: Rock concerts are out. Readings are in. Anyone who has ever watched a segment of ''MTV Unplugged'' before running out to the local bar or cafe for a literary reading can see that these days rock-and-roll lives not in the rock star but in the writer. For him, the public reading is a smoldering lounge act, an acoustic performance on the air guitar that is his manuscript. He can stammer his introduction and run his fingers through his hair. He can dress too casually for the occasion. He can carry his drink with him up to the lectern and sip it during the page turns. If he is remotely attractive, a stampede ensues when he finishes. The girls swoon and must be carried out on stretchers. Agents pick up swords and joust in the parking lot to win his heart.

title: Wool on the Go
description: To the Editor: My son Dave had just gotten his driver's license when we were planning a college inspection tour. He said, ''Mom, could I do all the driving on this trip?'' My heart leaped, but I remained calm and said, ''Sure.'' And then I headed for a knit shop.

title: Whitman vs. Insurance Rates
description: In what is regarded as a preview of her re-election campaign, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will announce plans for decreasing automobile insurance rates in her third State of the State address tomorrow. New Jersey's rates are the highest in the nation. The Governor has said recently that giving motorists more leeway to choose from various kinds of coverage and curbing fraud would drive rates down. She is expected to propose allowing consumers to buy less coverage at cheaper rates. But the Governor has said she does not favor abandoning the state's ''no-fault'' system, as some legislators have proposed.

Since the beginning of his career, Prince has been about control, from his insistence on playing almost all the instruments on the majority of his recordings to his recent battle for autonomy from Warner Brothers Records to his idiosyncratic rules about what names he is to be called, how business is to be conducted with him and how interviews are to be carried out.

She is partly a female James Bond, carrying exploding lipstick to blast through locked doors. And apparently she is part sheepdog. As the heroine of ''La Femme Nikita,'' Peta Wilson views the world from behind blond bangs that hang well below her eyes, yet she still has perfect aim with a gun. title: Arrest on Bogus-Chip Charge
description: A Rhode Island tool-and-die maker has been arrested in what authorities say is the country's biggest case of gambling chip counterfeiting, the A.P. reported yesterday. The man, Louis Colavecchio, was caught Dec. 28 with $49,000 in fake tokens in his car, according to the United States Secret Service. Mr. Colavecchio, 54, and his girlfriend had been seen playing the bogus chips at Caesar's Atlantic City Hotel Casino, the Secret Service said. Dies for 40 kinds of slot machine tokens used in Atlantic City, Connecticut and Las Vegas were found in a safe at Mr. Colavecchio's business, Diamonds in Design, Ltd., the authorities said. The fakes were some of the most authentic-looking ever seen, professional token-makers said, and their discovery has prompted casinos around the nation to check their security measures. Mr. Colavecchio and his girlfriend, Donna M. Ulrich, 45, face Federal counterfeiting and racketeering charges..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANCROFT, MARY
description: BANCROFT - Mary. Died peacefully in her sleep January 10, 1997, at her home in New York at age 93. She was born in Cambridge, MA, daughter of Hugh Bancroft and Mary Agnes Cogon. She was married to the late Sherwin C. Bodger. They had three children, George who died in infancy, the late Sherwin C. Jr. and Mary Jane. She later married Jean G. Rufenacht and moved to Zurich, Switzerland. She was a writer and journalist and wrote for Swiss newspapers. She worked with Allen W. Dulles in the Office of Strategic Services during World War II. She returned to the U.S. in 1953 and took up residence in New York and for some years was involved in local Democratic politics. She authored three books, ''Upside Down in the Magnolia Tree,'' ''The Inseperables,'' and her memoirs ''Autobiography of a Spy.'' She is survived by her daughter Mary Jane Taft of Atlanta, six grandsons and twelve great-grandchildren. A memorial will be held at a date to be announced. For information, contact Frank E. A few weeks later, after the couple spent the morning reminiscing about their 22 years together, wrote Mr. Humphry, his wife drank from a cup of pill-laced coffee and ''barely had time to murmur, 'Goodbye, my love,' before falling asleep.''

title: A medical equipment company says it has new tools and a new way to treat an enlarged prostate.
description: MILLIONS of men age 50 and older suffer from the symptoms of enlarged prostate. This benign condition occurs when prostate tissue, after decades of dormancy, begins to grow. The excess tissue blocks the urethra, the tube through which urine passes out of the body. As a result, sufferers often cannot empty their bladder completely and must strain to relieve themselves. But in spite of their discomfort, many men never consult a doctor, and most of those who do choose to live with the condition rather than undergo risky surgery.

title: Eartha Kitt Unsheaths The Claws Of Songs
description: That late 70's disco anthem ''I Will Survive'' may have found new life in recent years as a second-string cabaret standard. But until you've seen Eartha Kitt scratch its eyes out, you've probably never really heard it. In Ms. Kitt's hands the song, originally popularized by Gloria Gaynor, is more than just a vow of emotional resilience following a breakup. It becomes a fierce, clenched declaration of independence growled out with vengeful triumph by an unforgiving cat woman. Once the fur stopped flying at Wednesday's opening-night show of her two-month engagement at the Cafe Carlyle (76th Street and Madison Avenue), Ms. Kitt's performance received a resounding ovation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNE, ELLEN GRIFFIN
description: DUNNE - Ellen Griffin. Of Nogales, AZ. Died on January 9, at Holy Cross Hospital in Nogales after a long battle with multiple sclerosis. Mrs. Dunne was born in Tucson on January 28, 1932, to the late Thomas Francis Griffin and Beatriz Sandoval Griffin of the Yerba Buena Ranch outside Nogales. She attended schools in Tucson, Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, Briarcliff Manor College, and the University of Arizona. In 1954 she married Dominick Dunne of New York City. The later moved to Beverly Hills, CA, where their three children were raised. After the murder of her daughter Domnique in 1982, she founded Justice for Homicide Victims, a victims' rights organization, currently with 10,000 members. Her work on behalf of victims' rights was honored by President George Bush at the White House in 1989. After many years residence in California, she retured to Nogales in 1990, where she built a house on land that had once been part of her parent's ranch. She is survived by her two sons Griffin Dunne of New York City and Alexander Dunne of San Francisco, and her former husband Dominick Dunne. The family has suggested that in lieu of flowers, donations he sent to Justice for Homicide Victims, PO Box 2845 Malibu, CA 92065.

They may continue to re-elect the People's Action Party because they support it. Or, they may simply be trying to avoid the financial penalties that can come with opposing Singapore's autocratic leaders.

description: Now that marbled steaks, dry martinis and fat cigars are back in style, New Jersey's Democratic county leaders are hoping that equally old-fashioned politics will help them topple Gov. Christine Todd Whitman this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, DR. EDWARD
description: GOLDSTEIN - Dr. Edward. Beloved father of Bunny, Leonard and Maria. Cherished brother of Moe and Eve, Marty and Lee, Ethel and Norman. Devoted uncle of loving nieces and nephews.

title: A Gold Rush From Software Reinvigorates Silicon Valley
description: Awash in new, high-paying technology jobs, Silicon Valley is in the midst of its most remarkable economic boom in two decades.

title: In Green Bay, Dream Team Has Favre at Center
description: SO the great day has come: For the next two weeks this city of packers and industry will be wrapped in the glow of a long-awaited championship.

title: Betrayed in the Classroom
description: Children with learning disabilities are many times more likely to be hyperactive, delinquent and to end up in prison. Educators can roll out case after case of otherwise bright, vivacious students who work frantically to keep up and are driven to the verge of suicide by continued and unexplained failure. The most well-known example is Shannon Carter, a learning-disabled student whose parents withdrew her from public school, sued the county for private-school tuition and won their case in the United States Supreme Court.

title: Atlantis Blasts Off in Swift Pursuit of Mir Space Station
description: In a celestial chase around the Earth, the space shuttle Atlantis dashed across the skies today, pursuing the Russian Mir space station for a rendezvous and linkup.

title: Lawyers in Oklahoma Bombing Seek to Suppress Testimony
description: Lawyers for the defendants in the Oklahoma City bombing case sought this week to suppress the testimony of nine prosecution witnesses, some of whom appear to be central to the Government's case. Several witnesses were identified for the first time.

title: Much Debated And Diverse
description: If New York State allows the creation of independent public schools, it will become the 26th state to do so in the five and a half years since the concept was introduced in St. Paul and began to generate fierce debate.

title: Dow Finishes Up 5.39 After Strong Start
description: Stock prices went on a seesaw ride yesterday but eventually edged just slightly higher, as cautious investors prepared for today's reports on consumer prices and retail sales.

title: Capriati Bids Another Sad Farewell
description: Jennifer Capriati's comeback trail hit another Grand Slam roadblock today at the Australian Open, an event she had not visited since 1993.

title: Social Security Funds Don't Belong in Stocks
description: To the Editor:

title: China Convicts American as Trash Smuggler
description: An American businessman was found guilty in a Chinese courtroom here today of smuggling contraband: California garbage.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Duchess of Devonshire, who lives at Chatsworth, one of England's grandest houses, is coming to New York tomorrow to deliver two lectures. And she wants to see one of Tennessee's grandest homes: Elvis Presley's Graceland, in Memphis.

title: Pilon Finishes 2-Game Ban
description: The Islanders arrived at Madison Square Garden for last night's game with the Rangers without defenseman Rich Pilon, who was handed a two-game suspension yesterday after a telephone hearing with Brian Burke, the National Hockey League's senior vice president and director of hockey operations.

title: Intel Chief Named Chairman as Well
description: Andrew C. Grove, a co-founder of the Intel Corporation, was named chairman today and Craig R. Barrett was moved up to become president.

title: TELEPORT IN STOCK SWAP FOR INTERNET SERVICE PROVIDER
description: Teleport Communications Group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Internet company Cerfnet Services Inc. from General Atomics for $68.3 million in stock, based on yesterday's closing price of $32.50 a share. The combined company will provide telephone, Internet and World Wide Web services, primarily to business customers. Teleport will issue 2.1 million shares to buy Cerfnet, which is based in San Diego and provides Internet services to more than 6,000 corporate customers. Teleport Communications, based in Staten Island, is owned by several cable television companies, including Tele-Communications Inc., Cox Communications and the Comcast Corporation.

title: Global Climate Stayed Warm in 1996, With Wet, Cold Regional Surprises
description: THE world's climate system served up some big regional surprises in 1996, even as this decade's familiar string of warm years continued globally, climatologists have found as they tally their annual data.

title: Transit Program Imperiled
description: The Federal program with the cumbersome name (Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991) is usually referred to by its acronym, Istea (pronounced ''Ice Tea''), and it has been very good to New Jersey. This year, the state will get $850 million, or 44 percent of its budget for highway and mass transit projects, from Istea, even though New Jerseyans contributed just $576 million in Federal gasoline taxes last year, said Dave Brown, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation.

title: Sao Paulo to Sell Stake in Gas Gompany
description: A 20 percent stake in Cia de Gas de Sao Paulo is to be sold tomorrow by the City of Sao Paulo, which expects to raise at least 74 million reals ($71.1 million). The city will offer 1.71 billion shares in the company, which is known as Comgas, for a minimum of 43.29 reals ($41.60) for each 1,000 shares.

title: Still Tormented, but Less Withdrawn
description: In Tricky's songs, he couldn't be more alone. There are enemies outside his door, and if he's with a lover, she's not necessarily on his side. He can't feel his own heartbeat; sometimes, he can hardly breathe. He's paranoid and furious, and so bitter that all he can do is chant in a monotone that sounds as if it's scraping the bottom of an abyss. As a producer, he places that voice in music that seems to be closing in from all directions. In the last three years, he has spearheaded the style known as ''trip-hop'' and then, when it was embraced as hip background music, he added jagged noise to keep it ominous.

title: Run-Through of Favorites in a Risk-Free Recital
description: Accepting your limitations as an artist can be as important to your legacy as pushing yourself to try something risky. No doubt this is the realization Luciano Pavarotti faced when, earlier this season, he informed the Metropolitan Opera that he could not sing Don Alvaro in five performances of Verdi's ''Forza del Destino'' that were scheduled to begin at the end of this month. Adding this demanding new role to his repertory was not something he felt good about at this stage in his career. (The Met accommodated him by replacing ''Forza'' with ''Un Ballo in Maschera.'')

title: Prosecutor Answers Critics
description: The acting Bergen County Prosecutor sought to deflect criticism yesterday over his announcement of a case against four Ridgewood teen-agers accused of gang-raping a 14-year-old girl on Dec. 20. The Prosecutor, Charles R. Buckley, did not issue a news release until Jan. 9, but he said that there had been no need to publicize the case because the suspects were arrested soon after the incident and posed no danger to the community.

title: Whitman Outlines Plans for Record Bond Sale to Reduce Pension Costs
description: The Whitman administration today outlined plans to borrow $3.4 billion for the state's pension system, a move that would be the largest bond sale in the state's history and that would help avoid deep budget cuts in an election year.

title: Long Wharf Finds Its New Leader at the Guthrie
description: The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven has named as its artistic director Douglas Hughes, the director of artistic planning at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. He succeeds Arvin Brown, who led the Long Wharf for nearly 30 years and helped make it into one of the country's foremost regional theaters. Mr. Brown, 56, announced in June that he would retire at the end of the 1996-97 season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: VERITAS SIGNS $400 MILLION DEAL FOR OPENVISION
description: The Veritas Software Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday to merge with Openvision Technologies in a stock swap. Veritas, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would acquire Openvision for 7.5 million Veritas shares, valued at about $400 million. Veritas would issue 0.35 share for each Openvision share. Openvision, based in Pleasanton, Calif., has around 21 million shares and options outstanding. The new company will be based in Mountain View, Calif., and will combine the two companies' product lines. Veritas supplies operating system-level components for storage management. Openvision provides software for client/server systems management.

title: Former Executive Sues F.B.I. Agent
description: Mark Whitacre, the former vice president of the Archer Daniels Midland Company who was a Government informant in an investigation in which Archer Daniels pled guilty to price-fixing charges and paid a record $100 million fine, sued the F.B.I. agent who recruited him.

title: Jury Selection Begins In Megan Kanka Case
description: Under the glare of intense publicity, lawyers began picking a jury to hear the case of a man accused of raping and killing 7-year-old Megan Kanka, whose death spurred a nationwide movement to alert communities when convicted sex offenders move to their neighborhoods.

title: Modern Judaism Isn't Bred in the Genes
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Lot Near Times Sq. Is to Be Site of a New Hotel
description: In a deal to develop the largest remaining parcel of land in the Times Square redevelopment area, private developers will build a 35-story budget-rate hotel on what is now a parking lot on Eighth Avenue opposite the Port Authority bus terminal, state officials said yesterday.

title: Japan Pushes ASEAN Chiefs To Upgrade Ties to Tokyo
description: SINGAPORE  Japan and Southeast Asian countries appeared close to agreement Monday on the need for a major upgrading of their relations to help maintain the stability and economic dynamism of the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Making a Dance of Impending Death
description: In productions ranging from ''20 Years of Listening to America'' to the recent ''Genesis: A Living Conversation,'' Bill Moyers has shown a keen journalistic nose for fascinating subjects and people. Further evidence can be found in tonight's ''Bill T. Jones: Still/Here With Bill Moyers.'' Mr. Jones is a choreographer whose work and personality are rarely less than riveting.

title: With Johnson Ailing, the Road Looks Rougher for the Knicks
description: The Knicks have been in overdrive the past four games. They blew by Milwaukee and Dallas, and by Boston twice. But there is traffic ahead. The Knicks visit Houston on Tuesday night, move on to San Antonio and Phoenix, and then play Washington, Chicago, Indiana and Charlotte the following week.

title: Albert Wohlstetter, 83, Expert On U.S. Nuclear Strategy, Dies
description: Albert Wohlstetter, an influential innovator in strategic nuclear doctrine who advised Democratic and Republican Administrations on military strategy, died on Friday in his home in the Laurel Canyon area of Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: A.M.D.'s 4th Quarter Exceeds Expectations
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported yesterday a loss for the fourth quarter that was narrower than expected, helped by sales of microprocessors that legally mimic those made by the Intel Corporation.

title: BIBB PLANS BIG LAYOFFS AND A SALE OF STOCK TO PUBLIC
description: The Bibb Company said it would dismiss 580 textile mill workers, about 11 percent of its work force, by the end of March as it slashed production of home furnishings. Bibb, which emerged from Chapter 11 in October, also said it planned to sell stock to the public by the end of the first quarter, but would not comment further on the sale. The company, based in Macon, Ga., makes bedding, restaurant linens and bath towels. It has annual revenue of about $300 million.

title: Search Party Is Sought To Find a Commissioner
description: Four years and four months after Major League Baseball last had a commissioner without the word ''acting'' or ''interim'' before it, the owners will embark this week on yet another search for the right man for the job. How long it will take or where it will end nobody knows.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HILLS STORES CO., Canton, Mass., a discount retailer, said it would take a $12.5 million charge in its fiscal fourth quarter to shut eight unprofitable stores, reversing earlier plans to expand in the Southeast.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Funds' Record Year Ends With Strong Growth

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Mexican Rivals Campaign for Callers
description: Competition in long-distance telephone service arrived in this tranquil province capital recently with the buzz and bluster of a political campaign.

title: On Weapons Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Quietly Sticking to Plan
description: The Jets remain one of seven teams without a head coach, but they are also one that has not interviewed anyone. And why should they when talking to Bill Parcells is ''a no-brainer,'' one Jets assistant coach asked.

title: Clinton Said to Pick Chairman For the Democratic Committee
description: Roy Romer, the 68-year-old Governor of Colorado, is President Clinton's choice to be the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, a senior White House official and Governor Romer's office said tonight.

title: Arrests in School Vandalism
description: Three Brick Township teen-agers were arrested early Saturday after they broke nearly 100 windows in the local high school and in three district school buses, causing $50,000 in damage, the police said. The three boys -- ages 13, 15 and 16 -- had also stolen a cassette recorder and a fire extinguisher from Brick Township High School, said Sgt. Vincent Pacitti of the Brick Police Department.

title: Brooklyn Academy's Role In Renewal of Downtown
description: For many years after its revival in the 1970's, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's hulking neo-Renaissance opera house floated like a cultural and financial island on the outskirts of Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Bucharest Rediscovers Houses by a Modernist
description: It is hard for outsiders, and even for Romanians, to imagine that this city, where whole neighborhoods were razed by the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, was once a sophisticated urban capital with cutting-edge architecture and an avant-garde artistic movement. But in the 1920's and 30's, Bucharest was a pre-eminent center for modernist architecture, with dazzling white cubist-shaped houses with flat roofs and wide expanses of windows built for the newly rich.

title: Chess
description: Nowadays, the predominant form of organized chess competition is the tournament, in which the pairings follow the round robin or all-play-all method, as in baseball, or some delimitation of it, as in the Swiss system. But the original form was that of the match, a one-on-one challenge. Indeed, it was not until the International Tournament of 1851, held at the Crystal Palace of the London Exhibition, that tournament play entered the chess scene.

title: School Leaders Raise Doubt On Pataki's 'Charter' Plan
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to allow community groups to create publicly financed schools that would operate largely outside local school board control drew a muted reaction yesterday from top New York City school officials and the teachers' union.

title: Islanders' Puny Power Play Shows Rare Muscle
description: It figured the game would come down to the power play at Madison Square Garden last night, when the best one in the National Hockey League squared off against the worst one.

title: Playing the Stock Market Lotto
description: Late last June, when the stock market was in the midst of a summer swoon, I spent a day at the headquarters of Charles Schwab & Company in San Francisco. The discount brokerage's success is directly attributable to the astounding rise in the percentage of middle-class Americans who now invest in the stock market -- a proportion that is closing in on 40 percent of the country's households.

title: Another Day of Haggling Delays Mideast Accord
description: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators worked with American mediators through the day and into the night today, reportedly poring over every dot and comma in their drafts and thus delaying for yet another day the agonizingly elusive Hebron agreement.

title: 2 Floridians Talk of How They Taped The Speaker
description: John Martin said he and his wife, Alice, were on their way to Jacksonville, Fla., to do some Christmas shopping on Dec. 21 when they picked up a ''part of history'' on their hand-held police scanner.

title: Which Comes First: Depression or Heart Disease?
description: YEAR by year, the evidence has mounted. People who have heart disease are likely to be depressed, people with depression seem more likely to develop heart disease, and depression combined with heart disease is a double dose of adversity -- patients have a miserable life and tend to die sooner.

title: From a Loser's Father To a Legendary Winner
description: Jerry Stiller opened a plastic case and removed Vince Lombardi's teeth from a square of gray styrofoam. The teeth are a casting of the pigskin icon's gap-toothed uppers. He snapped it onto his teeth, then donned black-rimmed Lombardi-style specs. He was again Lombardi, whom he plays in 10 Nike spots.

title: Budget Equity in New York
description: By pledging to increase school aid for New York City and lower property taxes, largely for upstate and the suburbs, Gov. George Pataki has outlined some worthy goals. But the early numbers churned out by the Governor's budget office raise doubts about whether the city will end up worse off under the latest proposals. The Legislature also needs to resist locking in expensive new spending increases or tax reductions that later balloon in size. New York State's habit of launching programs with no thought about how to pay for them in the future has created chaos in its finances for years.

title: Saban Is Out and Fassel Is Likely to Be Named
description: More than a week ago, Giants General Manager George Young spoke with the Arizona Cardinals' offensive coordinator, Jim Fassel, the man who will probably become the team's next head coach. The conversation took place after Fassel had interviewed with Young. Young's message? Just hang tight; this process is not an easy one to endure.

title: New Push for a U.S. Chemical-Arms-Pact Vote
description: President Clinton renewed his drive today to win Senate ratification of a treaty banning chemical weapons, saying failure to act before late April would harm both the nation's national security and its economic interests.

title: Keep Research Access
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Emigres Run Afoul of Stock Regulators
description: The land of opportunity has meant the opportunity to defraud American investors for a small but persistent group of Russian emigres that law enforcement agencies and securities regulators are struggling to put out of business.

title: No Headline
description: ''I have told members of the corps in the simplest terms possible that the quickest way out of this college for anyone is to in any way behave in an inappropriate manner toward one of the female cadets.''

title: Mayor Plans to Put 40,000 Computers in Schools
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose a $150 million program today to provide enough computers so that every New York City public school student will have ready access to one, and to connect every school with the Internet, administration officials said yesterday.

title: 1996 changed the way Americans think about stock funds.
description: IT might not have been the biggest year ever for the mutual fund industry, but 1996 certainly transformed how Americans think about mutual funds that invest in the stock market.

title: Giving to the Neediest Cases, Out of Hope and Pain
description: Lonely, sick, weary, saddened, unemployed. These words describe not only New York's neediest, but sometimes those who help them.

title: Siemens to Buy 2 Units From Daimler-Benz
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany said yesterday that it would sell its AEG Electrocom G.m.b.H. and AEG Electrocom International Inc. units to the engineering company Siemens A.G. for an undisclosed amount. The units supply sorting and recognition systems for postal automation.

title: A Few of the Packers Know What to Expect
description: The afterglow of its National Football Conference championship victory over Carolina was still burning bright for Green Bay today, but Packers Coach Mike Holmgren was already putting the game behind him and turning his thoughts to Super Bowl XXXI in New Orleans on Jan. 26.

title: Safety Director Chosen
description: Mayor James Whelan of Atlantic City, who was assailed by the city's police union last month after he said that the Police Department should be run by a civilian administrator, announced his choice for the job yesterday. He nominated George Pugh, a former Camden police chief, as the city's first public safety director. If he is confirmed by the City Council, Mr. Pugh, 55, would start his job after the current police chief, Nicholas V. Rifice, retires in March, said Louis Toscano, a senior policy adviser to the Mayor. Mr. Whelan wants to eliminate the post of police chief, but it is not certain whether the council will agree. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Poland to Give Israel 13th-Century Haggadah
description: A rare illuminated 13th-century Haggadah telling the story of the Israelites' flight from Egypt is to be presented to Israel this week by the Polish Government, the World Jewish Congress says.

title: Gehe of Germany Wins Bid for British Drugstores
description: Gehe A.G. of Germany has won a yearlong battle for Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., a British pharmacy chain, after a competing bidder, Unichem, dropped out of the process.

title: Enron, seeking to be a household name, plans to start its campaign on Super Bowl Sunday.
description: EVEN IF it is the nation's largest independent natural gas company and even if it does aim to dominate an electricity market that is larger than the nation's telecommunications market, the Enron Corporation has found that just telling people what it is can pose unexpected challenges.

title: 2 Hurt at Arabic Paper as Bombs Are Mailed to London and U.N.
description: In a widening campaign of terror against an Arabic language newspaper owned by a Saudi prince, two mail clerks were injured this morning when one of four letter bombs addressed to the paper's offices here exploded.

title: Schubert, A Charmer No Matter The Form
description: Charm in Schubert has a lot to do with conviviality, and therefore with chamber music, and it was a charming program that the Chamber Music Society put together on Friday night for its first concert of Schubert's bicentenary year. None of these pieces went deep, and nobody was pretending they did, which was good. Charm is all the more effective for being put across with modesty and grace.

title: Korean Women Still Feel Demands to Bear a Son
description: When Lee Young Sun was pregnant for the second time, she secretly paid a doctor to learn the sex of the fetus. He told her she would have a girl, and she took off with her family on a vacation in misery.

title: Tyner's Balance and Contrast
description: McCoy Tyner played two sets for his show on Friday in the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse as part of Jazz at Lincoln Center, and through them both he maintained a balance between single-note lines and full chords. With that he mirrored the tension in jazz between the soloist and the band, between the role of solitary improviser and the democracy of the band, and the contrast gave his playing richness.

title: The Irvin Incident: Chapter 2
description: TWO months ago Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, visited the New York Times offices for a luncheon chat with about a dozen editors and writers. After he had answered questions about his team and his players for maybe an hour, he was asked whether he had any questions.

title: Russia Vows to Remove Georgia Nuclear Fuel
description: Responding to repeated American appeals, Russia promised today to remove a cache of nuclear material from Georgia by March.

title: Athletes Gain Two Changes in N.C.A.A. Rules
description: College athletes today earned two dramatic reversals in National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Division I members voted to allow those with athletic scholarships to hold jobs during the school year. And athletes who do not meet the academic requirements to play as freshmen were given the chance to earn a fourth year of eligibility.

title: In the End, Fatigue Defeats The Nets
description: There were four of them, each with his lungs stretched to capacity, each with his legs wobbling like a newborn colt's through more than 43 minutes of playing time.

title: Researchers Investigate (Horrors!) Nicotine's Potential Benefits
description: IN work that sounds a little like scientific blasphemy, medical researchers have begun paying increasing attention to some beneficial effects of nicotine that were first noticed in cigarette smokers.

title: The Citadel's Culture of Abuse
description: The resignation of Kim Messer and Jeanie Mentavlos, two of the four female cadets at the Citadel, demonstrates that the previously all-male, state-supported military college in Charleston, S.C., is not restructuring itself in good faith. Clifton Poole, the college's acting president, yesterday reiterated his commitment to educating women. But his words are not reassuring given his contention that the harassment of Ms. Messer and Ms. Mentavlos was not necessarily gender based.

title: Japan Stocks Calmer After A Statement
description: Japan's Finance Minister seemed to reassure the stock market today and said that the ministry would watch the stock market with serious concern after stocks plunged in early morning trading and sent the main market index down sharply.

title: The Toll For Becker: 120degrees Heat, 87 Miscues
description: He blamed the searing summer sun for scrambling his brains like eggs in a frying pan.

title: Cape Cod, Worried About Fresh Water Supplies, Seeks to Rein In Growth
description: With the number of permanent, year-round residents increasing steadily and putting new pressures on the limited supply of fresh water, Cape Cod is now wrestling with the question of how many more people can be permitted to move here.

title: The President Is Not Above the Law
description: The phrase ''equal justice under law'' is carved into the marble above the front entrance to the Supreme Court. Yesterday morning, President Clinton's lawyers walked through that entrance and asked the Court to create a special exception for the President.

title: Marvel Bondholders Seeking Control of Company
description: A group of Marvel Entertainment Group bondholders, including Carl C. Icahn, asked a bankruptcy court yesterday to effectively allow them to seize control of Marvel from Ronald O. Perelman, before Mr. Perelman can complete a reorganization that would leave the bondholders with little to show for their investment.

title: A Touch of Paris Glamour
description: Isabelle Guerin brought a welcome touch of worldly European glamour to the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Ms. Guerin, a guest ballerina from the Paris Opera Ballet, perfectly captured the steel-willed fragility of the daffiest music lover in ''The Concert,'' Jerome Robbins's witty look at an audience's reveries during a performance of music by Chopin.

title: Confusion Arrives Ahead of a Week of Tax-Free Clothing
description: Beginning Saturday, New York State will eliminate sales tax for a week on clothing and related items that cost under $500, in a plan aimed at stopping the flow of shoppers out of the city and into surrounding states that do not tax clothing purchases.

title: Limited Options In Serbia
description: The fiery nationalism that made Serbs the first free people of the Balkans in the 19th century has also made them the last to escape from Communism.

title: Chase Appoints Economist
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation of New York announced yesterday that it had named John Lipsky as chief economist and director of research for Chase's Global Bank. Mr. Lipsky previously served as the chief economist of Salomon Brothers Inc. since 1992. Before joining Salomon in 1984, he was an official of the International Monetary Fund for 10 years. Mr. Lipsky succeeds Richard C. Aspinwall, who was named director for public policy research, a new post.

title: Sears of Britain Selling Its Catalogue Unit
description: Sears P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sell its Freemans catalogue unit to the Littlewoods Organization for $:395 million ($671 million), in the latest attempt to shore up profits and margins at Sears. Freemans is the 23d of the Sears businesses to be sold in the last four years. Littlewoods is a private company with interests in catalogues and sports betting.

title: Irish Peace Process Is Dead, Thanks to Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Deals Extend the Financial Frontiers of Gene Therapy
description: A consolidation of the nascent gene-therapy industry advanced yesterday with two deals.

title: Genetic Differences in Rhinos Complicate Conservation Effort
description: SAVING the Sumatran rhinoceros, a shaggy beast unlike any other rhino, is one of the more challenging tasks facing wildlife conservationists. Now the effort may become more complicated because geneticists have confirmed that one of the animal's scattered populations is significantly different from the others and needs its own rescue effort.

title: Janus and One of Its Managers Agree to Fines to Settle Charges
description: The Janus Capital Corporation and one of its mutual fund managers agreed to pay $62,199 to settle charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the manager took personal advantage of an investment opportunity that he had recently rejected for the fund.

title: Thinning a Deer Herd
description: A campaign to lower the deer population at the Watchung Reservation is expected to begin today with the help of 30 volunteer marksmen, half of whom are law enforcement officers. The Union County Division of Parks wants to eliminate 189 deer by March 31 -- nearly half of the estimated herd of 400. The deer have destroyed flower gardens and plants in and around the 2,000-acre preserve, and attract the ticks that carry Lyme disease, said Daniel Bernier, chief of park operations.

title: Superman as Cyberman
description: Comic-book heroes get facelifts all the time, shedding the frumpy for the sleek and the homely for the handsome in a calculated attempt to entice younger readers. The makeovers tend to go unnoticed. But even editorial writers turned churlish last week when DC comics unveiled its new, somewhat androgynous togs for Superman, whose super suit is losing its trademark cape.

title: JUSTICES APPEAR TO SEEK TO DEFER CLINTON LAWSUIT
description: The long-awaited Supreme Court argument, which unfolded today, over whether Paula Corbin Jones can proceed with her sexual-harassment lawsuit against President Clinton found the Justices openly troubled by the prospect of a President's having to defend himself in court while he is in office.

title: Remembering the Good Old Days
description: No sane person would have wanted to trade places with Keith Sweat on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, where he was the opening act for New Edition, the 80's pop vocal quintet that has reunited as a superstar sextet. Bobby Brown, the New Edition member known for his violent outbursts, cursed Mr. Sweat from the stage, claiming that the bump-and-grind singer took too much time performing and that was why New Edition had to rush through their show.

title: Clinton's '96 Campaign: One Inside Point of View
description: BEHIND THE OVAL OFFICE

title: Man Testifies That Woman Coolly Plotted To Kill Spouse
description: Rita Gluzman calmly shopped for murder weapons at Home Depot, picking out an ax and a hacksaw, her cousin testified today. He said she coolly stopped at Grand Union for garbage bags to use in disposing of her husband's dismembered body.

title: INSIDE
description: Hotel Planned on 42d Street

title: Hampel/Stefanides Plans an Acquisition
description: Hampel/Stefanides in New York will acquire assets of Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley, a nine-year-old shop in San Francisco, as part of plans to open its first office outside New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NICHOLAS SCOPPETTA, Commissioner of New York City's Administration for Children's Services, will be honored tonight by some of his former colleagues for devotion to public service. . He is to receive the Hogan-Morgenthau Award of the Hogan-Morgenthau Associates, an organization of former and present assistant district attorneys on the staffs of the Manhattan District Attorneys Frank Hogan and Robert M. Morgenthau. The award is to be presented at a dinner for more than 300 people at the Tavern on the Green.

title: PRESIDENT WANTS CURB ON MEDICAID
description: Over the objections of senior members of his own party, President Clinton is drafting a budget that would set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending as a way to help balance the Federal budget by 2002.

title: Patterns
description: A Closing on Madison Ave.

title: Arnold Michaelis, TV Interviewer, 81
description: Arnold Michaelis, a television producer and host who interviewed heads of state and other public figures during a long career on television and radio, died on Jan. 4 at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Rock, War and Death: Call It a Reality Check
description: Dennis Russell Davies and the American Composers Orchestra must be thankful for the lethargy exhibited by other organizations, which allows them to call half a century and more of American music their own. On Sunday they continued their commitment to Roger Sessions by playing his Second Symphony, a work marked by the end of World War II and the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt. This is tough music: earnest, energetic, colorful. And it was played in that manner. The marching finale suggested a missing link between the Berg of ''Lulu'' and Shostakovich. This was music embattled, tumbling over with things to say.

title: Flight Attendants Reject Pay Cut at British Air
description: About 500 flight attendants at British Airways P.L.C. have refused to accept pay cuts of as much as 40 percent, forcing the airline to again delay an order for short-haul jets worth as much as $1 billion. The airline had hoped to ask manufacturers this month for bids to supply as many as 60 jets to replace aging short-haul fleets that serve routes in Britain, Germany and France. British Air had asked for bids from five plane makers in January 1996, but then shelved the order in April because it had not cut enough costs.

title: New Findings Suggest Massive Black Holes Lurk in the Hearts Of Many Galaxies
description: In the realm of extraordinary scientific concepts, black holes are the strangest and most awesome places in the universe, something out of the mind of Albert Einstein sharing spacetime with the imagination of Lewis Carroll.

title: For Liza Minnelli, the Affection Of Her Fans Is the Milk of Life
description: When the announcement came, around 3:15 P.M. on Sunday, you could feel the audience tensing at the Marquis Theater. ''We are experiencing a technical difficulty,'' said the voice, unreassuringly smooth, on the loudspeaker.

title: Several Agencies Conclude Deals
description: Deals involving several agencies have been announced.

title: At Ramadan, Islam's Stamp Shows Itself
description: AFTER he first arrived in New York from Bangladesh in the early 1980's, Abdul Khan had trouble keeping track of when the Islamic holy month of Ramadan came and went. There were not exactly many reminders then about when no food or liquid was allowed to pass his lips from sunup to sundown.

title: HILTON HOTELS TO TAKE A 5 PERCENT INTEREST IN LADBROKE
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it would take a 5 percent stake in Ladbroke Group, which holds the rights to the Hilton name outside the United States. Under the pact, which reunites the Hilton name, each company can take a stake of as much as 20 percent in the other company. The companies initially announced plans for the alliance in August. At the time, Hilton's 5 percent investment was valued at $180 million. Ladbroke, which is based in London, is a hotel and leisure group. Hilton Hotels is based in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Scientific Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: An Upgraded Leviathan Sets Sail
description: BATTEN down the hard drive! Microsoft Office 97 will officially arrive on Thursday with a bag of new features even bigger than the usual upgrade. Many are useful and potentially important, like a cornucopia of options involving hypertext and the Internet. But pesky cartoon critters descended from the late and unlamented Microsoft Bob get in the way.

title: Income Up at Morgan and Nationsbank
description: Several of the largest American banks, including J. P. Morgan & Company and the Nationsbank Corporation, said yesterday that their earnings rose strongly in the fourth quarter.

title: A New Center Is Almost Ready, But Will Patrons Fear to Use It?
description: It is barely past sunset on a clear winter evening, when about the only thing moving in the vicinity of Newark's Military Park is a go-go dancer in a turquoise string bikini and black spikes, grinding through her desultory routine inside the Dubonnet Cocktail Lounge.

title: Accounts
description: Novartis, Basel, Switzerland, to Ruder-Finn, New York, as the first creative agency for the company formed by the merger of Ciba-Geigy and the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp. Billings were estimated at $45 million. CIA Media Network International, London, handles media.

title: History Says Parcells Seems a Good Bet
description: Bill Parcells, alternately wistful and tough and humorous, said today of his latest trip to the Super Bowl, ''It's better now -- you know what you're going to.''

title: Tomkins Profit Up 34%, Aided by Denver Deal
description: Tomkins P.L.C. yesterday posted an unexpectedly large 34 percent rise in first-half profit, reflecting its $1.16 billion acquisition of the Gates Rubber Company in Denver. Tomkins is a British manufacturer with businesses ranging from bread making to garden hoses. Gates, formerly family controlled, makes auto belts and hoses; its results were included in those of Tomkins for 14 weeks of the first half of Tomkins's fiscal year. The pretax profit of Tomkins rose to $:168.8 million ($285 million) in the six months ended Nov. 2, from $:126 million the previous year.)

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES BUYING SOUTHWEST CAR DEALER
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it would buy Grubb Automotive Inc., an auto dealer in the Southwest, for $100 million in stock. The deal continues the plan by Republic, which is controlled by H. Wayne Huizenga, to own car dealerships in markets where it is developing its Auto Nation USA chain of used-car lots. Grubb Automotive owns and operates six new- and used-vehicle dealerships in the Phoenix area and a new-vehicle dealership in Midland, Tex. Republic, which already owns Alamo Rent-a-Car, recently announced plans to buy National Car Rental System Inc. from the General Motors Corporation. The rental chains give Republic, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., another way to funnel autos to the used-car lots.

title: As More Catholics Turn Against I.R.A., the Number of Police Informers Rises
description: The overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army has acknowledged that an increasing number of Catholics in Belfast have begun to inform on the guerrilla organization's planned violent attacks and has warned that it will punish such informers.

title: Developer in $38.4 Million Deal
description: The Starrett Corporation, the company that built the Empire State Building, Starrett City and Stuyvesant Town, said yesterday that it had signed a $38.4 million deal to sell 52 percent of its shares to a group of investors.

title: His Quill Is Fast
description: I'm just as disgusted as you are by Dick Morris taking zillions to write a book about how he elected President Clinton. It is shocking, and when I recover I shall write a column that will make patriots weep.

title: Lone Balloonist Tries for Trip Around World
description: As hundreds of spectators watched, a balloon piloted by Steve Fossett rose last night from Busch Stadium in St. Louis to begin what Mr. Fossett hopes will be the first nonstop balloon flight around the world.

title: Peru Rebels Fire Guns From Residence, but No One Is Hurt
description: Leftist rebels fired eight gunshots today from the Japanese Ambassador's residence, where they are holding 74 hostages, a day after plans for renewing direct talks between them and the Peruvian Government fell apart.

title: City Spending Less Per Pupil, Report Shows
description: The Board of Education is spending less money per student now than at any time in the last decade, a new budget analysis shows, even as the reading scores of third and sixth graders in New York City have fallen to their lowest point in nine years.

title: Motions Implying Reflection
description: The stage was bare except for a piano at which Richard Moredock sat playing Chopin. But when Isabelle Guerin and Damian Woetzel entered this space in Jerome Robbins's ''Other Dances,'' they might have been lovers strolling through a forest in the moonlight.

title: Army Has Final Say on Justice in Guatemala
description: To the Editor:

title: A Welcome Dialogue in Bulgaria
description: Bulgarians, inspired by their neighbors in Serbia, have taken to the streets to try to remove a Government that is one of the most inept in Europe. The strategy may be working. Yesterday the Government agreed to the protesters' main demand of early elections, though not early enough. New elections should be held this year, not in 1998. Nevertheless, the Government response suggests that a political dialogue may be possible in a country where inflexibility has been the rule.

title: Airbus to Be An Independent Corporation
description: Pressured by Boeing's plan to acquire McDonnell Douglas, the four partners in the European Airbus Industrie consortium said today that they had agreed to make Airbus an independent corporation.

title: Race Reconsiders Safety
description: Organizers of a round-the-world yacht race scheduled to begin in the United States in 1998 said yesterday that they were re-evaluating some of their safety rules. The reconsideration, discussed at the Sail Expo boat show in Atlantic City, was prompted by recent rescues in the Vendee Globe Challenge, a similar ocean race for solo sailors that began Nov. 3 in France. DAN McCONNELL, a spokesman for the Around Alone competition -- a successor to the former BOC Challenge -- said officials are reacting to capsizings by three yachts in the oceans south of Australia. In particular, Around Alone organizers will consider rules on how far south its race fleet will be allowed to sail in the treacherous waters 2,000 miles below Australia.

title: Bruno Suggests Retribution To Block Rent-Rules Revolt
description: Facing a possible revolt among some fellow Republicans over his plan to abolish almost all rent regulations in New York, the Republican leader of the State Senate threatened retribution today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday showing the most recent expansion fees paid in four professional sports leagues misidentified the teams paying the most recent fees in Major League Baseball. They are the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, not the Colorado Rockies and Florida Marlins. The Arizona and Tampa Bay teams, which will start playing in 1998, are both paying $130 million.

title: Fidelity Will Take Its Case Directly to Its Fund Investors
description: Fidelity Investments, stung by criticism in the last year over the performance of its mutual funds and a rash of departures from the ranks of its highly respected portfolio managers, has decided to take its case directly to the people.

title: Going Sheer but Not Going Overboard
description: The freshest styles for spring are feminine and romantic, all wispy chiffons, laces and delicate meshes, many in pale colors and soft floral prints. ''It's a new way to look,'' said Dawn Mello, the president of Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Limited to Close 200 of Its Stores
description: Limited Inc. said today that it planned to close 200 underperforming women's apparel stores this year and had made shifts in two executive posts.

title: A Cinderella of a City, And It's Nearly Midnight
description: It is one of the few paradoxes of this bland city that for all its days as a hub of the cold war, it never even began to shake the sobriquet attached to it decades ago by John Le Carre: a small town in Germany.

title: What Bibi Got
description: Benjamin Netanyahu spent most of the last few months trying to show the world that he was negotiating with the Palestinians in good faith. Now he faces the job for which he was elected: either show Israelis that he can give them a peace with security for themselves and their country, or in decent time tell them that it cannot be done, not now and probably not for many years to come.

title: Edna Morris, 88, Horse-Racing Figure And a Fund-Raiser
description: Edna Morris, prominent in thoroughbred racing and social circles for more than 50 years and a major fund-raiser for the Girl Scouts of Greater New York, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: Heating Oil Prices Slip a Bit As Inventories Seem Sufficient
description: The prices of heating oil fell to a one-month low yesterday, dragging crude oil prices lower, on mounting perceptions that inventories will be adequate this winter.

title: Citing Its Side Effects, F.D.A. Weighs Ban on Allergy Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday proposed to ban Seldane, a widely prescribed antihistamine, because of rare but potentially deadly side effects. Seldane can cause fatal heart-rhythm abnormalities, particularly when it is taken with other drugs, the Federal agency said.

title: ZURICH INSURANCE TO ACQUIRE REMAINDER OF U.S. UNIT
description: The Zurich Insurance Company of Switzerland said yesterday that it planned to buy the 34 percent it does not already own of Zurich Reinsurance Center Holdings Inc. for $323 million. Zurich Insurance said it would pay $36 a share for its United States unit, a 17 percent premium over Friday's closing price of $30.75. Zurich Reinsurance Center Holdings, a casualty and property reinsurer, is based in New York. Its shares rose $7.125 yesterday, to $37.875. The American depository receipts of Zurich Insurance fell 75 cents, to $53.25.

title: SANTA FE PACIFIC TO MEET WITH NEWMONT ON OFFER
description: The Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corporation said it would meet with the Newmont Mining Corporation to discuss Newmont's sweetened takeover offer. But Santa Fe, which is based in Albuquerque, N.M., also said that no decision had been made about whether to end a December agreement to be acquired by the Homestake Mining Company. Newmont, based in Denver, raised its stock-swap offer for Santa Fe last week to $16.50 a share, or $2.2 billion. The latest offer, to swap 0.40 Newmont share for each share of Santa Fe, is 10 percent more than Newmont's initial offer, made last fall. Newmont said its new offer topped Homestake's bid. Last month, Santa Fe accepted a bid from Homestake to swap 1.115 of its shares, worth about $17.42 each, for each Santa Fe share. But by the time Newmont issued its revised bid last week, Homestake shares had fallen, making Homestake's offer worth about $15.47 for each Santa Fe share. Shares of Santa Fe fell 25 cents yesterday, to $15.625, and Newmont fell 50 cents, to $40.50. Shares of Homestake, based in San Francisco, rose 12.5 cents, to $14.

title: Helen Foster Snow, 89, a Founder Of Industrial Co-ops in China
description: Helen Foster Snow, who helped bring social change to China in the 1930's, witnessed revolution and war and throughout wrote to promote American-Chinese understanding, died on Saturday at the Fowler Nursing Center in Guilford, Conn. She was 89 and lived in Madison, Conn.

title: New Masters of the Universe for the Go-Go 1990's
description: ''Betting on the Market'' is a zestful yet cautionary look at the go-go bullishness that has come over the nation in the 1990's.

title: Oakland Scratches Plan To Teach Black English
description: Hoping to quell the uproar set off by its resolution to treat black English as a second language in its classrooms, the Oakland school board will scratch parts of a plan that suggested it would offer instruction in the tongue that some linguists call ebonics, school officials said today.

title: Ameritech Exceeds Earnings Expectations
description: The Ameritech Corporation reported a better-than-expected 38 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday that was fueled by services including Caller ID and by an increase in the number of pager and cellular telephone customers.

title: A Pinelands Goal Is Reached
description: The Pinelands Commission, which has overseen land preservation in the Pine Barrens since 1979, has reached its initial goal of safeguarding 100,000 acres, officials said yesterday. Within three to five years, the commission hopes to use $9 million in Federal funds to acquire another 26,000 acres of land, said Terrence D. Moore, the executive director of the commission.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Princeton

title: Q&A
description: Seeing Faint Stars

title: Pataki Proposes Agency to Direct All Children's Services
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed consolidating the children's services provided by the state under a new department, giving greater prominence to the state's role as a caretaker of children while continuing to reduce the responsibilities of the state's main welfare agency, the Department of Social Services.

title: Excerpts From Arguments Before the Supreme Court in Clinton Case
description: Following are excerpts from the arguments of Robert S. Bennett, Walter Dellinger and Gilbert K. Davis before the United States Supreme Court today and the questions asked of them by the Justices, as recorded by the Alderson Reporting Company, a transcription service:

title: Exotic Inspirations
description: Fashion's fascination with exotic cultures, especially those of China, Japan, India and Africa, is never ending. But rarely is the influence traceable to one specific culture, so a costumey effect is generally avoided.

title: Two Styles Meet in One High-Stakes Case: Gilbert K. Davis
description: Gilbert K. Davis is juggling two tricky tasks these days. In addition to representing Paula Corbin Jones as he did before the Supreme Court today, Mr. Davis recently decided to run for attorney general of Virginia.

title: Back on Stand, Simpson Again Denies Role in 2 Killings
description: His voice sometimes choking with emotion, O. J. Simpson conceded today in a final appearance on the witness stand that he had his share of human frailties, among them womanizing, but he insisted over and over that he had not killed Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald L. Goldman and instead had done all in his power to help the police catch the killer.

title: Medals of Honor Awarded at Last To Black World War II Soldiers
description: Half a century after most of them died in combat, seven men today were awarded the Medals of Honor that they were denied after World War II because they were black.

title: Can't Afford to Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Referees Are N.H.L.'s Beleaguered
description: Two seasons ago, in the Stanley Cup playoffs, Referee Andy Van Hellemond made a split-second judgment under difficult circumstances. He disallowed a Nordiques goal because the Rangers' Aleksei Kovalev was writhing in pain at the other end of the ice.

title: NCR Forming an Alliance With Computer Associates
description: The NCR Corporation and Computer Associates International plan to announce an alliance today under which customers will be encouraged to adopt software from Computer Associates to manage their NCR computer systems.

title: Boeing Chief Wants McDonnell but Not Old Rivalries
description: It is difficult to doubt Philip M. Condit when he says his most important management rule at Boeing is to be a good listener.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Facing Unrest, Bulgaria Party Makes Offer
description: Apparently in an attempt to insure that it retains power, the Socialist Party, the direct heir of Bulgaria's hard-line Communists, announced tonight that it was ready to enter into a ''wide dialogue'' with the opposition party that has been holding mass demonstrations daily.

title: Cities Line Up To Join The N.H.L.
description: Eleven groups from nine cities started making formal presentations yesterday at a midtown Manhattan hotel for expansion franchises in the National Hockey League. They do not know how many teams will be added (probably two or four) or when (probably this summer) or when they will start playing (probably two seasons from now) or how much a franchise will cost (probably $75 million to $90 million). But all seem willing to be anointed first and learn the details later.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Stanley K. Strachan, a financial journalist who first reported on a 1987 meeting of Charles H. Keating Jr., the savings and loan executive, and five Senators, misidentified the state that one of the Senators, Dennis DeConcini, represented. It was Arizona, not New Mexico.

title: Citadel's President Insists Coeducation Will Succeed
description: A day after two of four women withdrew as cadets from the Citadel, saying they had been harassed and hazed, the head of the college expressed his determination to make coeducation work.

title: Jury Selection Under Way In Megan Kanka's Killing
description: When he walked through the door of the courtroom today, Jesse K. Timmendequas seemed bewildered, as if he were still trying to understand why he ended up here, on trial for his life and infamous enough to have spurred a change in American laws dealing with sex offenders.

title: Two Styles Meet in One High-Stakes Case: Robert S. Bennett
description: For several years now, Robert S. Bennett has been at or near the top of the heap of Washington lawyers who specialize in defending the famous and powerful when they are in trouble.

title: Inside and Outside, Contrasting Images
description: As the day in court evolved, the sobriety of nine robed Justices in the matter of Clinton v. Jones offered a welcome counterpoint to the japery of five raincoated Bill Clinton impostors protesting in mock luridness outside the courthouse.

title: Serbian City Said to Rebuff Opposition On Election
description: The local electoral commission in Serbia's second-largest city has balked at fulfilling a Government promise to honor election results and give an opposition coalition control of the city, opposition leaders said today.

title: Bonds Fall In Advance Of New Data
description: Treasury prices slipped yesterday, as investors awaited reports on consumer prices and retail sales.

title: Partners Vote To Dissolve Odyssey Fund
description: Continuing the trend of dissolving or reducing the size of the bigger investment partnerships, Leon Levy and Jack Nash wrote to their investors on Friday to tell them they were closing Odyssey Partners. They added that two new partnerships would carry on the work of the $3 billion hedge fund, as such private investment partnerships are known.

title: A Tyco Offer Of $4 Billion Is Rejected
description: The American Standard Companies said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer worth $4 billion from Tyco International Ltd. more than a month ago but that it had rejected the overture and prefers to remain independent.

title: COOPERS & LYBRAND TO ADD KWASHA LIPTON CONSULTANCY
description: Coopers & Lybrand L.L.P. said yesterday that it planned to merge the benefits consulting company Kwasha Lipton into its human resource advisory business. Terms of the deal, which is expected to close later this month, were not released. Kwasha Lipton, based in Fort Lee, N.J., will bring 42 partners and nearly 550 employees to the combination. Coopers & Lybrand's human resource advisory practice has 81 partners and more than 1,140 staff members.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Chrysler hopes a corporate-image campaign helps shake the memories of K-cars and bailouts.
description: THE Chrysler Corporation, having just ended a year of record sales, will begin showing new television ads tomorrow as it continues its first corporate advertising campaign in four years.

title: Outcast Gladiators Find a Home: New York
description: A little more than a year ago, city and state officials found a certain style of fighting competition so offensive that they blocked its promoters from holding a match in New York City. Human cockfights, they called it. Blood sport.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Consumer Prices Up 0.3%; Retail Sales Post Small Rise
description: Inflation remained under control in December, and consumer prices rose a total of 3.3 percent in 1996 spurred by food and energy prices, the Labor Department said today.

title: Fresh Grilled Salmon With a Chinese-Style Side Dish
description: This is an extremely simple, easy-to-prepare menu. The flavor of the salmon pairs delightfully with the salty-sweetness of the rice and brussels sprouts.

title: Bhopal's Second Tragedy
description: The leak of toxic gas from Union Carbide's plant in Bhopal, India, in 1984 was the worst industrial disaster in history, with the official death toll now at nearly 10,000. It has also become a cautionary example of how victims can suffer twice. The vast majority of those injured and the families of those killed waited a decade to get financial compensation, and many are still waiting for money, long-term health care and other help they deserve. Last month the Indian Government reopened the claims registry to allow new people to apply. That may correct some injustices, but more needs to be done to bring relief to the victims.

title: Expanding and consolidating, Golden Books takes six floors at Seventh Ave. and 57th St.
description: THE Lone Ranger, Lassie and Felix the Cat are moving to 888 Seventh Avenue.

title: Battles Flare Over King's Lucrative Legacy
description: Twenty-nine years after his death, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is at the center of a new struggle, not over civil rights but over the property rights to his speeches, writings and image.

title: Now Palmer Faces Tough New Course
description: ARNOLD PALMER will not be playing competitive golf for a while. The crowds at the senior tournaments and celebrity outings in which he participates will not be able to take pleasure in that unusual, ferocious swing, one in which it appears he is throwing not only the club head at the ball but his entire body, as well.

title: No Individual Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Accuses a Mutual Fund Of Violating Investment Policies
description: In its second enforcement action against a mutual fund company this week, the Securities and Exchange Commission has accused the managers of the Permanent Portfolio family of funds of fraud, charging that the funds' managers violated fund investment policies and wrongly billed investors in the fund family for thousands of dollars of expenses.

title: Do Children Get Too Much Juice?
description: OVER the last several years research has shown that drinking cup after cup of juice can cause chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain and, in extreme cases, malnutrition. But in a new study a pediatrician reports that as little as 12 ounces a day puts children at risk of obesity and short stature.

title: In Milan, Men Wave Goodbye To Pure Retro
description: Designers have always understood modernism, or so they claim. But look for a little post-modernism in the last six years of fashion, and you are bound to be a bit disappointed.

title: Al Hayat: A Journalistic Noah's Ark
description: On a gentle spring evening in 1966, an assassin walked into the Beirut office of Al Hayat and shot to death Kamel Mrowa, the newspaper's founder, as he checked final proofs of the next day's issue.

title: Monday's Menu Looks to Thomas Jefferson and Virginia
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON would be pleased. Virginia wine, which he tried but failed to cultivate at Monticello, will be served at the lunch following President Clinton's swearing-in ceremony on Monday.

title: AUTOTOTE SELLING OFF EUROPEAN LOTTERY BUSINESS
description: The Autotote Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its European lottery business, Tele Control, to the Scientific Games Holdings Corporation for about $25 million. Tele Control, based in Vienna, is an on-line lottery and transaction-processing company with revenue of $27 million in the 1996 fiscal year.
