Scientific Games, based in Atlanta, makes instant lottery tickets and provides lottery support systems. It had revenue of $149.3 million in 1995. Autotote, based in Newark, Del., makes computerized gambling equipment. It will use proceeds from the sale to pay bank debt.

title: What Crisis?
description: Critics of Social Security claim that the system is near collapse. Privatizing the system, they argue, will give everybody better protection in old age. But without a complete understanding of what Social Security already provides to Americans, how can we know whether to junk it in favor of something else?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREENWICH AIR SERVICES INC., Miami, said its Greenwich Turbine Inc. unit had signed a contract valued at $50 million with a Senegalese utility to build a 50-megawatt gas turbine power station in Dakar, Senegal.

title: Corrections
description: A television review yesterday about ''Bill T. Jones: Still/Here With Bill Moyers'' on PBS misstated the broadcast date. As reflected in the listing of credits, it is being shown tonight; it was not shown last night.

title: Vote Set on Baseball Bonds
description: By a unanimous vote, the City Council decided yesterday to allow Newark voters to hold a special election on whether the city should guarantee a $22 million bond issue to pay for a minor-league baseball stadium in a park along the Passaic River. But a negative vote in the March 11 referendum would have little impact, according to Councilman Henry Martinez, a supporter of the stadium plan, because Essex County has already agreed to guarantee the bonds. But it is not certain that the county would go ahead without support from the city, a county official said.

title: Hilton International wants its frequent guests to have the latest technology for staying in touch.
description: HILTON INTERNATIONAL is investing more than $35 million in a three-year program to develop advanced telecommunications technologies for its guests, including a toll-free telephone number that will follow them around the world when they stay at Hilton International hotels.

title: F.B.I. Reduces Scope of Proposal on Wiretapping Phone Networks
description: Scaling back its earlier plans for electronic surveillance in the digital age, the Federal Bureau of Investigation released a new, more modest proposal yesterday that would allow the bureau to place legal wiretaps on advanced telephone networks, but not with the scope previously contemplated.

title: Ford Sets Sale of Budget
description: The Ford Motor Company agreed today to sell its Budget Rent a Car unit to the agency's largest franchisee for $350 million, as auto makers continue to shed car-rental companies.

title: More Negative Calories
description: To The Living Section:

title: Personal Health
description: I HAVE been asked repeatedly in the last two months about my knees and whether the arthritis remedy I mentioned in a column on alternative medicine was actually working. It is a combination of glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate, natural substances that are centrally involved in the formation of the cartilage that caps the ends of bones.

title: Heresy Brings Hint of Martyrdom to Sri Lanka Priest
description: Before the Roman Catholic Church excommunicated him last week for heresy, few Catholics outside his native Sri Lanka had ever heard of the Rev. Tissa Balasuriya, much less his offending book, ''Mary and Human Liberation,'' which sold all of 600 copies.

title: Yankees' Wells Breaks His Pitching Hand in Fight
description: David Wells, the newly acquired left-hander who was being counted on as a fixture in the Yankee rotation, broke his pitching hand during an altercation in San Diego on Sunday night, and will need at least six weeks to mend. He is unlikely to be part of the starting rotation before opening day on April 1.

title: No Headline
description: ''He still wanted to do a ban, but there's a lot of people who just don't think that it's all that bad of a deal -- that boys will be boys.''

title: Lottery Tied to College Loans
description: Outstanding college loan payments would be deducted from state lottery winnings under a bill approved yesterday by the Senate Education Committee. The measure, which passed the Assembly unanimously in October, now goes to the full Senate. About $100,000 in unpaid loans could be collected through lottery winnings, according to an estimate by the Office of Legislative Services, the research arm of the Legislature. At present, lottery contestants have to pay overdue child support and money owed to the Welfare Department before they can collect winnings.

title: Fannie Mae Profit Meets Analysts' Estimates
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association met analysts' expectations for the fourth quarter with a sharp jump in earnings.

title: With a Nod to Oprah, Mayor Addresses Council
description: With a wireless microphone on his tie and an 83-minute speech firmly embedded in his memory, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday took the City Council on a lengthy tour of his first three years in office and promised a set of appealing spending plans that clearly signaled the beginning of an election year.

title: On Both Sides, Dissatisfaction With the Accord Feeds Tension and Anxiety
description: The message, freshly displayed on the pager that David Wilder wears belted to his hip, was chilling in portent: The Israeli Army had scattered medical supplies throughout the Jewish enclave in this West Bank city, a precaution against a ''massive terrorist attack.''

title: After 3-Day Pursuit, Shuttle Docks With Russian Station
description: The space shuttle Atlantis caught and docked with the Russian Mir space station tonight after a three-day chase across the sky.

title: Giuliani Says City Is Getting Far Too Little From Tax Cut
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday assailed one of the cornerstones of Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed state budget, asserting that Mr. Pataki's plan to cut property taxes in the state by $1.7 billion was unfair to New York City.

title: Where the Fat Goes
description: To The Living Section:

title: Oratory Caught in Scheduling Gridlock
description: January is the month of the grand statement for politicians, a time when they glorify their past deeds and announce their plans for the future.

title: Palffy Will Miss 7 to 10 Days
description: Five more minutes and Zigmund Palffy might still be on his way to San Jose, Calif., to play in his first National Hockey League All-Star Game on Saturday. ''I was looking forward to it,'' the Islanders' star right wing said yesterday, his sprained right shoulder in a sling.

title: Marijuana Advocates Sue To Stop Federal Sanctions
description: A group of doctors and patients advocating the medical use of marijuana sued senior officials of the Clinton Administration today to try to block the Government from sanctions on doctors who recommend the drug to sick people under a new California law.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Inflation Is Benign As Sales Rise Modestly

title: At Center of the Dispute, A Revered, Deadly City
description: Steeped in hatred, throbbing with cries for vengeance, Hebron is where the Palestinian-Israeli conflict has had some of its darkest moments.

title: Ford and Rivals Rewrite Rules of Production in Europe
description: Juan Jose Ubaghs once tried to drop a coin through the engine of the tiny new car that was coming off the assembly line here. It never hit the ground.

title: Young Mezzo Stands Out in Rossini
description: Concert performances of opera make the most sense when the works involved are unfamiliar. Fans and potential producers appreciate opportunities to at least hear worthy operas that have not made it to the opera house.

title: What Pataki's Budget Would Do
description: The Governor's $66.1 billion proposed budget would raise state spending 2.2 percent, and negotiations with the Legislature are almost certain to produce a final package that is larger. That is a marked contrast with last year, when Mr. Pataki proposed to leave state spending essentially unchanged. The Governor's plan would make a sizable cut in Medicaid spending, but most programs would see modest increases.

title: Hipper Hearts: Six New Ways To Blow A Candy Kiss
description: THIS is the time of year when words of love are stamped upon small hearts of pastel-colored candy. ''Be Mine.'' ''Kiss Me.'' ''Cupcake.'' They are sweet standards of old-time romance, of an era of gentle wooing and watchful manners.

title: Wine Talk
description: DANIEL JOHNNES, the sommelier at Montrachet, a prominent Manhattan restaurant, was recently opening a bottle of rare old wine, a 1945 Bordeaux, for some guests. Everyone paid rapt attention as he displayed the bottle, then carefully cut away the top of the lead foil. Gently, he extracted the cork. Only then was it obvious to just about everyone there that imprints on the side of the cork indicated it had been pulled, and reinserted, at least once before.

title: Calories and Math
description: To The Living Section:

title: From Rags to Riches. Then What?
description: When Oksana Baiul of Ukraine won a gold medal at the 1994 Winter Olympics, she riveted the figure-skating world with a story of inspirational triumph over staggering odds. Orphaned at 13, sleeping alone in an ice rink, she moved in with her coach, won the world title at age 15 and Olympic gold at 16. In the span of a year, she went from being an unknown to the most celebrated skater in the world. Some wonder whether it was too much too soon.

title: The West, the East . . . One Sprawl for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboys' Accuser Is Charged
description: Nina Shahravan, the 23-year-old woman who accused Michael Irvin and Erik Williams of the Dallas Cowboys and a third man of sexually assaulting her two weeks ago, was charged today with filing a false criminal complaint.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Pataki Presents Plenty of Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Plastics Factory Is Fined for Failure to Register Work Injuries
description: Federal officials announced a $720,700 fine yesterday against a plastics factory just west of Syracuse where four workers have had fingers cut off in the last 18 months.

title: Jones Case Can Wait Till Clinton Leaves Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Intel Doubled Its Earnings In 4th Quarter
description: The Intel Corporation reported strong fourth-quarter earnings today that more than doubled the amount reported a year ago, and exceeded Wall Street analysts' expectations. Intel attributed its hefty gains to record unit sales of its Pentium and Pentium Pro microprocessors and to high profit margins.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-9

title: Gatti to Fight Patterson In Long-Awaited Rerun
description: In December 1995, Arturo Gatti of Jersey City took the International Boxing Federation's junior-lightweight (130-pound) title from Tracy Harris Patterson in a Madison Square Garden battle so good that it was voted the national fight of the year by boxing writers. Now, after one false start, comes the rematch Feb. 22 in the 3,000-seat ballroom of the Atlantic City Convention Center.

title: Canadians Compete for a Merger and Gold
description: A fierce struggle for control of one of the world's richest gold deposits intensified today as one Canadian mining company tried to break up a deal between two other Canadian companies for control of the Busang gold project in the jungles of Indonesia.

title: Breaking Bread the Belgian Way
description: HEFTY, rustic loaves of sourdough bread are the specialty of a new bakery, Le Pain Quotidien (French for ''the daily bread''), at 1131 Madison Avenue (84th Street). The spacious, countrified bakery-cafe is the first New York outpost of a chain of 23 bakeries in Belgium, most of which are franchises.

title: NEW VENTURE TO CHALLENGE PHONE COMPANIES
description: The Central and South West Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture enabling it to be one of the first electric utilities to challenge Baby Bells for telephone customers. Central and South West said its venture with ICG Communications Inc. would compete against SBC Communications Inc. in San Antonio and the BellSouth Corporation of Atlanta for customers in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana. A Central and South West spokesman said the joint venture would be named CSW/ICG Choicecom and would be based in Austin, Tex., but he declined to say how much the companies would spend on it. Shares of ICG, based in Englewood, Colo., fell 37.5 cents, to $16.625 yesterday, while Central and South West shares rose 12.5 cents, to $25.375.

title: Tight-Lipped and Low-Key Preparations
description: Party planners all over town have been sworn to secrecy. As Inauguration Day approaches, their lips have been sealed by order of their anxious corporate clients.

title: Auto-Rate Overhaul Urged
description: New Jersey drivers have for too long paid the nation's highest automobile insurance rates, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday as she proposed overhauling regulations to allow lower-priced policies for motorists who give up their right to sue for pain and suffering after an accident. In her third annual address to the State Legislature, Governor Whitman cited a range of accomplishments. $(Page A1; see related stories on B5.$)

title: Giuliani Proposes Rail Tunnel To Carry Freight Past Hudson
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed building a tunnel beneath New York Harbor to carry rail freight efficiently between the water-fringed city and the rest of the country, and said the city would study transforming the weed-strewn waterfronts of Brooklyn and Staten Island into a port for a new generation of deep-hulled ships.

title: Police Give Russian Diplomat's Car 3 Tickets in 4 Hours
description: Maybe the cold war is over. But for up-to-the minute feuding, there are always those Russian diplomats and the New York police.

title: Whitman Vows to Cut Car Insurance Rates by Curbing Suits
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that New Jersey drivers have for too long paid the nation's highest automobile insurance rates and proposed legislation that would allow insurers to offer limited coverage for lower premiums.

title: NETANYAHU AND ARAFAT AGREE ON ISRAELI PULLOUT IN HEBRON
description: Meeting in the middle of the night at a military base between Israel and the Gaza Strip, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, today finally sealed the long-delayed deal on a partial Israeli withdrawal from Hebron.

title: How the Joffrey Became So American
description: THE JOFFREY BALLET

title: On Road to Recovery, Armstrong Is Gaining
description: His numbers are good and getting better, and so is he, Lance Armstrong happily said today.

title: U.S. public pension investors are eager pilgrims in Shanghai.
description: FOR a bunch of money managers with $234 billion to invest, China can look awfully tempting.

title: Berganza Is Replaced
description: The mezzo-soprano Teresa Berganza has canceled her recital at 5 P.M. on Jan. 26 at Alice Tully Hall because of a scheduling conflict. She is to be replaced by the mezzo-soprano Monica Groop in a program of works by Schubert, Ravel and Brahms. Rudolf Jansen is to be the accompanist. Remaining tickets are $25. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: McCarver Returns With Mets
description: TIM McCARVER will return for two more years of Mets telecasts on WWOR-TV, the final two years of the team's deal with the station. Channel 9 is reducing its schedule from 75 to 50 games, some of which McCarver will miss to call games for Fox.

title: Lord Todd, 89, a Nobelist For Work on Nucleic Acids
description: Alexander Robertus Todd, a Scottish biochemist whose investigations of the building blocks of heredity earned him the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1957, died on Friday in Cambridge, England, where he made his home. He was 89.

title: A New Optimism Grows at Howard University
description: When H. Patrick Swygert was named president of Howard University in April 1995, the historically black university faced immediate problems. Morale was low. Enrollment had fallen. Finances were tight. And the House Budget Committee had voted to end the $200 million annual subsidy to the university, about 40 percent of Howard's operating budget.

title: For Clinton, the District Becomes a New Priority
description: ''I expect to be out in the city a lot,'' President-elect Clinton said four years ago as he took a symbolic stroll down Georgia Avenue in the District of Columbia, underscoring his concern for the city.

title: Sara Lee Units And Ammirati Part
description: The Hillshire Farm and Kahn's division of the Sara Lee Corporation and its agency of six years, Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, have agreed to part ways. The account, with billings estimated at $15 million, has been placed in review.

title: Accused Youth Waives Right
description: The teen-ager accused of killing a Tinton Falls teacher who left a tape recorder running during the last hour of her life waived his right yesterday to be tried as a juvenile, officials said yesterday.

title: N.C.A.A. Seeks an End to Gambling Ads
description: Chris Chirimbe's advertisement said, ''I know how bad you feel and I know how desperately you need some big winners.'' Scott Thompson's offered ''three days of guaranteed free winners,'' while Sal Conti's boasted, ''Winners -- you need them, we've got them -- Free! Free! Free!''

title: Don't Look to Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: After a War, a New Normalcy: Parking in Manhattan
description: Taking a break from his job parking cars in a midtown Manhattan garage, Amir Behic drew slashes with a black pen across the weather map of his Croatian newspaper, circling cities and sketching new borders as he explained in halting English how the Yugoslav army surrounded his town four years ago.

title: Archer Daniels Informer Admits Recent Deception
description: The chief informant in a sweeping criminal antitrust investigation has conceded that he fabricated some documents to support his allegations of wrongdoing by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and sought hospitalization yesterday for his poorly controlled manic depression.

title: New York-New York, It's a Las Vegas Town
description: The Brooklyn Bridge will take you past the Whitney Museum, which is just down the way from the Haughwout Building, which almost nestles with Grand Central Terminal, which is right next to Ellis Island. If this confuses you, you can just look up and see the Empire State Building, which stands next to Lever House, which isn't far from the Chrysler Building.

title: Making Champagne Wait
description: To The Living Section:

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about Liza Minnelli in the musical ''Victor/Victoria'' misidentified the composer of the song ''Who Can I Tell?'' The lyrics and music are by Leslie Bricusse, not Frank Wildhorn.

title: White House Offers New Ties to District
description: The White House today unveiled a sweeping plan to rescue the nation's capital by transferring to the Federal Government many responsibilities that the city government proved unable to perform.

title: David Brodsky, 66, Executive of Educational Testing Service
description: David J. Brodsky, who retired in 1993 as executive vice president of the Educational Testing Service, died on Sunday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. Mr. Brodsky, who made his home in Princeton, was 66.

title: For the Knicks, Barkley's Bark Is as Bad as His Bite
description: The taunts kept coming, following every shot he made, each one louder and more derisive than the one before.

title: Corrections
description: Excerpts yesterday from arguments before the Supreme Court over whether Paula Corbin Jones can proceed with her sexual harassment lawsuit against President Clinton, and a highlighted quotation, misspelled the name of a member of Congress who proposed the 25th Amendment to the Constitution. He was Emanuel Celler, not Emmanuel Cellars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON, who wore clothes by relatively obscure designers for President Clinton's first inauguration, has turned to OSCAR DE LA RENTA this time.

title: In Balanchine's Tribute, an Inspiration to Dance
description: George Balanchine paid choreographic tributes to both Stravinsky and 19th-century classics and Peter Martins honored the neo-classicism of Balanchine and Stravinsky in works the New York City Ballet presented on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Plus, Slimming Beer
description: To The Living Section:

title: Living Wills Aside, Dying Cling to Hope
description: MANY Americans state adamantly that they do not want to die in a nursing home or a hospital or, worse yet, in an intensive care unit. They say that when their time comes, they want to slip away gently, surrounded by loving friends and family.

title: Democrat Quits Ethics Panel Over Leak of Gingrich Tape
description: Representative Jim McDermott of Washington stepped down from the House ethics committee today, seeking to still the controversy over his role in the publication of a tape-recorded conversation involving Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Book : THE LETTERS OF NANCY MITFORD & EVELYN WAUGH
description: LETTERS OF NANCY MITFORD & EVELYN WAUGH

title: Democrats Hear an Address And See Only a Candidate
description: If there was any question about how closely Gov. Christine Todd Whitman analyzed last November's election results -- in which a strong turnout in urban areas helped cause her party's candidates for the White House and the United States Senate to lose by wide margins -- the answer came today.

title: Car Dealerships Are Facing Consolidation And Change
description: Auto dealerships are rapidly beginning to issue stock or to be bought by publicly traded companies, a trend that could transform one of the last bastions of mom-and-pop businesses in American retailing.

title: Change of Marketers At Miller Brewing
description: The Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee is unexpectedly changing its vice president for marketing by hiring Jack Rooney, a longtime agency executive, to replace Neil Harrison, who had held that post since March 1993.

title: Pataki Budget Tries New Tack
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a $66.1 billion budget today that relies heavily on strong economic growth and cuts to higher education and health care programs to finance additional spending on public schools and prison construction as well as a new round of tax cuts.

title: Vow to Restore Arts Classes
description: After cuts to arts and cultural programs in public schools that go back many years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he planned to restore those programs ''to every single school in the city.''

title: A Rhodes Scholar's Strength Is Forged In the Torment of His Father's Scandal
description: When Cadet Adam Ake, first in his class at the United States Military Academy here, was honored last month with a Rhodes Scholarship, the Governor of his home state of Alaska sent the boilerplate congratulatory letter.

title: An Ambitious Plan For the Capital City
description: The Clinton Administration yesterday proposed major changes in the way the District of Columbia is run, the latest and most ambitious effort to help the financially struggling city. Under the plan, the Federal Government would take over many of the functions now handled by the city and assume a $4.3 billion unfunded pension liability, and the annual Federal payment to the city would be discontinued.

title: Child Support Fraud Charged
description: In 1978, when Addie Hart asked an Essex County judge for child support for her year-old son, the court ordered the child's father to comply, prosecutors said. But in 1985, Ms. Hart asked another judge to compel a second man to provide support for the same child. Prosecutors said Ms. Hart had tricked both the court and the second man into believing that he was the child's father. For more than a decade, they say, Ms. Hart collected money from both men. Yesterday, a grand jury charged Ms. Hart, now 48, of Irvington, with stealing $20,890 in payments.

title: INSIDE
description: Newspaper Is a Survivor

title: Giants Reach An Accord With Fassel
description: At the Senior Bowl in Mobile, Ala., this week, Jim Fassel was nowhere to be found. The Arizona Cardinals' offensive coordinator had instead traveled with his wife to New Jersey, where he spent much of yesterday working out the details to become the Giants' next head coach.

title: New Assignments For 2 Agencies
description: Two consumer marketers have made changes on their accounts.

title: Over Protests, Potential Juror Is Chosen in Megan Kanka Case
description: The first potential juror was selected in the Megan Kanka murder trial today, despite objections from the defense because the man said he knew about ''Megan's Law.''

title: Scattered Signs of Jitters In Aftermath of U.N. Bombs
description: In Queens, subway service was disrupted for an hour when someone spotted a package on the Queens Plaza platform in Long Island City that looked suspicious, but turned out to be harmless. In Manhattan, the Police Department's bomb squad dashed to the Iranian Mission, but it was a false alarm.

title: Conspiracy Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: A 'Puritani' With Everything It Requires (and Then Some)
description: Bellini can work only stupendously or not at all. On Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera, his swan song, ''I Puritani,'' was mostly stupendous and at times a little more.

title: In a Broadway Macho Race, Who Has the Longest Note?
description: What distinguishes the nondancing male star in a Broadway musical from the other men in the cast? As the title song of ''Leading Men Don't Dance,'' a jaunty new cabaret revue, puts it: ''Our teeth are whiter/Our jaws are stronger/Our pants are tighter/We do that matinee idol thing.''

title: PAYLESS SHOESOURCE TO ADD SUBSIDIARY OF J. BAKER
description: Payless Shoesource Inc., a discount shoe retail chain, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire J. Baker Inc.'s Parade of Shoes subsidiary. Financial terms were not disclosed. Payless, based in Topeka, Kan., said Parade of Shoes, which had sales of $113 million in 1995, would operate as a separate division. The company said it intended to retain many Parade of Shoes employees. Payless was spun off from the May Department Stores Company in May. The company said it had sales of $2.2 billion in the 11 months ended Jan. 4. J. Baker is based in Canton, Mass. Payless also said it planned to buy back $150 million of the company's 39.9 million shares outstanding. Shares of Payless closed up $2.375 yesterday at $37 each.

title: Ruling Hints Milosevic May Yield Belgrade to Opposition
description: In a move that could signal a Government decision to give up its attempt to annul local elections, electoral commissions in Belgrade and Serbia's second-largest city said today that opposition victories should be honored.

title: A Scene From Pages Of Tolstoy: At the Ball
description: Slim and eager as a Tolstoy heroine, Marina Katina, 17, took her preordained place in the French quadrille and swept down the ballroom parquet in a flowing baby blue gown.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Florida couple who said they taped a cellular transmission of a conversation involving Speaker Newt Gingrich referred incorrectly to Representative Karen L. Thurman of Florida, to whom the couple first took the tape. Ms. Thurman's office said she did not listen to the tape.

title: BLUE CROSS PLANS AGREE TO JOINT OPERATION
description: The Blue Cross and Blue Shield plan for Maryland and the one for Washington, D.C., said yesterday they would form a joint holding company with more than $3 billion a year in health insurance revenue and more than two million customers. The two plans said they would remain separate and would operate the holding company as equal partners. The deal must be approved by the insurance commissioners in the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia.

title: Only Law Can Guarantee Us the Right to Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Woes by Day, Cross-Dressing by Night
description: If clothes make the man, what do a red silk dress and matching heels do for him?

title: Parcells and His Staff Master Playoff Defense
description: No matter what the odds say, the New England Patriots have a powerful precedent on their side as they prepare for Super Bowl XXXI -- the defensive innovations put together by Bill Parcells and his staff. And that, in turn, could mean the high-scoring Green Bay Packers will be in for the surprise of their season.

title: Crispy Biscotti That Stand Up To the Dunk Test
description: JULIE CANEPA seems determined to rescue biscotti, the hard Italian dipping biscuits. Unlike many American permutations that are too soft, too sweet and too complicated, Ms. Canepa's Best Biscotti are remarkably like the original.

title: A Kind to Animals Hunk?
description: To The Living Section:

title: Facing Up Later
description: To the Editor:

title: LESLIE FAY DELAYS HEARING ON PLAN TO EXIT BANKRUPTCY
description: The Leslie Fay Companies said yesterday that a hearing on a plan to leave Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection had been postponed until Feb. 13 because it had not completed financing and other details of its reorganization. The clothing corporation, based in New York, entered bankruptcy proceedings in 1993 after an accounting scandal and had been scheduled to seek approval yesterday of its plan to split into two makers of women's apparel. Alan Miller, a lawyer for Leslie Fay, said the corporation had not finished arranging $130 million in financing. Creditors, who are owed $350 million, are expected to receive shares of the two new companies and debt securities.

title: Roll Like One Caused by Icing Preceded Crash of Plane Near Detroit
description: The Delta Connection flight that crashed on approach to Detroit Metro Airport on Jan. 9, killing 29 people, went through an uncontrolled roll to the left and then a jerk in that direction a few seconds before the crash, according to information released Monday night by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Using Black English Well (or Not)
description: It was sometime in the early 1970's that a black parent, listening to her daughter chat on the telephone with a friend, remarked: ''Your black voice is too crude. You sound like a white rock-and-roller. Why do they sing as if all Negroes came from the same part of Mississippi?''

title: Trenton Approves 17 Independent Public Schools, and Rejects 17
description: The Department of Education today granted state charters to 17 innovative schools, paving the way for more than 2,000 students to enroll next fall in autonomous public schools throughout New Jersey.

title: Desperate Devils Manage A Victory
description: The Devils and Martin Brodeur were desperate for a victory before tonight's game with the Boston Bruins, and had to hold on desperately to achieve it after going ahead by 3-0.

title: Banco Popular of Spain Says Profit Rose 6.1%
description: Banco Popular S.A., Spain's fourth-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that profit in 1996 rose 6.1 percent, to 61 billion pesetas ($459 million), as falling interest rates put pressure on loan revenue.

title: New Era for N.C.A.A.: Cooperation
description: Operating for the last time under the traditional one-school, one-vote approach, the 91st National Collegiate Athletic Association convention reflected a sometimes startlingly different outlook from sessions of recent years.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Brooklyn Waterfront
description: EARLY 1800's -- Brooklyn is incorporated as a village in 1816 and construction begins on the Brooklyn Navy Yard in Wallabout Bay. After the Erie Canal opens in 1825, waterfront warehouses and factories begin to appear along the East River.

title: A Softening Of the Hawk
description: A cartoon in The Jerusalem Post on Tuesday showed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu looking into a mirror with a copy of the Hebron agreement in his hand, and seeing an image of Shimon Peres reflected back at him.

title: Lawsuit Fights Albany's On-Line Obscenity Ban
description: A coalition including library groups, publishers and Internet companies asked a Federal court in Manhattan yesterday to block a New York State law banning the on-line transmission of indecent material to minors.

title: TV Notes
description: Rated NY, for 'Not Yet'

title: Hubble Detects Stars Belonging To No Galaxy
description: Astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope have discovered that some stars do not have a galaxy to call home. Somewhere along the way, they wandered off or were tossed out of the galaxy of their birth, out into the cold, dark emptiness of intergalactic space.

title: German Cabinet Backs Selling Lufthansa
description: The German Government said today that it would sell its remaining stake in Lufthansa, approving legislation intended to keep the carrier in German hands.

title: Letter-Bomb Hunt Stepped Up on 3 Continents
description: Law enforcement authorities on three continents today intensified their investigation into a mysterious letter-bomb campaign in which 18 greeting cards booby-trapped with high explosives were sent to an Arabic language newspaper and a Federal prison.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Sallie Mae Earnings Rise 9% in Quarter
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association said yesterday that its earnings grew 9.1 percent in the fourth quarter as it increased its portfolio of student loans and won a partial victory in a lawsuit over fees.

title: A Setback for Nets' Bradley
description: SHAWN BRADLEY was on the phone from his hospital bed yesterday, telling his teammates how he had felt feverish over the past 24 hours. That was not a good sign for the Nets. Bradley's expected 10-day absence when he fell ill a week ago has turned into three weeks. Bradley, who has been in Hackensack University Medical Center in New Jersey since last Friday, may be released today.

title: Leaders Drop Candidate Plan
description: Democratic Party leaders have decided to abandon their effort to anoint a consensus candidate before the gubernatorial primary in June, B. Thomas Byrne Jr., the state Democratic chairman, said yesterday. Several candidates, including United States Representative Robert E. Andrews of Belmar and former Gov. Jim Florio, had lambasted the plan as a throwback to back-room politics of an earlier era.

title: St. John's Is Cold, But Niagara Is Colder
description: Playing in front of a small and unenthusiastic crowd of 6,800, the St. John's Red Storm and Niagara Purple Eagles played a game within a game tonight: Who could shoot colder than the nearby Niagara River?

title: Peugeot Says Sales Rose 4.6% Worldwide
description: Automobiles Peugeot, a unit of PSA Peugeot Citroen, said yesterday that worldwide sales rose 4.6 percent in 1996, helped by a French Government incentive program for new car purchases. Peugeot said 1996 sales totaled 1.17 million vehicles compared with 1.12 million in 1995.

title: All Forces Seem to Be For Interleague Play
description: Just when it appeared that the owners were once again shooting themselves in their collective feet, the Darth Vader of their existence came to their rescue today.

title: France Moves to Crush Corsican Separatists
description: If it expected the usual impunity when it threatened the French Government with open warfare last summer, the most powerful separatist group on the Mediterranean island of Corsica was in for a surprise. Most of its principal leaders are now in jail.

title: Swiss Bank Shreds War-Era Data But a Suspicious Guard Halts It
description: Just weeks after the Swiss Government ordered its banks to preserve any remaining records of their dealings with Nazi Germany, a suspicious security guard at the Union Bank of Switzerland halted the destruction of some documents from the World War II era, including papers that appeared to deal with the ''forced auctions'' of property in Berlin in the 1930's.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Herself to Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO CLOSE BELGIAN PLANT, CUT 225 JOBS
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Belgian heart-catheter plant and would dismiss 225 workers there in a reorganization. Boston Scientific is based in Natick, Mass. The company acquired the Belgian plant in 1995 in its $1.1 billion purchase of Scimed Life Systems Inc., in Maple Grove, Minn. Boston Scientific's new plant in Galway, Ireland, will make the heart catheters for angioplasty and other cardiac operations that had been made in Belgium, the company said. Shares of Boston Scientific fell 25 cents yesterday, to $67.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 300 Semifinalists Are Chosen In Westinghouse Competition
description: There were more than 1,600 in their ranks this year, from nearly every state. For at least a year, they had spent their summers and weekends and evenings pondering mathematical models, or probing the medicinal mysteries of a Ghanaian tree.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday, comparing future technology predicted in the 1968 film ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' with real developments since then, misstated the date of the World's Fair at which AT&T demonstrated picturephones. It was in 1964-65, not 1963-64.

title: Favre to Be Perfect Packer Tour Guide On and Off Field
description: The Packers' quarterback, Brett Favre, can go from the driveway of his home in Kiln, Miss., to the Superdome in New Orleans in an hour, ''driving the speed limit.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column in The Living Section on Jan. 1, about the awards given by the Italian Government to owners of restaurants for serving the best authentic Italian food outside Italy, omitted one of the American recipients because of incomplete information supplied by the Italian Government. She is Laura Maioglio, the owner of Barbetta, on West 46th Street.

title: German Party Replies To Scientology Backers
description: FRANKFURT  Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party on Tuesday issued an indignant response to a group of prominent American entertainment industry figures who compared Germany's assaults on Jews under Hitler to its current stance toward Scientologists.

title: Food Notes
description: Carving a Skyline From Ice

title: Balloonist Reaches Ocean In Bid to Go Around Globe
description: After a smooth launching from St. Louis and an uneventful trip over the Eastern United States, a solo balloonist headed out over the Atlantic Ocean yesterday, beginning what he hopes will be a nonstop voyage around the world.

title: What Hebron Tells Us
description: There are many ways to define the importance of the Hebron deal forged between Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, but for me it comes down to this: The conservative right in Israel has finally recognized what the center and left have known for years -- there is only one peace process, there was only one peace process and there will be only one peace process. It is the Oslo process that Yitzhak Rabin began, that Shimon Peres advanced and that Mr. Netanyahu has now embraced.

title: Pocketful of Miracles, Or Plain Old Oddities
description: Watching tonight's premiere of ''Coast to Coast,'' the latest prime-time news magazine from a network that has had its problems with such shows in recent years, you can imagine the orders given to the CBS News producers who put it together: ''Deliver an upbeat hour, heavy on human interest, light on news, that will offend no sensibilities and strain no attention spans. Shun crime and sex, but it's all right to imitate 'On the Road.' ''

title: A Life Built On Dignity And by Hand
description: THE music has stopped in Jose Otero Cruz's Lower East Side apartment. Hundreds of records rest on cabinets and on the floor, under a shiny arch of album jackets and thick, old-time wax LP's tacked to the living room wall. A nearby calendar is still turned to December, the neat red X's that marked time stopping on the 21st.

title: Plan to Convert U.S. Plutonium Is Announced
description: The Energy Department confirmed today that it would follow a dual track to dispose of excess plutonium from nuclear weapons.

title: Tightening the Welfare Noose
description: During the debate over welfare reform, both liberals and conservatives made the new law seem tougher than it really is.

title: Introducing a Tender, Easygoing Cut of Pork for All Sauces
description: IF some culinary genie were to pop out of a lamp and grant three wishes, a pork lover would ask for a boneless pork roast that cooks in less than 30 minutes and that is exquisitely tender and yet as low in fat as a skinless chicken breast.

title: After the 'Cure'
description: ''The world only spins forward,'' says the AIDS-stricken hero at the very end of Tony Kushner's epic drama ''Angels in America.'' But it's unlikely that even he could have predicted that the world would spin so dizzyingly for people with AIDS.

title: As Term Ends, Bulgarian Is Torn Between Duty and Politics
description: President Zhelyu Zhelev, who was one of Bulgaria's few political dissidents in the Communist era, said today that he would do what was politically unpalatable but constitutionally correct and ask Bulgaria's former Communists, renamed the Socialist Party, to form a new government.

title: No. 2 Official at Justice Dept. Leaving After 3 Years There
description: Jamie S. Gorelick, who built a reputation as a hard-driving, efficient Deputy Attorney General, announced today that she was resigning to return to private life.

title: Stocks Surge, With Several Indexes at Records
description: The stock market staged another broad rally yesterday, breaking records on positive economic news about inflation and retail sales.

title: Looking for Someone On a Crowded Shore
description: Like some poor wretch in a Rodney Dangerfield nightmare, the fabulously wealthy producer Aaron Spelling can often be heard complaining that he gets no respect. That is, of course, not quite true. Some of his television series (''Family,'' ''Hart to Hart'') and movies (''Mr. Mom,'' ''Soapdish'') have modestly charmed both reviewers and audiences.

title: Feasts and Follies Of Inauguration Day
description: SURE, Inauguration Day is important for what is said: the unforgettable lines that historians will seize upon as having set the tone of a Presidency (''ask not what your country can do for you -- ask what you can do for your country'').

title: A Robinson Family Tradition
description: JESSE SIMMS, the heavily recruited two-way lineman from King Low-Heywood Thomas prep school in Stamford, Conn., will follow in the footsteps of his famous grandfather Jackie Robinson and play football at U.C.L.A. The 6-foot-3-inch, 270-pound Simms, who was primarily an inside linebacker, offensive guard and tight end during his four years at King Low-Heywood but also played fullback, was U.C.L.A.'s top defensive recruit. He had been recruited by about 20 Division I-A schools, including California, Penn State, Virginia and Michigan.

title: Applauded for His Rock Opera Trilogy, an American in Paris
description: Robert Wilson's home may be in New York, but to this day probably no city welcomes the 55-year-old American theater director more warmly -- or more often -- than Paris. In November, he directed Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex'' at the Theatre du Chatelet. Next month, he takes on Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande'' at the Paris Opera's Palais Garnier. And this month he has brought ''Time Rocker,'' the last in his trilogy of pop-rock operas, to the Theatre de l'Odeon.

title: Losing Their Cool
description: Smoking is cool. Air Jordans are cool. Anything with the Nike Swoosh on it is cool. Smashing Pumpkins are cool. Absolut ads are cool. Marlboros are cool. Kools are cool (and mentholated).

title: A Specialty Supplier to Chip Makers Is Acquiring Another
description: In a deal that would unite two strong niche semiconductor companies, the KLA Instruments Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Tencor Instruments in a tax-free stock swap valued at $1.32 billion.

title: Of Bodies and Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: Muddying the Gingrich Case
description: The House Republicans have stumbled upon a diversionary tactic that may play well inside Congress but will not fool a public grown weary of politicians who will do whatever they can to avoid full disclosure. Having destroyed any semblance of order in the ethics committee investigation into the conduct of Speaker Newt Gingrich, the Republican leadership now attempts to cloud the issue further by attacking those who have come forward with an audio tape in which Mr. Gingrich and his colleagues discussed ways to limit the political damage.

title: C. B. Huggins Dies at 95; Won Nobel for Cancer Work
description: Dr. Charles B. Huggins, who won a Nobel Prize for discoveries that helped open the era of drug therapy for cancer and provide underpinnings of the modern treatment of prostate and breast cancer, died on Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 95 and had been in failing health for several years.

title: Gold Prices Sink $5 on Fear Of Selling by Central Banks
description: Gold prices posted their biggest one-day loss in 10 months in New York yesterday, reaching the lowest point in more than three years, because of renewed fears that European central banks would sell gold and because of more evidence that inflation remained tame.

title: British People's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Irsay, 73, Executive In Shift of N.F.L. Colts, Dies
description: Robert Irsay, the owner of the National Football League's Indianapolis Colts and the man who moved the team out of Baltimore under the cover of darkness in 1984, died yesterday in Indianapolis. He was 73.

title: Robert Bezilla, 58, a Poll Taker for Gallup
description: Robert Bezilla, a national poll taker long affiliated with the Gallup Organization, died on Jan. 2 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 58.

title: In Her Own Words
description: GOV. CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

title: Mr. Giuliani Picks Good Targets
description: In his three years as Mayor of New York City, Rudolph Giuliani has battled everything from crime to the city's moribund school structure. In his election-year State of the City address yesterday, Mr. Giuliani promised to become a builder as well. His top priorities, he said, will include quality public school education, better police-community relations and a tunnel to provide rail freight service to the city. They are the right goals and deserve even stronger emphasis than the Mayor is proposing.

title: Justices Question Georgia Law Requiring Drug Tests for State Candidates
description: The question for the Supreme Court in a case argued today was whether a Georgia law violates the Constitution in requiring candidates for many state offices to pass a drug test to be placed on the ballot.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When you are becoming a nonagenarian it is no time to depart from tradition, says PAUL H. NITZE, the arms control adviser to every president from Truman to Reagan, who turns 90 tomorrow.

title: British Company Cutting Phone Rates
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C., faced with rising competition in a less regulated market, said yesterday that it would reduce call charges to 33 countries starting Feb. 19. The company said calls to North America would be cut by 20 percent, to Germany and France by 20 percent for daytime calls.

title: Taiwan Awards Licenses For Cellular Phones
description: Taiwan, in a bid to make its communications market more competitive, awarded six cellular phone licenses yesterday to groups backed by some of the world's largest telecommunications companies, including the AT&T Corporation and Deutsche Telekom. The licenses were awarded to companies led by Taiwan businesses. The companies, advised by their foreign partners, could begin operating early next year.

title: Trying to Embrace All That Is or Ever Was
description: What could be more typical of Mahler than his expansive concept of the symphony, expressed during a debate with Sibelius in 1907. ''A symphony must be like the world,'' Mahler insisted. ''It must embrace everything.'' At the time, Mahler was finishing his ''Symphony of a Thousand,'' but his notion of an all-embracing orchestral and choral work can be traced back a dozen years to his Third Symphony, in which he sought to describe everything in the natural world -- and a bit of the supernatural world as well -- in six movements, scored for a huge orchestra and lasting about 100 minutes.

title: Moya Puts Crowd and McEnroe in His Pocket
description: If Boris Becker, the dethroned Australian Open champion, had ventured out to Court 3, a sub-stadium far too tiny for him to worry about performing on, he would have seen a double nemesis in action this morning.

title: Barnett Is Offering $570 Million To Acquire Oxford Resources
description: Barnett Banks Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Oxford Resources Corporation, the largest automobile leasing company in the United States, for about $570 million in stock.

title: Treasury Securities' Prices Rise
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday after investors, concerned that the Fed was on the brink of raising interest rates, were relieved by a Government report showing that inflation was still benign.

title: Politics of Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: A Quarterback Doctor To Get Giants Healthy
description: The man the Giants chose as their 15th head coach yesterday possesses two crucial characteristics that made him their No. 1 candidate all along: He is a known commodity to a franchise that doesn't like surprises, and he specializes in an area in which the Giants desperately need help -- making quarterbacks better.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Jan. 7 about the National Society of Film Critics awards for 1996 omitted one winner. Tony Shalhoub shared the award for best supporting actor with Martin Donovan.

title: Columbia/HCA Agrees to Buy Value Health for $1.3 Billion
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest health care provider, added to its expanding network of hospitals, clinics and managed-care operations yesterday by agreeing to buy Value Health Inc. for $1.3 billion.

title: FLEET TO SELL MORTGAGE, AUTO LENDING AND TRUST UNITS
description: Fleet Financial Group said yesterday that it planned to sell its Option One residential mortgage unit along with its indirect auto lending and corporate trust businesses. The Boston-based financial services company said the decision was part of a plan to focus on core banking operations. Fleet said Option One originated about $1 billion in loans in 1996 and that it serviced about 20,000 accounts totaling $1.9 billion. The auto lending unit, with $1.7 billion in assets, provides new- and used-car financing originated by dealers in the Northeast. The corporate trust unit generates annual revenue of $20 million to $25 million, Fleet said. Separately, Fleet said it planned to buy back about 20 million of its 269 million shares outstanding over the next 12 months.

title: Harold Foote Gosnell, 100, Scholar of American Politics
description: Harold Foote Gosnell, a political scientist who studied voter behavior, political machinations and the ingredients of success in American politics, died on Jan. 8 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 100.

title: Courier Winning the Hard Way
description: Living dangerously, working arduously, and claiming not to mind it, Jim Courier plowed through another five-setter today at the Australian Open, the Grand Slam he won in 1992 and 1993 and in which he is trying to reassert himself this year. After sneaking into seeded contention by winning a title in the desert at Doha, Qatar, earlier this month, Courier has sneaked into the third round the hard way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLL, RICHARD T.
description: KOLL-Richard T. Of Rocky River, OH and NY. On January 14, 1997. Loving husband of Luisa, father of Ann and John and brother of Don. His mind and humor will be greatly missed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BOB LOOMIS, who has been an editor at Random House for 40 years, has always operated on the principle that good editors are invisible, remaining in the shadows of the authors with whom they work. But on Tuesday evening, he was the center of attention at a dinner given by HAROLD EVANS, president and publisher of Random House, at the New York Public Library, to celebrate Mr. Loomis's four decades with the house. Several of the authors Mr. Loomis edits were there to talk about him, among them MAYA ANGELOU, SHANA ALEXANDER, DANIEL BOORSTIN and WILLIAM STYRON.

title: Slaney in Millrose Mile
description: At age 15, her pigtails bouncing with every stride, a California schoolgirl named Mary Decker won the women's 1,000-yard run in the 1974 Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden. Now she is MARY DECKER SLANEY and the track meet is known as the Chase Millrose Games, and she will run Feb. 7 in its women's mile. In becoming America's best women's middle-distance runner, Slaney has won five titles, but none since 1985, in this, the blue-ribbon meet indoor track.

title: Messinger Tries to Define Herself Before Giuliani Does It for Her
description: ''I know who you are! I know who you are!''

title: Judge Rejects Giuliani's Sale of City Hospitals, Citing State Law
description: A State Supreme Court judge dealt a serious blow to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to sell the city's hospitals yesterday, ruling that any such sale would require a change in state law, as well as extensive public review and the approval of the City Council.

title: For Peres, a Sense of Vindication for His Peace Efforts
description: Former Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel welcomed the Israeli-Palestinian deal on Hebron yesterday, saying it vindicated the peace course he had charted with Yitzhak Rabin in the face of vilification from the very people now leading his country.

title: Sex Abuse Jolts Canada's Revered Pastime: Hockey
description: As another winter storm charges in from Georgian Bay, the Owen Sound Platers practice on the opaque ice of the Harry Lumly Bayshore Arena, not far from the water's edge.

title: Foes of Affirmative Action Form a National Group
description: The opponents of affirmative action who persuaded California voters to pass Proposition 209 last November announced today that they had formed the American Civil Rights Institute to argue ''aggressively'' that the rest of the states, as well as Congress, should abolish all race and sex preferences in hiring, contracting and college admissions.

title: The Governor's Divisive Cuts
description: The $66 billion budget proposed by Gov. George Pataki on Tuesday is tailored for his familiar theme that New York State is ''roaring'' back toward fiscal health. But his proposed cuts in higher education and health programs for the disabled, elderly and poor are certain to yank the Legislature right back into the bitter wrangling that has paralyzed the budget process for two years in a row. Despite the Governor's claim, the budget also relies too heavily on the kinds of gimmicks that have given New York the worst credit rating of any state in the country.

title: Stocks Falter as the Dow Slips 35.41 Points
description: The stock market fell yesterday for only the third time this year as investors lashed out at some of the leading technology stocks in a frenzied session of trading.

title: Looking for Changes
description: To The Home Section:

title: House Rule May Rein In Liberal Advocacy Groups
description: Last week, while all eyes on Capitol Hill were on the re-election of Newt Gingrich as Speaker, the House passed a little-noticed rule, long sought by conservatives, that could be the first step toward stripping liberal advocacy groups of Federal financing.

title: Tweaking A Show, Juggling Its Stars
description: The Comet, the sleazy tabloid that was the source of hilarious satire in last year's sitcom ''The Naked Truth,'' has been revamped along with the show. The paper's new owner has the cockeyed idea that a supermarket weekly can actually tell the truth. ''Forty pages with no Elvis sightings, no Batboy, no Big Foot,'' sneers Camilla Dane (Holland Taylor), once the Comet's editor, now demoted to gossip columnist. ''Just rob America of its hope!'' Whether this change will also rob ''The Naked Truth'' of its satiric edge is an open question. What is the Comet without its trashy taste?

title: Civil Rights Group Ends Boycott of Mitsubishi
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the civil rights leader, ended his call for a boycott of Mitsubishi cars and trucks yesterday because the company agreed to take a number of steps to improve job opportunities for women and minorities at its Illinois factory and at its contractors and its auto dealerships nationwide.

title: President to Award Dole With Medal, Aide Says
description: President Clinton intends to award the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor, to former Senator Bob Dole, his Republican opponent in the 1996 campaign, a White House official said tonight.

title: Another Perspective on the Dartmouth Scene
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO REIT PAYING $227.5 MILLION FOR 12 PROPERTIES
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust said yesterday that it had acquired 12 apartment properties for a total of $227.5 million. Equity, a Chicago-based real estate investment trust, said the properties, acquired in nine transactions, comprised 3,931 units. In separate transactions, the company sold three properties for a total of $31.1 million, posting a profit of $3.8 million.

title: F.A.A. TO REQUIRE REPAIR OF RUDDERS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would require changes in the rudder controls of all 1,100 Boeing 737's in this country to prevent a sudden rudder movement that is suspected of playing a role in two unsolved airline crashes in the last six years.

title: Artists Bring New Color To a Gray City
description: ''THE greatest thing about Peekskill,'' Ralph DiBart was saying with barely restrained pride, ''is the mix. The mix is the whole key to our renaissance.''

title: Crime and Punishment: Shame Gains Popularity
description: In the gray winter light, the views along the road into this small town in western Illinois are severe but serene -- stretches of brown, stubbled cornfields interrupted only by the occasional farmhouse. Abruptly a driver's reverie is jolted by the green plywood and white-lettered sign at the end of Glenn Meyer's driveway. ''Warning,'' it reads. ''A Violent Felon Lives Here. Travel At Your Own Risk.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, ELIZABETH (NEE O' ROURKE)
description: McGRATH-Elizabeth (nee O' Rourke). Native of County Leitrim, Ireland, on Wednesday, January 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John McGrath. Dear mother of Margaret Barry, Elizabeth Padden and John McGrath. Also survived by five grandchildren: Gregory Barry, Bridgid Cooper, Michael McGrath, David Padden and Matthew Padden, and many nieces & nephews. Funeral Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, on Saturday at 10AM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Benedict's Church at 10:30 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting on Thursday, 7-9:30 PM and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. James E. McQuade, Director.

title: Apple Reports a Loss of $120 Million for First Quarter
description: Apple Computer Inc. posted a loss of $120 million for its first quarter today and said that it does not expect to return to profitability as quickly as it had predicted, with the first positive earnings not aniticipated until the fourth quarter in September.

title: Jesse Jackson Sets Up Office To Monitor Corporate Action
description: As if Wall Street has not been frenetic enough in recent weeks, it will soon have a new tenant who plans to shake it up even more: the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.

title: Massimino Endures A Rough Night Out
description: Two months after Rollie Massimino led Villanova to the 1985 National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, the colorful coach turned down a multimillion dollar contract to take over the New Jersey Nets.

title: Sometimes a Great Notion
description: ''THIS was a 'bad luck' house,'' Lillian Vernon says, surveying the grounds, lake and pool from the floor-to-ceiling windows of her living room. ''The couple before us was separating, so we got a good price. Four couples had lived here and had trouble. One guy with his tootsie.'' She rolls her eyes. ''But it's been 19 years now.'' She smiles, and the sun prisms behind her, outlining her hair in a rainbow. If she could only see it, she could probably figure a way to sell it.

title: Inquiry on Gingrich Call to Look at Plausibility of Florida Couple's Account
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said today that they would explore whether it was possible for a telephone conversation between Speaker Newt Gingrich and other House Republican leaders to have been inadvertently intercepted through the use of a store-bought scanning device.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADNEY, MARGARET LEFFINGWELL
description: GLADNEY-Margaret Leffingwell, died January 13, 1997, in Damariscotta, ME. Beloved sister of Aillinn Leffingwell Albrecht and the late William M. Leffingwell, Sheila L. Hitchcock, and Ellen L. Grossman. She will be dearly missed by her many nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, MARCIA D.
description: HELLER-Marcia D. On January 14, 1997 at the age of 52. Survived by her loving brother Bobby, his wife Susan and their daughter Lisa. Beloved daughter of the late Justice and Mrs. Louis B. Heller. Cherished cousin of Glenda, Ellen, David, Beverly and Debby. She will remain in our hearts forever. Services today, 12 noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave, (Ave J).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, HAROLD (HAL)
description: KAUFMAN-Harold (Hal), 72; born 12/16/24 died 01/10/97. A memorial is being planned by the family. Please contact for information.

title: Cutting Car Insurance Cost Poses Challenge for Whitman
description: Auto insurance reform has bedeviled New Jersey's last two Governors. Both of them, Thomas H. Kean and Jim Florio, proclaimed themselves champions of change and lower premiums. Ultimately, neither succeeded, and residents still pay the nation's highest premiums and grumble about it.

title: Those Origami Nets: New Jersey Folds Again
description: The new fall lineups are months away, and yet the Nets are already in reruns. It is not a must-see, but a seen-it-before show the Nets are putting on these days, the way they lean ahead in the fourth quarter only to collapse in the final minutes.

title: Images of War, Made Graceful on a Rug
description: PEERING at a Baluchi rug made in Afghanistan or Pakistan, one can see flowers, trees, mountains -- and a rifle. It's possible to spot a helicopter between two mountains. But what about that hand grenade masquerading as a flower? Or that jagged abstract design?

title: Surreal Is Real
description: To The Home Section

title: The Camera-Shy Supreme Court
description: It has long been clear that the Supreme Court's refusal to allow televised coverage of its proceedings has done more than deprive the public of its right to observe the machinery of government at work. It has also denied Americans a chance to be educated on the content and the merits of weighty constitutional issues.

title: South Korean Labor Leaders Falter in Effort to Broaden Strike
description: Efforts to mount an overwhelming show of force by striking South Korean workers fell short today, setting the stage for what could be a winding down of three weeks of labor strife that has rocked the nation.

title: Of Love That Now Can Speak Right Up
description: It's hard to believe, but in 1955, ''South,'' a drama by Julian Green set on a Charleston plantation on the eve of the Civil War, was considered so scandalous by the British authorities that they denied its producers a permit to present it to the London public.

title: Prices of Crude Oil Increase On Yeltsin Health Rumors
description: Crude oil futures soared yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid speculation by traders that the health of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia was worsening, raising fears of political upheaval in the oil producing country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMORE, ANNE M.
description: AMORE-Anne M. On January 14, 1997. Beloved wife of Edward, cherished mother of Ann, Edward, Jr., and Glenn, dear mother-in-law of Kae and Phyllis, loving grandmother of Jackie, adored sister of Angelina Zucaro, Carmine Longo, and Antoinette Capo, and devoted aunt to her many nieces and nephews. This remarkable and beautiful woman will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. In lieu of flowers and other expressions of sympathy, please make donations to St. Francis College, 180 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201 for a memorial scholarship in her name.

title: No Headline
description: ''I want it to be over; I want it to be over. You know, the American people have given us larger responsibilities.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, SANDRA
description: BLASER-Sandra. In loving memory of our dearest sister-in-law and aunt. Love Sandy, Richard and Family

title: Intel to Purchase Stake in Xircom
description: The Intel Corporation has agreed to buy a 12.5 percent equity stake in the Xircom Corporation for about $52 million in cash, and the companies will cooperate on developing new PC Card-based network connectors.

title: A Clearer Road to Mideast Peace
description: The dynamic of peace in the Middle East has a surprising way of drawing even the most implacable foes together and overcoming seemingly insurmountable obstacles. It happened again this week with the agreements reached between Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, two men who were barely on speaking terms just a few months ago.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about job cuts by the Bibb Company misstated the company's stock plans. Bibb plans to list its shares on the Nasdaq market as part of a bankruptcy reorganization that transferred the company to its noteholders. It does not plan a public stock offering.

title: Mexico Repays Bailout by U.S. Ahead of Time
description: President Clinton said today that Mexico had repaid all of the $12.5 billion it borrowed from Washington to stave off a financial collapse two years ago, ending one of Mr. Clinton's riskiest overseas ventures and releasing Mexico from tight economic controls imposed by Washington.

title: Oscar Auerbach, 92, Dies; Linked Smoking to Cancer
description: Dr. Oscar Auerbach, a pathologist who found the first evidence in human lung tissue of a link between cancer and smoking and is credited with discoveries that turned millions of people away from cigarettes, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Knicks Listen To Van Gundy And Top Spurs
description: Jeff Van Gundy put the Knicks through the usual walk-through practice this afternoon at the team's hotel. Twelve tall men invaded an empty ballroom, went over plays and listened to their coach.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: 2 Acquisitions Are Announced
description: Two acquisitions in the outdoor advertising and media services fields have been announced.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROST, FREDERICK WILLIAM
description: FROST-Frederick William, age 85, of Thompson, Connecticut, died on January 15, 1997. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. F.W. Frost of San Francisco, California; husband of Joan Alice; father of Christopher and Jeremy. A graduate of Union College, Schenectady, New York in 1937, he was a Vice President and Manager, Television Art and Production Department, Young & Rubicam, Inc., NY. He retired as Administrative Manager of the N.Y. office. Funeral arrangements are private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Dr. C.W. Lowman Fund or the Crippled Children's Guild, C/O Los Angeles Orthopedic Hospital, 2400 South Flower Street, Los Angeles, California 90016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLIN, JOHN O.
description: MELLIN-John O. Distinguished minister of The First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York for over forty years, died Tuesday, January 14, in Orleans, MA. He is mourned by his wife Gloria; sons John, Jr., Peter, James and Timothy; the membership of the Church and the Village community. Services at First Presbyterian, Fifth Avenue at 12th Street, Wednesday, January 22 at 4 P.M. The family prefers that memorial gifts be given to the charity of the donors choice in Mr. Mellin's name.

title: Tandy Board Is Losing Its Dissident
description: The largest noninstitutional investor in the Tandy Corporation, who is also its longest sitting board member, resigned as a director yesterday, disappointing many shareholders who have looked to him as a voice of dissent on a board that has backed the company's embattled chief executive officer, John V. Roach.

title: Gingrich Phone-Taping Case Strains Belief
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani to Try to Prevent 'Extreme Fighting' Match
description: Just three months after New York became the first state in the nation to sanction an attraction known as extreme fighting, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other New York City leaders are banding together to try to prevent the no-holds-barred matches from taking place within the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, WILLIAM O
description: DOHERTY-William O. Of Pearl River, N.Y., on January 11, 1997. Past Editor and Publisher of the Journal of Accountancy with the American Institute of CPA's. Devoted husband of Margaret. Beloved father of William Jr. of West Haverstraw and Judith M. Doherty of Pearl River, NY. Also survived by three grandchildren. Memorials to Alzheimer's Disease Research, 5825 Shady Grove Rd., Suite 140, Rockville, MD 20850.

title: Outside Art on the Inside Track
description: ANYONE looking for feverish creativity untempered by art- school training need go no further than the annual Outsider Art Fair, Jan. 24 through 26. Among the outsiders with followings that many insider artists would envy is Carlo Zinelli (1916-1973). A schizophrenic, Zinelli spent decades in mental institutions in his native Italy. There he produced hundreds of paintings, often combining figures and nonsense syllables. The 1967 gouache at right is being shown by the dealer Phyllis Kind and is priced at $10,000. The fair is at the Puck Building, Lafayette and Houston Streets. Information: (212) 777-5218. Admission is $10.

title: Officer Gives His Account In Bronx Death
description: After months of street protests and a high-profile criminal trial, Officer Francis X. Livoti finally gave his own account yesterday of a fatal encounter with a man whose death became a rallying cry for concerns about police brutality. But he insistently denied using an illegal choke on the man.

title: Fire Hazards Seen in Some Torchere-Style Halogen Lamps
description: HOW safe are halogen floor lamps? The question was raised last week by the fire that destroyed the Upper West Side apartment of Lionel Hampton, the jazz vibraphonist. The fire burned so intensely and spread so rapidly that in minutes Mr. Hampton lost most of his personal belongings. Its cause was apparently an overturned halogen lamp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, MURRAY CHARLES, M.D.
description: QUINN-Murray Charles, M.D. On January 15, 1997. Devoted and loving husband of Jeanne. Adored and adoring father of Gail and Kenny (deceased). Brother of the late Irwin. Cherished uncle, cousin, friend. Admired, respected and beloved physician for over 40 years. He was a man of integrity, dedication and compassion and he will be sorely missed by every life he touched. Services to held today Jan. 16th at 12:30PM at Congregation Kol Ami (Jewish Community Center) of White Plains, NY.

title: Accounts
description: Informix Software Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., to Young & Rubicam San Francisco, to handle the creative, media and strategic parts of its account, previously at Hodskins Simone & Searls, Palo Alto, Calif. Billings were estimated at more than $11 million.

title: A Take-Charge Fassel Names Brown His Starter
description: Jim Fassel wasted no time taking charge. When he took the podium today as the 15th head coach of the Giants, he made two things very clear.

title: Merrill Hires Retail Head
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had hired Amy Lane to be managing director of the investment banking group for the retail industry. Ms. Lane has headed up the retail sector at Salomon Brothers, the brokerage firm unit of Salomon Inc., which she joined in 1989 from Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Glassware As a Toast to Jefferson
description: FORGET forecasting the look of the new millennium: the freshest designs are often the oldest -- like Thomas Jefferson's wine glasses, now reproduced by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in cooperation with Monticello.

title: Norway's Rieber & Son Bids for Danish Concern
description: Rieber & Son A.S.A., a Norwegian food, packaging and asphalt company, said yesterday that it had bid about 747 million Danish kroner ($123 million) for Phoenix Contractors A/S, a Danish maker of roofing and building materials.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Vermont

title: Hundley and Mets Confront Price of Fame
description: Since baseball was invented, there has always been room for a catcher who bats only .250, hits a few home runs and drives in a few more.

title: Jerry Garcia's Second Wife Wins Ruling in Fight Over Money
description: A nasty fight over the money left by Jerry Garcia, guitarist of the Grateful Dead, may have come to an end here today with a ruling by a Marin County judge that Mr. Garcia's second wife, Carolyn Adams Garcia, was entitled to all of the $5 million he promised her before their divorce.

title: Guerrillas in Peru Assent to Proposal To Seek Siege's End
description: Marxist guerrillas holding 74 hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here said today that they were willing to accept a Government proposal to set up a commission to negotiate an end to the siege, now in its fifth week.

title: Parcells Is Ignored Once Again
description: NOT once, but twice. That's how often George Young, the Giants' general manager, has ignored Bill Parcells when he needed a coach and the ''Jersey guy'' was available. Now and four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MONTE, LILLIAN
description: MONTE-Lillian. 1/16/96. Perhaps the only remedy for grief is time and tears. Love, Marty and Sylvia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAINES, SYLVIA (NEE TOMBACK)
description: GAINES-Sylvia (nee Tomback), January 11, 1997 in White Plains, N.Y. Wife of the late Herman Gaines, she is survived by daughter Julia Hyman and husband Dick, son Edward Gaines and wife Phyllis, brothers Lester and Harry Tomback, five grandchildren and two great grandchildren. She will be missed. Services to be held at noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, New York, Friday, January 17.

title: Look! A Bird, a Plane, a Bucket of Money!
description: To the Editor:

title: Intricate suspense at Conrail as shareholders judge two suitors.

title: Pataki Wary on Financing Of a Hudson Freight Tunnel
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he was not ready to support Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to build a $900 million freight-rail tunnel under New York Harbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, SANDRA BROWN
description: KATZ-Sandra Brown. On January 13, 1997. Mother of Michael and Melissa. Sister of Judi Brown. Daughter of the late Helen and Meyer Brown. May she rest in peace. Service Thursday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHSTADT, HARRY
description: HOCHSTADT-Harry. Temple Beth Torah offers its deepest condolences to Carol Fliegelman, wife of our beloved Cantor Kal, on the loss of her father, Harry Hochstadt, on January 10th. Our condolences as well to her mother, Sylvia, and her children, Stuart and Jody, and Larry, and to the great-grandson, Noah.
