title: Property Tax Reduction Plan
description: Bergen County Executive William P. Schuber unveiled a $446 million budget yesterday that county officials said would reduce the property tax rate by 1.4 percent, saving the owner of a $200,000 home about $50 this year. The budget actually increases spending by just under 1 percent, but it uses a $40 million surplus to hold down taxes for the fourth year in a row, said Charles A. Nurnbuger, the county finance director.

title: Clinton Urges House to Settle Its Differences Over Gingrich
description: President Clinton broke weeks of silence today over the ethics investigation against Speaker Newt Gingrich, saying that both he and the public had grown weary of the partisan bickering over the case and urging House members to put it behind them and ''get on with it.''

title: Connecticut's Top Gambling Regulator Quits to Take a Job With Giant Indian Casino
description: The state's top gambling regulator resigned today to take a job with the giant Indian casino he had been charged with overseeing, bringing a hail of criticism from legislators who called the move a conflict of interest.

title: Isles Break Down Again at Break
description: Even playing without Zigmund Palffy, the Islanders' 2-1 loss to the Buffalo Sabres tonight symbolized their season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRINS, GERTRUDE BUTTENWIESER
description: PRINS-Gertrude Buttenwieser. 1/16/87. Ten years have not erased the pain of our loss. Your family

title: Visiting Mr. Ed, Beaver and Lucy
description: SOME children dreamed of being Beaver Cleaver's friend. Mark Bennett just wanted to live in his house. He memorized the homes in his favorite television series and even made sketches and lists of the family's possessions.

title: Rayovac Picks Young & Rubicam
description: The Rayovac Corporation, the battery maker in Madison, Wis., said yesterday that it had selected the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Inc. to handle its account, which had been handled by the FCB/Leber Katz Partners unit of True North Communications in New York for 14 years. Billings were estimated at $15 million. The decision came after a five-month review that began with eight agencies and had been narrowed to Y.& R. Chicago; the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, a sibling of FCB/Leber Katz; Bozell Worldwide in Chicago, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, which is owned by top managers and the Interpublic Group of Companies. Y.& R. Chicago will work with its sibling, Wunderman Cato Johnson in Chicago, on direct marketing and sales promotion.

title: Jury Seated for Trial In Crown Hts. Case
description: After a week and a half of effort, jury selection was completed yesterday in the trial of two men charged with violating the civil rights of a Hasidic scholar who was killed during the violence of 1991 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Opening arguments are expected today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, EDITH WOLFSON BARNETT
description: HYMAN-Edith Wolfson Barnett. January 12, 1997. Born in Glasgow, Scotland, 1902. Devoted wife of the late Esmond Barnett and the late Ralph Hyman; dearly beloved and cherished mother of Adele Suslak and Victor J. Barnett and motherin-law of Helaine Barnett; loving sister of Rosie Wolfson Martyn, Dolly Wolfson Raisler, Bebe Wolfson Steinberg, and the late Sam Wolfson, Sir Isaac Wolfson, Charles Wolfson, Jeannie Wolfson Williams, Eva Wolfson Gerber, Esther Wolfson Levy, Bette Wolfson Schapiro; adored grandmother of Brian and Annette Suslak, Neil Suslak, Valerie Suslak, Pamela and Joe Ferraioli, Craig and Jennifer Barnett, and Roger Barnett; and dear great-grandmother of Lauren Suslak and loving aunt and great aunt of many nieces and nephews. She will be remembered always for her abiding love of family, her elegance, grace and kindness. Her unique spirit, optimism and great inner strength served as a model for her family and touched the lives of so many people throughout the world. She will always be loved and forever missed.

title: Bruno Says Senate Is Unlikely to Approve Casino Measure
description: Amid a growing campaign by church groups to block a measure that would legalize casino gambling, the Republican leader of the State Senate said today that he considered it increasingly unlikely the proposal would pass in the Senate this year.

title: Harlem Tenements Sifted For Drug Gang's Victims
description: Dozens of police officers and Federal investigators searching for the murdered victims of a ruthless street gang descended on two abandoned tenements in northern Harlem yesterday, ascending to the splintered roof in a metal cage hoisted by a crane and returning with mysterious black boxes.

title: Just Wondering
description: To the Editor:

His fellow directors express their sympathy to his wife Kathleen Pflueger. Harvey L. Parker William L. Mack Arturo H.P. Ramos Leon David Black

title: A Singer Who Has Made Weird an Art Form
description: He has sung a ''sound sculpture'' inspired by a round trip on the E train to Queens, introduced an opera about a secret agent who has forgotten whom he's spying on, and improvised vocalizations in breath sounds ranging from gurgles to clucks to a syrupy baritone.

description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR donated a T-shirt and an autographed canvas bag; FRAN DRESCHER a ''Nanny'' doll; the Beastie Boys a limited edition record, and ROSIE O'DONNELL two Halloween costumes and four T-shirts, all for a young actor they have never met.

title: Japan is in a mess, but there's optimism that the worst is past.
description: THERE'S nothing like a few hundred billion dollars in losses in the stock market -- in just a few hours last week, no less -- to stir interest in an economy's failings. The economy (knock on wood) is Japan, where near panic in the stock market has drawn attention to the surprisingly fragile machinery driving what was long seen as an unstoppable industrial juggernaut.

title: Pacific Telesis and 2 Other Bells In Dispute Over a TV Venture
description: In another digital-age relationship gone sour, the Pacific Telesis Group is clashing with its corporate partners over the future of Tele-TV, their ambitious but troubled phone company venture into television.

title: Defense Hints at Strategy in Trial in Girl's Murder
description: Lawyers for the man accused of raping and killing Megan Kanka suggested for the first time today that they would try to avoid the death penalty for him by arguing that he was a victim of sexual abuse as a child.

title: Royal Ahold in Deal With Royal Dutch/Shell
description: Royal Ahold N.V. and Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that they had agreed to put supermarket outlets in Shell service stations throughout the Netherlands.

title: Porsche will make a splashy debut for its new Boxster sports car during Super Bowl XXXI.
description: THE Green Bay Packers are finally returning to the Super Bowl, as are the New England Patriots. Porsche Cars North America Inc. hopes that may prefigure an automotive comeback: revived demand for two-seat sports cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, ETTA
description: SILVERSTEIN-Etta. On January 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Larry and Klara, and the late Annette. Adoring grandmother of Roger and Liana, Lisa, Sharon and Annette, Laurie, Kevin and Lori, Todd and Julie. Great grandmother of Rachel, Robby, Ariel, Cory, Marty and Zachary. Also survived by her sister Elizabeth. Service Friday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: After Joyful Space Docking, 2-Nation Crew Gets to Work
description: The shuttle Atlantis and the Russian space station Mir began five days of joint operations today as the American astronaut John E. Blaha got ready to return home after four months on the Russian craft.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Dec. 26 listing the 50 largest political contributors included an erroneous figure from the Federal Election Commission overstating the contributions of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation. Records show that from January 1995 through June 1996, the period covered by the chart, Georgia-Pacific made $440,446 in political contributions, not $890,446.

title: Bridge
description: Two star-studded fields will compete in European events during the next eight days. The Cap Gemini World Top tournament begins tonight in The Hague, the Netherlands, and the Macallan International Pairs starts Wednesday in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, MELVIN
description: SCHIFF-Melvin. CPA and attorney. Beloved husband of Rose. Devoted father of Sandra Schiff and Dr. Irwin Schiff. Service Friday, 10 AM at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, (opposite LIRR).

title: At Other End of 'Big Bang' May Simply Be a Big Sputter
description: The end is not near.

title: The Muse of Taos, Stirring Still
description: D.H. LAWRENCE slept here. So did Georgia O'Keeffe, Ansel Adams, Willa Cather, Leopold Stokowski, Martha Graham, Marsden Hartley and Carl Jung, to name only a few visitors to the infamous house that Mabel Dodge Luhan built.

title: REPUBLIC PICKS UP THREE SOLID WASTE COMPANIES
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had acquired three solid-waste management companies for $79 million in common stock. Republic said the three acquisitions would add about $42 million in annual sales. Republic posted revenue of $260.3 million for the year ended Dec. 31, 1995. The companies acquired were Meyer Waste Systems Inc. of Chesterton, Ind.; Monarch Environmental Inc. of Bowling Green, Ky., and Rainbow Industries of Chantilly, Va. Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., also owns auto dealerships and sells electronic security devices.

title: Calendar: Art and Gardens
description: Folk-Art Show and Classes

title: Syracuse Jerks the Hall Back Into Real World
description: Consistency has eluded the Seton Hall Pirates all season, and the problem continues. After stunning Providence, the hottest team in the Big East, last Saturday, Seton Hall faced a struggling Syracuse team that had not won a Big East contest all season, and lost, 83-66, tonight at Continental Arena.

title: A Victory for Pragmatism
description: The agreement between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat to place Hebron under Palestinian rule is a right and necessary step. Yet this is not an easy moment for the Jewish people. Were it not for the aggressive self-righteousness of many Jewish extremists in Hebron, moderate Israelis would probably have been more reluctant to cede King David's initial capital city, where an ancient Jewish community lived meekly for centuries under Islamic rule.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERINI, WALTER
description: PERINI-Walter. November 22, 1950-January 16, 1996 Love always, Laura

title: Martin Gruppen Buys Its French Distributor
description: Martin Gruppen A/S, a Danish producer of computer-controlled lighting and stage equipment, said yesterday that it had acquired SLD S.A., its distributor in France, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Teen-Agers May Get Bail in Son's Death
description: Signaling a new legal strategy, Delaware prosecutors pursuing murder charges against two New Jersey teen-agers in the death of their son said yesterday that they would no longer insist that they be held without bail.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a legal challenge to a New York State law that bans the on-line transmission of certain material to minors misstated the scope of the law. As the article stated, it prohibits transmission of indecent material, not just obscenity. (The courts have ruled that obscene material, which appeals to prurient interest and has no redeeming value, does not have First Amendment protection; the state's power to ban obscenity is not at issue. Indecent material does have some First Amendment protection, though the courts have ruled that it can be regulated to protect minors.)

title: When Money Counts
description: MANY of the most glittering items from January's sales are silver, bronze or aluminum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, WALTER WOOSTER (PHILIP)
description: RICHARD-Walter Wooster (Philip), 77, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, passed away January 10, 1997. He was born in NYC, attended the Allen Stevenson School and Andover Academy, and served in the United States Navy in WWII. A long time resident of Havana, Cuba, he was the owner of Caribbean Electronics. He and his family fled the Castro regime in Cuba in 1959. He had been a resident of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, until the present. He was an avid traveler, a kind and generous gentleman, treasured by family and numerous friends. His memberships included Coral Ridge Country Club, New York Yacht Club, Tower Club, and CSYC. He is survived by his devoted wife, Janet, daughters, Annete Richard of Lansing, MI; Susanne Richard of Houston, TX; Patricia Richard-Ogle of Houston, TX; a son, Philip Andrew Richard of San Diego, CA; a sister, Edith Townsend of Delray Beach, FL and Wakefield, RI; and five grandchildren. For information, Fred Hunter's Fort Lauderdale Home, 718 S. Federal Highway. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice Care of Broward County, Inc., 309 SE 18th Street, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33316.

title: Setback for Giuliani On Sale of Hospitals
description: A State Supreme Court judge has dealt a major setback to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to sell the city's hospitals, ruling that such sales violate state law and first require the approval of the City Council. The ruling calls into question the sale of Coney Island Hospital and the planned sale of other hospitals.

title: Auction For an Eclectic Collection
description: PACK-RAT collectors who are space-challenged had a friend in Robert C. Woolley. A bearded bon vivant and Sotheby's auctioneer, and a grand acquisitor himself (right, in a graphite portrait by Michael Leonard in the Moroni style), he once said: ''Don't fret. Just move everything one inch to the left.''

title: Time Warner Is Licensing 12 Films to Its Cable Outlets
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that its movie companies would license the rights to 12 feature films to two of its cable services, continuing a trend in which big media companies are increasing the value of their distribution businesses by putting their own programming on television networks or cable services they own.

title: Bankruptcies Up 31% In Buenos Aires in '96
description: The number of companies declaring bankruptcy in Buenos Aires jumped nearly 31%, to 1,168, in 1996, compared with 893 in 1995, the credit risk agency Fidelitas S.R.L. said in a report released yesterday.

title: Fickle Winds Change Course Of Balloon Trip
description: As Steve Fossett sped over the Atlantic Ocean in his bid to be the first balloonist to circle the earth nonstop, the winds changed yesterday, forcing him to change course toward some countries that might object to his flying over.

title: Repercussions of Getting a Story by Sneaky Means
description: If a reporter receives credible accounts of dirty doings in the back rooms of a supermarket, may the reporter obtain a job there, perhaps in hopes of capturing the evidence with a hidden camera?

title: From Flexible Flyer To Olympic Favorite
description: When he was 12 years old and on a family vacation in Lake Placid, N.Y., Gordy Sheer copied a phone number from the side of a van and began his improbable career in the arcane sport of luge.

title: Informant in Archer Daniels Price-Fixing Case Is Indicted
description: Mark E. Whitacre, the former executive with the Archer Daniels Midland Company who worked as a Government informant in a sweeping price-fixing investigation, was indicted yesterday on charges that he defrauded the company of more than $9 million.

title: Heavy Supply Of Debt Hurts Bond Prices
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday as investors grew concerned about an abundance of new debt coming to market.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday about the Bhopal disaster erroneously stated in some editions that the award of $5 billion in punitive damages in the Exxon Valdez oil-spill case preceded Union Carbide's attempts to move the Bhopal case to Indian courts. The Bhopal settlement preceded the Exxon Valdez case.

title: 2 Firms Settle S.E.C. Charges
description: Two New York brokerage firms agreed today to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had failed to supervise employees. The commission warned other securities firms to guard against similar problems.

title: Preserving Garden Spots
description: To The Home Section:

title: For Palestinians, New Sense of Order
description: On the morning after the nighttime agreement that sealed Hebron's fate, Palestinians mused today about what the partial end to three decades of Israeli occupation might bring.

title: Swiss Bank Cannot Identify Papers in Cache It Shredded
description: A historian working for the Union Bank of Switzerland ordered the destruction of hundreds of pounds of archives compiled by a subsidiary that had extensive dealings with Nazi Germany, investigators said today.

title: 10 Architects to Compete For Project at the Modern
description: Officials from the Museum of Modern Art confirmed this week that they have selected 10 architectural firms to compete for the commission to design the museum's expansion. The list, representing a broad international scope, is notable for the relative youth of the architects, most of whom are in their early 50's, and for its relative lack of star power.

title: A McCarthy Era Memory That Can Still Chill
description: The shadow of Elia Kazan still hovers over Hollywood.

title: Q&A/ Strobe Talbott: NATO Expansion Is Not Intended to 'Move the Iron Curtain Eastward'
description: Staying on as a principal foreign policymaker in the second Clinton administration, Strobe Talbott, the deputy secretary of state, will continue to be an architect of U.S. policy toward Russia. Prior to consultations in Europe this week with allied governments, he talked to Joseph Fitchett of the International Herald Tribune about NATO's expansion, potentially a crucial issue for future relations with Moscow.

description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP., Maynard, Mass., said it had won a contract to supply the Veterans Affairs Department with computer hardware and software. The contract has a potential value of $1.5 billion over five years.

title: Media Circus Eclipses Story of Colorado Girl's Slaying
description: The first arrests were announced today in the JonBenet Ramsey murder case, but they did nothing to clear up the mystery of who strangled the 6-year-old beauty queen on Christmas night.

title: Sending a Message
description: Whoever sent letter bombs to Al Hayat, the Arab newspaper, missed the main point: In newspapers, you print the message, not mail it with Semtex.

description: FURLONG-Joannie. On January 14, 1997 after a five month battle with lung cancer. She was 65. She is survived by her best friend and companion Bill Marshall; her five grandchildren Robbie, Nick, AJ, Kara and Chris; her six children Anni, Charley, Fal, Jacques, ZaZa and Andre. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Patrick's Church, Bedford, NY on Jan. 17, 1997 at 11AM. Contributions in lieu of flowers, can be made to the House of Peace, POB 696, Bronx, NY 10469.

title: Sports Station Is Ready to Go
description: WBIS-TV/Channel 31 will make its full-fledged debut as a business and sports station next Wednesday night with the Knicks-Bulls game, followed Thursday by an Oilers-Islanders telecast. But WBIS, which has run the Classic Sports Network and infomercials since July, declined to say how many other hockey and basketball games moved from MSG and SportsChannel it would run.

title: In the Fight Over Medicaid Cuts, Signs of a Tense Year in Albany
description: Representatives of the health care industry today began a fierce attack on the deep cuts Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed for the state's Medicaid program, saying the reductions would be devastating for elderly and disabled residents of the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYAMS, PHILIP
description: HYAMS-Philip. The Board of Directors of America-Israel Cultural Foundation extends its heartfelt sympathies to Blanche and Romie Shapiro on their loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTHRIE, ELIZABETH A.
description: GUTHRIE-Elizabeth A. The Board of Directors of the Camille and Henry Dreyfus Foundation records with deep sorrow the death of our dear friend and colleague on January 13, 1997. We remember her intelligence and strength of purpose, qualities which contributed substantially to the Foundation's work throughout her 41 years of service. Her enthusiasm and courage were inspiring, and she will be greatly missed. We extend condolences to her family, and especially to our fellow director, her husband, Henry.

description: SCHWARTZ - Joseph. Beloved husband of Dr. Rosalie. Devoted father of Adam and Joy. Cherished son of Henrietta. Dear brother of Judith Millman. Services Friday, 10:15AM, ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: MVSI SHELVES BID FOR NICHE COMMUNICATIONS COMPANY
description: MVSI Inc. yesterday shelved its $60 million plan to buy E-Net Inc., citing the decline in its own stock since its primary underwriter, Stratton Oakmont Inc., was banned from the securities business. MVSI agreed to buy the closely held E-Net for stock in August, when MVSI shares were trading at about $15 apiece. Since then, MVSI's shares have dropped by more than two-thirds because of regulatory problems at Stratton Oakmont, which led a $12.6 million initial public offering of MVSI shares in August 1995. Shares of MVSI, a Vienna, Va., maker of electronic scanner systems, closed down 6.25 cents yesterday at $4.25. Under its accord with E-Net, MVSI will retain a five-year option to purchase E-Net securities in exchange for a $1.25 million loan and the rights to E-Net's Telecom 2000, a system for providing voice communications over the Internet.

title: Paul Kresh, 77, a Producer Who Preserved Poets' Voices
description: Paul Kresh, an author, critic, record producer and broadcaster who specialized in spoken-word recordings, died on Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Major Themes In Life's Smaller Dramas
description: Neil Greenberg addressed the living of everyday life in the three dances he presented on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater as part of the Altogether Different series. That is not an unpopular topic in modern dance, but Mr. Greenberg does it in unusual and thought-provoking ways.

title: G.M. Selects Mullen For Used-Car Account
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had named Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., as the first agency to handle advertising for its certified used-car program meant to compete with chains like Carmax and Auto Nation. Though billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $25 million to $40 million in the first year and as much as $75 million in the second year.

title: Hero as Pitchman
description: To the Editor:

title: ARVIN TO BUY REMAINING INTEREST IN DUTCH JOINT VENTURE
description: Arvin Industries said yesterday that it would buy the remaining 50 percent of its European replacement auto-exhaust joint venture from its partner, Sogefi S.p.A., for about $30 million. The Dutch joint venture was established in 1993 between Arvin's Timax exhaust system division and two Sogefi operations, Rosi S.A. in France and Ansa Marmitte S.p.A. in Italy. Arvin, an auto parts maker based in Columbus, Ind., said the acquisition would add about $100 million to its annual sales. The company had 1995 revenue of about $2 billion. Arvin's shares rose 25 cents, to $25.625, on the news. Sogefi, with headquarters in Milan, Italy, is also an auto components company.

title: ACCORD ON HEBRON GETS ENDORSEMENT OF ISRAELI CABINET
description: After almost 12 hours of what were described as vicious disputes, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's coalition Cabinet endorsed the Hebron agreement early today by a vote of 11 to 7. Officials said Israeli troops could now conclude the long-overdue withdrawal from most of the West Bank city by late Friday.

title: Can England Save Its Hedgerows? Whipping Is Out
description: ''The countrie enclosed I praise, the other delightith not me,'' Thomas Tusser wrote in his guide to English husbandry, and four centuries later that quintessentially British preference for tidily arrayed land is being uttered again across this cherished terrain.

title: The Gingrich Case: When Politics Divides Process
description: Inside the Beltway, the Gingrich ethics case is now just another Washington partisan wrangle, with the Republicans winning and the Democrats losing. Getting Representative Jim McDermott out of the investigation on Tuesday was a trophy scalp for the majority party.

title: Now It's Heigh-Ho, Off to Sea We Go
description: ARE the high seas ready for Mickey moderne?

title: Animals Seized at Farm
description: Animal control officers seized 100 chickens and more than 40 other animals, including a steer, pigs, ducks, dogs, geese, a rabbit and two emus from a nonworking farm in Vineland. Most of the animals looked well fed but were extremely filthy from having lived amid garbage and other debris, said Linda Catalano, director of the Cumberland County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. They will be placed in farms and homes in the area, she said. Bev Greco, manager of the S.P.C.A., described the owner of the home, James Bass Jr., as someone with a ''collector mentality'' who had acquired more animals than he could properly handle. He will be cited for having too many animals on his property and not adequately caring for them, she said.

title: Philharmonic Season Offering 3 Premieres
description: Highlights of the New York Philharmonic's 1997-98 season, which will begin on Sept. 17 with an opening night gala conducted by Kurt Masur and featuring the soprano Renee Fleming, are to include three world premieres, the second year of the orchestra's American Classics survey, the visit of the Polish composer Krzysztof Penderecki for Composer Week in late October and the Philharmonic debuts of the soprano Dawn Upshaw and the bass-baritone Bryn Terfel.

Loving father of Judith Loeb Chiara, Ambassador John Langeloth Loeb, Jr., Arthur Lehman Loeb, Ann Loeb Bronfman and Deborah Loeb Brice. Adored grandfather of 14 and great-grandfather of 24. Dear brother of Henry A. Loeb, Margaret Loeb Kempner and the late Carl M. Loeb, Jr. Interment private. Memorial service Thursday, January 16th, 11 AM, Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65 Street. description: The National Football League's revolving door of coaches made a sudden, unexpected stop here today.

title: Caution Urged on New Shaped Skis
description: A majority of the nation's ski schools this season are swooning over the hourglass figure of the sport's newest innovation in downhill equipment, the so-called shaped ski. But are the skis too good to be true?

title: Whitman Assigns Forbes
description: Last year, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman shrugged off the presidential bid by her old friend Steve Forbes and endorsed Bob Dole for the Republican nomination. But old friendships die hard. Yesterday, Mrs. Whitman said she had established a fund-raising committee for her re-election campaign, and she named Mr. Forbes as a co-chairman.

title: The Lowly Chamber Pot Is Getting Its 15 Minutes
description: A CHAMBER POT may be a homely object, but it will soon have its moment of glory at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum Gallery. ''The Chamber Pot Show,'' in which 20 pots are transformed by artists, opens tomorrow and runs through April 6.

title: ULTRAK ACQUIRING MAKER OF ACCESS CONTROL SYSTEMS
description: Ultrak Inc., a maker of closed-circuit video cameras and monitors, said yesterday that it planned to buy Monitor Dynamics Inc. for about $25 million. Monitor Dynamics, a privately held company in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., makes security and access control systems and is expected to report pretax profit of more than $3.5 million on sales of $12 million for its fiscal year ending March 31. Ultrak, based in Carrollton, Tex., had $101.2 million of sales in 1995. Its shares rose $1, to $29, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Wells's Story Is Said to Call Pitcher Victim

Cisco, the maker of networking equipment, in turn will recommend Hewlett-Packard computers to buyers of its equipment. The companies will also develop standards for Internet security. Shares of Cisco, of San Jose, Calif., slid $1.75, to $70.375. Shares of Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose 37.5 cents, to $54.375.

title: As Fox Prepares Bash, CBS Yearns to Return To the N.F.L.'s Fold
description: On the dais yesterday, there was considerable mirth among the Fox Sports folks, from Rupert Murdoch, their Big Daddy, and Pat Summerall to James Brown and Ed Goren, executive producer of the sports division. And why not? On Jan. 26, Fox will broadcast its first Super Bowl, the largest, juiciest fruit of its four-year, $1.6 billion contract with the National Football League. And all 58 of the game's 30-second advertising spots are sold out for $1.2 million each.

title: Bald Eagle Bounces Back
description: Improving on a trend of two decades, New Jersey's bald eagle population has grown by 56 percent in a year, state wildlife officials said Tuesday. The Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife and the New Jersey Audubon Society counted 176 birds, 63 more than they found during last year's winter count, said Dr. Larry Niles, the chief of the endangered and non-game species program. The bald eagle population increased thanks to a ban on DDT and -- more recently -- the release of offspring of domestically raised eagles into the wild, Dr. Niles said. TERRY PRISTIN

description: KLEIN-Helen. Jan 15, 1997. To our dear, beloved grandmother and friend, we love you and miss you. Ellen, Marcie, Tony and Victoria

title: French Doctor With AIDS Reportedly Infected Patient in Surgery
description: A surgeon suffering from AIDS has almost certainly infected a patient during an operation at a hospital near Paris, the French Health Ministry says.

title: AIRBUS SAYS IT CAN'T GUARANTEE DELIVERY OF JETS TO USAIR
description: Airbus Industries has told USAir Group Inc. that it cannot guarantee delivery of 57 jets in 1998 and 1999 because the airline has not cut its costs far enough, a stipulation of the $2.6 billion purchase. The announcement came as USAir and the Air Line Pilots Association, which represents USAir's 5,000 pilots, began to negotiate on wage and productivity issues. USAir, based in Arlington, Va., has a memorandum of understanding with Airbus, a European consortium, to buy up to 400 planes by 2001, but the purchase is contingent on the airline's ability to reduce costs to a competitive level.

description: Opening a campaign to defeat a constitutional amendment that would require balancing the budget, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today that he planned to warn Congress on Friday that it was on the brink of making ''a terrible mistake'' that would pose ''unacceptable economic risks to the nation.''

title: Treasury Issues Fall In Selloff
description: Treasury securities fell yesterday, as a heavy calendar of new corporate and municipal debt inhibited buyers. A Federal Reserve official's warnings on inflation contributed to the selloff.

title: Ex-French Defense Chief Linked to KGB
description: PARIS  Offering fresh evidence of a former French defense minister's Cold War links to the East bloc, a French magazine on Thursday published what it said are KGB documents showing that the late Charles Hernu was a regular paid informant of Moscow from 1953 to the early 1960s.

title: Benefactor Wants Private Group to Manage Central Park
description: A trustee of the Central Park Conservancy who has donated millions of dollars to it is arguing that the city should step aside and let the private group manage the nation's pre-eminent urban park.

title: British Insurers In Merger Deal
description: Lowndes Lambert Group Holdings P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a rival insurance broker, Fenchurch P.L.C., in a stock deal worth $:27.6 million, or $46 million. Combining the businesses to form Lambert Fenchurch Group will allow the companies to cut costs by at least $:5 million before taxes in the year to end March 31, 1998.

We have decided to redeploy our forces in Hebron, the first capital city of the ancient Israelites and the burial place of our biblical forefathers. Even though I voted for the redeployment, I know that it is no cause for celebration.

description: THE generic flaw of ''political art'' is not that its range is too narrow, but that its subjects are too vast. How can even the best-intentioned painting address a catastrophe as unspeakable as ethnic genocide without drastically softening its impact, even prettying it up?

title: 1996 Sales Fell For Renault's Truck Unit
description: Renault Vehicules Industriels, the truck and bus unit of France's second-largest automobile maker, said yesterday that full year sales fell 16 percent. Car and truck sales totaled 63,680 vehicles last year, compared with 75,770 in 1995. Sales of Renault V.I.'s European unit fell 15.4 percent, to 38,670 vehicles; Mack Truck, the unit based in the United States, reported a 16.8 percent drop in sales, to 25,010 vehicles.

description: The Lincoln National Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy the mutual funds business of Voyageur Companies for about $69 million in stock. Lincoln National will acquire 37 funds with a combined $2.8 billion in assets, including 33 municipal bond funds, from Voyageur, which is based in Minneapolis. For Lincoln National, an insurance holding company based in Fort Wayne, Ind., Voyageur would be the company's second acquisition of a mutual fund group in the last two years. The company purchased Delaware Management Holdings for $510 million in April 1995. Shares of Lincoln National closed down 37.5 cents yesterday at $52.

School personnel have been asked to report all incidents that appear to be bias-related to the local police and the Monmouth County Prosecutor's office, said Frank Lineberry, district administrator for curriculum.

He will be succeeded by James M. Zimmerman, Federated's president and chief operating officer.

description: A former stable hand at the Pelham Bit Stable in the Bronx was charged early today with murdering the wife of the stable owner in a fruitless effort to steal cash receipts he thought might have been hidden in her home in the affluent village of Pelham Manor, the police said.

title: Maine Is on the Road Back

Bundled up in a beige ski jacket and khaki cotton pants, he spoke over the cheers of the Alfond Arena crowd about what it meant to be in this isolated spot 243 miles north of Boston.

description: A 25-year-old computer at the Chicago air traffic control center, probably the frailest major piece of equipment in the Federal Aviation Administration's creaky system, was retired today when its replacement was declared operational, a step the agency says will make air travel faster and more reliable.

title: Ulysses, Ozymandias And Lenin in the Balkans
description: Theo Angelopoulos, the Greek director of ''Ulysses' Gaze,'' had the temerity to envision a Homeric voyage through the Balkans and surround his film's main character, a world-weary film director known only as A., with the self-conscious aura of a mythic hero. When his film won the Grand Jury Prize at the 1995 Cannes International Film Festival, Mr. Angelopoulos cemented his reputation for chutzpah by expressing disdain for what was basically only second prize.

title: Silence of the Beltway Feminists
description: It was American feminism's darkest hour since Eleanor Roosevelt took a stand against the equal rights amendment. Having initially dismissed Paula Corbin Jones's accusations as a right-wing plot against President Clinton, leaders of feminist groups were taunted on Tuesday by a dozen women picketing the Supreme Court on behalf of Ms. Jones. The demonstrators were members of the conservative, anti-feminist Independent Women's Forum, and their signs bore the caustic challenge, ''Where is NOW Now?''

title: America Online Moves to Placate Its Angry Users
description: With its network and the patience of its customers strained to the breaking point, America Online announced a series of new initiatives yesterday to try to relieve the congestion that has led to at least four class-action lawsuits and thousands of complaints from frustrated consumers.

title: A Realm of Poses and Perplexities
description: The Joyce Theater calls its current series of programs by up-and-coming choreographers Altogether Different. Poppo Shiraishi's ''Crazy Me, Crazy You,'' presented there on Wednesday night, was certainly that. When dancegoers entered the theater, they beheld nine toilet bowls arranged onstage like austerely elegant sculptures. Once the performance began, dancers sat on the bowls, embraced them and stuck their heads into them. And they did all this with ritualistic dignity.

title: Americana (and a Few Surprises) At the Winter Antiques Show
description: WITH the number of antiques events multiplying every year, quality is no longer enough: it takes a gimmick to distinguish one show from another. In the case of the Winter Antiques Show, which opens today at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan and runs through Jan. 26, the slant is as American as a rooster weather vane.

title: Collectors Who Could Trust Their Own Taste
description: Although they didn't know each other, as art collectors Charles H. Carpenter Jr. and Charles Simon had a few things in common besides first names. For one, neither played the money-power games of the big bad art world. They rarely sold or ''traded up,'' and they never used their acquisitions for social status or financial gain. For another, they didn't pay much attention to what was trendy, in or out, up or down. Buying more by eye than ear, each was close to artists and dealers (Simon's mentor was the respected Curt Valentin). Pursuing what they liked, they wound up with major holdings.

title: Edwin Sutherland, 82, Soldier and Scholar, Is Dead
description: Brig. Gen. Edwin Van Valkenberg Sutherland, a soldier and scholar who was one of the first Americans to start fighting the Germans in World War II and among the last to quit, died on Jan. 6 at a hospital in Rochester, N.Y. A longtime resident of Amagansett, L.I., he was 82 and had ended his 41-year Army career after teaching literature to cadets as head of the English Department at West Point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLENTINE, GEORGE NEWTON
description: BALLENTINE-George Newton, age 87, an internationally known gynecologist died on January 15, 1997 in Muncy, PA. He was best known for his instrument and equipment designs in the field of gynecology, including the Ballentine Hysterectomy Clamp. A graduate of Bucknell University and Cornell University Medical College in New York City. He was a diplomat of the National Boards and the American Academy of Obstetrics and Gynecology and a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons. A diplomat of the World Medical Association, he traveled to world famous cancer research institutions and operated in many hospitals throughout the world. An American relative of Sir Isaac Newton, he was the son of Floyd George Ballentine and Grace Agnes Newton. He is survived by his son George Newton Ballentine, Jr. Richmond, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, ETTA
description: SILVERSTEIN-Etta. New York University's School of Continuing Education and its Real Estate Institute extend sincere condolences to the Institute's founder and Chairman Emeritus, Larry A. Silverstein, and his family on the death of his mother, Etta. Through the influence of her warmth, strength, and intelligence, the Silverstein family has made extraordinary contributions to the School, the University, and the community as a whole, with Larry's visionary leadership of the Real Estate Institute serving as an outstanding example. It was a great joy to have known her and experienced her energetic generosity, and a great sorrow to mourn her passing. Dr. Gerald A. Heeger Dean, NYU School of Continuing Education Arthur Zabarkes Associate Dean, Real Estate Institute

title: Shipping Out Solid Waste
description: Mayor John Rooney of Northvale says he does not want to wait for a Federal appeals court to rule on the constitutionality of New Jersey's solid waste law. Consequently, the town began yesterday to seek bids from private haulers to dispose of Northvale's trash directly. In July, a Federal judge struck down a state law requiring towns like Northvale to pay the county to dispose of its trash, but he gave the state two years to change the law. The case is before the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTHOLOMEO, WALTER E.
description: BARTHOLOMEO-Walter E. Regis High School mourns the loss of Walter E. Bartholomeo, affectionately known as ''The Boss''. Walter passed away on January 1, 1997, after serving the Regis community as Superintendent of Maintenance for 39 years. A memorial Mass will be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue and East 84th Street, on Tuesday, January 21 at 2 P.M. All alumni, parents and friends of Regis are welcome. Walter has left an indelible impression on Regis. He will forever be remembered as a loyal and true friend. May Walter rest in peace.

title: Break in the Action for Fassel
description: With more than 100 assistant coaches looking for jobs, it is no wonder that the phones at the Giants Stadium offices in East Rutherford, N.J., have been ringing off the hook.

title: Art in Review
description: Betty Woodman

title: For Children
description: Fighting the deep-January blues with children doesn't seem easy at first if you live in New York City. The parks can feel as cold as Siberia, and skating arenas are often too jammed for figure-eights. And have you noticed the lines at the movies? If only we were bears and could sleep until spring. Yet an eclectic array of remedies exists. Here is how four children (and their parents) manage, along with information about a map that families may find useful when they venture farther afield.

title: Hand in Glove: Sounds That Lie Up a Sleeve
description: Laeticia Sonami plays a unique instrument: the lady's glove. It's a sheer, elbow-length, left-handed glove with 16 pressure and motion sensors controlling electronic sounds. Alone onstage at the Kitchen on Wednesday night, she sometimes looked like a human antenna searching the air for sounds, or like a dancer focused on her hands, or like a deity summoning earth-shaking rumbles with a brusque gesture.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISS, EMMANUEL A.
description: WEISS-Emmanuel A. Dearest Manny, it is 2 long years of your departure and my life is incomplete without you, but the memory of your smiles, laughter and love fills my heart. ''When a good man dies, his goodness does not perish''. With My Love Forever, Vera

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 'Absolutely Fabulous'

title: USA WASTE TO ADD TO ITS OPERATIONS IN CANADA
description: USA Waste Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Canadian solid waste units of Allied Waste Industries for about $518 million. The acquisition would include 7 landfills, 41 collection operations and 8 transfer stations in Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec and Saskatchewan. Those operations generate annual revenue of about $270 million, the company said. USA Waste, of Houston, would add the operations to its existing Canadian businesses, which include the solid waste operations acquired in August from Philip Environmental Inc. and other assets from its merger with Sanifill Inc. Shares of USA Waste rose 50 cents yesterday, to $31.75, while shares of Allied Waste rose 50 cents, to $9.625.

title: Barclays to Close 19 Paris-Area Branches
description: Barclays P.L.C., Britain's third-largest bank, is closing 19 branches in and around Paris, a spokeswoman said yesterday. Barclays, which had 10 branches in the Paris area four years ago, now operates 50. Not all have performed well enough to remain open, the spokeswoman said. Another 20 branches in the French provinces will be kept, she said.

title: Swiss Producer Prices Fell 2.2% Last Year
description: Swiss producer and import prices fell 2.2 percent last year, the lowest yearly rate since 1986, providing fresh evidence that Swiss interest rates are set to stay at their lowest levels in 18 years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How many authors tote their own furniture to a book party? BARBARA SEAMAN took her own bar to the celebration for the reissuing of the biography ''Lovely Me: The Life of Jacqueline Susann.'' The book, published in 1987 by William Morrow, has been brought out again this week by Seven Stories Press.

title: U.S. Balloonist Trying a Circumnavigation Conquers the Atlantic
description: Some 64 hours after launching his Solo Spirit balloon from Busch Stadium in St. Louis, Steve Fossett crossed the Portuguese coast yesterday after a speedy crossing of the Atlantic on his way around the world.

title: High Treasury Official to Join Salomon
description: Jeffrey R. Shafer, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, will resign on Feb. 1 to join Salomon Brothers as a managing director and vice chairman of the Wall Street firm's international division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYAMS, PHILIP
description: HYAMS-Philip. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the brother of its esteemed member, Mrs. Blanche Shapiro, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. Shelley S. Goren, Chairman David Yagoda, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARYANOV, DAVID
description: MARYANOV-David. On Jan. 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Myrna (Metrick), dearest father and father-in-law of Phyllis and William Mack, Sheila and Allan Applestein of Porta Vita, Florida. Adoring grandfather of Robin Chesler of San Francisco, Andrew Chesler of Florida, Richard and Stephen Mack of New York.

title: Digital Says It Was Again Profitable In 2d Quarter
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it regained profitability in its fiscal second quarter, but it is still suffering from slow sales of its flagship high-performance computer systems.

title: Salvador Ferigle, 73, Priest Who Brought Opus Dei to the U.S.
description: The Rev. Dr. Salvador Ferigle, who nearly 50 years ago brought the conservative Roman Catholic movement Opus Dei to the United States from his native Spain, died on Jan. 9 at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIET
description: COHEN-Harriet. January 17, 1991. Mom, singing your ''songs'' comforts and inspires us. Always Jane and Peter

title: G.M. to Sell A Hughes Unit To Raytheon
description: In what is expected to be one of the last major takeovers in the weapons industry, the Raytheon Company announced today that it had agreed to acquire the military businesses of the Hughes Electronics Corporation from the General Motors Corporation for the equivalent of $9.5 billion.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Chunking Express

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, WILLIAM O.
description: DOHERTY-William O. Of Pearl River, N.Y., on January 11, 1997. Past Editor and Publisher of the Journal of Accountancy with the American Institute of CPA's. Devoted husband of Margaret. Beloved father of William Jr. of West Haverstraw and Judith M. Doherty of Pearl River, NY. Also survived by three grandchildren. Memorials to Alzheimer's Disease Research, 15825 Shady Grove Rd., Suite 140, Rockville, MD 20850.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRESH, PAUL
description: KRESH-Paul. The American Jewish Public Relations Society mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Paul Kresh. Henry Hecker, President

title: Begin's Son Quits Cabinet Over Hebron
description: Though many ministers, mayors and other officials on the Israeli right threatened various measures to block the Hebron agreement, in the end only one, Science Minister Binyamin Begin, bit the bullet and resigned.

title: Mercedes-Benz Chief Quits Over Merger Plans
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that Helmut Werner, the popular head of its Mercedes-Benz A.G. unit, had resigned because he saw no appropriate role for himself after the planned merger of his unit into the parent company.

title: Effort to Reduce Legal Immigration Loses Impetus in Congress
description: Soon after President Clinton enacted broad new restrictions in September against illegal immigration, many conservative lawmakers vowed to make reductions in legal immigration a chief goal in 1997.

title: Ford Plans Cutbacks at British Assembly Plant
description: In the first big step toward turning its unprofitable European operations around, the Ford Motor Company announced today that it would reduce employment by a third, or 1,300 workers, at its Halewood assembly plant near Liverpool, which makes its European Escort models.

title: On Turning Art Songs Into Character Sketches
description: The description William Bolcom chose for his work, ''cabaret songs,'' probably best fits most of the material the New York Festival of Song chose for its program at Weill Hall on Wednesday night. There were a few trawls back into the 1930's to bring us numbers by Harold Arlen, the Gershwins (the comic ''Freud and Jung and Adler'' effectively done as a trio) and Marc Blitzstein (''Penny Candy''), but otherwise we were in the more modern times of not-so-very-popular American songs: songs that look back to the golden age and emulate its mix of sentimentality and sophistication.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 'Ellis Island'

title: Real Estate Company In Japan to Close
description: The All Corporation, a real estate financing company in Tokyo, said yesterday that it would cease operations and set up a company to collect its outstanding loans. The company said its total debt is 341.4 billion yen, or $2.93 billion. All had 181.2 billion yen in bad loans, mostly for real estate investment in the late 1980's. Bad loans amounted to 85 percent of all lending, the company said.

title: Art in Review
description: Patti Smith

title: PFIZER INC. (PFE, N)
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose 23 percent in the fourth quarter, driven by surging sales of relatively new drugs, including the antibiotic Zithromax and the heart drug Norvasc.

title: AGCO TO BUY GERMAN TRACTOR MAKER FOR $321 MILLION
description: Agco Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the German tractor maker Xaver Fendt G.m.b.H. & Company for $321 million in cash and debt. The acquisition for $283 million in cash and the assumption of $38 million in debt is part of Agco's plan to spend $1.5 billion to expand its European business. Fendt had sales of $580 million in 1995 and employs 3,000 people. Agco, which is based in Duluth, Ga., makes farming equipment, including Massey Ferguson tractors and combines. Shares of Agco closed up 12.5 cents yesterday at $27.125.

title: 14-Point Underdogs? That Seems to Be Just Fine With the Patriots
description: The Patriots seem not to mind at all that they are the third-greatest underdogs in Super Bowl history.

title: The Dossier on Anthony Lake
description: As the Senate considers the nomination of Anthony Lake to be Director of Central Intelligence, it must separate the serious questions about Mr. Lake's fitness from the frivolous and malicious. Mr. Lake has served the country with distinction in a variety of high-level jobs over three decades, including four years as President Clinton's national security adviser. His suitability to manage America's intelligence services should be judged on his record and the plans he presents at Senate hearings next month, not on outlandish charges made by ideological foes of the Clinton Administration.

title: Montgomery Ward Changes Agencies
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, the troubled retailer that operates stores under names including Montgomery Ward, Lechmere and Electric Avenue and More, said yesterday that it had named DDB Needham Chicago to handle its consolidated national broadcast advertising assignment. Billings were estimated at more than $50 million.

title: Rock Singer's Raucous Role: Serbia's Jeer Leader
description: Shortly after midnight one night this week, with more than 300,000 people jammed into Republic Square and surrounding streets here, a 44-year-old rock musician, his left lobe adorned with a double-headed Serbian eagle earring, launched into one of the most popular songs of the two-month-old protest movement.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the resignation of Jamie S. Gorelick, the Deputy Attorney General, referred incorrectly in some editions to one of the people who died in a confrontation in August 1992 between Federal agents and a white separatist in Idaho. The wife and teen-age son of the separatist were killed, not the wife and infant child; the infant was unharmed.

title: Three Works Filled With a Sense of Community
description: Zvi Gotheiner is a widely respected teacher of dance, and he was born and raised in Israel, where he began his artistic career as a teen-age violinist in a kibbutz orchestra. It was not surprising, then, that the three dances presented by Zvi Gotheiner and Dancers on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater were well made, set to interesting music and filled with a sense of the dancers and the characters they portrayed as members of a community.

title: Yanks May File Protest for Pitcher
description: If the Yankees officially protest the exclusive negotiating rights to a highly regarded Japanese pitcher acquired by the San Diego Padres, recent precedent will undermine their case. Hideki Irabu has expressed a desire to play for the Yankees, and the Yankees are highly interested in having him pitch for them.

title: Brooklyn Mother Wins Millions, Just in Time
description: For the last six nights, she had slept on a couch in a girlfriend's living room, her bed and most of her other possessions padlocked inside the Crown Heights apartment from which she was evicted last Friday.

title: A New Crown Hts. Trial Revisits Brooklyn Night of Murder in '91
description: Five and a half years after racial violence tore through Crown Heights and sent shock waves from City Hall to Washington, the case once again riveted a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday, as two black men were accused of being part of a murderous ''vigilante gang'' that stabbed a Hasidic man to death in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENESEVICH, FRED A.
description: DENESEVICH-Fred A., 66 of Bridgewater. Retired Regional Manager Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Husband of Greta. Father of Mark and Karen. Brother of Richard, Daniel and Marion Quagliariello. Funeral service 10am Saturday at Cusick Funeral Home, 80 Mountain Avenue, Sommerville. Memorial donations to Somerset Medical Center-Hospice, Rehill Avenue, Somerville, NJ 08876. For information contact Cusick Funeral Home 908-725-4100.

title: Art in Review
description: Felix Gonzalez-Torres

title: Head of Daimler Unit Resigns as Germany's Biggest Firm Regroups : Mercedes Chief Out in Power Struggle
description: FRANKFURT  A months-long power struggle between the two most powerful men at Daimler-Benz AG, Germany's biggest industrial company, ended Thursday when Helmut Werner resigned as chairman of Mercedes-Benz AG, Daimler's profitable luxury-car and truck division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENVIR, WILLIAM CREMIN
description: DENVIR-William Cremin, age 75, of Seabrook Island, SC, formerly of New York, died on Saturday, January 11, 1997 at his residence. He was the son of the late James Peter Denvir and Grace Cremin Denvir. Mr. Denvir was an interior designer associated with B. Altman's, NY. Services will be held today in SC, with burial in New Haven, CT. Information, McAlister Funeral Home, Charleston, SC.

title: Shadowing Industry Trends, Morgan Stanley Creates 2 Big Divisions
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, reflecting recent changes in financial markets and its own rapid growth, reorganized itself yesterday into two main divisions, securities and asset management, and named Peter F. Karches to head its newly integrated securities business.

title: In a Bar Slinging Slang
description: The three hoodlums on the lam in ''Albino Alligator'' have the good luck to stumble into hipster heaven. They find themselves holed up in a bar called Dino's Last Chance, which has artfully preserved Prohibition-era decor and a huge likeness of Humphrey Bogart on the wall. With a great big nod to ''The Petrified Forest,'' this small, contrived film confines itself to the bar and walks a gangbusters cast through a series of stagey confrontations. Kevin Spacey has a sang-froid that would fit into this set-up perfectly, but he keeps it behind the camera instead.

title: SYNOPSYS TO MERGE WITH EPIC DESIGN IN A STOCK SWAP
description: Synopsys Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Epic Design Technology Inc. for $427.1 million, or $31.25 a share, in a stock-swap merger that would combine two developers of engineering software. Shares of Synopsys, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., were unchanged yesterday at $41.75. Shares of Epic fell $1 yesterday, to $30.25. Synopsys said it would issue 0.7485 share of its stock for each outstanding Epic share. Both companies make software used to help engineers design the circuitry imprinted on computer chips.

title: Out West, When Men Were Quiet And Heroic
description: Before he became an author of best-selling crime novels like ''Get Shorty,'' Elmore Leonard wrote westerns, developing early on his favorite theme, that ''we don't control our lives.'' ''Last Stand at Saber River,'' one of the best, has now been given a rich and sensitive television production, which can be seen Sunday on TNT. Tom Selleck, who at times seems as attractively embarrassed as Clark Gable used to be about being in the suspicious business of acting, plays Paul Cable, returning in the waning days of the Civil War to his wary family and a world still filled with violence.

title: Documentary on Yugoslavia Receives a Top TV Award
description: A documentary on the breakup of Yugoslavia won the highest honor at the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University awards for broadcast journalism, the university announced yesterday.

title: In Green Bay, No Turmoil at the Top
description: Dan Reeves left the Giants after he and General Manager George Young split over who would have authority on personnel matters. Bobby Ross fled from San Diego to Detroit because he and Chargers General Manager Bobby Beathard couldn't see eye to eye.

title: An Evening Of Slavic Folkishness And Flair
description: It's no great ''theme'' by the standards of latter-day thematic programmers, but Kurt Masur likes to present entire evenings of Slavic music with the New York Philharmonic. His current subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall offer a particularly lovely assortment of unhackneyed works, united by a thread of folkishness: Dvorak's ''Devil and Kate'' Overture and Violin Concerto, and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 2, the ''Little Russian.''

title: Bill Cosby's Son Is Slain Along Freeway
description: Ennis William Cosby, the only son of Bill Cosby, was shot to death early today on a Los Angeles freeway ramp in what the police said might have been a robbery attempt as he changed a flat tire.

title: $9.5 Billion Merger In Weapons Industry
description: Raytheon has agreed to acquire General Motors' military businesses for $9.5 billion in stock and new debt in what could be the last big takeover in the weapons industry.

title: For Sale: Yesterday's News (a Million Copies)
description: Those who are thrilled by front-page articles from the day after Lincoln was shot, by headlines from the Spanish-American War, by patent medicine advertisements or by the earliest color comic strips will get a rare opportunity at an auction of old newspapers here in Topeka.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZDAN, SAMUEL, D.D.S.
description: KAZDAN-Samuel, D.D.S. January 15. Devoted brother of the late Aralee. Service Sunday, 10:30 AM ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: $25 and Under
description: Here are some sure signs of a restaurant with good Mexican food: a jukebox that blasts Mexican hits at conversation-stopping volume and several dour men sitting, silently of course, nursing beers.

title: Egypt's Canal Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Leadership Hunts Show The State of the Parties
description: While President Clinton had to twist arms to find a suitable chairman for the Democratic Party, eight candidates who want to lead the Republican Party are engaged in a furious competition, pitching themselves on videotapes and plying prospective supporters with food and drink at cocktail receptions.

title: Plan Calls for Trump to Turn St. Moritz Hotel Into Condos
description: The St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South, a once-chic establishment whose Continental atmosphere has faded in recent years into that of a somewhat dowdy refuge for bargain-conscious international tour groups, would become luxury condominiums under an agreement between its Australian owners and Donald J. Trump, real estate sources said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAIN, JANE MURTAGH
description: McCAIN-Jane Murtagh, died November 26, 1996 in Pinehurst, NC. Mrs. McCain was born on January 22, 1910 in West Chester, PA. She graduated from the Shipley School, Bryn Mawr, PA., in 1927 and from La Lierre, in Paris, in 1928. She was married to Samuel Adams McCain, general counsel of Corn Products Company who died in 1964. She is survived by her daughter Sarah (Mrs. John) Currie of Southern Pines, NC, and two nephews, and was pre-deceased by her son, Samuel Adams McCain, Jr. Mrs. McCain was an active member in the Riverdale, New York community from 1940 to 1991. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Christ Church, 5030 Henry Hudson Parkway, Riverdale, New York, 10471, or a charity of your choice.

title: RYERSON TULL AGREES TO ACQUIRE THYPIN STEEL
description: Ryerson Tull Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Thypin Steel Company, a closely held processor and distributor of carbon and stainless steel products, for about $140 million in cash and assumed debt. Thypin is a Long Island City, Queens, company with annual revenue of about $335 million. Ryerson Tull, a Chicago processor and distributor of metals, said it would pay $120 million in cash for Thypin and assume about $20 million of its debt. Ryerson Tull, which has about $2.5 billion in annual revenue, operates service centers that process and distribute steel and other metals. Thypin has about 500 employees and operates service centers in seven cities. Shares of Ryerson Tull closed up 25 cents yesterday at $15.25.

title: Peru Rules Out a Rebel 'Suggestion' in the Hostage Crisis
description: The Peruvian Government today rejected a proposal by the leader of the Tupac Amaru rebels holding 74 hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here that a Guatemalan official be included on a commission that is being formed to end the standoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, LUCILLE (NEE LAWSON)

Memorial service at St. James Episcopal Church to be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Body Is Found in Abandoned Building
description: After two days of searching an abandoned Manhattan building reputed to be the burial ground for a drug gang's murder victims, investigators said yesterday that they found one badly decomposed body, of a woman who had been shot to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, JOHN J.
description: MANN-John J., died in Lenox, MA, on January 16, 1997. Partner with Jaros Baum & Bolles, retiring in 1990. He leaves his wife, Ruth Bergmann Mann, and two sons, James and Robert. Wellington Funeral Home, Pittsfield, MA.

title: HOME DEPOT PLANS TO BUY MAINTENANCE WAREHOUSE
description: Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Maintenance Warehouse/America Corporation, a direct-mail marketer of maintenance and repair supplies. Terms of the stock transaction were not disclosed. Maintenance Warehouse, which is based in San Diego, had sales of $130 million in 1996. The purchase will be accounted for as a pooling of interests and is expected to be completed early in the first quarter, Home Depot said. Shares of Home Depot, which has 480 home improvement stores, closed down 25 cents yesterday at $50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEL, DR. BERT
description: ABEL-Dr. Bert. The Alumni Society of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn records with deep sorrow the passing of an esteemed colleague of long standing and extends condolences to his family. Dr. William Kahan, President Dr. Martin Bandler, Treasurer Diane Shapiro, Secretary

title: Strength of Kodak's Results In Period Surprises Wall St.
description: In a report that delighted Wall Street, the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that operating profits in the fourth quarter rose by 21.5 percent, spurring the company to announce its first dividend increase in eight years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASER, LEE BABIN
description: GLASER-Lee Babin. Muriel Cadel, Joseph Goldberg Bert Rosenberg, Barbara Rudikoff Ruth Samuels, Anne Silberling Milton Sutton, Florence Zlowe

title: 2 Bomb Blasts Rock Abortion Clinic at Atlanta; 6 Are Injured
description: Two bomb explosions, apparently timed to go off about an hour apart, damaged a suburban Atlanta abortion clinic this morning and injured six people, including investigators and news reporters who were drawn to the first blast.

title: China's Free Market Must Stress Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: Witness Who Called the Police Describes Wells's Fight
description: Earl Bridgeman had just finished singing at a bar in the Ocean Beach section of San Diego when he stumbled into what resembled a commercial for professional wrestling. The singer spied five men punching and pushing one another, so he stopped to watch the early-morning scuffle.

title: UConn Bans 2 Starters and Opens Inquiry
description: Kirk King, a senior and the lone survivor from dominant Connecticut basketball teams that posted an 89-13 record over the last three seasons, and Ricky Moore, a sophomore and the catalyst of a rebuilding squad, were suspended yesterday pending completion of an investigation.

title: Torre Irked As Yankees Fail to Meet His Price
description: Joe Torre is savvy enough to keep controversial contract discussions with George Steinbrenner private, but a friend of the Yankees' manager said Torre was perturbed that Steinbrenner's only attempt to sign him to an extension has fallen significantly short of Torre's expectations.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES TO ACQUIRE SHAWNEE STATE BANK
description: Commerce Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Shawnee State Bank of Shawnee, Kan. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. The privately held Shawnee State Bank, with $205 million in assets, has three locations in Johnson County. Commerce Bancshares, of Kansas City, Mo., has assets of $9.4 billion and operates more than 240 branches in Missouri, Kansas and Illinois.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENSIL, JIM
description: KENSIL-Jim. We record with great sorrow the passing of our former President, Jim Kensil and extend condolences and sympathy to his entire family. New York Jets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSBY, ENNIS
description: COSBY-Ennis. New York University's Tisch School of the Arts extends its deepest sympathy to Camille and Bill Cosby on the sudden and tragic loss of their son Ennis. The entire community shares in their loss. Mary Schmidt Campbell, Dean, NYU Tisch School of the Arts Alec Baldwin, Chair, Dean's Council

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, JAMES A., JR.
description: McDERMOTT-James A., Jr., age 64, January 17, 1997, after a long illness. Former President and CEO of Lion Ribbon Co., past-President of The Advisory Board of Saint Vincent's Hospital, Westchester. Beloved husband of Penelope (Penny) F. McDermott; adored father of James A., III, Mark C., Jeffrey F., and Douglas J.; fatherin-law of Margaret S., Susan B., Maureen L.; grandfather of James IV, Peter, Kevin and Margaret; dear brother of Mary Jo McCarthy Mitchell; and uncle of ten nieces & nephews. Visiting hours will be at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, New York, Monday, January 20, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be held 10 AM, Tuesday at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye. Donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital of Westchester, 275 North Street, Harrison, New York 10528 or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: Africa Museum Director
description: The National Museum of African Art in Washington has named Roslyn Adele Walker to be its new director. Ms. Walker, who was the museum's senior curator, succeeds Sylvia H. Williams, who died last year. Patricia L. Fiske, who has served as the museum's acting director, will resume her job as assistant director.

title: Plea in Deaths of 5 Women
description: A Bernards Township man pleaded guilty to manslaughter and drunk driving charges yesterday in the July 1995 death of five Paterson women who were riding in a van that he struck head-on while driving the wrong way on the Garden State Parkway, officials said.

title: Rescuers Are Called Target Of 2d Explosion in Atlanta
description: Although evidence and common sense point to an abortion clinic as the target of the first bomb blast at a suburban Atlanta office complex on Thursday, there is little doubt among investigators that a second blast, an hour later and 100 feet away, was aimed at rescue workers and law-enforcement officers who responded to the first explosion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, IRA
description: FREEMAN-Ira. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ira Freeman, associated with The Times from 1928, until retiring in 1961.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend yesterday about long-running Broadway musicals misspelled the surname of a co-director of ''Les Miserables.'' He is John Caird, not Laird.

title: Douglas Greenwald, 83, Editor And Economist for McGraw-Hill
description: Douglas Greenwald, the retired chief of economics for the publications unit of the McGraw-Hill Companies and editor in chief of the McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of Economics, died Wednesday at his home in Sarasota, Fla.

description: SUSLOW-Rose. Age 92. Devoted wife of the late Robert. Beloved and cherished mother of Nancy Ragovin and Howard and Renee. Adored grandmother of Seth, Wendy, Scott, Lisa, Clifford and Stacy. Dear great grandmother of Eric and Adam, Danielle and Adam. She will always be loved and forever missed. Services Sunday, 12 noon. Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: No Bill of Orange
description: One reason nobody takes Washington seriously anymore except people far gone on political hashish is the names they use down there.

title: Accompaniment for an Art Show
description: Simply as an evening of small-scale works from the Italian Baroque, the concert by the Arcadian Academy on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art held modest interest. With few exceptions, the instrumental sonatas and solo vocal works were unmemorable, seldom rising above the trivial. The performances, though skilled, lacked inspiration even where it might have been warranted.

title: There Is No Hierarchy Among Victims
description: If a society is interested in justice, it should honor the memory of those who have been persecuted. This is a particularly pressing matter in Germany because of the vast scope and murderous intensity of Nazi crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, ETTA
description: SILVERSTEIN-Etta. An outstanding person who came to our great country with courage, determination and a devotion to productivity, Etta Silverstein helped develop this country and city for the benefit of the generations to come. She devoted her life to her family and to worthy institutions. Young people benefited enormously from her dedication to help them develop their careers. Always full of enthusiasm and optimism, she was the favorite of many of us and to many students and faculty who benefited from her wisdom and generosity. She had a great deal of pleasure witnessing our students develop into the finest of physicians. Her son Larry and his spouse Klara, and their children and spouses were totally devoted to Etta, who was the glorious queen. Larry and Klara, leading citizens of our city and community, created an environment that was, and is, the gold standard for the care of parents. We at New York University School of Medicine and Etta's numerous friends mourn her passing. A wonderful friend has left our community and our institution. To Larry, Klara and their family, we extend our deepest sympathy. Saul J. Farber, M.D., MACP Provost and Dean, New York University Medical Center and School of Medicine

title: Offstage in the Lima Drama, Fearful Families Pray
description: Each day since Luisa Sivina's husband was taken hostage, his younger son has wondered where his father is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEVIN, MARGARET Q.
description: BLEVIN-Margaret Q. Sister of Josephine E. Quinn. Aunt of Mary Lin Faries, Eugene Grossman and James P. Quinn. Funeral Mass Monday, 10 AM, Sacred Heart R.C. Church, Hartsdale, NY. Interment Tuesday, Rolling Green Memorial Park, Camphill, PA. Reposing at the Ballard - Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY, Sunday, 2-5 PM.

title: For Messier, Unpleasant Surprises
description: Mark Messier, the Ranger captain, is one of the more cooperative athletes in major sports. But he abruptly left the National Hockey League All-Star news conference today without conducting interviews. The problem might have been that he was denied a seat at the head table. And he might have been irked by a television stunt.

title: Big Chill Fills Homeless Beds
description: At the Hoboken Clergy Coalition Shelter for the Homeless, the 30 beds will probably be full all weekend, Sister Norberta Hunnewinkel, a co-director, said yesterday. Others seeking refuge from the cold will be welcomed, she said, but will have to make do with a chair or the floor.

description: German and Spanish Art Songs,

title: Moynihan Says He Plans To Run Again For the Senate
description: Moving to end speculation that this will be his last term in Washington, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he had arranged a birthday fund-raising event to kick off his re-election campaign. The unusually early event -- the election is not until 2000 -- is also intended to discourage fellow Democrats from jockeying for his seat, aides said.

title: Devising an Experiment To Save the Song Recital
description: The heritage of the song recital is floundering. This was a recurring theme in a panel discussion that was part of an engrossing two-day presentation by the Marilyn Horne Foundation and the Juilliard School called ''The Art of the Vocal Recital.'' The events, which included two master classes on Tuesday and a final concert on Wednesday, were aimed at correcting that problem. But the problem persists.

title: Another Record as Dow Closes Above 6,800
description: The stock market continued its January rally yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 67.73 points, or 1 percent, to close at 6,833.10, its eighth record this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEL, BERT, M.D.
description: ABEL-Bert, M.D. We note with sorrow the passing of a highly respected colleague. As a Founding Physician of Central General Hospital (North Shore University Hospital at Plainview) he served our community members with skill and compassion. This dedicated humanitarian will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his family. Glenn Hirsch V.P. Administration Alan Mensch, M.D. Medical Director North Shore University Hospital at Plainview

description: Following are excerpts from remarks opening the hearing on the ethics investigation of Speaker Newt Gingrich today, made by the ethics committee's chairman, Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut; its ranking Democrat, Representative Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, and the outside counsel in the inquiry, James M. Cole, and from the question-and-answer session between committee members and Mr. Cole, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Expansion May Cause Teams to Trade Leagues
description: Like kids trading baseball cards, the National and American Leagues may soon trade teams -- Houston for Kansas City, for example, or maybe Montreal for Tampa Bay.

description: He's gonna get caught

title: South Africa's Truth Panel Accuses de Klerk of Lies and Cover-Up
description: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission has fired its first major salvo at former President F. W. de Klerk, accusing him of lying to Parliament and covering up the involvement of high-level army officers in murder and dirty tricks during the apartheid era.

title: Elspeth Huxley, 89, Chronicler of Colonial Kenya, Dies
description: Elspeth Huxley, a witty and energetic journalist and author of more than 30 books, including memoirs, biographies, crime stories and novels, many inspired by her childhood in colonial Kenya, died on Jan. 10 in a nursing home in Tetbury, in Gloucestershire, England, a family friend said. She was 89.

title: Port Authority Chief to Leave, After Cutbacks and Criticism
description: George J. Marlin, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, announced yesterday that he will leave his post when his term expires in April. His resignation was officially portrayed as a natural return to a booming Wall Street and unofficially depicted as the culmination of clashes with the sprawling agency's Board of Commissioners.

description: Hitting More Than Net
