title: BRODERBUND PLANS TO END VENTURE WITH RANDOM HOUSE
description: Broderbund Software Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy Random House's 50 percent interest in the companies' Living Books joint venture. Financial terms were not disclosed. Broderbund, a publisher of interactive software, and Random House, a book publisher, formed Living Books in 1994 to provide interactive story-telling software in 1994. The venture lost money in the fiscal fourth quarter. Analysts attributed the loss to lower-priced products from the Walt Disney Company. Under the preliminary agreement, which requires approval from the boards of both companies, Living Books would become a unit of Broderbund, which is based in Novato, Calif. Random House, a unit of the closely held Advance Publications Inc., based in New York, would continue to be a partner only in connection with the content for future Living Books products.

title: Sabretech Shuts Down Airline Repair Shop
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said this evening that Sabretech, which performed repair work for Valujet in Miami that contributed to a deadly crash there in May, had agreed today to shut down another repair shop, in Orlando, before the Government ordered it to close.

title: L.I.U. Is Stunned by Marist
description: In Poughkeepsie, N.Y., two Marist players enjoyed career-best performances last night to lift the Red Foxes to an 88-84 upset over Long Island University in one of the biggest surprises in local college basketball this season.

title: In a Trice, Decorous Becomes Party Time
description: Wednesday night's Jazz Explosion at Carnegie Hall, which wasn't jazz but did have a few explosions, split up into two concerts. The first featured decorous performances by the singers Diane Reeves and Will Downing, the saxophonist Gerald Albright, the guitarist Doc Powell and the keyboardist Alex Bugnon, all of whom maintained the distance between the performers onstage and the audience.

title: Fidelity Forms An Alliance With Salomon
description: Fidelity Investments and Salomon Brothers Inc. announced a unique alliance yesterday that will give the giant mutual fund company better access to stock offerings and sophisticated research and the Wall Street firm an instant retail brokerage network.

title: With Ballots Still Warm, Clinton Pays Homage to Dole
description: After President Clinton had spoken slowly and earnestly today, after he had all but embraced his old Republican rival Bob Dole to hang the Medal of Freedom around his neck, it was left to Mr. Dole to crack the solemnity and bring the house down.

title: Sound Bites Showcased Song and Dance Routine
description: Even conscientious viewers of C-Span and the all-news channels that carried yesterday's House ethics committee hearing must be forgiven if they judged the performances by the punch lines. That, after all, is the way things go on television, and we have all been trained to listen for -- pardon the expression -- sound bites.

title: Steinbrenner Denies Trouble
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that there were ''no problems'' between him and Yankees Manager Joe Torre regarding the possibility of a contract extension, and said that the two would meet to discuss the topic as soon as their schedules coincide.

title: PANEL, CITING PATTERN OF ETHICS FLAWS, SEEKS A GINGRICH REPRIMAND
description: The House ethics subcommittee declared today that Speaker Newt Gingrich's misuse of tax-exempt funds for a politically tinged college course reflected a pattern of years of ''disregard and lack of respect for the standards of conduct'' a Congressman should follow.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trade Deficit Up Slightly As Exports Reach Record

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMMER, GEORGES M.
description: TEMMER-Georges M. Born April 10, 1922, Vienna. Died January 12, 1997, Princeton, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Sylvia, and loving step-father to Julianna Mastroserio, Jenni Spencer and Edward Twerdahl IV, and grandfather to five. He was a professor of Nuclear Physics at Rutgers for 29 years. Memorial service Trinity Church, Princeton, New Jersey, Sunday, January 19, 1:30 P.M.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: After 30 Years, the Palestinians Take Over in Hebron
description: Amid flashes of old tensions and scenes of celebration, hundreds of Palestinian policemen and paramilitary soldiers emerged on the ancient streets of Hebron today to claim control of most of the West Bank city that Israeli forces had occupied for the last 30 years.

title: Rodman's Kick Is Costly: 11 Games and $1 Million
description: Dennis Rodman was suspended for at least 11 games and fined $25,000 by National Basketball Association Commissioner David Stern yesterday for kicking a cameraman in Minneapolis on Wednesday night.

title: Prison Contract Is Delayed
description: Averting a confrontation with unions representing state employees, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that she will postpone turning over prison food services and maintenance to private hands. Mrs. Whitman invited the unions to come up with other cost-saving ideas, The Associated Press reported. The administration had expected to save $2.2 million through privatization, but 200 state workers would have lost their jobs, and the unions were adamantly opposed.

title: With a Tip Jar, a Country Band That Likes a Joke
description: Most nostalgia trips are a yawn, but this one makes you think more than twice: young women screaming ''Opie! Opie!,'' hoping to hear an old-timey country tune about an imaginary episode of ''The Andy Griffith Show.'' That was before BR5-49's third set of encores at Tramps on Thursday night, and a minute later the group bounded back on stage to play its song ''Me 'n' Opie (Down by the Duck Pond).''

title: Mexican Embassy Shielded Salvadoran Gunman, Officials Say
description: Several months after a commando force of leftist guerrillas killed six Americans and seven others as they sat eating at sidewalk restaurants in El Salvador one evening in 1985, the Mexican Embassy in San Salvador provided safe haven to the rebel gunman who led the assault, United States officials concluded.

title: ODYSSEY SATELLITE SYSTEM IN PACT WITH CHINA
description: TRW Inc.'s Odyssey satellite cellular phone system signed a memorandum of understanding with its first regional provider of the Odyssey service. In a statement, TRW said yesterday that the China Telecommunications Broadcast Satellite Corporation, or Chinasat, would have exclusive rights to distribute cellular phone, fax and data services in China. Chinasat will also operate one of Odyssey's earth stations that covers China, Japan and other areas in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a TRW spokesman. The Odyssey system is expected to have seven earth stations worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSSON, FLORENCE A. (RYAN)
description: CARLSSON-Florence A. (Ryan). Of Sayville, L.I. until recently of East Meadow, L.I. On January 17, 1997 at age 86. Beloved mother of Kathleen and sister of Frank Ryan. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School in 1938. She practiced privately and in the 1950's became the first woman Assistant District Attorney in Nassau County. She was active for many years in Nassau GOP politics. She was one of the first members of the Nassau County Womens' Bar Association which was formed at least in part because of the then-unwelcoming attitude of the Nassau County Bar Association. She was the first woman President of the Catholic Lawyers Guild of Nassau County. Mass of Christian burial today, Saturday, Janaury 18 at St. Lawrence R.C. Church, Sayville at 10am. Burial follows at St. Lawrence Cemetery, Sayville. Her friends should call her home or office for arrangements to visit the family. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, for its schools would be appreciated.

title: Stores Gear Up for Week of Tax Relief
description: Today is Day 1 of a weeklong experiment in which most clothing costing less than $500 will be free of sales tax in much of New York State, and retailers have reprogrammed cash registers and beefed up sales forces, hoping to serve throngs of bargain hunters.

title: Times and Drivers Reach an Agreement
description: The New York Times and its drivers yesterday announced the ratification of a union agreement that will permit the start of an edition to be printed in Boston and in Washington. The edition will begin next month after an agreement is reached with a final union, the pressmen, the paper said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFLUEGER, EDWARD M.
description: PFLUEGER-Edward M. Age 91, January 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Kathleen Powers Pflueger. Survived by several nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Saturday, January 18 and Sunday, January 19, 3-5PM. Services and interment private. Memorial service at St. James Episcopal Church to be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: JAZZ
description: Displaying Jazz Contrasts,

title: Wells's Lawyer Is Confident
description: The lawyer for DAVID WELLS, the Yankee left-hander who broke his pitching hand during a fight in San Diego last Sunday morning, said yesterday for the first time that his client was not guilty of any wrongdoing.

description: BAUMWELL-Julia (nee Blotner), on January 16, 1997, at Northridge Hospital, Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved wife of Maxwell, loving mother of Clyde Baumwell and Stephanie Gerstein, sister of Evelyn Acaso, grandmother of Kate, Blair and Alex Baumwell. Funeral services, Sunday, 1PM, at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels Inc, 44 Wilson Ave., Manalapan, NJ. Interment to follow at Temple Beth El Cemetery, Neptune, NJ.

title: SFX BROADCASTING TO PURCHASE 7 RADIO STATIONS
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it would buy seven radio stations for $225 million from Secret Communications L.P. instead of the nine stations it originally agreed to buy for $300 million. Omitted from the original purchase agreement, first announced in October, are WLTF and WTAM-AM in Cleveland. Robert F. X. Sillerman, SFX chairman, said that though the Cleveland stations had good potential, they did not fit the company's ''core acquisition profile for value enhancement.'' Instead, SFX will acquire Secret's four stations in Pittsburgh and three Indianapolis stations. The privately held Secret will have just the Cleveland stations in its portfolio after the deal closes. SFX also said that it had completed the sale of $225 million of preferred stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZDAN, SAMUEL, D.D.S.
description: KAZDAN-Samuel, D.D.S. January 15. Devoted brother of the late Aralee. Service Sunday, 10:30 AM ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Heating Oil Prices Take Drop As Supplies Appear Adequate
description: Heating oil prices dropped to a five-week low yesterday as expectations grew that inventories, now greater than last year, would be adequate this winter.

title: South Korean Labor Group to Reduce Strikes
description: In what could be a significant easing of more than three weeks of labor unrest, the organization coordinating nationwide strikes said this morning that workers would return to work Monday and would strike only one day a week.

title: Casinos Don't Belong in Saratoga
description: As New York State lawmakers consider a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling, residents of Saratoga Springs, a city with a colorful history of gambling, continue to debate the pros and cons of a casino in the community.

title: A Jewish Movement Takes Stock of Itself at Age 40
description: The experience of passing one's 40th birthday offers an obvious opportunity for reflection and self-examination -- not just in individuals, but in institutions as well.

title: Tenants Forced to Use Ovens for Heat
description: On days so cold he can see his breath, Mark Brown Sr., a single father who lost a leg to a bullet as a teen-ager, cooks up his Brooklyn home like he would a piece of chicken.

title: Connecticut Students' Test Scores Improve
description: Scores on the state's academic achievement tests improved for the third year in a row, though students in urban schools continued to lag behind their suburban counterparts, the State Education Department announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOSTETTER, CHARLOTTE M.
description: HOSTETTER-Charlotte M. On January 16, 1997. Beloved wife of Rev. Donald A. Hostetter. Loving mother of Mark and Jonathan. Dear sister of Jacqueline Lowe. A memorial service will be held at Riverdale Presbyterian Church, Monday, January 20, 1997 at 11 AM. Memorial gifts may be made to Presbyterian Conference Association, Holmes, NY 12531, Charlotte Hostetter Memorial Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, ARTHUR J.
description: SOLOMON-Arthur J. Age 85, on January 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Blanche, loving father of Gregg, and Lisa (Steve) Liebman, dear brother of Gloria Miller and Diana (Seymour) Steiger. He engaged in the practice of law for 57 years, retiring at 80. We shall deeply miss his charm, his humor, his courage and his devotion. Service Sunday 1 PM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Swiss Stonewalling
description: No one is making a better case that Swiss bankers may have looted the accounts of Jewish depositors who were killed in the Holocaust than the bankers themselves. For years the bankers coldly rebuffed inquiries from relatives of depositors, then resisted international efforts to investigate the matter. Now the Union Bank of Switzerland, the country's largest bank, has been caught shredding documents that might be relevant to several investigations belatedly opened in recent months.

title: Wintry Air Blows Into New York And Makes Everyone Take Notice
description: New York City tramples away snow, chills away heat with a zillion air-conditioners and sheds rain with the flick of a $4 umbrella. But the bitter cold that blasted into the region yesterday for the first time this winter was even a bit much for the city that never notices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LEE E.
description: PHILLIPS-Lee E., on January 16, 1997, in Stamford, CT. Beloved husband of Jane. Devoted father to Derek. Loving son to Lee D. and Marjorie Phillips. Dear brother of Glenn S. Real Estate consultant and President of Phillips/Norwalk Co. of Westport, CT. Funeral service Monday, at 11 AM, in the F. Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan, CT. Donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANGELO, FRANK
description: ANGELO-Frank. After being admitted to a Florida hospital for routine surgery on Tuesday, January 7, 1997, Frank Angelo suffered complications, which led to a cardiac arrest. With family and friends at his side, he passed away on the evening of Sunday, January 12, 1997. Frank's passion for people and for life was expressed in all that he did. Although his devotion and generosity to people seemed extraordinary to others, it was ordinary for Frank. Frank was the co-founder of M.A.C. Cosmetics. The memorial service will be held in Toronto for family, friends and colleagues on Wednesday, January 22, 1997 at 1:00 PM at St. Paul's Anglican Church at 227 Bloor Street East. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the M.A.C. AIDS Fund.

title: A Good Deed, Well Punished
description: A Nutley police sergeant has given new meaning to the expression, ''No good deed should go unpunished.'' Sgt. Steven Rogers parked in front of the Park Diner during a routine patrol Wednesday in order to help an elderly woman cross the street. Afterward, he went inside the diner, leaving his patrol car parked illegally.

title: A Tunnel to the Future
description: In an age when New York City seems to have given up on big building projects, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has made a smart, farsighted decision to press for construction of a $900 million rail freight tunnel between the city and New Jersey. But to succeed, the Mayor will have to build some political bridges.

title: Two Radio Stations Battle Bitterly for the Soul of the City
description: It's ''Isaac Hayes in the Morning,'' and the soul singer turned deejay is sitting in a gleaming new studio on Hudson Street under porthole-like windows. He is munching on lentil pate and pasta and popping hard-boiled eggs into his mouth.

title: Nets Find A Team Even They Can Beat
description: Kerry Kittles is a regular to the toll booth attendants on the New Jersey Turnpike, often hitting the road after a Nets practice to see his old college friends at Villanova. Most of them just want to know one thing: what's it like in the National Basketball Association?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, LILLIAN G.
description: UNGAR-Lillian G. On January 16, 1997. Beloved mother of Alan and Judith Mann. Loving sister of Jacob Goldman. Grandmother of David, Elizabeth, Richard and Barbara. Great grandmother of Leo, Joseph, Shaked and Ayelet. Services on Sunday, January 19, at 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mother Sentenced for Killings
description: A 31-year-old woman who was convicted in November of killing her two infants in 1994 by setting her car on fire while they were inside it was sentenced yesterday to two 50-year prison terms.

title: STARWOOD LODGING IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE HEI HOTELS
description: Starwood Lodging Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire HEI Hotels L.L.C., and 10 hotels that HEI owns jointly with the Prudential Insurance Company of America, for $327 million in stock and $112 million in assumed debt. Starwood Lodging Trust is a real estate investment trust based in Phoenix. HEI is a hotel management company based in Westport, Conn. HEI's joint-venture partner is Prisa II, a real estate investment fund managed by Prudential Real Estate Investors, a unit of Prudential. Shares of Starwood Lodging rose $1.875yesterday to close at $60.50. HEI will become a wholly owned unit of Starwood.

title: Bonds, Ignoring Strong Reports, Are Unchanged
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in choppy trading yesterday in an abbreviated session ahead of a long holiday weekend. The market will be closed Monday for Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

title: Former Dinkins Aide Offered Party Post
description: Bill Lynch, the New York Democrat who managed David N. Dinkins's successful campaign for Mayor in 1989 and went on to serve as his deputy mayor, has been nominated to be a vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Democratic officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LILLIAN WEISLER
description: GOLDMAN-Lillian Weisler, Jan. 11, 1997, age 93, Tucson, Arizona, formerly of Belle Harbor, LI. Private services. 3270 N. Cmno. del Oeste, Tucson, AZ 85745.

description: MARGULIES - Nettie. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Philip Adler, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MININBERG, SADIE
description: MININBERG-Sadie. On January 17. Beloved mother of Naomi Stein and Henry. Devoted sister of Ceil Levine. Loving grandmother of Hope and Robert. Cherished great-grandmother of Rebecca. Services Sunday 10:00 AM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: At Risk: Health Care for the Poor
description: As the city and state look for ways to curb skyrocketing health care costs, New York's public hospital system has unfairly become a target.

title: U.S. Balloonist Over Africa; Sets Long-Distance Record
description: Steve Fossett's hope of circling the world non-stop in his Solo Spirit balloon was nearly crushed yesterday when Libya denied him permission to fly over. But 12 hours later the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, sent word that Mr. Fossett could pass over Libya.

title: Vindication of the Mexican Bailout
description: Mexico's early repayment of loans made by the United States in 1994 puts the finishing touch on a public-policy success. President Clinton's decision to bail out Mexico, over Congress's opposition, was politically unpopular. But with support from the Republican leaders Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole, Mr. Clinton tapped an obscure Treasury fund to lend Mexico more than $13 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the Israeli-Palestinian deal on the West Bank city of Hebron mislabeled the region in some editions. The West Bank is not part of Israel.

title: Microsoft's Earnings Top Wall St. Expectations
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday reported second-quarter earnings that far exceeded Wall Street analysts' expectations. But the software giant also said that its growth could slow in the 1998 fiscal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABINE, BLANCHE SCHAFRAN
description: SABINE-Blanche Schafran. On January 16, 1997. Beloved wife of Arnold. Loving mother of Conrad. Dear sister of Edith, Ruth and Seymour. Service on Sunday 12:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hot Garden Rivalry: Battle for Tickets
description: Forget about the Knicks versus the Bulls. Forget about the Rangers versus the Islanders. The hottest Madison Square Garden clash of the winter season took place yesterday in State Supreme Court. And when the smoke cleared, the outcome was still in question.

title: White House Picks a Slow Path To World Ban on Land Mines
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it would seek to negotiate a worldwide ban on antipersonnel mines, but chose to take the slower of two diplomatic tracks. It also committed itself to capping and eventually eliminating the military's inventory of seven million land mines.

title: Police Work on Sketch of a Cosby Suspect
description: Chief Willie L. Williams said today that police artists were working up a composite sketch of a suspect in Thursday's roadside killing of Ennis William Cosby, son of the comedian Bill Cosby, but that there were no significant developments in the case.

title: Trade Gap Modestly Wider; Industrial Production Surges
description: Record exports and a surge in industrial production combined late last year to propel the economy at an accelerating pace, Government figures showed today.

description: DEERING-Margaret E., on January 17, 1997, age 58, of New York City, formerly of Los Angeles and Cherry Hill, NJ. title: Report Describes How Gingrich Used Taxpayers' Money for Partisan Politics
description: In a 227-page report released today, based on interviews with 70 people, on material gathered from 90 subpoenas and gleaned from 150,000 pages of documents, the House ethics committee tracks how Speaker Newt Gingrich used taxpayer-financed projects to achieve partisan political ends.

title: In the Bronx, A Father Feels Cosby's Pain
description: THE image on the television was from Southern California -- a roadside crime scene where Ennis Cosby's body lay under a blanket. But the landscape flashing through Alfredo Valentin's mind was strictly the Bronx. His 17-year-old son, Derek Paul, and his friend Heith Simmonds, were murdered on Allerton Avenue two and a half years ago while trying to settle an argument over a girl.

title: Not a Culture Clash
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in some editions yesterday about Bill and Camille Cosby's departure from their Manhattan apartment misstated their destination. They did not head for Los Angeles, where their son, Ennis, was shot to death.

title: Patriots Aren't One-Man Show to Owner
description: He has rooted for the Patriots since their inception in 1960, and watched his hometown team roam from Boston University Field to Harvard Stadium to Fenway Park and finally to Foxboro (nee Schaefer) Stadium. He watched as the Pats changed hands, from the Sullivan family to Victor Kiam and Fran Murray to James Busch Orthwein. By 1993, he owned the stadium, and by 1994, the team.

title: Suburban Nassau, at 50, Attempts to Create a Central Hub
description: ''When the Islanders won the Stanley Cup, they had a hard time figuring out where to hold a parade, so the motorcade drove around and around the Nassau Coliseum parking lot,'' H. Claude Shostal recalled. ''In a way, it's humorous, but in a way serious. There's no focal point, no there there.''

title: Prison for Bilking the Navy
description: During and after the Persian Gulf war, the Military Sealift Command, a naval support fleet based in Bayonne, was overcharged $2 million by two companies selling fuel for transport and supply ships, prosecutors say. Yesterday, June King, the president of one of the companies, Kimac, of Barbados, was sentenced in Federal court to 18 months in prison for inflating prices the company charged the fleet and defrauding other naval outfits by as much as $5 million from 1989 to 1993.

title: Sanchez Vicario Makes Early Exit
description: Confronted by a limp second serve on her opponent's second match point, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario did not make a vintage reply. Instead, she plopped a limp forehand return into the net. Suddenly confronted by the worst Australian Open loss of her career, she ran away from the same stadium court where she had twice been a runner-up.

title: On Divided Isle of Cyprus, Missile Deal Widens Rift

title: High Court To Consider Insider Issue

The case is likely to produce one of the most important Supreme Court decisions in years on a question of securities law.

title: EXTENDED STAY AMERICA BUYING STUDIO PLUS HOTELS
description: Extended Stay America Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Studio Plus Hotels Inc. for about $290 million in stock. Extended Stay, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Studio Plus, of Lexington, Ky., both operate long-term hotels. Under the agreement, Extended Stay will exchange 1.2272 common shares for each of the 12.5 million outstanding Studio Plus shares. Based on Thursday's stock prices, the deal values Studio Plus at about $22.86 a share. Shares of Studio Plus rose $5.125, or nearly 35 percent, to $19.875 a share on the Nasdaq. Extended Stay stock fell $1.625, to $17.

title: The Man Who Helped Indict Smoking
description: The death of Oscar Auerbach this week at the age of 92 is a startling reminder of how far we have come in understanding the damage caused by smoking. Nowadays it is difficult to find anyone outside the tobacco industry who does not acknowledge that smoking is hazardous. A slew of surgeons general and the warnings on cigarette packages have told us so. But three to four decades ago it was not so clear. That was when Dr. Auerbach, a compulsively meticulous and hard-working pathologist, produced critical research findings that greatly strengthened the case against tobacco.

title: IS IT ART?
description: 1. This week the Museum of Modern Art opens ''Willem de Kooning: The Late Paintings, the 1980's,'' work executed while the artist was in the advanced stages of what is believed to be Alzheimer's disease. 2. The pictures were panned in San Francisco; one critic said they consist of ''big loopy ga-ga strokes.'' 3. Maybe so, but plenty of artists have done just fine with handicaps. Monet painted the water lily series at a time when cataracts and eye surgery affected his vision. 4. 'Style,' neurologically, is the deepest part of one's being,'' Oliver Sacks has written, ''and may be preserved, almost to the last, in a dementia.'' 5. Now 92, de Kooning is under round-the-clock supervision at his Long Island home. Visitors say he no longer recognizes anyone and seldom speaks.

title: Her Son/Daughter

I'm wearing black; we all are. It's my mother's funeral service, after all, and the little old ladies are taking inventory of the mourners. Me, I have to take inventory of my own identities whenever someone asks me who I am, and the answer that tumbles out of my mouth is rarely predictable. title: No Pants, No Head
description: The Chilean author Jaime Collyer was trained as a psychologist, but judging by PEOPLE ON THE PROWL (Latin American Literary Review, paper, $13.95), he is a born storyteller. The briefest entry in this elegant and engaging collection of short fiction is less than a page long but in no way slight, either in style or content; called ''Entropy,'' it employs its very brevity as an expression of its theme. Mr. Collyer writes stories that are centered on the striking incident, the odd turn of events or the perennial peculiarities of human nature -- like the scenario in ''Our Neighbor's Last Days,'' in which a man is much more interesting to his neighbors when he might be fatally ill than when his malady turns out to be treatable. As translated by Lillian Lorca de Tagle, Mr. Collyer's style is eminently clear and dry. (Consider, for example, this description of the title character from ''A Businessman Disappears'': ''He would pierce pasta, sauce and cheese with his fork, and twirl it solemnly, like a deposed prince brought down to the gutter, intent on regaining the privileges of his position under the humblest of circumstances, even when ingesting a dish of noodles.'') Whether telling of the fishmonger's forebear whose literal understanding of the phrase ''sans culottes'' leads him to the guillotine or of a ragtag band of youths who hijack a Santiago subway train, intent on somehow taking it to Cuba, Mr. Collyer is keenly aware of the absurdity that can infect the politics of rebellion, and his sense of irony is just as keen. He seems to know full well that armchair revolutionaries do less harm to themselves and the world if they remain seated. His supremely civilized intelligence, given to teasing the imagination, is predominantly on display, but a more emotional side occasionally surfaces. And in ''Round Trip Ticket,'' when the narrator explains why he cannot face a final encounter with a woman he once loved, Mr. Collyer reveals that he is just as deft at probing the heart. Frank Wilson

His entire career was in the life insurance business and for 25 years he was a member of the Million Dollar Round Table. Active in philanthropic activities, he was on the Board of Directors of the Third Street Music School Settlement, a ruling elder in the Brick Presbyterian Church and a past president and longtime Trustee of the North Carolina Society of New York. A passionate musician, he was dedicated to the musical education of young people. He was instrumental in founding the Diller Quaille-Brick Church summer music program for children. He is survived by his wife Agnes MacArthur Hayes, his children Alice MacArthur Hayes and John Sadler, by three grandsons Adam, Brian and Keith, and his sister Eleanor Barnhardt and two brothers Robert and Francis Hayes. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st St and Park Ave, at 4 PM, on Thursday, January 30. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Diller Quaille Music School, 24 E. 95th St, NYC 10128 or to the Third Street Music School Settlement, 233 E. 11th St, NYC 10014 or to the Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 E. 92nd St, NYC 10128.

The attractive Carle Place restaurant should continue to be a haven for diners intent on undoing holiday excesses and living up to their New Year's resolutions.

description: A picture caption on page 12 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the New York City Ballet misspells the name of a dancer. He is Sebastien Marcovici, not Sebastian Marcouici.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAEHENBUEHL, DAVID
description: KRAEHENBUEHL - David, 73, composer, teacher, pianist and music theorist died Jan. 3, 1997 in Trempealeau, Wisconsin. Known for founding the influential Yale ''Journal of Music Theory'', he is also widely appreciated by legions of piano teachers and their students for his hundreds of imaginative piano pieces in varied contemporary styles, accessible to young players. These he composed for the ''Frances Clark Library for Piano Students'' and for the National Keyboard Arts Associates. Other, much more major works, both sacred and secular, are performed frequently throughout the country. In 1983 he was honored by the Yale Music Alumni Association for his distinguished contributions. A ''David Kraehenbuehl Memorial Fund'' (call 415-392-3340) has been established by the Music Teachers' Association of California (MTAC) to support its composer-related programs and projects. His friends and associates express sympathy to his family. title: Deregulation: A Seismic Shift, Intensity Unknown
description: NO one knows with any degree of certainty what the impact will be if the New York State Legislature takes steps in the next few months to further deregulate the state's 1.2 million rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments. Empirical studies of the economic and social consequences of removing rent regulations have simply not been done, scholars of housing say.

title: Tax Respite May Not Prove Much
description: The one-week repeal of the sales tax on clothing that costs less than $500 may have stirred a tumult of promotion yesterday in stores across New York City and most of the state, but in the end this experiment will probably be of little use in gauging what would happen if the tax were reduced permanently.

title: Pants, Knickers and Plus Fours
description: THE SAINTED DIALECTICIAN STUART Berg Flexner liked to show us how men and women often use different words to describe the same things. Men say dishes and women say china; men say visitors and women say house guests; men say pants and women say trousers. (''I'll sing to him,'' sang the female lead in the Rodgers and Hart musical ''Pal Joey,'' adding, ''and worship the trousers that cling to him.'')

description: Mary Elizabeth Olazabal, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francisco J. Olazabal of Miami, is to be married this evening to Ivan Paul Harris, a son of Dr. Jacob J. Harris of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Marilyn R. Harris. The Rev. Ernesto Travieso, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate with Rabbi Suzanne Carter at Villa Vizcaya in Miami.

Survived by his wife, Muriel; his son Gilman of New York; his daughter Kate Burke Wood of Princeton, New Jersey; 3 step-children, Simon Atkinson, David Atkinson and Judy Atkinson Moy, all of England; 7 grandchildren, six step-grandchildren and 5 great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, kindly send contributions to a favorite charity.

description: Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts who was the only candidate in the 1992 Democratic Presidential campaign to offer painful solutions to the nation's economic problems, died last night at a hospital in Boston. He was 55.

Had a suitor arrived, he would have been shown into one of the beau parlors, two rooms off the lobby filled with elegant furniture and the smell of roses. In there, and only in there, courting and flirting are permitted -- but not past 11 P.M.

Montoya of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Dr. Solomon A. Montoya Jr. Msgr. James P. Swiader performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: The Revision Of Rte. 25A Plans
description: The article ''Protests Lead to Revised Plans for Rte. 25A'' did a good job of presenting opposition to the Department of Transportation's plan but neglected to mention some important facts. This project has been under consideration since the 1980's which is why it's being funded by the New York State Transportation Bond Issue approved in 1988. The Concerned Citizens group had their own meeting with Edward J. Petrou, the regional director, on Nov. 6. 1996; their alternative plan will not ''do everything the state plan would have done.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Styles pages on Dec. 29 about celebrity endorsements of designers referred incorrectly to the involvement of the Fugees and Eric Clapton in a party for Giorgio Armani last fall. The Fugees were not paid to perform; Armani says $20,000 was donated to a charity of the band's choice. Armani and Mr. Clapton's manager say he performed free, not for $100,000.

title: Ahna Hogeland, Geoffrey Petersen
description: Ahna Elizabeth Claiborne Hogeland, the daughter of Virginia Lea Mulligan of Haverford, Pa., and Richard Wright Hogeland of Kirbymoorside, England, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Morley Petersen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Geoffrey Petersen, also of Haverford. The Rev. Samuel P. Riccobene performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: When 'Kill the Ump' Is No Longer a Joke
description: After Bob West, a referee with 20 years of experience, disqualified a high school wrestler last January in Spokane, Wash., for an illegal mount, the 17-year-old athlete head-butted West so hard the official was knocked unconscious.

title: Exercise In Small Town Aviation
description: MOST airfields are bustling centers of activity, but at Danielson Airport they do in a month what some would do in a busy afternoon. There are generally just 100 to 200 takeoffs and landings a month, including students at the flight school. ''Sometimes in the winter when the weather's real bad, we might not have any for a day or two,'' said J. Gary Boroughf, president of Northeast Air Management Inc., which manages the airport.

title: Sharing Tax Break On Clothes
description: CREATIVE fund-raising is the hallmark of the Westchester Arts Council. And New York State's tax experiment, suspending for one week the state and local sales tax for clothing and footwear under $500, is giving the Arts Council a golden opportunity to raise money pleasantly and painlessly.

description: ''We've seen trains with their whole sides done, like in the 70's and early 80's,'' says Lieut. Steve Mona (pictured below), who heads the N.Y.P.D.'s Tran-sit Bureau Vandal Squad. ''Sometimes they'll give us a clue, like, 'Hi, from Berlin!'''

description: Hockey cranks have complained all season that there aren't enough goals being scored because too many restraining fouls are going uncalled and too many teams are playing the boring zone trap.

description: SOUTHOFF-Bill, January 13, 1997. A dear, brave man, leaves many friends and beloved wife, Olga. R.I.P., sweet William.

description: In 1995, as ethics questions enveloped Speaker Newt Gingrich, his allies sought to discredit the accusers, a memorandum shows. Page 23.

title: A Peripatetic Festival That Edison Would Love
description: THIS year is the 150th anniversary of Thomas Edison's birth. Given all his inventions, from the light bulb to the phonograph, we might be forgiven for overlooking one of the most significant: the movies. But not if John Columbus can help it.

title: Penalties And Power
description: The next question after the House ethics committee's recommendation of a stiff fine and a reprimand for Speaker Newt Gingrich, at least for those for whom the Speaker is neither savior nor devil incarnate, is whether the level of punishment is enough to enable the House to function.

title: At Pier 63, a Place for the Horsy Set
description: ''Imagine riding in our arena on a summer's eve with the doors up as boats go by,'' said Grania Williams, vice president of operations of the members-only Chelsea Equestrian Center. The 40,000-square-foot indoor/outdoor arena is to open in May at Pier 63, next to Chelsea Piers sports complex, at West 23d Street and the West Side Highway.

title: China on a Budget
description: To the Editor: Having recently completed an independent trip to Beijing, we enjoyed reading Ms. Spano's article about it. We were sorry to read she was disappointed with her trip to the Great Wall. We have two suggestions for seeing it.

title: Glitz and Extravagance And Claims of Restraint
description: Washington claims to have sworn off the corrupting influences of the dollar and the freebie for the second installation of Bill Clinton as President. But for this town, that is more than a little like the dieter who makes a show of ordering a one-calorie cola with his double cheeseburger and fries.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: When planning a trip, it is certainly possible to do the initial research on the World Wide Web, much as you might buy a couple of guidebooks. The difference is that a guidebook has a finite number of pages while the Web, though not endless, is so vast that it might just as well be. Many of the most popular destinations have Web pages put up by chambers of commerce and the like. These can help, but it is the job of such organizations to make their places sound wonderful. Following is an account of approximately two days of Web research, with many dead ends and detours left out.

description: To the Editor:

title: Jesse Jackson: Bull or Bear?
description: On the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. last week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson told applauding black executives, ''Today, we bring The Dream to Wall Street.''

title: From Madonna To Aristide
description: EL DIARIO/LA PRENSA -- Wednesday's teaser acress top raises the issue: Was Madonna the right actress to play Eva Peron?

title: Dr. King's Message, Through Lives He Touched
description: In August 1968, shortly after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., June Clark of Harlem left her job as a secretary at Columbia University and fled to Amsterdam with her husband.

title: Freshly Washed Taxis and Slanting Light
description: WHATEVER their twists of plot or revelations of character, works of fiction set in New York can conjure up a rich atmosphere in which to set their stories. The city backdrop, with its hustle and bustle of the morning or enigmas of the evening, is important to three recent works, despite their varied themes.

title: Blustery North Kohala Gives a History Lesson
description: THE richly historical district of North Kohala, in the northwest corner of the Big Island, is also one of the most remote and least visited areas in Hawaii. At the rocky beaches that line the rugged coast, including dramatic Keokea Bay, the water is too rough for swimming. The eastern slopes of Haleakala, on Maui, are visible across the restless waters of the 'Alenuihaha Channel, and the 'apa'apa'a winds, which have inspired many a song, cross the channel with such force that the trees along the North Kohala coastline lean toward the mountains. From the shore, windblown grasslands rise to pasture land, deep green rain forest, then the Kohala Mountains.

title: Celebrating Mozart's Birthday Twice
description: THE Orchestra of the Old Fairfield Academy has scheduled twin celebrations of Mozart's birthday (Jan. 27, 1756) over the weekend, with an 8 P.M. Saturday program and a 3 o'clock encore next Sunday afternoon at the Norwalk Concert Hall. On both programs are the Overture to ''Lucio Silla,'' the Clarinet Concerto, the Fourth Horn Concerto and the ''Linz'' Symphony, No. 36. In both concerto performances the soloists will be using the instruments for which the pieces were originally written (Erick Hoeprich playing bassett clarinet, R.J. Kelley a natural horn), rather than their modern counterparts.

title: Trimming Pounds With Modest Portions
description: NOTHING occupies the list of New Year's resolutions like diet. Need it be repeated that long-term moderation will inevitably be a more successful weight-loss plan than some quick fix?

title: With AIDS, Advance,More Disappointment
description: In the last year, the widespread use of combinations of new and older drugs has changed the face of AIDS, promising to transform a fatal infection to a manageable chronic disease.

title: Seeking Shelter in Real Estate Trusts
description: WHEN someone recommends real estate as a good, steady investment for those worried about iffy times, survivors of the real estate boom and bust of the 1980's might be stunned. But they should get used to it. The companies known as real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, are now commonly seen as a good way to invest defensively.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 19, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Speak Up If HOV Lanes Were Your Idea
description: DEBI SANCHELLI's boss lets her bring her infant daughter to work. Visitors to the office in downtown Morristown are usually pleasantly surprised to enter a reception room that has baby furniture along with the usual chairs and desks.

title: Hello Again
description: WHEN we packed up three children and a dog and left our rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper West Side for an old farmhouse in Connecticut, our friends said it was an act of treason. They were angry, accusing and wounded, as if we had broken the faith or forsaken a cause, and we were heavy-hearted and apologetic, but adamant.

title: Please Stop Thinking About Tomorrow
description: The President approached his second inauguration with a chip on his shoulder. His volcanic temper -- according to his personal secretary, no sound on earth compared to that of the President of the United States swearing a blue streak -- had been severely tried by press attacks alleging undue influence in his Administration by foreign interests. It was a resentful chief executive who repeated his oath of office, delivered an address of 135 words and took his leave, no doubt consoling himself with the thought that republics are notoriously ungrateful.

title: This Is a Quiz: Why Is Silas Deane on Route 99?
description: THEY are better known by their numbers than their names. Yet the names of Connecticut's many highways reflect a fascinating cross section of state history, some of it familiar, some of it otherwise.

title: A Long-Orphaned Family Plot
description: The inscription on the brown stone marker reads:

title: Honoring Fassbinder The Director, Not the Man
description: THE YEAR HAS JUST BEGUN, BUT IT'S SAFE to predict that the Museum of Modern Art's Rainer Werner Fassbinder retrospective, opening Thursday night and running through March 20, will be remembered as one of the most exhilarating cinema events of 1997.

title: An Ancient's Cave of Inspiration
description: Athens was clearly the place to be in the fifth century B.C.

title: Ailing Gulf War Veterans Search for Some Answers
description: MICHAEL DONNELLY spent 15 years in the United States Air Force flying fighter jets and traveling throughout the world. During that time, Mr. Donnelly, who lives in South Windsor, flew 44 combat missions in the Persian Gulf war and rose to the rank of major. But his flying days ended when he retired from the Air Force last year, disabled by a degenerative nerve disease that some doctors say is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease. The tall, slim former pilot, who used to soar across the sky, moves across the floor with the aid of a walker. And when he travels now, he uses a wheelchair.

title: A Victim of DES Puts Experience Into a Documentary
description: JUDITH HELFAND was 14 when she heard about DES, a drug given to five million women from 1938 to 1971 to prevent miscarriages. Ms. Helfand was home from Kennedy High School in Bellmore because of a broken leg when she saw a talk show about DES, the synthetic estrogen diethylstilbestrol, a and its legacy. Of the 2.4 million daughters of the women who took DES, half have malformed reproductive organs or child-bearing problems, and 1 in 1,000 has developed or is expected to develop DES-related cancer.

title: China on a Budget
description: To the Editor: When reading the Travel section, I usually save the articles by Susan Spano for last because her subjects, writing and judicious blend of plain information and personal responses never fail to mark her as a remarkable traveler. She makes me want to pack right up.

title: A Deft Ski Maker Works a Slippery Slope
description: FOR several years, the ski business has been about as exciting as the bunny slope at a winter resort. That's why Mark Greenberg, who manages the Invesco Strategic Leisure fund, recently went to see for himself a supposedly hot new ski from K2 Inc. His aim was to find out if there might be some signs of life in an otherwise dismal industry.

title: Lubov Rostova, Dancer, 80
description: Lubov Rostova, a dancer with the Ballets Russes companies of the 1930's, died on Monday at her home in Oyster Bay, L.I. She was 80.

title: Educating New Haven, and Its Critics
description: THE chairwoman of the New Haven Board of Education, Patricia McCann-Vissepo, is determined to dispel stereotypes about urban schools. In fact, said Ms. McCann, ''I would send my own child to any New Haven high school before I would send him'' to the suburban West Haven High, East Haven High or Hamden High. And she does. Her eighth-grader attends a New Haven magnet school, West Hills Middle School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEEDLEMAN, ABRAHAM
description: NEEDLEMAN-Abraham. Died January 16, 1997. Beloved father and grandfather. Contributions inhis memory to the United Jewish Appeal.

description: HOMEOWNERS' insurance is probably not the first thing you think of when the talk turns to civil lawsuits. Sure, you are covered if a neighbor sues after tripping over your garden hose. But if things get more serious, you figure you have to turn elsewhere.

title: Whitman Emphasizes A Record Beyond Taxes
description: Her proposal to cut the state's income tax helped get her elected. But Governor Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey says she is concerned that she seems to be known only for cutting taxes. In an interview, she laid out a re-election strategy intended to broaden her appeal among Democratic and independent voters.

title: The Portrait Of a Dazzler Who Found Repression Is Rewarding
description: IT SEEMED NOTHING COULD quiet the man on the mobile phone propped against an ornate pilaster of the Lanesborough Hotel's Withdrawing Room. Not the bewigged Earl of Huntingdon scowling from the wall, not the humbling rich Regency appointments of the suite, not the censorious glances of the crisply uniformed staff.

title: Mixing Brecht With the Brighter Colors of Milhaud
description: This afternoon, at the Bouwerie Lane Theater, the Jean Cocteau Repertory will present the world premiere of a version of Bertolt Brecht's ''Mother Courage and Her Children,'' with songs and incidental music by the composer Darius Milhaud and book and lyrics by Eric Bentley. The cast of 15 will be directed by Robert Hupp. Mr. Bentley, the critic, translator and playwright, worked on the project with Milhaud in 1959 and 1960. Here, he describes their collaboration.

title: Santa Monica Without a Car
description: HERE are the usual complaints from friends who have taken quick trips to Los Angeles: 1. They spent the entire weekend in the car. 2. They never once saw the ocean. 3. They didn't spot a single celebrity.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: KINK

title: America's Gateway
description: Mandy Patinkin, like 4 in 10 other Americans, traces his roots to forebears who came through Ellis Island as immigrants. In the documentary ELLIS ISLAND -- SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on HIST -- he narrates the story of the island, from its construction in 1892 until its closing in 1954 as a result of new immigration laws and its conversion to a national park. The three-hour program profiles some of the more than 13 million men, women and children who came through Ellis Island (about 20,000 a day at its peak), some of whom were detained because of disease for periods of a few hours to several weeks. -- Suzanne O'Connor

title: Ex-Cabby Accused in Stolen Taxi Plot
description: In November 1995, Sung Min, then a 20-year-old college student, was named by the Taxi and Limousine Commission as No. 2 on the list of the city's 10 worst cab drivers. In 22 months, he had amassed 43 violations, including speeding, abuse of passengers and failing to cooperate with the police.

title: Experts Agree: We're Finished
description: With the year 2000 approaching, it seems that everyone Christians and

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'HAVING OUR SAY'

title: A World of Enchantment, Page After Illuminated Page
description: FOR MORE THAN a thousand years, beginning around A.D. 500, Roman Catholic monks copied stories and illustrated them with heroic saints and fantastic beasts, capturing the glorious imagery also seen in medieval stained-glass windows. These illuminated manuscripts have been popular ever since, first with monarchs and bishops, and more recently with bankers and industrialists.

title: Decoding Electrical Codes and Regulations
description: ELECTRICITY is essential to our daily existence. We use it to light homes, run motors and power our communication devices. It is a powerful source of energy, but it can be dangerous unless properly controlled.

title: An Ex-Marine's Way to Build Self-Esteem
description: THE United States Marine Corps calls the obstacle course for new recruits at Parris Island, S. C., a confidence course. This semantic distinction had a major impact on a resident here, Walter Anderson, when he went through Parris Island as a 17-year-old recruit in 1961.

title: The Vital Center Will Not Hold
description: President Clinton approaches his second inauguration with his campaign still running at full throttle. Having spent 1996 embracing the political center so fervently that his Republican opponents were hard-pressed to find an issue on which they disagreed with him, he has been talking ever since of governing from a new ''vital center.'' ''The public wants us to work together,'' he said recently. ''I stand ready to forge a coalition of the center. . . .''

title: America, Syria and South Africa
description: The usually warm relations between the United States and Nelson Mandela's South African Government were troubled last week by news of a prospective arms deal between South Africa and Syria. Washington put Pretoria on notice that the transfer to Syria of a sophisticated system for accurately directing tank fire might force the suspension of American aid to South Africa, which this year amounts to $82 million. President Mandela responded icily that his country would make its own decisions in these matters.

title: Arena Football Team Runs Into Name Problems
description: For decades, the phrase red dog has been synonymous with quarterback pain, a plaintive wail brought on by the crushing blow of a linebacker. So when it came up in the search for a name for Jim Leahy's new arena football team, he thought it set just the right vicious tone. Surely the nearest geographical competitors -- the New York Cityhawks and the Albany Firebirds -- would take notice.

title: Ebonics Reconsidered
description: The choice of words, it seems, was everything.

title: 3 Accused of Kidnapping Connecticut Boy
description: Three men described by investigators as members of a Fujianese gang were charged in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Friday with the November kidnapping of a 12-year-old Connecticut boy, Federal law-enforcement officials said. The boy was held for six days and released unharmed in Queens after his father paid a ransom of $88,000.

title: Clue to Global Warming: The Tango Is Coming Back
description: The crowd watched nervously from the sidelines at Bistro Latino as Daniela Arcuri and Armando Orzuza glided gracefully from one end of the dance floor to the other. Arm in arm, eyes locked, they moved effortlessly to the beat, teaching the dance of love, the tango. Moments later couples spilled onto the floor, some expert and some just beginning, hoping to experience ''the connection'' that people at the restaurant were talking about in hushed tones.

title: From a Rental to a Co-op to a Single-Family House
description: WHEN they couldn't find another square inch to show off the wedding presents, Nina Phillips and Malcolm Pollack decided to leave their third-floor walk-up studio on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and move to a bigger place.

title: Russians Learn Secrets of the New World, and Some From the Old
description: The unraveling of the Soviet Union released a tidal wave of educated emigrants, thousands of whom settled in Brooklyn's Brighton Beach and other vibrant Russian enclaves. Their intellectual curiosity and growing affluence have given rise, by one count, to 38 Russian-language papers, plus a cable television channel, the Russian Television Network. The Moscow newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets has published a New York weekly, B Novom Svetye, since 1995.

title: MAKING ART OF SPORT
description: I enjoyed Michiko Kakutani's ''Making Art of Sport'' (Culture Zone, Dec. 15) but would challenge her on one important point. Sports differ from movies and novels precisely because they do not guarantee a neat, morally satisfying ending. Yes, the Yankees' come-from-behind victories, with the manager's dying brother being saved in a subplot, would be too neat and heartwarming to be credible in a movie. But how often does life exceed art in that way?

title: Inside the White House Closet
description: First Ladies' inaugural gowns wind up in the Smithsonian. But what about the outfits worn by Presidents? A look at Mr. Clinton's fashion sense, and at Presidential garb through the years, in Styles, page 35.

description: THE show by Cathleen Lewis at Lehman College Art Gallery here is the latest in a series devoted to artists who have lived, worked or grown up in the borough.

title: What Is 2BZ? And Why Is It On the Phone?

title: Liquor's Double Blue Laws
description: Dave Orlander is a Hasidic Jew who, like his brother in Bay Ridge and their father before them, owns a kosher liquor store. That means he does all of zero sales each weekend.

title: A New, Spacey Look For MTV
description: THREE years ago, a video appeared on the MTV alternative-rock show ''120 Minutes'' notable for its complete discordance with everything around it. The music consisted of the sound of rushing water and tinkling electric piano topped by a warped electronic beat, the calling card of the spaced-out variant of techno music called ambient. The image was a cardboard cutout of the performer popping in and out of a stop-motion collage of jetsam and garbage on a beach.

title: Spring Comes Back to Greenbay
description: The river through this small blue-collar city is full of islands of ice, and the farm fields on the edge of town are covered with snow. Overhead, the sky is as gray as stubble on an old man's chin, and it is hard to remember the last time that the temperature was above freezing.

title: An Accidental Tour
description: IF a poll-taker were to ask me, right now, ''What's your favorite place in Great Britain?'' I would answer ''Accident and Emergency at St. Thomas's Hospital.'' I really would. During a recent two-week working visit to London, I landed in the blessed haven of A. & E. three times -- if you count a pause there on the way to physiotherapy. Each time it was like wandering into an exceptionally soothing TV hospital sitcom.

title: One China? Maybe, But 3 Newspapers
description: The tens of thousands of Chinese living in the city are divided by old-world politics, a reality reflected in the pages of New York's three major Chinese-language dailies: The World Journal, published by the United Daily News group, based in Taiwan; Sing Tao Daily, published by Sing Tao Ltd., based in Hong Kong, and The China Press, run by a group of local investors.

title: In Santa Fe, Residents Turn Cold Shoulder to Newcomers
description: As white millionaires and New Yorkers, Paul and Susan Tierney do not seem like the usual plaintiffs seeking redress under the 14th Amendment, originally written to protect freed slaves after the Civil War.

title: 2 Concert Virtuosos To Make County Debut
description: TWO of the brightest lights in the rising generation of concert virtuosos are coming to Westchester. The violinist Chee-Yun and the cellist Allison Eldredge will be featured in the Brahms Double Concerto with the Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra at 8 P.M. next Saturday at Temple Beth El in Chappaqua. Both are winners of Avery Fisher Career Grants and have appeared with major orchestras worldwide. The music director, James Sadewhite, will round out the all-Brahms program with the Serenade No. 1 and an excerpt from ''A German Requiem.'' Tickets will be available at the door or by calling 241-0558.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVINE, DONNA WILBANKS
description: LAVINE-Donna Wilbanks, 71. On January 16, at home in Berkeley, CA. Formerly of Manhattan. Born Gadsden, AL. Also lived in Grants Pass, OR, and Eureka, CA. Survived by husband of 39 years Mel Lavine, former producer with NBC and CBS news; brothers William Wilbanks of Willsboro, OR, Richardson Wilbanks of Berkeley, Jan Wilbanks of Eugene, OR, and half brother Charles Wilbanks of Washington, DC. Private commemorative gatherings planned in Berkeley and later in New York.

title: Jill Devine and Alexander Hornig

Hornig of Los Angeles. The Rev. Thomas Cushman performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

description: In the latest sign that racial and ethnic tensions on the Dallas school board are still festering, white and Hispanic board members unanimously elected a new superintendent this month in a vote that black members boycotted.

title: Comparing Sport Sedans for the Status-Conscious
description: I HATE to bring my middle-class bias to bear here, but I can't help it -- those glittering playthings in the driveway are worth 10 times the price of my first house.

title: The Power Women Share as Lobbyists
description: THE president of a prominent taxpayers' group has discounted them as ''self-annointed do-gooders'' who squander public money. And the chairman of the county chapter of the Christian Coalition recently claimed their ''so-called people's agenda'' was a front for Planned Parenthood. But judging by the handprint that the Westchester Women's Agenda left on the county's latest budget, the impact of their political influence is difficult to deny -- their critics' sentiments notwithstanding.

title: Restaurant Revival Goes to Court
description: A TWO-YEAR battle over Atlantic Beach waterfront has moved to State Supreme Court in Mineola.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED
description: You will probably get a lot of static for leaving out notable people who died last year. My beef, however, is with your inclusion of Tony Kushner's ''A Backstage Pass to Hell.'' With all due respect to the Schine family, G. David Schine was an airhead who was led by his nose and deep pockets through Europe and the news media by Roy Cohn in one of the most ridiculous and unfruitful witch hunts of the McCarthy era. The fact that David had the good sense to use his money more effectively in Hollywood to wrap himself around some real talent is insufficient to warrant two pages in this issue.

title: Looking Back at 'Is New York Back?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Toys 'R' Us Tries to Shed Unused Space: Zabar May Bite
description: The two huge signs over the construction site at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and 80th Street still read, ''Toys 'R' Us Coming Soon,'' but one is marred by graffiti, a scarred symbol of the toy retailer's clouded future in upper Manhattan.

title: Inaugural Poetry: The Ode Not Taken
description: ACROSS four years in office, President Clinton has made familiar that near-teary gesture of seeming touched in public by a story, a phrase, a humble presence, and of punctuating it with the patriarchal smile and head-bobbing display of approval patented by a predecessor, Ronald Reagan. At his second inauguration tomorrow, Americans might look for such a moment from Mr. Clinton when Miller Williams, an Arkansas poet, rises to honor him in a burst of inspiration ordered up for the occasion.

title: A 60's Original With a New Life on the Fringe
description: INFLUENTIAL AMERICAN artists are often cranks recalcitrant, inscrutable, possessors of a nearly untenable vision. When John Fahey's recordings of syncopated, finger-style guitar compositions, redolent of old blues, rags and hymns, began appearing in the early 1960's, he was taken to be an acoustic blues revivalist or a coffeehouse folkie. An early LP cover even confirms the typing a bit, showing him in an honest-looking herringbone jacket and desert boots. But an arrogant look in his eyes seem to dare you to figure him out.

title: O Glorious France! (Born In the U.S.A.)
description: AMERICANS. HANG YOUR HEADS. France is not pleased with you. It is not enough that your State Department fails to treat her as a mighty diplomatic power; now you persist in fiddling with her culture. Careful, lest you and your British colleagues find yourselves relegated to the wrong side of the French border, wistful outsiders looking in at the musical glory that is modern France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, ROSE C.
description: LIBERMAN-Rose C. Yeshiva University and its Women's Organization mourn the passing of a longtime, devoted friend and tireless worker, beloved wife of the late Norman Liberman and mother of Barnet (and Sue) Liberman and Gladys (and Dr. Robert) Richter. A stalwart advocate of Jewish education and the State of Israel, she strengthened YU through nearly seven decades of extraordinary service to the YUWO-as a founding member and vice president, Manhattan Chapter; national tablet chairman and, with her mother, the late Sara Rivka Cunin, founder of the YUWO Hall of Plaques in our Main Building; chairman, theater and opera benefits; and esteemed mentor of YUWO's national chairman. Sue Liberman and Gladys Richter carry on her noble efforts as YUWO vice presidents. Heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Dinah Pinczower Chairman, National Board, YUWO

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED
description: What was missing in Allen Ginsberg's portrayal of the life of Herbert Huncke (''The Hipster's Hipster'') was not more episodes of thievery like the one about his supposedly stealing some books from Ginsberg in 1947. What was missing was the reason that an incredible group of poets, writers, film makers, artists, photographers, musicians and scholars surrounded him for 40 years.

title: French Food in an Unpretentious Setting
description: FRANKLY old-fashioned, stamped tin ceilings, lace curtains and a butterscotch and milk chocolate color scheme are just a few of the features of this unpretentious spot, once a neighborhood tavern for the factory workers of Anaconda. The small scale of the dining rooms and the manageable menu no doubt explain in part this restaurant's staying power. The other part can be explained by the appeal of the food. Dishes are big on flavor; sauces, in particular, are divine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANDEN, SUMNER ANTHONY
description: STANDEN-Sumner Anthony. Suddenly, in London, January 18. Age 59. Son of the late Anthony Standen, author of ''The Sacred Cow'' and other books. Beloved husband of Jane and father of Julian, both of London. Brother of Julian of San Francisco. Nephew of Edith Appleton Standen of New York City. Stepson of Lisl Standen of South Kent, CT.

Former President and CEO of Lion Ribbon Co., past-President of The Advisory Board of Saint Vincent's Hospital, Westchester. Beloved husband of Penelope (Penny) F. McDermott; adored father of James A., III, Mark C., Jeffrey F., and Douglas J.; fatherin-law of Margaret S., Susan B., Maureen L.; grandfather of James IV, Peter, Kevin and Margaret; dear brother of Mary Jo McCarthy Mitchell; and uncle of ten nieces & nephews. Visiting hours will be at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, New York, Monday, January 20, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be held 10 AM, Tuesday at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye. Donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital of Westchester, 275 North Street, Harrison, New York 10528 or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: Ready, Set, Inaugurate
description: President Clinton's inauguration is still a day away, but the avalanche of parties and hype is in full swing. Bleachers have appeared along the parade route, bands are assembling, and, of course, the big speech is being polished. Page 20.

title: 2 Rebels Making Paris Debuts
description: The fashion world is in a high state of anticipation. Today and tomorrow in Paris, two Englishmen, John Galliano, 36, and Alexander McQueen, 27, both known for rebellious, phantasmagorical designs, will show their first collections for two top houses. Can their imaginations be harnessed to the discipline of couture?

description: Kristina Ann Emanuels, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Emanuels of Sacramento, Calif., is to be married today to George Dyer Phipps, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Phipps Jr. of Old Westbury, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike is to perform the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Columba in Inverness, Calif.

title: Renewal of Union Square Reaches a Key Block
description: THE long-awaited construction of a mixed-use building on the full block south of Union Square between Broadway and Fourth Avenue is under way, foreshadowing a large expansion of retailing and entertainment activities in an area that has been one of the most active for redevelopment in Manhattan.

title: South Koreans Limit Strike To One Day Of Each Week
description: The leaders of a strike that has paralyzed some important South Korean industries announced today that workers would return to their jobs on Monday while continuing to strike one day a week.

title: Strong Faith, Slow Funds
description: Every Sunday morning, 150 parishioners walk up the stairs of St. Mary's Romanian Orthodox Church and settle into a cavernous space enlivened by traditional Byzantine touches but cluttered with construction debris. The altar has been finished and icons have been hung, but the walls are unplastered. Yellow and pink insulation sets off the greens and the purples of a painting of Jesus carrying the cross. Plastic sheeting substitutes for stained glass.

title: Governor of Puerto Rico Presses Battle for Statehood
description: At his inauguration as Puerto Rico's re-elected Governor earlier this month, Pedro J. Rossello apologized to those who find him ''stubborn, obsessive, even intransigent.'' He then promised more of the same for his next four-year term, including forging ahead with a new plebiscite to get the island and the United States to redefine their nearly century-old relationship once and for all.

title: A Peace Dividend For Jordan Tourism
description: Citing an increase in visitors since it signed the peace treaty with Israel in 1994, Jordan is beginning to market itself and has started opening tourism offices. The first has opened in its Washington embassy, to promote travel to Jordan in the United States and Canada. In 1994, about 13,000 Americans visited Jordan on package tours. That figure more than doubled, to over 31,000, in 1995. Along with more visitors, there has been an expansion in services, for example, more licensed tour guides, more car rental offices, and more hotels.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SMALL WORLDS By Allen Hoffman. Abbeville, $24.95.

title: In Jackson Heights, Indian Food for Indian Diners
description: CHINESE pack the restaurants of Chinatown and Japanese fill good sushi bars, but in the Indian restaurants on Sixth Street, a South Asian face is rare at the table.

title: The Outcasts
description: TWO YEARS AGO, WHILE RWANDA'S Hutu militias were murdering half a million Tutsis, most of them men, Hutu soldiers and civilians also raped more than 250,000 women. Never having enjoyed a particularly high status even in the best of times, these women soon found themselves in the most dire straits. Widowed by the genocide and stigmatized by rape, they were often cast out of their hometowns. Without husbands to protect them, they lost their connection to community, which forms the bedrock of Rwandan village life.

title: Park Is Pit-Bull Killing Field
description: Until about a year ago, Sundays at the Frederick B. Judge playground in South Ozone Park were serene. Then came the snarling hounds.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SHORT-TERM LOSSES Stories. By Mark Lindensmith. Southern Methodist University, cloth, $22.50; paper, $12.95.

title: To the Battlements at Fortress Fidelity
description: AFTER one of the most disappointing years in its half-century existence, Fidelity Investments has decided that its mutual fund customers need a little hand-holding. If only it can first get them to stop their hand-wringing.

title: Pilot and Mother, 71, May Have Died Before Crash
description: Investigators searching the wreckage of a mall plane on a wooded hillside in New Hampshire said yesterday that it had crashed on Friday when it apparently ran out of gas after cruising over three states on automatic pilot. They said the occupants -- a Long Island pilot and his 71-year-old mother -- had apparently been overcome and perhaps killed by carbon monoxide fumes 90 minutes before the final plunge.

title: On a 'Block Beautiful,' An Architect's Legacy
description: BLOCKS, not individual buildings, are the tissue of the city, and yet blocks are studied much less often than the structures that line them. A good place to start is the picturesque little ''block beautiful,'' the mixed bag of houses on 19th Street between Irving Place and Third Avenue. A variety of owners there are making changes that reflect multiple attitudes toward the individual buildings and even the block as a whole.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood's Long Memory
description: Elia Kazan informed on his old friends in the Communist Party when he was summoned to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1952. Other prominent entertainment personalities, among them Lee J. Cobb, Burl Ives and the choreographer Jerome Robbins, also named names, but nobody has suffered the sustained censure inflicted upon Mr. Kazan. In the last few weeks, he has again been denied two prestigious Hollywood awards for lifetime achievement, one from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, the other from the American Film Institute.

title: Newsstands Go Downhill, for Now
description: In the last 12 months, many of the green steel newsstands around the city have become grubbier. Rust has spread, paint has peeled, metal racks covered with crude plastic tarpaulins jut in front of pedestrians. And display space once devoted to newspapers and magazines has shrunk, with the reading material replaced by earrings, combs, barrettes, scarves, gloves and assorted ''I Love New York'' souvenirs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, FRANK
description: ANGELO-Frank. God's Love We Deliver honors the memory of our friend Frank Angelo, who died on Jan. 12. Frank was a co-founder of MAC Cosmetics, and an extraordinary supporter of God's Love We Deliver's free meal delivery service for homebound people with AIDS. He will long be remembered for the creation of the MAC AIDS Fund-a model of responsive corporate leadership-and for his passionate commitment to the fight against AIDS.

title: No Such Thing As Safe Radiation
description: ''How much radiation would it take to cause cancer, especially breast cancer?'' Dr. Jean Howard of the Brookhaven National Laboratory (Letters, Dec. 15) asks this question and replies that she has ''found that there are no scientific data to show that radiation doses less than 10,000 millirems cause an increased cancer risk.''

title: The Christmas the Car Died
description: It's about time for the Christmas tree to come down, but I'm having second thoughts. This year's holiday has been one to remember, mostly because of a few generous souls who made it possible for us to have a proper Christmas.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be legally observed.

description: Stretching his body across an iron grate, Jose Torres ignored the stale smells and savored the warmth, not knowing how long it might last.
