title: Classy Italian Fare at Pizza Parlor Prices
description: THE sound of cool jazz and Gershwin tunes fills the sleek, stylish, little Pasta Cucina in Farmingdale.

title: Like Her Paintings, Quiet, Unchanging and Revered
description: AGNES MARTIN IS A LEGEND IN American art. The spare abstract paintings she has produced over the past 40 years -- graphite lines through fields of white or gray or washy colors -- are as highly revered, and as unchanging, as icons.

title: Leave Ozzie and Harriet Alone
description: On a gray morning last August I was riding with David Nelson in the hills just above Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood. We were on our way to see the house where he grew up with his parents, Ozzie and Harriet, and his brother, Rick, the same house shown at the beginning of episodes of ''The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet.'' That program, which was on the air from 1952 to 1966, was the original family situation comedy, a television genre that David's father invented. ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Roseanne'' and even ''The Simpsons'' are direct descendants of ''Ozzie and Harriet'' and owe their existence to Ozzie's -- let's call it what it was -- genius.

title: THE HOLOCAUST WAS NO SECRET
description: Vanden Heuvel states that ''we all knew, and couldn't do anything about it -- except win the war.'' It is comforting to note that Wallenberg, Schindler and many others did not take this passive stance.

title: On Hospitals And Cancer Care
description: The article ''More Hospitals Providing Cancer Care'' (Jan. 12) did not include Winthrop-University Hospital among the Long Island hospitals that offer radiation and chemotherapy on an outpatient basis.

title: China on a Budget
description: To the Editor: Susan Spano's article about Chongqing ''Touring China's Past, and a Bit of America's'' (Dec. 8) inspires me to write. The high point of my visit to Chongqing in October with Smartours was the painters' village mentioned by Ms. Spano. Here one can visit a number of studios, meet the artists and see some nice art. I was able to purchase an oil painting for a very reasonable price through ''hard'' bargaining. This I did by setting my limit, making an offer way below, coming up slightly to show interest, and then walking away pleasantly when my offer wasn't accepted.

title: Mexico Repays Its Debt
description: No sooner had President Clinton bailed out Mexico in 1995, forestalling an economic collapse that might have also sunk other big, emerging markets, than critics warned he could kiss that $12.5 billion goodbye. ''You'll never see it again,'' Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato warned. Last week the Treasury saw it again. Getting a better rate from the international lenders who have returned to Mexico, the Zedillo Government repaid Washington -- and the Administration boasted that it made $560 million in interest. DAVID E. SANGER

title: Fort Lauderdale
description: With its reputation as a spring-break capital long behind it, Fort Lauderdale -- along with its neighboring beach towns -- is working hard to become known as a destination for grown-ups who cherish good food, shopping bargains and a taste of Americana. While Miami, just 25 miles to the south, offers Cuban food and salsa music, the 28 municipalities known as Greater Fort Lauderdale boast cowboys, a flea market with drive-in movies, and a circus.

title: Russia's Gross National Legislature
description: WHEN Communist legislators in the lower house of the Russian Parliament threatened last week to try to impeach President Boris N. Yeltsin -- bedridden with double pneumonia -- on charges of absenteeism, even some of their own party members blushed.

title: No-Fault Divorce Has Damaged the Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor Pepper
description: HISTORIANS SPECULATE THAT PEPPER changed the course of European history. These green, black and white berries of the Piper nigrum vine are potent pellets that enhance rather than mask the flavor of food. Lust for them drove Europeans to find trade routes to the East, which should come as no surprise to anyone who cooks.

title: Swiss Shredding
description: When Switzerland temporarily lifted its bank secrecy laws late last year to allow investigators to track stolen assets deposited by the Nazis a half century ago, it was big news in a small country. So was the legal provision calling for banks to preserve all pertinent documents. Maybe the Union Bank of Switzerland didn't read the papers. Its historian ordered the shredding of a huge cache of old documents last week, but a suspicious security guard grabbed some and slipped them to a Swiss Jewish group. The bank said the documents were irrelevant; the guard said they appeared to include information on ''forced sales'' of Jewish assets in the 1930's. The historian and the guard have been suspended -- one for shredding, the other for possibly violating secrecy laws. DAVID E. SANGER

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on Jan. 5 for Arts of Pacific Asia, an exhibition and sale of Asian art in San Francisco, misstated the date. The event is Feb. 14 to 16, not Feb. 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERGER, RABBI RALPH MOSES
description: WEISBERGER-Rabbi Ralph Moses, 84, died in Herzog Hospital, Jerusalem, Israel on December 20, 1996. Born in Poughkeepsie, NY, Rabbi Weisberger lived mainly in Poughkeepsie and New York City until he made Aliyah to Israel in 1969. He held dual citizenship. In the US he lived in Somerville, NJ. His religious education was at Yeshiva University and The Jewish Theological Seminary, where he received an MA in Religious Education and was ordained Rabbi. He also received a BS from University of NY in Pre Med and completed his Ph.D. candidacy at Philadelphia Dropsie University in the field of Israel and the Middle East. Rabbi Weisberger served as Rabbi and Religious School Principal in Philadelphia and in several southern states as a ''traveling'' Rabbi. As Captain and Chaplain in the US Army, he did field service and worked in a military hospital. In the Persian Gulf he served American Forces, Polish-Jewish refugees and Jewish personnel in the British Forces. His decorations included the American Theater Ribbon, the European Theater Ribbon, the World War II Victory Medal and the Meritorious Service Unit Plaque. In Israel, he took the name Moshe Ben-Zion and worked for Kibbutz Hadati, the Jewish Agency, and the Evening University in Tel Aviv. Rabbi Weisberger was buried on the Mount of Olives, overlooking the Old City of Jerusalem. He is survived by his sister, Estelle Klein of NYC, and 2 brothers, Cantor Irving Weisberger of Fair Lawn, NJ, and Israel Weisberger of Williamsville, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAHANE, ARTHUR S.
description: KAHANE-Arthur S., 8/7/14-1/19/88. So long gone, still remembered, vigorous, generous, talented. Devotedly, Jane

title: The Goal Is Clear, But Not the Road

The fine and the language of the subcommittee's report add up to something far more damaging than a reprimand, which is serious enough in itself.

title: Tinkering for Effect
description: Already an accomplished painter, Helen Frankenthaler embarked on a printmaking career in the early 1960's. Her first 33 years of work in the medium is collected in FRANKENTHALER: A Catalogue Raisonne, Prints 1961-1994 (Abrams, $125). Pegram Harrison, an art dealer, has done the heavy lifting of documenting the finished prints and their antecedents. Suzanne Boorsch, associate curator in the department of prints and drawings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, contributes an essay that discusses Frankenthaler's work in printmaking and flags the seminal works; it prepares the reader to enjoy the colors and textures of the 235 prints. The excellent reproductions show to good advantage Ms. Frankenthaler's disciplined compositions, whose artful simplicity exemplified what Ms. Boorsch calls the ''endless, stunning possibilities that can result from extreme restriction.'' Of course, it only looks simple; we learn how painstaking the process of printmaking is, and that Ms. Frankenthaler sometimes tinkers for years. That her work is highly thought out does not mean it cannot also be romantic, as is shown in VALENTINE FOR MR. WONDERFUL (Rizzoli, $35). This volume, dedicated to Ms. Frankenthaler's husband, comprises just seven hand-printed intaglios and William Carlos Williams's poem ''St. Valentine.'' The prints are marked by pink tones, hearts and even Cupid himself. Although unusually literal, the images retain the artist's characteristic elegance. Ms. Frankenthaler writes in her dedication that the book ''just fell into place like a little rose'' and that she had ''very little to do with it.'' From what we have learned from the catalogue raisonne, we know better. Ted Loos

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRATT, BROWN, HILARY GROVER
description: BARRATT-BROWN-Hilary Grover. Age 71, resident of Pollensa, Mallorca, died January 10, 1997, in NYC. He was the son of the late Alfred and Eileen Barratt-Brown of Oxford, England. A graduate of Christ's College, Cambridge, he became associated with the World Federation of United Nations Associations, the World Monuments Fund, and the World Wide Fund for Nature. In his later years, he was active in the conservation of Mallorca's unique history and ecology. His wife Patricia Rinehart Barratt-Brown pre-deceased him in October, as well as his son Charles in 1988. He is survived by a daughter Elizabeth P. BarrattBrown of Washington, D.C., a brother Michael, and two sisters Deborah Henry and Bridget Nutter, all of England and his former wife Carla P. Darlington of New York City. Services were private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the World Federation of United Nations Associations, D.C. 1-1177 United Nations, New York, New York 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, ETTA
description: SILVERSTEIN-Etta. An outstanding person who came to our great country with courage, determination and a devotion to productivity, Etta Silverstein helped develop this country and city for the benefit of the generations to come. She devoted her life to her family and to worthy institutions. Young people benefited enormously from her dedication to help them develop their careers. Always full of enthusiasm and optimism, she was the favorite of many of us and to many students and faculty who benefited from her wisdom and generosity. She had a great deal of pleasure witnessing our students develop into the finest of physicians. Her son Larry and his spouse Klara, and their children and spouses were totally devoted to Etta, who was the glorious queen. Larry and Klara, leading citizens of our city and community, created an environment that was, and is, the gold standard for the care of parents. We at New York University School of Medicine and Etta's numerous friends mourn her passing. A wonderful friend has left our community and our institution. To Larry, Klara and their family, we extend our deepest sympathy. Saul J. Farber, M.D., MACP Provost and Dean, New York University Medical Center and School of Medicine

title: An Underdog Who Makes Big Plays
description: Willie Clay remembers being 14 and being sent by his mother to a boarding school in Wheeling, W.Va., near his hometown, Pittsburgh. It was an all-boys school. He was one of two blacks enrolled. It was so different from the rhythmic shuffle of his neighborhood, where he had begun to learn street smarts, how to survive without a father and how to dream impossible dreams.

The ticket tax, which finances the nation's air traffic control system, lapsed last January and was reinstated on Aug. 27 through the end of 1996. Congress has not passed legislation to collect the tax this year, but it is expected to do so.

Playoffs are now inevitable. And while college football will be the lesser for it (less fun, less tradition, less controversy), its administrators won't grieve long because when playoff projections are firmed up a couple of years hence, they will see the membership getting a whole lot richer. Two cheers for getting richer.

title: The Clinton Principle
description: CLINTON IS AT MIDCOURSE. WILL THERE BE A MIDCOURSE CORRECTION? A thing must first have a shape for the shape to be correctable. How does one ''correct'' a chaos? In last fall's election, though Clinton won 49 percent of the vote, according to a Time/CNN poll only 14 percent of those voting said they agreed with his positions -- and one wonders how even those few divined what those positions are. In the last half of his first term, Clinton's pliability was traced to Dick Morris, who called his strategy ''triangulation,'' a metaphor from sailing, where you tack with the wind given you, deviating from a course in order to angle back toward it. But Clinton needed no lessons in shiftiness. How do you teach a cat to twist as it falls?

title: Murphy's Law Takes Effect For a Stumbling Seton Hall

title: The Real Star Wars: Between Order and Chaos
description: THE Navajos, trying to explain the uneasy pull between order and chaos that seems to rule the night sky, tell the story of Black God and Coyote. In the days when the universe was under construction, Black God stood high atop a mountain carefully arranging the stars into the constellations we see today. But when he sat down to rest, the celestial architecture barely begun, Coyote stole his bag of star crystals, mischievously scattering them across the sky. The result was a tiny bit of order -- those connect-the-dot pictures of people and animals -- surrounded and overwhelmed by randomness.

title: Africans Reaffirm Trans-Atlantic Ties
description: THE ATLANTIC OCEAN IS NO sound barrier. For centuries, African and New World music have traded ideas, creating endlessly varied styles from shared songwriting foundations: call-and-response, polyrhythm and the conviction that listeners can learn and dance at the same time. The music of African religious ceremonies was preserved by slaves and adapted into both sacred and secular music of the New World. In the 20th century, African musicians heard their trans-Atlantic kin, and they reappropriated elements like rumba rhythm and gospel harmony. The interchange has never subsided.

title: In the Game's Effort to Go Global, Idea of a World Cup Gains Support

Think of the reaction to the news that Marlon Brando's son had been arrested for shooting his sister's fiance at the actor's house. However unkind and unfair it may be, among ordinary people Hollywood tragedies usually evoke the unspeakable idea that messed-up parents have spawned messed-up children and brought grief on themselves.

title: Correction

Prattella, Superintendent of Schools in Mount Vernon, about scores at Pennington-Grimes School, which were higher than the seven other district schools. title: Perpetual Bootie
description: Inauguration Day is all about winners, but let's not forget that other crucial breed in the American system: losers, especially those hardy souls who vow to fight again. A vivid embodi-ment of this spirit is James W. (Bootie) Hunt, a crag-gy citizen-campaigner from Mississippi who last fall made his second bid for a U.S. Senate seat. A plain-spoken Democrat, Hunt was outspent 425 to 1 by his opponent, Senator Thad Cochran, and used half of his $4,700 on gas for a borrowed car that, by Election Day, went only 30 miles per hour. He traveled to the Dem-ocratic National Conven-tion on a Greyhound and slept in a homeless shelter. He got only 250,000 votes, but that, notes Shawn O'Hara, his cam-paign manager, ''was with-out diddly squat to spend.'' He plans to run again in 2000, at age 74. Can he handle it? ''All that de-pends on the Good Lord,'' Hunt says. ''But I've always been a person who wants to see how far I can go out on a limb before it gets chopped off.''

title: China on a Budget

title: London's Letter Bombs

The bombs, including four sent last week to Al Hayat's United Nations bureau, were disarmed. But in London last Monday, one exploded, causing serious injuries to an Al Hayat employee. The newspaper and Federal law enforcement officials say they do not know who is responsible. SARAH LYALL

title: Nature With a Sybaritic Spin
description: I SAT on a weathered wood bench and gazed out at a sea of blues -- peacock, sapphire, teal and every other shade in a Crayola 64 box. From my vantage point high on a hill, I saw nothing remotely connected with civilization. No people. No houses. No electrical wires. No cola cans. Just rugged green volcanic hills to punctuate all those blues. Behind me, the overgrown dirt trail I had walked poked bravely through dense tropical foliage. The air, which had felt heavy and humid on the trail, was now a sweet breeze that caressed my bare legs. The sensation was doubly pleasing because it was December. This, I thought, is why people come to the Caribbean.

title: Vision and Reform

President Clinton's oath-taking today takes place in an atmosphere chilled by scandal, contentiousness and widespread public disappointment in the ethics of Mr. Clinton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich. This is a moment when both parties need to pause and think soberly about past mistakes and put forward an agenda to drive tainted money, reckless fund-raising and special interests out of national campaigns. She is survived by 8 grandchildren, 15 great-grandchildren, 2 great-greatgrandchildren, a daughter-in-law Joy Schieffelin, son-in-law, Cameron Bradley and nephews John Sargent and Charles Devens. She was a member of the Colony Club, Thursday Evening Club, the Contemporary Club and the Garden Club of Maine. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at a later date. Burial is private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to charities of personal choice. ''She has deeply enriched our lives forever.''

Movie studios are competing with one another to churn out bigger -- but not necessarily better -- action movies for men, but the films at this swarming 10-day festival seem to be focusing on themes involving women, troubled teen-agers, despairing families and other groups that Hollywood often ignores.

Some critics want President Bill Clinton, freed of the necessity of facing the electorate again, to abandon the NATO initiative or at least fold it into a wider, slower program for European stability.

With that as the precedent, it's hard to imagine that Mr. Clinton won't say something eloquent about race relations today in his second inaugural address, which falls on the King memorial holiday.

description: Senate Republicans who want to demonstrate that their investigation into campaign-finance abuses will be genuinely bipartisan have an easy way to prove their fairness. They can make Senator Alfonse D'Amato's creative fund-raising practices one of their initial targets.

title: Perform Now, Pay Later
description: The Wildcat Wranglers, country and line-dance performers from Lake Highlands High School in Dallas, almost did not make it to the parade. Told on Jan. 6 that they had been chosen to participate, the group's director, Katha Black, posted a notice on Jan. 7 saying the group would not be able to to because at least one-third of the 34 dancers could not afford to pay their way.

title: Packers Won't Settle
description: They sound relaxed. They say they are relaxed. They laugh at the word ''pressure'' and even say things that would make most coaches cringe -- such as, if they lose this game then their season, a brilliant one thus far, would be a failure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, ETTA
description: SILVERSTEIN - Etta. National Jewish Medical and Research Center in Denver, Colorado, offers deeply felt condolences to Larry A. Silverstein, National Jewish treasurer, and his family on the passing of his beloved mother and the family matriarch. We hope the Silverstein family takes solace in and celebrates the knowledge that Etta made a lasting impact on the community with her diligence, commitment and support of many charitable causes. A generous donor to National Jewish, Etta instilled a tradition of philanthropy early on in her children that continues to this day. Fostered by his cherished mother, Larry's long and continuing tenure with National Jewish and leadership in the New York Real Estate and Construction Industries Dinners on behalf of National Jewish goes back many decades. Larry is nurturing the same respect for philanthropy in his family. His son Roger and daughter-in-law Liana are members of the executive committe of the National Jewish AIR Society, a young leadership group. We at National Jewish remember Etta Silverstein as the foundation of a great family that takes pride in its civic duty and the betterment of society. Lynn M. Taussig, M.D. President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TALLMER, LOUISE
description: TALLMER-Louise. January 20, 1992. You were one-of-a-kind. And I love you. Alice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOSEPH F.
description: MURPHY-Joseph F. Born April 4, 1915 in White Plains, NY. Died January 19, 1997 in Chatham, NJ. Mr. Murphy received his A.B. and law degrees from Fordham University. He served in the United States Navy from 1942 to 1946 in the Air Combat Intelligence division, receiving the Bronze Star, Commendation Ribbon and Presidential Unit Citations. He was Deputy Superintendent of Insurance at the Insurance Department of the State of New York from 1952 to 1955, and later served as Executive Vice President and General Counsel of the Continental Corporation. Mr. Murphy was the Commissioner of Insurance for the State of New Jersey from 1980 to 1982 and both before and after that service was a partner at LeBoeuf Lamb Leiby & Greene. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, the former Marion L. Barrett, and three children, Dr. Elizabeth Whelan, Kevin and Brian Murphy. A wake will be held at the Doyle Funeral Home in Morristown on January 22 (2-4 PM; 7-9 PM). A Funeral Mass will be offered on January 23 at the St. Thomas More Church in Convent Station. Burial will be at Holy Cross Cemetery in Brooklyn on January 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, HERBERT A.
description: ALLEN-Herbert A. We at The Presbyterian Hospital, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, deeply mourn the death of Herbert A. Allen. Through his exemplary generosity, Mr. Allen made possible the creation of the community hospital that bears his family's name, The Allen Pavilion, which benefits the residents of Washington Heights, Inwood and Riverdale, among others. We extend our condolences to his family, who may rest assured that Mr. Allen's memory will always be honored by the life-saving and -enriching services provided at The Allen Pavilion. Daniel B. Burke, Co-Chairman of the Board of Trustees John J. Mack, Co-Chairman of the Board of Trustees William T. Speck, M.D. President and CEO

title: Casino Plan Stumbles in Albany, But Maneuvering for Bill Persists
description: To the casual observer, a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling now before the State Legislature must have looked like a wounded animal in its death throes last week. Support for it had eroded among the State Senate's Republican majority. Democrats were complaining that it did nothing for New York City. The opposition was in full-tilt mobilization.

title: Protesters Want Zoo Closed
description: Carrying signs that read ''Life Sentence, No Parole'' and ''Free Rusty,'' protesters marched outside the Scotch Plains Zoo yesterday, demanding that the state shut the zoo. The protesters, who included representatives of the New Jersey Animal Rights Alliance, say that many of the zoo's roughly 150 animals are kept in filthy, poorly ventilated indoor cages. An orangutan, Rusty, has no access to the outdoors and no branch to swing from, said Sherryl Volpone, one of the demonstrators.

title: PEST-CONTROL CONCERN TO JOIN SEARS SERVICES DIVISION
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire All America Termite and Pest Control as part of its plan to expand its services division. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. All America, based in Orlando, Fla., is the nation's largest privately held termite and pest control business, with annual revenue of more than $100 million. It has been a licensee of Sears since 1982.

title: Hunger Strike by Humble Sweepers: Mood in Mexico Is Angry
description: After a protest that has drawn nationwide attention, two hunger strikers who fasted for 97 days to regain their jobs as street sweepers are in serious but stable condition in a city hospital where they were forcibly admitted, doctors said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELIG, MARTHA
description: SEELIG-Martha, 94, of Amherst, MA, formerly of NY, died Friday, Jan. 17th, in a local nursing home. Beloved wife of the late Fred Seelig, dearest mother of Richard W. and Harry E. Seelig. Loving grandmother of Catherine and David Seelig. A Memorial Service will be at a later date. For information, the Douglass Funeral Service, Amherst, MA. Memorial donations may be made to Center for Extended Care, ''Tree of Life'', 150 University Dr, Amherst, MA 01002.

title: Credit Cards Are Clearest Path to Growth For Banc One
description: Arguing that growth in the traditional banking business is simply too sluggish, the Banc One Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $7.3 billion in stock for First USA Inc. to expand in the much more rapidly growing credit card business.

description: TRACHTENBERG-Mark David. January 21, 1987. In loving memory. Milly and Karen

title: Executive Changes
description: BARRICK GOLD CORP., Toronto, named John K. Carrington as a director and the company president.

title: Ideal Economy, but Fed Has Its Guard Up
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve say they believe the economy is finely balanced between healthy growth and inflation, and they are almost certain to leave interest rates unchanged when they meet early next month to consider monetary policy for the first time in 1997.

title: For Pianist of 'Shine,' A Life Depicted Turns Into a Life Transformed
description: Shoes off, head bowed nearly to the keyboard, David Helfgott winds his way back and forth through the phrases of a Chopin prelude, singing, sighing, making buzzing noises with his mouth, talking to himself.

title: Fear and Anger Heard Deep Inside the Brain
description: SCIENTISTS have new evidence that the human brain contains a special structure for detecting fear and anger, two emotions that underlie much of human behavior: a woman with damage to the structure, called the amygdala, cannot hear intonations of fear or anger in other people's voices.

title: Single Father Finds Work and a Home
description: On a cold day in 1991, Felix Arias was shoveling snow outside the building in Washington Heights where he worked as a superintendent when a woman walked by and asked him for a dollar. The chance encounter began a rocky four-year relationship that ended with the woman snared by her drug addiction and Mr. Arias left to care for their daughter, Alyssa.

title: Appliance or Computer? Your Call
description: THE Winter Consumer Electronics Show is always a glimpse of things to come, but the 1997 edition this month in Las Vegas seemed more like a masquerade ball. Computers dressed like television sets, TV sets donned Web browsers, phones were accessorized with screens and keyboards for sending E-mail, and intimate connections with mysterious outsiders were the norm. In the so-called digital convergence, do appliances or computers have more fun? Only your programmer knows for sure.

title: We Hardly Know Him

title: CLINTON, SWORN IN FOR 2D TERM, ASSAILS 'BICKERING AND EXTREME PARTISANSHIP'
description: William Jefferson Clinton began his second term as the 42d President of the United States today, appealing to Americans for racial unity and asking the Republican Congress to put aside partisanship and join with him ''to move on with America's mission.'''

title: Of Inaugurals And Brushes With History
description: THINK of all the visitors who might have flocked to New York City instead of Washington for the Presidential inauguration yesterday. Think of the money that might have come New York's way with thousands filling hotels and restaurants. Think of New York, reaffirmed as center of the known universe.

description: Broadway started out as a street. It became a theater district. Now it's a brand name.

title: Indonesia's Cynical Crackdown
description: Few people outside Indonesia have heard of Muchtar Pakpahan, but his problems are a good index of how the country's democrats are faring. The Government is carrying out the most severe persecution in years of independent organizations and leaders such as Mr. Pakpahan, who is the head of the nation's largest independent labor union.

title: Utah Mill Lies at Heart of Fight for Air Pollution Limits
description: Nearly 10 years ago, a researcher at Brigham Young University documented a striking finding. During a winter when a steel mill near Provo, the biggest source of air pollution in the region, was closed by a strike, two-thirds fewer children were hospitalized for lung ailments than in the previous winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUTNER, JOHN SAMUEL
description: MAUTNER-John Samuel. Jan. 15, 1997. Son of the late Jesse and Hilda, brother of J. Jay. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Harvard College, and professor of German language and literature at Columbia University until his illness caused him to retire. Since then, he devoted his life to writing poetry and to administering to the needs of his fellow dialysis patients at the Rogosin Institute of New York Hospital. Friends will be received at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Wednesday evening, 7-9 P.M. with a service on Thursday, 1:30 P.M. Entombment Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y.

title: Six Weeks to Plan and Cook and 20 Minutes to Eat

title: Ending the Litigation Gravy Train
description: Trial lawyers contribute heavily to state and Federal politicians, largely because they want to block reforms that would eliminate excessive litigation that follows automobile accidents and other mishaps. For the most part they have succeeded, but their gain is the average driver's loss. Americans pay punishingly high premiums, much of which land in lawyers' bank accounts. Now, however, bipartisan proposals in Washington and New Jersey would give drivers, especially those who are poor, substantial relief.

title: Elegance Meets Energy at the Inaugural Balls

description: Two days after Bill Cosby's only son was shot to death in Los Angeles, a woman claiming to be his illegitimate daughter was arrested in what officials described as an apparently unrelated scheme to extort millions of dollars from the comedian, the United States Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Seismic Mystery in Australia: Quake, Meteor or Nuclear Blast?
description: LATE on the evening of May 28, 1993, something shattered the calm of the Australian outback and radiated shock waves outward across hundreds of miles of scrub and desert. Around the same time, truck drivers crossing the region and gold prospectors camping nearby saw the dark sky illuminated by bright flashes, and they and other people heard the distant rumble of loud explosions.

title: Mets Court Fan
description: Until last fall, MICHAEL VOLPE was a lifelong Giants fan, in New York and San Francisco. Now he says he will never watch them play again. Volpe, 44, who grew up in Manhattan and now lives in Falls Church, Va., returned to the city yesterday as a guest of the Mets, who are interested in signing him as a free-agent fan.

Out of range of the noise, Mr. Dorner, the man who invented Eudora, the E-mail software used by 18 million people, was at work in his backyard office, intense and, as always, alone.

description: An 18-year-old who went into a coma 10 days ago at a police station where he was being booked on charges stemming from a Bronx stabbing died yesterday morning, the police said.

description: The GTE Corporation, looking to build its global presence as competition increases in the United States telephone market, appointed two senior executives today to oversee international operations and business development.

title: Defense Teams Square Off In Joint Crown Heights Trial
description: When the latest trial in the stabbing death of a Hasidic Jew during the Crown Heights racial violence resumes today, it will not just pit the prosecution against the two defendants. It will also pit one defendant against the other, defense lawyers say.

title: Unpredictability of Life And Those 'Acts of God'
description: As demonstrated by his best-known work, ''Sherman's March'' (1986), a quirky trip through the South, Ross McElwee has camera, will travel. Tonight finds him on the road again, in search of ''reality,'' by which he means the victims or near-victims of disasters glimpsed on the 6 o'clock news. There he is in South Carolina taking pictures of an old friend whose house was not destroyed by Hurricane Hugo; at an Arizona trailer park ravaged by a tornado; hiking into a California forest fire; visiting a worker who barely escaped death when a Los Angeles parking garage collapsed during the Northridge earthquake; tracking down a man whose wife was murdered in a Mississippi hold-up.

title: Flood Was a Man for Every Season
description: In a recent letter to Frank Slocum, executive director of the Baseball Assistance Team (B.A.T.), Curt Flood wrote: ''The 1996 holiday season brings mixed feelings of joy and sadness. Therefore, we'll take the advice that mother Laura gave to me when I was a kid. She'd say 'Start counting your blessings, Squirtis, by the time you've finished, you won't have time for anything else.' ''

title: The New-Look Knicks Are Intriguing to Jordan
description: Like everyone, Michael Jordan is curious. He wants to know if his guys still match up well against those resourceful Eastern Conference bullies he used to know. Or, if the revamped, viewer-friendly Knicks merely look nice in the pre-game program.

title: An Upset Shakes Big East's Wild Race
description: Most people see a nasty-looking traffic jam throughout the Northeast corridor, and Jim Boeheim sees an opportunity. His Syracuse Orangemen managed to grab hold of a game tonight that had appeared lost soon after it began.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was just a talent show at Passaic (N.J.) High School, but the 1957 performance helped propel a rock-and-roll quartet to stardom. So, 40 years later, the site of the show has been renamed Shirelle Auditorium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, ROBERT
description: O'BRIEN-Robert, 60, of Little Egg Harbor, New Jersey, died Friday at Atlantic City Medical Center Mainland, Poamona. Mr. O'Brien worked for the New York Times for over twenty-nine years. He was an Advertising Makeup Assistant Manager. Mr. O'Brien was a veteran of the Marine Corps. He was born in Jersey City and lived most of his life in Monmouth County. Survived by his wife Barbara, son Robert Michael, and step-children Rebecca and David Byrnes. His remains will be donated to Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, Piscataway, N.J.

title: Tossing Away Anxieties And Quite a Few Oranges
description: Losing control became a fine art on Saturday night when Sara Pearson/Patrik Widrig & Company danced as part of the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater.

title: UConn Trounces Georgia in Its Own Backyard
description: The UConn Huskies, relentless and unbeaten, showed why they are the nation's No. 1-ranked women's college basketball team by storming through the backyard of nationally ranked Georgia today and obliterating the No. 5 Bulldogs, 97-65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOSEPH F.
description: MURPHY-Joseph F. Born April 4, 1915 in White Plains, NY. Died January 19, 1997 in Chatham, NJ. Mr. Murphy received his A.B. and law degrees from Fordham University. He served in the United States Navy from 1942 to 1946 in the Air Combat Intelligence division, receiving the Bronze Star, Commendation Ribbon and Presidential Unit Citations. He was Deputy Superintendent of Insurance at the Insurance Department of the State of New York from 1952 to 1955, and later served as Executive Vice President and General Counsel of the Continental Corporation. Mr. Murphy was the Commissioner of Insurance for the State of New Jersey from 1982 to 1984 and both before and after that service was a partner at LeBoeuf Lamb Leiby & Greene. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, the former Marion L. Barrett, and three children, Dr. Elizabeth Whelan, Kevin and Brian Murphy. A wake will be held at the Doyle Funeral Home in Morristown on January 22 (2-4 PM; 7-9 PM). A Funeral Mass will be offered on January 23 at the St. Thomas More Church in Convent Station. Burial will be at Holy Cross Cemetery in Brooklyn on January 23.

title: The Risk Of Losing Russia
description: Boris Yeltsin and Bill Clinton, now both in their second terms, remain on friendly terms and call each other Boris and Bill. The two Presidents have a summit meeting scheduled for March in Washington. Yet relations between Russia and the United States are almost certainly in for difficult times.

description: I.B.M. will break with tradition today and announce its fourth-quarter results after the stock market closes rather than before it opens.

title: CHARTWELL LEISURE TO BUILD 20 HILTON GARDEN INN HOTELS
description: Chartwell Leisure Inc. said yesterday that it would spend $200 million to build, own and operate 20 Hilton Garden Inn hotels under an alliance with the Hilton Hotels Corporation. Under the pact, which will initially be for three years, Chartwell, a hotel owner and operator based in New York, will borrow 80 percent of the construction funds from Nationsbank, and Hilton Inns Inc., a unit of Hilton, will guarantee 25 percent of the loan. Chartwell will raise the remaining 20 percent by selling stock. The first Hilton Garden Inns under the alliance will be built at the international airport in Albuquerque, N.M., and in Santa Fe, N.M. Shares of Chartwell rose $1.25 yesterday, to $13.625. Shares of Hilton increased 37.5 cents, to $26.625.

title: Civil Rights In Hong Kong: Chinese Law Rattles Many
description: China's plans to reimpose colonial laws restricting the rights of protest and free association have outraged democracy advocates here, who warn that basic rights recently accorded to the people of Hong Kong are now under siege.

title: U.S. Recruited Ex-Rebel Despite Links to Deaths, Reports Say
description: A former Salvadoran guerrilla commander was recruited by American officials as a paid informer and allowed to resettle in the United States despite intelligence information from half a dozen rebels that he had planned a 1985 attack in El Salvador in which six Americans and seven others were killed, newly released Government reports show.

title: Yeltsin Goes After a Russian Religion: Vodka
description: She may not look the part, but Tamara Chernyshkova recently became one of Russia's most wanted criminals. Feeble, aged and practically blind, she is nonetheless a foot soldier in this country's most profitable illegal enterprise.

description: Publicis S.A. in Paris is continuing its international expansion by moving into Asia, acquiring control of agencies in Singapore and the Philippines. Terms were not disclosed.

title: COX IN $160 MILLION DEAL FOR SEATTLE TV STATION
description: The Gaylord Entertainment Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its KSTW-TV station in Seattle to Cox Broadcasting Inc. for $160 million. Gaylord, based in Nashville, said KSTW was a CBS-affiliated station. The transaction is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission. After the sale closes, Cox Broadcasting, a unit of the closely held Atlanta media concern Cox Enterprises , will own or operate 12 television stations. Shares of Gaylord fell $1 yesterday, to $23.

title: Verdict: No Bridge to the History Books
description: The White House made no secret that President Clinton agonized for days about his second Inaugural Address, poring over past Presidential speeches and anthologies of poetry and repeatedly reworking the text himself in hope of hitting an oratorical home run for the history books.

description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that its net income fell in the fiscal first quarter, though operating results were up 18 percent because of strong sales in its electronics systems division.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD HOWARD, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet and translator, feels more than the routine admiration of one writer for another, in this case for JULES VERNE. The 19th-century novelist provided Mr. Howard with an escape hatch from a troubled family situation in his youth.

title: Conoco Says It Wants To Invest More in Poland
description: Conoco, the oil unit of the Du Pont Company, said yesterday that it was prepared to invest up to $1 billion in Poland by building more service stations and taking stakes in the nation's two largest refineries. Du Pont Conoco Poland Ltd., the Polish subsidiary of the Houston-based Conoco, has built 18 service stations in Poland since 1991 and plans to build 17 more this year.

title: Avoiding The Oakley Stomp
description: CHRIS CHILDS's greatest concern during yesterday's basketball game in Madison Square Garden was not necessarily the Knicks' opponent, the Bullets, nor was it the slight headache and still-sore cheekbone, a carry-over from the mild concussion from his last game, two days earlier. No, his greatest concern -- or what ought to have been -- during the game was the whereabouts of his teammate, Charles Oakley, all 6 feet 9 inches, 240 massive pounds of him. Plus, of course, the neighborhood of Oak's feet, shod in size 16 sneakers.

title: Boston Scientific to Acquire Specialized Catheter Maker
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Target Therapeutics Inc., a maker of specialized catheters primarily used for treating the brain, in a stock swap valued at about $1.1 billion.

title: Olivetti Selling Its PC Unit to Stanch Losses
description: Olivetti S.p.A., the information technology giant, said today that it would sell its money-losing personal computer company to Piedmont International, a newly formed investment group, for 250 billion to 300 billion lire -- $159 million to $190 million.

title: Joffrey Ballet Names New Executive Director
description: The Joffrey Ballet Chicago has named Robert Alpaugh as its executive director, effective immediately. Mr. Alpaugh succeeds Arnold Bremen, appointed when the Joffrey moved from New York City to Chicago in 1995.

title: Moeller Joins Lions' Staff
description: Gary Moeller, fired from the University of Michigan two years ago after his disorderly conduct arrest at a restaurant, was named the running backs coach for the Detroit Lions yesterday.

title: Utility Worker Electrocuted
description: A Public Service Electric and Gas Company mechanic was electrocuted yesterday while doing repairs at a switching station in Newark, a company spokesman said. The mechanic, Charles J. Matta Jr., 49, of Maplewood, died instantly when he came in contact with up to 26,000 volts coursing through a fuse disconnect, a device that interrupts electric current. Mr. Matta, who had worked for the utility since 1969, was trying to shut off power in the line attached to the fuse disconnect.

title: Horses, Mollusks and the Evolution of Bigness
description: PALEONTOLOGISTS in the 19th century kept digging up fossils of early horses no bigger than a diminutive mouse deer. Over the expanse of evolutionary time, they came to see, the horse lineage showed tendencies to increase in body size, leading to the sole surviving genus Equus, which includes such imposing animals as Kentucky thoroughbreds and Clydesdales capable of pulling wagons heavy with beer barrels.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICHARD, ZELDA
description: RICHARD-Zelda, January 21, 1997. Thinking of you on your birthday, Aunt Zel. Love Ferne, Bernie, and Chad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASARRE, TOM
description: NASARRE-Tom. June 9, 1937-January 17, 1997, in Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of New York City. Son of Carol Maupin, of McAllen, TX, and brother of Gene of Houston. Donations in his memory may be made to the Lupus Foundation of S.E. Florida, 6501 N. Federal Hwy., Boca Raton, FL 33487.

title: Behind the Scenes Of a Dream Factory
description: Documentaries about the good old days of major Hollywood studios can be great fun, especially for those of us who spent a somewhat alarming portion of our youth in movie palaces that nurtured fabulous fantasies. Old film clips can set off almost Proustian memory trips. Alas, though it tries mightily over slightly more than two hours, tonight's ''20th Century Fox: The First 50 Years'' doesn't quite succeed. In the end, it's a commercial for a company that today, primarily focused on television, is but a shadow of its former adventurous self.

title: Latest Failure to Communicate: Wrong Number
description: HYPERTERMINAL is the anemic communications program that comes with Windows 95 and Windows NT 4.0. It is an improvement over Terminal, the Windows 3.1 ''applet,'' in that it handles more file settings and terminal emulations, but it is strictly text-based in a graphical world. If your computer came with a modem, Hyperterminal is a way to dip into on-line communications without spending extra money at the outset, but it will not do for long.

title: New Species of Bird Is Discovered (Or Rediscovered) in Philippines
description: THE tiny sunbirds, with their dazzling colors and long pointed bills for sipping nectar from flowers in tropical forests, are in many ways the Old World counterparts of the hummingbirds of the Americas. Sunbirds are found from Africa, where they are especially abundant, to the islands of Southeast Asia; like the hummingbirds, there is a large number of known species: 126 to be exact with the discovery, being announced today, of a new sunbird on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao.

description: The New York Times asked a variety of political and public figures the following question: ''If you could get the Democratic President and the Republican Congress to set aside their differences and get one thing done, what would it be?''

title: Dow Moves Higher by 10.77 in Quiet Trading
description: Good earnings reports, particularly in the technology sector, sent stocks higher yesterday in a quiet holiday session.

title: Sudanese Rebels Claim a Major Advance in Their Offensive
description: A Sudanese rebel army that began a major offensive eight days ago has advanced to within 45 miles of a Blue Nile city whose dam and hydroelectric station provide the capital, Khartoum, with most of its power, opposition leaders said today.

title: Deer Left in a Driveway
description: Who dumped 13 deer carcasses in Russell Mergogey Jr.'s driveway? Mr. Mergogey is not sure, but a state police spokesman said the deer may be the most visible signs of a dispute between Mr. Mergogey and a local hunting club. Mr. Mergogey said he called the state police on Saturday to have several hunters ordered off a wooded lot he owns next to his house in Plumsted Township. On Sunday, he said, the heads, rib cages and legs of 13 deer were in his driveway. The state police are investigating, said the spokesman, John Hagerty. ANDY NEWMAN

title: On This Special Day, A National Triumph
description: When the trumpet blast of a preliminary fanfare burst upon the inaugural air, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist removed his snappy-looking winter cap, all the better to swear in President Clinton for another term.

title: In Albany, Frenetic Tug-of-War Over Who Will Get Cash From Environmental Bonds
description: Two months after New York voters approved borrowing $1.75 billion to pay for environmental improvements, fevered negotiations have sprung up in Albany over who will determine how that money is spent.

title: Deutsche Telekom Says 1996 Sales Rose 6%
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said yesterday that 1996 sales rose an adjusted 6 percent, to 63 billion marks ($39 billion), and that earnings for 1996 would exceed forecasts. The national telephone company had said last year that it expected an operating profit of 6 billion marks. That would be a 50 percent increase over 1995, after adjusting for the effect of a value-added tax that Telekom had to pay for the first time in 1996.

title: Yanks Tender Offer to Williams
description: The Yankees offered Bernie Williams a one-year contract believed to be worth more than $5 million last week in an attempt to avoid arbitration. But General Manager Bob Watson conceded that the possibility of an agreement is slim since he has not received a response from Scott Boras, the player's agent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELO, FRANK
description: ANGELO-Frank. The clients, volunteers, Board, and staff of The Momentum AIDS Project mourn the death of our friend, Frank Angelo. As a co-founder of MAC Cosmetics and the MAC AIDS Fund, Frank was a dedicated supporter of Momentum's mission of providing free communal meals and counselling services to New Yorkers living with HIV and AIDS and played a special role in establishing our annual gourmet fund raiser, Tastings, as a signature event. We will always be grateful for his leadership and commitment to fighting the AIDS crisis.

title: Netscape Takes On Rivals in KPMG Deal
description: In its effort to prove itself a viable competitor in the corporate computer-networking market, the Netscape Communications Corporation is expected to announce today that the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick L.L.P. has selected the newest version of Netscape's business communications software as the standard for 17,000 workers in its 120 offices in the United States.

title: Jose Domecq, 82, 'The Nose' Of Spanish Clan's Sherries
description: Jose Ignacio Domecq Gonzalez, the aristocratic head of a Spanish wine-making family who was renowned as El Nariz (The Nose) for his ability to sniff out the nuances in the creation of his clan's highly regarded sherries, died on Wednesday at his home in Jerez de la Frontera, in southern Spain. He was 82.

title: SEQUANA AND PERKIN-ELMER TO FORM JOINT VENTURE
description: Sequana Therapeutics Inc. and the Perkin-Elmer Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to provide genetic-analysis services in China. The venture, to be called Genecore Biotechnologies Inc., plans to provide large-scale, automated DNA analysis and gene-sequencing services. Sequana conducts gene research; Perkin-Elmer makes automated DNA-analysis systems. Sequana, based in La Jolla, Calif., and Perkin-Elmer, based in Norwalk, Conn., will each hold a 47.5 percent interest in the joint venture, which will be based in Shanghai. Siniwest Holdings Inc., an international consulting company specializing in the Chinese biotechnology industry, will hold the remaining 5 percent. Shares in Sequana rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $16.875, while Perkin-Elmer fell 75 cents, to $69.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIFERT, ALAN F.
description: EIFERT-Alan F. A native of New Jersey died Sunday in Lake Worth, FL., at the age of 92. He was the founder of Eifert, French & Company, Inc., a 63 year old insurance firm located in Pelham, NY and Tenafly, NJ. Mr. Eifert began his business career in 1918 with the Bank of Manhattan (now Chase). He was a leader in the insurance business since 1927, starting his own firm in New York City in 1933. Mr. Eifert was Chairman of the Insurance Committee of the New York Real Estate Board and a member of the New York Board of Trade and the New York City Insurance Agents Association. He served on several committees designed to improve service to the customer. Mr. Eifert served on the Board of Directors of the Ridgewood Country Club, the New York Athletic Club and the New York Law Journal. He was Chairman of the Golf Committee for both the Ridgewood Country and the New York Athletic Club. He was a founding member of Grace Lutheran Church in Teaneck. Mr. Eifert was predeceased by his wife Helen who died in 1980. He is survived by two sons, Donald of Tryon, NC and Robert of Alpine, NJ. He has seven grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Contributions to Grace Lutheran Church, 1200 River Rd, Teaneck, NJ, would be appreciated.

Giuliani and a focus on two highly contentious issues: requiring that police officers live in the city and eliminating the runoff provision in mayoral primaries.

title: Bankrupt Airline Flies Again
description: Still in bankruptcy but back in the air, Kiwi International Air Lines resumed scheduled service yesterday after three months of running only charter flights. About half of the seats on Kiwi's 29 flights were filled, at $99 each way, a normal passenger load for this time of year and ''great'' for Kiwi's first day back in service, said Rob Kulat, a spokesman for the airline, which is based in Newark.

title: MELLON BANK AGREES TO BUY GANZ CAPITAL MANAGEMENT
description: The Pittsburgh-based Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Ganz Capital Management Inc., a privately held investment management company based in North Miami Beach, Fla. Terms were not disclosed. Mellon said that Charles B. Ganz, Ganz's president, would run Mellon's private asset management business in key markets. Ganz Capital manages about $400 million in assets and will operate in Florida under the Mellon Private Asset Management unit, which has $54 billion in assets under management.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki was hospitalized today after a refrigerated poultry truck collided with a state-owned car that was taking him to meet his family for a skiing trip, his aides said.

Now Mr. Gluck's admission, published in yesterday's Star-Ledger of Newark, could spell legal difficulties for him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEYER, HILDA (NEE CANNSTATT)
description: SPEYER-Hilda (nee Cannstatt), on January 18, 1997, at home in New York City. Adored wife for fifty-two years of the late Walter Ludwig Speyer. Dear mother to sons Ronald and Franklin and their wives Ellen and Carol. Proud grandmother of Joshua, Gabriel, Alexandra, Emily and Elizabeth. Special appreciation to sister-inlaw Germaine Speyer and her family for their great affection and support. Born in Berlin, Germany on July 4, 1923. After escaping the Holocaust as a teenager, she forged a full life together with her parents, Martha and Albert Cannstatt, first in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil and then in New York City, where she met Walter and with him raised their family. A fiercely devoted and loving wife, mother and friend, who spent her lifetime looking out for others before herself. title: Discussing Farmers' Futures
description: Some of New Jersey's 8,800 farmers have begun cultivating plots in cyberspace, selling soybeans on the Internet and designing Web sites. But too many others still rely on the rotary telephone, state agriculture officials say. Using technology on the farm is the subject of the general session at the state agriculture convention that opens today at Harrah's Casino Hotel in Atlantic City. About 1,000 people are expected to attend the two-day conference.

title: House Ready To Discipline The Speaker
description: For the first time in its history, the House of Representatives is expected to vote Tuesday afternoon to reprimand and fine its Speaker for bringing discredit on the House.

title: Immigration Center Reopens After Uprising
description: Eighteen months after an uprising at a privately run Federal detention center for immigrants in Elizabeth, N.J., the center has reopened under new management, with promises of a faster hearing process for those seeking asylum. The revamped center underwent a host of changes to transform it from what one lawmaker called ''the worst immigration detention center in the nation.''

title: Balloonist Ends 9,600-Mile Flight in India
description: An American balloonist made a rough but safe landing in northern India yesterday, breaking world records for distance and duration, but failing in his attempt to fly nonstop around the world.

title: COLONY CAPITAL TO INVEST IN TRUMP'S CASTLE CASINO
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement under which the struggling Trump's Castle Casino Resort in Atlantic City would receive an infusion of $125 million from Colony Capital, a real estate investment firm based in Los Angeles. The companies will establish a joint venture in which Colony Capital will hold a 51 percent stake, while Trump Hotels will retain a 49 percent interest and continue to manage the property. The venture will more than double the number of rooms at Trump's Castle, which will be renamed the Trump Marina. Shares of Trump Hotels, which is based in New York, rose $1.125 yesterday, to $11.25.

title: Doesn't Love a Parade?
description: At a low point in my newspaper career, editors decided I had a unique talent for covering cold-weather parades. Whenever frostbite was in the air and a parade was scheduled to march down Main Street, the joy of covering it was mine.

title: Facing Huge Costs, Airlines Shift Scheduling Tactics
description: Four years ago, it was the ''Storm of the Century,'' wreaking havoc up and down the Eastern Seaboard with tornadoes and six-foot snowdrifts. Last year, it was record snows in New York and other parts of the Northeast. And this year, much of the country has been buried under record snows and ice. Throughout all those ordeals, airlines have struggled to cope with an avalanche of delays and cancellations, and furious passengers have camped out overnight at crowded aiports. Industry losses have run into the hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Packers Stand By Their Coach
description: The Packers are sick of hearing about Bill Parcells and his two Super Bowl rings and how great a coach he is. They respect him, but the Packers say that if Parcells thinks he can pull off some great defensive scheme to stop their powerful offense, well, Green Bay isn't going to be caught napping.

title: Corrections

It was people familiar with the discussions, not company officials. The company has declined to comment on whether it is in such talks.

title: South Koreans Assess Strike And Find Loss Manageable
description: Workers returned to their jobs on Monday and factories hummed to life after more than three weeks of strikes, with business leaders and economists saying South Korea's economy would suffer little lasting harm.

title: Health Care Costs Edging Up And a Bigger Surge Is Feared
description: Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for the last three years, are beginning to inch ahead and may be poised for a sharp rise, especially for small businesses, according to employers, actuaries and industry consultants.

title: Tap Water Near Nuclear Lab Is Deemed Safe, Despite Leak of Contaminant
description: People living near the Brookhaven National Laboratory were assured today by Senator Alfonse D'Amato that their supply of underground drinking water was safe, despite a plume of contaminants leaking from a tank filled with radioactive waste.

title: Dollar Soars vs. Yen as Tokyo Hints Central Bank Won't Act
description: The dollar reached its highest point against the yen in almost four years yesterday as the Tokyo stock market tumbled and expectations grew that the the Bank of Japan would not move to prop up the yen.

Among those he will compete against are ROGER KINGDOM, the 1984 and 1988 Olympic gold medalist, and DAN O'BRIEN, the decathlon gold medalist in Atlanta.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT RECEIVES $240 MILLION IN CONTRACTS
description: The General Instrument Corporation said yesterday that it had received $240 million in contracts to provide digital wireless systems to the People's Choice TV Corporation and CS Wireless Systems Inc. General Instrument, based in Chicago, said People's Choice and CS Wireless had committed to ordering 600,000 set-top boxes and associated equipment over three years. People's Choice TV, based in Shelton, Conn., owns and operates wireless cable television systems. CS Wireless Systems, based in Plano, Tex., is a privately held company that operates wireless cable systems. It was formed by a partnership of Heartland Wireless Communications Inc., CAI Wireless Systems Inc., the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation.

title: Proposal to Allow Marijuana
description: Amid the growing national debate over whether marijuana should be legalized for medical purposes, a state senator is proposing to revive New Jersey's long-dormant program to make the drug available to ill people. But the administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman opposes the idea, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

description: The stock of Elf Aquitaine S.A. rose to a record yesterday after the company chairman said Elf wanted to spend up to 15 billion French francs ($2.74 billion) on acquisitions in chemicals businesses.

title: In the West, A Matter Of the Spirit
description: A coalition of 40 American Indian tribes and the nation's largest conservation group have asked Montana and the National Park Service to stop slaughtering wild bison that leave Yellowstone National Park and instead allow the animals to be used as seed stock to re-establish free-roaming herds throughout the American West.

title: Brain-Tied Gene Defect May Explain Why Schizophrenics Hear Voices
description: SCIENTISTS have linked a genetic defect to a brain abnormality that might help explain a hallmark of schizophrenia: the inability to filter out irrelevant sounds and other distractions. That lack of filtering can result in a flood of heightened sensation that makes it nearly impossible to concentrate, and may be part of the reason schizophrenics hear voices and hallucinate.

title: EASTMAN KODAK TO COMBINE SALES FORCES OF 2 UNITS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would combine the sales forces of its Consumer Imaging and Qualex film processing units as part of the reorganization of its photofinishing operations. Kodak, which is based in Rochester, said the move would let a single sales representative visit a retailer and handle all of its film, photo supply and film processing business. Jobs will probably not be cut but a realignment of the sales force is likely, Kodak said. Shares of Kodak advanced $2.625 yesterday, to $87.875.

description: Paine Webber Group, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and Alex. Brown Inc., benefiting from the continuing bull market in stocks, yesterday reported earnings for the last three months of 1996 that exceeded analysts' forecasts.

title: The Politics of Reconciliation
description: Inaugural addresses often evoke a sense of triumph and a vision of battles to come. For lovers of such sailing rhetoric, President Clinton's address yesterday was distinctly earthbound. But it was also notable for its ennobling appeal to conciliation and what he called ''a new spirit of community for a new century.'' The overarching theme of the entire ceremony, in fact, was of racial healing, drawing from the celebration the same day of the Rev. Martin Luther King's birthday. The selection of speakers such as the Rev. Jesse Jackson at a morning prayer service and a series of inclusive religious and musical events during the day were especially appropriate for the swearing in of Mr. Clinton and another Southerner, Vice President Gore. Dr. King's message was that Southern politicians could one day become the healers rather than promoters of what Mr. Clinton called the ''constant curse'' of racism in American history.

title: BOEING PLANS TO REDUCE EFFORTS TO CREATE A LONGER 747
description: The Boeing Company said late yesterday that it planned to scale back efforts to develop a longer version of the 747 passenger jet and would instead focus on building enhanced versions of its midsize jets. ''Sufficient market demand has not yet developed to justify committing the significant investment required to develop larger versions of the 747,'' Ron Woodard, president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said in a statement. Boeing had been testing airlines' responses to the proposed extended versions. One proposed version would carry 400 passengers, like current 747's, but would have a greater range. Another would be able to fly slightly farther than the current models, with as many as 550 passengers. Earlier, the company announced that China Yunnan Airlines had ordered two 737-300 aircraft valued at $68 million. It was Boeing's second sale this month to a Chinese airline.

title: Stores Hail First Two Days Without Tax
description: Encouraged by the combination of fat clearance racks and a one-week suspension of the sales tax on clothing, shoppers went to New York stores in droves over the weekend, giving many merchants 20 percent to 250 percent sales increases over the same period last year, retailers said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the cold snap in the metropolitan region misstated the record low temperature for Jan. 17 in New York City. The record, set in 1977, was 2 degrees below zero, not 2 degrees.

title: A Masterwork Lost in a Generation Gap
description: Born of Handel and father to the Victorian choral movement, Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' finds itself stranded in a chronological no man's land. History is cruel to those who cannot demonstrate their place in it, and so a mighty biblical oratorio -- appearing to be neither Classical nor Romantic but only Mendelssohnian -- survives in genteel poverty: respected by many, politely ignored by more.

title: Physicists Confirm Power of Nothing, Measuring Force of Universal Flux
description: FOR a half century, physicists have known that there is no such thing as absolute nothingness, and that the vacuum of empty space, devoid of even a single atom of matter, seethes with subtle activity. Now, with the help of a pair of metal plates and a fine wire, a scientist has directly measured the force exerted by fleeting fluctuations in the vacuum that pace the universal pulse of existence.

title: Nasdaq experiment starts well, but real tests are still to come.
description: THE Nasdaq stock market began trading 50 stocks under widely heralded new rules yesterday, producing few surprises. The biggest technological problem of the day was caused by a human, and had little impact. There was limited evidence that investors may have benefited from better markets in some of the affected stocks, but it is too early to reach conclusions.

title: Curt Flood Is Dead at 59; Outfielder Defied Baseball
description: Curt Flood, the All-Star center fielder for the St. Louis Cardinals in the 1960's who became a pioneering figure in the legal attack on baseball's reserve clause that foreshadowed the era of free agents, died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 59.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, HERBERT
description: ALLEN-Herbert. We at The Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, deeply mourn the death of Herbert Allen. Through his exemplary generosity, Mr. Allen made possible the creation of the community hospital that bears his family's name, The Allen Pavilion, which benefits the residents of Washington Heights, Inwood and Riverdale, among others. We extend our condolences to his family, who may rest assured that Mr. Allen's memory will always be honored by the life-saving and -enriching services provided at The Allen Pavilion. Daniel B. Burke, Co-Chairman of the Board of Trustees John J. Mack, Co-Chairman of the Board of Trustees William T. Speck, M.D. President and CEO

title: President Remains Ebullient As a Second Chance Begins
description: President Clinton listened to a reading from St. John the Evangelist at a prayer service here this morning. ''And I saw a new heaven and a new earth,'' the speaker began, as Mr. Clinton started to mouth the words: ''for the first heaven and the first earth were passed away.''

title: G.E. PICKS ALLIED SIGNAL TO SUPPLY AVIONICS EQUIPMENT
description: Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that it had received a $100 million contract from the General Electric Company to supply auxiliary power units and avionics for as many as 80 Airbus A320 aircraft that G.E. is purchasing. Allied Signal, of Morristown, N.J., said the GE Capital Aviation Services unit would lease the aircraft to various airlines around the world. The auxiliary power units, which are small gas turbine engines mated with generators, are used to supply electrical and pneumatic power for aircraft and ground operations. Allied Signal's aerospace division supplies equipment and systems for commercial transport, regional, general aviation and military aircraft.

title: Young Woman Steps Out
description: All day, from a morning prayer service through the solemn swearing-in and sun-dappled stroll down Pennsylvania Avenue to the White House, Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton were never far from a buoyant young woman in a blue-gray suit.

title: Golden Globes for 'English Patient' and Madonna
description: The 54th annual Golden Globe Awards were presented on Sunday night in a ceremony in Beverly Hills, Calif., that was broadcast on NBC. Unlike the Oscars, the Golden Globes divide the film category into two sections -- dramatic, and musical or comedy -- and are also awarded to television shows.

title: Tsongas's Legacy: Checking Health of Candidates
description: On this Inauguration Day, the death of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts on Saturday night from complications of treatment for cancer recalls how important it is for candidates for elected office to make full disclosure of their medical information.

title: Pease Tops The List As Fassel Builds Staff
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel is working quickly to assemble his staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAINIK, ARDIS
description: KRAINIK-Ardis. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our esteemed colleague and beloved friend, Ardis Krainik. Virtually synonymous with the Lyric Opera of Chicago, she was one of the great figures of the opera world. We had the privilege to work closely with her on many occasions, allowing us ample opportunity to admire her creative spirit, artistic wisdom, and devotion to excellence. A staunch champion of new works, she brought enthusiasm, optimism, and courage to everything she did, serving as an inspiration to every professional in the field of opera. Her contributions to the operatic life of this country are inestimable, and we shall miss her deeply. We extend our sincerest sympathy to her family, to all her friends, and to our colleagues in Chicago. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Lebed Admits A Bit of Envy For Transition Done in Peace
description: Aleksandr M. Lebed, the gruff former general who says flatly that he will become Russia's next President, came to the American inauguration to see how it is done. He said it left him with a feeling of ''white envy,'' which is the benign kind.

description: In Manhattan, where Borough President Ruth W. Messinger is giving up her post to run for mayor, nearly a half-dozen Democrats are preparing to run for her seat in the Democratic primary Sept. 9. But in the Bronx, where Borough President Fernando Ferrer is about to make a mayoral bid, none of the usual suspects seems to be trying to enter the fray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVITY, LEONARD HOWARD
description: McVITY-Leonard Howard, died early Friday morning, January 17, 1997 at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City. Born in Toronto, Canada on September 20, 1906, he graduated from the University of Toronto in June 1928. While still a student, he began his actuarial career as an Actuarial Clerk with Manufacturer's Life of Canada in June 1925. He remained there until January 1936 when he became Secretary and Actuary for the Canadian Life Insurance Association in Toronto. In April 1938, Mr. McVity joined the Business Men's Assurance (BMA) Company in Kansas City, Missouri and remained there until March 1943. He left BMA to become an Associate Actuary with The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in New York City. In February 1964, he was appointed to the position of Vice President and Comptroller which he held until December 1969 when he left to become Vice President and Secretary of Equitable Life Mortgage and Realty Investors. In September 1972, after almost 30 years as an actuary, Mr. McVity retired from The Equitable. Subsequently, he was associated with Coopers & Lybrand and Tillinghast as an Actuarial Consultant. In September 1979, Mr. McVity joined the New York State Department of Insurance as a Supervising Actuary, a position he held until shortly before his death. In 1993, Mr. McVity celebrated a milestone-the 60th anniversary of attaining his Fellowship in the Actuarial Society of America, now called the Society of Actuaries. In addition to his wife, Frances, he is survived by a son, Richard L. McVity of Newton, MA, a daughter, Anne E. Miles of Chapel Hill, NC, ten grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service is planned for Friday, January 31, 1997 at the Church of the Ascenscion, 12 West 11th Street, in New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of choice.

title: A Famous Sherry and a Noble Nose
description: HE was one of those larger-than-life figures in the wine industry, a legend far beyond his family's centuries-old holdings, the 10,000 acres of vineyards for table wines and brandy in Spain and the five wineries and distilleries in Mexico -- and wines and brandy were only a sideline. What Don Jose Ignacio Domecq y Gonzales was known for was his sherry. And his nose.

title: MILLENNIUM PHARMACEUTICALS IN DEAL FOR CHEMGENICS
description: Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Chemgenics Pharmaceuticals Inc. for about $88.8 million in stock. Millennium, based in Cambridge, Mass., offered Chemgenics shareholders 4.8 million Millennium shares, worth $88.8 million at Monday's closing price of $18.50. The deal will bring Millennium up-to-date screening technology for use in drug development. Shares of Millennium rose $1.25 yesterday, to $19.75.

title: F.D.A. Moves Back Oatmeal And a Test For Drug Use
description: The Food and Drug Administration issued two rulings today that have little in common except the certainty that they will have an impact in many American homes. One ruling affects the labels on cereal boxes, and the other will allow parents to test their children for drug use.

title: One of Newest Take-at-Home Tests: I.Q.

title: CHRONICLE

He is inviting his future neighbors on East 64th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues to a party at the Wildenstein Gallery. He says his goal is to minimize the irritation they may feel as he builds Foundation House on two lots he bought last year from David Geffen. Demolition began on the two houses at 7 1/2 and 9 East 64th Street last week.

title: Illness Delays Deportation
description: Ferenc Koreh, 87, of Englewood, is too ill to spread much hate these days. But during World War II, he has admitted, he edited pro-Nazi newspapers in his native Hungary, writing hundreds of articles calling for the ''de-Jewification of Hungarian life.''

title: A Dangerous Abortion Protest Ruling
description: Judge John E. Sprizzo of the Federal District Court in Manhattan has produced a bizarre opinion justifying the illegal actions of two abortion protesters who repeatedly obstructed entry to the Women's Medical Pavilion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Instead of upholding the law as he is sworn to do, Judge Sprizzo seems to think that if the defendants before him find a law inconsistent with their own moral or religious beliefs, he can acquit them of violating it. His action aids those who will grab any excuse to interfere with the constitutional right to abortion.

title: Lethal to Sinful to Legal, and Then Backward
description: ''The Roots of Roe'' begins with the 1742 Connecticut case of a 19-year-old pregnant woman whose lover declined to marry her. She found a doctor who was willing to do an abortion. She died, and the doctor was convicted of a misdemeanor. The law, indebted to medieval theology, declared abortion to be illegal if it occurred after ''quickening,'' a few months into the pregnancy, when movement could be felt. The main concern was for the soul of the fetus.

description: New York City today began spending $660 million on a five-year program to cut the flow of pollution into its upstate reservoirs and avoid the need for a $4 billion filtration plant.

title: Too Many Cooks, Yes, but Never Too Many Cookbooks

Some cannot resist taking the latest cookbook into the kitchen to see what promises it will keep. Others just read and dream, letting their minds do the measuring and mixing, the greasing and grilling, the slicing and sauteeing.

This time, the car not only has advanced technology but also more seats, benchlike in shape and comfortable enough to accommodate New York's roundest riders.

title: Earnings Up 25% for Computer Associates

title: Clinton Announces New Limits On Fund-Raising by Democrats
description: Trying to regain the high ground after months of questions about Democratic finance practices, President Clinton announced today that his party would no longer accept money from noncitizens living in the United States. He also said the Democrats would immediately stop taking the unlimited donations known as ''soft money'' -- if the Republicans did the same.

title: Van Gundy Is Wary Of a Smile
