title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about racial tension on the Dallas school board referred incorrectly to the board president's departure from office. The president, Sandy Kress, served his term and chose not to run for re-election; he did not resign over a furor caused by a fellow board member's racist comments.

title: THERMO INSTRUMENT READIES BID FOR LIFE SCIENCES
description: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc. said yesterday that it planned to begin a $395 million cash offer for Life Sciences International P.L.C., a British maker of laboratory equipment. Thermo Instrument said Life Sciences' board had recommended that shareholders accept the bid, which amounts to $2.24 a share. Life Sciences, which is based in London, has about 175 million shares outstanding. Thermo Instrument makes instruments used to detect and measure air pollution, radioactivity, complex chemical compounds and toxic metals. It is a publicly traded unit of the Thermo Electron Corporation, of Waltham, Mass. Shares of Thermo Instrument closed down 25 cents at $34.75.

title: Simpson Case Wrapping Up; His Testimony Is Called 'Lies'
description: Closing arguments began today in the wrongful-death lawsuit against O. J. Simpson, with the plaintiffs' lead lawyer leveling an accusatory finger at the former sports and entertainment personality and loudly asserting that ''there's a killer in this courtroom.''

title: Discredit on the House
description: Representative Newt Gingrich has earned an ignoble footnote in the history books. He is the first holder of his high office to be sanctioned for serious ethical violations. By a big margin, his colleagues voted to reprimand Mr. Gingrich and to impose a $300,000 penalty for actions that, by his admission, brought discredit on the House.

title: Scholars Attack Public School TV Program
description: In separate research, professors from Vassar and Johns Hopkins sharply attack Channel One, the 12-minute television program seen daily by an estimated eight million public school students in the United States, as an advertising vehicle loaded with superficial, biased and sometimes hurtful programming.

title: Democrats' Shift on Gifts May Affect Coffers Less Than Image
description: The Democratic Party's decision to reject donations from American subsidiaries of foreign companies could prove to be unworkable in the global economy of the late 1990's.

title: Packers Work; Patriots Rest
description: The Green Bay Packers went through a light practice yesterday in shorts and helmets, working for 90 minutes at the New Orleans Saints' practice facility in Metairie, La. The New England Patriots took the day off.

title: The nature of airline fare sales is changing as carriers focus on specific markets for short times.
description: WHEN Trans World Airlines announced a fare sale on Monday, to 17 domestic and four international destinations, a principal reason was to stimulate traffic and revenue during the industry's slowest time of the year. But the more important aspect of the sale may have been to underscore the changing nature of airline fare sales.

title: Jobs That Got Away Upset a Packers Aide
description: The television was the bearer of shocking news for Sherman Lewis, the Green Bay offensive coordinator. The report last week announced that San Francisco had hired Steve Mariucci, who had once worked under Lewis with the Packers, as the 49ers' head coach.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OLIVETTI S.p.A., Milan, Italy, the information systems company, said it had sold its United States venture capital holdings and the non-Italian operations of its Decision Systems International unit for $56 million.

title: Sulzer Technology Unit To Offer Public Shares
description: The Sulzer Technology Corporation, which makes machines for industrial and medical use, said yesterday that it planned to sell about 25 percent of its Sulzer Medica unit in an initial public offering. Sulzer Medica makes medical prostheses. The unit, with annual sales of about 1.2 billion Swiss francs ($846.5 million), generates more than 90 percent of Sulzer Technology's earnings before interest and taxes, while accounting for less than 20 percent of total sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, HORTENSE (NEE MONOGHAN)
description: O'CONNELL-Hortense (nee Monoghan), of Staten Island formerly of Manhattan. Wife of the late Maurice. Mass of Christian burial Saint Ann's Church, Staten Island, on Friday at 11 A.M. Interment in Calvary Cemetery. For further information, the Virginia Funeral Chapel Services, Staten Island.

title: Hebron After the Handover: A City of Vivid Contrasts
description: The rows of vivid Palestinian pennants over the streets, marking the handover of most of this city to Palestinian rule, end abruptly at a road leading toward enclaves of Jewish settlers downtown.

title: A Cool Santa
description: To The Living Section:

title: Price-Indexed Bonds Draw Big Demand
description: Inflation-indexed bonds began trading at surprisingly high prices and low yields yesterday as the Treasury Department announced plans for its first auction ever of such securities, to be held next Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, ALICE A.
description: MARTIN-Alice A., died January 21, 1997. Wife of James. Mother of Paula, Joshua, Elizabeth. Grandmother of Lloyd and Julia. Our love goes with her. Private.

title: Character Issue R.I.P.
description: As Bill Clinton sailed into his second term so tranquilly that his Inaugural Address all but invited the nation to join him in a cozy nap, he made Houdini look like an amateur. Despite Whitewater, Travelgate, Filegate, Paula Jones and campaign-finance shenanigans with a shady cast large enough to populate a new Coppola epic, he took the oath of office not in manacles but with an approval rating rivaling Ronald Reagan's.

title: Man Saves Dog but Drowns
description: A man trying to save his dog from a frozen creek yesterday fell through the ice and drowned, Pemberton Township police told the A.P. The dog survived. The man, James Simenson, 51, was walking with his wife and grandson along a creek behind their house when their dog walked out on the ice and fell in the water. Mr. Simenson tried to rescue the dog while his wife went to the house to get a rope. When she returned, her husband had slipped out of sight. He resurfaced a few minutes later, but rescuers could not revive him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDES, BERNARD E.
description: BRANDES-Bernard E. On Jan. 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Helen. Dear brother of Peter. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, January 23, at 11 AM. The family will receive friends on Thursday, January 23, at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60 Street, from 5-7 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Salomon Says Its 1996 Profit Nearly Doubled
description: Salomon Inc., bouncing back from a difficult year in 1995, said yesterday that its net income nearly doubled in 1996, driven by strong trading and investment banking revenues.

title: Even a Hen Might Be Fooled
description: EGG-WHITE omelets, Egg Beaters scrambled eggs and the like are one thing. But for people who want fat- and cholesterol-free whole eggs, there is another option, one that is so egg-like it can be fried sunny side up. Sunny's Without, patented by Health Style, was introduced for commercial use last summer by Papetti's Hygrade Egg Products in Elizabeth, N.J. Each imitation egg, made with real egg whites, starches, gums and gelatin plus beta-carotene for color, comes frozen in its own little container. Once thawed, it can be fried or poached like a real egg.

title: Greenspan Is Upbeat On Economy
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave an upbeat assessment of the economy today, saying that after nearly six years of uninterrupted growth it had retained ''considerable vigor, with few signs of the imbalances and inflationary tensions that have disrupted past expansions.''

title: The Parker House: Grant Ate Pie Here
description: AT the Parker House hotel, Boston cream pie has not for a moment been forgotten, even as Americans relegated it to old-line restaurants and grocery stores.

title: A Hammerstein Theater, No Phantom, Is Reborn
description: It would seem hard to lose a three-balcony opera house, with room for 3,000 people under its broad dome, that was built in 1906 by the flamboyant impresario Oscar Hammerstein and once gave the Met a run for its money.

title: The Slow Way to Ban Mines
description: Having considered two available routes for achieving its declared goal of a worldwide ban on land mines, the Clinton Administration has chosen to pursue the slower, less promising track. It is taking its case to the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, sponsored by the United Nations, where virtually any country can block agreement and several are likely to try.

title: Juilliard Quartet Chooses New Violinist
description: Ronald Copes, the violinist in the Dunsmuir Piano Quartet, is to join the Juilliard String Quartet this summer, immediately after the group's final concert with its founding first violinist, Robert Mann. Mr. Mann, who has played in the Juilliard String Quartet since it was founded in 1946 and is its last original member, is to play his last concert with the ensemble on July 2 at Tanglewood, where the group was formed. Mr. Copes's first performance, also at Tanglewood, is on Aug. 6.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RONAN, ELENA VINADE
description: RONAN-Elena Vinade. Memorial service Saturday, January 25th, St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City, 4:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBS, MADGE
description: DEBS-Madge. Of Delray Beach, FL., and South Yarmouth, MA. Died on Monday, January 20, 1997, in Bridgeport, CT. Beloved wife of the late A. G. Debs, devoted mother of Richard A. Debs of Greenwich, CT., dear mother-in-law of Barbara Knowles Debs, loving grandmother of Elizabeth Debs of Delray Beach, FL., and Nicholas A.R. Debs of New York City and great-grandmother of Isabel Sophia Turner-Debs. Funeral service at 2:00PM on Thursday, January 23, 1997, at the Nickerson Funeral Home, Orleans, MA, 508-255-0259.

title: Making the Most of an Opportunity
description: Felix Burgos's profile in The New York Times during the Neediest Cases Fund campaign in December 1993 was a portrait of a man laboring to keep his self-respect. Out of work for more than a year, he relied on public assistance for a meager existence. He had side-stepped eviction from his Brooklyn apartment by working as an unofficial superintendent for his elderly landlords. ''I had maybe $1.30 to my name,'' he recalled the other day. ''I was back in my December rent.''

title: Police Release a Witness
description: It seemed at first a promising lead: the police in the investigation of Ennis Cosby's killing had picked up a man they believed was the possible witness they had been seeking.

title: Nestle Says Sales Rose 7.1% in 1996
description: Nestle S.A. of Switzerland said yesterday that its sales rose 7.1 percent, to 60.5 billion Swiss francs ($42.68 billion) in 1996 from 56.48 billion francs a year earlier. Sales volume growth, excluding acquisitions and divestitures, was at 2.7 percent in the latest year, Nestle said. Both figures were in the range of analysts' estimates. The effects of currency translations helped sales growth by about 1.4 percent, somewhat lower than some analysts had expected.

title: Bruised but Cheerful, Pataki Returns to Work
description: Limping slightly and complaining about chest pains when he laughed, Gov. George E. Pataki returned to work this morning after spending the night in a local hospital recovering from minor injuries suffered when his state-owned car collided with a poultry truck.

title: Personal Health
description: THE virus that causes AIDS, H.I.V., is hardly the only virus that can invade the body and wreak havoc for years without the person even knowing it is there. Another insidious and perplexing organism, already present in more than 3.5 million Americans, is the virus that causes hepatitis C. When it first infects a person, it may produce no discernible symptoms. But while still in hiding, it can disrupt vital functions of the liver, and in the long run it may severely damage the liver, causing cirrhosis, organ failure and even cancer.

title: Seed Money for Students
description: For years, Eugene M. Lang has been a philanthropic giant, financing the college educations of entire classes in urban high schools. Now, he's assisting budding entrepreneurs at Columbia Business School. The Eugene Lang Entrepreneurial Initiative Fund, begun with an initial $1 million gift, is offering seed money of $50,000 to $250,000 per project, either in the form of a loan or for a stake in the company. About a dozen students have submitted proposals, and at least 40 more are expected by the March 1 deadline.

title: Experts Take Up Divisive Issue: Mammograms for Women in 40's
description: Hundreds of people doctors along with advocates for women who have breast cancer -- crowded into a basement auditorium at the National Institutes of Health today to hear the opening arguments in a two-day meeting on one of the most divisive issues in women's health: Should women in their 40's have mammograms?

title: Rape Trial of Male Cadet Under Way at West Point
description: The court-martial of a male cadet accused of raping a female classmate opened at the United States Military Academy here today with the young woman's tearful recollection of a party at a New Jersey vacation cottage that turned horrific when she awoke, in a drunken stupor, to find the accused cadet on top of her.

title: INSIDE
description: South Korean Concessions In Response to Labor Unrest

description: To the Editor:

Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. Shelley S. Goren, Chairman David Yagoda, President

title: Boston's Dowdy Pie Takes the Cake Again
description: IT has been honored by the Massachusetts legislature. It has been filmed for the evening news. It has graced the Governor's plate and fork. And it now beckons anew from restaurant menus.

title: Intel is using star power and funky music to entice Super Bowl viewers to a new kind of chip.
description: CONSUMERS are used to watching commercials for snack chips during the Super Bowl. As they watch Super Bowl XXXI on Sunday, they will see -- for the first time -- a commercial for computer chips, too.

description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAINE, HARRY G.
description: RAINE-Harry G., 83, husband of Eliane, father of William and Henry Raine, died December 23, 1996, in South Charleston, Ohio, where he was interred. A memorial mass will celebrated at the Church of Saint Bartholomew, 6900 River Road, Bethesda, MD, Saturday, January 25, 1997 at 11 AM. Flowers and charitable contributions are respectfully discouraged.

title: Styron, With All His Contradictions
description: The writer William Styron gets the ''American Masters'' celebratory treatment tonight on public television. Merely being selected for the series signals an occasion for preening, but Mr. Styron, a courtly Southerner born in Newport News, Va., in 1925, is a bit too complex to fit easily into this comfortable format.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIFF, DAWN CAHOON
description: KNIFF-Dawn Cahoon, 79, died Jan. 16, 1997. Lived in New York in the 1970's and was the widow of Bernard ''Bernie'' Kniff. Bernie was well known in shoe designing. Dawn sang soprano in St. Patrick's Choir. Memorial Services 1:00 PM., on Saturday, January 25, 1997, Woodlawn Funeral Home Chapel, 1101 Antoine Drive, Houston, TX 77055. (713-682-3663).

title: Not With a Bang or a Whimper
description: If a star falls into a black hole and no one is there to see it, does it still shine? If the universe ends, and no one is around to witness it, are your lost keys still lost?

title: Foreign Car Makers Seek Low End of Sport Utility Niche
description: Clutching a white plastic shopping bag full of car brochures, Carolyn Spicer, a 52-year-old credit union manager, stood at the North American International Auto Show here and carefully studied the light-gray, Jeep-like Honda CR-V on the platform. After looking at it from the front and the side, she guessed it would sell for $25,000 when it goes on sale next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAILEY, RICHARD G.
description: DAILEY-Richard G., of Bridgeport, CT. died January 21, 1997. Services Thursday, January 23, 1997 at 11 A.M., in Trinity Church, Southport, Connecticut.

title: Gap Plans to Build Fifth Ave. Megastore
description: In a deal that should make Fifth Avenue look even more like a new shopping zone for megastores, the Gap announced yesterday that it had leased three floors covering 40,000 square feet for a new flagship store at 680 Fifth Avenue, on the southwest corner of 54th Street.

title: Iona Knocks Out St. Peter's And Stands Alone in First
description: So much for those preseason coaches' polls. In August, neither Iona nor St. Peter's was picked to take first place in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference. Fairfield, currently in last place, was picked to win the conference.

title: Amount of Fine Was a Sticking Point
description: As Speaker Newt Gingrich was formally reprimanded today, Democrats and Republicans alike seemed preoccupied about the implications of the $300,000 sanction against him, while his lawyer said that the fine was originally nearly three times as high.

title: Sextets by a Quartet With Two Guests
description: Town Hall was once a major venue for classical music in New York. Many factors contributed to its loss of favor: deterioration of the building, the unattractiveness to concertgoers of its location just east of Times Square and the increasing dominance of Lincoln Center.

title: Microsoft Goes to Manhattan in Search of Countercultural Cool
description: Microsoft is a corporate behemoth with 20,000 workers famous for their Dockers office wear and their cool rationality, whether analyzing a line of computer code or a marketing plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHODROW, ROSE R. (NEE FEINMAN)

Dear sister of Blanche Alexander. Loving grandmother of Sarah, Daniel & Philip. Funeral services conducted from Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ, Wed, January 22, 1997, 1:00 P.M. Interment United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Metro Business
description: Today, The Times introduces Metro Business. Appearing in this section Tuesdays through Fridays, it will offer news and features on local business, from real estate and retailing to Wall Street and the economy.

title: Williams's Price Is Right for the Yankees
description: It was no surprise that record-breaking salary-arbitration figures were exchanged yesterday, particularly by Mike Piazza and the Los Angeles Dodgers and Mike Mussina and the Baltimore Orioles. But the Yankees were surprised at Bernie Williams's number.

title: MEDPARTNERS PLANS $416.7 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: Medpartners Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Inphynet Medical Management Inc. for stock valued at $416.7 million, the latest in a series of purchases by Medpartners, the nation's largest physician-management company. Inphynet stockholders will receive 1.311 Medpartners shares for each Inphynet share they hold. The tax-free transaction values Inphynet at $26.38 a share, based on Medpartners' closing price of $20.125 yesterday, down $1.75. Shares of Inphynet, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., rose $2.875, or 13 percent, to $25.625. Physician practice-management companies negotiate with health maintenance organizations on behalf of doctor groups and handle their administrative tasks. The agreement is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval.

title: Cosby Extortion Scheme: Did Good Deed Go Awry?
description: Autumn Jackson spent several years attending a community college in Florida, but she never graduated. Still, according to law enforcement officials, she had an important benefactor: Bill Cosby, the famous comedian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMB, WILLIAM P.
description: LAMB-William P., age 79, of Mahwah, NJ and Weekapaug, R.I., died Monday, January 20, 1997. Retired Vice President for Ralph M. Parsons Corporation. Husband of Patricia (nee Wise). A memorial service will be held Thursday 11 A.M., at the Wyckoff Reformed Church, 580 Wyckoff Ave, Wyckoff, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Weekapaug Foundation For Conservation, Weekapaug, Westerly, R.I. 02891.

title: Early Reports of Abuse Cited in Citadel Inquiry
description: Months before a woman who was a cadet at the Citadel dropped out, complaining of harassment, college officials had received detailed complaints from her parents that she was being mistreated by a male cadet.

description: BORZATTI-Captain B. John, of West New York, New Jersey, on Monday January 20, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Catherine (nee Radonich) Borzatti. Visitation Friday 11AM-1PM. Parking on premises.

title: Reich Takes Brandeis Post Over a Return to Harvard
description: Robert B. Reich, the outgoing Labor Secretary, will not return to Harvard, where he spent most of his career, but will instead join the faculty of Brandeis University next fall as a professor of social and economic policy, Brandeis announced today.

title: CITYSEARCH TO ANNOUNCE JOINT VENTURE IN AUSTRALIA
description: Citysearch, an Internet start-up based in Pasadena, Calif., plans to announce partnerships today with two of Australia's largest media companies to offer on-line services in Sydney and Melbourne. Citysearch said it would work with John Fairfax Holdings, publisher of the newspapers The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age in Melbourne, to supply local news and other information, and BIG Color Pages, a directory publisher, to provide data on local businesses. Service will start in Melbourne this summer and in Sydney shortly after.

title: Times Expanding Nationwide Distribution
description: The New York Times will begin a series of major changes next month to make the daily more widely available around the country and to offer readers an improved paper with later-breaking news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAY, FANNY (KEITH)
description: DAY-Fanny (Keith). January 19, 1997, age 87 of Falls Church, VA. Formerly of Plainfield, NJ, wife of the late Francis P. Day. Mother of Mary Welby Day Garrison, Anne Day Herrmann and Rosalie Day Hughes. Grandmother of Thomas and James Newbold, Jed and Tim Herrmann, Lindsay, Maisie and Eliza Hughes. Services are on Wednesday, at 1 P.M., St. James Church, Warrenton, VA. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. James Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARYANOV, DAVID
description: MARYANOV - David. The Trustees and staff of The Jewish Museum note with great sadness the death of David Maryanov, father of our esteemed Trustee, Phyllis Mack. We extend heartfelt sympathy to Phyllis, Bill and their children. E. Robert Goodkind, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: A Japanese Generation Haunted by Its Past
description: Nearly six decades have passed, but when Shinzaburo Horie sees a baby he still cringes inside, and his mind replays the indelible scene of himself as a young soldier in China, thrusting his bayonet through the chest of a Chinese infant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAYES, SADLER
description: HAYES-Sadler. Memorial Service Monday, January 27, 1997 at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave and 92nd St. NYC, 4PM.

description: BAUM-Donald J. On January 20. Beloved husband of Lillian, loving father of Mitchell, devoted brother of Robert. description: Old wounds, pain, resentment and anger furnish the building blocks for Shelly Mars's anguished but undistinguished ''Whiplash.''

description: ELLEN ROSE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMERKA, RENY (NEE STIEFFEL)
description: SMERKA-Reny (nee Stieffel). On Jan. 20, 1997 after a lengthy illness. She leaves behind a large number of admiring family and friends and a generosity of spirit which will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Triplex Lloyd of Britain Raises Takeover Offer
description: Triplex Lloyd P.L.C. said yesterday that it had raised its offer for William Cook P.L.C., a fellow British castings maker, to $:74.8 million ($124.2 million) in what analysts described as a ''knockout'' bid. William Cook urged shareholders to reject the offer, saying it greatly undervalues the company.

title: Win or Lose, for Party Some Things Stay the Same
description: Two years ago today, President Clinton stood before members of the Democratic National Committee gathered at the Washington Hilton Hotel, praised the newly installed chairmen and declared that the party's troubles were behind it.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Fall 2.6% On the New York Stock Exchange
description: Breaking a streak of record-breaking results, the number of open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange fell for the first time since July, the Big Board reported yesterday.

title: A Life and a Country Stripped of Illusions
description: The old man longs for a uniform: something ''with a touch of gold,'' he says, like a child with a Christmas wish list he knows will never be answered. For Thomas Dunne, once a superintendent of Dublin's metropolitan police and now a resident of a bare cell in a mental home, the shelter and camouflage of clothes are as distant as youth. Time and age have stripped him raw, and there is no one in the world, he says, to identify him as human.

title: Rivera vs. King
description: Is Geraldo Rivera threatening the reign of the king of cable talk shows, Larry King?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, DAVID N.
description: GOLDMAN-David N. Beloved husband of the late Miriam, dear father of Stanley, Lester, and Pauline Walters. Adored grandfather of Michael, Howard and Jennifer. Services on Thursday, 11:30 A.M. ''Parkside Chapels'', 2576 Flatbush Avenue (Avenue U), Brooklyn.

title: Captain's Place as a Yankee Great Is Secure
description: In ''On the Waterfront,'' Marlon Brando as the boxer Terry Molloy says, ''I coulda been a contender.'' In the Bronx today Don Mattingly could say, ''I could have been a Hall of Famer.''

title: What's the Bowl Without the Brats?
description: FOR many Green Bay Packers fans, Super Bowl XXXI is a chance to have a brat party, which is not to be confused with a frat party. Both may well be punctuated by yelling, screaming and what the neighbors would consider immature behavior. But only a brat party is sure to have Wisconsin-made bratwurst, the distinctively spiced pork sausage.

title: Tracing The Process Of an Artist
description: We all know how profoundly the personal iconography of childhood is woven into most artists' mature work. But how explicitly do such images manifest themselves? Peggy Stern's short film, ''Jim Dine: Childhood Stories,'' in which the artist reminisces about his youth in Cincinnati, presents his childhood memories as the undisguised meat and potatoes of his work. Mr. Dine's paintings of hearts, bathrobes and most of all of a worker's tools are direct reflections of his fascination with his father's hardware business and of the smothering devotion of his artistically inclined mother, who died of cancer when he was a child.

title: AT&T TO DISMISS 709 LONG-DISTANCE WORKERS
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 709 long-distance operators, clerks and customer-service employees at eight offices around the United States by April. The company said it needed fewer operators now that more than 99 percent of the 220 million calls during business days were handled by automated devices. A spokesman said the largest number of dismissals would be in Norfolk, Va., where 125 jobs would be cut. The company has offered to retrain dismissed workers.The job cuts are among 40,000 AT&T announced last year at both AT&T and Lucent Technologies Inc.

title: MOTOROLA BUYS STAKE IN INTERACTIVE MEDIA COMPANY
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired a stake in Worldgate Communications Inc., which offers users access to the Internet over cable-television networks. For $4.95 a month, Worldgate offers its customers access to the Internet through their television sets, remote controls and cable-television converters. Unlike traditional Internet access services, no computer or modem is needed. Motorola did not disclose the size of the investment or how much of the equity of Worldgate, based in Trevose, Pa., it had acquired. Shares of Motorola, with headquarters in Shaumburg, Ill., rose 75 cents, closing at $68.25.

title: Lag Seen in Aid for Depression
description: THERE is a perception in some circles that everyone either is taking an antidepressant or knows someone who is taking one. Prozac and Zoloft are household words and the sales of these drugs have soared to the point where the global market for all antidepressants is estimated at $6 billion a year. But at the same time a panel of experts recently concluded that depression was still being underdiagnosed and undertreated.

title: Y.& R. Loses a Chief And Names Another
description: Young & Rubicam Advertising said unexpectedly yesterday that J. Steve Davis would leave after only eight months as president and chief executive of its New York office. The executive promoted to succeed him, effective immediately, was Linda J. Srere, executive vice president, business development director and group managing director for that office.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-8

title: From Page to Stage: Race and the Theater
description: Anna Deavere Smith will be at stage center, and extreme voices on both sides of the racial divide will be heard, but this time, for a change, Ms. Smith will not be playing all the parts. The gifted actress, playwright and performance artist will moderate a debate between two real antagonists, the playwright August Wilson and the critic Robert Brustein, who will take to the stage on Monday night at 8 at Town Hall for a live version of the battle over race and cultural power they have been conducting in print for most of the last year.

title: LSB TO ACQUIRE OLD NORTH FOR $30 MILLION IN STOCK
description: LSB Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Old North State Bank for about $30 million in stock. Under the terms of the agreement, which is expected to close in the middle of this year, each Old North share will be swapped for 0.948 LSB share. LSB Bancshares said it had also received the right to buy 265,675 Old North shares for $8 apiece. Shares of LSB Bancshares closed down $1.50 at $19. LSB Bancshares, based in Lexington, N.C., is the holding company for Lexington State Bank, which has $426 million in assets and 14 branches. Old North State Bank, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has $128 million in assets and 7 branches.

title: Justices Void Federal Law Restricting Indian Estates
description: The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Federal law that prohibits members of Indian tribes who own very small pieces of land within a reservation from passing the property on to their heirs.

title: Just Another Hot Night In Chicago
description: SAME old same old. Bulls-Knicks. Champions versus challengers. Practitioners of elegance versus promoters of ugly.

title: I.B.M. Earnings Top Forecasts, But Stir Doubt On Stock Price
description: I.B.M. reported fourth-quarter earnings yesterday that were better than expected, but some analysts feared that the results were not strong enough to maintain the momentum that has seen shares of the company soar more than 30 percent in the last three months.

title: Feminists Sacrifice Jones Case to Bigger Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, WILLIAM D.
description: SULLIVAN-William D. Age 91. Jacksonville, FL. Born Wakefield, Mass. Married the late Flora (nee Beggs), Birmingham, Alabama. Graduate St. John's law school. Senior Associate, Estate & Trust, Cravath, Swain & Moore. Survived by Dana Mullee, Jacksonville, John H., Garden City, NY, Paul L., Bklyn, NY, and 8 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Interment Oaklawn Cemetery.

title: SWEDEN'S SPECTRA-PHYSICS ACQUIRES STAKE IN PLUS 3
description: Spectra-Physics A.B., a Swedish industrial equipment maker, said yesterday that it had acquired 92 percent of Plus 3 Inc., an American software company, for an undisclosed sum. Spectra-Physics will merge its United States software unit with Atlanta-based Plus 3, which develops and sells software for the building industry.

title: PERELMAN PLANS CONSOLIDATED CIGAR SHARE OFFERING
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the financier, yesterday proposed taking one of his companies private for $173.3 million, while selling $248 million in shares and notes tied to his Consolidated Cigar Holdings Inc.Mr. Perelman's Mafco Holdings Inc., a unit of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., proposed buying back the 15 percent in Mafco Consolidated Group Inc. it does not already own, at about $38.50 a share. Mafco Consolidated would then sell about 4 million shares in its Consolidated Cigar unit, which makes the Montecristo and Dutch Masters brands, at about $24.50 each for $98 million, while also selling about $150 million in Mafco Consolidated notes, which would be convertible into Consolidated Cigar shares. The proposal, intended to cash in on strong investor interest in cigar markers, would be Mr. Perelman's first foray into the market since an offer to raise capital for Marvel Entertainment Group in November angered investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOORSCH, LOUISE TOTTEN
description: BOORSCH-Louise Totten, 88, of Millbrook Road, North Haven, CT., died Tuesday, January 21st, at her home after a long illness. She was the wife of Jean Boorsch, Professor Emeritus of French at Yale. Mrs. Boorsch was born on July 16, 1908. She received a B.A. from Jackson College in 1929 and an MA. in French from Middlebury College in 1930. Professor and Mrs. Boorsch recently celebrated the 63rd anniversary of their marriage. Besides her husband, she leaves her children: James T. of New Milford, CT, Suzanne of NYC, Mary Louise Vogler of Redding, CT., and John Peter of Princeton, NJ, and 3 grandchildren, Sophia and Nathaniel Appel of N.Y.C., and Elizabeth Louise Vogler of Redding. Memorial contributions may be made to the French Summer School, Middlebury College, Middlebury, Vermont 05753. title: PIMCO NEGOTIATING ACQUISITION OF OPPENHEIMER UNIT
description: Pimco Advisors L.P. said yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire Oppenheimer Group Inc.'s one-third stake in Oppenheimer Capital L.P., an institutional money manager. Pimco, a bond-fund manager, has been seeking to increase its equities management business, and Oppenheimer Capital, which oversees about $48 billion in assets would give Pimco that opportunity. The talks between Pimco, which manages about $110 billion in assets, and Oppenheimer Group were reported in The Wall Street Journal and confirmed by Pimco, which is based in Newport Beach, Calif.The deal would be valued at $275 million, a person familiar with the negotiations said. Oppenheimer Capital is a master limited partnership that is two-thirds owned by investors and one-third by Oppenheimer Group. Shares of Oppenheimer Capital fell 50 cents, to $36.875. Pimco's stock rose 50 cents, to $24.

title: Mattingly's Final Bow Will Be Today at Yankee Stadium
description: Don Mattingly will finally and officially announce his retirement this afternoon at Yankee Stadium, ending speculation about his future and ending his impressive career precisely where it started and precisely where he wanted it to conclude.

Dear mother to sons Ronald and Franklin and their wives Ellen and Carol. Proud grandmother of Joshua, Gabriel, Alexandra, Emily and Elizabeth. description: The Nissan Motor Company said yesterday that it would build a new midsized car at its Sunderland plant in Britain, raising its investment by $:215 million ($357 million) and adding 800 jobs at the factory by 2000. Nissan has 4.6 percent of the British market.

description: In a concession aimed at ending nearly a month of labor unrest, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea said on Tuesday that he was willing to allow the National Assembly to amend a new labor law, and he hinted at recognition of a now outlawed labor organization.

description: PARIS  The U.S. and European arch-rivals Boeing and Airbus flew in sharply different directions Tuesday with plans to develop a new generation of super-jumbo passenger aircraft, a divergence that analysts said carried great risks for the company that gets it wrong and great rewards for the one that gets it right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, SADLER
description: HAYES-Sadler. The DillerQuaile School of Music mourns the passing of our friend Sadler Hayes, who founded the School's first outreach program in 1973, because he believed teaching mussic to young children would help them learn to read; tirelessly, he fund-raised for the program each succeeding year. Thanks to Sadler, The Summer Music Study Program, co-sponsored by Brick Church, has enabled thousands of children in Harlem and East Harlem to experience the language of music through song and dance. title: A Simple Blood Test Helps Predict Patients' Prospects After Strokes
description: A SIMPLE blood test can predict which patients are most likely to deteriorate in the first day or two after a stroke, researchers in Spain report. The test, for abnormally high levels of a potentially harmful substance called glutamate, may allow doctors to determine which patients are most in need of aggressive treatment aimed at minimizing brain damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINKMANN, SCHAFRANEK RUTH
description: BRINKMANN - SCHAFRANEK Ruth. Actress, director, producer and co-founder with her husband, Dr. Franz Schafranek, of Vienna's English Theatre, born in Berlin, Germany in 1934, died in Vienna, Austria on January 18 of cancer. A graduate of the Yale Drama School, she performed at the Cleveland Playhouse and Williamstown Theater before moving to Vienna, where she became a prominent figure in the theater world beginning with her first English language performance there in Jerome Kilty's ''Dear Liar'' in 1963. She starred in numerous productions including the world premier of Tennessee Williams' ''The Red Devil Battery Sign'' in 1976. In 1982 she won acclaim for her character interpretations in the one-woman show, ''The World of Ruth Draper'', which played in Europe and at the South Street Theater in Manhattan. In 1994 she was awarded an MBE by Queen Elizabeth II. In conjunction with her work on behalf of cancer victims, she gave the opening address at a world conference of oncologists in Vienna in November 1996. In December 1996 she was awarded an honorary professorship by the Austrian government. She is survived by her mother, Anna K. Brinkmann of Delray Beach, Florida; her brother Klaus Brinkmann and sister Karin Brown, both of Manhattan; her daughter Julia Schafranek and 2 grandchildren. Funeral service to be held in Vienna on January 31, 1997. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a memorial donation to the American Cancer Society.

title: NATO or Tomato?

Don't get me wrong, the West Europeans support NATO expansion, but it's nothing they ever seem to talk much about or debate. They treat it as something America will take care of, something America will finesse with the Russians and something America will pay for.

title: USA WASTE TO BUY COMPANY THAT FILED FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: USA Waste Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay about $180 million for the assets of Mid-American Waste Systems Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Tuesday because it would be left with significant debt after the transaction is completed. Mid-American listed assets of $61.4 million and liabilities of $371.8 million in its filing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. USA Waste's proposed acquisition of Mid-American, based in Canal Winchester, Ohio, includes the assumption of $49 million in debt. The rest of the purchase price will be paid in cash or a combination of cash and up to $90 million in USA Waste common stock. USA Waste, based in Houston, is the larger of the two solid-waste management companies, with $936 million in revenue during the first three quarters of 1996. Mid-American Waste had $94.7 million in revenue for its first three quarters in 1996. Shares of Mid-American Waste, which traded at more than $25 in 1992, have steadily declined since then as losses mounted. Its shares closed at 43.75 cents on Tuesday. Shares of USA Waste rose $2 yesterday, to $34.125.

title: A Fine for Fouling the Bay
description: Ronald J. Santee, owner of the 65-foot paddle-wheel boat the Sandy Hook Lady, makes his living showing tourists the scenic wonders of Sandy Hook Bay. But last summer, Mr. Santee admitted, he dumped the Lady's 1,000-gallon sewage holding tank directly into the bay, even though there was a free hookup to the municipal sewage system at the boat's home dock in Atlantic Highlands. Mr. Santee, who pleaded guilty in Superior Court on Tuesday, faces probation, community service and a fine of up to $30,000. He was caught red-handed in August when police, working undercover, slipped nontoxic dye into the boat's holding tank.

title: Those Little Lulus

Although the State Legislature is famous for concentrating authority in a few hands, the monthly payroll boasts more leaders than the Continental Congress.

title: China Now Leads In Crude Steel Production
description: China replaced Japan in 1996 as the world's leading crude steel producer, a Japanese industry group said yesterday. China's output last year rose 5.2 percent, to 110.4 million tons, ahead of Japan's output of 98.8 million tons, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said. The group attributed China's increased output to that country's economic expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, WILLIAM
description: HUGHES-William. Age 83. Pianist, accompanist and vocal coach. Died in New York City, December 31, 1996. A Cleveland native, he attended the Cleveland Conservatory of Music and came to New York on a scholarship to continue his musical studies. A graduate of the Juilliard School of Music and a Fellow of the Wurlitzer Foundation in Taos, New Mexico, he was a resident of the Upper West Side of Manhattan for over fifty years. He toured internationally as accompanist to such prominent vocal artists as Rose Bampton, Nadine Conner, Donald Dickson, James King and Blanche Thebom. Taught vocal interpretation at Temple University and served as private vocal coach to hundreds of classical singers. He is survived by several nieces and nephews of Cleveland. He also leaves many devoted friends and colleagues who were profoundly touched not only by his superior and sensitive musicianship, but by his kindness, generosity and flair for living. He will be deeply missed. At his request, there will be no funeral. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: Oldest Tools Are Described
description: Scientists have published a paper in the journal Nature describing stone tools made 2.5 million to 2.6 million years ago that are considered the oldest-known artifacts created by humans or their direct ancestors. The discovery, which was announced in 1995 at a scientific meeting, was made in excavations at Gona, Ethiopia, from 1992 to 1994. It included almost 3,000 rounded, fist-size stones and small, sharp-edged flakes, a finding that pushed the date of the first tool making back 200,000 years. The principal author of the paper was Dr. Sileshi Semaw, an Ethiopian paleoanthropologist.

title: Lobbyists' Gifts to Politicians Reap Benefits, Study Shows

title: Happier Motoring: Choices in Buying Insurance
description: The proposal from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey last week to allow motorists to buy no-frills, no-fault auto insurance that could pare premiums by as much as one-fourth was a strong endorsement for a fledgling idea that has been unable to take flight nationally. The idea is known as auto choice, and the seal of approval from an adroit Republican who has her sights on bigger things, may finally be the step that lifts it off the ground.

title: A Man Who Repaid His Debts
description: Charles F. Feeney, who secretly gave away a business enterprise worth billions of dollars, said he never set out to build a fortune, just to make a good living for his family. But as his fortune grew, he said, he never forgot that the reason a poor boy from Elizabeth, N.J., could make it through Cornell University was the G.I. Bill and a scholarship in his senior year.

title: Earnings at Bear Stearns Exceed Projections
description: The Bear Stearns Companies yesterday became the latest investment bank to surpass analysts' forecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, IRVING MORRIS
description: GREENBERG-Irving Morris. On January 22 in New Brunswick at age 84. For many years, he was a commercial real estate broker, landholder, and investor. Born in Manhattan on May 23, 1912, he moved with his parents, Louis and Dora, to Etra, New Jersey, where he met and married Rose Sokolow, his beloved wife of 61 years. Generous in all aspects of his life, he was a man of great integrity and heroic perserverance. He lent his strength to all who knew and loved him. Father of Joan Rencarge and the late Linda Kahny, grandfather of Sheri, Debra, Robert and Lisa, great grandfather of Michelle. He is survived by his loving sisters, Ruth Fagan and Miriam Diner. A resident of East Brunswick, New Jersey during the prime of his life, he moved to Monroe Township in 1972 and was a founder and past president of the Jewish Congregation of Clearbrook. An extraordinary supporter of many charities, he was devoted to the State of Israel, Beit Halochem, Special Olympics, educational funding, research in diabetes, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, and many other humanitarian causes. Those who wish to remember him may give to research in Alzheimer's disease, cancer, or Parkinson's disease, all of which deeply affected his life. Private family services.

title: U.S. Is Selling Missiles It Once Banned
description: Just a few years after they ended their nuclear arms race, the United States and Russia are locked in a fierce competition for arms sales to Southeast Asia, with both countries offering potential purchasers some of the world's most sophisticated missiles as incentives.

title: Of Kings and Empires In Realms of Football
description: WITH the now familiar sea of microphones and platform full of cameras before them, Bob Kraft, the owner of the Patriots, and Bill Parcells, his head coach, yesterday appeared before the news media to give the serfs and knaves another day's morsel.

title: Ford to Lift Stake In Chinese Truck Maker
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to invest $40 million to lift its stake in the Jiangling Motors Company, a Chinese truck maker, to 33 percent, a Jiangling official said yesterday.

title: Vietnam Museum Is Planned
description: While nearly 50,000 people visited the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial in Holmdel last year, many visitors said the memorial raised more questions about the war than it answered, according to the New Jersey Vietnam Veterans' Memorial Foundation, which runs the monument. Today, in an effort to answer some of those questions, the foundation will announce plans to build a museum next to the memorial. The 11,000-square-foot Vietnam Era Educational Center, scheduled to open in November, will be the only museum in the country devoted to the war, said Kelly Watts, the foundation's executive director.

title: Microsoft's Muppet Deal
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that Jim Henson Production Inc. had agreed to jointly develop interactive programming featuring the Muppets for Microsoft's on-line network, MSN. Financial terms for the three-year development deal were not disclosed. The companies expect the first set of shows to be introduced this summer. MSN offers information, entertainment and communications on the Internet. Jim Henson Productions, based here, is a film, television and video production company.

title: Bill to Ban Some Abortions
description: A bill to ban a type of abortion that involves the partial delivery of a live fetus will be considered today by the Assembly health committee. The procedure would still be allowed when the mother's life is in danger.

title: Simpson Lawyer Accuses Plaintiffs of Seeking Money, Not Justice
description: O. J. Simpson's lawyer asserted today that the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald L. Goldman were seeking money, not justice, in filing a wrongful-death suit against the former sports and entertainment personality.

title: Top Researcher Postpones Plan for Test to Determine if AIDS Patients Can Be Cured
description: Dr. David Ho, a leading AIDS scientist, said here today that he had pushed back by up to a year his plans to do crucial tests to determine whether infection with the AIDS virus can be cured in some people.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Organizations everywhere seem to be in a mood for presenting awards, announcing them or making plans for ceremonies. The New York Academy of Medicine will pay tribute tonight to Dr. DAVID A. HAMBURG, who in July will step down as the president of the Carnegie Corporation in New York, and EVELYN H. LAUDER, the senior corporate vice president of Estee Lauder, at its 150th anniversary celebration at the Museum of Natural History. Dr. Hamburg is being honored for bringing critical issues to public attention, especially those involving the needs of children, and Mrs. Lauder for her work raising awareness of breast cancer.

title: In Home Electronics, the Future Now Has a Due Date
description: FOR years now, electronics manufacturers have promised that homes would soon be cocoons outfitted with every type of entertainment and information component. No longer far-off fantasies, such devices were on display at the Consumer Electronics Show here earlier this month. What's more, many will be on the market in a few months.

title: White Wants Pulpit Between Hash Marks
description: They call Packers defensive end Reggie White the minister of defense. It's a clever play on the fact that White is an ordained minister and an associate pastor at the Inner City Church in Knoxville, Tenn., and one of the most menacing pass rushers in the National Football League.

title: Save Social Security, Save Our Families
description: For more than 20 years, I have worked to defend average American families, which time and again get the short end of the stick. I fear they will be the chief victims again as Washington considers three plans to ''reform'' Social Security, all based on putting payroll taxes or private contributions into the stock market.

title: Pizza Chain to Withdraw Its 'Low-Fat' Claims
description: One of the nation's leading restaurant chains, Pizzeria Uno, has conceded that its previous advertisements for low-fat, thin-crust pizzas were false and misleading, and has promised the Federal Trade Commission not to make such claims again.

title: West Point Rape Trial Focuses on Female Cadet's Drinking
description: Testimony in the court-martial here of a male cadet charged with raping a female classmate focused today on the questions of precisely how drunk the 20-year-old woman was and, by implication, whether she had the ability to consent to a sexual act.

title: Egyptian Company to Buy Stake in Israeli Concern
description: Egypt's Kato Industries said yesterday that it planned to purchase a holding in Israel's Koor Industries on Jan. 28 or 29.

title: Bipartisan Praise for Cuomo At Hearing on HUD Position
description: The Senate Banking Committee opened hearings today on the nomination of Andrew M. Cuomo as Federal Housing Secretary, offering a chorus of bipartisan praise for Mr. Cuomo and a round of criticism against the troubled agency that he has been picked to lead.

title: Joint Takeover Bid For Australian Mine
description: Camelot Resources N.L., an Australian gold mining company, and Canada's Teck Corporation, an affiliate of Germany's Metallgesellschaft A.G., said yesterday that they would make a joint takeover bid of $158 million (Australian), or $123 million (United States), for Mount Edon Gold Mines (Australia) Ltd. The bid will be made through Reachwest Pty. Ltd., which already holds about 14.2 percent of Mount Edon.

title: YELTSIN'S ABSENCE BRINGS AN OUTCRY FROM LEGISLATORS
description: In a display of Russia's mounting restiveness about President Boris N. Yeltsin's seemingly permanent absence from the Kremlin, the Parliament voted overwhelmingly this evening for a resolution to remove Mr. Yeltsin from his post because of his poor health.

title: Hometown Recalls Paul Tsongas as Hero Who Inspired Renewal and Pride
description: To most people beyond this city, Paul Tsongas was the man with the odd voice who made a quixotic run for the Presidency in 1992. No one really believed that Paul Tsongas was going to be President.

title: With Little Fanfare, A Leading Horn Player Ends a 50-Year Career
description: Those who have lost close track of Barry Tuckwell's illustrious career over the last decade or two may be surprised to learn that his final public performances on the horn, tonight, tomorrow and Saturday, are to take place in Baltimore. With no insult intended to that fair city, it seems an out-of-the-way place for this ultimate musical cosmopolite to take his leave.

title: HUIZENGA'S COMPANY ADDS 3 CAR DEALERSHIPS IN FLORIDA
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had acquired Carlisle Motors in Florida for $35 million in stock, the latest in a flurry of car dealership acquisitions by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga's holding company. Carlisle operates three automobile dealerships, including the nation's fourth-largest Lincoln-Mercury dealer. Carlisle, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., owns Lincoln-Mercury, Ford and Hyundai dealerships in St. Petersburg and Clearwater, Fla. For Republic, Carlisle is the 15th such acquisition announced since last summer. Shares of Republic closed up $1 yesterday, to $41.125.

title: Fraternizing Over for Miller
description: Yes, he had been serious about entertaining offers from the Knicks. And, yes, he believes the rivalry still lives. ''The Hatfields and McCoys, all over again,'' Reggie Miller said today after the Indiana Pacers prepared for Thursday night's game at Market Square Arena. ''Both teams don't like one another. They don't pretend like they like one another, and that's fine with us.''

title: Things Turn Wacky On Planet Parcells
description: They got off the elevator together. They shared a podium and even tried cracking jokes. But the Bill Parcells-Bob Kraft act most likely played to one of its final audiences.

title: Films Leap From the Mainstream
description: They may be ugly, blind and foul, but they're among the major attractions at the 1997 Sundance Film Festival. And when hairless pink mole rats start looking like movie stars, it's proof that Park City is witnessing Bizarro Sundance this year.

title: Childs Says Socializing Is Not Path To Victory
description: Chris Childs considers it a great honor to start at point guard for the Knicks. He knows with that responsibility sometimes comes the unenviable chore of letting his teammates know what he believes to be the truth, even if they do not want to hear it.

title: Top Officials of 3 Railroads to Meet on Conrail Takeover Dispute
description: In what may be a breakthrough in the costly three-month-long battle for Conrail, the CSX Corporation and Conrail agreed yesterday to a meeting with the Norfolk Southern Corporation to discuss reshaping the rail freight industry in the East.

title: Britain's Surprise: The Queen Gets a Brand-New Yacht in 2002
description: When the royal yacht Britannia sailed from Plymouth on Monday on a final Far East tour before its decommissioning in August, Britons thought they would never see her costly like again.

title: Jury Says ABC Owes Damages Of $5.5 Million
description: A Federal jury in Greensboro, N.C., yesterday awarded a supermarket chain more than $5.5 million in punitive damages from ABC and two of its employees in a closely watched case that focused on the propriety of widely used television news techniques like hidden cameras and undercover reporters.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Sets Back Perelman Bid to Keep Marvel
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the financier who is seeking to maintain control of the Marvel Entertainment Group in bankruptcy, suffered a setback yesterday when a United States Bankruptcy Court judge in Delaware rejected parts of a borrowing agreement that Marvel had negotiated. But a spokesman for Mr. Perelman said the ruling ''is really not a problem for us.''

title: SWING-N-SLIDE TO BUY GAMETIME IN $40.5 MILLION DEAL
description: The Swing-N-Slide Corporation, a maker of wooden playground equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Gametime Inc. for $27 million in cash and securities. Swing-N-Slide, based in Janesville, Wis., said it would assume about $13.5 million in Gametime debt, bringing the total value of the deal to $40.5 million. Swing-N-Slide primarily makes do-it-yourself products sold through retailers. Gametime sells playground equipment to schools and municipalities through sales representatives. Gametime is a closely held company based in Fort Payne, Ala. It had sales of $48 million in 1996. Swing-N-Slide had sales of $40.4 million and earnings of $1.65 million in the last year. Shares of Swing-N-Slide rose $1.125 yesterday, to $4.50.

title: Roots From Israel to Alaska
description: Watching Neta Pulvermacher and Dancers on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater was like eavesdropping on an animated conversation in a foreign language. Ms. Pulvermacher's choreography made her performers gesticulate with great excitement, although it was seldom possible to discern what made them so passionate.

title: QUICK & REILLY TO ACQUIRE JERSEY CITY SECURITIES DEALER
description: Quick & Reilly Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Nash Weiss & Company, a securities dealer, for an undisclosed sum. Quick & Reilly, based in Palm Beach, Fla., is a discount brokerage firm with 116 offices nationwide. Nash Weiss, based in Jersey City, trades securities on the Nasdaq computer network. It has annual revenue of $60 million. The combined company will continue Nasdaq trading under the Nash Weiss & Company name, Quick & Reilly said. Shares of Quick & Reilly were unchanged yesterday at $33.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MARGUERITE (GRACIE)
description: ALLEN-Marguerite (Gracie). It is with great sadness that we announce the death at the age of 94 of our esteemed colleague and friend Gracie, who passed away peacefully at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. Gracie devoted her life to Douglas Elliman and more than anyone symbolized the great history and traditions of the firm. She joined Douglas L. Elliman in 1927 and for over 68 years served the firm with unquestioned loyalty and distinction. Douglas Elliman was both her life and her family and we all mourn her passing, remembering always her kindness and caring nature. Her concern for colleagues and her quiet dignity were standards to which we all aspire. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, January 28, at noon, The Little Church Around The Corner, 1 East 29th St. Howard P. Milstein Chairman Douglas Elliman

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL I. SOVERN, the former president of Columbia University and former dean of its law school, will receive Columbia's highest award, its Medal of Excellence, tomorrow along with one of his students of 40 years ago, MARIE L. GARIBALDI, class of 1959 and now a New Jersey Supreme Court Justice. The awards will be presented at the law school's winter luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.

title: A Top Canadian Visits Cuba, Nettling Washington
description: In a brief visit that clearly signaled the sharp divisions between the United States and Canada over how to deal with Cuba, Canada's Foreign Minister dined with President Fidel Castro and other Cuban officials on Tuesday before signing joint declarations today on human rights and foreign investment.

title: Bridge
description: A match played a week ago at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, determined two titles. The defending champions in the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams won their final match by 33 imps, going unbeaten. And Jim Krekorian of Manhattan became the New York Team Player of the Year for 1996.

title: Police-Escort Plea Denied by Goldberg
description: It was a routine morning in Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's office on Tuesday until an excited secretary told Mrs. Whitman's chief spokeswoman, Becky Taylor, that the actress Whoopi Goldberg was on the line.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Japanese stocks closed lower today after trading higher much of the day. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 104.42 points, about six-tenths of a percent, to 17,909.46. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rebounded somewhat from days of sharp declines, gaining 655.72 points.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALBERT, YONAH ZAYDE
description: ALBERT-Yonah Zayde 1-23-37. Loving memories of you and Bubbe Susah. My daughter Susan Joan is named for you two. Chana

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUML, ELAINE K.
description: BAUML-Elaine K. To my oldest buddy and my special friend forever. I'll miss you as will so many others. Vivian Degani

title: Ad Review Council Names New Chief
description: The National Advertising Review Council in New York, the advertising industry's self-regulation organization, said yesterday that Eric D. Haueter, executive director of its National Advertising Review Board unit since 1990, had been promoted to chairman. Mr. Haueter, 72, succeeds Kenneth A. Cox, 80, who is retiring. The council includes members from the American Advertising Federation, the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the Association of National Advertisers and the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: Young Americans Triumph in Paris
description: PHILIPPE STARCK, watch your back. American design students stormed Paris two weeks ago.

title: Debate on a Non-Police Chief
description: The hotly debated restructuring of Atlantic City's police department took two steps forward last night. The City Council approved by 5 to 4 the first reading of a measure to abolish the post of police chief, and the Council voted to hire the recently retired police chief of Camden, George Pugh, as the city's first civilian Public Safety Director. The switch to a civilian director, advocated by Mayor James Whelan, is opposed by the city's police union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, GLADYS SHANDLING
description: COHEN-Gladys Shandling. For 50 years devoted wife of Robert E., loving mother of Charles and Richard, grandmother of Amber, cousin of Terese and Jay Siegel and Robert and David Addison, daughter of the late Lillian and Charles, mother-in-law of Christine Schindler, niece of Milton Siegel, and loyal friend to so many. Loving and caring, a gracious, strong, and vibrant woman-the portrait of a lady. Friends will be received at home on Thursday, Saturday, and Sunday. Friday friends will be received from 10 AM-Noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel before proceeding to Beth David Cemetery for a 1 P.M. service. Contributions to cancer research would be appropriate.

title: Rental Car Giant Successfully Shuns Industry Shakeout
description: For 40 years, Enterprise Rent-a-Car Inc. has gone against all the conventional industry wisdom. Not only has it ceded the bread-and-butter airport business to Hertz, Avis and other national competitors, but it has also done without celebrity-driven advertisements and catchy slogans.

title: Dynamite Was Used in Attack at Clinic, Officials Say
description: The Federal authorities investigating the bombing at an abortion clinic near Atlanta last week have concluded that each of the two bombs was built with 10 to 20 sticks of dynamite, a high explosive that experts say is unusual in homemade terrorist devices.

title: FRANKLIN QUEST TO ADD SELLER OF TRAINING PRODUCTS
description: The Franklin Quest Company, a time-management seminar provider, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $160 million in stock for Covey Leadership Center, a closely held company that sells productivity training books and other products. Franklin, based in Salt Lake City, sells products through its catalogue and retail stores. Shares of Franklin Quest closed down 62.5 cents yesterday at $22.

title: Herbert Allen Sr., 88, an Early Specialist in Corporate Takeovers
description: Herbert Allen Sr., the financier who with his brother Charles engineered some of the earliest corporate takeovers by Wall Street firms, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: At Blaze, Firefighters Find 4 Shot to Death
description: Firefighters rushing to put out a smoky blaze this morning forced open a first-floor bedroom door and found the bodies of a mother and her three young daughters, all shot to death, the authorities said.

title: At Least One Partner Is Angry
description: AN uneasy Don Mattingly said his wife had just told him to speak from the heart, but the retiring Yankee, not one to wear emotions on his pinstriped sleeves, played it diplomatically safe, never wandering very far off first base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, WILLIAM R.
description: MEYER-William R., 47. Author and film historian, of natural causes at his home in Staten Island. Graduated 1967 from Pascack Hills H.S., Montvale, NJ; The New School for Social Research, BA, 1974; NY Univ., MA, 1976. Books include ''The Making of the Great Western'', ''The Warner Bros. Directors'' and ''The Film Buff's Catalog''. For information call A. Azzara Funeral Home, Inc., Staten Island, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMERANZ, JONATHAN N.
description: POMERANZ-Jonathan N. Husband of Marilyn, father of Jacques and Frank. Grandfather of Jeffrey and Sharon. Died on January 21, 1997 and was 88 years old. Funeral Services Friday, Jan. 24, 11 AM, Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, Plandome, N.Y. Nat lived in Hollywood, Fla. after moving from Baldwin, NY. He was an active member of the Baldwin Jewish Center. He was a Vice President of Roberts Company, a textile machinery manufacturer headquartered in Sanford, NC. He led a full life, was loved, and will be missed greatly.

title: Profits Rise At Compaq; Stock Jumps
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation reported earnings yesterday for the fourth quarter and all of last year that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates, and the company's stock rose sharply.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about new editions and business ventures at The New York Times misstated an estimate of the company's earnings in some editions. Steven N. Barlow, senior media analyst with Smith Barney, has predicted that The New York Times Company's earnings will grow to $2.15 a share this year, from an estimated $1.80 a share last year (not to $3.85 from $3.43).

title: Harlem Dance Troupe, United, Goes on Strike
description: The 32 dancers of Dance Theater of Harlem went on strike yesterday after unanimously voting down a one-year contract offer at a meeting on Tuesday night at the troupe's headquarters.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO. (BMY,N)
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had earned $716 million, or $1.43 a share, in the fourth quarter, after a net loss of $142 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said that its operating results rose 11 percent as stronger sales of its cholesterol-lowering drug Pravachol and cancer drug Taxol helped offset slumping sales of its heart medicine Capoten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Samuel J. The partners and staff of Hall Dickler Kent Friedman & Wood mourn the loss of our long-time friend and partner, Samuel J. Friedman. His dedication to our firm and his love and caring for all his co-workers will never be forgotten. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Doris and his daughters, grandchildren and other family members.

title: Giving a Fortune, Secretively
description: Over the last 15 years, a self-made businessman from Elizabeth has given more than $600 million to hospitals, universities and other institutions -- but he has done it in such complete secrecy that most recipients never learned who their benefactor was. $(Articles, pages A1 and B4.$)

title: Affidavit Released in Baiul Accident
description: OKSANA BAIUL, the Olympic champion facing drunken-driving charges, was traveling at close to 100 miles per hour when she ran her Mercedes off the road, the police in Bloomfield, Conn., estimate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, JOHN MCQUIGGAN
description: PHILLIPS-John McQuiggan, 64, of Scarsdale, New York, died unexpectedly of a heart attack on January 19, in St. Bartholomew's, Guadeloupe (FWI). He was a graduate of the Phillips Exeter Academy, class of 1951, and of Yale Univ., class of 1955. At Yale he played guard on the varsity football team in the 1952-1954 seasons and was a member of the Wolf's Head Senior Society and Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity. Following graduation he entered the U.S. Army and served for two years as a First Lieutenant in the Tenth Mountain Division based in Aschaffenburg, Germany. Mr. Phillips was a Vice President in the Municipal Bond Dept. of the First Boston Corporation, retiring after 31 years of service in 1989. During his career he was active in the Municipal Bond Club of NY. He was a member of the Yale Club of NYC and the Fox Meadow Tennis Club and was formerly a member of the Downtown Athletic Club. He maintained a residence at Point O' Woods, on Fire Island and served as President of the Club at Point O' Woods. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Barbara Becker; a daughter, Julia Hawley; a son, James McQuiggan and three brothers, Alfred C., Paul B. and Robert O. For those who wish, contributions may be made to the Church at Point O' Woods, Point O' Woods, New York 11706. Reposing Friday, January 24, at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, N.Y., from 7-9 P.M. Services will be held on Sat., January 25 at 11 A.M., at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Reeves Avoids Turnovers and Eases Pain
description: Khalid Reeves needed a massage and he needed it now. This wasn't a good time. Didn't he know that?

title: Former Susannas Sing New Roles in 'Figaro'
description: Operagoers understandably pay greater attention to the handful of new productions the Metropolitan Opera stages each season than to the repertory works it pulls out of storage. But the company's production of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' which returned to the house on Monday evening, is as good a reminder as any that these stagings evolve as new singers, stage directors and conductors come to them with fresh ideas.

title: A Symphonic Debut For an Opera Conductor
description: The New York Chamber Symphony and its founding conductor, Gerard Schwarz, are usually as inseparable as Sir Neville Marriner and the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields. But Mr. Schwarz occasionally surrenders his baton to a colleague, and for the group's Saturday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall, John Fiore was on the podium.

title: When What You See Is All You Get
description: PRELIMINARY designs for Michael Eisner's multimillion-dollar log cabin in Aspen, Colo., included stone fireplaces to rival Yosemite National Park's Ahwahnee Hotel -- and a retaining wall so thin that it would have buckled under its own weight.

title: Kazan and Others
description: To the Editor:

title: Stalking Antiques With Mona
description: MUSES have gone out of fashion, but given the largely unsurprising wares at the 43d Winter Antiques Show, the exposition could have used a deity like Mona Strader Schlesinger Bush Williams von Bismarck de Martini.

title: COMMERCE NOMINEE VOWS TO ROOT OUT POLITICAL AGENDAS
description: President Clinton's nominee for Commerce Secretary, William M. Daley, said today that if confirmed he would take steps to depoliticize the department, which Republicans say has become an outpost of Democratic Party fund raising.

title: Army's Sutton Wins Sheehan Award
description: BOB SUTTON, who guided Army to a 10-2 record and a spot in the Independence Bowl last fall, was named the winner yesterday of the Joseph M. Sheehan Award as Division I-A coach of the year.

title: Asking Lawyers to Pay Up
description: Tax-dodging lawyers, beware. Yesterday, the Internal Revenue Service and the state Division of Taxation announced a program to collect delinquent taxes from about 400 of New Jersey's 22,000 attorneys. ANDY NEWMAN

title: The Shrinking Science Budget
description: The National Academy of Sciences reports that Federal spending on basic research and new technologies in 1997 will barely rise above 1996 levels, despite years of steady decline. Even worse, the five-year deficit reduction plan, as embraced by Congress and President Clinton, will knock 35 percent out of the country's science programs by the year 2002. The trend is ominous because research pays big dividends, accounting for perhaps half the growth in living standards and raising output by 30 cents or more on each invested dollar.

title: Gardens or Houses?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKSTEIN, ROSE
description: BERKSTEIN-Rose. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends extend sincerest condolences to Mrs. Judith Haimoff, Director of Global Development at Bar-Ilan University in Israel, her sister and the entire family on the loss of their mother, Mrs. Rose Berkstein. Both of them may derive a measure of solace not only from the fact that they were exemplary daughters, but also from the fact that they afforded their mother great nachat from their respective careers. To Bar-Ilan University, the leadership of Mrs. Haimoff has been most noteworthy and we are in her debt forever. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Yehuda Halevy, Exec. V.P. Jane Stern Lebell, Pres., American Friends of Bar-Ilan University

title: The Quotable Lebed
description: Aleksandr I. Lebed's reputation for blunt speaking comes in part from his taste for the folksy aphorisms to illustrate a point, put down an opponent or tout his own achievements. A few examples from his visit to New York:

title: New York Shoppers, Unleashed
description: It wasn't the lime green cashmere sweater that found its way home from Brooks Brothers, or the navy blue fedora. It wasn't that new Lanvin necktie from Saks, the Calvin Klein underwear from Bloomie's or the light blue Banana Republic sport shirt.

title: From Pinsk to Brooklyn, The Kings of Klezmer
description: Time and memory are woven through the captivating documentary ''A Tickle in the Heart,'' which opened yesterday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center as part of the Sixth Annual Jewish Video and Film Festival.

title: Judge Says Military Bases Can Sell Sex Material
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the Defense Department could not enforce a law banning the sale of sexually explicit magazines and videos on military bases because it violated Constitutional protections for free speech.

title: N.Y.U. Plans a Revival of Luchow's
description: Amid a dormitory-building spree that has made it one of the biggest developers in Greenwich Village, New York University now finds itself in the position of trying to resurrect a ghost of New York culture: Luchow's restaurant, the elegant German restaurant and beer hall that became a cultural icon in the 1890's.

title: Giuliani Gains in His Long Fight With Authority on Airport Rents
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani won a victory yesterday in his long battle with the Port Authority over back rent at the city's two airports when the Federal Aviation Administration partly reversed an adverse decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKIN, BEATRICE
description: BARKIN-Beatrice. Beloved wife of Martin for over 50 years. Loving mother to Judy (Kenneth), Jeanne (Mark), Allen (Julie), and Daniel (Carol). Devoted grandmother to Adam, Jordon, Rebecca, David, Pauline, Ellie, Perry and Jeremy. She was a special person who will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Progressive Credit Union, Robert Familant, Treasurer

title: Too Timid to Lead
description: Vice President Al Gore, whose Buddhist-temple fund-raiser has become a national joke, is reported to fear that former Senator Bill Bradley could win the Democratic Presidential nomination next time by running on a pledge to clean up campaign finance. That raises the question why Mr. Gore does not talk President Clinton into protecting him by building a strong record on this issue. Yet Mr. Clinton just cannot bring himself to step forward as a bold leader determined to drive dirty money out of campaigns and to give up unconditionally the soft money that corporations and wealthy favor-seekers pump into the national committees of the two major parties.

title: Albright Picks 2 Diplomats For Top Posts
description: Madeleine K. Albright, who was confirmed today by the Senate as Secretary of State by a vote of 99 to 0, has chosen two highly experienced government hands for top jobs in the State Department.

title: Freer Choice for Gas Service
description: One week after deregulating the residential electricity market, the Board of Public Utilities voted yesterday to give 30,000 natural gas consumers free choice over where to buy their gas. Under the plan, residential customers of New Jersey Natural Gas Company, which serves Morris, Monmouth, Ocean and Middlesex counties, will be able to buy their gas from as many as 30 different companies.

title: Dan Flavin Memorial
description: A memorial for the Minimalist sculptor Dan Flavin, who died on Nov. 29 at the age of 63, will be held today at 5 P.M. at the Dia Center for the Arts, 542 West 22d Street, Chelsea. Speakers will include Brydon Smith, curator of 20th-century art at the National Gallery of Canada, Ottawa; Fariha Friedrich, a Dia trustee, and Michael Venezia, an artist. The tenor Robert White will sing.

title: Coffee Rises to 5-Month High And Gold Tumbles Further
description: Coffee prices jumped to a five-month high on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York yesterday amid concern that a Colombian dock workers' strike and a disappointing Brazilian crop would reduce exports from the world's two top producers.

title: Fresh Tension for Cyprus: Counting the Newcomers
description: Almost everything about northern Cyprus its name, its status, the reasons for the 110 miles of barbed wire that divide it from the rest of the island -- is a matter of dispute. But little stirs passions on either side of the nearly 23-year-old buffer zone like the issue of exactly who lives north of it.

title: Girl, 13, Injured in Fall Down School's Air Shaft
description: Trying to hide from a dean who was looking for her and nine other students who had cut class, a 13-year-old girl fell two floors down an air shaft at an intermediate school in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday morning, police officers and school officials said.

title: Truck Sped Through C.I.A. Security, Agency Says
