description: An emotionally disturbed man sped past the security checkpoints at the Central Intelligence Agency headquarters last month in a pickup truck that came to rest on the building's front steps, the agency said today.

title: Appointee of Clinton Pushed Deal Sought by a Big Donor
description: Maria Haley, a longtime aide to President Clinton who is now an appointee of his at the Export-Import Bank, tried last year to push through an unusual $6.5 million financing deal sought by a woman whose large donations to the Democratic Party are under investigation, interviews and Government records show.

title: Luxury High-Rise Planned for Brooklyn Heights
description: A Manhattan developer is advancing plans for the first new luxury high-rise apartment building in 10 years in Brooklyn Heights.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Fan

title: RENO SAYS SAUDIS DID NOT COOPERATE IN BOMBING INQUIRY
description: The Clinton Administration's top law enforcement official sharply criticized Saudi Arabia today for failing to cooperate in the investigation into the terrorist bombing last June in Dhahran that killed 19 American airmen.

title: Wake Gets Its Wish (Respect) At Clemson
description: The game was billed locally as the biggest in the 29-year history of Clemson's Littlejohn Coliseum. The second-ranked Tigers were poised atop the Atlantic Coast Conference standings, rated higher than at any time in school history, and riding a 13-game winning streak.

title: Administration Won't Merge Programs Promoting Exports
description: The Clinton Administration decided today that the three Government agencies that play a major role in financing American exports abroad should not be merged, concluding that while the current system was fragmented and awkward, the political costs of reorganization were too high.

title: Respect Integrity of Peaceful Abortion Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Miller Brings Pacers Back, but Ewing Slams Door
description: The movements were unpolished and awkward. The timing was awful. Reggie Miller, convinced he had again shot down New York's basketball team, broke into a playful dance with 1 minute 14 seconds remaining.

title: Union Vote in Midtown
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters is not giving up its fight to unionize the more than 50 workers in the Grand Central Partnership, the business improvement district surrounding the famed rail terminal. Robert Hill, an organizer with the teamsters, said the National Labor Relations Board would conduct an election on Feb. 21 to determine whether the janitors and other partnership workers want to join the teamsters.

title: West Mustn't Bow to Russia's NATO Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: Serious Face on a Texas Independence Group
description: Texas is the only state to have entered the Union as an independent nation, and even a century and a half after it did so, schoolchildren say a daily pledge to, ''Texas one and indivisible,'' and a state tourism slogan beckons visitors, ''Texas -- It's Like a Whole Other Country.''

title: Shop Till They Drop? The Mall Hasn't Palled, Yet
description: From the very beginning, with independence from France in 1960, this country has been capitalism's most willing laboratory in a region of poor peasant societies and failed socialist experiments.

title: Moment of Realization: Home Has Disappeared
description: In every life there comes a moment of realization that what we assumed would always be there is actually vanishing. Our parents die, the houses we grew up in are sold, neighborhood landmarks disappear and sooner or later what we used to call home just isn't there anymore.

title: Switzerland and Banks Agree to a Fund for Holocaust Victims
description: After months of pressure from American Jewish groups, the Swiss Government, leading banks and businesses agreed today to establish a memorial fund for Holocaust victims in what a senior official called ''the humanitarian traditions of Switzerland.''

title: Insight Optical Goes To DeVito/Verdi
description: Insight Optical Manufacturing in Miami, which operates the For Eyes Optical retail chain, said yesterday that it had named DeVito/Verdi in New York to handle its account, which had been handled for three years by Tinsley Advertising in Miami. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $6 million. The decision came after a two-and-a-half-month review that had been narrowed to DeVito/Verdi and two other finalists, both in New York: Farago Advertising and Lord Group, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: What Will Prevent a Missile Attack?
description: Most Americans believe that the United States can protect itself from ballistic missile attacks. Yet the truth is that we are completely defenseless against limited nuclear attacks from rogue states like North Korea and Iraq and from accidental launches by any country with nuclear weapons.

title: Iraqi Exiles Say Hussein's Son May Be Paralyzed by Shooting
description: More than a month after he was shot in an attempted assassination in Baghdad, the eldest son of President Saddam Hussein still has not been pictured standing, and there are suggestions that he may have been wounded more seriously than first reported.

title: Restaurants
description: The first requirement of restaurant criticism is the ability to transcend personal taste. ''I don't like it'' is not a professional response, and after 20 years, I have no trouble judging food on its merits. I can easily assess dishes I wouldn't dream of ordering if I were not on the job. But ''I like it'' is not appropriate either, and that one is more difficult. After all these years, I still find it hard to control my enthusiasm when I come across food that is very much to my taste.

title: Bombing Defendant Pleads for Victims
description: Terry L. Nichols, a defendant in the Oklahoma City bombing case, asked the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit today to allow bombing victims and survivors of those who were killed, even those who will testify against him, to view his trial.

title: CONAGRA TO SETTLE CHARGES IT ADDED WEIGHT TO GRAIN
description: Conagra Inc. said yesterday that it was close to settling the Federal Government's charges that its Peavey Grain unit illegally sprayed water on stored grain to increase its weight and value. The United States Justice Department began investigating practices at Peavey Grain elevators around Terre Haute, Ind., and elsewhere five years ago. Conagra, a food processor, declined to detail the settlement until it was made final, which is expected to be ''within a week,'' a spokeswoman said. Analysts said Conagra was unlikely to be hurt by the penalty, which The Wall Street Journal reported would be less than $10 million. Shares of Conagra fell 75 cents yesterday, to $50.875.

title: Stuart Kaufman, 54, Expert On History of Labor in U.S.
description: Stuart B. Kaufman, a University of Maryland history professor who edited the papers of the labor leader Samuel Gompers and played an instrumental role in setting up the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s historical archives, died on Sunday at his home in Garrett Park, Md. He was 54.

title: Gingrich's Revenge
description: One thing above all led to the undoing of the Republican revolution that Newt Gingrich and his colleagues launched after their election victory in 1994. That was Mr. Gingrich's decision to shut down the Government at the end of 1995 as a way of waging the policy conflict with President Clinton.

title: Frenchman to Be Tried For Nazi War Crimes
description: France's highest court today ordered an ex-Government minister to trial on charges that during the German occupation of Bordeaux in World War II, he had knowingly deported more than 1,500 Jews to certain death in Nazi camps.

title: A Major Robbins Work, Both New and Familiar
description: THE freewheeling, cartwheeling approach to Bach that Jerome Robbins takes in his major new ballet, ''Brandenburg,'' looks both startling and right. Bach's good humor runs through his ever-popular six Brandenburg Concertos, and Mr. Robbins's latest work for the New York City Ballet to some of this music is festive and astonishing.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about various account reviews, omitted one of the seven agencies participating in a review for Autodesk Inc. It is the Van Bronkhorst Group in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: The Super Bowl predicts the market, and vice versa.
description: THE New England Patriots are distant underdogs to the Green Bay Packers in this Sunday's Super Bowl game, according to the bookies and the commentators in sports pages across the country. But they are favored by the stock market. And if that forecast comes true, the stock market could be in for trouble this year.

title: U.N. Chief, in Washington, Finds Climate Much Warmer
description: Kofi Annan, the new Secretary General of the United Nations, worked his way through the nation's capital today, meeting with President Clinton and Republicans in Congress on a tour that seemed part victory lap, part obligation and part campaign to persuade the United States to support the world organization by finally paying its dues.

title: Beyond Sweet and Light: Virtuoso of the Poignant
description: GIAMBATTISTA TIEPOLO, who died in 1770 at 74, was, of course, the peerless master of airborne views. His balletic multitudes do the loop-the-loop on vaulted ceilings, painted pink and baby blue like Venice skies. Who can't admire his almost implausible technical brilliance and beamy light? You get lightheaded craning your neck at his frescoes, though that is only what you'd expect from peering into heaven.

title: FLORIDA POWER TO BUY TIGER BAY POWER PLANT
description: Destec Energy Inc. said yesterday that Tiger Bay L.P. had agreed to sell a 220-megawatt power plant to Florida Power Corporation for $445 million. Destec, based in Houston, holds a 50 percent stake in Tiger Bay. Destec estimated that its share of the proceeds after repayment of debt and other obligations would be $140 million. Destec said the sale would include the plant, equipment, spare parts and assigned contracts, including natural gas supply and transportation contracts. The Tiger Bay plant, in Fort Meade, Fla., began operations in early 1995. The Florida Power Corporation is based in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: FCB/Leber Katz Changes its Name
description: FCB/Leber Katz Partners, the New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding, has changed its name to Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: The Spoken Word
description: KENNETH KOCH AND RON PADGETT, Posman Books, 1 University Place, at Waverly Place, Greenwich Village. Readings by the two poets. Sunday at 3 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 533-2665.

title: Shalom (and Salaam) as Tourist Lure
description: If the advertisements appearing in various American newspapers are anything to go by, the Israelis, the Palestinians and the Jordanians are as quick at marketing peace as they are slow to make it.

title: Time Running Out on Compensation Deal for Americans Held in Nazi Camps
description: In a little-known chapter of World War II history, thousands of American citizens stranded in Europe or taken as prisoners of war found themselves herded into Nazi concentration camps. Now, under a recent agreement with Germany, those who are still alive may be eligible for compensation. But time is running out for them to make their claims.

title: Report of South African AIDS 'Breakthrough' Angers Experts
description: An appearance by three South African scientists before the Presidential Cabinet to tout what they say is a breakthrough in AIDS treatment has angered AIDS researchers, who say subsequent articles suggesting a miracle cure has been found are irresponsible.

title: No Headline
description: ''I like my country and its traditions. But the Government and the economic situation often make it impossible to see why I should stay.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: New chefs have taken the helm at some of New York City's most revered restaurants, among them the Rainbow Room, Gage & Tollner and Windows on the World. Now Erik Blauberg, who was chef at his own American Renaissance, has taken on the ''21'' Club.

title: Patriots Prepare for the Long Ball
description: The customary cat-and-mouse game that takes place between offense and defense, receiver and defender, will be suspended on Sunday when Green Bay and New England face each other in Super Bowl XXXI.

title: INLAND STEEL INDUSTRIES TO DISMISS 450 WORKERS
description: Inland Steel Industries said yesterday that it was dismissing about 450 salaried workers, or 2.9 percent of its work force, after reporting lower fourth-quarter earnings. The steelmaker said fourth-quarter profit from operations fell 28 percent, to $17.9 million, or 32 cents a share, compared with net income of $24.9 million, or 47 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Inland, based in Chicago, took a charge of $17.1 million, or 35 cents a share, to dismiss the workers at its Inland Steel Company unit, resulting in net income of $777,000, or a per-share loss of 3 cents. Shares of Inland Steel Industries fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $19.125.

title: Fassel Assembling Staff
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel is beginning to put together his staff, and yesterday he hired the former Cardinals running back coach Jim Skipper as his offensive coordinator.

title: A Bill to Open Welfare Files
description: Shortly before his 2-year-old granddaughter was beaten to death Jan. 4, Cleaveland Ross warned the state agency in charge of the girl's welfare that she was in danger and demanded to know what was being done to protect her. But the agency, the Division of Youth and Family Services, told Mr. Ross that its records were confidential. And though Mr. Ross said the girl, Amara Wilkerson, had been burned and was losing weight, case workers who visited her mother and her mother's boyfriend saw no reason to take her from her home in New Brunswick. The boyfriend is now charged with killing her.

title: Focus on Dual Office Holding
description: When Jack G. Sinagra ran for State Senate in 1991, while he was Mayor of East Brunswick, he promised to step down as Mayor if elected because, he said, ''I knew it was impossible to do both jobs.'' Mr. Sinagra, a Republican, introduced a bill to make it illegal to hold two elective offices, and yesterday a Senate committee approved it.

title: Is Murder Justified?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sega to Acquire Bandai, Creating Toy-Video Giant
description: Sega Enterprises, the Japanese video game maker, said today that it would buy the Bandai Company Ltd., the Japanese toy company famous for the Power Rangers, in a stock swap valued around $1 billion, creating the world's biggest toy and video-game company.

title: Money Doris Duke Meant for Charity Is Making a Lot of Other People Rich
description: This was Doris Duke's predicament. She was worth $1.2 billion, but had no relatives or friends she particularly cared to enrich so massively when she died. Instead, she decided with immodesty befitting one of the world's richest women that her estate would go toward ''the improvement of humanity,'' as her will said. Her money would allow dancers to dance, artists to paint, doctors to cure diseases, animals to escape the cruelty of people.

title: Russia's Frail President
description: Boris Yeltsin's weakened health has understandably preoccupied Russian politics for months, but a new surge of calls for his resignation as President is premature. Mr. Yeltsin may eventually prove unable to give his country strong and enduring leadership. But unless he suffers a sudden decline, it will be several months before a sound judgment about his fitness can be made.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES ACQUIRES TWO SECURITY COMPANIES
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had acquired two security-systems companies for $36 million in stock and assumed debt. Republic Industries, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is a diversified automotive, solid waste and electronic-security company. It acquired Acadiana Alarm Systems, based in Lafayette, La., and Commonwealth Security Systems, based in Lancaster, Pa. Together they have 40,000 accounts in 11 states. Shares of Republic Industries jumped $1.625 yesterday, to $42.75.

title: The Man Behind The Brain
description: What the splendid Irish actor Donal Donnelly serves up in ''My Astonishing Self,'' his one-man show about the life of George Bernard Shaw, is not exactly a Shavian feast. It's more like a tasting menu.

title: Securities Gains Help Lift Bankers Trust Net
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose 17 percent in the fourth quarter as the company's securities trading and derivatives businesses continued a long recovery from problems in 1995.

title: Congressmen Say President Will Push Campaign Reform
description: After meeting with President Clinton at the White House, the leading Congressional advocates of stricter campaign finance laws said today that they were convinced that he was committed to the cause and to building public pressure to persuade Congress to pass such legislation.

title: Spare. Sometimes Wry. Summerall.
description: Pat Summerall has built a sparkling reputation on restraint, knowing that verbosity is unwelcome if you merely describe what viewers can see for themselves. His first boss at CBS Sports, Bill MacPhail, told him in the early 1960's, ''I'll never criticize you for saying too little.''

title: Just Fill This Out, Coach
description: Even high-profile coaches have to fill out job applications.

title: In Victory, Sampras Pushes All the Right Buttons
description: Thomas Muster had his stealth weapon, a computer programmed to expose the kinks in Pete Sampras's arsenal, and his kinetic weapon, an extra-long racquet to give him extra power. But even backed by all the technology that money can buy, the Austrian could not finagle a method of preventing Sampras from reaching the final of the Australian Open.

title: Big Chinatown Restaurant Sued on Wages and Tips
description: The New York State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, filed suit yesterday against Jing Fong, Chinatown's largest restaurant, charging it with cheating 58 workers of more than $1.5 million in tips and wages.

title: Help George Appreciate What He Has
description: THE voices are angry on my answering machine. My theory is, they can't get through to America Online, that laughingstock of electronic bumbling, so they've got to vent somewhere.

title: New Bricks, Same Old Walls For Europe's Poor Nations
description: Svetlana Raykova should represent the hope for the future of this shattered country. As generations of her family have done before her, she would like to marry and settle down here.

title: Cadet in Rape Case Says Woman Climbed in His Bed
description: A male cadet charged with raping a female classmate took the witness stand at his court-martial here today and, in a steady voice, testified that his sexual encounter with the young woman occurred when she climbed into his bed and woke him from a sound sleep with her kisses.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Kansas City

title: Clothing Tax's End Inevitable, Pataki Says
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that it was inevitable that the sales tax on most clothing would be eliminated, his strongest statement yet on the subject.

title: Infants' Lung Bleeding Traced to Toxic Mold
description: Dr. Dorr G. Dearborn of the Rainbow Babies and Childrens Hospital here realized he faced a horrible mystery in November 1994 when he treated three babies in a single day with a rare ailment: their lungs were bleeding for no apparent reason. If one more case showed up, he decided, he would call Federal health investigators.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Set to Offer $1.2 Billion for Cable Maker
description: In its first takeover since amassing a new, $5.8 billion war chest, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company announced an agreement yesterday to buy control of the Amphenol Corporation, a leading maker of electronic cables and connectors, for roughly $1.2 billion in cash.

title: Police Officer Is Arrested
description: A Willingboro police officer who helped run a program to teach teen-agers about careers in law enforcement was arrested yesterday for sexually abusing two 13-year-old girls who took part in the program, called the Explorer Post. Burlington County prosecutors said the officer, David Barnes, 26, a five-year veteran, had consensual intercourse with one of the girls several times over six months until her father intercepted an E-mail message to her from Mr. Barnes and called police, who suspended Mr. Barnes without pay on Jan. 9.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Off Broadway, Too, Goes on the Move

title: Loving Animals and Not Just Eating Them
description: It would have been beastly to have to forgo the further antics of the ''Fish Called Wanda'' crew. Fortunately, this team returns in merrily good form with ''Fierce Creatures,'' a zoo story that sends up corporate profit-gouging and shows a fine, satirical appreciation for the real laws of the jungle.

title: Parcells Defends Bledsoe
description: Drew Bledsoe is a quarterback of limited experience, a player who is in the big game in only his fourth season. He has not had heady statistics in the playoffs this season: in games against Pittsburgh and Jacksonville, he was intercepted three times and threw for only one touchdown. His yards-per-passing-attempt number is low at 6. He has fumbled and he has forced some plays.

title: Wells's Friend in Fight Surrenders to the Police
description: The unidentified friend of David Wells who was involved in a street fight with the Yankee pitcher and two other men on Jan. 12 in Ocean Beach, Calif., surrendered to the San Diego police with his attorney yesterday and was arrested on charges of felony battery and filing a false report with the police.

title: Quiet Man With Big Charity Mission
description: On Wednesday, Harvey Philip Dale, a respected but not famous New York law professor, had lunch with two friends in midtown. It was the day before everyone learned that he has had a secret life that involved giving away hundreds of millions of dollars of someone else's money.

title: Bonds Fall Late in Day After Rally
description: Bond prices fell yesterday but stayed in a narrow trading range as the market absorbed a fresh supply of debt.

title: $25 and Under
description: The Red Light Bistro is aptly named. Being on the edge of the meat-packing district, it is in an area that seems to have more restaurants than people, except for prostitutes. The geography gives the two-month-old restaurant a sort of raffish charm, and sitting at the handsome, old-fashioned bar breeds fellowship.

title: India Rehabilitates Wartime Leader Who Fought for Japan
description: With elaborate ceremonies marking the 100th anniversary of his birth, India today officially rehabilitated an independence leader who left India in 1941 to travel to Berlin and Tokyo, and became leader of an Indian army that fought alongside Japanese forces in World War II.

title: Investigators in Montclair Focus on Murder-Suicide
description: The woman who was found shot to death alongside her three children in their home here on Wednesday had recently won a job promotion. Her oldest daughter had been elected ''secretary general'' at her elementary school, where the studies focus on United Nations themes. And just last week, the woman had volunteered to tutor students in a job-training program that had helped her get off welfare three years ago.

title: A Mythical Hemingway In a Blur of Muted Love
description: Richard Attenborough's film ''In Love and War'' laboriously adheres to the three rules that any period romance had better follow if it hopes to re-moisten hankies still damp from reruns of ''Summer of '42.''

title: Silicon Graphics Profit Lower than Expected
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., which makes high-powered computer work stations, yesterday reported lower-than-expected profit from operations because of production delays.

title: Kenneth Thimann, 92, Pioneer in Research on Plant Growth
description: Kenneth Vivian Thimann, a leading botanist whose discoveries advanced the basic understanding of plant life, died on Jan. 15 at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 92.

title: Keep Out The Noise! A Refrain At Phoenix
description: The leader needed hiking boots, the runner-up needed nasal spray and Tiger Woods needed earplugs. The PGA Tour is visiting its annual zoo, the Tournament Players Club of Scottsdale, where no noise is good noise. They are building condominiums near the second fairway, they should be building a subway between the driving range and the first tee and, if nothing else, they should build a moat around Woods.

title: First, His Own Burger; Can a Title Be Far Off?
description: Gilbert Brown, King of the hamburger.

title: King Papers Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Give Miller a Hand? Not in This Rivalry
description: Reggie Miller compares the Knicks-Indiana Pacers rivalry to the Hatfields vs. the McCoys.

title: Pilar Barbosa, 99, Puerto Rican Political Mentor, Dies
description: Pilar Barbosa de Rosario, a revered Puerto Rican historian and political authority who served as teacher, mentor and mother confessor to generations of Puerto Rican politicians, scholars and intellectuals, died on Wednesday at a hospital near her home in San Juan. She was 99 and widely regarded as the conscience of the ruling New Progressive Party.

title: F.B.I. Agent Runs a Brooklyn Club to Snare a Mafia Outfit
description: From the outside, the Portofino Soccer Club in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn was just another nondescript social club. But inside, the authorities say, it was the rendezvous for a select gathering of men who arranged million-dollar business deals for products like dresses from Donna Karan and Liz Claiborne, exercise machines, computers, video-cassette recorders, television sets, cigarettes and featherbeds.

title: Cleaning Up Commerce
description: William Daley, President Clinton's nominee for Commerce Secretary, promised at his confirmation hearing to take politics out of the most politicized department in the Government. It was a necessary pledge that may not go far enough.

title: What a Difference a Boy Makes
description: A charming Czech roue named Frantisek Louka (Zdenek Sverak) leads a life of quiet dissipation. His favorite pursuits are musicianship, skirt-chasing and looking after his elderly mother, not necessarily in that order. Louka's mother is very vocal in her political opinions. The year is 1988, and she thinks the Russian troops occupying her country are locusts.

title: MATCHUP: SUPER BOWL XXXI
description: Key stats: The Packers have the No. 1 scoring offense and the No. 1 scoring defense in the N.F.L. In the last two playoff games the Patriots defense held Pittsburgh's Jerome Bettis and Jacksonville's Natrone Means to 43 yards each.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Postman (Il Postino)

title: China's Leader For Hong Kong Backs Repeal Of Rights Laws
description: In the face of international and local criticism over China's intention to roll back laws protecting a range of civil rights in Hong Kong, the man who will rule the territory under Chinese sovereignty has declared his support for repeal of the laws.

title: U.S. Beer Shipments Show Surprise Gain
description: The American beer market grew unexpectedly last year for its first gain since 1990, according to a new estimate.

title: Don't Restrict Auto Insurance Lawsuits
description: To the Editor:

title: Worst Freeze In Years Ruins Florida Crops
description: A freeze last weekend, the worst here in seven years, caused $93 million in damage to winter vegetable and tropical fruit crops in Dade County, officials said today, and losses for all crops could total $250 million statewide. The damage could lead to sharply higher prices across the nation.

title: People
description: * G. Steven Dapper, president and chief executive at Rapp Collins Worldwide, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group, was promoted to chairman, a vacant position. Edward R. McNally Jr., chief operating officer, was promoted to succeed Mr. Dapper as president.

title: Chaney Bristles in Victory
description: John Chaney began loosening his tie early. With each missed shot, each turnover, he loosened it a bit more, until it was nearly hanging at his knees.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York., the bank holding company, said it had received approval from the Comptroller of the Currency to establish an operating subsidiary to reinsure mortgage insurance on loans originated by Chase Manhattan Bank and its lending affiliates.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GERARD DEPARDIEU, the French actor, likes to shop when he travels. This week, he visited Bucharest with his friend ILIE NASTASE, the former tennis star.

title: A Portrait Of a Brief, Intense Life
description: At the start of Steve James's troubled ''Prefontaine,'' there's a stunning miscalculation. Mr. James, so highly esteemed for the insightful honesty of the documentary ''Hoop Dreams'' (which he made with Peter Gilbert), creates bogus documentary interviews to help define his new film's hero.

title: Winning Wasn't Everything
description: My team, the Green Bay Packers, won the first Super Bowl 30 years ago because of one man, our coach, Vince Lombardi. He molded us from losers into winners -- and into men as well. Most of my teammates have enjoyed great success since they stopped playing football. This, too, is because of Lombardi -- the principles he urged on us, the dreams he stirred in us.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Chechen Voters' Key Concerns: Order and Stability
description: The war is over, and now the battle for control over the secessionist republic of Chechnya is being waged on the airwaves.

title: Ex-Head of H.U.D. Is Joining Univision
description: Univision Communications Inc. said yesterday that Henry G. Cisneros, the departing Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, would become the company's president and chief operating officer. The company said that A. Jerrold Perenchio would remain as chairman and chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a Federal judge's acquittal of two anti-abortion demonstrators, who were accused of violating his order not to block access to an abortion clinic, referred incorrectly to jury decisions in the first two trials in the murder of Medgar Evers. Those trials -- cited as examples of a legal principle under which jurors protest laws by voting to acquit defendants -- ended with deadlocked juries, not acquittals.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Selections Winter '97'

title: Sauntering Improvisations Within a Relaxed Context
description: The poetic in jazz is sometimes separated from the prosaic by the simplest of ideas. At the saxophonist Chris Potter's first set on Wednesday at Visiones, where he will be through tomorrow, most of his original compositions did the right thing with a well-set tempo, or a bass line or concept. They worked. One or two conventional pieces stuck to common jazz practice, powered by the watery rhythms jazz musicians often describe as Latin. They didn't work.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans to build a new yacht for the British royal family referred incorrectly to an earlier product of the Scottish yard that is to build it. The old ship was the Queen Elizabeth, named for the current Queen Mother -- not the Elizabeth I, after the 16th-century Queen.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about indictments of officials and lawyers of the Transit Police Benevolent Association in New York City misstated the charges against two lawyers, Barry Agulnick and William Gogel. They were charged with conspiracy to defraud the Internal Revenue Service, not racketeering.

title: Trivial Concerns Writ Very Large
description: DO THE WINDOWS OPEN?

title: How Many Borough President Candidates? Probably 5
description: Five Democrats eager to succeed Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan turned the steps of City Hall into a makeshift convention hall yesterday as one officially entered the race, two reiterated their intentions to run and two others stayed on the periphery of their opponents' news conferences.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARTIN BARON, the research editor and the former head of the fact-checking department at The New Yorker, is not perfect at his job, he admits, but 20 of his colleagues and friends tossed him a surprise 60th birthday party Wednesday night anyway.

title: INSIDE
description: A Swiss Holocaust Fund

title: A multimillion-dollar Super Bowl party will have familiar guests.
description: STEVE YOUNG, Jim Kelly, John Elway, Troy Aikman and other familiar Super Bowl faces will be missing Sunday when the Green Bay Packers play the New England Patriots. As if to compensate for that paucity of star power, the advertisers peddling products during Super Bowl XXXI will crowd their commercials with enough celebrities to populate three ''Love Boat'' reunions, two Friars Club roasts and a remake of ''Airport'' or ''Grand Hotel.''

title: Arrests in Abortion Protest
description: Five days after a group of anti-abortion activists were arrested for trespassing in an abortion clinic in Englewood, four more were arrested at the same clinic yesterday, Englewood police said. Six of the 15 protesters arrested on Saturday were still in the Bergen County jail, where they were not formally accused because they would not give their names. The clinic, Metropolitan Medical Associates, attracted national attention last September after it was reported that it had performed 1,500 late-term abortions each year. In Trenton yesterday, a bill to ban the procedures was approved by the Assembly Health Committee.

title: Inside Photography
description: Using her own 11-by-14-inch color photographs as her canvas, Teresa Caselle Hack transforms them with broad strokes of acrylic. Sometimes she covers so much of the photographs with paint that the finished works resemble paintings; sometimes, she applies just a few daubs.

title: Gains at Boeing Are Short of Expectations
description: The Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which Boeing agreed to acquire last month, reported strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, but the results fell slightly short of Wall Street analysts' estimates.

title: United Technologies Earnings Are Up 23%
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that its earnings increased 23 percent in the fourth quarter, driven by higher profit at its Pratt & Whitney aircraft-engine unit and at its automotive units.

title: Man Is Accused Of Killing Mother
description: A 47-year-old administrative associate at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem was bludgeoned to death in her home on Wednesday, and the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday that it was charging her 28-year-old son with murder.

title: Tatum Request Troubles Fund
description: In a move that may foreshadow things to come for the National Football League Players Association, the former Oakland Raiders safety Jack Tatum has applied for benefits of at least $156,000 a year from the N.F.L. pension fund, citing mental anguish from his hit that paralyzed Darryl Stingley two decades ago.

title: U.S. Revives Art Theft Case
description: The Quedlinburg art theft case, seemingly a dead issue in October after being dismissed by a Federal judge in Texas, has come back to life with a recommendation by the Department of Justice that the decision be appealed.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Growing, Christie's Plans a Move To a Space in Rockefeller Center
description: Christie's, the expanding grande dame of the auction world, is negotiating a consolidation of its warehouses, offices and auction space in a new home at Rockefeller Center.

title: Accounts
description: * Samsung Electronics Europe, London, to various offices of Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, to handle its pan-European account, previously handled by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, London, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: COURT GRANTS BARNEY'S EXTENSION FOR REORGANIZATION
description: Barney's Inc. won court approval yesterday to extend until May 5 its exclusive right to file a bankruptcy reorganization plan. The New York retailer, which originally sought approval to extend exclusivity to June 3, revised the deadline at the request of its creditors, including its Japanese partner, the Isetan Company. Without the extension -- Barney's fourth since it entered Chapter 11 protection in January 1996 -- the company would have had to file a plan by Feb. 3. Barney's, which operates 13 upscale department stores, said it needed more time to conclude ''sensitive negotiations'' with Dickson Concepts International Ltd. of Hong Kong and two other potential investors.

title: 2 Democratic Lawmakers Urge Limit on 'Soft Money'
description: Two Democratic lawmakers proposed legislation today to restrict so-called soft money donations to New York State lawmakers -- the same sort of contributions that have brought a barrage of criticism on the national Democratic Party.

title: Shares of Xerox Turn Upward On Better-Than-Expected Profit
description: The stock of the Xerox Corporation climbed yesterday after the company reported better-than-expected earnings and said it had agreed to sell several parts of its Talegen Holdings subsidiary.

title: Art in Review
description: David Mann

title: Bias Intensified By Inertia
description: Jesse Finch was pumped. He and his wife were planning to adopt a baby. Eager to share the good news, he told his supervisor, a man named Wayne Lessig.

title: Rug Pulled From Stocks In Last Hour
description: The stock market dropped sharply in a sudden late-afternoon selloff yesterday, ruining what looked to be another record performance. The fall came on the busiest day of trading in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: For Children
description: 'Something's Come Over Rapunzel'

title: Turning Allowance Into Help for Others
description: ''Hi. I am Sarah. I'm 6 years old. I get allowance.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Texas Instruments Stock Rises on Plan to Sell Unit

title: Sony Is Planning to Create A New York Headquarters
description: The Sony Corporation plans to make New York City into a second headquarters to better supervise its sometimes troubled American operations and keep track of fast-changing American media and technology trends, company executives said today.

title: Small Water Line Break Makes Torrent of Trouble
description: A small water-main break in Brooklyn yesterday had the ripple effect of disrupting subway service all the way into Manhattan yesterday, as transit officials shut down parts of two lines for nine hours, fearing that two brownstones might collapse.

title: Plea in Teacher's Death
description: The teen-ager accused of killing a Tinton Falls teacher who secretly tape-recorded the last hour of her life pleaded guilty to murder yesterday, The Associated Press reported. The youth, Michael LaSane, 17, of Berkeley Township, faces a life sentence because he waived his right to be tried as a juvenile last week.

title: Court Says 2 Pataki Aides Can Be Forced to Testify
description: A New York State appellate court ruled today that the Democratic-controlled Assembly can compel two advisers to Gov. George E. Pataki to testify about the activities of two private corporations that raised more than $2.6 million for the Governor's inauguration and transition in 1995.

title: McDonald's Posts a Gain of 12% in Profits
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose 12 percent in the fourth quarter as its expansion offset declining sales at existing restaurants.

title: Giving More Weight To Lightness
description: It sometimes seems that the French are going to end up like some indigenous tribe studied by future cultural anthropologists for their odd dress. Today's French resistance is against revolutions in fashion occurring elsewhere, made more glaring this season by John Galliano's updating of the greatest French standard of them all, Christian Dior.

title: A Corporate Wife Holds Out for a 50-50 Split of Assets
description: He works at full throttle. She raises the children and creates the elegant home. She plays hostess at business dinner parties, orchestrates charity events, relocates on command, accompanies him on trips and listens to his office woes. She is the corporate wife, and her career, she believes, is managing her husband's career.

title: Art in Review
description: Michael Joo

title: Spring, That Tease, Drops By, but Only for a Day
description: Winter still has eight weeks to go, but spring slipped in early yesterday to remind people of its virtues, and for a few hours, its rites were evident everywhere in the region.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 26 about the return of a member of the Korean royal family from exile in Japan misstated his title. The Korean, Yi Koo, is the son of Crown Prince Yi Eun, who died in 1970. But Yi Koo did not inherit the title; the Yi dynasty ended in 1910 when Korea was formally annexed by Japan. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Confederate Flag Divides G.O.P. in South Carolina
description: The South Carolina House of Representatives dealt a debilitating blow today to Gov. David Beasley's proposal to remove the Confederate battle flag from atop the dome of the Capitol.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Feminism and Inclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Beauty Pageants Foster Sexual Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Dishonest 'Bell Curve'
description: To the Editor:

title: Davy Jones Seriously Hurt In Wreck During Practice
description: Davy Jones, the runner-up in last year's Indianapolis 500 and a co-driver of the winning car in last year's 24-Hour race in Le Mans, France, suffered a serious head injury yesterday in a crash during practice at Walt Disney World Speedway in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

title: Japan's Economic Report Card: Where Did the A's and B's Go?
description: Many Japanese used to think that the next century would be the Japanese century. But after years of unremitting economic struggles and a convulsing stock market, that now sounds like a bitter joke to people like Yukiko Shinya.

title: Texas Instruments to Sell a Computer Unit
description: Texas Instruments today reported a loss for the fourth quarter, but immediately dressed it up by announcing a deal to sell its money-losing notebook computer business to the Acer Group of Taiwan.

title: Once More, The Nets Turn It On Too Late
description: They are the kind of people who would wear one pair of dirty jeans too long before doing laundry, the kind who would get around to renewing their license after the expiration date.

title: In Green Bay, the Ghosts Are Friendly Ones
description: FOR these Packers, the ghosts won't go away. The ghosts of Vince Lombardi's teams that won the first two Super Bowl games, the ghosts of nearly a dozen of Lombardi's players now in the Pro Football Hall of Fame, the ghosts who earned all those green-and-gold championship banners hanging in their Lambeau Field complex.

title: As Slade and McGinest Go, So Go the Patriots' Chances
description: One comes from the East Coast, the other from the West Coast. One lines up on the left side of the New England Patriots' defense, the other on the right side. One uses speed, the other strength.

title: Milbury Holds On to 2 Titles
description: Mike Milbury is still the only man in the National Hockey League to hold the dual titles of coach and general manager.

title: Final Bursts Of Joyful Energy
description: OVER the last several months, the Museum of Modern Art has brought off an impressive trilogy of painting exhibitions. Starting in the spring with Picasso's portraiture, followed immediately by an exhaustive Jasper Johns retrospective, it has now reached the final installment: a sometimes dazzling, sometimes disturbing exhibition of late works by the great Abstract Expressionist painter Willem de Kooning. In all, it has been an amazing run, a highly compressed, often moving argument for modern painting as one of the most profound of human achievements.

title: The Last Train From Oakland
description: The Oakland, Calif., school board deserved the scorn that greeted its December edict declaring broken, inner-city English a distinct, ''genetically based'' language system that merited a place in the classroom. The policy is intended to build self-esteem for failing students by introducing street language as a teaching tool. In theory, teachers would use street talk as a ''bridge'' to help children master standard English. But as practiced elsewhere, so-called ''ebonics'' instruction is based on the premise that street English is as good as or better than the standard tongue. This means that students could use urban slang in their schoolwork.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-11

title: Affirmative Action's Grateful Alumni
description: ''Shattering the Silences'' presents seven college teachers -- two black, three Hispanic, an Indian and an Asian-American -- testifying to the worth of affirmative action and multiculturalism in academe. They make an attractive group as they tell of the hard work that earned them their jobs and the goals that continue to motivate them. The program's point is that their presence on such campuses as New York University, the University of California at Berkeley and Rutgers University has brought new insights to scholarship and new models for minority students.

title: TEXACO GETS TENTATIVE APPROVAL FOR BIAS SETTLEMENT
description: Texaco Inc. received tentative court approval yesterday for its $176 million settlement of a race-discrimination suit by 1,342 black workers and former employees. Judge Charles Brieant of Federal District Court in White Plains also scheduled a fairness hearing for March 18 to decide whether he should give final court approval. Separately, Texaco, in reporting its fourth-quarter results, said its profit fell slightly short of analysts' expectations but only because of currency fluctuations. Texaco reported income, without special charges, of $380 million, or $1.41 a share, up from $367 million, or $1.35 a share, a year earlier. Analysts polled by I.B.E.S. International expected earnings of $1.54 a share. Texaco stock rose $1.375 yesterday, to $108.375.

title: Strong Clothing Sales Spur Rise In 4th-Quarter Earnings at Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that earnings surged 25 percent in the fourth quarter, led by strong sales of clothing and other goods and an increase in credit card revenue.

title: Not a Fugitive Financier
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life's Work in Word and Image, Secret Until Death
description: THE term ''outsider art,'' with its radical-chic ring, has been much in the air in the last few years. Often used as a spicy alternative to ''folk art'' or ''self-taught art,'' it is essentially a marketing peg but one that sometimes hits the mark.

title: Madly In Love And Mad
description: Heartbreakingly good and filled with a desperate intensity, ''Angel Baby'' offers a breakthrough role to John Lynch, the Irish actor more familiar for his character roles. Not since ''Cal'' has the tender, mournful Mr. Lynch had a comparable chance to shine. As written and directed with great depth of feeling by Michael Rymer, this wild, doomy love story casts Mr. Lynch and Jacqueline McKenzie as two mentally fragile people caught up in a whirlwind courtship that is as perilous as it is intoxicating. The film won a number of well-deserved awards in Australia in 1995.

title: Suicide by a Mental Patient
description: A 72-year-old patient at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital hanged himself on Wednesday, becoming the troubled state-run hospital's third suicide in less than a year. Officials said Vladimir Korotkin, who was committed to Greystone in 1984 after shooting his boss, used a nylon rope that he had cut from an extension ladder he used to paint the institution's firehouse. The day before, he had been cleared by a staff psychiatrist for a weekend pass, said John McKeegan, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services, which runs the hospital.

title: Art in Review
description: The Outsider Art Fair

title: Hardly Child's Play: Shoving Toys Into Darkest Corners
description: IT'S the ultimate boyhood fantasy: the toy soldiers come to life, and so do the cowboys and Indians. And you know those tiny sex dolls from Japan, the ones with their hands strapped behind their backs and their legs spread? They come to life, too. And the Hitler doll is doing a ''Sieg heil!'' It's just too thrilling for words. It must be captured on film. Wait. It already has been.

title: Russian Phone Company Stock Hits Record High
description: Shares in RAO Rostelecom, Russia's dominant phone company, reached a record high yesterday after the Government announced that it would almost double the number of shares in its parent company to be sold off. Rostelecom shares jumped 15 cents, or 5 percent, to $3.18 after the Government said it would sell 24 percent of RAO Svyazinvest, the telecommunications holding company, to domestic investors in addition to the 25 percent stake already offered to foreign portfolio investors.

title: New York Police, Seeking Raises, Assail Mayor They Once Backed
description: In a choreographed expression of scorn for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, police officers by the scores marched outside every station house in the city yesterday afternoon in orderly though occasionally raucous protests against the Mayor's final proposal to improve their pay.

title: New Yorker Buys Cartoons
description: Until now, The New Yorker simply sold reprints of its cartoons to those who asked for them; anyone seeking unpublished cartoons had to find their way to the Cartoon Bank, a digitized archive of sketches that did not make it into the magazine.

title: Cathay Pacific Orders 3 New Airbus Planes
description: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd., Hong Kong's biggest airline, ordered three new wide-body planes from Airbus Industrie worth about $380 million. Cathay ordered two A340-300's and one A330-300 from the European plane-manufacturing consortium to fly long-haul routes, a company statement said yesterday.

title: Story of Russian Teen-Ager Is Begging for Script Writer
description: ''So who wants to buy from me the story?'' asked the venerable Russian skating coach, Tamara Moskvina, a smile playing across her lips.

title: PLACER DOME EXTENDS ITS OFFER FOR HIGHLANDS GOLD
description: Placer Dome Inc. said yesterday that it had extended its takeover offer for Highlands Gold Ltd. to Feb. 8 from Jan. 25. Placer Dome, a mining company, is offering 75 cents (Australian) a share for each share in Highlands Gold. The bid values all of Highlands at about $423 million (Australian), or $328.7 million (United States).

title: Home Video
description: Directors Honor History

title: 'Hot Spots' for American Endangered Species Cover Surprisingly Little Land
description: Populations of most endangered species live in a relatively few critical ''hot spots'' covering a surprisingly minuscule portion of the United States, scientists have found in the first county-by-county analysis of the species' distribution.

title: Security Framework
description: To the Editor:

title: MAMMOGRAM TALKS PROVE INDEFINITE
description: In a unanimous decision, a panel of experts convened by the National Institutes of Health concluded today that it could not recommend that all women in their 40's have mammograms.

title: Parcells May Wait For Parade To Pass By
description: If the Patriots win Super Bowl XXXI on Sunday, there will be a victory parade in Boston next Wednesday, and that could delay for a few days the anticipated departure of Coach Bill Parcells and his likely decision to go to the Jets.

title: Restaurants and TV
description: Today's restaurant pages are A22 and A23. The television pages are B15 and B16.

title: The Gracious G.O.P.
description: The Republican leadership in Washington has developed a gracious practice of helping Democrats escape from political crises, messes and stupidities. They simply divert public anger from their opponents, by creating matching crises, messes and stupidities of their very own.

title: Let Us Remember All Blacks Who Served
description: To the Editor:

title: Players Rate the Stadiums
description: The N.F.L. Players Association has announced the results of a player survey of the best and worst stadiums. According to more than 1,000 players, the five best stadiums (all grass fields) belong to Tampa Bay, Miami, Jacksonville, Arizona and Kansas City. The five worst (all artificial turf) belong to Philadelphia, Cincinnati, Houston, Pittsburgh and the Giants. MIKE FREEMAN

title: Simpson Jury Is Told That Shoe Evidence Is Fake
description: Continuing their summation today, the defense in the O. J. Simpson wrongful-death suit finally confronted one of the few pieces of evidence to arise in the four-month-long civil case but not in the earlier criminal case: 30 separate photographs of Mr. Simpson wearing a type of shoe he earlier had said he never owned.

title: Pepsico to Spin Off Its Fast-Food Business
description: Pepsico Inc. announced yesterday that it would spin off its KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell restaurant businesses as a publicly traded company, one that would be second only to McDonald's in the fast food market.

title: Agitator Tied Directly to Crown Hts. Attack
description: A witness in the trial of two men accused in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew in Crown Heights testified yesterday that the same man who incited an angry black crowd at the scene of an auto accident also directed the attack on the victim at short time later.

title: Art in Review
description: Walter Rosenblum

title: Allied Domecq to Sell Restaurants to Morland
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sell its Exchange Bar restaurants to Morland P.L.C., a British brewer and pub operator, for $:32 million ($52.3 million).

title: Some Packers Say They Plan to Pray Publicly
description: If they are victorious in Super Bowl XXXI and the opportunity presents itself during the live presentation of the Lombardi Trophy following the game at the Super Dome, some members of the Packers say they will deliver a religious message to the stadium crowd or say a prayer.

title: Peru's Police Yield as Red Cross Draws a Line in Hostage Crisis
description: Bowing to pressure from the International Committee of the Red Cross, Peruvian security forces agreed today to restrict their maneuvers outside the Japanese Ambassador's residence here while aid workers are providing services to the 73 hostages being held by Marxist guerrillas inside.

title: TRANSCANADA TO GET TWO BUSINESSES FROM ENRON
description: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy two gas liquids businesses from the Enron Corporation for $210 million (Canadian), or $150 million (United States). TransCanada said it would buy the Enron Louisiana Energy Company, which has five plants in Louisiana that process ethane, butane and propane from natural gas, as well as two pipelines and a storage site. TransCanada said the acquisition would increase its gas liquids production about 42 percent. TransCanada also plans to buy Enron's wholesale propane marketing business, which is supplied mainly by Enron Louisiana. Enron shares fell 50 cents yesterday, to $43.

title: Metro Business
description: The Times this week introduces Metro Business. Appearing in this section Tuesday through Friday, it will offer news and features on local business, from real estate and retailing to Wall Street and the economy.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Pompatus of Love

title: The Devils' Dunham Battles Idle Hands
description: Try as the Devils and Mike Dunham may to downplay the backup goalie's season on a string, there must be at least some effect to having your playing time increase, oh, about 110-fold from one night to the next.

title: Thriller in an Icily Futuristic Tokyo
description: There's a moment of excruciating claustrophobia early in the Japanese thriller ''Angel Dust,'' when Setsuko (Kaho Minami), a criminal psychologist, is led quaking with fear through volcanic caves inside Mount Fuji by her husband, Tomoo (Etshushi Toyokawa). At the very moment she stumbles upon a decomposed body, her husband suddenly disappears.

title: Minimalism as an 18th-Century Idea
description: Jonathan Sheffer is a musician with a mission, or rather with several missions. Speaking on Tuesday night at a symposium he had organized at the Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea, he defended with quiet intensity the essentialness of concerts, for immediacy of contact between public and performers, and unpredictability of content. He also wants his concerts to make a point.

title: Ex-Hostages Could Help Peru Captives
description: FAR from New York City, the hostage crisis in Peru struggled yesterday through yet another day, its 37th. Then again, for some New Yorkers it is not far away at all. For starters, hanging in the balance is the fate of a young woman from Manhattan, Lori Helene Berenson. She is serving a life sentence in a notoriously harsh Peruvian prison because of her ties to the Tupac Amaru rebels holding 73 people captive at the Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima.

title: Bail Is Set at $250,000 Each For 2 in Cosby Extortion Case
description: A Federal magistrate in Manhattan set bail at $250,000 each for a woman and a man who are accused of trying to extort $40 million from Bill Cosby by claiming that she is his out-of-wedlock daughter.

title: Who's Smirking Now? It's Mason, the Hornet
description: Anthony Mason has already silenced his critics. It will be much more difficult for Larry Johnson and the Knicks to silence theirs.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday about a proposed acquisition by the Medicis Pharmaceutical Corporation misstated its headquarters location. It is Phoenix, not New York.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO ADD SEMPELL VALVE GROUP
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy Sempell Valve Group from Deutsche Babcock A.G. to expand its industrial valve service business. Sempell, which has annual revenues of $130 million, makes and services specialty valves like high-pressure shut-off and safety relief valves used in industry and power generation. Tyco's revenue grew from $3.07 billion in 1992 to $5.09 billion in 1995. The company makes specialty valves, disposable medical bandages, fire and burglar alarm systems and sprinkler systems. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Tyco shares rose 50 cents to close at $56.75.

title: The Dark Rage of Jews Puts on a Happy Face
description: Long before Frankenstein's monster lumbered into the world's nightmares, there was the golem: a homicidal creature made of clay who emerged from ancient Jewish folklore and has haunted Jewish literature ever since.

title: Chemical Weapons Pact Still Raises Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: Interspecies (Surf and Turf) Friends
description: Let's take a meeting.

title: Aerialist Was 'Like Family'
description: Laura Patterson, the 43-year-old woman who died Thursday in New Orleans while practicing a bungee-jumping act for the Super Bowl halftime show, grew up under the big top as the daughter of circus performers. Known as Dinky because of her small size, she worked as an aerialist for Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus.

title: At 95, Saxophonist Wonders 'What If' About Ellington
description: ''Sometimes it's hard to get people to believe the truth,'' the saxophonist Benny Waters said recently during a master class at the Manhattan School of Music. Then Mr. Waters -- who turned 95 on Thursday and is playing a three-night stand (through tonight) at Birdland to celebrate it -- floated a revisionist theory. He contended that if the band he was playing with in 1927, led by the pianist Charlie Johnson, had accepted the offer of an underpaid long-term engagement at the Cotton Club instead of letting Duke Ellington's Washingtonians take it, perhaps Ellington and Johnson would have had entirely different career trajectories.

title: New York Warning to America Online
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco threatened today to sue America Online, the nation's largest on-line service, if the company did not relieve the congestion that has produced busy signals for members when they try to dial into the service.

title: Science Fair Is On
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, BERTHA S.
description: NEWHOUSE-Bertha S. Died on January 23 in New York City at the age of 78. Beloved wife of Roy for over 53 years. Loving mother of Martin and Lina Wood. Devoted grandmother of Katherine, Philip, Samuel, Emma and Rebecca. Born in Mt. Vernon, New York, she lived most of her life in New York City, where she was educated and where her children were raised. She graduated from Morris High School in the Bronx, received her B.A. from Hunter College and an MS from the School of Business, Columbia University. In addition to caring for her family, she was the first woman accountant to do field work for the firm of S.D. Leidesdorf Co. and the first woman CPA in the department of Accountancy at Baruch College, CUNY, where she taught for many years and, at her retirement, was Associate Dean and Professor of Accountancy in the School of Business and Public Administration. As an officer of the Gustave Hartman YM/YWHA in Far Rockaway, she helped formulate an ongoing drug abuse discussion program. She was also founder and president of the Atlantic Shore Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, setting up the first recreation center for senior citizens in the area. In 1984, she was named as a distinguished alumna to the Hunter College Hall of Fame by the Alumni Association of Hunter College. A voracious reader, a devotee of The New York Times cross word puzzle, a woman of inspired conversation, a deeply caring friend, and a person who never lost her passionate love for the cultural life of this city, her death leaves a void that can never be filled. Funeral services will be at 10:45 a.m. on Sunday, January 26 at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., followed by burial at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York. Thereafter, her family will be at 140 Nassau Street, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, MORRIS
description: SANDERS-Morris, 86, of Palm Beach, Florida, on January 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Toby, loving father of Carole and Jack Berger and Arthur and Dorothy Sanders. Grandfather of Jody (Bruce) Wenig, Jamie (Gary) Katz, Gerald (Brenda) Sanders and Holly Sanders. Great grandfather of Samantha, Cody, Eric, Dylann and Jacob. Services to be held Sunday, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon. Interment at Sharon Gardens.

title: Bridge
description: Italy, which dominated the world bridge scene from 1957 to 1975, is again a power to be reckoned with. Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace, European Team Champions in 1995, zoomed to a convincing victory yesterday in the Macallan International Pairs Championship in London. The event was a Simple System contest, with complex methods barred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGHIERI, MARIE. (NEE YANNERELLI)
description: BRAGHIERI-Marie. (nee Yannerelli). On January 23, 1997. Beloved wife of Martin. Loving mother of Cheryl King, Adele Brehler and Eileen Starace. Dear sister of Frances Rudzianis. Cherished grand mother of Alex, Maria, Christopher and Michael. Reposing at the Lloyd's Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave, Sat, 7-9 and Sun, 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian burial on Mon, 9:45AM, St. Robert Bellarmine Church. Interment to follow.

title: A Smorgasbord of Styles (Even Puccini's)
description: Douglas Moore's 1956 opera, ''The Ballad of Baby Doe,'' currently in a new production at the Washington Opera, jumbles styles in a quintessential American way.

title: Water Main Breaks, Swamping Chelsea
description: A water main laid down when Ulysses S. Grant was President and Boss Tweed was looting New York ruptured in Chelsea early yesterday. Cascading flood waters disrupted subway service for 200,000, snarled the choreography of midtown traffic, deprived hundreds of residents of water and steam heat and struck a blow to neighborhood business on the last day of tax-free shopping.

title: Azinger Is Among Leaders Again
description: His chemotherapy was three years ago, his back spasms were seven days ago and his last birdie was a minute ago. Paul Azinger has visited his mortality, not to mention last place in Houston, but he is now at an old residence: the leader board.

title: School That Never Sleeps Offers More Than Three R's
description: At 8 yesterday morning, 14-year-old Jason De la Cruz sat in the cafeteria at Intermediate School 218 in Washington Heights, eating a croissant with grape jelly, a banana and Cheerios, fueling up for another day of school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKIS, BERTHA
description: PERKIS-Bertha, on January 22, 1997. Mother of the late Donald Twerie. Survived by her grandchildren Hillary and Vincent Sofield, Andrew and Colleen Twerie and great-grandchildren, Vincent and Dylan Sofield. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. We love her and will miss her very much. Service information (718) 263-7600.

title: Show Me the Money
description: In recent weeks, Ted Turner has likened Rupert Murdoch to Hitler, Gloria Steinem has likened Larry Flynt to a Nazi and Richard John Neuhaus, the neoconservative theologian, has likened the United States to Nazi Germany. But when it comes to loose talk that trivializes both Nazism and the Holocaust, leave it to Hollywood to do so in the grand manner we expect from an industry that can dream up ''Evita.''

title: Superdome Death Stirs Questions on Risks of Shows
description: The death of a 43-year-old woman rehearsing a bungee jumping routine Thursday night at the Superdome for Sunday's Super Bowl halftime show raised questions here today about the extravagant and often risky entertainment productions that have become commonplace at large sporting events.

title: Knicks Rally But Falter In Overtime
description: The off-balance shot from behind the arc on the left baseline was not going in. The Knicks knew it as soon as Vlade Divac released it. To waltz out of the Charlotte Coliseum tonight with the wildest comeback victory in their 42 games, they needed to have someone, anyone on their team, grab that basketball.

title: DEATHS FROM AIDS DECLINE SHARPLY IN NEW YORK CITY
description: For the first time since the AIDS epidemic was recognized in 1981, deaths from the disease in New York City dropped sharply last year, declining by 30 percent, a City Health Department official said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page on Wednesday about a finding that a blood test can predict which patients are most likely to deteriorate in the first day or two after an ischemic stroke misstated the time during which a stroke victim should be treated with clot-dissolving drugs. It is within three hours of the onset of symptoms, not six.

title: Rehabilitate a Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: $70 Million in Cheeseheads
description: The Dallas Cowboys, America's most-marketed team, have been displaced this month by the Packers. The Cowboys usually account for 24 percent of all NFL Properties sales; the Packers make up 12 percent.

title: Explore Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Abandoned Children Found
description: With no electricity and nothing to eat but canned vegetables, 10 children lived alone for three weeks in an abandoned house just blocks from Atlantic City's casinos, authorities said yesterday. They cared for a baby, scurried to school each morning for a free breakfast and used a water bucket for a toilet. $(Page A1.$)

title: One Courtly, One Jazzy, Both Energetic
description: The New York City Ballet danced two jolly works by Jerome Robbins on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. The program included a repeat performance of ''Brandenburg,'' a new Robbins work, and ''Interplay,'' a 1945 ballet that has become a Robbins classic.

title: Shades of the Niners
description: Green Bay Coach Mike Holmgren has been to two Super Bowls as a 49er offensive assistant. He said this week's Packer practices were almost identical to the 49ers' in terms of intensity and structure.

title: Not Yet Ready for Talks With Israel, Syria Says
description: The American Ambassador to Israel has said that the Hebron agreement reached last week should be a ''springboard'' for new talks between Israel and Syria. The Israeli Foreign Minister has said he is ready to meet with his Syrian counterpart ''at any time, in any place.''

title: New Jersey Treasurer Plans To Sell State Disability Fund
description: The Whitman administration announced plans today to sell the State Disability Benefit Fund, which distributes about $325 million annually to New Jersey workers who are temporarily disabled as a result of sickness or injury unrelated to their jobs.

title: Clinton, Bush and Powell to Share Ideas About Volunteerism
description: In a ceremony suffused with the soft glow of bipartisanship -- and the electric crackle of what might have been -- President Clinton announced today that he, George Bush and the other living former Presidents would hold a three-day summit meeting on community service in Philadelphia this spring, to be headed by Gen. Colin L. Powell.

title: Glenn Walter Johnson Jr., 75; Invented Brace for Ankle Sprains
description: Glenn Walter Johnson Jr., an inventor who devised a pneumatic ankle brace that is now widely used in the treatment of ankle sprains, died on Thursday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 75 and lived in Summit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, GLADYS SHERR RITTER
description: LIVINGSTON-Gladys Sherr Ritter. With great sadness we record the passing of our beloved Gladys Livingston, a woman of style, humor and generosity. Mother of Toby and Nataly Ritter, Frances and Robert Weisman. Grandmother of Louis and Laurie, Ward and Loree and Adam Weisman; Louis, Victoria and Meridith Ritter. Great grandmother of the most precious Erin Rose. Aunt of David and Marie Ritter, Alan and Eileen Silverstein Ritter, Daniel Sherr, Irene and Leigh Breslau, Miriam and Gedaliah Wollosh. Stepmother to Peter and Ellen Livingston, Patricia and Richard Perlman. As the matriarch of our family, she has been a role model and an inspiration to many. She brought a joy and unity to her family that will endure as a living memorial. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., 10AM, Sunday, January 26, 1997. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: HEALTHDYNE REJECTS INVACARE'S TAKEOVER BID AS TOO LOW
description: Healthdyne Technologies Inc. said yesterday that its board had rejected an unsolicited takeover offer of $163 million, or $12.50 a share, from the Invacare Corporation, saying the bid was too low. Healthdyne said its directors were not interested in selling the company. The company also said its financial adviser, Cowen & Company, had called the share price of the offer ''grossly inadequate.'' In Nasdaq trading, shares of Healthdyne closed yesterday at $14, up 50 cents. Shares of Invacare rose 50 cents, to $27.75.

title: FARMERS GROUP SELLS UNITS TO GREAT SOUTHERN
description: Farmers Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Ohio State Life and Investors Guaranty Life units to the Great Southern Life Insurance Company for $330 million. The sale is part of Farmers Group's strategy of focusing on its Farmers New World Life Insurance Company, which sells property and casualty insurance through its own agents. Farmers Group is a unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. of Britain. Great Southern is a unit of closely held Americo Life Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, LOUIS
description: HIRSCH-Louis, on January 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Mildred and the late Selma; father of Howard and Jacqueline Hirsch, Henry and Jeanne Epstein, and Eleanor and Barry Krasner; grandfather of Steven and Brett. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

title: TV Judge Put Off the Air
description: Not long ago, Judge Evan W. Broadbelt, a municipal judge in five Monmouth County towns, had a flourishing side career as a guest analyst for Court TV and CNBC's ''Geraldo Live,''. But in October, the State Supreme Court ordered Judge Broadbelt off the air. Even though Judge Broadbelt never discussed his own cases and was not paid, the high court said he could compromise the integrity of the judiciary if he commented on other pending cases or used the prestige of his office to further others' private interests.

title: Red Cross Suspends Aid To Hostages Held in Lima
description: For the second time this week, the Red Cross suspended services today to hostages being held in the Japanese Ambassador's residence here after security forces crossed a boundary they had promised to respect.

title: Beliefs
description: There are two widespread impressions about the growth and decline of religious groups in this country, and both of them -- at least in their unqualified form -- are wrong.

title: MEREDITH TO BUY 4 TV STATIONS FROM FIRST MEDIA
description: The Meredith Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire four television stations from First Media Television L.P. for $435 million. Meredith would gain a CBS affiliate in Orlando, Fla., and affiliates of the Fox network in Portland and Bend, Ore., and Greenville, S.C. Meredith, which publishes magazines including Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies' Home Journal, already owns seven stations. The company said the acquisition would have a ''minimal impact'' on its earnings in the 1997 fiscal year and would raise cash flow during the first full year. The transaction would hurt earnings per share in the following two fiscal years, Meredith said. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Meredith fell $2, to $51.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, PHILIP
description: LOEB-Philip. On January 24, 1997. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of New York City. Dear husband of Ronnie Eisman Loeb. Beloved father of Carla (Leonard) Feinkind, Beryl (David) Hoffman and Anita (John Rafkin) Levin. Adored grandfather of seven. Dear brother of Jack Loeb. Funeral Sunday, January 26, at 10 A.M., Parkside Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Memorial service in Florida to be announced at a later date. Donations in his memory may be made to Florida Atlantic University Foundation, (Holocaust Research Collection), Attn: Dr. William Miller, POB 3092, Boca Raton, Florida 33431-0991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMEL, MAX
description: TEMEL-Max. Beloved husband of Hannah (Hanka). Devoted father of David and Cory, Charles and Judy, Sofia and Jay Maisler, and George Shana. Loving grandfather of Rachel, Brian, Aaron, Erika, Laura, Dan, Greg and Alex. Adored great-grandfather of Adam and Brandon. Funeral Service on Monday, at 10 A.M., ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: MARVEL'S CREDIT AGREEMENT WITH BANK IS APPROVED
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge approved Marvel Entertainment Group Inc.'s $100 million credit agreement with the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday after provisions that would set off a default were changed. Marvel's bondholders had opposed the original credit agreement. They said the agreement was an attempt to create a pretext under which Marvel could argue that challenges to Ronald O. Perelman's reorganization proposal would threaten vital financing. Marvel, a trading card and comic book company, filed for Chapter 11 protection on Dec. 27, proposing a reorganization plan that leaves Mr. Perelman in control. The plan would dilute the 18.84 percent stake in Marvel held by public shareholders to 3.63 percent and would dilute the bondholders' collateral to about 15 percent of the outstanding shares.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nasdaq Reports 3.4% Drop In Short Sales Outstanding
description: Uncovered short sales in Republic jumped sharply in June, when the company announced it would acquire Addington Resources, a landfill and waste-hauling company, for $350 million in stock.

title: Miami Official in Corruption Scandal Is Sentenced to 27 Months
description: Former City Commissioner Miller Dawkins, one of three top Miami officials charged last year in a Federal corruption investigation, was sentenced today to 27 months in prison after pleading guilty of bribery.

title: Gershwin's Musical Guide to Kindness in Love
description: Jazz's essential desire to transform, to avoid the literal, was on display on Thursday at Carnegie Hall. The hall's jazz program began its season with an evening of Gershwin, and if that suggests a night of wilted cabaret, it should. The program, as an idea, was tired at best. But the second half featured a singer, Nnenna Freelon, and Gil Evans's transcendent orchestral reworkings of ''Porgy and Bess,'' and two more different interpretive approaches couldn't be found. The material, used in radically opposed ways for different purposes and with totally different performance history, stood up under the pressure.

title: A Clinton Social With Bankers Included a Leading Regulator
description: The Democratic National Committee organized a coffee meeting at the White House last May in which some of the nation's most prominent bankers met to discuss banking regulation with President Clinton, a senior banking regulator, the Treasury Secretary and the top fund-raiser for the Democratic Party, Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a Western-style shopping mall in Ivory Coast misstated its location. It is in Abidjan, the country's largest city, not Yamoussoukro, the capital.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Laura Ashley Seeks to Balance Change and Tradition
description: When Laura Ashley died after falling down the stairs at her daughter's house in 1985, she left behind a company that was, in many ways, a victim of her success. So closely was it identified with her signature products -- loose-fitting, high-necked Victorian dresses and ultra-busy chintzes -- that the company seemed stuck in a frilly rut, unsure of how to move forward with new fashions and new tastes.

title: Russia's New Court Sculptor: Only the Colossal
description: Zurab Tsereteli swept through his skylit studio as he proudly described how he is single-handedly transforming Moscow's cityscape.

title: Conviction in Holdup Killing
