description: A man who claimed he was trying to grab a gun from a jewelry store owner during a holdup when it went off and killed the owner's wife was convicted yesterday of murder and robbery. The man, Marquis Kennon, 31, of Kansas, was one of five accused of taking part in the botched 1995 robbery attempt in Franklin Park that left Brenda Wolf dead. Last year, juries declined to convict two co-defendants, Harry Insabella and Robert Williams, after their lawyers argued that the store owner, Jeffrey Wolf, actually shot his wife deliberately. Mr. Wolf has not been charged. A. Peter DeMarco, an assistant Somerset County prosecutor, said he hoped to persuade Mr. Kennon to testify at the other retrials.

title: Coffee Prices Take Sharp Fall As a Strike in Colombia Ends
description: Coffee prices tumbled after dock workers in Colombia ended a 10-day strike, allowing thousands of bags of coffee to flow into the world market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, IRVING A.
description: GREENE-Irving A., on January 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Corinne Greene. Dear father of Michael and Peggy, Andrew and Barbara, and Steven. Adored grandfather of Adam, Sam and Billy.

title: HANDY & HARMAN TO BUY OLYMPIC MANUFACTURING
description: Handy & Harman said yesterday that it planned to acquire the Olympic Manufacturing Group Inc. from an investors group for $53 million. Handy & Harman makes engineered products and precious-metal components for the silverware, jewelry, electrical and appliance industries. Olympic Manufacturing makes and supplies fasteners for the commercial roofing industry. It had 1996 sales of about $42.5 million. Olympic will become a unit of Handy & Harman in its Engineered Products division. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Handy & Harman were up 12.5 cents yesterday at $16.25.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in The Living Section on Wednesday with an article about bratwurst was published in error. It showed summer sausage.

title: How the President's Team Courted Key Voting Blocs
description: From plans to send sub-Cabinet level officials as speakers to ethnic groups, to a recommendation that ''code words'' be used to appeal to ''ethnic Americans,'' documents released today show how an aggressive Clinton White House set out during the 1996 election year to court every conceivable constituency.

title: Freeh's Attack on Saudis Surprises Other Aides
description: When Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the F.B.I., and Janet Reno, the Attorney General, voiced their frustrations this week about a lack of Saudi cooperation in the investigation of a terrorist bombing last summer that killed 19 Americans, it came as a shock to just about every senior official in the Clinton Administration.

title: The Cuban Tango
description: The trip to Cuba this week by Canada's Foreign Minister, Lloyd Axworthy, was meant to send a strong message of protest to Washington about the overreaching Helms-Burton law. That misguided effort to punish foreign companies that invest in Cuba has already led to Canadian executives' being barred from United States soil, and, if fully enforced, could inundate Canadian businesses with scores of costly lawsuits. Unfortunately, Mr. Axworthy failed to deliver an equally strong protest against the human rights abuses of his Cuban hosts.

title: The New Out Crowd
description: People who live in trailers are now learning what it used to feel like to be Episcopalians. It used to be -- remember? -- that Episcopalians were the only group of Americans left about whom it was O.K. to joke. Then Episcopalians got their backs up.

title: Edgy Market Tumbles for a Third Day as Dow Loses 59.27
description: The stock market fell yesterday for the third consecutive session as investors appeared to be growing more concerned about rising interest rates and this year's fast climb to repeated record highs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREEM, THERESA DE VOE
description: CREEM-Theresa De Voe, 90, widow of John J. Creem Jr. died at St. Francis Hospital after a long illness on January 23, 1997. A long time member of the Munsey Park and Sands Point Garden Clubs. She was a nationally accredited horticultural judge. She is survived by her 3 sons: Michael, Anthony and Timothy, seven grandchildren & 2 great-grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Sunday from 3-5 PM and Monday from 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday 11 A.M., at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial donations to the Brooklyn Botanical Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11225.

title: No Headline
description: ''Several of us don't really recall having an opportunity for bankers to visit with the senior regulator, Mr. Ludwig, with his boss, the Secretary of the Treasury, and his boss, the President.''

title: INSIDE
description: New Nuclear Deterrent

title: Stand Firm on Police Pay
description: For the last two years, the union representing New York City's nearly 38,000 police officers has tried every conceivable tactic to avoid the realities accepted by other municipal employees. The union tried to run around Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and get the Legislature in Albany to arrange for higher wages than the city can afford. Now that the courts have effectively blocked that approach, the union has rejected the Mayor's latest sensible offer and thrown up picket lines at precincts around the city. Mr. Giuliani, whose political reputation rests heavily on his crime-fighting zeal, must stand firm and not be bullied by these police protests.

title: STRATTON OAKMONT FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: Stratton Oakmont Inc. filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors yesterday. The small-stock brokerage firm and its Oakmont Securities affiliate filed for bankruptcy restructuring in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Last month, Stratton, which has an extensive disciplinary history, was expelled by the National Association of Securities Dealers' regulatory unit. The industry body accused Stratton of fraudulently marking up securities, poorly supervising its brokers and repeatedly flouting securities rules.

title: Twisted Talk, Ulster's War
description: Winston Churchill's phrase ''To jaw-jaw is always better than to war-war'' has passed into collective parlance, but how tenable is it? In the downward spiraling of Ulster, the jaw-jaw has reached a vitriolic low.

title: Happy New Duo: A Rare Guitar and a Proud Musician
description: James L. D'Aquisto was considered a modern-day Stradivarius of sorts, a genius at carving the full-bellied archtop guitars favored by jazz virtuosos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ZANDT, LEONA THOMPSON
description: Van ZANDT-Leona Thompson. On January 21. Beloved widow of Roland Van Zandt, historian and author of The Catskill Mountain House and other books. A woman of great culture, vitality, creativity and love who enriched the lives of her many friends and family. She is survived by three children: Caroline, Carla and Carter. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Women's City Club of New York City or a charity of your choice. Memorial services will be held in the Spring at a time to be announced. Private interment.

title: Isles' Owner Prevails and Milbury Steps Down
description: Over the last two days, Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury spoke intensively with the new owner John Spano about the future of the team. The most immediate subject was whether Milbury should also remain as the team's head coach.

title: Tories Are Seduced Again By Their Wanton 'Toff'
description: Britain's Conservative Party, bedeviled in its attempts to cast itself as a protector of family values by a succession of sex scandals, found itself today welcoming back into the fold its most wanton former official.

title: Fighting Wet War to Restore Service
description: Like an army ready to fight back an onslaught, 300 Transit Authority workers descended into the subways yesterday morning, armed with water pumps, shovels and even leaflets.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Back to the Blackboard

title: CLINTON TO BATTLE FOODBORNE ILLNESS
description: President Clinton's 1998 budget will propose spending $43 million for a program to detect outbreaks of foodborne illnesses before they become widespread and to improve food safety.

title: Military Jury Acquits Cadet In Rape Case
description: After precisely five hours of deliberations, during which the accused and his family paced nervously outside the courtroom, an all-male court-martial panel of seven senior Army officers acquitted a male cadet at the United States Military Academy here of raping a female classmate.

title: The Future Has Risen: It's Hingis
description: With the precision of a Swiss clock and the temperament of a piranha, Martina Hingis became the youngest Grand Slam champion in 110 years with a ruthless 59-minute annihilation of unseeded Mary Pierce today in their Australian Open final.

title: Quarterbacks Then and Now
description: Mike Holmgren has coached both Joe Montana and Steve Young. How does Brett Favre compare to them?

title: Detective Describes Crown Hts. Confession
description: A retired police detective testified yesterday that Lemrick Nelson Jr. had confessed to him that he had stabbed a Hasidic Jew who was killed during the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: A Green Light for Burma To Join ASEAN 's Ranks
description: SINGAPORE  The Association of South East Asian Nations has decided to include Burma as a new member this year, even though the presence of the Burmese military regime could cause a rift in relations with the West and disrupt plans to hold a summit meeting between European and Asian leaders, officials and analysts say.

title: At Sundance, the Signs of Maturity
description: Lurking alone in the lobby during a screening of ''Ulee's Gold'' was Peter Fonda, the film's star. ''Hey!'' called out a Sundance Film Festival volunteer, surprised to see him. ''Best thing you've done in 20 years.'' It really is.

title: Teammates Have Come To Miss Bradley
description: His frame seemed shaved by 10 pounds, and maybe his face looked a little washed out. Who knows for sure with Shawn Bradley? It is hard to tell when he is thin and pale.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the made-for-television movie ''Last Stand at Saber River'' on Jan. 17 misstated the previous film credits of one actor and misidentified the director of the films cited. The actor Harry Carey Jr. did appear in ''Red River'' but not in ''Rio Bravo''; both were directed by Howard Hawks, not John Ford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTULSKY, CLAUS
description: MOTULSKY-Claus. Died Jan. 14, 1997, of a heart attack. Husband of Ursula; father of John, Michele and Dan. Memorial service on Jan. 27 at Yale Club, NY, 4:45 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to International Center for the Disabled, 340 E 24, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, ARTHUR
description: JORDAN-Arthur. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Arthur Jordan, associated with The Times since 1977.

title: U.N. Presses for Truce to Help Refugees Trapped in East Zaire
description: With 400,000 Hutu refugees trapped in desperate conditions in eastern Zaire, where the Zairian Army is struggling to retake territory from Tutsi rebels, the United Nations is pressing for a truce to allow the refugees to move to safer areas along strife-free ''humanitarian corridors,'' officials said today.

title: Sex, Speech and the Military
description: The mistreatment of women in the military is a serious concern. But trespassing on important First Amendment protections for free speech is not the way to address it. That is the welcome message of this week's ruling by a Federal district judge in New York striking down as unconstitutional a new law banning the sale of sexually explicit magazines and videos on military bases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, PHILIP C.
description: BRODSKY-Philip C., on January 24, 1997 of cancer. Beloved and adored husband of Jeanne, cherished father and grandfather of sons Paul, Gabriel and Eugene, daughter-in-law Karen, children Nancy, Marc and Sue Lazarus and grandchildren Sascha, Kirsten, Anya, Kate, Emma, brother Nathan and sister Ruth Leopold. His elegance touched everyone. Service Sunday, January 26th at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 1:15 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Yale Drama School.

title: Teaching Johnny to Read
description: Americans have been deluged with studies that describe how schools fail. But few if any offer convincing answers to the question of why so many children find reading so difficult that they never learn. Long-term studies begun by the National Institutes of Health in the early 1980's are shedding light on this problem. The studies offer clear strategies for teaching children who struggle to read -- and a cautionary tale for schools that would mainstream learning-impaired children without making careful plans for their instruction.

title: Yanks Top Pitcher's List
description: Hideki Irabu, the outstanding Japanese pitcher whose negotiating rights were acquired by San Diego earlier this month, says he wants to play in the major leagues, but not for the Padres. ''I have absolutely no desire to conclude a contract with San Diego,'' Irabu told The Associated Press yesterday at Narita Airport outside Tokyo.

title: O.A.S. Rights Panel Censures Mexico Over General's Imprisonment
description: Leaving a black mark on Mexico's human rights record, a panel of the Organization of American States has condemned the Government for jailing a general who publicly criticized the armed forces.

title: G.O.P. Governors Seek to Restore Immigrant Aid
description: Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and other Republican governors urged Congress today to restore some of the benefits taken away from legal immigrants under the new welfare law, signed just six months ago by President Clinton.

title: Myfanwy Piper, 85, Art Critic Who Wrote Britten's Librettos
description: Myfanwy Piper, an English art critic and the librettist for three of Benjamin Britten's operas, died last Saturday at Fawley Bottom, the farmhouse home near Henley, England, that was a center of artistic activity in the 1940's and 50's. She was 85.

title: Feted in China, Artist Worried By Walls Here
description: THE windows in Robert Craddock's Long Island City artist loft give him a grand view of the Manhattan skyline rising over the factories and train tracks. From his side of Queens, it can make him feel all the more anonymous in the art capital of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIS DAVID

description: At her first news conference on her first full day as Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright promised today to stay the course of President Clinton's foreign policy but to sell it better to Congress and the American people.

title: Whitaker, Knocked Down, Comes Back to Knock Out Challenger
description: Coming into tonight's World Boxing Council welterweight title fight, the champion, Pernell Whitaker, said he was concerned that the undefeated but unheralded challenger, Diobelis Hurtado, might not make it out of the dressing room.

description: In the cloud of statistics that surface when the city and its largest police union sit down at the bargaining table, whose numbers are to be believed?

title: An Austrian Conducts Mozart And Ravel
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night was a far better indicator of the orchestra's excellence than the program it presented in late November, just after the players ended their bitter strike. The conductor was the compelling Austrian Franz Welser-Most; the program, though it made a curious package, included some intriguing items; and for the most part, the orchestra played with lustrous sound and incisive ensemble.

title: UConn's King Receives Seasonlong Suspension
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association issued its verdict against the University of Connecticut today, suspending the captain of the men's basketball team, the senior Kirk King, for the remainder of the season, and ruling that the sophomore Ricky Moore will have to sit out three more games.

description: Bill Parcells has pronounced his underdog New England Patriots ready for Green Bay.

title: Body Taken from Mausoleum
description: The body of man interred for 36 years was stolen yesterday from a Newark mausoleum, the police said. Officials at the Cemetery of the Holy Sepulchre said that while the man's body was taken, the body of his wife, which lay beneath his, remained unharmed. Sgt. Derek Glenn of the Newark police said there was evidence that the body was taken ''for use in a ritualistic ceremony.'' ANDY NEWMAN

description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday arrested a resident of Astoria, Queens, on charges that he made threatening or harassing telephone calls to Delta Air Lines and Swissair for almost two years.

description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, as investors sold on concern that coming reports on the economy and wages would show faster growth and greater inflationary pressures.

title: Walking a Delicate Line:Men's Dress Takes a Feminine and Sexy Turn
description: PARIS  There is certainly nothing unusual about back-combed hair, varnished nails, or matching bags and shoes worn by women at a haute couture show. It is another story when these things are seen on male bodybuilders like the models in Jean Paul Gaultier's couture collection shown here last Sunday.

description: ''Evidence exists that Republican staffers surf the Internet, interacting with extremists in order to exchange ideas and information.'' So reads a posting on alt.current-events.clinton.whitewater, an Internet discussion group for conspiracy-theory aficionados. It asserted that Republican minions shrewdly used the Internet to turn ''fringe stories into legitimate subjects of coverage by the mainstream media.''

title: MONTGOMERY WARD MOVE PORTENDS POWER SHIFT
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation has given two board seats to Roger Goddu, its new chief executive, in a move that could give the GE Capital Corporation control over the department store company. The two seats were taken from Montgomery Ward's chairman, Bernard F. Brennan, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. That breaks a long deadlock between Mr. Brennan and GE Capital. Each had 5 directors on the 10-member board. The shift in directors means that GE Capital -- which has been said to want to shed the struggling 400-store chain -- could pass a board vote with Mr. Goddu's support if it wanted to sell, dismantle or take the company public, analysts said. A GE Capital spokesman, John Oliver, said the company had played a ''key role'' in selecting Mr. Goddu, a former Toys ''R'' Us executive.

description: GAINES-Michael Christopher, of Palisades Park, NJ on January 23, 1997. Beloved son of Nancy (nee Siegel) of Lancaster County, PA., and the late William M. title: Abortion Pill's Legal Woe May Be Nearing an End
description: Three years ago it seemed inevitable that the French abortion pill would soon be sold on the American market, ushering in an era when, with greater privacy in abortion and fewer of the surgical procedures, the abortion debate would be less dominated by demonstrations and violence outside clinics.

description: The yellow ribbons have long since been taken down at 1718 Washington Street, the house where Anne Marie Fahey once lived, and Ms. Fahey's four brothers and sister no longer hold a constant vigil on the front porch, awaiting some news of her fate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, RAE FISHBERG
description: GLANTZ-Rae Fishberg, 94, at home on Bay Harbor Islands, Fla. Widow of Harry; cherished mother of Geraldine, Janice and Lois. Beloved mother-in-law of Sidney Bergman, Robert Greenstein and Arthur Rosenfeld. Adored grandmother of the late Pamela, Susan, Ivy, Tod, Felicia, Carolyn and Sara. Loving great-grandmother of eleven. Devoted sister of Marte and aunt. A woman of incomparable grace, charm, intelligence and insight. She was a natural beauty whose character was as unforgettable as her face. A member of the Fishberg-Glantz musical family, her life was a symphony of great personal accomplishment, filled with warmth, love and serenity. She will be deeply missed. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

The private sector created 5,700 new jobs last month, most of them in retail, but the public sector lost 2,200 jobs.

title: Richard Berry, Songwriter of 'Louie Louie,' Dies at 61
description: Richard Berry, who wrote the legendary three-chord rock song ''Louie Louie'' died in his sleep on Thursday at his home in South-Central Los Angeles. He was 61.

title: Ex-Mayor May Run Again
description: Former Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City has kept a low political profile since his 1994 release from Federal prison, where he served two years for bank fraud. But perhaps not for much longer. Mr. McCann, 46, was cleared by the state Thursday to run for public office again -- just in time for the May 13 mayoral election. Mr. McCann, a Democrat who served two terms, said that supporters have gathered enough signatures to put his name on the ballot. He said he plans to announce his decision within three weeks.

title: Defendants Kept in Delaware
description: Amy S. Grossberg and Brian C. Peterson, the Bergen County teen-agers accused of murdering their newborn son, will remain in Delaware over the weekend, even though they are free on bail, while officials iron out the logistics of their house arrests. One problem, Delaware corrections officials said, is that the phone number programmed into the electronic monitor bracelets works only in Delaware, not in New Jersey. Yesterday the pair, who were released on $300,000 bail Tuesday, were being kept at separate homes in the Wilmington area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, VALLE WEBER
description: FAY-Valle Weber. Of Rowayton, CT, who led the efforts to revitalize South Norwalk in the late 1970's and 80's, died Wednesday night in Norwalk Hospital of complications following an emergency operation. Beloved wife of Francis X. Fay, Jr. and loving mother of Valle Gaynor Blake of Brighton, MA, was 77. As Founder and President of the Norwalk Preservation Trust in 1977, Mrs. Fay arranged the educational programs and forums that redirected the focus of Norwalk's urban redevelopment from demolition to rehabilitation. Concurrently, as one of five Norwalk Redevelopment Agency Commissioners, she influenced the agency between 1978 and 1981 to adopt the rehabilitation of the Washington Street Historic District, a project that won two national awards in 1988. Mrs. Fay was one of five cited in the US Department of Interior Historic Preservation Award for the ''creative use of contemporary historic preservation techniques.'' The project was also selected and she was cited for the Downtown Development Award of the Downtown Research & Development Center of NYC, ''as a demonstration of public/private partnerships creating a vibrant downtown.'' ''Valle was the inspiration behind the city's approach to restoring the wonderful assets of South Norwalk,'' said former Mayor William A. Collins, who had appointed her to the Redevelopment Agency. ''I don't belive we could have gathered enough strength in the community to support the program without her effort.'' ''Valle was the pivotal person, and her voice was the stongest in saving the South Norwalk heritage despite the tremendous opposition at the time,'' said Rod Johnson, former Redevelopment Agency Excecutive Director. Mrs. Fay's interest in architectural antiquity had been inspired as a youngster by visits to St. Genevieve, Missouri, 60 miles south of St. Louis. Her paternal ancestors, the LaVallee family, had been among the early settlers in that first white development of Missouri (1735), and had produced three governors general of what was then known as the Louisana Territory. Mrs. Fay was Chairman of the Norwalk Green Historic Commission, Trustee and Secretary of the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum and served twelve years as a member and Vice Chairman of the Norwalk Historical Commission. Mrs. Fay had been Post Master of the Rowayton Post Office from 1961 to 1963. She had been a trainee with the Women's Air Service Pilots (WASP) during WW II. She was cited for her accomplishments in 1995 by Celebrate Women!, a Norwalk organization honoring women's achievements. Mrs. Fay was born in St. Louis on March 5, 1919, and raised in nearby Webster Groves, MO, the only child of the late John A. and Ethel Bass Weber. She was a gradaute of Mary Institute (1936) in the St. Louis area. She also attended Mills and Barnard colleges. She was predeceased in 1969 by a son, Robert E. Blake III. A memorial program will be held at 7 PM, February 2, at the Norwalk Maritime Aquarium. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Norwalk Museum, 141 East Ave., Norwalk, CT 06851, or the Norwalk Maritime Aquarium, 10 Water St, South Norwalk, CT 06854.

title: Glue, Glaze, Gum, Grabs
description: Combining 27 new poems with others from 10 previous collections, Nancy Willard's SWIMMING LESSONS: New and Selected Poems (Knopf, $25) reveals a poet whose gifts have remained constant throughout her career. In an early selection entitled ''Picture Puzzles,'' she claims, while assembling a jigsaw puzzle of a Nativity by Fra Angelico, ''It's because we're broken / that we love / puzzles.'' This sense of brokenness propels Ms. Willard toward discovery and understanding. Her imagery is both elemental and ethereal, her characteristic forms the litany, elegy and ballad. While she doesn't shy away from singularly painful subjects (''Clearing the Air,'' for instance, addresses the assailant who ''tried to kill me''), her overriding impulse is to celebrate the ordinary: a puffball, her son's wooden alphabet, even the hardware store: ''In a world not perfect but not bad either / let there be glue, glaze, gum, and grabs.'' Personal relationships, history and nature furnish the material for her newest work. ''The Alligator Wrestler,'' ''The Exodus of Peaches,'' ''The Wisdom of the Jellyfish'' and ''Sand Shark'' stand out and delight with their fresh, precise imagery, rendering the natural world mysterious as well as instructional. ''Swimming Lessons'' is a generous collection -- one that will please Ms. Willard's established fans and attract many new ones. Gardner McFall

She appeared to be a regular customer. As the saleswoman wrapped the books, the woman told her that she was buying copies for her two sons and her two married daughters. With so much idle talk after reunification of ''We are finally able to turn the page,'' she said, it was proper that the ''past'' was in the news again and a hot issue on all the television talk shows. This Goldhagen, she pronounced, was ''kolossal.''

title: AWAKENING TO SLEEP
description: Allan Rechtschaffen's experiment on sleep deprivation in rats, as described in your article, is the kind of cruel and fundamentally useless research typical of so many behavioral studies with animals. Rechtschaffen kept rats awake for two and a half weeks until they died (similar studies have been done on cats). What could he have thought he could learn from these brutal studies that would be useful? That sleep deprivation is debilitating and leads to death? Everyone knows that.

''The Steeple-Jack,'' the first poem in the final edition of her ''Complete Poems,'' begins: ''Durer would have seen a reason for living/ in a town like this, with eight stranded whales/ to look at.''

For the past five years, though, as host of a series of arts programs on the BBC, she has become a beloved figure in Britain. She has a publicist; she visited John Major at 10 Downing Street last month; she is parodied on Saturday morning kiddie shows. She is both a Consecrated Virgin and a pop star.

title: My Unsentimental Tutee
description: A literacy tutor is taught to connect with adult students by pointing out common beliefs. So when I first met Renzhen, a 30-something Chinese woman, I told her, hand on heart, how stirred I was by the spirit of the 1989 Tiananmen Square uprising. She cocked her head at me and blurted: ''Why? That guy who fight the tank - he totally crazy!'' She then twirled an index finger around her temple, her way of saying ''Duh.'' Hardly a ''Miracle Worker'' moment. But it was typical of my experiences with Renzhen, a former university math instructor who came to the United States in 1991 believing (wrongly) that she would find a better teaching job. My reasons for becoming a tutor combined Pollyanna-ish social activism with too much free time. Her motivation was a more prosaic desire to pass the English-proficiency exam and a nagging suspicion that she was getting shortchanged in stores. After two years, our sessions have cured her of calling men ''she,'' and I have been cured of something as well - my sometimes sentimental notions about what this country means to newcomers.

Instead, squatting on cushions, Japanese viewers huddle around low, mini-tables and nibble peanuts, salty fried peas and rice crackers, called osembei. Another favorite, especially among women, is dried sweet potatoes -- sliced sweet potatoes dried under the sun and then warmed up in a toaster. SHERYL WuDUNN

title: LIPSTICK FRACAS
description: School officials have taken heat for overreacting to innocuous adolescent styles, but there's such a thing as over-counterreaction. After being sent home twice for ''disruptive'' lipstick shades (black and purple), Karla Chapman, a 13-year-old in Pikeville, Ky., took a razor to her wrist in a fortunately halfhearted suicide attempt. ''That was stupid,'' she now admits. This month, Chapman's parents solved the conflict by transferring her to a school that permits black lipstick, but her lawyer, Larry Webster, filed suit over her emotional upheaval. ''If nothing had been said,'' he insists, ''some guy would have said, 'That looks stupid,' and she never would have worn it again.''

title: Watch It: Hot Stuff
description: What Mexicans eat in front of the tube depends on what they're watching. When men watch soccer on TV, it's usually at a neighborhood cantina, where they down beer, rum, tequila or a sickeningly sweet mix of brandy and cola. Once everybody's ravenous, waiters ferry in food from the kitchen -- free, as it turns out. First course is often carnitas (fried pork cutlets) and chicharron (fried pork skin). The main fare is usually pozole, a pork broth with a floating hunk of corn on the cob, or menudo, a stew of cow stomach and chile, often fiery hot. It's supposedly great for hangovers -- though it's unclear whether for producing or curing them.

That is the highest figure, at this point in the appeal, since 1992, but it is still well below that year's total of more than $5 million.

title: Collective Art
description: As the forms of fine art and the content of commercial art continue to merge, one thing that separates them is the exhibition space itself. Art on the wall is fine art; art in print is commercial. A few respected artists, like Barbara Kruger, Robbie Conal and Rodney Alan Greenblat, bridge both worlds without sacrificing either integrity or stature. And there are others, like Mark Kostabi. His paintings, prints and objects are at once satiric commentaries on the nature of the art business and a lampoon of artistic pretensions. But what makes him unique -- and anathema to the art world -- is that his art is produced on an assembly line. As he explains in his book CONVERSATIONS WITH KOSTABI (Journey Editions, $50), he takes pride in the commodification of his work and has built a reputation on the fact that he does not actually conceive or paint most his of own pictures. Virtually every canvas released from Kostabi World, his art factory, is the work of various art workers and idea people. ''I couldn't come up with that many different good ideas a day,'' he writes. The committee, as he calls his production group, develops ideas and renders the narrative and surrealist paintings in Mr. Kostabi's airbrushed-looking velvet style. Like Keith Haring's pop store, Mr. Kostabi's Kostabi World loft/gallery in SoHo sells art, artifacts and souvenirs. Owing to the large scope of production, many of his images are repetitive and some are frankly kitsch, but what makes Mr. Kostabi the artist more interesting than his conceit of creating assembly-line art is that many of the paintings, like the absurd ''Mario and His Muse,'' are genuinely funny. Despite a few bouts of pretension (''my creation of Kostabi World is like Gauguin's move to Tahiti, or like van Gogh's cutting off his ear''), ''Conversations With Kostabi'' is a genuinely honest view of a distinct artistic vision. Steven Heller

title: In Titusville, a Farm Where Breaking the Ice Is No Metaphor

Instead, farmers on the old Phillips-Howell Farmstead in Titusville would use pulleys to drag the 22-by-32-inch blocks of ice up the ramp before stacking them, layered with sawdust, in the icehouse's 10-foot-deep fieldstone foundation to be preserved through the summer.

title: Russia's Tradition Grows Stronger With Sweep in Europe
description: When the Soviet Union ceased to exist in 1991, many close observers of figure skating saw the Cyrillic writing on the wall.

title: Houdini's Legend
description: To the Editor:

title: New National Library Stirs Dissent in Paris
description: The Bibliotheque Nationale de France, which opened last month in Paris, is raising as much controversy about its appearance and exorbitant cost as did the Opera Bastille, its predecessor on the list of ''great works'' achieved in the city by the late President Francois Mitterrand.

title: 'Meltdown Has Begun'
description: DO THE WINDOWS OPEN?

title: A Bill to Promote Truth in Politics
description: If a candidate for office says his opponent is a criminal when he knows he is not, that is a lie. But if he says his opponent is a windbag, is that a lie? That decision would be left up to a judge under a bill that has cleared the Assembly's State Government Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, RAE FISHBERG
description: GLANTZ-Rae Fishberg, 94, at home on Bay Harbor Islands, Fla. Widow of Harry; cherished mother of Geraldine, Janice and Lois. Beloved mother-in-law of Sidney Bergman, Robert Greenstein and Arthur Rosenfeld. Adored grandmother of the late Pamela, Susan, Ivy, Tod, Felicia, Carolyn and Sara. Loving great-grandmother of eleven. Devoted sister of Marte and aunt. A woman of incomparable grace, charm, intelligence and insight. She was a natural beauty whose character was as unforgettable as her face. A member of the Fishberg-Glantz musical family, her life was a symphony of great personal accomplishment, filled with warmth, love and serenity. She will be deeply missed. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WHAT KEEPS ME HERE A Book of Stories. By Rebecca Brown. HarperCollins, $20.

title: Elizabeth Brainerd And Robert Burge
description: Elizabeth B. Brainerd, a freelance cookbook writer and editor, was married yesterday to Robert Dana Burge, the owner of Yale R. Burge Antiques Inc. in New York. Village Justice William Rand of Cove Neck, L.I., performed the ceremony at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York.

title: Female Veterans Find Help for Assault
description: LIKE many veterans, Nancy Alexander suffered from traumatic shock after her tour of duty during the Vietnam War era. But Ms. Alexander was not just reacting to the things she saw and heard while caring for critically wounded airmen in the intensive-care unit at a Strategic Air Command base hospital in Oklahoma. Like thousands of other female veterans who have begun to come forward, Ms. Alexander, a former Air Force nurse, had been sexually assaulted by a fellow airman.

title: Solid Old Cadillac
description: You know that downsizing has gone too far when Cadillac comes up with a new type of car that's no bigger than a Lexus. This fall, in its most craven attempt to appeal to a younger market, the company that defined spacious luxury at its most American started selling the Catera. It's made in Germany, of all places, and is being billed as ''the Caddy that zigs.'' ''Cadillac,'' a General Motors apologist recently stated, ''has a lot of baggage . . . to get over.''

title: Branching Out From Embodying Classical Ballet
description: TWO EVENTS STAND OUT AS defining moments in the career of Peter Boal, a leading dancer with the New York City Ballet who will perform this week at the Joyce Theater with the avant-gardist Molissa Fenley. At 12, an elegant, tiny Mr. Boal drew gasps from the audience as he danced in a children's ballet choreographed by Jean-Pierre Bonnefous for a School of American Ballet workshop program. Two decades later, on an evening last February, rapt silence greeted him as he appeared alone and nearly still as Balanchine's Orpheus, on the huge stage of the New York State Theater in a memorial service for Lincoln Kirstein.

title: Historic Church, Uncertain Future
description: FOR more than a century and a half, the sanctuary now called the First Church of Christ Congregational has been the most picturesque view in Redding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, JOAN
description: ZUCKERMAN-Joan, on January 24, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Robert Zuckerman. Dear mother of Donald and Donna, Barry and Roberta. Adored grandmother of Ethan, Elizabeth and Adam. Services Monday January 27, 10 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: How to Make A Politician Say 'Ouch!'
description: ''The next step is to put people in stocks on the steps of the Capitol and throw vegetables at them.''

title: Back to the Future
description: PARIS IN THE

title: Senior Doctors And Nurses See Threats to Jobs
description: As hospitals merge and shrink under pressure from managed care, a large and growing number of senior doctors and nurses have found themselves suddenly dismissed or demoted at the height of their careers.

title: German Holocaust Memorials Should Be Private
description: To the Editor:

title: More of Same Bumbling Leaves Storm Reeling
description: It is a problem Fran Fraschilla has seen far too often this season and now seems helpless to rectify. Turnovers -- most of them unforced, all of them maddening -- sent St. John's into a second-half tailspin that ended in a 72-59 loss to Providence last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Is Station Worth Saving If Special Character Is Lost?
description: To the Editor:

title: Go Shout It From the Tent Tops!
description: The theme of the 1997 National Religious Broadcasters convention, which opened yesterday in Anaheim, Calif., is ''Announce His Message.'' Though the N.R.B. hands out achievement awards, it has somehow neglected one very deserving member: the Among Foundation, a seat-of-the-pants South Dakota-based outfit that through a unique station called Eagle TV has taken pro-democracy, Christian-oriented television to the vast, frozen steppes of Mongolia. (Mongolia, which was closely aligned with the Soviet Union until its breakup, is mainly Buddhist and Muslim.) Here's how the eagle landed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTASERSE, MURIEL D. (NEE DODD)
description: ARTASERSE-Muriel D. (nee Dodd), of Clifton, NJ on Jan. 23, 1997. Survivors include her loving husband, Hon. Peter P. Artaserse, and her son, Peter, Jr. Funeral services Tuesday, 10:30 AM from the Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, Clifton and 11:00 AM at St. Philip the Apostle R.C. Church, Clifton. Visiting Sunday and Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Five Times the Fun
When the Blazers Met the Love Beads
description: In the mid-1960's, Warner Brothers Records was a struggling record company that bet its future on rock-and-roll. The signing of the notorious bohemians the Grateful Dead in 1967 was a watershed event for the label. In a new book, ''The Mansion on the Hill,'' the journalist Fred Goodman chronicles how the underground rock movement of the 60's fueled the rise of the modern entertainment industry. In this excerpt, he describes a St. Patrick's Day party and concert in San Francisco to which two label executives were dispatched to present the band with a copy of its first Warner release.

title: A Cake Filled With Memories, and Poppy Seeds
description: I was well into adulthood before I realized that poppy-seed coffeecake -- the kind that looks like a jelly roll and tastes like home on a cozy winter morning -- was Polish, not Irish Catholic. My Irish-American mother made them every Christmas, using a recipe that came, I later learned, from the wife of my father's long-ago Polish boss.

title: Suing Pace, Nuns Cling to Values
description: SOME would argue that they live in the past. And in a sense, life in this cache of turn-of-the-century buildings proceeds in much the same manner that it always has. In contrast to the street outside, the pace is unhurried inside the historic chapel, where an antiquated heating system clanks incessantly and the Sisters of the Divine Compassion go quietly about their duties.

title: Upstairs, Down the Hatch
description: An informal survey suggests that British television snackers prefer tea with chocolates or chocolate biscuits (meaning cookies), beer or wine with potato chips or nuts, and occasionally cheese and crackers. Some people like their nibbles with dips, while the health-conscious can opt for one of many low-fat crisps (chips). Also available are ''prawn flavour maize snacks.''

title: Julie Harris, Taking 'Road to Mecca' Higher
description: ''THE ROAD TO MECCA'' is about the power of art to give sustenance within a restrictive society, and it is about the glory of the individual as a transcendent being. The play's creator, Athol Fugard, has the vast reach of the absolute poet, ever in search of purpose, of self-fulfillment, of collective responsibility.

title: Why Do They Shoot Horses?
description: ALAIN JUPPE, THE POLITICIAN Jacques Chirac chose to be Prime Minister of France, has long come across as a bit of a stiff. With his popularity plunging to a new nadir, the brusque technocrat, to dispel his image of intellectual arrogance, has decided to let all his hidden passion and repressed angst hang out in a new book titled ''Between Ourselves.''

title: Pain or Pleasure, It's Super Bowl Time
description: AFTER a record five hours of pre-game programming, Fox will finally offer us Super Bowl XXXI tonight, sometime after 6 P.M. Will it be great? Will we remember it tomorrow? Or will it fade into the oblivion of blowouts?

title: 'Nobody Dead. God Willing.'
description: PEERING from behind the wheel of a dirty blue 1989 Chevrolet van, the Rev. Steven Sinari of Covenant House said he could use a break.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Dec. 1 in the Travel Advisory column, about the Lyceum Theater in London, referred to its history incompletely. The main stage of the theater had, indeed, not been used for a theater performance for 57 years, but the Lyceum's ballroom did serve in 1985 as the setting for a 12-week run of three medieval mystery plays. A reader's letter dated Dec. 3 pointed out the more recent performances. This correction was delayed because of an editing oversight.

title: Science Fiction
description: Margaret Wander Bonanno is smarter than you are. This is apt to be your first impression on reading through her PRETERNATURAL (Tor/ Tom Doherty, $23.95), an enormously challenging puzzle story. But not to worry. Within the complex web she weaves, her displays of erudition -- in fields as disjunct as classical scholarship and Star Trek ephemera -- are somehow not distancing but reassuring. Solving a simple-minded puzzle is no fun. We want our puzzle masters to stay one step ahead of us, drawing us on to new feats of inference and illumination.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CURLING IN DARIEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANLEY, HELEN SWENSON
description: MANLEY-Helen Swenson. At Lakewood, NJ, on January 23, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John Howard Manley. A longtime resident of New York, she was a valued member of the support staff of Sullivan and Cromwell, as secretary to Eustace Seligman, a prominent senior partner. Survived by her brother Victor H. Swenson, Jr., of Mantoloking, NJ, and several nieces and nephews. For information contact D'Elia Funeral Home of Lakewood, NJ.

title: Usually Unseen, From Storage in 2 Museums
description: ''19th-Century Children In Portraits and at Play''

title: It's Official: Mara Joins The Elite In the Hall
description: First, Wellington Mara went to church today, and that was why no one could find him to give him the news.

title: Generation Gaps
description: The Fourth Turning

title: AWAKENING TO SLEEP
description: Sleep is necessary, although scientists do not know exactly why. I make a real effort to get 8 or 9 hours of sleep in every 24-hour period. I am told that I look 5 to 8 years younger than my actual age (42). Does looking youthful have any connection to sleep? Is my 99-year-old grandmother alive and in good health because she also believes sleep is important?

title: The Conscious Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Nagasaki's Kitchens Stir a Hodgepodge Of Several Cultures
description: LOCAL lore describes the culinary history of Nagasaki as wa ka ran -- literally, ''I don't understand.'' The Japanese fondness for punning, though, provides additional meanings: wa refers to things Japanese, ka to things that are Chinese, and ran to things of Dutch origin. The result is a happy hodgepodge -- a blend of Chinese and European influences on indigenous Japanese food. Collectively, this eclectic cooking is known as shippoku ryori.

title: Carrying Out Megan's Law
description: Every state in the nation now requires registration of convicted sex offenders, and 42 states have enacted laws requiring public notification when a sex offender is released into a community. These are the so-called Megan's laws, triggered by public anger over the 1994 slaying of young Megan Kanka by a released sex offender living near her home in New Jersey. A Federal Megan's law enacted last year accelerated the trend by directing all states to create some form of public notification.

title: Money Tap Loosens, But Rules Tighten
description: THE way developers and bankers tell the stories, Manhattan was like the Wild West during a good part of the 1980's: Bankers were lending developers money with flimsy pay-back guarantees; in some cases, without any money down. Loans were handed out based on inflated estimates. Approvals were taken for granted -- some developers started to dig foundations for their tall apartment towers before they even held the deed to the land. Money was flowing.

title: Confirmation of Novelties
description: In a possibly misleading sign of bipartisanship, the Senate unanimously confirmed the core of President Clinton's new national security team, giving Madeleine K. Albright and William S. Cohen 99-0 votes of confidence last week as Secretary of State and Secretary of Defense respectively.

title: The Battle of the Braid Brigade
description: AT Walton High School in the Bronx, Andrean Russell was the student her peers went to when they wanted their hair braided.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: GONE FISHIN'

title: At a Reopened South Salem Landmark
description: THE responsibility of running a lovely historic landmark inn the building dates back to 1721 -- with a well-founded reputation for serious cooking must be daunting. (Longtime residents will remember when wild boar, alligator and wild turkey were as common here as the lamb chops and duck that shared what was then considered an exotic menu.) Expectations for the reopening of such a place naturally run high as many diners remember burnished wide-plank floors, low beamed ceilings, a splendid fireplace, candlelight and pewter, not to mention savory fare, which memory might have embellished with just a tad of undeserved finesse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMEL, MAX
description: TEMEL-Max. Beloved husband of Hannah (Hanka). Devoted father of David and Cory, Charles and Judy, Sofia and Jay Maisler, George and Shana. Loving grandfather of Rachel, Brian, Aaron, Erica, Laura, Dan, Greg and Alex. Adored great-grandfather of Adam and Brandon. Funeral Service on Monday, at 10 A.M., ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: INVESTING WITH: Ronald C. Ognar, Strong Growth Fund
description: IF you like the leaders of the pack, you will feel right at home with the Strong Growth fund.

title: Spin Nation
description: Now that the turmoil over Newt Gingrich's ethics violations has led to a reprimand, one aspect of the saga is being overlooked. In an unusual development, the deal in which Mr. Gingrich admitted bringing discredit to the House involved a separate pledge by the Speaker not to belittle the charges against him. The ethics panel's concern, according to James Cole, the special prosecutor, was ''not wanting 'spin,' to use a common phrase,'' making the charges seem trivial.

title: Intensive Shelling, the Fun Kind
description: The Israeli slang for TV snacks is pitzuhim -- loosely, anything that can cracked open and shelled. A typical sports fan here, glued to the screen for a critical soccer match or basketball game, can be found nibbling anxiously on roasted and salted sunflower or watermelon seeds, or pistachios, spewing out shells onto piles that get higher as the game gets closer. The seeds are accompanied by generous infusions of the national stimulants: caffeine and nicotine in the form of coffee, Coke and cigarettes. JOEL GREENBERG

title: Panel on Air Security May End Without Reaching a Consensus
description: A White House commission established because of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 will probably go out of existence without agreement on the feasibility of two significant security steps: matching passengers and bags on domestic flights, and identifying passengers who are possible risks and warrant closer scrutiny.

title: Barbara Thomson, Robert Previdi
description: Barbara Susan Thomson and Robert William Previdi were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. George Hommel, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOEY, MARY W. (NEE NEE)
description: McGOEY-Mary W. (nee Nee). On January 22, 1997. Native of County Mayo, Ireland. Retired teacher N.Y.C. Public School System. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Maeve Scott, John, Peter, Desmond, Barry, Patrick and Bernard. Proud grandmother of Courtney, David, Kaylyn and Shannon. Reposing David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball Ave), Yonkers. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30 AM Saint Paul the Apostle Church. Interment Saint Mary Cemetery (Yonkers). In lieu of flowers, kindly make donations to Burke Rehabilitation Institute, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, New York 10601.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDTOWN

title: Q and A
description: Hosts Aboard Ship

title: What a Difference A Year Makes
description: AT LAST YEAR'S SUNDANCE Film Festival in Utah, one Australian film, ''Shine,'' became a sensation in the Premiere section and had two distributors battling over it. Meanwhile, another Australian film, ''Angel Baby,'' languished in the almost invisible World Cinema section.

title: He Composes Differently, Therefore He Exists
description: AT A TIME WHEN SO MANY composers have given up on radical innovation, the Greek composer Iannis Xenakis, who turns 75 this year, has become a heartening figure. His music, as represented in new recordings, is hardly less uncompromising than it was in the 1950's, though it is certainly richer and more adept, probably because he has been able to build on his successes while retaining an extraordinary imperviousness to his mistakes.

title: OPTIMISM GROWING THAT BUDGET DEAL CAN BE NEGOTIATED
description: Two years ago, the Republicans proposed cutting $270 billion from the growth of Medicare spending over seven years, setting off a bitter political battle that has poisoned efforts to balance the Federal budget ever since.

title: As Industry Changes, Networks Feel a Ripple Effect
description: AS corporate America downsizes and looks for outside suppliers for non-core operations like property management, the real estate industry is reorganizing itself as well, consolidating into fewer, but bigger, companies that can take over the jettisoned corporate departments.

title: A Visual Lesson in the Evolution of Prints
description: IN a game of free association, art aficionados might respond to ''Rutgers'' with ''prints.'' The Zimmerli Art Museum at the university has more than 50,000 of them from all eras and constantly mounts shows approaching prints from various angles. Currently, it's back to basics with ''Four Centuries of Prints.''

title: A Battle Shapes Up On West 72d Street: Trade vs. Esthetics
description: ''47 on the Dollar Name Brand Bras Girdles Lingerie''

title: At Former Synagogue, Proper Burial and End to Seamy Chapter
description: The life of the last synagogue in Soundview is over. The doors are locked, the lights are out, and the remaining holy texts, which were allowed to deteriorate during the building's seamiest days, are on their way to a traditional dirt-covered burial.

title: Maria Negrete, Andreas Gruson
description: Maria Jose Negrete, a daughter of Matilde Guzman de Negrete of Bogota, Colombia, and the late Luis Manuel Negrete, was married yesterday to Andreas Yutaka Gruson, a son of Dr. Hiroko Tsubota Gruson and Dr. Michael Gruson of New York. The Rev. Alvaro Gonzales, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Hacienda Fagua Chapel in Bogota.

title: It's Still Down to the Sea in Ships
description: ''THE Heritage of the Sea'' at the Geary Gallery here is a sturdy and engaging exhibition of paintings of ships and other boats. Paintings from the 19th century are hung alongside contemporary ones, and it is often hard to tell the difference, for the recent painters often like to reinvigorate a glorious past.

title: T.E. Tibbs Jr., 44; Dealt in African-American Art
description: Thurlow Evans Tibbs Jr., a dealer in African-American art who donated about 30 paintings, sculptures, prints, photographs and drawings to the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington last year, died on Jan. 16 at his home in Washington. He was 44.

title: This Guy Wants to Sell You a Car
description: For anyone who thinks that car salesmen lack empathy, flexibility and openness, guess what? It's true.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IAMS, SAMUEL H. (JACK)
At Crown Hts. Trial, Taped Images of Chaos
description: When a friend gave Luis Vettorazzi a video camera to use on vacation in 1991, Mr. Vettorazzi, then a building superintendent in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, thought he would be shooting scenes that he and his family would look back on with fondness in future years.

title: People
description: * Doug Fidoten was named to the new position of executive vice president and strategic planning director at DCA Advertising, New York, part of Dentsu Inc. He had been executive vice president and managing director at Bates Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. Also at DCA, Steve Penchina was named executive vice president and executive creative director, a vacant position. He had been chairman and creative director at Penchina & Partners, New York, which closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURGER, LILLIAN
description: HAMBURGER-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Loving mother of Michael and Andrea, Richard and Lisa. Cherished sister of Dora Portnick and Rivi Wasserman. Adored grandmother of David, Gillian, Adam and Amanda. Funeral services today, 10 AM, at the ''Dix Hills Chapel'' of I. J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: Price Tags on the King Legacy
description: There is something deeply wrong with copyright law when it restricts access to historic texts by treating them as nothing more than private property for sale. That is the situation presented in the lawsuit filed by the estate of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. against CBS. In November, the estate sued the news organization for copyright infringement for marketing a five-part video documentary series that included film footage from the CBS archives of Dr. King's ''I Have a Dream'' speech.

title: The Many Questions Are Written on Parcells's Back
description: AS Bill Parcells stalked the sideline in Super Bowl XXXI last night, two questions were written in invisible ink on the back of his Patriots windbreaker.

title: After Years of Secrecy, Santeria Is Suddenly Much More Popular. And Public.
description: The recreation room is thick with cigar smoke by late afternoon. Three drummers frantically pound sacred drums, enticing worshipers to crowd around and step to the pulse. A singer chants insults in an African language, hoping to anger the santos, or deities, into appearing.

title: Liberian Militias Lay Down Arms and Raise Hopes
description: Outstripping expectations, thousands of fighters from this country's rival militias have been turning in their weapons in recent days in compliance with a disarmament program intended to dissolve Liberia's armed factions formally by the end of this month.

title: With Game on the Line, Holloway Does It Again
description: It took more than 39 minutes for the best point guard to step forward. When he did, it surprised no one.

title: An Element Complicates Conversion Of Plutonium
description: Nuclear weapon scientists say that plutonium the Energy Department wants to take out of surplus bombs and turn into fuel in civilian reactors contains an element that will not only interfere with the conversion but will also cause chemical problems after the fuel is used.

title: $250,000 Buys 'the Best Access to Congress'
description: For elite donors who contributed at least $250,000, the Republican Party offered a new enticement in its gilded invitations to the party's convention in San Diego last summer. Beyond the smorgasbord of perks, like access to the party's private skybox and a photo session with the Republican nominees, the party promised a special benefit: staff members to help with problems in Washington.

title: Patriots Spurn Run, And Shurmur's Moves Prove Much Too Wily
description: One of the biggest concerns of the Patriots' offensive coordinator, Ray Perkins, heading into last evening's showdown with Green Bay was the ability of the Packers' defensive coordinator, Fritz Shurmur, to make adjustments on the fly.

title: Ticketing Roadway Rudeness
description: Drivers heading through Lambertville should mind their manners, says Police Director Al Varga, who has ordered his department to begin a crackdown on rude drivers. Among the offenses in this new category: tailgating, cutting off other drivers, blowing car horns and making obscene hand gestures.

title: No New Rules Seen on Political Donations
description: A leading Republican advocate of campaign finance reform said today that his party probably would not limit political contributions voluntarily, and the new head of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee said the party would not back a bipartisan bill to ban huge ''soft money'' donations.

title: Louise Roberts, 85, Director Of Modern Dance Center, Dies
description: Louise Roberts, who directed the Clark Center for the Performing Arts in Manhattan, died on Jan. 17 at Bellevue Hospital. She was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Said to Step Up Criticism of Germany's Scientology Curbs
description: The United States was reported today to have decided to step up its criticism of Germany for its restrictions on the Church of Scientology.

title: Convict Says He Got Bribe From Prosecutor's Husband
description: An imprisoned former Yonkers official has made allegations to Federal and state authorities that Albert J. Pirro Jr., the husband of the Westchester County District Attorney, paid him a $5,000 bribe in 1992 to speed municipal approvals for a new multiplex movie theater in Yonkers, according to lawyers for the convicted felon and Federal law enforcement officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMEL, MAX
description: TEMEL-Max. The directors and staff of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York extend sincerest condolences to Board Member Charles Temel on the death of his beloved father. May Charles and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Philip Schatten, President David Mann, Executive Vice President Stephen A. Kramer, Chairman of the Board

title: Block Legalization of Casinos
description: Legalizing casino gambling is a lot like betting against the house. Promises of windfall riches are seductive to states. But by the time the risks are revealed, there will be no way to dismantle the gambling trade or pay for the social and economic costs gambling imposes on weakened communities.

title: Devolving History
description: The rush to parcel Federal money into block grants for the states can easily transmogrify into the Beltway's oldest budget game: pulling money from a single worthy recipient and spreading it thinly across scores of Congressional districts. This is now happening to some of the smallest and most efficient expenditures of taxpayer dollars: projects to document the lives and writings of the Founding Fathers.

title: U.S. Shifts Strategy On Balkan Leaders
description: Only a year ago, after the signing of the accord that ended the war in Bosnia, the Clinton Administration viewed the authoritarian leaders of Serbia and Croatia as the guarantors of the peace. Now, it has concluded that their days are numbered, quietly shifting policy and supporting political opponents in the search for a new generation of leaders.

title: Indians' Cruel Winter of Aid Cuts and Cold
description: Arctic winds swirled around Asa Lester's flimsy house, piling drifts to the roof and making it feel like 60 below zero. As his propane supply sputtered to an end, his furnace shut down, leaving Mr. Lester, a wiry Sioux, to face days wrapped in blankets, huddled around a glowing hot plate.

title: Force Flourishes on 'Star Wars' Sites
description: Millions of people have vivid memories of the ''Star Wars'' science fiction adventure movies, the first of which was released 20 years ago. Those awesome special effects. The humming light sabers. The Yoda dolls.

title: Joe Dominguez, 58, Championed A Simple and Frugal Life Style
description: Joe Dominguez, a pioneering author and speaker in the Voluntary Simplicity movement, who urged Americans to relearn the lost art of saving money and to cut their profligate consumption, died of cancer on Jan. 11. He was 58.

title: On Seventh Avenue, It's Still a Squeeze for Traffic
description: The 5- to 10-minute delay yesterday for cars navigating the choppy seas of pavement along Seventh Avenue in Chelsea was a harbinger of greater turmoil to come, as rush hour dawns today before repaving of the street is complete.

title: Treasury Auctions This Week Include Inflation-Indexed Note
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises sales of bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction a new 10-year inflation-indexed note.

title: Independent Films Have Their Sundance Night
description: Two New York stories and one from South Philadelphia were big winners in this snowy mountain town. The top honor for a dramatic film at this year's Sundance Film Festival, the Grand Jury Prize, went to Jonathan Nossiter's ''Sunday,'' a quiet, delicately balanced drama about two people who meet oddly and go on to weave a web of shared illusions. David Suchet plays a dejected homeless man, with Lisa Harrow as the desperate actress who eagerly mistakes him for a famous film maker. ''Sunday'' also won the Waldo Salt Screenwriting Award.

title: Chechens Hail Today's Vote As Step Toward Sovereignty
description: In this village of 7,000 people in the southern Russian republic of Chechnya, two Western election observers sat stiffly in the unexpectedly opulent house of their host, Suliman Akmatov, a businessman who is chairman of the local election commission. They smiled uneasily at their election-eve entourage: the chief of police, his deputy, four other armed guards, and several armed and fierce-looking well-wishers ordered to accompany them on their rounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, IRVING A., D.D.S.
description: GERBER-Irving A., D.D.S. A man of accomplishment and good humor, who excelled at everything he attempted-dentistry, musicianship, athletics and most of all fatherhood. Beloved husband of the late Paula, father of Marc and Terry, grandfather of Lauren Partridge and Michelle Gerber, greatgrandfather of Alexandra Partridge. Services to be held at Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY, 11 AM, Monday, January 27.

title: A Bad-Neighbor Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Bledsoe Gets His Duel, But Then Misfires
description: Drew Bledsoe hesitated only slightly last week when he was asked whether he wanted to get into a shootout with the Green Bay Packers in Super Bowl XXXI.

title: Report of Corrupt Deal by Israeli Officials Is Investigated
description: The Israeli police began an investigation today into a report that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's appointment of a new Attorney General this month was part of a deal to win a plea-bargain for a political ally on trial in a bribery case.

title: Fueled by Anger, Headed for the Border
description: Dean Noble may live in Connecticut, but he no longer buys gasoline there. On a recent trip into Manhattan, Mr. Noble waited until White Plains to fill his tank.

title: Voice of Britain, First Thing Each Day
description: It is hard to imagine a more convincing example of one broadcast's impact on its own culture than the one that recently emerged about Britain's leading news program.

title: No One Comes Close To Catching Jones
description: Steve Jones's so-called duel with David Duval at the Phoenix Open lasted a total of 20 minutes today -- or the time it took Duval to double-bogey the second hole -- and, if not for the fickle cup on the 17th green, Jones's name would be next to Ben Hogan's in the record book.

title: Three Bands Join for a Trip on the Road
description: It's unfortunate, but the Verve Jazz Fest, a touring show of three bands signed to the Verve label that played at Town Hall on Saturday night, can be read as a record company's response to a drop in sales in the jazz world. The label grouped together Charlie Haden's Quartet West, Joe Henderson's trio and the Kansas City All-Star Band and has sent them out on the road to rustle up some business; it is the sort of commendable record company largess that's rarely seen anymore.

title: Arrests at a Crowded Club
description: A surging crowd of about 300 teen-agers hoping to see a performance by a rising pop star caused a few hours of confusion on Saturday outside the Music Factory, an East Rutherford dance club, resulting in two minor injuries, one arrest for disorderly conduct and the cancellation of the concert, the police and the club's manager said.

title: Tension and Dissonance In Tribute to Modernism From the City Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet's latest novelty is ''Schoenberg/Wuorinen Variations,'' a happily serviceable tribute to the modernist esthetic that is unlikely to be confused with ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet,'' a work that was choreographed by George Balanchine in 1966 and, incidentally, is receiving a revitalized performance this season.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded sharply lower here today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 354.46 points, or 2 percent, at 17,334.90. On Friday, the Nikkei sank 220.10 points, or 1.23 percent.

title: W. H. Groverman, 87, Submarine Warfare Expert
description: Rear Adm. William Heald Groverman, a commander in World War II and the Korean War who became one of the leading cold war experts on anti-submarine warfare and Soviet naval forces, died on Dec. 25 at the Peninsula Hospital in Burlingame, Calif. He was 87 and lived in San Mateo, Calif.

title: Huskies Miss Their Starters, And Shots
description: Connecticut demonstrated again today how much it misses its best rebounder, Kirk King, and its leader in assists, Ricky Moore, who have both been suspended for accepting free airline tickets from an agent in the fall of 1995.

title: At Sundance, disappointment over the latest independent films.
description: AT a panel discussion the other morning on the economic state of the independent film business, Jonathan Dana, a veteran producer and movie company executive, opened the session on a Dickensian note: ''It was the best of times; it was the worst of times.'' The crowd of independent film producers, writers and aspiring film makers laughed -- but knew exactly what Mr. Dana meant.

title: Unfamiliar Music Propels a Familiar Tale of a Woman and a War
description: The music written for Brecht's ''Mother Courage'' by Darius Milhaud, which has lain unplayed in manuscript for more than 35 years until now, brings an extraordinarily intimate emotional power to this ferocious antiwar chronicle play. In it, an indomitable woman drags a kind of traveling PX in a cart, along with her three children by three fathers, across Europe for more than a decade during the Thirty Years' War in the 17th century. Brecht has seldom had a more familiar human face than in this production by the Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater, and he has seldom seemed more threatening.

title: Peru Rebels Free an Ailing Hostage but No Sign of Talks Is Seen
description: Red Cross workers wheeled a stretcher carrying an ailing hostage out of the Japanese Ambassador's residence here after midnight Saturday, but there were still no tangible signs today that long-awaited talks with the rebels still holding 72 captives would begin any time soon.

title: With New Year's resolutions about getting into shape still ringing, marketers try to cash in.
description: IT is still early enough in the new year that people who resolved to make this the year to lose weight or stop smoking are eating bagels without the cream cheese or substituting celery sticks for cigarettes.

title: The Fleetest Feet in The Super Bowl Were Fred Astaire's
description: Even when the main event lagged a bit, the viewers of Super Bowl XXXI had the commercials to look forward to. Once again, they were as technically spectacular -- and expensive -- as ever.

description: WEINRAUB-William C. L. Age 49, of Norcross, GA. Beloved husband of Anita Z. Devoted father of Stephanie and brother of Jerome. Graduate of Horace Mann School, Yale University, University of Massachusetts, he was an accomplished businessman, craftsman, musician, and raconteur. His passing leaves a void in all our lives. title: Fox Covered the Game From Every Angle, but the Words Were Not Special
description: Let's get the startling revelation out of the way first: The Fox announcers Pat Summerall and John Madden lip-synced their call of last night's Super Bowl. They taped their words early yesterday morning after James Brown, the Blues Brothers and ZZ Top taped their halftime songs. Summerall and Madden performed better at mouthing their commentary than Brown and ZZ did their songs because they were not encumbered by skintight red suits or peculiar faux hair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, WILFRED R.
description: O'CONNOR-Wilfred R. Judge of the Civil Court, former Director of the Legal Aid Society's Prison Legal Assistants' Program, and former Associate Attorney-In-Charge at the Queens Supreme Court Branch of the Legal Aid Society, on January 23, 1997 at Calvary Hospital. The Board, members and staff of the New York State Defenders Association mourn his death. He was a founding member of our association, who served with distinction as President (1978-1989), and brought us into the spirit by which he lived - pure devotion to the belief that everyone, including the disadvantaged, have a right to the equal protection of the law. Our friend Bill will be greatly missed and we extend to his family our prayers and deep sympathy.

title: Blessing Same-Sex Marriages
description: The Episcopal Diocese of Newark has approved a standard liturgy for blessing same-sex marriages, officially permitting a rite that is already commonplace in scores of its parishes. The resolution, passed after little debate on Saturday by the 600 delegates to the diocese's annual convention in Newark, also urged the national governing body of the 2.4 million-member denomination to develop rites for blessing gay and lesbian unions. According to the resolution, clergy members of the Newark diocese, which includes about 40,000 Episcopalians in northern New Jersey, may decide for themselves whether to perform ceremonies blessing same-sex marriages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUTTON, AUBREY WHITELEY
description: DUTTON-Aubrey Whiteley, age 86, of Brooklyn, NY, on January 25, 1997, in Allentown, Pennsylvania. Born on August 23, 1910 to Lawrence Amor Dutton and Eunice Holt (Whiteley) Dutton at Twin Oaks, Delaware County, Pennsylvania, on a farm owned by the Dutton famly since 1682. Resident of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn since 1916. Graduate of P.S. 99, James Madison High School and Pratt Institute, Class of 1932. Artist and cartoonist whose work appeared in The Saturday Evening Post, Colliers Magazine and other national publications and whose paintings hang in homes and offices all along the Eastern Seaboard, but his greatest role in this life was as the totally devoted and loving husband of fifty-two years of his wife, Ruth M. Dutton (nee Andorfer) and as the extraordinarily caring and nurturing father and best friend of his son, Richard L. Dutton, of West Orange, New Jersey, and his daughter, Barbara L. Dutton, of Allentown, Pennsylvania, by whom he will be greatly missed. He was also loyal and unselfish in his concern for his other relatives and his many longtime friends. Funeral arrangements handled by Horace Schantz Funeral Home, Emmaus, PA; memorial service at later date to be announced. Contributions in his memory to Kings Highway United Methodist Church, Brooklyn, New York, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Art of an Improviser Is Thriving on Chaos
description: IN the control-freak world of the National Football League, which is regimented and inflexible, Brett Favre is viewed with an odd mix of curiosity, suspicion and unrestrained admiration. He is not a textbook kind of guy.

title: On a Day for Mouthing Off, Desmond Howard's Gallops Speak Loudest for Packers
description: Kick returner Desmond Howard is about 180 pounds, which makes him a pipsqueak in football. But there he was after his explosive 31-yard punt return to open the first series for the Green Bay Packers tonight, sticking his face in a group of New England Patriots players and talking trash. One of those players was a 300-pound offensive lineman, Bruce Armstrong. Not exactly a smart thing for Howard to do.

The plan, proposed last week by Mayor James Whelan, comes as the city, which has 13 casinos, is seeing the development of several more.

Beer, who won a gold medal in rowing at the 1956 summer Olympics in Melbourne, Australia, and carried the Olympic torch through Princeton, N.J., last June on its way to the summer Olympics in Atlanta, died on Saturday in a nursing home near Princeton. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, SIDNEY W., JR.
description: DEAN-Sidney W., Jr. The family and friends of Sidney W. Dean, Jr., will always remember him with love as father, friend, mentor and exemplar of a life well lived. He departed this life January 24, at his home in Greenwich Village, age 91. A lifelong champion of civil liberties, active in the Democratic Party and ADA, he was also active in community affairs and served over 30 years as trustee of the City Club of New York. His longtime friend and fellow City Club trustee Joel Harnett praised Sidney's ''almost religious respect for the First Amendment.'' A memorial service will be held Sunday, February 2, time and location to be announced.

description: Gov. George Pataki of New York has a sensible plan to consolidate many children's services that now reside in two agencies. He hopes this will provide more effective help to the state's most troubled children.

title: States Resisting Urge To Use Tax Revenue
description: Five years of economic growth has left state governments flush with money. The restraint are efforts to avoid a painful mix of spending cuts and tax increases in the next business decline.

He was 54 and lived in London.

title: Man Is Beaten and Killed
description: A 48-year-old man found yesterday lying next to his car on a Brooklyn street, severely beaten about the head and with a gunshot wound to his buttocks, died on arrival at Maimonides Medical Center, the police said.

title: Charities Fear Climate of Cynicism Around Poor
description: With the most sweeping changes to American social welfare policy since the New Deal set to take effect in coming months, the leaders of seven of New York City's oldest and largest private social service agencies said last week that they foresee deepening poverty, homelessness and misery among the city's poorest residents.

title: Knicks Players Know Where Loyalty Lies

This was too big a game to risk one of them buttering me up, conning me into a competitive disadvantage.

title: Expelled Student Files Suit

title: Bill to Widen Child Support
description: A bill that would require a divorced parent without custody of his or her children to help pay the cost of their college education is scheduled for a hearing today before the Women's Issues, Children and Family Services Committee of the State Senate. Under the bill, that parent would be required to help pay college bills if the judge in the divorce case determined that he or she would have helped pay for college if the family had stayed together.

title: Mets and Mlicki Reach Agreement
description: The Mets have not had a salary arbitration hearing since 1992, and yesterday they reduced the likelihood of having one this year from three possibilities to two. They reached agreement with DAVE MLICKI on a $610,000 salary, leaving BOBBY JONES and GREG McMICHAEL on their arbitration list.

title: New Paper Chase in Old Scandal Leaves India's Ruling Elite Edgy

The move has also raised potential new problems for Sonia Gandhi, widow of the Prime Minister who oversaw a $1.4 billion deal with Bofors.
