title: In Paris, Men's Wear Sizzles
description: The best news for Paris women's fashion happened not at couture, where it was supposed to, but during the fall men's-wear collections, which ended Sunday night. For the first time since the late 1970's, the body of work shown here by designers was not only deeply creative, but relevant. Retailers, who have resigned themselves to Paris runways as an over-the-top ritual rather than a place to find viable men's fashion, were stunned by the one-season transformation.

Developers rushed in, announcing projects to transform the city from a day-trip destination for gamblers into a Las Vegas-style resort drawing visitors from around the country.

Earlier this month, Home Depot, the home-improvement retailer based in Atlanta, said it would buy the company but did not disclose the purchase price.

title: Corrections

title: Defense Budget's Familiar Ring: Readiness Over New Weapons
description: Since his appointment as Defense Secretary, William S. Cohen has argued that the military needs more money for new hardware and equipment to fight the high-tech battles of the future, even if it means cutting manpower. But Pentagon officials said today that the military budget for the 1998 fiscal year would reflect different priorities, closely following the budgets of the last several years.

title: Honeywell in Deal to Buy Measurex for $600 Million
description: Honeywell Inc., the Minneapolis maker of electronic controls, said yesterday that it would acquire the Measurex Corporation, a Cupertino, Calif., maker of controls for the paper industry, for $600 million in cash. The merger makes Honeywell the leading seller of controls and services for pulp and paper plants.

title: INVACARE PLANS SUIT AGAINST HEALTHDYNE TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Invacare Corporation said yesterday that it would sue Healthdyne Technologies Inc. over Healthdyne's efforts to deflect its hostile takeover bid. Invacare, a medical products company based in Elyria, Ohio, said the suit would seek to force Healthdyne to let its stockholders consider Invacare's offer. Healthdyne officials were not immediately available for comment. On Friday, Invacare sweetened its offer to $169.5 million after its earlier $163 million takeover bid was rejected as ''grossly inadequate.'' Invacare already owns a 4.9 percent stake in Healthdyne, which is based in Marietta, Ga., and also makes medical products. Invacare's new offer, at $13 a share, is still below Healthdyne's current trading price. Shares of Healthdyne rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $14.625. Invacare fell 25 cents, to $27.50.

title: AT&T Is Venturing Cautiously Into Local Telephone Business
description: The AT&T Corporation announced its first significant foray into the local telephone business yesterday. But the modest scope of its two new services underscored that AT&T was tiptoeing into this $100 billion market, even a year after it was thrown open to competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, BERTHA S.
description: NEWHOUSE-Bertha S. I wish to express our faculty's sadness on the occasion of the death of our long time and esteemed colleague, Bertha S. Newhouse. Her illustrious career ending as a Professor of Accounting began in 1946 and lasted until her retirement in 1985. She was the first woman CPA to teach in the School, to reach the rank of full professor in accountancy, and to serve as associate dean in the School of Business. We who knew her remember her as a dedicated colleague and friend. We offer our condolences to her beloved husband Roy Newhouse, her children Lina and Martin and her five grandchildren. Sidney I. Lirtzman, Dean Baruch School of Business Baruch College, CUNY

description: IN the culture of hockey, the handshake line exists for only one thing, and that is shaking hands at the end of a playoff series. Hard feelings are left at the buzzer -- or at least not carried out to center ice.

description: When New Jersey plays Cleveland Tuesday night at Continental Arena, all of the Nets will be there. For most teams, that would not be such a strange occurrence. But for the injury riddled Nets, it will be something that they have not experienced all season.

title: U.S. Report Rebukes China Over Rights
description: By the end of 1996, there were no active dissidents left in China who had not been jailed or exiled, Clinton Administration officials said today, describing the conclusion they reached for the United States Government's annual report on human rights conditions.

title: Police Say Curfew Worked
description: When the Jersey City Council announced plans to enforce a long-ignored curfew for minors, skeptics abounded. But yesterday, Michael F. Moriarty, the police director, said juvenile arrests fell 21 percent for the first three months after the curfew went into effect on Oct. 7, compared with the same period in the previous year.

title: Why Those Hidden Cameras Hurt Journalism
description: When a North Carolina jury took a swipe at hidden-camera television exposes last week, the press mostly circled the wagons and declared it a travesty. But what the Fourth Estate is defending is shoddy journalism, unworthy of the best tradition of investigative reporting.

title: RAYTHEON CONSORTIUM GETS $262 MILLION CONTRACT
description: A consortium led by the Raytheon Company received a $262 million contract to plan and build an iron-production plant in Guayana City, Venezuela, the company said yesterday. Raytheon, which is based in Lexington, Mass., and has defense electronics, engineering and other units, said it would be responsible for around 70 percent of the work. The plant, which has an estimated total cost of $378 million, is scheduled to be completed by mid-1999. The consortium also includes Posco Engineering and Construction, a unit of South Korea's Pohang Iron and Steel Company, which is the majority shareholder in the joint venture. Other shareholders include South Korea's Hyundai Corporation.

title: Tappan Zee Car Toll To Rise to $3 in July
description: Tolls for automobiles on the Tappan Zee Bridge will rise by 50 cents, to $3, in July, but the 40-cent toll for cars at Spring Valley, seven miles north of the bridge, will be eliminated, state officials announced today.

title: INSIDE
description: Simpson Case Winds Down

title: Chess
description: Garry Kasparov upheld his dominance of the chess world in December by winning the power-packed Las Palmas International Tournament on Grand Canary Island. Kasparov scored 6 1/2-3 1/2 in the double-round event.

title: For One Miner, the Old Ways Are the Only Ways
description: Anyone who has watched old Western movies or visited deserted mining towns in the Rockies has probably seen 25-foot-tall wooden frames standing over mine shafts, with huge pulleys near the top for bringing up buckets of ore.

title: Chechens Crowd Polling Places in a Vote for 'Freedom'
description: Voters pushed and jostled in crowded polling places all over the secessionist republic of Chechnya on Monday with the kind of anxious zeal usually reserved for airport check-ins and white sales at Macy's.

title: All Welfare Is Local

title: At a 'Tax Free' Pep Rally, Giuliani Claims Clothing Sales Almost Doubled
description: With a good deal more enthusiasm than hard economic data, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went to a pep rally sponsored by a large retailer yesterday to claim that clothing sales in New York City almost doubled last week when the sales tax was eliminated as a brief experiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIGH, CHARLES R., JR.
description: SLIGH-Charles R., Jr. The Directors and Staff of the Deafness Research Foundation note with sorrow the passing on January 25th in Delray Beach, Fl, of its former Chairman, benefactor and loyal friend. Mr. Sligh was former Chairman of the Sligh Furniture Co. of Grand Rapids, MI and former President of the Natioanl Association of Manufacturers. He will be greatly missed. We extend our sympathies to his widow and his family. Collette Ramsey-Baker, Founder, DRF

title: Banning 'Drive-By' Surgery
description: The State Senate unanimously passed a package of bills yesterday that would prohibit ''drive-by'' mastectomies. Under the legislation, health insurance companies would be forced to pay for a woman to remain in the hospital for 72 hours after a radical mastectomy and 48 hours after a simple mastectomy. The bills would not apply to women who were covered by out-of-state insurance firms.

title: Republicans Find Fault With Nominee For C.I.A. Post
description: In a shot across the bow of Anthony Lake's nomination as Director of Central Intelligence, House Republicans tonight sharply criticized Mr. Lake, President Clinton's first-term national security adviser, for his execution of a secret policy to stand silent as Iran shipped arms to Bosnian Muslims in 1994.

title: Political and Corporate Elite Soak Up Big Ideas at Davos
description: This Alpine ski resort will be the place to be starting Jan. 30 -- at least for the likes of Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman, and John F. Welch, the head of General Electric. Speaker Newt Gingrich will also be there, rubbing elbows with Boris A. Berezovsky, Boris N. Yeltsin's deputy national security chief and one of the most powerful executives in Moscow, and Kofi Annan, the new United Nations Secretary General.

title: Swiss Envoy to U.S. Resigns After His Report on Holocaust Dispute Is Disclosed
description: Switzerland's Ambassador to the United States resigned today after the publication of a long diplomatic cable in which he advised his Government to make up its mind about how to deal with disclosures about its role as banker to Nazi Germany, and concluded with a warning that ''this is a war which Switzerland must conduct on the foreign and domestic front, and must win.''

title: Mrs. Bissell Must Start Term
description: Barbara Bissell, the widow of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the former Somerset County Prosecutor, must begin her 27-month prison sentence on Thursday, a Federal judge ruled yesterday. The judge, Alfred J. Lechner Jr., turned down Mrs. Bissell's request to remain free on bail while she appeals her conviction on fraud and tax evasion charges.

title: Baiul Applies for Court's Alcohol Program
description: Oksana Baiul, the Olympic skating champion who was arrested for reckless and drunken driving earlier this month, sought to have the charges dismissed today by applying for an alcohol education program and volunteering to appear in a public service advertising campaign about the dangers of alcohol.

title: National Semiconductor to Shed Fairchild
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell a majority interest in its Fairchild Semiconductor business to a group led by Fairchild management and Sterling L.L.C, a unit of Citicorp, for $550 million in cash.

description: The Cali Realty Corporation, a rapidly expanding owner of suburban office buildings, said it had agreed to acquire the Robert Martin Company, which owns 4.1 million square feet of office and industrial property in Westchester County and Fairfield County, Conn.

title: France to Look for Property Stolen From Jews in World War II
description: Pursuing its belated confrontation with its collaborationist past under Nazi occupation, France has announced the formation of a committee to identify and locate property stolen from Jewish families during World War II.

title: An Invitation To City Police: Try City Life
description: BEFORE the salary tussle between City Hall and the police rank and file gets any nastier, is there room for a stray thought? Perhaps this dispute would not have reached a crisis point in the first place if New York City's uniformed forces were required to live in town.

description: It was three weeks ago when Don Sutton, the only 300-game winner eligible for baseball's Hall of Fame but not yet elected, learned that he had missed induction by a painfully small nine-vote margin.

title: Hilton Makes $6.5 Billion Bid for ITT
description: In a move that took the hotel and gambling industries by surprise, the Hilton Hotels Corporation made an unsolicited $6.5 billion takeover offer yesterday for the ITT Corporation. The acquisition would make Hilton the largest hotel and gambling company in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMEL, MAX

title: Friend of Crown Heights Suspect Says He Confessed
description: A former girlfriend of Lemrick Nelson Jr.'s testified at his trial yesterday that he had told her that he stabbed the Hasidic man who was killed during a period of racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991.

title: For Packers, 1 Wedge of Cheese at a Time
description: As the National Football League's champions, the Packers took the Vince Lombardi Trophy back to Green Bay today. Now they have to find a way to keep it.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Hunter College students ought to have no difficulty recognizing BRIAN LAMB, who will deliver the address at the winter commencement this afternoon at the school, on East 69th Street.

title: MARVEL EXPECTS BIG LOSSES FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
description: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. said yesterday that it would post huge losses for the fourth quarter and the year, mostly because of $350 million to $385 million in costs related to the revamping of its trading card division. Marvel, the comic-book publisher based in New York, expects to report a fourth-quarter loss of about $405 million to $440 million, or $4 to $4.35 a share, and a full-year loss of $435 million to $470 million, or $4.25 to $4.60 a share. Even before the charges, Marvel said that its earnings would be lower than expected because of weak results from its operations and reorganization expenses related to its Dec. 27 bankruptcy filing.

title: Edith Hurd, 86, Who Introduced The Planet to Young Readers
description: Edith Thacher Hurd, whose books on subjects from the earth to whales to firemen reached several generations of readers learning their way around the printed page, died on Saturday in Walnut Creek, Calif. She was 86.

title: The Secretary Is Tough
description: On Jan. 22 and 23, the world press reported that Beijing was moving swiftly now in Hong Kong, getting ready to cancel basic freedoms when Communist China takes over from Britain on July l.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONSKY, MARILYN
description: DONSKY-Marilyn. Happy birthday, Sweetie. You are the brightest star in the heavens. We love you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DROOZ, RICHARD, M.D.
description: DROOZ-Richard, M.D. Passed on Friday, January 24th. Survived by his beloved wife, Miriam. Dr. Drooz, psychoanalyst and psychiatrist, will be remembered for his brilliance as an academician, clinician, teacher, mentor, and for his kind, generous spirit. He will be greatly missed. Neither he nor his words of wisdom will ever be forgotten. Marla F. Wald, M.D. Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDLER, ADOLPH

title: Tough Georgia Summer For Adolescent Tomboy
description: Television returns once again, tomorrow night on USA, to ''The Member of the Wedding,'' Carson McCullers's classic 1946 tale of painful adolescence. The first stage production was a triumph, with the roles of the black cook and two white children played by Ethel Waters, Julie Harris and Brandon de Wilde. A 1982 television version adapted by Miss McCullers for ''NBC Live Theater'' starred Pearl Bailey and Dana Hill. It was produced by David W. Rintels, who is the writer and producer of this new version, directed by another distinguished television veteran, Fielder Cook.

title: Guilty Plea in Mob Case
description: Gennaro Dellamonica had a problem. A Russian fuel dealer in Woodbridge wanted to do business with a company that refused to pay tribute to the Gambino crime family, of which Mr. Dellamonica is a member, prosecutors said. Mr. Dellamonica tried to dissuade the fuel dealer from doing business with the company. So in May 1992, Mr. Dellamonica admitted yesterday in Federal court, he or his associates punched the dealer and destroyed his telephone and computer equipment.

title: Cosby Embraces Dignity, Then Laughter
description: In a two-and-a-half hour interview with Dan Rather, his first since the killing of his son, Ennis, Bill Cosby spoke of his family's anguish and said that he and his wife wanted to be able to grieve with dignity.

title: Noel Keane, 58, Lawyer in Surrogate Mother Cases, Is Dead
description: Noel Keane, a lawyer who became a focus of deep affection and bitter debate for arranging surrogate motherhoods, including the one that led to the Baby M battle in 1986, died on Sunday at his home in Dearborn, Mich. He was 58.

title: In the Utah Wilderness, A Question of Definition
description: Some Utah environmentalists, when they want a dose of activism, hike into the remote red canyons in the southern part of the state to look at roads that they say are not really there.

title: Cosby Seeks Dignity, And Some Laughter
description: In his first interview since the killing of his son, Ennis, Bill Cosby spoke of his family's anguish and said that he wanted to be able to grieve with dignity and still provide laughter.

title: State Attorneys General Urge Limits on Campaign Spending
description: The top law-enforcement officials of 24 states are calling for the reversal of a 1976 Supreme Court decision that equated limits on political-campaign spending with limits on free speech and thereby undid some of the spending curbs enacted after the Watergate scandals.

title: Undaunted By Failure, Balloonists Vow to Try Again
description: WITH another season of failures behind them but still fired by passionate faith in the possibility of flying nonstop around the world, balloonists are betting that many small improvements in technology will add up to victory in the next few years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAKAKJIAN, BECKMANN, MARY E.

Friends will be received on Tuesday from 2-4 and 6-8 PM at the Babione Funeral Home in Boca Raton, FL. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday at 11:00 AM with the Rev. Anthony Osimo officiating at Babione Funeral Home.

title: Du Pont Was Insane or Scheming, Lawyers Say
description: John E. du Pont was a manipulator who thought he could get away with murder, prosecutors told jurors today in opening statements of Mr. du Pont's trial in the murder of the wrestler David Schultz.

description: The Knicks have won their last 14 home games. Tonight, they play host to the Boston Celtics, one of the worst teams in the National Basketball Association.

title: Woodchucks Are in the Lab, but Their Body Clocks Are Wild
description: THERE are no wild woodchucks in Australia; like Groundhog Day, which will occur on Sunday, the plump, low-slung animals are a North American invention. But there are woodchucks at Cornell University that behave as if they lived Down Under, and others that are convinced the year is eight months long.

title: Ruins in Yemeni Desert Mark Route of Frankincense Trade
description: EXPLORING the remote back country of Yemen, over hills and through wadis, a party of archeologists this month came upon ruins and monuments from the time when frankincense and myrrh were among the world's most coveted commodities. Here were lithic memories of a happily prosperous epoch in the land known to the Romans as Arabia Felix.

title: 2 Southern Utilities Make Assignments

title: Mammograms -- or Not -- at Age 40
description: The muddled message from a panel of experts last week on whether women in their 40's should have mammograms to detect breast cancer is probably an accurate reflection of the muddled state of the scientific findings. For this is a case where it is devilishly difficult to be certain of the risks and benefits. The panel, convened by the National Institutes of Health, concluded that mammograms might indeed save a very small percentage of women from death. But it warned that such mammograms might also harm some women through radiation or by leading to unnecessary surgery or false complacency.

title: Uneasy Ghosts and Reveries

Like Meg Stuart, one of her choreographic collaborators here, Ms. Green does not take prisoners. title: WISCONSIN CENTRAL BUYS UNION PACIFIC TRACK
description: The Wisconsin Central Transportation Corporation said yesterday that a subsidiary had completed the purchase of 220 miles of track in northern Wisconsin and Michigan from the Union Pacific Corporation for about $85 million. Wisconsin Central, which is based in Rosemont, Ill., said its Sault Ste. Marie Bridge Company unit also acquired contiguous property and related track facilities. The tracks, known as the Green Bay North Lines, serve the paper and steel industries. Wisconsin Central shares fell $1.75 to close yesterday at $39. Shares of Union Pacific, with headquarters in Bethlehem, Pa., rose 12.5 cents, to $62.50.

title: ENERGY GROUP LOOKING FOR ACQUISITION IN AMERICA

Energy Group laid out the plan in its prospectus for the Feb. 24 spinoff. It plans to create a British-American company with a market value of about $:2.3 billion ($3.7 billion) that will include its Peabody Coal Company unit, which is the largest coal miner in the United States. Energy Group executives said that deal would lay the groundwork for a broad push to become a marketer and supplier of power in the United States as deregulation opens the industry to competition.

title: SEARS DROPS OFFER FOR REMAINING MAXSERV SHARES
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday it had withdrawn its $23 million offer to acquire the 35.6 percent of the publicly traded information-services provider Maxserv Inc. it did not already own. In a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chicago-based Sears said Maxserv's board had evaluated the proposal and decided it would not accept the $7-a-share bid. Sears said it was unlikely that it would agree on a price with Maxserv, of Austin, Tex. Maxserv officials could not be reached for comment. Maxserv shares closed down 75 cents, or 11 percent, to $6 a share. Sears dipped 25 cents, to $47.375.

title: Too Little Leadership

He also reaffirmed his support for bipartisan campaign-finance reform legislation introduced by Senators John McCain and Russell Feingold and Representatives Christopher Shays and Martin Meehan. But given several chances to establish himself as a bold leader in the drive for cleaner politics, Mr. Clinton fell short, ceding the field to Congress while offering a series of defensive rationalizations for his party's sleazy behavior.

title: Facts Are Facts

title: EAGLE FINANCIAL IN STOCK DEAL FOR MIDCONN BANK
description: The Eagle Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Midconn Bank for about $49 million in stock. Eagle Financial said it would exchange 0.86 share for each Midconn share. Shares of Midconn rose 16 percent, or $3.50, to $23.50. Eagle Financial stock was unchanged at $29.25. Midconn, which is based in Berlin, Conn., has $363 million in assets and 10 branch offices in central Connecticut. Eagle Financial, based in Bristol, Conn., had loans of $829 million, deposits of $1.1 billion and equity of $105 million as of Dec. 31.

title: Apple Juice With Grown-Up Fizz
description: CIDER, which slaked America's thirst a couple of centuries ago the way Coca-Cola does today, is becoming familiar again. The cider in question, though, is not plain apple juice, but hard cider, the golden, fizzy, lightly alcoholic quaff that is made by fermenting apple juice.

title: MCI Earnings Up Despite Lag in Long-Distance Business
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 6.7 percent on strong sales of data communications and other services, although the company's long-distance business expanded at its slowest pace in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WUNDERLICK, JACK
description: WUNDERLICK-Jack. 83 years old. On January 27, 1997 in San Diego. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted father of Beth and Frank Wal and Lewis and Sharon. Services 10am Wednesday at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURCHEN, STEVEN
description: TURCHEN-Steven. On January 23, 1997. Of San Diego, Calif., formerly of NYC. Age 39. Beloved husband of Tina. Loving son of Cynthia Richmond and the late Abe Turchen. Brother of David Turchen and the late Michael Turchen. Nephew of Barbara and Ed Simpson. Cousin of Gary, Andrea and Robert. He is deeply loved by all of us and will be greatly missed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a takeover offer by the Hilton Hotels Corporation for the ITT Corporation referred incorrectly in one instance to the number of casinos owned by ITT. It is 14, not 16.

title: Cellular One is taking the phone out of the briefcase and putting it in the backpack.
description: CONCERNED about more competition on the horizon, Cellular One is reaching out in all directions for customers in a new campaign this week that humorously suggests unusual uses for cellular phones.

title: Ford to Sponsor New Theater on 42d Street
description: With 42d Street turning more and more into Main Street, U.S.A., it was probably only a matter of time before the Ford Motor Company came rumbling along.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, DOROTHEA. (NEE OBERKEWITZ)
description: KATZ-Dorothea. (Nee Oberkewitz). Professor Emeritus, educator, lifetime community service. Chairperson of the Department of Physical Sciences of New York City Technical College of CUNY from 1983 to 1986. She began to serve on the faculty in 1959 of the then innovative concept of public community college as instructor, and continued into professorship and then to chair the department. Professor Katz contributed to the movement of women in science education. She is survived by her husband Leon, two sisters, four children, and five grandchildren. Services today, Wednesday, January 29, 12:00 noon at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave (at 10 St), NY, NY

title: National Campaign For New York Times
description: A national campaign for The New York Times will begin on Sunday, the Times Company said yesterday. The campaign, with a budget of $20 million, is part of efforts to build a broad brand image for The Times as it undertakes significant expansion plans this year that include new editions for readers in New England and the Washington area. Television, radio and print ads will carry the theme ''Expect the world.'' The campaign was created by the newspaper's longtime agency, Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in New York.

title: Donald E. Stokes, 69, Leading Political Scientist
description: Donald E. Stokes, a leading political scientist and former dean of Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, died on Sunday in a Philadelphia hospital. He was 69 and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: CITIZENS BANKING TO MERGE WITH CB FINANCIAL
description: The Citizens Banking Corporation agreed to acquire the CB Financial Corporation for $130 million in stock in a bid to gain customers and cut costs. The combination will create a bank with $4.31 billion in assets, shareholder equity of $390 million and 95 branches in Michigan and suburban Chicago. Citizens, of Flint, Mich., will issue 4.17 million shares, or 1.489 shares for each CB Financial share, giving the transaction a value of about $130.3 million at Citizens' closing price of $31.75. CB Financial, which is based in Jackson, Mich., has 29 branches. Its shares rose 50 cents, to $41.50.

title: Money Pours Into the Stock Mutual Funds
description: Mutual fund investors, showing few signs of wariness in their pursuit of the outstanding returns offered by the stock market over the last two years, have poured money into equity funds at a near-record pace so far this month.

title: Use of Mass Transit Increases
description: More New Jerseyans are riding trains and buses, officials said yesterday. From July through November, the number of passengers on New Jersey Transit trains rose by 6 percent over the same period last year, and the number of bus riders rose by 3.3 percent, the agency reported.

title: Give 2 Hugs and Call Him in the Morning
description: The supermodel Frederique threw the supertherapist John Gray for a loop on Monday night.

title: Hilton Bid for ITT Wins Wall St. Praise
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation's $6.5 billion bid for the ITT Corporation excited Wall Street yesterday as Hilton's shares jumped 10 percent, an unusual move for the stock of an acquiring company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, GERALD
description: MARKS-Gerald, songwriter, died on January 27, 1997 in New York City. The passing of the wonderful man who composed ''All of Me'' is a sad occasion for all of us-his friends and colleagues at ASCAP. Few have served the Society and the song writing profession with the devotion and charm of Gerald Marks, a former member of the ASCAP Board and a beloved member of the ASCAP family since 1931. ''Your goodbye left us with eyes that cry.'' Marilyn Bergman President & Chairman ASCAP

title: Wine Talk
description: FROM what one reads and hears, it would not be at all difficult to conclude that the wine business is in a nearly permanent state of crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANZ, SALLY
description: GANZ-Sally, on January 27th, 1997. The Whitney Museum of American Art notes with great sadness the passing of Sally Ganz, beloved wife of the late Victor W. Ganz, a former Trustee and Vice President of the Museum. Together with her husband, she was a true friend and a generous benefactor. We extend our deepest sympathies to their children and grandchildren. She will be missed by all. Whitney Museum of American Art Flora M. Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Gilbert C. Maurer, President David A. Ross, Alice Pratt Brown Director

title: PRESIDENT REGRETS TOP U.S. REGULATOR MET WITH BANKERS
description: President Clinton acknowledged today that the White House should not have included the nation's senior banking regulator in a coffee session last spring where Mr. Clinton and prominent bankers discussed banking policy in the presence of the Democratic Party's senior fund-raiser.

title: A Consensus Is Sought On Coding
description: The Clinton Administration's top overseas representative on cryptography -- or data scrambling -- told a group of skeptical computer industry executives and technical experts today that important allies support the Administration's position that governments should have access-coded computer files and digital communications.

title: Budget From Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Balanced-Budget Politics
description: The House Republicans pledged an early vote on the balanced-budget amendment in part to bolster their wounded Speaker by giving him a quick victory. But the two-thirds majority that Newt Gingrich and his allies thought they had may be slipping away, a reflection of Mr. Gingrich's diminished control and the 10-seat electoral swing to the Democrats. The outcome is also uncertain in the Senate, where the first committee vote is scheduled for this week.

title: Clinton Toughens Stand On Changing Constitution
description: With the issue at the top of the Congressional docket, President Clinton took his strongest stand ever today against a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget.

title: Wells Won't Face Charges Over Fight
description: David Wells finally found relief yesterday when the San Diego County District Attorney's office decided not to file felony assault charges against the newest Yankee pitcher for his participation in a street scuffle on Jan. 12.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. JO IVEY BOUFFORD knows a thing or two about government and policy making, so she seems a logical choice for a position directing the education of future policy makers.

title: Palestinian Held in U.S. May Halt Fight On Extradition
description: A leader of the militant Palestinian faction called Hamas intends to drop his challenge to a Federal court decision to extradite him to Israel to face terrorism charges, the State Department said today.

title: Once More, a Jury Will Decide Whether Simpson Was the Killer
description: For the second time in 16 months, a California jury was charged today with deciding whether Orenthal James Simpson was responsible for the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman.

title: The Rainbow Finds a Voice That Rarely Speaks of Itself
description: ''I USE a Sony,'' said Anna Deavere Smith, the actress and playwright, as she waited for a reporter's tape recorder to get up to speed. ''A professional one like the ones the guys, reporters, use, but even then something can go wrong. What's terrifying to me is that notes won't help me because I have to have the real voice. You're so embarrassed to be calling again.''

title: Cross-Franchising
description: New Yorkers may have accepted cross-dressing at tableside, but is the rest of America ready for McDrag? Lucky Cheng's thinks so.

title: Childs Comes To Rescue For Knicks
description: It was bad enough that the Knicks played poorly. To make matters worse, Patrick Ewing pulled a groin muscle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, ANNA
description: ROSENBLUM-Anna. Loving wife of the late Robert. Adored mother of Marcia Saperstein and David Robinson. Also survived by 4 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. Services I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, L.I. 12:15PM Thursday.

title: G.M. Says Profits Fell Throughout 1996
description: Weighed down by some of the heaviest strike-related losses ever suffered by an American company, the General Motors Corporation announced today that its profits fell in the fourth quarter and for all of 1996 from a year earlier.

title: Focus on Lawyers' Wives in Police Union Case
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have subpoenaed documents related to a police insurance contract held by the wives of two police union lawyers who were indicted last week on racketeering charges, according to lawyers familiar with the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUDO, SAM
description: PLUDO-Sam. Special friend, wise counsel, dear brother and beloved uncle. We will miss you forever. All our love, Frances, Jimmy and the Becker family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREYFUS, HATTIE NEE RAUNHEIM
description: DREYFUS-Hattie nee Raunheim, 92, of Mamaroneck, N.Y. on January 28, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Erwin Dreyfus. Loving aunt of Susan Meadow, John Raunheim, Jane and Dan Philip, Terry and Jim Dreyfus, Janet and Joel Gray, and several grandnieces and grandnephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIN, JOHN
description: PIN-John. Extraordinary chef at Camp Idylwold for 30 years. A dedicated professional as well as a fine human being and dear friend. The Edelman Family

title: Duke Charity Names Chief
description: The newly formed Doris Duke Charitable Foundation yesterday named Joan Edelman Spero, the Under Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, as its first president and set to the task of dispensing at least $17.3 million a year in grants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DROOZ, RICHARD B.
description: DROOZ-Richard B. The Mount Sinai Alumni records with sorrow the passing of their longtime colleague and friend. His dedication as a clinician, teacher and colleague has earned him the respect of the alumni and all who knew him. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Albert M. Lefkovits, M.D., Pres. Alisan B. Goldfarb, M.D., Sec'y.

title: Cantor Fitzgerald Agrees to Settle With U.S.
description: Regulators said today that Cantor Fitzgerald & Company had agreed to pay a $500,000 fine to settle charges it assisted fraud committed by the First Republic Financial Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, DR. WERNER
description: WEINBERG-Dr. Werner. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of Dr. Werner Weinberg. Professor Emeritus of Hebrew Language and Literature, Dr. Weinberg served with distinction on the Cincinnati Campus for over three decades. He was widely regarded as a scholar of Hebrew orthography and an author of books on Hebrew literature, medieval Hebrew poetry and Moses Mendelssohn. A survivor of Bergen-Belsen an author of Self-Portrait of a Holocaust Survivor, Dr. Weinberg dedicated his life to bear witness to the Holocaust and to the education of generations of rabbinic and graduate students at HUC-JIR. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughter, Mrs. Susie Konicov and family whose loss we deeply share. May his memory be for a blessing. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, President Burton Lehman, Chairman, Board of Governors

title: Howard Is Finding That There's No Rest for the Speedy
description: Besides the phone messages seeking his speedy appearance (literally and figuratively) from people and places as diverse as Disney World and David Letterman to ''NBC Nightly News,'' where he will be featured as Hero of the Week, Desmond Howard also hears something else: play-by-plays of his remarkable kickoff and punt returns in Super Bowl XXXI.

title: Citic Pacific to Buy Hong Kong Utility Stake
description: Citic Pacific Ltd., China's largest investment company in Hong Kong, said yesterday that it would pay $16.25 billion (Hong Kong), or $2.1 billion (United States), for a fifth of the territory's biggest power utility, China Light and Power.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When the Republicans lost the White House in 1992, Capitol Steps, a theatrical troupe made up of former Congressional aides, was concerned about the disappearance of Dan Quayle from the scene. The group puts on musical revues poking fun at politicians and other public figures.

title: There's a new scheme afoot for getting, and then using, hotel guests' credit card numbers.
description: THE latest scheme aimed at travelers involves people telephoning hotel guests in their rooms late at night, saying they are members of the hotel staff, and asking guests' credit card numbers. Those unwary enough to fall for the trick soon find charges on their billing statement for purchases they never made.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Major Developments:

title: New President of the N.A.S.D. Is Named
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the Nasdaq stock market and regulates the conduct of securities firms and individual stockbrokers, named Frank G. Zarb as its new president yesterday.

title: 3-Company Pact on Internet Technology
description: The 3Com Corporation, the Cascade Communications Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation are cooperating in an effort to provide systems that will speed access to the Internet and intranets.

title: Mira Ziminska-Sygietynska, 96, a Singer
description: Mira Ziminska-Sygietynska, a founder of Mazowsze, the Polish State Folk Song and Dance Ensemble, died on Sunday in Warsaw. She was 96.

title: In Performance: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Leon Botstein Introduces

title: INSIDE
description: New Bonds Go on Sale

title: After A Hush, A Gleam: Russian Jewels In U.S.
description: Few blockbuster exhibitions have popped into view as suddenly as ''Jewels of the Romanovs: Treasures of the Russian Imperial Court,'' the jewel-studded display of art and artifacts that opens here on Wednesday at the Corcoran Gallery of Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, THOMAS
description: LEAHY-Thomas, on January 27, 1997. Native of Co. Limerick, Ireland. Devoted husband of the late Lillian (nee Barry). Beloved father of Thomas P. and the late Noreen. Reposing Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (207th St.), Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Mother Cabrini Shrine, 701 Ft. Washington Avenue (190th St.), Friday, 10:00 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Cancer Research Institute, 1225 Park Ave. N Y, N Y 10128.

title: History of a Nation in Its Song to Itself
description: When one concert asks the question, ''What Is American Music?,'' a partial answer is the best anyone can expect. On Saturday night, that concert inaugurated Project America at the 92d Street Y: a series, stretching into the millennium, of performances, lectures and discussions about American identity. Music is one way to map that identity.

title: And You Thought Recovery Was Serious Business
description: Tupac Shakur, who was 25 when he died last September, played one of his last roles in ''Gridlock'd,'' a smart, well-made buddy film about two junkies desperate to kick the habit. In a successful change of pace, Mr. Shakur played the straight man to Tim Roth's more unhinged character, Stretch, a hotheaded honky who often needs to be reminded, for the sake of his own safety, that he isn't black. Mr. Shakur's Spoon spends a lot of time doing damage control for Stretch and persuading him to pipe down.

title: Mob Fighter Named Chief of Javits Center as It Switches Focus to Growth
description: Gerald T. McQueen, a veteran police executive and specialist in organized crime who has been a central figure in the fight against corruption at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, was nominated to be the center's chief executive yesterday. The nomination comes as the center shifts its focus from fighting mob influence to expanding its marketability and size.

title: Bill Cosby Unplugged
description: It is tragedy enough, you'd think, when a young man of apparently boundless promise loses his life in a senseless murder -- or when any parent loses a child. But when Ennis Cosby was shot in Los Angeles, that wasn't tragedy enough for the American culture of celebrity, in which every headline event must be inflated into an unambiguous, though often fictional, morality play that will make us feel better about our own pathetically humdrum little lives.

title: Agencies Set Up Marketing Groups
description: Two agencies have formed units specializing in automotive advertising and marketing communications.

title: MONSANTO OFFERS $218 MILLION FOR REST OF CALGENE
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it had offered $218 million, or $7.25 a share, for the Calgene Inc. stock that it did not already own. Monsanto, based in St. Louis, has owned shares in Calgene since mid-1995 and recently increased its holding to 54.6 percent. Calgene, an agricultural biotechnology company that developed the first genetically engineered tomato, has been struggling with high development costs and low tomato prices. In November, it reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $17.9 million. The company is developing other bioengineered products such as canola oil and cottonseed. Shares of Calgene, of Davis, Calif., rose 56 cents yesterday, to $5.50, while Monsanto gained $1.25, to $37.875.

title: Accounts
description: * Bausch & Lomb eyewear division, Rochester, to Bozell Worldwide, New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, as agency of record for its worldwide Ray-Ban sunglasses account, with billings estimated at $40 million. The assignment had been expected since last month, when Bausch & Lomb and Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, the Ray-Ban agency for six months, parted ways. Bozell also handles Bausch & Lomb skin-care brands like Curel.

title: Study of Bias in Death Penalty
description: Since capital punishment was restored in New Jersey in 1982, the death penalty has been imposed in roughly equal numbers on black defendants and those of other races, according to a report commissioned by the State Supreme Court that was released yesterday.

title: Dow Roars to Early Gains But Finishes the Day Lower
description: After four days of declines, the major stock market indexes jumped about 1.5 percent yesterday only to give up the gains in a late-afternoon selloff.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS TO SELL GROUND SERVICES UNIT
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that it planned to sell its ground fleet services unit to Ryder System Inc., another step in the British airline's plan to spin off nonessential businesses. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The unit, which employs 500 people, provides specialized ground equipment and leases vehicles to airlines at London's Heathrow and Gatwick airports. BA said it had notified staff of the sale to Ryder P.L.C., a unit of Miami-based Ryder that rents and leases vehicles. British Airways said it planned to award Ryder a five-year contract to provide services.

title: Jet Order to Bombardier
description: Bombardier Inc. said today that it had received 12 firm orders and 36 options for Canadair Series 200-ER regional jets from Atlantic Coast Airlines Inc. The value of the 12 firm orders is more than $240 million. Bombardier said deliveries of the 50-seat jet would begin in July and continue through September 1998. Atlantic Coast is a regional carrier based in Sterling, Va.

title: ITT Expected To Fight Off Bid by Hilton
description: ITT, the recipient of an unsolicited $6.5 billion takeover offer from the Hilton Hotels Corporation on Monday, is expected to fight the overture, analysts said yesterday.

title: Look in the Body? Easy. What It Means? Hard.
description: ''Doctors With X-Ray Vision,'' tonight's clear-eyed offering from ''The New Explorers,'' gives us a look at our insides from the vantage point of radiologists using smart new detectors that can spot cancers and other once-hidden killers while they are still treatable. On a visit to the University of Illinois at Chicago Medical Center, Bill Kurtis is introduced to the workings of ultrasound; M.R.I.'s, or magnetic resonance imaging, and CAT scans, known to technicians as computerized axial tomography.

title: Face-to-Face Encounter On Race in the Theater
description: It was billed as a discussion but sounded like a debate and, at times, a good old-fashioned argument. The playwright August Wilson and the critic Robert Brustein, symbolically entering from the opposite sides of the stage at Town Hall on Monday night, delivered an evening of passion, principle and drama as they addressed the racial politics of the American theater.

title: Accord on Welfare Offices
description: The major issue that has stalled the legislation to put new restrictions on welfare recipients has been resolved, state officials said yesterday. The bills are scheduled to be voted on in the Assembly today.

title: Trade Center Sweetens Deal to Keep Brokerage Firm
description: After flirting with New Jersey, Cantor Fitzgerald, a major institutional-bond brokerage firm and provider of financial information services, has decided to remain at 1 World Trade Center and expand its space. The company has leased an additional 75,000 square feet, bringing its total in the building to 175,000 square feet. The deal involves New York City tax incentives, including sales tax relief, valued at about $2 million.

title: Police Picket Traffic Courts, as Pact Protests Go On
description: As the Police Department tried to end a ticket-writing slowdown by officers upset by stalled contract talks with the Giuliani administration, the officers' union picketed outside traffic courts around the city yesterday, denouncing what it called ticket-writing quotas.

title: Senate Roll Call For Casino Vote
description: Following is the 41-19 roll call by which the Senate voted yesterday to kill a proposed constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling.

title: MCKESSON TO ACQUIRE GENERAL MEDICAL
description: The McKesson Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy General Medical Inc., a privately held medical and surgical supplier, for $347 million in cash and stock and $428 million in assumed debt. General Medical, of Richmond, had sales of $1.7 billion in 1996. McKesson, based in San Francisco, said that as a result of its offer General Medical would terminate a planned initial public offering. McKesson, a wholesaler of pharmaceutical and health care products, said the $347 million of the purchase price would be roughly half cash and half stock. McKesson shares closed up 37.5 cents yesterday at $55.25.

title: RJR Nabisco Holdings Posts Gain in 4th-Quarter Earnings
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation yesterday reported improved fourth-quarter earnings, driven by strong revenues from its international tobacco operations and growing profits from its food business.

title: Atlanta Papers Are Sued In Olympic Bombing Case
description: Nearly six months after finding himself in the bold, black type of a front-page headline, Richard A. Jewell filed a libel suit today against the Atlanta newspapers that first proclaimed him a suspect in last summer's bombing in Centennial Olympic Park.

title: First Bill to Fail in 5 Years Shows Republicans' Rift
description: It is an article of faith here that by the time a bill gets to the floor of the Senate or the Assembly for a vote, it is certain to pass. The leaders of each chamber, who strictly control what bills come before the membership, simply do not allow a vote until they are sure they have enough support for passage.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Congressional Budget Office's projections for the Federal deficit misstated the office's estimate for 2002. Assuming continued progress in balancing the budget, the office estimated that in that year Congress and the Administration would need to close a gap of $154 billion, not $158 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, ROSE
description: RUDIN-Rose. Wife of the late Jack. Beloved mother of Fred and Bruce. Loving grandmother. Dear sister of Morris Goldstein. Services Wednesday, 2:00 pm., Sinai Chapel, Horace Harding Expressway and 162 St, Fresh Meadows.

title: Noninflationary Pay Report Relieves Markets (for a While)
description: Despite a tight labor market, American workers have not won pay and benefit increases large enough to push inflation up at a faster rate, Government figures showed today.

title: Ebonics Isn't 'Street English' but a Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Scouts Taking a Look At Latest Cuban Imports
description: When the agent Joe Cubas calls, baseball scouts come. The pied piper for Cuban baseball defectors showed off three of his latest imports today, and more than 40 scouts crowded into the Homestead Sports Complex to check them out.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC., New Orleans, said it had agreed to sell its shipyard in southern Louisiana to the closely held Bollinger Shipyards Inc. of Lockport, La. Terms were not disclosed.

title: It's McMullen's Turn to Snap U.S. Out of Doldrums in the Mile
description: The next great American miler started out playing high school football in Cadillac, Mich. He excelled on offense and defense, returned kickoffs and was the fastest man on the squad. But as a middle-distance runner on the track team, he was untested, unranked and uninspired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, PHILIP
description: CHASIN-Philip. 87, on January 27. Beloved husband of the late Sarah, adored father of the late Gail, and of Mark and devoted fatherin-law of Roni of Short Hills, NJ and loving grandfather of Yale, Zachary and Alex. We miss him. Service private.

title: Y.M.C.A. and School Board Unite on a Reading Program
description: Using private donations to make up for city budget cuts, the Board of Education and the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York announced a plan yesterday for new after-school programs with a special focus on improving reading skills for 10,000 elementary school students.

title: Step Right Up
description: In the hype before the Super Bowl, The A.P. ran an article about ''crazy betting.'' Las Vegas was not only giving odds on whether Green Bay would beat New England but whether Shaquille O'Neal would grab more rebounds that day than the Patriots would score points, or whether Brett Favre in the Super Bowl would have more passing yards than Tiger Woods would have strokes in the Phoenix Open. Now that the Super Bowl is behind us, Las Vegas will surely be looking for even crazier bets. I say bring foreign policy to Vegas. Ladies and gentlemen, place your bets:

title: If Deal Occurs, the Garden Faces Still Another Round
description: Once again, Madison Square Garden may have a new owner.

title: Well, Not a Debut, but Maybe a Rite of Passage
description: The New York debut has lost its once familiar mom-and-pop status and taken on a corporate look. If grocery stores, why not musicians? The days of walk-up, freelance concerts in which unknown (and often undeserving) artists could for a modest fee hire a hall and reasonably expect their first and last review ended when institutions with small performing spaces overwhelmingly raised fees and turned what had largely been rental halls into engines for their own productions. The changing format of the daily newspaper has made coverage not the automatic thing it used to be.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Monday's stock trading misstated a decline that occurred over three days last July in the Dow Jones industrial average. It was 254 points, or 4.5 percent (not 245 points, or 4.4 percent).

title: Rangers' Trance Doesn't Enchant
description: Their dismal record in their division is well-known. Their struggles against sub-.500 teams like the Islanders and Tampa Bay Lightning are well documented.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LEO, FRANK JOSEPH
description: DE LEO-Frank Joseph. On January 27, 1997. Former proprietor of De Leo's Restaurant & Cabaret. Beloved husband of Matilda (nee Alloca). Devoted father of Frank E., Janet Smith, Jeanne Cashman and Thomas. Loving grandfather of Bryan, Gregory, Dylan, Megan, Michael and Lindsey. Fond brother of Vita Kelly. Funeral Friday, 9AM, from the McMANUS F.H., 2001 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass 9:45AM, St. Thomas Aquinas R.C. Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visit Wed. and Thurs., 2-5, 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWART, REVEREND RUSSELL
description: DEWART-Reverend Russell, 95, of Prides Crossing, MA, Rector Emeritus of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Beverly, MA, on Jan. 21. Husband of Ann de D. (Stevenson) Dewart. Also survived by 7 children, Timothy of Beverly, Alan of Buffalo, NY, Brian of Ithica, NY, William (Ted) Dewart of Conshohaken, PA, Beth Rowe of Silver Spring, MD, Judith Stinson of Haydenville, MA and a foster daughter, the Reverend Dr. Eleanor McLaughlin of Southampton, MA; 10 grandchildren; 2 sisters, Frances Morgan and Elizabeth Scott-Kilvert; and numerous nieces and nephews. His funeral service will be held Saturday, Feb. 1st in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Ocean St., Beverly, MA at 11am.

description: DYER-Jack. To Bobbie, his mother-inlaw, Carolyn, his wife, and to his children, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Norman D. Tilles, President Martin A. Wenick, Executive VP

title: Buy 10, Get 1
description: The buy-10-get-1-free concept has caught on in New York City, with stores and restaurants dispensing cards that are punched with each purchase. The Great American Backrub offers customers the discount cards, as does the Emerald Planet in Greenwich Village (for its sandwiches and fruit shakes), Simon Sips in midtown (for coffee) and Park Slope Video in Brooklyn, to name just a few.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLOFSKY, MARTIN
description: ORLOFSKY-Martin. Young Israel of West Hempstead mourns the loss of its beloved member Martin Orlofsky. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yehuda Kelemer Joel Klein, President

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a review of ''Vilna's Got a Golem'' at the American Jewish Theater reversed the names of two actors. Scott Rabinowitz was second from the left; Jason Kravits was second from the right.

title: Eating Well
description: CHROMIUM PICOLINATE is the hottest dietary supplement on the market. The Federal Trade Commission says that at least nine million consumers spend $100 million a year on various forms of it.

But here is what it had to say when it announced its findings earlier this month: ''Eating at a steakhouse doesn't have to bust your waistline or help finance your cardiologist's next Mercedes.''

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANTA CORP., Horsham, Pa., said James W. John, senior vice president for corporate administration, had been promoted to president of Advanta International.

title: Clinton Agrees on Idea of Tax Relief in Capital
description: President Clinton said today that he agreed in principle with the idea of tax relief for the District of Columbia and that in fact he would introduce his own plan to revive the flagging economy of the nation's capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SARAH L.
description: GREENE-Sarah L. (Sally), January 26th, 1997. Longtime Peter Cooper resident. Loving wife of the late Howard L. Devoted mother of Nancy G. Jonas and the late Alice G. King. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside services were held.

title: The First Taste of Defeat For Islanders' New Coach
description: Just when you think it is safe to embrace the Islanders, they turn in an inconsistent effort like tonight's, reminding everyone why they still may be closer to having a high draft pick than a playoff berth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, RITA
description: SIMON-Rita. On January 27, age 76. Beloved wife to the late Morris. Adored mother to Jeffrey Simon and Melanie and Arnold Salkin. Cherished grandmother to Michael, Justin and Kimberly. Services today, 9AM at 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. She was a treasured woman and will be greatly missed by all.

title: How Very English: To Market, to Market, To Save That Fat Pig
description: NIGEL, a ginger-haired Tamworth boar, was listlessly rooting for barley and oats, scattering his straw on a chilly Yorkshire morning with sweeps of his rheumy snout. ''He's not really hungry,'' said David Bradley, the farm manager. ''He's just looking for savories the same way you do when you go to the kitchen and hope to find a bag of crisps.''

title: 3 Drug Makers Report Profits Better Than Forecast
description: Continuing a surge of strong profits in pharmaceuticals, three big health care companies surprised investors yesterday by reporting fourth-quarter results that exceeded securities analysts' projections.

title: Rise in Business Travel Cited For Jump in UAL's Earnings
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, said today that profit rose strongly in the fourth quarter as more business passengers paid full fare in the United States and sales improved overseas, offsetting a 25 percent increase in fuel prices.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: OFFICIAL INDICTED -- The ex-head of New Jersey's Sports and Exposition Authority is charged with using the post to win contracts for a private business. B4.

title: Evaluating State Justices
description: ''The best way to preserve the independence of the judiciary is to have a judiciary that is worthy of people's trust.'' That is the sound thinking behind a new plan by New York State's chief administrative judge, Jonathan Lippman, to revamp the system for elevating lower court judges to the main trial court, the State Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROWS, JUDI
description: BURROWS-Judi. Dear friend, there will be a void in our world forever. We will miss your laughter and your love, and will never forget our friendship. Helaine and Fred

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEISHEIM, GEORGE, JR.
description: BEISHEIM-George, Jr., retired NY State Supreme Court Judge on January 27, 1997 of South Salem NY, formerly Ossining, NY. Husband of the late Harriet; father of Susan Eleanor Beisheim and George Beisheim III; grandfather of Steven. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY Thursday and Friday 7-9pm. Funeral service at the South Salem Presbyterian Church on Saturday at 11:00am. Interment, South Salem Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAYLE, MICHAEL
description: GAYLE-Michael. February 29, 1960-January 29, 1996. Our hearts still ache in silence, and the secret tears still flow; What it means to lose you, only those who truly love you, really know. Sadly missed by Mother, Dolores; Father, Dudley; Sister, Andrea; Wife, Sonia; Son, Christopher; Gladstone, Nieces and nephew.

title: C.I.A. Taught, Then Dropped, Mental Torture in Latin America
description: The Central Intelligence Agency taught techniques of mental torture and coercion to at least five Latin American security forces in the early 1980's, but repudiated the interrogation methods in 1985, according to documents and statements the agency made public today.

description: Stratton Oakmont Inc., which filed for bankruptcy protection last week and was expelled from the securities industry almost two months ago, wants to reorganize as a merchant banker.

description: Sally Ganz, an art collector and benefactor of educational and cultural organizations, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

Services 2:30 Wednesday January 29 at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Juilliard School of Music.

title: Report Acknowledges Wild Horses Are Being Slaughtered
description: Most Federally protected wild horses placed for adoption ended up at slaughterhouses, a Justice Department inquiry has found. Investigators also concluded that the Bureau of Land Management, which runs the Adopt-A-Horse program, followed a ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy toward adopters who planned to sell the horses for slaughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEDOVICH, ALBERT
description: DEDOVICH-Albert. The New York State Society of Medical Oncologists and Heomtologists (Downstate Division) expresses condolences and sympathy to Monica Dedovich, Society Administrator on the death of her husband Albert. Richard T. Silver, M.D, Presient

description: In an abrupt turnaround, Mount Sinai Medical Center agreed yesterday to link the amount of money it is paid to run two city hospitals to how well it meets certain health care goals and to give the city more control over who works in the hospitals.

title: A Convergence of Views in Israel
description: Something new and important has emerged in Israel in recent weeks -- the makings of a consensus on peacemaking with the Palestinians. One clear sign came in the decisive 87-to-17 parliamentary vote supporting the Hebron agreement two weeks ago. Another is the set of guidelines for a final peace settlement jointly endorsed by a number of leaders of both the Labor and Likud parties.

title: Tale of the Tape: Black Tuesday
description: On Oct. 29, 1929, Wall Street investors lost millions in what became known as Black Tuesday. Now, the New York Stock Exchange ticker tape that documented the first few minutes of that day has been sold for $5,000 to the Museum of American Financial History.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Strikes Cut G.M. Profit By $1.2 Billion for Year

title: S.E.C. Adopts Derivatives-Disclosure Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted rules yesterday that will force most American companies to provide additional information to investors about the derivative securities they own and the risks those securities entail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORODETZER, PHILIP
description: GORODETZER - Philip, Jewish educator and Cantor. Served communities and congregations in Houston, Omaha, Rochester, Laurelton, Bayswater and Long Beach, NY. Beloved husband of Paula Kalish. Devoted father of Moshe and Yehudit Ganot, Harvey and Bonita Ganot, Leya and Dr. David Diamond. Additionally, he is survived by his mother Bessie Gorodetzer; sister Helen Funk; brothers Alvin, Julian, Sumner, and Marvin; 10 grandchildren; and 3 great-grandchildren. NAFLA ATERET ROSHAINU

title: Rubber Gloves: Peril for Some
description: She was merely present in a hospital emergency room where a nurse was wearing latex gloves. But for Debbie Anderson, 37, the encounter was almost fatal. Later that night, a latex allergy sent her into anaphylactic shock and she nearly died. Her brain was deprived of oxygen for so long that she went into a coma, and, now, more than two years later, she remains seriously brain damaged.

title: Options Are Open, Clinton Says, On How to Gain Balanced Budget
description: President Clinton said today that he would not rule out raising Medicare premiums for the wealthy or cutting capital gains taxes more deeply than he would prefer, in negotiating a balanced budget agreement with the Republican Congress.

title: Ditka Aims to Change Saints' Image
description: The Saints have not won a playoff game since joining the National Football League in 1967. They did not have a winning season until 1987.

title: In Animal Tests, New Pill Seems to Stop Flu
description: A newly developed pill has been able to prevent or cure influenza infections in tests on animals, researchers said today.

Javits Convention Center two years ago, skeptics wondered whether he was cut out for the task of eliminating the mismanagement, labor problems and mob corruption that had long consumed the state-run center. description: New Jersey will receive $26.2 million to help young people get jobs this summer, a 42 percent increase over last year, the United States Labor Department said yesterday.

title: RAYTHEON REPORTS CONTRACTS WORTH $269 MILLION
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that it had received contracts valued at $269 million for coke factory projects in the United States and India. Raytheon, of Lexington, Mass., will receive $180 million for providing engineering and construction services to the Sun Company for the Indiana Harbor Works steel plant in East Chicago, Ill. Raytheon will receive $29 million for services at the same steel plant for installing waste-heat boilers for Nipsco Industries. It will receive $60 million for providing engineering and construction advisory services at Bellary Coke and Power Ltd.'s coke plant in Tamil Nadu, India.

description: Robert E. Boyle garnered widespread praise when, exceeding expectations, he spearheaded a largely successful fight to drive out organized crime and lower operating costs at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: These Nets Will Not Blow Smoke
description: THE crushing medical report came at the same time as the grant proposal. Michael Rowe, president of the New Jersey Nets, learned last June that his mother was suffering from lung cancer, just when he was approached to run an anti-tobacco campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, SYLVIA
description: ROSENFELD-Sylvia. Age 86, formerly of Lido Beach, NY. Beloved wife of the late Harry, devoted mother of Jeffrey and mother-inlaw of Susan, caring grandmother of Jordan.

title: KISTLER WINS $100 MILLION LORAL SATELLITE CONTRACT
description: The Kistler Aerospace Corporation said yesterday that it had received a $100 million contract from Space Systems-Loral for 10 communications satellites launchings aboard Kistler's K-1 re-usable aerospace vehicles. Kistler Aerospace, of Los Angeles, said the launchings would begin in late 1999 and continue through early 2002 and that the deal was the first contract for its K-1 re-usable vehicles. Loral Space and Communications Ltd., of New York, owns 51 percent of Space Systems-Loral. Loral Space makes telecommunications, weather and direct broadcast satellites. Kistler Aerospace develops launching vehicles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MICHAEL I
description: WEISS-Michael I. On January 27, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Cherished father of Susan. Adored brother of Dorothy and Bertha. Dear uncle of Bunny and Alfred. A man of grace, dignity and integrity. Graveside service Wednesday, 2PM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y.

title: Food Court Signs Deal With ABC Unit
description: The Food Court Entertainment Network in New York has signed a multiyear agreement with ABC New Media Sales, a division of ABC National Television Sales in New York, under which ABC will sell commercial time for Food Court's Cafe USA, a network of television monitors in shopping malls.

title: Hints of a Possible Cloud Over Labor Appointment
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, cast a shadow today over President Clinton's nomination of Alexis M. Herman as Secretary of Labor, saying her political activities while in the White House last year may have run ''awfully close to the edge'' of Federal law.

title: A. R. Goodlatte, 57, Dies; Freed Subways of Graffiti
description: A. Richardson Goodlatte, the Transit Authority official who fought graffiti tooth and nail but found that eternal vigilance and a bit of elbow grease was all it took to keep subway cars more or less pristine even as similar measures kept them on the rails and out of the shop, died on Saturday at a hospital near his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 57 and had retired last year.

title: Visitors From India Find Help And Home
description: Shobha and Mohamed A. never intended to become New Yorkers. In January 1987, they arrived from India as tourists with their twin 2-year-old sons, Tariq and Abraham, hoping to make connections for a costume jewelry business they owned in New Delhi. They planned to return home 10 months later.

title: NEW YORK SENATE ROUNDLY REJECTS CASINO GAMBLING
description: The State Senate overwhelmingly rejected a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling today, effectively killing the proposal until at least 1999.

description: CARDIFF, Wales  Prime Minister John Major will sink a silver-plated spade into the thin Welsh soil near here Wednesday, officially breaking ground for what is said to be the largest foreign investment Europe has ever seen  the new $2.75 billion manufacturing base for LG Group of South Korea.

description: Imperial Tobacco P.L.C., which was spun off from Hanson P.L.C. of Britain three months ago, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Rizla International, a Dutch producer of cigarette paper, for $:168 million ($277 million). Imperial will also assume debt of $:17 million.

description: Working very different sides of the music street, two PBS specials score handsomely this evening.

description: Vowing to secure independence from Russia, the Chechen military chief of staff who led and won the rebel republic's war against Moscow's forces declared victory today in the presidential election on Monday.

title: Hush Money?
description: In his ''errors were made'' press conference, President Clinton became flustered when asked by The Washington Post's John Harris if he had found anything ''unusual or suspicious'' in large payments by the Lippo Group to Clinton's friend Webster Hubbell just after he was forced out of the Justice Department and before he went to jail.

title: Growing Up Surreal and Psychic
description: Whatever else it does, ''Saint Clara,'' a surreal comedy about a bunch of rambunctious Israeli junior high school students and the clairvoyant 13-year-old Russian girl who is their classroom savior, is a movie that keeps you continually off balance. Set in 1999, this futuristic social satire with distant echoes of ''Lolita'' is a punked-out coming-of-age film that changes tone every few minutes.

title: Subsidiary Asks Democrats to Return $15,000
description: Reacting to the Democratic National Committee's decision to ban contributions from foreign subsidiaries, at least one international corporation has asked the Democratic Party to refund its campaign contribution, and other companies are uniting to oppose the ban.

title: Colorado and Ohio Accused of Skirting Federal Environmental Laws
description: Saying that their states are circumventing parts of major national environmental laws, labor and environmental groups in Colorado and Ohio filed petitions today to take away the states' enforcement powers.

title: PLAYERS INTERNATIONAL TO SELL RESORT IN NEVADA
description: The casino operator Players International Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a preliminary agreement to sell its Players Island Resort Casino and Spa in Mesquite, Nev., to Robert Black Sr. for an undisclosed amount. If the deal is completed, Players, based in Atlantic City, said it would report an after-tax loss on the sale. The company did not disclose when it would account for the expected loss. Players operates riverboat casinos in three states. The company reported yesterday that revenue fell 10.8 percent, to $64.8 million in the most recent quarter, and that it had a loss of $1.4 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with a profit of $3.3 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Shares of Players closed down 43.75 cents yesterday, to $5.375.

title: With Talks Fragile, Book Embitters Ulster's Mood
description: Exactly 25 years ago Thursday, 14 Irish Catholics were shot dead by British paratroopers in Londonderry, in the western part of Northern Ireland.

title: Mellow Home Thoughts From Chicago
description: AMERICA'S houseware makers think the future you are demanding is decked out in yellow and chrome, easily disassembled, highly caffeinated and frighteningly tidy.

title: Restaurant Union Criticizes Riese Tactics
description: At a feisty demonstration in yesterday's cold, the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union stepped up its yearlong labor dispute with one of New York's largest restaurant companies, the Riese Organization, by contending that it has engaged in an unusual shell game.

title: Raya Garbousova, 87, Cellist Honored by Composers
description: Raya Garbousova, a cellist who gave the premieres of several contemporary works, including the Samuel Barber Cello Concerto, died on Tuesday at her home in De Kalb, Ill. She was 87.

description: A DESIGN company was born one morning six years ago when Graham Berg had a flat tire on his bike. ''I changed the inner tube, took the old one home, and used it to hang my speakers,'' he said. ''That led me to play with alternative uses for tubes and other bike parts.''

title: The Return Of the Merchandiser
description: To hear the film makers and marketers talk, it is the ultimate example of technology in the service of pure art: George Lucas's Star Wars trilogy, which began a special effects revolution 20 years ago, has been refurbished using even more advanced computer wizardry and will be rereleased in thousands of theaters on Friday. Mr. Lucas has described the project as a loving gesture to a new generation of fans who had never before witnessed Luke Skywalker's quest on the big screen.

title: SUNBEAM CORP. (SOC,N)
description: The Sunbeam Corporation reported a loss yesterday for the fourth quarter, even before special charges for revamping, but said it had wrapped up the cost-cutting part of its turnaround plan.

title: U.S. Report on Human Rights Faults China, Nigeria and Cuba
description: Despite American efforts, from jawboning to sanctions, human rights performance worsened last year in China, Nigeria, Cuba and Myanmar, according to the Administration's annual report on human rights in 193 countries, which is to be released on Thursday.

title: Dr. King Memories
description: WHEN new wallpaper was needed last year for the boyhood home of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Atlanta, the house's historian, Dean Rowley, worked with Dr. King's sister, Christine Farris. They tried to find a pattern that fit in with her memories.

description: Mercury Finance, an auto lender that specializes in lower-quality borrowers, said yesterday that its No. 2 official, who supervised the company's accounting policies, had vanished after accounting irregularities were discovered. The company also slashed its reported profits for the last four years.

description: While General Manager Bob Watson waited for George Steinbrenner to approve a three- or four-year contract proposal the Yankees plan to make to the arbitration-eligible Bernie Williams, he also fielded 20 phone calls yesterday about Cecil Fielder's continuing demand to be traded. Unfortunately for Fielder, all the calls were from reporters.

Yet this suggestion for changing the Constitution -- first proposed by Thomas Jefferson -- continues to receive rough treatment, almost all of it misguided.

description: The Ford Motor Company reported higher earnings today for the fourth quarter and all of 1996, despite continued losses in the European and Latin American divisions.

description: Bad as things have been going for the Connecticut men's basketball team, it got even worse tonight when the Huskies played Providence, the enigma of the Big East.

title: Fixing Racial Imbalance in Hartford
description: Six months ago Connecticut's Supreme Court ruled that racial segregation in Hartford's schools violated the State Constitution. A special panel now says that one way to attack the problem is to give more students the chance to attend schools outside their home districts, without forced busing. This is a sound idea but it will cost money. Connecticut's state government should be prepared to bear that cost.

title: Many Black Men Barred From Voting
description: Fourteen percent of black men are currently or permanently barred from voting either because they are in prison or because they have been convicted of a felony, according to a study to be released today.

title: Gambling Proponents See Indian Casinos as Alternative
description: A day after the Senate rejected a constitutional amendment to legalize casinos, gambling proponents in the Legislature said they plan to push for state approval of Indian casinos in places like the Catskills, Niagara Falls and Buffalo, areas that would have been given the right to build casinos under the failed referendum.

title: The Agency Scene Changes in Atlanta
description: One agency is opening in Atlanta as a second is revamping.

title: SUSPECT'S SKETCH IN OKLAHOMA CASE CALLED AN ERROR
description: After nearly two years of investigation, Federal officials have officially acknowledged that the circulation of a sketch of John Doe No. 2 -- the mysterious, thick-necked man depicted as a prime suspect in the Oklahoma City bombing -- was based on a mistake by a witness who remembered the wrong person.

title: Toyota Repurchases 5.7 Million More Shares
description: Japan's Toyota Motor Corporation said yesterday that it had bought back 5.7 million of its shares for 18.10 billion yen ($149.9 million) on the Tokyo market from Dec. 26 to Jan. 28.

description: Total S.A., France's second-largest oil company, said yesterday that its 1996 earnings rose more than expected, buoyed by higher oil prices and increased profit margins from refining.
