description: With his comeback now two fights old, the former undisputed heavyweight champion James (Buster) Douglas will make his Broadway debut on Feb. 12 when he takes on Dickie Ryan at Madison Square Garden.

title: REPUBLIC ENGINEERED STEEL TO CUT 12% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Republic Engineered Steel Inc. said yesterday that it planned to reduce its work force by 500 jobs, or 12 percent, as part of a cost-cutting plan and company revamping. The steps were announced as the steel producer said its second-quarter loss widened to $11.6 million, or 59 cents a share, compared with a loss of $5.4 million, or 27 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales were $174.7 million, up 1 percent from $172.9 million. Republic, based in Massillion, Ohio, said its results were hurt by a continuing decline in steel prices. Shares of Republic rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $2.375, on the Nasdaq Stock Market.

title: Those inflation-indexed bonds are like L'il Abner's schmoos.
description: WHILE the inflation-indexed bonds issued yesterday by the Treasury are seen by Wall Street as just another opportunity to make a buck, economists' pulses are racing over other potential uses of the new financial instruments. For like the mythical schmoo in Al Capp's Li'l Abner comics (which tasted like chicken when fried and sirloin when grilled), indexed bonds may work a variety of wonders -- everything from helping the Federal Reserve to detect inflation on the horizon to providing a lower-risk way for states and cities to finance new infrastructure.

title: Judith Fugate Resigns
description: Judith Fugate, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has resigned, effective immediately. Ms. Fugate joined City Ballet in 1973. She was promoted to soloist in 1979 and to principal dancer in 1986.

title: Record Year in TV For Political Billings
description: Political advertising on television reached record levels last year, according to a survey by the Television Bureau of Advertising in New York.

description: REMEMBER the pantry, that secret, archaic space that kitchen cabinets were supposed to abolish? Where mice dwelt, fruitcakes bathed in brandy and butlers worked their silver-polish magic? Well, the pantry is back.

title: Giuliani To Propose a Budget To Cut Less and Spend More
description: Taking advantage of a rebounding economy as he begins his re-election campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to announce a preliminary budget today that would include the first overall increase in city spending and the fewest reductions in services that he has recommended since becoming Mayor.

title: Drugs and 'Dalmations' Books
description: Not even Cruella De Vil could have hatched a scheme this wicked. Colombian smugglers hid 806 pounds of cocaine in a shipping container full of ''101 Dalmatians'' pop-up books that was intercepted at a warehouse in Edison yesterday, United States Customs agents said. Marty Ficke, a special customs agent, said the duffel bags full of cocaine, worth $12 million on the street, were probably buried under the 876 cartons of books shortly before the ship that carried them left port in Colombia, where the books were manufactured.

title: For British Health System, Grim Prognosis
description: This has been the worst winter in memory for Dr. Don Wijetunge, who runs the emergency room at St. George's Hospital in South London. At times as many as 30 patients have been sprawled on gurneys outside his emergency room, waiting for treatment for things like pneumonia, heart attacks, stabbings and injuries from car accidents.

title: Stock Regulators Reconsider Plan
description: Securities regulators have reconsidered a controversial change in the arbitration system that governs disputes between brokers and their customers.

title: Stratton Oakmont Ordered to Liquidate
description: Stratton Oakmont Inc., which has been kicked out of the securities industry for defrauding hundreds of customers, will not stay in business but will be liquidated by a court-appointed trustee, regulators announced last night.

(An Op-Ed page article on Tuesday about the use of hidden cameras in television news gathering repeated the error.) The lawyer is Bill Jeffress, not Jeffries.

title: U.S. Wins A Round Against Cartel
description: The Government has snared a new and influential quarry in its long-running effort to crack an illegal international cartel in the food additives industry.

title: Robert E. Pelletier, Times Design Artist, 68
description: Robert E. Pelletier, who worked at The New York Times for 37 years doing everything from executing promotional drawings to helping redesign the newspaper, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 68 and had retired in 1994 as assistant to the editorial art director.

description: A local alderman once said of this mighty city, ''Chicago ain't ready for reform.'' The rest of the state ain't ready either for campaign finance reform, according to a statewide bipartisan task force of civic leaders and former elected officials.

title: Gambling Vote Imperils Yonkers Raceway
description: Yonkers Raceway, the 99-year-old fixture of the harness racing world, may be sold because of the New York State Senate's rejection of a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling, which would have let the track put 5,000 slot machines into a renovated grandstand, raceway officials said yesterday.

title: Before a Fire, 3 Shootings
description: Autopsy results released yesterday showed that the former commandant of the state's juvenile boot camp in Tabernacle Township and a woman friend were shot to death on Saturday by the women's former husband, the state police said. The ex-husband then set fire to the house where the slayings occurred before turning a gun on himself, the police said.

title: BBC's 'Today' Show
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times on Tuesday about balloons that tried or will try round-the-world flights reversed the direction to be flown by the Dymocks Flyer balloon late this year. It will travel from west to east.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday about plans for the Lunar New Year, Feb. 7, which include a banquet at the Peking Park restaurant, misstated the address. It is 100 Park Avenue.

title: People
description: * Frederick R. Smith, vice chairman and chief operating officer at Leap Group, Chicago, was named to an added post, president of Quantum Leap Communications, a new product-development unit.

title: Whitman Asks $16.4 Billion In New Budget
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed a $16.4 billion election-year budget today that provides spending increases for public schools, prisons and the environment, and more than a dozen modest initiatives aimed at Democratic and swing voters.

title: Army Learned Early of Evidence of Sexual Harassment
description: In the course of a sweeping Army inquiry last year into whether extremist groups and deep-seated discrimination were pervading the service's ranks, investigators turned up numerous complaints of sexual harassment, Army officials say. But the investigators did not mention those complaints in their final report.

title: Giants Study Accounting
description: Facing impending salary-cap problems, the Giants have begun to rework some contracts, and one of the first to get a new deal is guard Ron Stone.

title: Snow-Groomers Work the Night Shift
description: A full moon lighted the terrain like candlelight on ''The Right Stuff.'' Riding on the slope of Barker Mountain here, it was not a bad place to be on a cold winter's night. Slowly and methodically, the giant snow-groomer plied the slope like a mammoth ice crusher, blending hardpack into soft corduroy for the next day's skiers.

title: Airliner at Kennedy Skids Off a Runway
description: An Air China jet skidded off a runway at Kennedy International Airport last night as it was taxiing shortly after it touched down, officials said. None of the 222 passengers and crew were injured.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Jan. 16 about the lawsuit by the Food Lion supermarket chain against ABC misstated the surname of the ABC lawyer it quoted. (An Op-Ed page article on Tuesday about the use of hidden cameras in television news gathering repeated the error.) The lawyer is Bill Jeffress, not Jeffries.

title: Deliberating, Simpson Jury Reveals Little Of Its Intent
description: Behind closed doors, with a scattering of the curious and an army of reporters and photographers hanging outside the courthouse, the jury in O. J. Simpson's second trial put in its first full day of deliberations today.

title: In Cologne, Early Designs Are Reprised, Then Revised
description: IT might have been the record-breaking cold temperatures in Germany this winter. It could have been the new fascination with minimalism, the architectural style du jour that goes by the name new simplicity in Europe. Or perhaps it was the stagnant economy that dogged Germany in 1996. Whatever the cause, brave new designs were few at the International Furniture Fair held in Cologne earlier this month. Straight lines and simple forms reigned -- a kind of Bauhaus revisited.

title: With Defeat of Gambling Initiative, Catskill Winter Turns Gloomier
description: Mark Kutsher was going through the motions of running his family's 420-room Catskills resort, inspecting the ski lift, the steamy indoor swimming pool and the darkened Stardust auditorium. But his mind was still focused on the day before, when he sat in the gallery of the State Senate chambers in Albany, watching a dream evaporate.

title: Tele Danmark Planning Big Cuts in Work Force
description: Tele Danmark A.S., the majority state-owned Danish telephone company, said yesterday that it would reorganize and dismiss 2,500 employees by mid-1998 in an effort to fight increasing competition. The company declined to disclose how much it expected the changes to reduce its annual costs when the revamping is complete or what the charges for staff cuts and organizational changes would cost.

title: Sony Names New Head at Columbia-Tristar
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment promoted Kenneth Lemberger, its corporate development chief, to president of the Columbia-Tristar Motion Picture Group today.

title: Air Traffic From Abroad Rises
description: Last January, a $120 million terminal opened at Newark International Airport to meet the demands of increasing traffic from overseas. Yesterday, Port Authority officials said that 3.9 million international travelers had used the airport from January through October and projected that the volume of overseas traffic for the year would increase by 19 percent.

title: Emergency Funds Promised for Hanbo Steel
description: South Korea's Government said yesterday that it would keep the bankrupt Hanbo Steel Company, a unit of the Hanbo Group, running by infusing $670 million in emergency funds. The money will be used to cover the company's gas and electricity bills and to pay suppliers of scrap iron and other raw materials.

title: Arabs May 'Punish America' for Extradition, Hamas Says
description: A spokesman for the militant Islamic group Hamas warned today that the extradition of one of its top leaders to Israel by the United States could provoke efforts to ''try to punish America.''

title: Ex-Mayors Seeking Post Face Odds
description: If David N. Dinkins looks to history as a guide to running again for Mayor, the ghosts of his predecessors might respond in an unequivocal chorus: Don't bother.

title: Study Hints Allergy Shots May Not Help Some Who Already Receive Proper Treatment
description: Allergy shots do not provide additional benefits to children with moderate or severe year-round asthma who are being given the proper medications to treat the disease, researchers are reporting today. Their study is expected to heighten a controversy over the effectiveness of the widely used injections.

title: Lord Rippon, 72, Who Haggled With Europe
description: Lord Rippon of HexhamRippon of Hexham, the chief negotiator of Britain's entry into the Common Market, died on Tuesday at his home near Bridgwater in the county of Somerset in southwestern England. He was 72.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The PRINCESS OF WALES is cleaning out her closets, or so it seems. But she won't be sending her clothes to a thrift shop or handing them on to relatives. Rather, negotiations are under way to auction 65 of her evening dresses at Christie's, with the proceeds going to charity.

title: Gulag Cellmates Reminisce (Now They Can Laugh)
description: It was a reunion like most Russian reunions, with anecdotes about the old days, sentimental toasts and a table loaded with sausage, potatoes and herring.

title: Even the Small Donations Can Make a Big Difference
description: A Bronx woman wanted to add four zeroes to the check she sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, but like many readers who contribute what they can afford, her wish was bigger than her bank balance. Taken together, however, these contributions continue to drive the fund's efforts to help thousands of impoverished New Yorkers.

title: Brazilians Excel With Shopping Bags
description: Canadians may dominate the tourism landscape in New York City in numbers of visitors, and the Japanese may be the fastest-growing market. But the biggest spenders are the Brazilians, according to a Federal survey of passengers taken during arriving flights.

title: Jazz Flexes New Muscles In Lincoln Center Schedule
description: Six months after being granted full constituency on the Lincoln Center campus, Jazz at Lincoln Center yesterday announced its schedule for the 1997-98 season and beyond. It entails more performances, longer runs, expanded education programs and a new corporate sponsor, the Discover Card, all making jazz an even more visible part of New York's cultural life.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the economic prospects for Atlantic City casinos misstated the financial situation of the Claridge Hotel and Casino, and an article yesterday about the industry's reaction to a New York State Senate vote against casino gambling repeated the error. The company announced in December that it was seeking to negotiate a restructuring of its debt with corporate bondholders; it did not file for bankruptcy protection.

title: New Inflation-Indexed Note Receives a Strong Response
description: The Treasury's first auction of inflation-indexed securities went better than expected yesterday, with strong interest from large institutional investors.

title: 9-Year Jail Term for Russian Named by U.S. as a Mobster
description: A man whom the F.B.I. called one of the most powerful Russian mobsters in America was sentenced yesterday to nine years and seven months in prison for attempted extortion and taking part in a fraudulent marriage.

title: Whitman Plans $2 Million to Help Immigrants Become Citizens
description: New Jersey would spend $2 million a year to help poor legal immigrants who are elderly or disabled become United States citizens under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new budget proposal, a move that might protect them from losing benefits under the new Federal welfare law.

title: Saddam's Wife Under House Arrest, Senior Officer Says : U.S. Sees Struggle For Power In Baghdad
description: WASHINGTON  Bolstering reports of ferment in Iraq, the White House claimed Wednesday that "complicated internal struggles for power" were swirling around the regime of Saddam Hussein.

title: British-Dutch Firm Asks for Tax Breaks
description: In the latest round of corporate poker, ING Capital, a giant British-Dutch financial services firm, is threatening to abandon New York for a new headquarters in Stamford, Conn., unless New York grants the company a package of tax breaks and other incentives, real estate and city officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about MEMC Electronic Materials Inc., a silicon wafer maker, referred incorrectly to a forecast that called for semiconductor companies to consume 6.2 billion square inches of silicon in the year 2000. Such consumption would represent an 80 percent increase from 1995, not 1985.

title: Bush Tax Plan for Texas, and 2000
description: It is no secret to anybody in Texas' massive pink-granite Capitol that Gov. George W. Bush is already thinking about running for President in 2000, although the first-term Governor worries aloud about what he calls the Icarus syndrome: ''It's like trying to fly to the sun too quickly,'' he says. ''You could burn up.''

title: Hispanic Households Struggle Amid Broad Decline in Income
description: If he dared to tattoo gang symbols on his neck, Myrna Morales warned her strapping 17-year-old son, William, she would burn them off with her iron. Or a frying pan.

title: Putting Bamboo And Seashells Back to Work
description: SOME of the materials that despite (or because of) their rarity fascinated Art Deco furniture designers are today among the cheapest to obtain. And for Ria and Yiouri Augousti, a husband-and-wife design team who split their time between Paris and their production headquarters in the Philippines, they are also among the easiest to find. They have been using those materials -- coconut husks, bamboo, seashells, fish skin and shagreen -- for eight years. The results have a sleek Art Deco look that would be equally at home in Josephine Baker's Paris apartment or a TriBeCa loft. The line ranges from round lacquered coasters for $15 to the chest above, which was made with wood and inlaid bamboo and sells for $1,250. There are picture frames ($40 to $84), hand mirrors with squiggly shaped handles ($42 to $80), rectangular trays ($118 to $205), vases ($195) and lamps ($400). Available at Barneys New York, Madison Avenue at 61st Street, (212) 826-8900, and Seventh Avenue at 17th Street, (212) 539-7800.

title: Financier Leverages Influence for Poor Urban Areas
description: James E. Quinn routinely travels to some of the most rarefied shopping districts in the world for his job as an executive vice president at Tiffany & Company. Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, for example, is typical Tiffany turf. But until this month, Mr. Quinn -- though born and raised in New York -- had never once been to the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, where shopping opportunities for even basic needs are scant if not entirely absent.

title: Ask for Sun And Settle For Moon
description: ROBERT K. KRAFT cannot force Bill Parcells to coach his football team. He can only make Parcells disappear for one year and keep the Jets grounded in the process. Unless Kraft is a very bad businessman, he will not do this. He will, now that Commissioner Paul Tagliabue has awarded to New England Parcells's coaching rights for 1997, exact his compensation package and send Parcells back to New Jersey, where he may resume his life's mission of one day having a turnpike rest stop named after him.

title: Back and Forth, With Duke Rising to Top
description: On the surface there was nothing more at stake than a chance to grab a piece of fourth place in the Atlantic Coast Conference midway through the league race. But feelings extend way below the surface when Duke and North Carolina meet, and tonight's game at Cameron Indoor Stadium proved no exception.

title: Bridge
description: Some of the most interesting defensive moves are those that sever the opponents' communications, and the diagramed deal from the International Team Trials played in San Francisco in June is a case in point.

title: Missile Defense System Is Still a Bad Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: When Money Counts
description: IT is difficult to put a price on comfort, but why heat a whole house when all you need is to cozy up the cold spots?

title: What's in a Name? Ima Hogg Knew
description: THE LANGUAGE OF NAMES

title: Patriots Will Seek the Jets' No. 1 Pick for Parcells
description: If the Jets want Bill Parcells to coach them next season, they will learn that the New England Patriots' owner, Robert K. Kraft, will demand the No. 1 pick in the National Football League draft.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Yale

title: A Hub in Search of Its Heart and Soul
description: Bobby Orr's game jersey hangs framed like a sacred relic, which in this city it is, over the bar at Fours, but to the diehard sports fans there this afternoon the old glory days only made the current mood of bitter disillusionment more poignant.

title: The Berlin Wall and China
description: Bill Clinton offered a revealing glimpse into his thinking about China when he predicted this week that liberty would eventually triumph there, much as freedom brought down the Berlin wall. The demise of Communism may come someday in China, but it would be a mistake to adopt a passive American policy based on that optimistic prospect, as Mr. Clinton seems to be doing. There is already abundant evidence suggesting that Communism in China is not dying but is instead mutating into a new form that tolerates economic liberties while still suffocating political freedom.

title: Blows From Nafta Batter the Caribbean Economy
description: Three years after the United States, Canada and Mexico agreed to become a single market as part of the North American Free Trade Agreement, their exports to each other are booming. But here in the Caribbean, the economies of America's much smaller neighbors are reeling from the impact of that success and finding it nearly impossible to compete.

title: M.T.A. to Buy 500 Gas and Electric Buses
description: Transit officials said yesterday that they would buy 500 new buses that run on compressed natural gas and electricity, the largest such purchase of the buses as efforts are pressed to clean up the New York City fleet.

title: Gun Lobby in Bitter Power Struggle
description: A fierce battle is under way for control of the National Rifle Association, with a hard-line dissident faction threatening to oust the current leadership.

title: Add Civil Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Surges 84.66 Points, Reversing Five-Day Slide
description: Wall Street halted a weeklong decline yesterday as stock prices rallied while interest rates fell.

title: No Headline
description: ''Everybody's going up the escalator but there's a big queue at the bottom and the queue's getting bigger, so the average number of steps people have gotten up has slipped.''

title: Orders Down For Durables In December
description: Factory orders for big-ticket goods fell unexpectedly during December, indicating that economic growth could be more restrained than many analysts believe.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Red-Twigged Dogwood

title: As Small Towns Grow, Small-Town Justice Is Under Debate
description: In the towns and villages of New York State, justice is dispensed by elected judges, most of whom are not lawyers. And it is not uncommon for these judges to have ties of one kind or another to the people who appear before them.

title: Al Agonistes
description: Is the Spot getting bigger? Tipper says it isn't, but I know it is. At this rate, by the year 2000 I'll look like Joe Biden, wandering around with okra plugs in my head. It's making me a little crazy. Actually, everything these days is making me a little crazy. I've been so loyal for four years, staying in the shadow of President Smarmy and just praying I don't get splattered.

title: Devils Salvage a Tie and Yank a Teammate Off the Hook
description: After two victories and a loss in California last week, the Devils returned to the comfort of home tonight, and for a long while they looked too comfortable.

title: St. John's Grand Visions Are Blurred by Rutgers
description: They were serenaded by the small but appreciative crowd at Madison Square Garden last night, recognized as champions of their sport. A gold-plated trophy sparkled at halfcourt, symbolizing their achievement of excellence.

title: Calendar: Talks, Shows, Tours and a Camp Fair
description: Benefit Luncheon

title: Increases Offered for Schools
description: After three years of cutting taxes and reining in spending, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman took a different approach in the election-year budget she outlined yesterday. Mrs. Whitman's $16.4 billion budget would maintain spending at current or higher levels for most state programs.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the Monsanto Company's proposed acquisition of the part of Calgene Inc. that it does not already own referred incorrectly in some editions to the value of the offer and the number of shares outstanding for Calgene. The worth was $218 million, not $30 million; the shares number 66.25 million, not 60 million.

title: 4 Are Mourned in Montclair
description: More than 900 mourners crowded into the St. Paul Baptist Church in Montclair yesterday to remember a woman and her three daughters who were shot dead last week, perhaps by the woman herself. White caskets containing the bodies of Delfrances Bennett, 38, and her children, Brittney Bennett, 5, Adrienne Cheeks, 9, and Kristen Cheeks, 6, were placed near the altar as two choirs sang and the pastor of Ms. Bennett's childhood church in Newark, the Rev. Stacy McQueen, delivered the eulogy. The deaths are still officially a mystery, but investigators have said that notes found in Ms. Bennett's home indicated that she was depressed.

title: One Club to Honor 2 Executives
description: The One Club for Art and Copy in New York will induct two more executives into its Creative Hall of Fame. They will join 30 members, including Leo Burnett and David Ogilvy.

title: Trial to Be Shown in Oklahoma for Victims
description: The Federal judge hearing the Oklahoma City bombing case agreed today to allow the closed-circuit television broadcast of the trial to be moved to an auditorium of a building at Oklahoma City's airport, so more victims and their families can attend.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At age 68, the singer VIC DAMONE is graduating from high school, 52 years after he dropped out to help support his parents and his four sisters.

title: Letterman Is Denied NBC Clips
description: The bad blood that marked David Letterman's departure from NBC four years ago apparently lingers. The network has withheld clips of Mr. Letterman's old ''Late Night'' show from use on CBS.

title: Franco Appears Prepared in Body and Spirit
description: For pitchers who stand as the last line of defense as a bullpen stopper, less is often more. The less your name appears in the first line of reports about your team, the better you are likely to be performing.

title: Salem Plants on 'Watch List'
description: Nuclear regulators said yesterday that they would keep a close eye on the troubled Salem nuclear power plants. The plants, which have been shut down since 1995 because of a number of problems, were placed on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's ''watch list'' for the first time and will be subject to frequent inspections, Neil Sheehan, a commission spokesman, said.

title: A Director Who Collects Honors, Not Millions
description: For nearly 30 years Charles Burnett has struggled quietly to make films about the black experience in the United States, only to see his work ignored by movie studios and remain largely unnoticed by most moviegoers, perhaps because his films have no gangs or guns.

title: Elegance In Plastic (Yes, Plastic)
description: IT was as if the companies exhibiting at this year's International Housewares Show in Chicago were trying to paraphrase that line from ''The Graduate.'' Designers and manufacturers wanted to say two words to us -- just two words -- ''colorful plastics.''

title: For Marsalis, the Poison of Slavery Bends to Love
description: Love, along with its close relatives religion and responsibility, permeates Wynton Marsalis's three-hour meditation on slavery, ''Blood on the Fields.'' Mr. Marsalis, never shy about explaining the world, has produced an extraordinary, expansive work in which the poison of slavery is extracted by love. ''Blood on the Fields,'' which opened a 24-concert American and European tour at Woolsey Hall here tonight, is a piece finally about the power of care to redeem even the most malevolent and persistent crimes.

title: Nassau Chief Hints at Run For New Term
description: The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, delivered his State of the County address today, but it sounded more like the opening of his re-election campaign.

title: THOMSON REACHES DEAL WITH RIVAL ON LEGAL PUBLICATIONS
description: The Thomson Corporation, the Canadian publishing and travel-services concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell some of its legal publications to Reed Elsevier Inc. for an undisclosed amount. The sale will fulfill some of the requirements of Thomson's recent settlement with the United States Department of Justice and seven states stemming from the company's $3.4 billion purchase of the West Publishing Company, the legal publisher. Reed Elsevier, which is based in Newton, Mass., was one of the companies that sought to block the Thomson-West Publishing deal. Reed Elsevier, an on-line competitor of Thomson and West Publishing and a unit of Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the British publishing concern, will acquire United States Code Service; United States Supreme Court Reports, Lawyer's Edition; Auto-Cite; four state annotated statutes, and about 40 other titles. Thomson is based in Toronto but also has a headquarters in Stamford, Conn.

title: Senate Greets Congressman As U.N. Envoy
description: Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico cruised today through the Senate's committee hearing on his nomination as the next American delegate to the United Nations, but his appearance exposed sharp differences over President Clinton's forthcoming proposal to repay the United States' outstanding dues to the world organization.

title: Heated Battle Is Expected On Financing Birth Control
description: The Clinton Administration is preparing to send Congress a measure to speed up spending on family planning overseas, setting up what abortion opponents describe as the first abortion-related vote in the new Congress.

title: U.S. Trade Official Warns the Chinese
description: The Clinton Administration's top trade official said today that the United States would block China from entering the World Trade Organization -- an important goal for the Chinese leadership this year -- if Beijing continued to block the import of American agricultural goods.

title: U.S. to Put Airline Safety Data on Internet, but Carrier Ranking Is Ruled Out
description: Under pressure to release information on airline safety and mishaps, the Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would do so next month on the World Wide Web but that the information would not help rank airlines by safety.

title: In Her Own Words
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

title: Dennis Rodman, Bad Boy As Man of the Moment
description: Now that America is no longer in the forefront when it comes to industrial and mechanical invention, its job is to produce new cultural types. Today, this is being done largely on the popular culture front. It is here that performers splice myths and roles together in what we might call feats of stylistic engineering.

title: New Media Invade the Old
description: When the alternative-music Web venture Sonicnet was sold to a music entertainment start-up company recently, it was emancipation day for Nicholas Butterworth. He is the creative director at Sonicnet and the man credited with taking a dial-in bulletin board and turning it into a valuable Web-based property that made recordings available on the Web.

title: Tax Credits for Welfare Hires
description: President Clinton's proposal to give tax credits to companies that hire long-term welfare recipients can modestly boost employment and income of this hard-to-hire group. The positive impact is unlikely to be large, but tax credits are probably the most that Congress is willing to do to protect those who are in harm's way of the new welfare law, which imposes time limits on Federal cash assistance.

title: Accused French Ex-Official Says Jews Aided Nazi Deportations
description: Maurice Papon, the former French official facing trial on charges of crimes against humanity in World War II, has broken a long silence and accused French Jews of helping to organize deportations to Nazi death camps.

title: A Weakened Yen Also Worries Japanese Industry
description: For the big exporters of corporate Japan, the nightmare should be over. With the dollar continuing its rise in trading here today above 122 yen to the dollar, a four-year high, the exchange rate is now virtually back to where it was in 1993 -- before the latest appreciation in the yen, or endaka, began.

title: Toyota Links Investments To U.K.'s Embrace of Euro
description: LONDON  Toyota Motor Corp. shifted the debate over Europe's single currency from the theoretical to the practical Wednesday, reportedly threatening to limit its future investments in Europe to countries that are part of the European Union's planned single currency.

title: Where 'Bespoke' Is Spoken Fluently
description: I had tried my best. I wore the chalk-stripe suit. But the verdict was that the shoulders were both too narrow and unnecessarily padded. It turned out that my shirt collar was too low for someone with a long neck. And the one-and-a-half-inch trouser cuffs were deemed meager for someone 6 foot 2 with size 11 feet.

title: Calipari Takes Nets' Flop Stoically
description: It has been a free fall for the Nets this season. And on Tuesday night, the Nets found out how it feels to hit bottom.

title: Works of Art That Go Right to the Inner Core
description: I'LL X-ray anything and everything that is not tied down,'' said Kate Judge, a 30-year-old artist, who became a certified X-ray technician to make ends meet. But once an artist always an artist. Ms. Judge began experimenting with X-raying shells, keys and flowers, and last year she decided to use the images to make eerily elegant pieces that range from key chains to place mats to lamp shades.

title: Knicks Prove They Can Win Without Ewing
description: The Knicks did not need Patrick Ewing, after all. The game of basketball needed him. Badly.

title: Distinct Style, but Easy to Mold
description: Each section of ''Trace,'' a strange and riveting three-part solo that Molissa Fenley has choreographed for herself and her new season at the Joyce Theater, is seen in a strikingly different context.

title: Hilton to File ITT Bid Terms With S.E.C.
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, which on Monday announced an unsolicited $6.5 billion takeover bid for the ITT Corporation, will file its tender offer with the Securities and Exchange Commission today, the company said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: America Online to Give Refunds and Credits

title: REFUNDS PLANNED BY AMERICA ONLINE IN NETWORK JAM
description: America Online Inc., the fast-growing company that has ushered nearly eight million Americans into cyberspace, agreed yesterday to give millions of dollars of credits and refunds as compensation for network traffic jams that had been frustrating its customers since December.

title: Islanders' Strong Finish Can't Erase Weak Start
description: It was the worst of games; it was the best of games. In the space of 60 minutes here at the Olympic Saddledome on Tuesday night, the Islanders turned in another of those maddening performances that have characterized a season in which the team is developing awkwardly from toddler to adolescent.

title: Chairman Of Joint Chiefs Plans to Retire In September
description: Gen. John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who guided American military operations in Haiti and Bosnia, plans to retire from the military in September, a White House spokesman announced today.

title: The Pop Life
description: Roy Harper Is Back

title: Chechnya's Mild but Steely New Chief
description: The newly elected President of Chechnya served most of his life in the Soviet Army to reach the rank of colonel, but he never saw combat until Russian tanks rolled into the secessionist republic in December 1994 and he began plotting strategy against his former fellow officers.

title: Train Those Without Skills
description: To The Home Section:

title: Chiron to Make Room for One More at the Top
description: The Chiron Corporation, a growing biotechnology company that has suffered setbacks in the last year, said today that it would seek a new president and chief executive to succeed Edward E. Penhoet, who will become vice chairman.

title: Company Sells L.I. Site
description: The Northrup Grumman Corporation, which was Long Island's largest private employer 10 years ago, has sold the largest building on its former site in Bethpage, leaving only 2 buildings of an original 18 unsold, the company's real estate broker said yesterday.

title: N. L. Robinson, Jesse Jackson's Natural Father, Is Dead at 88
description: Noah Lewis Robinson, the biological father of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, died on Monday at Greenville General Hospital in South Carolina. He was 88 and lived in Greenville, S.C.

title: OMNICARE TO ACQUIRE RESEARCH COMPANY IN STOCK DEAL
description: Omnicare Inc., the pharmacy-services concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held contract research company Coromed Inc. for $40 million in stock. Coromed, based in Troy, N.Y., provides clinical drug development and research and data services to the pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical device industries. It had revenue of $8.7 million in the year ended June 30, 1996. Omnicare, based in Cincinnati, buys, repackages and dispenses prescription and nonprescription pharmaceuticals to long-term-care institutions. The company had revenue of $399.6 million in 1995. Shares of Omnicare closed down 75 cents yesterday, to $28.

title: Cyprus Settlement
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Im Bank Official Acted Within Ethics Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Belatedly, the Riddle of an Attack on Rather Is Solved
description: Over the course of a decade, it evolved from an incomprehensible utterance during a quizzical crime to the possible measure of a news anchor's unraveling to a kernel of kitschy folklore, memorialized as the title of a popular hit by the rock band R.E.M.

title: Real Campaign Reform Will Give Access to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Safe Food? Not Yet
description: President Clinton wants to spend $43 million of his 1998 budget on improving food safety. The good news is that $11.5 million of this money would go to an early-warning system to identify causes of foodborne illness. But while this proposal could help us spot oubreaks more quickly, weaknesses in a new Agriculture Department meat inspection plan mean we aren't likely to see fewer such episodes any time soon.

title: Peruvian and Japanese Leaders to Meet to Discuss Hostage Crisis
description: In response to Japan's increasing frustration with Peru's handling of the siege of its embassy residence here, the Japanese Prime Minister and the Peruvian President agreed to hold talks in Toronto on Saturday.

title: Forever Fishing In History To Catch A Story
description: Thomas Mallon is busy arranging a fresh love affair for one of the great philanderers of Washington political life, a big, charming man with that power politician's grin who crests scandal with the self-confidence of every victor who has ever reigned here.

title: Strong International Profits Lift Philip Morris in Quarter
description: Powered by robust international tobacco profits and better-than-expected performance of its Marlboro cigarette brand in the United States, the Philip Morris Companies announced strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, posting its 11th consecutive quarter of income growth in the double digits or better.

title: Top Negotiator for Police Pulls Away From Table
description: In a sign that the Federal investigation into corruption at the city's police unions has had repercussions at the bargaining table, the top labor negotiator for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that he would no longer participate in the stalled contract talks with the city.

title: Accounts
description: * The Street.com, New York, to Ryan Drossman & Partners, New York, as the first agency for the Internet financial publication. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Rodman to Pay Stern a Visit

And for good reason. Since the turn of the century, more than 1,300 visual artists (besides lots of writers, composers, film makers and architects) have put in quality time at MacDowell, the country's oldest and largest cultural retreat -- certainly enough to serve as the basis for a very large display.

title: MOBILEMEDIA FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: Mobilemedia Communications Inc. filed for Chapter 11 protection yesterday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington. The big paging company said it would seek court permission to pay important suppliers' claims. It will also seek permission to use $70 million of $200 million in financing, to be provided by a group of banks, to pay those suppliers. The company said it needed that permission to operate normally. The most important supplier is the pager maker Motorola Inc., with a $35 million pre-petition claim. The company said the financing agreement with the group of banks was contingent on agreements by Motorola and other important suppliers to sell it equipment and services. The company said it had adequate cash for operations until it completed an agreement with Motorola and obtained the new financing. The company, based in Ridgefield Park, N.J., listed assets of $1.7 billion and liabilities of $1.3 billion in its Chapter 11 petition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPARO, IRVING

The partners and staff of Rochlin, Greenblatt, Gallo & Company mourn the pass ing of our dear and cherished friend, Irving Paparo, Chairman and President of House of Ronnie, Inc. Irving was a man of great compassion, intelligence, courage, kindness and dignity, who treated all people with dignity and respect. It was a privilege and honor to work with this wonderful man who enriched the lives of all of us who were fortunate to know him. Our sincerest condolences to his wife Diane, his children Russ, Leslie, Harvey, Brooke and Jackie, his grandchildren Kate, Alexi, and Nicholas, his sister Beatrice, his brother-in-law Stanley and all the rest of his family. We will miss him and always remember his goodness and kindness. Robert E. Rochlin, Managing Partner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIFER, AGATHA I.
description: LEIFER-Agatha I. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Aaron Leifer. Daughter of the late Rabbi Elihu and Froma Ann Inselbuch. Devoted mother of the late Rabbi Daniel Leifer. She is survived by her loving son, Elihu Leifer, her grandchildren, Eric, Joshua, Andrea and Ariel, her great granddaughter, Miriam Clair Leifer, her brother, Samson Inselbuch, her daughtersin-law, Myra and Sheila Leifer and many fine nieces, nephews and other family members. Funeral service will be Friday, 1:15 PM at ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial will be in the Mount of Olives Cemetery, Jerusalem, Israel, next to her beloved husband and near her beloved parents.

title: Sharansky Ends Russian Trip With a Visit to His Old Prison Cell
description: Natan Sharansky wrapped up his visit today to the land that once imprisoned and expelled him by fulfilling two of his major goals: visiting the prison cell where he sat in Moscow and fulfilling a childhood dream.

title: SUMMIT TECHNOLOGY TO RID ITSELF OF VISION CENTERS
description: Summit Technology Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell or spin off its money-losing chain of vision-correction centers that compete with ophthalmologists who buy the company's laser machines. At its 19 Summit Vision Centers, Summit uses the same Apex vision-correction lasers that its sells to ophthalmologists. The doctors have complained about the competition, the Waltham, Mass.-based company said. Summit is also embroiled in shareholder lawsuits and a Federal inquiry into its receipt of confidential documents about a competitor. If Summit cannot find a buyer, it will spin off the business to shareholders, a Summit spokeswoman said. Summit's shares rose 43.75 cents, to $7.825.

title: Samsung Electronics Plans to Buy the Rest of AST Research
description: The Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea said yesterday that it would acquire the 51 percent of AST Research that it does not already own for $162 million in an effort to end the personal computer maker's troubles.

title: A Re-election Budget
description: Running hard for re-election, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has presented a $34 billion spending plan for New York City that eases up on the austerity he has pushed since taking office in 1994. In the next year the Mayor wants to cut taxes, including the sales tax on clothing, and spend more money for schools, police and the environment. This bonanza of crowd-pleasing initiatives is to be financed by increased tax revenues from the city's economic boom and an array of fiscal gimmicks that budget monitors and credit-rating agencies have rightly deplored. Mr. Giuliani's thinking on tax cuts and some spending priorities is sound, though his bookkeeping is not.

A practitioner whose technically brilliant work extends the fine art tradition of painting and sculpture, he's well acquainted with the values of non-Western cultures. Over the last 20 years, he's been acclaimed for poetic, meditative videotapes and installations that use images from nature and man-made environments to explore consciousness and sensory perception. In 1995, he represented the United States at the 46th Venice Biennale.

George Lucas, who once had a hard time peddling his script idea to the studios, ended up creating his own movie empire with the ''Star Wars Trilogy,'' winning an extraordinary series of bloodless battles at the box office and overturning the rules and expectations that governed movie making and watching.

title: $400 MILLION AGREEMENT FOR MAGELLAN HEALTH
description: Magellan Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it would divest its 95 psychiatric-hospital operations in a sale-lease-back agreement to Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc. for about $400 million in cash. The hospitals will be operated as a joint venture through a company called CBHS that will be 50 percent owned by Magellan and 50 percent owned by an affiliate of Crescent. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, is a real estate investment trust led by an investor, Richard Rainwater, who along with his wife, Darla Moore, bought 12 percent of Magellan last year. The transaction, which is expected to be completed during the fiscal third quarter of this year, would result in a $45 million to $55 million pretax loss. In the third quarter ended June 30, 1996, Magellan lost $5.7 million on $346.4 million in revenue. Shares of Magellan Health rose $2.50, to $26, while shares of Crescent Real Estate remained unchanged at $53.

title: Will the West Fail Again?
description: As of five o'clock yesterday, there was no war in the Balkans. Violent street protests -- yes; electoral fraud -- yes; currency collapse -- yes; terrorism -- yes; grand larceny -- yes; ethnic clashes -- yes; mass strike action -- yes; but war -- no!

title: Art in Review
description: Mark Francis

title: Russian Hints at Compromise Over NATO
description: Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia assailed the expansion of NATO today, even as he hinted at a possible compromise on the issue.

title: A Village Dies, A Park Is Born
description: IN today's world, it is hard to imagine even a progress-minded city administration evicting a well-established minority community after arbitrarily paying its residents for their possessions. But that's how Central Park was made, with most newspapers cheering the removal of ''the insects.''

title: Pressure on the Slumping Sykora Is His Own
description: Petr Sykora is a reflection of why the Devils have had problems scoring goals. Sykora is considered the premier center on the team, yet has no points in his last eight games.

title: Coping With Blindness, Finding a Home
description: Rosemarie McCaffery used to say, ''We're all just a paycheck away from homelessness,'' but she never thought it would happen to her. Then, last winter, she and her guide dog, Cassy, found themselves in a Manhattan shelter.

title: 200 Images Leisurely Chatting
description: ''PHOTOGRAPHY FROM THE BEGINNING'' is a huge, often beautiful gathering of images at the Robert Miller Gallery, though its sweeping title is misleading. The selection of some 200 works begins early and ends late as advertised, but with staggering omissions and idiosyncratic choices it can't be taken seriously as a historical survey, nor was it intended to be. In fact, it isn't a single exhibition at all.

title: New Guidelines Proposed for Waterfront
description: Two weeks after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $900 million freight tunnel and a state-of-the-art shipping terminal for New York Harbor, City Hall has compiled a new set of planning guidelines for the city's waterfront, mapping out areas where the city would like to see port facilities, parks, housing and other projects.

title: If It's of the Virgin Mary, You're Sure to Find It Here
description: Guessing the location of the world's largest library devoted to the Virgin Mary wouldn't seem very difficult. The Vatican? Some historic Roman Catholic educational institution -- the University of Louvain in Belgium, for example? Or possibly one of the great Marian pilgrimage sites, like Lourdes?

title: At Sotheby's, Old Masters Sell Beyond Estimates
description: Despite talk about the weakness of the market for Old Master paintings, yesterday's sale at Sotheby's in New York brought hefty prices, often several times their estimates.

title: Bonds Rise On Jobs and Factory Data
description: Treasury securities traded higher yesterday for the third consecutive session after reports suggested the economy might be slowing enough to keep inflation benign and the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.

title: Judge Suggests He Might Deny Guilty Verdict
description: The judge in the Crown Heights trial strongly suggested last night that he would not accept a guilty verdict for one of the two defendants who is accused of inciting the attack on a Hasidic man, unless the jurors concluded that the man was actually present at the fatal stabbing.

title: Hilton Delays Its S.E.C. Filing On Offer for ITT
description: File this item under the category of watch what we do, not what we say.

title: Judge Rules Against Alabama's Prison 'Hitching Posts'
description: Denouncing a practice that experts have likened to punishments from Puritan days, a Federal magistrate here has ruled that the Alabama prison system should not be allowed to chain inmates to a metal bar for hours at a time.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: On-Line Ire Is Not Pacified By Agreement
description: One day after the nation's largest provider of cyberspace services, America Online Inc., agreed to pay millions of dollars to compensate subscribers for two months of network congestion, many customers refused to be mollified yesterday, saying that the refunds could hardly make up for their lost business and time.

title: INTUIT TO ACQUIRE JAPANESE SOFTWARE DEVELOPER
description: Intuit Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Nihon Micon K.K., a closely held Japanese business accounting software developer, for about $39 million. The addition of Nihon Micon with Intuit's other Japanese unit, Milkyway K.K., will help form the business software unit of a new company that Intuit is creating, Intuit K.K., Intuit said. Intuit acquired Milkyway last January as part of its effort to increase its presence in international markets. Intuit, based in Palo Alto, Calif., develops personal-finance software. Intuit shares fell 62.5 cents, to $28.50.

description: To the Editor:

title: Champions of Liberty
description: The House of Lords has been a target of reformers for a century, derided as an anachronistic drag on British democracy. Spoofing the peers in ''Iolanthe,'' W. S. Gilbert said the country thrived when ''noble statesmen do not itch / to interfere in matters which / they do not understand.''

description: Charles G. Shaw

title: Restaurants
description: When the big, noisy table full of lawyers finally left, those of us still eating toasted one another in jubilant congratulation. ''What a relief,'' said the stranger at the next table as she raised her glass, ''to actually be able to hear what my friends are saying.''

description: 'Terra Bomba'

title: 3 Cuban Defectors Go All Out for Scouts
description: The two hugged, then they talked and laughed together. There was so much to catch up on. It had been more than four years since Mets shortstop Rey Ordonez and Roberto Colina, a recent Cuban defector, were teammates on Industriales, a team in the top Cuban league.

title: Soviet Emigre Is Guilty In Ax Murder of Husband
description: Rita Gluzman, a Soviet emigre who went on an 18-day hunger strike in 1971 to gain her scientist husband's exit from the Soviet Union, was found guilty today of killing him with an ax last April when it appeared he would divorce her for another woman.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 17 about an Italian court's acquittal of a defendant in the 1994 shooting death of a young American tourist incorrectly described twins born recently to the dead child's parents. They are a boy and a girl, not two girls.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the disappearance of the controller and secretary of Mercury Finance misstated the executive's given name. He is James A. Doyle, not John.

title: Composers Who Broke Their Reins
description: From the beginnings of the 20th century issued a cluster of composers whose hearts were bigger than the musical means at their disposal. Many were Americans and one was Henry Cowell. Receivers of a European tradition and the instruments to go with it, these people were like fast-growing adolescents bursting out of an older sibling's clothes. What had fit before fit no longer.

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''YEATS ON STAGE: THE PLAYS,'' Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22d Street, Chelsea. A weekend of staged readings of works by the writer, performed by the Irish Repertory Theater Company. Part of a series that runs through Feb. 16. Today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets, $12 for each performance; $50 for the entire series. Information: (212) 727-2737.

title: Sponsor of Montana School Punishment Bill Accused of Abuse
description: A Republican State Senator who recently introduced a bill to restore corporal punishment in Montana's public schools has been accused by at least 10 of his former students of inflicting abuse on students when he was a teacher in the 1960's and 70's.

title: 2 Hostages In a Village So Remote
description: The setting is exotic and beautiful, as if Sergei Bodrov's ''Prisoner of the Mountains'' were a travelogue rather than a war story. In a remote Muslim village high in the Caucasus Mountains, two Russian soldiers abruptly find themselves taken hostage. Their captors live in pristine isolation, following archaic customs in a place that time seems to have passed by. ''The mountains will protect us,'' the children sing. ''The wind frightens the heart of any stranger here.''

title: Bette Midler, Entertainer And Singer. Absolutely.
description: ''Oy Vegas, what have they done to you?'' Bette Midler kvetches from the stage of the MGM Grand Hotel. ''You've gotten so respectable!''

title: Pepsi-Cola Tops Super Bowl Ad Poll
description: A survey conducted after Super Bowl XXXI showed that Pepsi-Cola was the most-recalled advertiser.

title: Accounts
description: Titan Auto Insurance, San Antonio, a unit of Titan Holdings, to Publicis/ Bloom, Dallas, part of Publicis S.A., for advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES E.
description: INNISS-Charles E. The Board of Trustees, the Central Administration, the College Presidents, the faculty, students and staff of The City University of New York deeply mourn the passing of Trustee Charles E. Inniss. Appointed to the Board by the Governor in 1992, he served the University with great distinction and honor, chairing the Fiscal Affairs and Audit Committees and the CUNY Construction Fund. His dedication to the University's mission, his love of education, and his extraordinary service to the community will have an enduring impact. He will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. James P. Murphy, Chairman Board of Trustees W. Ann Reynolds, Chancellor

title: Pathmark Trims Jobs at Headquarters
description: Pathmark Stores said yesterday that it had eliminated about a quarter of the positions at company headquarters in Woodbridge, N.J. Harvey Gutman, a Pathmark vice president, said about a third of the 200 to 250 jobs eliminated were done through layoffs while the rest were lost through attrition and early retirement.

title: Literacy, A Weapon For a Slave
description: Lest we forget, knowledge is power, and for slaves in the antebellum South, learning to read was forbidden. Some slaves who dared to become literate were punished by having a finger chopped off in front of the whole slave community. Or worse.

description: National Black Fine Art Show

title: Flirting Yet Turning Songs Into Impassioned Vows
description: Toni Braxton sobbed, flirted, moaned and flirted some more through her set at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday, opening a six-night engagement for her double bill with the saxophonist Kenny G.

title: Drugs and Technology Reinforce Stock Rally
description: Any jitters the stock market had this month temporarily disappeared as stocks soared yesterday for the second consecutive session, largely on the strength of technology and drug issues.

title: Sinclair, for Today
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MARSH & McLENNAN COS., New York, an insurance company, bought 59 percent of the French company Compagnie Europenne de Courtage d'Assurances et de Reassurances it did not already own for an undisclosed amount.

title: Greenspan Urges Action to Curb Cost-of-Living Rises in Benefits
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urged Congress today to move quickly to limit cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other Federal benefits. In doing so, he waded directly into one of the most politically sensitive issues facing the Government.

title: Court Supports Transmission Of Sports Data
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the National Basketball Association may not stop Motorola Inc. and a sports statistics-gathering company from transmitting continuously updated scores of N.B.A. games on a hand-held pager that Motorola sells. The ruling could also protect news information transmitted via on-line services.

title: New Welfare Rules Are Issued
description: To avoid losing millions of Federal dollars, state officials will begin implementing parts of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new welfare plan on Saturday, even though the Legislature has delayed a final vote on the plan until March.

title: Dollars and Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Plans to Scrutinize Drug Cases by a Late Prosecutor
description: A New Jersey judge plans to conduct a personal study into whether the late Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., during his years as Somerset County Prosecutor, routinely reduced charges against major drug dealers who had surrendered cash or property to his office after their arrests.

title: Trailer Plan Won't Solve Crowding
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to use customized trailers and prefabricated annexes to help solve school overcrowding would still leave the system short of space, school officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: A Re-election Dream
description: The general rule for campaigns should be the more candidates the merrier, with the possible exception of those times when Ross Perot says he is ready to run for President yet again. Certainly when a seasoned public servant like David Dinkins sends up a trial balloon, he deserves respectful consideration and full recognition that he has earned the right to make another run for mayor of New York City if he chooses.

title: Amphenol Agrees to Fee if Deal Fails
description: The Amphenol Corporation has agreed to pay Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company $37.5 million if a proposed $1.05 billion leveraged buyout of Amphenol by Kohlberg Kravis fails, according to an Amphenol filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Woman Dead And 9 Treated After Fumes Fill Buildings
description: Undetectable by sight or smell, carbon monoxide from an apparently collapsed internal chimney permeated three attached apartment buildings yesterday on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. A woman was found dead, possibly from the fumes, and another four people were found unconscious.

title: Chechnya Picks a President
description: The healing powers of the ballot box were at work in Chechnya this week. In a land still staggering from a punishing war that ended last summer, hundreds of thousands of citizens turned out to choose a president. They elected Aslan Maskhadov, a moderate leader who seems capable of handling the difficult work of sealing some form of separation from Russia.

title: NEWELL TO BUY COOPER'S DRAPERY DIVISION
description: The Newell Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cooper Industries' Kirsch drapery division for an undisclosed price. Kirsch, based in Sturgis, Mich., makes drapery rods and window shades and blinds. It had sales of about $252 million last year and employs 2,400 people at eight North American plants and five international plants. Newell shares fell 12.5 cents, to $32.75. Cooper shares rose 50 cents, to $42.875. Newell, based in Freeport, Ill., makes and sells Anchor-Hocking glassware and other housewares.

description: Stuart Shils

title: Beyond Battle: A Soviet Portrait
description: THE look of war, the face it wears back home, changes for reasons beyond technology and strategy. World War I was a deluge of blood and death, but censorship kept it from appearing that way in the papers. Photographs and paintings of World War II grew more fierce and explicit, though for a long while whatever horrors were represented had been visited on our enemies alone.
